title: Travers Surgery a Success
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 31 (UPI)The rniiwaukee Brewers said today that an operation on Bill Travers's left elbow was a success and the lefthanded pitcher should be ready to play by May 1. Dr. Frank Jobe removed calcium deposits and relocated the ulnar nerve in Travers's elbow yesterday in Los Angeles, a Brewer spokesman said.

title: MARKETS
description: The stock market, which turned in a disappointing performance in 1977, ended the final day of the year with a token gain in sluggish trading. Last week the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.35 point to 831.17. For 1977 as a whole, the key barometer was down 173.98 points, or 17.2 percent.

title: At Home: Mr. FixIt And His Helper
description: PEOPLE in New York City have psychotherapists, and people in the suburbs have handymen. While anxiety in the city is existential, in the country it is structural. A therapist helps you hold your life together, and a handyman holds together your house. To move to the country is to transfer your paranoia from people to things. And things are even less permanent, less reliable, than people.

title: There's Athletic Life After School
description: As a college English teacher for nearly 20 years, I have taught many athletes, listened to them talk, read their compositions. All come under the general charge that the taxsupported publicschool system does not do the job that should, namely to prepare all its students as much as possible for a physically fit life.

title: Balzac of Caricaturists
description: Thomas Rowlandson (17561827) was a veritable Balzac of British caricaturists. His drawings ranged over the English scene in town and country, from the haute monde to the demi monde, and the Continent as well. This considerable body of drawings makes up a social history of his times, but now they are scattered among numerous collectors. One of the main collectionsover 400 in allbelongs to Paul Mellon, and these have now been published in a book entitled THE DRAWINGS OF THOMAS ROWLANDSON IN THE PAUL MELLON COLLECTION (Brandywine Press, $20). Mr. Mellon's collection emphasizes the more witty and elegant side of Rowlandson. The boqk was compiled by John Baskett and Dudley Snelgrove, who have provided the catalogue notes on each drawing.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 31 (AP)Cambodia and Vietnam, Communist neighbor nations, today traded charges of aggression after Cambodia severed diplomatic relations with the Hanoi regime because of border fighting.TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda said today he would like to meet President Carter to discuss economic matters before the next summit meeting of major nonCommunist industrialized countries, which is to be held in West Germany next July.SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 31The South Korean Government released five more political prisoners today under New Year's Eve clemency program, all of them clergymen who had been jailed since 1976 for violating an emergency decree banning criticism of ,the Government.PEKING, Dec. 31 (Reuters)China said today that the Soviet Union met rebuffs wherever it went in the Arab world in the last year and the longer the countries there dealt with Moscow, the fiercer their resistance.LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP)A bomb exploded in an automobile near Piccadilly Circus shortly before midnight tonight, killing its two occupants, the police said. Scotland Yard said the car belonged to the;Syrian Embassy.ROME, Dec. 31 (Reuters)A branch office of the Italian Communist Party was set on fire early today and a young man was stabbed in the hand during another night of political violence in Rome.

title: Amin Orders Refugees to Register.

The report said the Uganda leader had given no reason tor the order but had warned the 100,000 refugees believed living in Uganda that they will he in trouble if they ignore his directive. The refugees had fled to camps in Uganda to escape political and tribal conflicts in neighboring African countries.

title: No More Bonners

title: Food
description: B lessed, indeed, is the house that finds itself on this first day of the year with some leftover caviar in the refrigerator, especially if it happens to be a full, onepound tin. But no matter how small the amount, it can serve to extend the festive feeling. Paul Steindler, chef and proprietor of Paul's Restaurant in Manhattan, contributes a caviar parfait (served in tall parfait glasses), made with scrambled eggs to stretch the sturgeon roe. There is also a recipe for bitesize potato halves topped with sour cream and caviar, from James Nassikas, proprietor of the elegant Stanford Court Hotel in San Francisco. Mr. Nassikas has his chef, Marcel Dragon, prepare this simple but marvelous, though expensive, fare on request for special occasions. The potatoes are split in half, the pulp scooped out, the potato shells deepfried. The crisp shells are then refilled with potato, dabbed with sour cream and served with a spoonful of caviar on top. When made at home, the amount of caviar used, whether a heaping teaspoonful or a demitassesize dollop, depends on how much one has left over. For those who must start from scratch, we offer relatively inexpensive red caviar pie.

title: A BiologistHunter Defends Use of Steel Shot
description: Waterfowl hunters who feel that steel shot is vastly inferior to lead are wrong, says Dr. Robert Smith, the softspoken wildlife biologist who is project coordinator for the migratory bird management office of the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Save the Airport, The Neighbors Said
description: BAYPORT The Town of Islip has taken the first step toward acquiring Ed- wards Airport here, and thus preserving one of the halfdozen small private airports remaining in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Peter Sowerwine, Jazzman, Marries Miss Stiles, Sculptor
description: Judith Newcomb Stiles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith N. Stiles Jr., was married yesterday to Peter Van Nest Sowerwine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Orvis Sowerwine. Both families are of Summit, N.J., where the Bev. Horace Westwood performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church.

title: Iranians Protest at White House Against Carter's Visit to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)Ahout 200 Iranian students demonstrated in front of the White House today to protest President Carter's visit to Teheran, the Iranian capital. More than 100 policemen watched the protest, a United States Park Police snokesman said.

title: New York City Employees Lag in a Study on Total Compensation
description: The total compensation for New York City employeesincluding salaries and employer contributions for pensions and health benefitsis lower than that paid in several of the nation's major cities and is in line with that in many others, according to a new study.

title: Playoff Matchups
SHOP TALK
description: THERE is no spreading chestnut tree where this village smithy stands. But there is majestic silver maple shading the rustic quarters of the Village Blacksmith of Northport. And the antique forge really works, with coals glistening and an aproned artisan deftly.hammering iron into trivets and tools, sconces and hooks, railings, chandeliers and whatever else is commissioned by an increasing corps of customers.

title: K9c1:11s5Totnin4sCi 's105th Mayor
description: FINAL PREPARATIONS: Mayorelect Koch, left, conferring with associates on the sixth draft of his inaugural speech at his Park Avenue headquarters yesterday. Aiding in preparations are, second from left, Clark Whelton, a speechwriter; Henry J. Stern, a Councilman at Large, and Herman Badillo, a Deputy Mayordesignate. Mr. Koch was later sworn in as the 105th Mayor of New York. The ceremony will be repeated today at City Hall. Page 17.

title: For 3 Sisters, a Holiday Reunion
description: SOUTH RIVER IF THEY talk from now until they return to their homes on the western border of the Soviet Union later this month, Margaret Kovacs. and Irene Butella will not have said everything that they wished to say to their sister, Grace Kosa. There is that much catchingup to do after a 40year separation.

title: Snowed Under By Grievances

If the experience of past years is repeated, hundreds of.these grievances will ultimately be resolved by the nation's 500 or so orofessional labor arbitrators.

title: The Nation.
description: The United States and South Korea have settled on a way for Tongsun Park to tell the Justice Department what he knows about his countrys efforts to buy friends in Congress. But assuming the deal goes through, it will win few cheers and in Congress more than a few Jeers. It also creates the possibility of a serious breach between the legislative and executive branches.

title: Come Home, Jimmy
description: Rappy New Year, folks. As of today your payrolldeduction tax for Social Security is going up from 5.85 percent on the first $16,500 of your wages to 6.05 percent on the first $17,700a tax increase from $965.25 to $1,070.85 if you're paying the maximum.

title: R. I. Knapp Fiance Of Gail A. Wallace
description: The engagement of Gail Ann Wallace to Richard Ian Knapp has been announcd by Mr. and Mrs. Cluren R. Wallace of Daingerfield, Tex., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. R. Knapp of Northampton, England.

title: Lyle Held in Shooting
description: LAKEWOOD, Colo., Dec. 31 (UPI) Ron Lyle, the No. 3 ranked heavyweight, was held for questioning in connection with the fatal shooting :of a man at his home tonight. Dave Sletto of the Lakewood Department of Public Safety said the shooting took place at Lyle's Green Mountain, Colo., home shortly before. P.M. The victim was not immediately identified,

title: What's Doing in RENO
description: BACKGROUND  Before the Civil War the site of The Biggest Little City in the World was a mere toll bridge across the Truckee River. In 1868 the Central Pacific Railroad crossed the Sierras from the west and set up an endoftrack camp near the river crossing, and at the insistence of a group of exUnion soldiers, the town was named after their fallen leader, Gen. Jesse Lee Reno, killed at the Battle of South Mountain. The railroad also contributed to the birth of Sparks, a sister community that, like Reno, spilled across the Truckee Meadows.

description: Today

title: Grants to Playrights --A Look Backstage
description: The other day Megan Terry, the Off Broadway playwright who now works with the Magic Theater of Omaha, Neb., was telling her fellow judges on the nominating committee for the Rockefeller Foundation's playwrights-in-residence grants, about theater in the Midwest. We have identified, she said, five new playwrights who may not speak to New York, but who speak to the Middle West. Edith Oliver, Off Broadway critic of The New Yorker and another Rockefeller judge, bristled at the provincialism. It's rubbish to say that a playwright appeals to the Middle West. Either you're a playwright or youre not.

title: The Star of 77: Municipal Bonds
description: The headlines of 1977 went to New York City and New York State and their prodigious.efforts to put their financialaffairs back in order. Behind the headlines, however, local and state governments throughout the nation were winning an unprecedented vote of confidence from that most critical of judges, the investor.

title: Chile's Voters Will Speak This,Week, Though Not Exactly Freely
description: SANTIAGO, ChileThis country's 4.5 million voters will be required on Wednesday to answer yes'- or no to that leading proposition. In maneuver that has severely strained Santiago's fourman mihtary junta, President Augusto Pinochet decreed the vote to refute charges by the United Nationsand othersthat human rights are violated in Chile.

title: Harriet Dvores to Be Bride Of Hilton Goldman in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Dvores of Elizabeth, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Dvores. to Hilton P. Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerson Goldman, also of Elizabeth. Plans have been made for a.wedditig next April.

title: DINING OUT; Pasta and Seafood With Verve; **Giulio Cesare
description: GJULIO CESARE in Westbury was named for its owners, Giulio Donatich and Cesare Duntiara and, coincidentally, for the noblest Roman of them all. It is a modest place of smallness that could never be called intimate. Intimacy is impossible here. Conversations at tables thrice removed fall within earshot.

title: The ABC's Of &
description: T HOROUGH and ciet jerseefyfismandated system of education, is threatened by its own Trojan horse. Although this one, unlike the original, was not constructed by an enemy or planted with evil intent, the consequences will turn out to be anything but benign.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: BACK in this country with a new book is Nigel Nicolson, whose Portrait of a Marriage was a best seller in 1973. Mr. Nicolson, who is English, was only visiting, but his book, Mary Curzon, published this month, should have a longer stay. To employ the language of soap opera, which the book is not, Mary Curzon asks the question, can a young millionaire's daughter from Chicago find happiness with a brilliant, if somewhat impecunious, English lord? The answer is that Mary Curzon, nee Mary Leiter, daughter of Chicago merchant prince Levi Leiter, had a happy marriage to Lord George Curzon, Viceroy India.

title: LETTER TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: We are always delighted to see an article about environmental issues on the Island. However, certain aspects of Economics vs. the Environment [Dec. 11] seem less than clearnot only the hiatus between Pages 1 and 12, but the thesis as well. May we clarify the procedures in question and give the facts behind the decision by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Michelle Foss Sets Nuptials for April
description: Michelle Maria Foss, a teacher at the New Canaan (Conn.) Nature Center Nursery School, and Michael George Buscher, manager of the ski department of Bob's Sports in New Canaan, will be married this April.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT'S that time of year again. Just as soon as you wish people happiness in the New Year, they are off returning the Christmas presents that you gave them the week before.

title: Around the Nation
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 31 (UP1)A 22-year-old man using a highpowered rifle fired a single shot from his bathroom window into the lobby of a police station a block away today, wounding police captain and a woman, the police charged.ATLANTA, Dec. 31 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell says that he will release a report next week on alleged financial wrongdoing by former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation even though one Justice Department lawyer maintains the disclosure would violate the Privacy Act.WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)House investigators, harshly denouncing the United StatesSouth Korean agreement to obtain Tongsun Park's testimony on alleged Capitol Hill influence buying, have said that they will subpoena him to testi-BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)A 2-year-old boy severely burned in a Christmas fire has died after a judge's ruling that cleared the way for him to be removed from a respirator.

title: Memories: XMorgue to Morgue
description: PARISIn my first editorial column for The New York Times (Oct. 27, 1954), following'. a talk with General Eisenhower, I wrote that he may eventually have to alter his technique of being President in order to accom- plish his foreign policy .goals. Precisely the same statement applies in this, my last column, with reference to Jimmy Carter.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS,; Philanthropy Science.; Corp[orate Charity: Running,the Alms Race
description: When the railroads were laying tracks in the late 1800's, they'sorely needed housing for their transient workers. To get it, they sprayed clouds of dollars to the Y.M.C.A., enough, in fact, to cover more than half of the construction costs of about a hundred Y.M.C.A. buildings. The railroads benevolence represented.the first major corporate support of a charitable, organization.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Harry W. Bass, Jr., of Dallas, Texas, has been nominated to be president of the American Numismatic Society, according to the Society's director, Leslie A. Elam (nomination is virtually tantamount to election in this case).

title: The EDITORS 19.CHOICE.77
description: For 10 years now, at the turn of the year,- the Book Review has been picking the best books published in the preceding 12 months. A year ago there were 17 titles (Speedboat, To Jerusalem and Back, The Uses of Enchantment . . ), our longest list to date. This year we've chosen 20. The break seemed to come there, between 20 and 21. If it had come between five and six or eight and nine, the five or eight titles might have been superior to the present 20. In short, there was a sense of quantity consoling quality. .

title: The World
description: In an audacious counterattack against his enemies at home and abroad, Chilean President Augusto Pinochet has, called for a popular mandate to legitimize his authoritarian rule. His appeal for an obligatory national consutation, to De nem tins week, - followed a nearunenimous United Nations condemnation . of Chile's human rights .record. And it almost immediately sharply divided Chile's fourman military junta.

title: Andre Eglevsky's Company Plans Its Future
description: For the ballet world the sudden death of Andre Eglevsky last month represented the passing of an era. Often acclaimed as the greatest male classical dancer of his generation, his illustrious performing career

title: How To Build Audiences And Lessen Decibels
description: Elsewhere on this page, Harold C. Schonberg lists some of the more quirky happenings in the music world 1977. It seems only reasonable to note in this column some of the brighter aspects of the new year. For instance, today is the beginning of a musicvoucher program by the Theater Development Fund (TDF).

title: Annalee Gillette'Plans To Marry on June 24
description: Announcement ha's been made by Capt. Robert Charles Gillette, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs, Gillette of Washington of the engagement of their daughter, Annalee Gillette, to Richard Francis Regensburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Regensberg of Garden City, L.I.

title: The 1951 College Basketball Scandals: The Scars Will Never Vanish
description: Had the players in the 1951 college basketball scandals been guilty of more conventional offensea crime against person or property, a stolen car, a burglary, a simple assaultredemption no doubt would have come more quickly, more completely, and with less pain. But they had trespassed instead against something far holier than property. They had tampered with childhood ideals, and who among us would not sooner surrender his wallet than his trust?

title: 1977: Shift to Stability
description: IN a year that opened with the bleakness of a deep freeze and the first uneasy, electionyear murmurings about the fate of the state's fiscal future, New Jersey opted in 1977 for stability and security and fenally accepted the personal income tax, which had been regarded as an anathema for decades.

title: Some Christmas Traditions Survive in Soviet New Year Holiday
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31Even the flakes of wet snow fluttering down out of a murky sky could hardly conceal the absence of needles on the New Year yolka trees on sale at the outdoor state market in the center of Moscow yesterday.

title: MONDAY NIGHT FEVER
description: Tomorrow's Orange Bowl pits the Oklahoma favorites against the University of Arkansas. But don't count the Arkansas Razorbacks out. They have a secret weaponthousands of fanatically spirited fans.

title: The Battle to Buy a Bridge
description: DETROITGenerations of New York City parents have taught their children to laugh at anyone gullible enough to think that the Brooklyn Bridge was for sale. But some very canny and moneyed folk are battling these days for a chance to buy the graceful sixlanehridge that links Detroit to Windsor, Ontario. For the investor in search, of a New Year's resolution, the story of the Ambassador Bridge suggests this one: Keep your eyes open; opportunities may take strange and wondrous forms.

title: Computer System Reduces Blacklogs In Housing Courts
description: The judges of the Housing Courts in Manhattan and Queens are enjoying a special sort of luxury these daysinstant evidence, brought to them by a computer system that is designed not only to reduce delays in the courts but also to save hundreds of dollars.

title: Scientists Study The Senses In New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Their Eyes Are on the Sparrow
description: How many kinds are there on the Island? FROM Merrick to Montauk, from Oyster Bay to Orient Point, birders are participating in the 78th annual National Audubon Society Christmas Bird Count. In the previ- ous one, in 1976, more than 30,000 people in 1,200 count areas in the continental United States, Canada, Alaska, Mexico and Central America took part in what has been called both the biggest sporting event of the year and an annual exercise in masochism, depending on weather, success and point of view.

title: Author's Query
description: We would be grateful if the representatives of the late Boyne Grainger, o_f Greenwich Village, would get in touch with us, as we would like to republish some of her work.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The camera never lies, right? Wrong. The camera always lies, in the sweetest, most seductive manner possible. So one must conclude when looking at the photographs of his, on view at the Carlton Gallery, 127 East 69th St., through Jan. 14, and David Hamilton, at Images Gallery, 11 East 57th St.. through Jan. 21.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: RAPFOGELWilliam E. Due to an Error an Announcement of the Death of William E. Rapfogel aPpeered on Friday December 30, 1977. Mr. Raptogel Is not deceased. We regret this unfortunate error.

title: Fluoridation: Defeat for Dentists
description: NEW JERSEY'S dentists have finally given up all hope of achieving statewide fluoridation. The New Jersey Dental Association has formally dissolved its Special Committee on Fluoridation, which had been in existence for 14 years.

title: Leslie Jean Engel Engaged to Paul Joseph Cicurel
description: The engagement of Leslie Jean Engel to Paul Joseph Cicurel has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harvey J. Engel of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Rene Cicurel and Iviaggy Harari, both of Paris.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WHEN Sheriff Joseph De Marino of Middlesex County took the guns away from those of his officers who could not pass the qualifying test, he expected a major protest from the unions. But the Police Benevolent Association supported his action, with the result that the gunless sheriff's officers didn't have a leg to stand on.

title: It's No Longer Chairman Burns
description: Their disagreements over economic policy were so fundamental, logic dictated that President Carter would not reappoint Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Yet, Mr. Carter also has been so effusive in his praise of the chairman that a question arose whether, he might not pull a surprise. He did not. Even a President serves no more than two terms, he said last week, and so to make way for new leadership Dt. Burns; at 7.3, will be out on Jan. 31 after eight years as the country's principal banker.

title: Nazis, Skokie and the A.C.L.U.

description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Gifford of Old Brookville, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mae Gifford, to David A. Gross, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Gross of New Rochelle, N.Y. The wedding planned for July 30.

Even if you.didn't drink, you have a hangover from all that talkwhat in the world were they talking about?arid froth all that noise.

description: Mr. and Mrs. David Deutsch of Hollis Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Ellen Deutsch, to Mark Alan Mizner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Mizner of Marblehead, Mass. Miss Deutsch and her fianc graduated last May from Ithaca College.

title: Mets Exhibition Opener March 11 Against Cards
description: The New York Mets, who open spring training camp officially on March 1 at St. Petersburg, Fla., will play 25 exhibition games in Florida before opening the National League schedule on April 7 against the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium. Fifteen of the games will be played at Al Lang Stadium in St. Petersburg.

title: COAST FISHERMEN SET FOR THE NEW. SEASON
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 31 (UPI)There is a different spirit this year as the 130 tuna boats based in San Diego prepare,: to depart for the 1978 fishing season.

title: Dentists Solve Criminal Cases by TeethMarks Study
description: BALTIMORE Dec. 31 (UPI)Not long ago, a defendant in a Maryland murder case pleaded not guiltyat least until he was given a dental examination. The dentist's work Was painless but persuad7 ed the defendant to change his plea.

title: Townhouse Market Is Bubbling Along
description: New townhouses in Manhattan are few and far between. They are almost always isolated and usually are renovations rather than completely new construction.

title: More Than 90 Women Became Episcopal Church Priests in 77
description: In the 12 months since the Rev. Jacqueline Means made history on Jan. 1, 1977, by being ordained an Episcopal priest under new rules effective that day, more than 90 other women have been formally received into the priesthood, according to a survey released by the church's Diocesan Press Service.

title: They're Centered On TaiChi Chuan
description: ON Mondays, James de Peyster Jr. hurries to catch the 5:11 P.M. train from Grand Central Terminal to Hastings-on-Hud- son to make his 6:30 class in taichi chuan, the centuriesold Chinese ballet- like calisthenics.

title: 11 Children, 9 to 11, Serve Radio Listeners on Coast As Junior Meteorologists
description: MEYERS, Calif. (AP)Eleven children, 9 to 11 years old, give radio listeners in this area periodic fiveminute weather forecasts from Meyers Elementary School. They use data that they have collected themselves.

description: Looking at the Evidence In New Castle's Zoning

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: A Tempest in a Track Suit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corning Up,a Good Year for the State
description: IT should be a good year for New Jersey, perhaps the best in this decade. Why? The state will have more moneymoney from casino gambling in Atlantic City, money for bigger school budgets and money from tourism, which is expected to soar. And, the experts predict, there will be more road construction. more lobs and freer spending.

title: Joseph Chaikin Enters the Mystical World of The Dybbuk
description: As leader of the experimental Open Theater during the 1960's and early 70's, Joseph Chaikin was adamantly opposed to working in any commercial situation, on or off Broadway. And he was primarily involved not in directing plays but in theater researchexploring new possibilities for expression on stageand in creating theater works collaboratively from scratch, most notably the Open Theater's final works, The Serpent, Terminal, The Mutation Show and Nightwalk.

title: POLITICS
description: IN the final act in the yearlong struggle within the powerful Nassau Republican organization, Francis T. Purcell assumed office today as Nassau County Executive.

title: Looking Ahead: 1978 Portends New Life for old Cities
description: WESTCHESTER may be synonymous with suburbs, especially among those unfamiliar with the county's diversity, but a look into the new year suggests that 1978 may be the year of the county's cities. These longsuffering urban areas, responsible large measure for the county's declining population and stagnant tax base, will begin this year to see the results of revitalization programs.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: AUTOBIOGRAPHY is not only a school of selfknowledge, but one of the most demanding all forms of literary expression. It calls for energy, hard work, an excellent memory, a sense history, exceptional powers of evocation and an inability to be boring. Great events and high adventure some times enhance its appeal, but they are by no means indispensable. They are to autobiography what the sublime in nature is to painting: a dangerous option. More great paintings have been made of ratty little village streets within an hour's drive of Paris than will ever be made of the Matterhorn.

title: Nanci Beth Heller Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Heller of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of, their daughter, Nanci Beth Heller, to David Mark McAlpin, son of the Rev. and Mrs. David H. McAlpin Jr. of Skillman, N.J.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: INTERMISSION, by Anne Baxter. (Ballantine, $2.25.) When she went to live with her husband and children on a rugged ranch in the Australian outback, the film actress at first felt purified and trimphant, then caged and restless. Our reviewer declared that if Anne Baxter had transformed her four years experience into fiction, she'd now be compared with Doris Lessing.

title: SE1FF APPOINTED BY CAREY TO TOP POSITION AT S.C.I.
description: Eric A. Seiff, the first deputy commissioner of the New York State Commission of Investigation, has been appointed chairman of the panel, Governor Carey announced yesterday.

title: Kimberly Campbell Engaged
description: Dr. Alan K. Campbell, chairman of the United States Civil Service Com, mission, and Mrs. Campbell of Washington and Austin, Tex., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Ann Campbell, to Carl Oxholm 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oxholm Jr. of Devon, Pa., and Quogue, L.I.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: PARISThrough a complex and daring series of takeoversnow completed successfully in the United States, Britain and France-49-year-old James Goldsmith has achieved personal control of an international empire that includes maior financial and publishing interests and an interlocking food group that counts the Grand Union supermarket chain among its major assets. Though his flamboyant life style keeps him in the headlines in Europe, Sir James does not like public investors as partners. Much of his wheeling and dealing lately, such as his tender offer for the Grand Union Company, has been aimed at freezing out the little investor:

title: Carolyn P. Thomas Wed to Richard L. Lawson
description: In the Central College Presbyterian Church in Westerville, Ohio, yesterday morning, Carolyn Peters Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Woodford Thomas of Galena. Ohio, became the bride of Richard Loughead Lawson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Lawson of Miami. The Rev. Richard D. Ellsworth performed the ceremony.

title: At Home: Mr. And His Helper
description: PEOPLE in New York City have psychotherapists and people in Connecticut have handymen. While anxiety in the city is existential, in the country it is structural. A therapist helps you hold your life together, and a handyman holds together your house. To move to the country is to transfer your paranoia from people to things. And things are even less permanent, less reliable, than people.

title: CAMERA
description: There is no doubt about it: connoisseurs of vintage photographs have sent prices soaring. Who are they? Museums, art galleries, large corporations, and individual collectors.

description: The business world has completed its homework in preparation for the New Year, and now the onus falls on the political world of Wasbington, to which the nation and the world look for leadership in so many areas.

title: Like Talk
description: New and Collected Poems. By William Stafford. 267 pp. New York: Harper& Row. $10.95.

description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 31Doug Barrow of Bayside, Queens, and John Manderson of Australia defeated Joe Fahey of Weston, Conn., and Phil Dukes of New Canaan, Conn., 62, 64, today in the final of the men's New York State indoor doubles tournament.

title: Further Meditations On Ram Dass
description: It's like throwing boulders at a butterfly for Colette Dowling (Confessions of an American Guru, Dec. 4) to insist that Baba Ram Dass's expression of his particular wisdom is outright psychopathic. It is even worse to do so just because she herself has not found a way to enlightenment. Let me quote Ram Dass for you, Miss Dowling: I can do nothing for you but work on myself . . . you can do nothing for me but work on yourself.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Princeton will begin. defense of its , Ivy league, championship with three games at home, against Pennsylvania on Tuesday, Dartmouth on Friday and Harvard Saturday. In games tomorrow night, Catholic University will play at St. Peter's and Seton Hall at John's. Niagara will play at St. Peter's on Wednesday night and Maine will play at Long Island University Thursday night. Iona plays at Pace and Lehman visits Brooklyn College Friday night and Maine meets Fairleigh Dickinson and Manhattan travels to St. Peter's Saturday night. All games begin at 8 o'clock.

title: Correction
description: A typographical error in an article on Dr. Asher Finkel [12/25] distorted quotation attributed to the rabbi. The correct quotation is: The ways Jews relate to the Temple, and Christians to the body of Jesus, have a similar meaning in experiencing God's presence in their midst.

title: U.S.C. Leads Bluebonnet Bowl Game
description: By The Associated Press

title: Carol Anne Kilhenny, Lawyer, Is Married To .Arthur H. Moore, Financial Analyst
description: Carol Anne Kilhenny, a lawyer, was married last evening to Arthur H. Moore of London, a financial analyst there with Vickers Ltd. The Rev. John Weist performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: C.A.B. Proposing to Give ,Additional Compensation To Paisengers in Delays
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)A set of proposed rules from the Civil Aeronautics Board provides that airlines that keep passengers waiting six hours for a charter flight must provide room and board, or give each passenger $16 initially and $8 more for each succeeding sixhour delay.

title: ART
description: LTHOUGH it is difficult to predict what directibns the art world will take in the new year, 1978 shbuld be a rich one. Artists generally are going through trialanderror periods, experimenting with different media, styles and techniques, so we can be reasonably sure that there will be many different kinds of art with no specific overriding tendencies.

title: On the Training of Skilled Workers
description: THE comments by Donald Davis in your Dec. 18 issue on the way Connecticut could effectively train skilled workers for its in dustrial needs had a hollow ring. Its theme was that in order to best utilize public and private resources for this purpose, coordination could be obtained, and duplication avoided, by a new state government manpowertraining setup.

title: Henry E. Harris Is Dead
description: Henry Ellis Harris, who founded and built H. E. Harris and Company of Boston into the world's largest stamp concern, died Thursday in NewtonWellesley Hospital in Wellesley, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Wellesley Hills.

title: PEOPLE
description: In April 1968 the annual meeting of the American Association of Adyertising Agencies was told: The cry from the ghetto is cry of despair.... Don't wait for Negroes to come to you. Few will come. You must take the first step. The impassioned speech marked the beginning of a drive to increase minority employment in the advertising industry. The man who made the speech and who was the sparkplug of the campaign was the association's president, John Henderson Crichton.

title: Turkish Government Falls
description: Turkey's coalition Government was defeated on a vote of confidence, opening the way for a return of former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit. Page 3.

title: Leslie Carroll Becomes Bride

The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church was per formed by the Rev. Peter Holroyd, chaplain of the Taft School, assisted by the Rev. Jeffrey Kittredge, rector of the church.

title: Running The Numbers
description: LEGALIZED gambling, it seems, is here to stay in Connecticut, whether we like it or not. While the citizens of this state are properly concerned over the moral and sociological issues involved, we should not lose sight of the practical and economic factors of this enormously powerful industry.

title: Switzerland Avalanche Warning
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Dec. 31 (AP)Avalanche warnings were issued for large areas of the Swiss Alps today following snowfalls of up to 15 inches during 24hour period. The. Federal Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research said that the danger had increased decisively and cautioned skiers against using unmarked trails.

title: Tuckahoe Losing Storied Library
description: THERE is jubilation in this village. Plans are under way for the construction of a community center where Columbus and Circuit Avenues meet and no small source Of joy is the fact that the project is completely underwritten by $800,000 in Federal Community Development funds.

description: The weak light of a red dawn glinted on the ice of a frozen farm pond as four men shivered , and stamped the dead grass along the shore.

title: Ideas &Tren s; In Summary; To Sleep, Perchance to Fire Neurons; Oak Park Plants A Housing Acorn; When Dumb Is Smart; U.S. Portrait, By the Numbers; Lighting Up? Bounced Out; Consumer spending in selected countries, 1973
description: According to Freud, people dream because a psychic censor disguises the nightly urgings of the subconscious, with its lusts to rape and slay, as odd but harmless experiences with fishes and asparagus. But Freud also suggested that eventually all mental events would be traced to their physiological causes in the brain. A theory of dreaming has now been proposed that would do just this, replacingor at least parallelingFreud's theory with neurobiological explanation.

description: Patricia Regina Rich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rich of Dallas, was married there yesterday to Jeannot Roger Barr of Brussels. title: Notes: Canal Cruises The Newest Old Thing
description: Year after year, to keep their heads above water, as it were, cruiseship operators around the world have designed their voyages to appeal to such specialized groups as eclipsewatchers, whalewatchers and even weight-watchers. And now they've turned their attention to headlinewatchers by promoting cruises through the Panama Canal.

title: Fancy Fiction
description: SEVERAL of these extraordinary stories by William S. Wilson, describing operations, satirize the rhetoric and emotional tone of scientific writing. Wilson evidently has grasped the modern sciences as ways of using language and metaphor, not just as canon of thought. Every problem of medicine is a problem of language, says the inventor of the operation Fatherhood, and this operation was malapropism. In the title story, a literary eminence part Wilson's counterpartis interviewed by a callow graduate student, a voiceactivated Master Arts. Of scientists, the writer says: I am envious. They have had the important moral experience of our time.

title: A New Year's Warning From Paris: That Kiss Can Cost You Your Wallet
description: PARIS, Dec. 30 (Reuters)If a pretty girl throws her arms round your neck during New Year festivities on the ChampsElysdes and kisses you passionately, keep your hand on your wallet; the police warned Parisians today.

The ceremony was performed in the Red Bank Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Blanchard Romaine, the assistant pastor. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob H. Wirick of Columbus, Ohio, has been previously married and divorced, as has the bridegroom. Mr Stanger is son of Wesley A. Stanger of Summit, N.J., executive director of MacKay Shields Financial Corporation, and the late Sarah McKee Stanger.

title: If You Decide to Go Goose Hunting
description: The Maryland goose season does not end uuntil Jan. 27 so there still time for some hunting this year. The very late season hunting can spotty when compared to November and, unfortunately, by the end January the moon will be in a bright phase again. Geese are intelligent and during lull or nearfull moons tend to feed at night, which hurts the hunt. ing. If planning a visit for next season, which usually begins close to lst of November, try to make reservations in periods of a dark moon.

title: 5 Killed in Taiwan Crash,
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 31 (AP)At least five persons were killed and 19 injured today woman 22 cars and trucks piled up in heavy fog on a busy highway near Tainan, 210 miles southeast_ of here, the police reported. A police spokesman blamed high speeds and poor visibility for the crash.

title: Demands for Strong Measures to Combat Redlining Are Growing
description: Bart Meyers, a 41-year-old associate professor of psychology at Brooklyn College, and. his wife, Alice Radosh, a psychologist wanted to buy a fourstory limestonehouse in the revitalized Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Banned Editor Escapes From South Africa.
description: CAPE TOWN, Dec. 31  Donald Woods, an editor who campaigned vigorously against South Africa's racial laws until the Government barred him from journalism two months ago, fled the country in disguise today and took refuge in the neighboring black state of Lesotho.

title: Social Security Tax Rises Today for Nearly Every American Worker
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31  For just about every working person in the United States, the New Year will bring an increased tax on earnings designed to pay for the soaring cost of Social Security benefits.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: FOR the last three winters, my house has been plagued. with sweating windows. As a result many of the windows wont hold paint, and mildew has developeed in places. I don't know how to rectify this problem and wonder if there is any assistance you can offer?  W.E. W., Bayside. N.Y.

title: Deborah Lee Syrek Betrothed to Robert Ream 2d

title: t Home: Mr. Fixit And His andyman
description: EOPLE in New York City have psychotherapists, and people in the suburbs have handymen. While anxiety in the city is existontial, in the country it is structural. A therapist helps you hold your life togethe?r, and a handyman holds together your house. To move to the country is to ransfer paranoia from people to things. And things are even less permanent, less reliable, than people.

title: MUSIC
description: CHRISTMAS may have come and gone, but Gregory Sandow's appealing new operatic setting of Dickens's A Christmas Carol could well be around for quite a few holiday seasons, so let me start the new year by telling you a little about it. It was given its world premier the week before Christmas at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, and attracted 1,000 or more satisfied customers to each of its three performances, which is pretty impressive for modern opera.

title: The Cactus Connection: Notes From the Far West
description: The way I see the map, there are two loops through the Westone Up, to show the kids Yellowstone and let them float themselves silly in the mad specific gravity of the Great Salt Lake, one Down if you're a sucker for big rocks and have a boy like mine, a fellow who's 6 and can't wait until he's 7 to see a real saguaro cactus. Either way, loop high, loop low, you arc west from Las Vegas to wind things up in San Francisco. driving down through old trees and Mendocino or up through Disneyland and Carmel.

description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 31East Germany, rocked by disputes with dissident intellectuals for more than a year, furiously attacked today a report by a West German magazine that an opposition Eurocommunist group had sprung up within the country's ruling Communist Party.

title: Perverse Story
description: THIS novel is a meticulously and subtly composed tour de force on the imagination, that Miss Ethel, a 70-year-old spinster schoolteacher, now retired, and the author of Too Much Flesh and Jabez. She has written, as Mr. Dowell states in the frame within which her novel rests, perverse story'; what a delicate ambiguity suffuses that phrase! Mr. Dowelllike all writers whose intelligence rummages through the minutiae of life, turning and sifting them until he has isolated some few things that will not be reducedwrites prose in which meanings shift just as they appear to assume some clarity. Whatever is perverse in this story is so only because it is a symptom of a general emotional decay its effluvium, so to speak.

title: Headliners
description: His silhouette was as umistakable as a sunrisea little man with a tiny derby, oversized shoes, baggy pants, prop cane and a lopsided walk. Of course, it was funny. But it was a very human comedy practiced by Charlie Chaplin. His appreciation of the absurd and deprecation of the arrogant separated his work from the pratfall humor of the day. The human race I prefer to think of as the underworld of the gods, said Chaplin, who died last week in Switzerland at the age of 88. That bittersweet intelligence ran through The Kid, The Gold Rush, Modern Times'80 films in all from 1914 to 1967. As an actor he was perfectionist, as a director a despot. But in the edgy America of the 1950's, his leftward politics, four marriages and extramarital entanglements counted more than his talent. A British subject, he was abroad in 1952 when the Government told him not to came back unless he could prove his moral worth. Chaplin never returned, except once, in 1972, when a different Hollywood got around to thanking him for helping to create it.

title: Quake Jolts Southwest Yugoslavia

The quake struck at 5:24 A.M. (11:24 P.M. Saturday New York time), and several smaller tremors were felt afterward. Officials reported no casualties and only minor damage.

title: The Minutes of January
description: The old year is gone, the new year is upon us, and those of us who set store by the calendar have drawn the line to sum up a total, since it is man's habit count minutes and days and make maps of time. Nature, of course, has her own time map, and man's calculations only approximate it. If we insist on starting the yearmidwinteror midsummer, half the world away to the south of usthe solstice would be the logical moment; but the solstice occurred ten days before our New Year. The ancients, being people of a practical nature, started their year with the vernal equinox, the beginning of spring.

ThiS time he squeezed through a footsquare hole in the ceiling of his jail cell, crawled 40 feet through an attic, entered a jailer's anartment and walked away.

title: Assembly to Vote A gain on Waiving Bond Rule for Minority Contractors
description: TRENTON, Jan. 1The State Assembly has one more oppportunity this month to go along with a Senateapproved plan to allow construction companies owned by members of. racial minorities to bid on small government projects without first posting bonds. The Seriate endorsed the measure a year ago by a vote of 25 to1.

title: CHESS CONTEST IS RESUMED RY SPASSKY AND KORCHNOI
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 (AP)'7, Boris Spassky and Viktor Korchnoi resumed their match today to determine the challenger to the world chess chamion after resolving differences that had threatened to cancel the match.

title: TEN ROLE IN PEKING BELIEVED BOLSTERED
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 2A recent 'series of appointments to key Communist Party and Government posts in Peking seems to mark a further consolidation of power by China's tough Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping.

description: In what its president said was a reflection of the reviving New York City and state economies, the New York Telehone Company announced yesterday that it would spend a record of nearly $1.1 billion on construction this year to meet growing communications needs.

title: Student Will Be Tried ih Killing of His Family
description: CAMDEN, Jan. 2 (AP)Jury selection is to begin here tomorrow in the Thal of a former militarycollege student charged with murdering his parefits and two younger brothers during Thanksbiving vacation in 1976.

title: so. Carolina 68. Term. Tech 51
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 2 (UPI)  Mike Doyle and Jackie Gilloon, guards, paced South Carolina to a 6851 victory over Tennessee Tech tonight. Doyle scored 19 points and Gilloon, 12, Tennessee Tech closed to within 6 points, 4236, midway through the second half, but the Gamecocks went on a 122 spurt that put the game out of Tech's reach.

title: LINKS SOUGHTM SHOOTINGS OF THREE IN. PENNSYLVANIA
description: BREEZEWOOD, Pa., Jan. 2 (AP)The state police are looking for links between two shotgun Shootings that left three persons dead within five miles of this Bedford County community.

title: Landry, Cowboy Coach, Enjoys Day at Movies
description: DALLAS, Jan. 2  Coach Tom Landry went to the movies today and liked what he saw, especially on defense, about the Dallas Cowboys 23.6 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: How to Bypass Needless Operations
description: Ten years ago a new type of operationcoronary bypass surgeryachieved dramatic results in easing the agonizing chest pains suffered by some victims of heart disease. Patients who had been unable to walk across a room without pain were able to return to work. Soon the operation was being performed by surgical teams at hospitals throughout the country. often on patients suffering little or no pain in the belief it would help them live longer. In the last year alone, there were 70,000 such operations at a cost of a billion dollars. Now, fierce debate has arisen over whether the operation is generally worthwhile, a debate which underlines a disturbing truth about modern medicine: Many widely used treatments have never been demonstrated to be effective in rigorous clinical studies.

title: NEW JOBLESSAID LAW MEANS CUTS FOR SOME
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2Several hundred thousand New Jersey workers who earn less than $4 an hour stand to lose some of their unemployment benefits under new law signed last Friday by Governor Byrne.

title: Deaths
description: HOEFERPriscilla Bi'adford. The National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York records with deep regret the death of its valued member.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DALLAS, Jan. 2 (UPI)  An official of the Dallas Cowboys said today that he expected the team's ticket allotment for the Super Bowl on Jan. 15 would be sold out by noon tomorrrow.

title: South Korea Achieves Its 77 Export Goal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 2Half the sweaters sold in Sweden, 90 percent of the wigs that Americans buy each year and 70 percent of the fishing rods that the Finnish use come from South Korea.

title: Ttansit Aid Rise Planned, But State Calls It Too Low
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2New York City and State can expect substantial increases in Federal funds for modernizing subway, bus and commuter rail systems under the Carter Administration's proosed transportation bill, according to state experts who analyzed draft copies.

title: A Year of Korea Inquiries Leaves Much More to Do
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2After more than a year of investigations into the Korean scandal by the Department of Justice and the House ethics committee, there is nn light at the end of the tunnel.

title: World News Briefs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan, 2 (UPI)Defectors from the Justice Party of the ousted Prime Minister, Suleyman Demirel said today they would participate in a government to be led by Bulent Ecevit, the former opposition leader, virtually assuring his appointment as Prime Minister.

title: Pilot Tells.of Fighting. Sharks Near Hawaii After Plane Ditching and Loss of His Wife
description: KAILUAKONA, Hawaii, jab. 2 (AP)The pilot of a light plane that ditched at sea Saturday night told rescuers that be had to fight off sharks during the 15 hours before his rescue.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)The Deartment of Health, Education and Welfare, which has used computer matching to identify H.E.W. employees who defaulted on Governmentbacked student loans, is about to extend, the check to all civilian Federal workers.

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros
description: UNHAPPY SNOWMAN: Although the temperature remained about the freezing point all day, this hoursold snowman wore a mournful expression as he held an umbrella to keep from melting in the brilliant sun over Manhattan.

title: Tower of Pisa's Tilt Did Not Worsen in 77
description: PISA, Italy,, }an. 2 (AP)The Leaning Tower of Pisa stood still in 1977 for the first time since devices to measure its movement were installed in 1913..

title: MISSING LI, STUDENT FOUND SLAIN UPSTATE
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., Jan. 2The frozen body of 18yearold Linda Velzy of Woodbury, L. 1., a student who had been missing since Dec. 9, was found yesterday, and a man who the police said was trying to move the body was charged with murder.

title: TV: A Look at Medicine in U.S.
description: Tonight at 8, NBC News gets to preempt three hours of prime time for another of those marathon surveys of a single subject, In the past, the network has treated such areas as civil rights, energy and violence in this manner. This evening, in the eighth such venture since 1963, the subject is Medicine in America: Life, Death and Dollars.

title: Italian Party Offices Attacked
description: ROME, Jan. 2 (Reuters)Unidentified extremists today attempted to set fire to a Communist Party office in the northern city of Udine and Christian Democratic offices in Bologna and Bergamo. No serious damage was reported.

title: United Press Internetional
description: TWO DIE IN MOTEL FIRE: The 6 Motel in Belle Vernon, Pa., after fire raged through it yesterday. At least two persons are known dead. More than 20 people died in fires throughout the United States this past weekend.

description: Music

description: As Wall Street moves into the new year with the investment outlook uncertain, concern is mounting over the continuing shrinkage of the securities industry through mergers and the adequacy of brokerage revenues to support longterm profitability.

description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 2President Carter disclosed today that he and Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai had disagreed sharply over United States demands that India accept safeguards aimed at insuring that Americansupplied nuclear fuel be used for peaceful purposes.

title: AILING CANADA GETS GET WELL GREETING
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 2  Canada Is not happy country now, said Governor General Jules Ldger, a former diplomat who represents Queen Elizabeth as the formal head of state, in his New Year message to Canada's 23 million people.

title: Bid Made for Civil War Guns
description: HIGHTSTOWN, Jan. 2This tiny Mercer County borough has been offered $6,000 for four cannons surrounding a monument erected soon after the Civil War in honor of New Jersey troops who served in that conflict.

title: Koch, vows to Ban Discrimination, By the City Against Homosexuals
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday he would issue an executive order to ban discrimination against homosexuals by the city governmentguaranteeing, among other things, their right to be hired as policemen and firemen.

title: Candidate for 3d Term as Mayor of Newark
description: Kenneth Allen Gibson, the Mayor of Newark, jogged as usual yesterday morning, but there seemed to be a special lift in his stride. Several hours later he announced at a news conference at City. Hall that he would seek a third fouryear term as the head of New Jersey's largest and most troubled city.

title: Topics Ballot, Billet and Bear
description: Tomorrow the people of Chile will be asked to vote on the following proposition: In the face of the international aggression unleashed against the government of the homeland, I support President Pinochet in his defense of the dignity of Chile, and I reaffirm the legitimacy of the republic to conduct in a sovereign way the process of the institutionalization of the country. International aggression means the widespread criticism of the ruling junta's repressive practices, especially last month's United Nations resolution, cosponsored by the United States. The ballot's yes line will be marked by a Chilean flag, the no line will be unadorned.

title: COMPROMISE IS SEEN BY U.S. ON WEST BANK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2United States officials have detected the outline of possible compromise between Israel and Egypt over the Palestinian issue despite the publicized differences between Prime Minister Menahem Begin and President Anwar elSadat.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All securities and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday in observance of New Year's Day. Government offices, banks, and most businesses also were closed for the holiday. Normal operations will resume today for the exchanges, the Postal Service and most businesses.

title: Around the Nation
description: BENICIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)Three men died and six men were injured today after they apparently suffered an oxygen failure while working inside a huge tank at an Exxon oil refinery, the company said.

title: Delta State Wins Women's Final
description: Carol Blazejowski scored 23 points, grabbed 11 rebounds, had four assists and was unanimously selected to the alltournament team, but otherwise was a bit of a frustrating afternoon for the 5foot10inch Montclair State senior yesterday.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 2Former Pl'esident Eduardo Frei Montalva rejected today the form and substance of a national plebiscite called by President Augusto Pinochet while young Christian Dethocrats shouted in the streets for political liberty in Chile.

description: LOS ANGELES My God, you seem relaxed! my friend Stone blurted in the fourth day of,his visit to Los Angeles. Everyone out here seems relaxed.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The maximum permissible spee' of Amtrak's turbineowered trains across New York State will be raised from 70 to 79 miles an hour on many stretches next Sunday because the state and Conrail have made track improvements,

description: David W. Brown, the Deputy Mayor in charge of policy, is emerging in the opening days of the new administration as the closest aide tp Mayor Koch, according to City Hall officials.

By that time, the couple had won 40 international awards, three Oscars and many citations. The Hubleys were also on the faculty of Yale University and worked indeendently in their own studio.

title: Dr. DeBakey Is Injured by Smoke As Fire Damages Home in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)Dr. Michael DeBakey, the noted heart surgeon, is imroving after suffering smoke inhalation in a fire at his home on Saturday night, a Methodist Hospital spokesman said today.

title: Alabama Conquers Ohio State
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2  On the sideline across from each other in the Sugar Bowl game today, they resembled two old generals, Grant and Lee perhaps. But this time, Lee won. Paul (Bear) Bryant, the 64yearold Alabama coach, wearing a Confederate gray suede sports jacket, enjoyed a 356 rout of Ohio State, coached by 64yearold Woody Hayes.

title: Of Flowers, Darwin. And a Space Mission
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP)Scientists are planning to send 20 sunflower plants on a space shot in an attempt to determine why they wiggle.

description: Harry F. Andrews, a trustee of the Dry SaVings Bank, of which he was execxutive vice president at his retirement irr.1 975, died Sunday in Elizabeth (N. J.) General Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 46 Palisade Road in Elizabeth.

description: BONN, Jan. 2Thirtytwo years after the end of World War II, a fragment of the diary of Dr, Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi Propaganda Minister, has been published for the first time, offering a daytoday account of the disintegration of the Third Reich.

description: GERSONEsther Lila. On December 31, 1977, beloved wife of Jules, adored mother of Harriette and Dr. Fred Schecter and the late Martin Gerson. Cherished grandmother of Suzanne and Julianne. Services Tuesday January 3rd at 1 P.M. at Temple Shaarav Tefila, 250 East 79th Street, N.Y.C.

description: DALLAS, Jan. 2Notre Dame loosened the University of Texas's claimto the collegiate football championship in the Cotton Bowl today while waging an impressive campaign itself for the top spot.

title: Israel TV Says. Sharon Will Join Peace Team Sitting in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 (AP)Retired Gen. Ariel Sharon, hero of the Sinai campaign in the 1973 ArabIsraeli war, will be member of the Israeli delegation at peace talks with Egypt opening here Jan. 15, Israeli television reported today. A Foreign Ministry spokesman denied knowledge of the appointment.

title: 25 Die in Thailand Bus Crash
description: BANGKOK, Thailand. Jan. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)  Twentyfive persons were killed and more than 86 injured in northeastern Thailand when a truck collided headon with a bus load of New Year revelers, The Bangkok Daily Times said. The accident occurred in Chaiyahum District, 170 miles northeast of Bangkok.

title: DOLLAR CONTINUES TO FALL ON SOME MARKETS ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP)The dollar continued its decline on the first day of 1978 trading on those European money markets that had reopened after the New Year holiday.

description: Memo to playwrights: If you want to know exactly how bad your, new play is, give it to the best possible company of actors.

title: Low Mail Rates of 2 Groups for Elderly Under Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)The Post, al Service is investigating two organizations that represent 11 million elderly Americans to see if the organizatidns should continue to receive nonprofit mail rates that are worth millions of dollars a year.

title: Collection Provide,s a History of Black Dollmaking
description: DETROITTen years ago Myla J. Perkins bought an antique doll for her daughter Julie. But, as it turned out, what she was really doing was starting on a hobby of her own. Mrs. Perkins now has a collection of 250 dolls, and it includes what she believes is the most extensive collection of black dolls in the country.

description: In recent months a number of mutual funds have been set up to exploit feature of the Tax Reform Aot of 1976 that makes it possible to sell options on portfolio shares for added fund income.

description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 2 (UPI)  Topranked and undefeated Kentucky took advantage of coldshooting by Vanderbilt and posted a 7259 victory tonight in the Southeastern Conference opener for both teams. James Lee, a reserve, led Kentucky with 17 points.

title: A Blue Law Gap in Ocean Grove
description: OCEAN GROVE, Jan. 2Rising costs and diminishing revenues have forced this seaside religious enclave to dissolve its eightman police force and thus eliminateat least for the presentenforcement of its tough, centuryold restrictions on most activities on Sunday.

title: Devine Says He Intends To Stay at Notre Dame
description: DALLAS, Jan. 2Dan Devine, head coach of Notre Dame's Cotton Bowl winners, said tonight, I have had no idea of stepping down I have two more years to go on my fiveyear contract and I intend to remain here.

title: Against Federal. Creation of Jobs
description: President Carter has at last endorsed a modified version of the muchdiscussed HumphreyHawkins fullemloyment bill, which, when and if it receives Congressional approval will commit the GovernMent to reducing unemployment to 4 percent of the work force by 1981.

title: Virgin Islands Governor, 56, Dies; Cyril E. King Was Cancer Victim
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., Jan. 2Cyril E. King, the second elected Governor of the United States Virgin Islands, died tonight after a long battle with cancer. He was 56 years old.

title: 3 Proxy Brides From Syria to Wed New Suitors in Brooklyn Jewish Rites
description: Joy suffuses the Brooklyn community that adopted 13 Jewish women from Syria last August because next month the first of them will be married, and within a few weeks two others will also become brides.

description: Steel imports, the target of a. reference price system that the Treasury Department plans to outline today, have moderated in the last two months.

title: Hussein Rejects Israeli Proposal, Says It Contains Nothing Positive

title: TED BURKE, AT 44
description: Ted Burke, a writer and editor at large at Town & Country magazine, died of cancer Jan. l at his home in Pelham Manor. N.Y. He was 44 years old.

title: Notre Dame, Washington, Alabama and ArkansasWin
description: Notre Dame's Vagas Ferguson, left, in end zone after first of his three touchdowns in 3810 rout of Texas in Cotton Bowl. Above, Roland Sales, (21) and Greg Kolenda of Arkansas celebrate first score during 316 triumph over Oklahoma in Orange Bowl. Alabama crushed Ohio State, 356, in Sugar Bowl; Washington defeated Michigan,.2720, in Rose Bowl. Page 39.

title: BOND YIELDS END 77 WITH A RISING TREND
description: Longterm Government and corporate bond yields ended 1977 at their highest levels since August 1976, and most other interest rates climbed during the year. Taxexempt bonds were the one major exception to the general trend toward higher rates and lower fixedincome se. curity prices, that beset the credit markets all year.

title: Bridge:
description: The world of international bridge is mourning the loss of Julius Rosenblum, who died at his home in New Orleans yesterday.

title: ICE SLOWS TRAFFIC AS HOLIDAY WINDS UP
description: Returning from the long New Year's weekend, New Yorkers yesterday encountered icy streets and sidewalks, arctic blasts of wind and more than the usual postholiday traffic jams around the airorts.

title: Advertising
description: As a number of marketplace sages had predicted, 1977 turned out to be better than 1976. Advertising agehcies and the media were in clover. Judging from the record number of newproduct introductions, advertisers were nrettv bullish too.

title: Polish Minister in moscow for Talks
description: WARSAW, Jan. 2The Polish Foreign Minister, Emil Wojtaszek,, flew to Moscow today to report on President Carter's recent visit.

title: Candidate for 3d Term as Mayor of Newark
description: Kenneth Allen Gibson, the Mayor of Newark, jogged as usual yesterday morning, but there seemed to be a special lift in his stride. Several hours later he announced at a news conference at City Hall that he would seek a third fouryear term as me head of New Jersey's largest and most troubled city.

title: State Program Gives Local Units The Power to Award Art Grants
description: The New York State Council on the Arts has started a pilot program to allow local administrative units to award grants under $3,000 to local art groups. A total of $104,642 in Federal funds has been earmarked for the project, which has just been approved by the funding group.

title: Koch Vows to Ban Discrimination By the City Against Homosexuals
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday he would issue an executive order to ban discrimination against homosexuals by the city governmentguaranteeing, among other things, their right to be hired as policemen and firemen.

title: California Gets Israeli Player
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Israelts top tennis player, Yair Wertheimer, left for the United States today to take up a tennis scholarship at the University of California. He will study business administration there.

title: Koch Finds Snow on Front Steps, Struggles With Desk at City Hall
description: Mayor Koch rode the Lexington Avenue express to. City Hall yesterday and, when he got there for his first business day as Mayor, he found that no one had shoveled the snow from the front steps, that there was a painting that he despised on his office wall and that the desk he wanted to use bumped his knees.

title: Spanish Parliamentary Committee Approves Home Rule for Basques
description: MADRID. Jan. 2 (Reuters)A special parliamentary committee tonight apr proved two royal decrees granting the Basaue country provisional home rule.

title: Marsha Mason Unveils Her. Life With ActressHating Playwright
description: About three years ago, Neil Simon confessed to his new wife, Marsha Mason, the actress, that he really hated actresses, He added: You've got to choose. It's either me, or your career. She chose him, and he, perhaps startled by such a choice in this decade of feminism, turned around and wrote two movies for her to star in.

title: Seattle, Without Federal Pressure, Will Begin to Desegregate Schools
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 31  This city, apparently with widespread support, has chosen to desegregate its public schools within two years through the mandatory assignment of students by race.

title: Books of The Times
description: The artist feeds on the accumulated fat of experience like a hibernating bear, but some writers are more autobiographical than othrs. Mark Schorer, who died earlier this year, has given us in Pieces of Life both a collection of his short stories and fragments of an autobiography. The fragments are interposed between the stories, and, as Mr. Schorer is the first to tell us, do not cast any bright illumination on them. They can probably not be read as counterpoint to the stories, he writes, since the thematic relationships are, as far as I can see, almost nonexistent. (I may be deceived.)

title: CLUE TO SMUGGLING CASES SEEN IN COAST DRUG RAID
description: BANDON, Ore., Jan 2 (UPI)Sixteen suspected smugglers captured with six tons of marijuana reportedly worth $17 million may have provided a clue to a landsea pattern of narcotics trafficking in the United States, officials said today.

title: Boy Finds Offering a Wordto the Wise Has Its Ups and Downsand Acrosses
description: When he scanned faculty biographies in the New School's bulletin for next spring, Michael Miller was, of course, pleased to see his name. But, as he recalled recently, it was shocking to find two faculty members without ad vanced degreesMichael Miller and the woman who teaches belly dancing.

title: Richard Pryor, Comedian, Freed On Bail on a Charge of Assault
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP)Richard Pryor, the comedian, surrendered to the police tonight, was charged with assault with a deadly weapon and was released on $5.000 bail. the police said.

title: Late Michigan Comeback Fails in Rose, 2720
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2  The Pacific Eight, this year represented by the University of Washington, again deflated the Big Ten Conference in the Rose Bowl game today as the Huskies upset Michigan, a twotouchdown favorite, 2720, before a crowd of 105,312.

title: Roosevelt Mutuel Clerks Sign 3Year Contract
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 2Roosevelt Raceway and the Mutual Ticket Agents Union No. 23293 agreed on threeyear contract today and it was unanimously ratified several hours later at a meeting of the membership at Plumbers Hall in Mineola. The previous agreement had expired Saturday night and the union had threatened strike.

title: Reds to Tour Japan
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 (UPI)  The Cincinnati Reds announced today that they would make a goodwill exhibition tour of Japan in the fall of 1978 at the invitation of The Yomiuri Shimbun, one of Japan's leading newsapers and the sponsor of the tour.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Economists seldom agree about anything, but one item that many of them thought should be on President Carter's tax reform agenda was some sort of change in the current method of taxing corporate income, particularly income paid out as dividends. Coupled with elimination of preferential treatment of capital gains, it would reduce many of the inequities and distortions caused by the present tax system.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the business/finance section of The Times on Saturday incorrectly described the terms of a bid by Humana Inc. for American Medicorp Inc. The correct terms involve an offer by Humana to pay $15 in cash phis half of a $25 preferred share, or a total of $27.50, for each of 5.7 million American Medicorp shares.

title: Former New York Budget Director Sues City for $17,000 in Back Pay
description: A former New York City Budget Director; Melvin N. Lechner, has sued the city to collect more than $17,000 he claims in unused vacation pay, with interest, according to a spokesman for City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who was named in the suit along with former Mayor Abraham D. Beame.

title: Events in Garden for 3 Weeks Send Knicks on Rocky N.B.A. Road for 8 Games
description: It was in mid July and the Knicks had just completed their training campfor rookies when Eddie Donovan, the general manager, and Willis Reed, the coach, saw the first version of the National Basketball Association schedule. Almost immediately concern was exressed by. Madison Square Garden executives, by the players and by the people who sell tickets.

title: MRS. GANDHI SETS UP NEW POLITICAL GROUP
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 2Backers of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi formally separated from the rest of the Congress Party today, with each side asserting that it had the support of the party's rank and file.

title: Ron Lyle Plans to Plead Not Guilty In Killing of His Former Trainer
description: DENVER, Jan. 2 (AP)An attorney for Ron Lyle, the worldranked boxer, said today that Mr. Lyle would plead not guilty to any charges in connection with the fatal shooting of his former trainer on New Year's Eve.

title: FansWhoop It Up in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Dec, 2 (AP)  It was too cold for dancing in the streets, but there was bedlam lin the bars tonight after the University of Washington upset Michigan in the Rose Bowl.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter disclosed in India that he and Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai had disagreed sharply over United States demands that India accept safeguards aimed at insuring the peaceful use of Americansupplied, nuclear fuel for Indian power reactors. Nevertheless, in a speech to the Indian Parliament, Mr. Carter said that shipments of nuclear fuel would be made to India under longstanding commitments. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Only 5 of 24 Bronco Starters Are New
description: DENVER, Jan. 2  The Denver Broncos are going to bring to the Super Bowl scene fresh enthusiasm, harmless naivete and considerable football skills. This is a team whose time arrived suddenly this season, especially yesterday when the Broncos were superior to the Oakland Raiders and beat them, 2017, for the American Conference chamionship and the privilege of taking on the Dallas Cowboys, many of them old hands at Super Bowling, in New Orleans on Jan. 15.

title: 5 Killed and 10 Hurt As Pakistan Police Shoot at Strikers
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan, 2 (UPI)The police opened fire today on thousands of striking workers, killing five persons and injuring two others in an industrial town southwest of the capital, an official statement said.

title: Cambodia Refuses to Talk With Vietnam Over Border Until Forces Are Removed
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 3 (Reutcrs)Cambodia told Vietnam today that it Would not negotiate over their border dispute until all Vietnamese forces withdrew from the country.

title: Marquette 67,WichIta State 56

In a letter that contained a check for $105 for the 66th annual appeal, Elyse AbramsDavis, executive secretary, explained how the money was raised.

title: Volkswagen Assumes Operation Of West Virginia Stamping Plant
description: The Volkswagen Manufacturing Corpol ration; of Ainerica announced yesterday that it would assume opetration today of millionsquarefoot metal stamping plant in South Charleston W.Va., thus coinpleting a transaction Matted 11 months ago when it purchased the facility from the American Motors Corpora president of E. Dauch, Volksivagen's vice president of manufacturing, said the plant Will begin to fabricate sheet metal parts. for Volkswagen Rabbits Which will go.into produition this April.at our new car assembly plant, which is being corn pitted about 35 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. The assembly plant is called Volkswagen Westmoreland and is named after the southwestern Pennsylvania county in which it is located.

title: Seattle, Without Federal Pressure, Will Begin to Desegregate Schools
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 31  This city, apparently With widespread support, has chosen to desegregate its public schools within two years through the mandatory assignment of students by race.

title: Julius Rosenblum, 71, Played Role In Expansion of World Bridge Body
description: Julius Rosenblum, former president of the World Bridge Federation, died at his home in New Orleans yesterday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: 3 Proxy Brides From Syria to Wed New Suitors in Brooklyn Jewish Rites

title: Saudis Shun Open Backing of Sadat
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 2Saudi officials said today that the Government would probably not give open support in the near future to Egypt's peace efforts despite the arguments they expect President Carter to advance in favor of such an endorsement when he arrives tomorrow.

title: Etna Spouts Rocks and Lava
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Jan. 2 (Reuters)Mount Etna, Europe's largest active volcano, erupted today, hurling molten lava and rocks hundreds of yards into the air. The police said the stream of lava posed no immediate threat to local inhabitants.

title: Kupfer Starts With Four Winners As Racing Returns to Aqueduct
description: Thoroughbred racing returned to Aqueduct yesterday after a hiatitS.:e nine days: and officials were ple,aSed with the result; A crowd of 21,062. came out despite an overnight snowstorm, brisk, cold winds and the absence of Steve Cauthen.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the business/finance section of The Times on Saturday incorrectly described the terms of a bid by Humana Inc. for American Medicorp Inc. The correct terms involve an offer by Humana to pay $15 in cash plus half of a $25 preferred share, or a total of $27.50, for each of 5.7 million American Medicorp shares.

title: New Year's Emotions Are Tied to the Score
description: The start of the new year means collegiate football as well as champagne and noisy parties. Although the football festivities were delayed for a day, the outcomes were just as heartrending for the particiants. For Ohio: State, it was a bleak start to 1978, but Alabama and Notre Dame so far are finding the new year a prosperous and happy one.

Israeli commandos later freed the hostages in a daring raid on the airport. Ambassador Bonnefous, a 53yearold career diplomat, has held embassy posts in Algeria and Peru.

title: Letters
