title: News Summary
description: President Carter, after the meeting in Aswan with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, read a prepared statement declaring that the Palestinians should be caabled to participate in the determination of their own future. He said this was one of the basic principles that should be observed before comprehensive Middle East peace can be achieved. In. 1srael, Prime Minister Menahem Begin rejected Palestinian selfdetermination because he said would mean a Palestinian state that would be a mortal danger to Israel. [Page A1, Columns 12.]

title: How the Cityscape Fared in 1977
description: NINETEENSEVENTYSEVEN was the year that Citicorp Center opened, and it was the year that, on July 13 at least, the city itself closed, All of that drama aside, however, it was not otherwise a year of mafor changes in the city's physical environment: New York got little more builtup, a little dirtier, and a little more torndown. Now, the virtual halt in major new construction seems to be ending, so the coming years should bring more drama tic changes in the cityscape. But looking Design Notebook back at buildingwatching through 1977, it was a time to count the little things, good and bad.

title: Chirac Will Boycott Carter Ceremonies
description: PARIS, Jan. 4 (Reuters)  Jacques Chirac, the mayor of Paris who is also the principal political opponent of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, said tonight that he would boycott all ceremonies for President Carter.

title: Wallaces Divorced After 7 Years; Suit Settled Before Trial Starts
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 4Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and his wife, Cornelia, were divorced today on their seventh wedding anniversary after a surprise settlement of their longpendina divorce suit.

title: TV: The Psychics Of Step Beyond
description: ANEW syndicated dramatic series called The Next Step Beyond is that rare kind of project that could ;leave denianding critics slipping Into weepy gratitude for the existence. of game shows, the normal fare of the 7:30 P.M. slot. Having its premiere on ABCTV this evening, Next Step is stupefying in its sincere exploitation of junk.

title: Frankel Stages Contessa Drama
description: THE PROFESSIONALISM of the staging and the effectiveness of the performance do not,obscure the fact that N. D. Bellitto's The Contessa of Mulberry Street is a clicheridden exercise in stereo, type behavior. The play officially opened last night at the Gene Frankel Theater and Media Center, after an earlier showcase engagement..

title: Bonds Edge Up in Credit Markets; U.S. Support.of Dollar Spurs Rise
description: Eticouraged by the Government's decision to support the dollar in the foreignexchange trading, the credit markets recovered moderately yesterday, erasing part of their steep Tuesday declines.

title: Marlene Sanders Quits ABC for CBS
description: MARLENE SANDERS, vice president of documentaries for ABC News, is resigning to join CBS News as both producer and correspondent concentrating on documentaries. Miss Sanders who became a vice president two years ago, gives up the distinction or being the only woman to hold that high a title in a network news division.

title: Crash, Pacer, Is Syndicated
description: Crash, a pacer who has won several stakes and $399,000 in purses during the last two years, has been syndicated for $1.7 million. Hugh Grant of New York announced yesterday that Crash would be retired to Castleton Farm in Lexington, Ky.

title: A. & P. POSTS A LOSS PUT AT $6.02 MIWON
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday a loss of $5.02 million for the third fiscal quarter ended Nov. 26 in contrast to the $5.09 million, or 20 cents a share, earned in the similar three months a year earlier. The figures were almost the same as the estimates announced three weeks ago.

title: Bridge:
description: Last year was one of triumph for New York players in the McKenney Trophy, which is determined annually by performance in tournaments at all levels. For twwdecades, New York experts were eclipsed by more energetic performers from California and Texas, but times have chaneed.

title: In London. Too, It's Bend or Die
description: LONDON, Jan. 4Arthur's, a gentlemen's club established in the early 1800's, hesitantly installed an automatic elevator about 1922. During one of its first runs, on a quiet Sunday morning, three members were stuck between floors for several hours and were almost asphyxiated for lack of ventilation.

title: A Fair Deal for American Steel
description: President Carter made good this week on his pledge to protect American steelmakers from a world market awash in excess production. The Treasury unveiled system of minimum prices, keyed to the production costs of efficient Japanese mills, at which foreign steel may sold in this country. Now it is up to the steel companies to decide whether they will settle for this helping hand instead of.a crutch.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR.

title: Betting on a British Election
description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI)  Ladbrokes, the big bookmaking organization, said today that it had taken a single bet of $25,000 at odds of 4 to 5 that a British general election would take place in the first half of 1978. Odds for the Conservative Party are currently given at 4 to 5 while it is even money on the governing Labor Party.

title: 4 Shops to Compete For A.M.C. Account
description: The American Motors Corporation has narrowed the field. competing for its account to four agencies, and that's official.

title: Canadian Reserves Up in December
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 4 (AP)  Official monetary reserves grew by $417 million to $4.6 billion during December as the Canadian Government added to its holdings of United States dollars, figures released today by the finance department showed. The Finance Department also announced terms of the $1.5 billion United States standby credit for use if needed to protect the dollar on foreign currency markets. The terms permit the Government to borrow United States dollars for periods of one, two, three or six months at its option. A standby fee of threeeighths of 1 percent a year must be paid on the unused funds.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk reports on the anxiety sweeping through the markets that the Federal Reserve will be less monetarist under its chairmandesignate than it was under Arthur F. Burns. Pane D7.

title: Layoffs at New England Telephone
description: BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP)The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would lay off about 400 workers whose jobs were outmoded by new technology. At the same time, however, the company said it would hire back about 300 telephone installers who were laid off or shifted to new jobs in the company over the last few years.

title: Struggle in India for the Control Of the Congress Party Builds Up
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 4 (Reuters)The battle for control of India's Divided Congress Party built up today when the rebel wine expelled the official president.

title: House Ethics Panel To Issue Subpoena For Tongsun Park
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI)The House ethics committee has ordered Tongsun Park to testify in its inquiry into alleged South Korean influence buying and a subpoena will be served immediately on his return to Washington, the panel's chairman, Representative John J. Flynt Jr., said today.

title: 2 New Stores Join South St. Seaport
description: The opening of two new South Street Seaport Museum stores will add shopping to the reasons for taking a family excursion to the city's historic seaport district.

title: HOW TO ASSIST THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times NeediestCases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193; Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Treasury Tells New York Not to Count on U.S. Funds
description: The United Stiies Treasury Department has told New York City informally to assemble a financing plan from local sources without assistance from the Federal Government, but the state, the banks and the pension funds, who control the money needed for such a package, said yesterday that they were not inclined to participate.

title: Where to Buy Firewood in the City
description: AAA Dry Ice and Ice Cream Distributors, 241 East 24th Street; 6833606. A sack of approximately a dozen 12inch piece's of split wood costs $5; 16inch pieces, $6. A bundle of kindling is $3. Free delivery throughout Manhattan.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON  Statistically, an American businessman's chances of being killed in a terrorist attack are less than death by dog bite. But terrorism is what experts term a high leverage form of violencea few episodes can spread panic within a community nr a country.

title: Baker Says Senate Won't Approve Canal Pacts Without Key Changes
description: FARALLON, Panama, Jan. 4 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Republican leader, told the Panamanian Chief of Government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, today that the Senate would not approve the Panama Canal treaties without maior changes.

title: SIR GILBERT ROBERTS, 78; DESIGNED MANY BRIDGES
description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP)Sir Gilbert Roberts, the British engineer who designed the 3,300footlong Firth of Forth highway bridge in Scotland and other famous spans, is dead at the age of 78.

title: Stolen Cab Used to Lure Victims
description: When Michael Shepard and Paula Boxer hailed a Checker cab at Third Avenue and 59th Street, they wanted a ride home after a movie. Instead, the police said, they were taken to Queens, robbed, beaten and threatened with murder and rape the way.

title: California to Vote on Plan to Limit Property Taxes; Schools and Local Governnments Fear Revenue Loss
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4A growing national discontent over soaring property taxes has produced tit confrontation in California between homeowners and government that threatens the fiscal foundation of education and local government in this state.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter, after the meeting in Aswan with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, read a prepared statement declaring that the Palestinians should be enabled to participate in the determination of their own future. He said this was one of the basic principles that should be observed before comprehensive Middle East peace can be achieved. In Israel, Prime Minister Menahem Begin rejected Palestinian selfdeterminatibm because he said would mean a Palestinian state that would be a mortal danger to Israel. [Page A1, Columns 12.]

title: Home Beat
description: THIS PROMISES to be the year of the foot. At the end of March, the Museum of Contemporary Crafts will open an exmbtion entitled The Great American Foot, featuring artwork dealing with the foot as well as footwear old and new.

title: Cairo Residents Ponder Reasons For U.S. President's Stopover
description: CAIRO, Jan. 4  An argument in Cairo bookstore today reflected the prevalent confusion among Egyptians over why President Carter decided to ston briefly in Egypt.

title: Disks: Music at Notre Dame
description: GRANDES HEURES LITURGIQUES A NOTRE DAME DE PARIS, Choirs and organs of Notre Dame, Pierre Cochereau at the great organ, with Contrepoint, a choral ensemble. (Delos DEL FY001).

title: Gershwin, By George
description: FTER BUILDING programs around a distinctive performer, Nat Cole, and a pair of singers who were also songwriters, Fats Waller and Johnny Mercer, Gil Wiest has now turned to the music of George Gershwin for a presentation called For George, By George, which wil be. at his Michael's Pub until the end of:the month.

title: People and Business Massachusetts Financial Elects Cooper to Head Funds Service
description: The election of John L. Cooper as chairman of the Massachusetts Financial Services Company was announced yeserday by the Boston concern, one of the nation's largest mutual fund ad. vicnry nroanizations.

title: Rangers Score Early, Subdue North Stars, 53
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan, 4The New York Rangers won their first game on the road in more than a month last night, defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 53.

title: Congress to Hear. Consolidation Plan For Five Railroads
description: The consolidation of many as five of the nation's railroads into one strong Midwestern road will be proposed to Congress in hearings scheduled today by the House transoortation subcommittee.

title: Dance: Nina Wiener's New Ritual
description: NINA WIENER and three dancing friends gathered for 50 minutes of dance at the St. Marks Church Danspace on Tuesday. It was a solemn hour, as rapt and hermetic as some alien ritual.

title: Growing a Palette
description: The color range in coleus leaves has been extended considerably beyond the common reds and dark greens through hybridization and the careful cultivation of mutations. The brilliant yellow Pixie, for example, laced with streaks of red, or the pure orange Winter Surf. The chartreuse Cream positively glows; Buttermilk is the mintiest of green laced with cream.

title: Shortage of Ski Lifts Limits Use of Silvermine's Slopes
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 3One of the mysteries puzzling skiers for many years is why the Silvermine area at this popular Palisades Interstate Park center is still operating with only limited lift facilities.

title: Printer Is Indicted on Charges of Using Inside Data
description: A. printer was indicted yesterday on Federal charges that he purchased stock on the basis of confidential information tEat he obtained as an employee in the composing room of a financial printing concern in New York.

title: I.T.T. Signs Contract
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced that is Argentine subsidiary, Compania Standard Electric, has signed a telephone supply contract valued for $88 million with Entel, the Argentinian telecommunications agency. The conract requires the I.T.T. subsidiary to fabricate, install and put into operation 180,000 equivalent telephone lines and 23g,000 telephone subsets, beginning in mid1979 and extending through 1982. Manufacturing of the telephone switching equipment will take place at Compania Standard Electric's plant in Buenos Aires.

title: Rift Bettveen Jersey State Police And S.C.I. Emerges at a Hearing
description: TRENTON, Jan. 4A serious rift between the New Jersey State Police and the State Commission of Investigation, a split that could affect state efforts to keep organized crime out of gambling casinos in Atlantic City, broke into the open today during a legislative hearing.

title: U. S. to Monitor Hiring Practices Of Big Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The nation's largest business concerns can expect their hiring and promotion practices to cone under close new scrutiny soon by Federal officials, according to Eleanor Holmes Norton, the,new chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: I've. Got a Secret
description: WASHINGTONWhether the journalists who served the C.I.A. should be numbered in the dozens or the hundreds hinges, it has become clear, on how one reads the files: Groping through the thicket of C.I.A.media relations, the House Intelligence Committee has come up with a distinction between contacts (voluntary) and assets (paid). Not so, say veteran intelligence officers. An asset could be anyone, enlisted, even unwittingly, to provide assistance,, or sometimes merely claimed as an asset by a selfaggrandizing field officer.

title: ACCUSED I.C.C. OFFICIAL SEEKS PUBLIC HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)An attorney for a highranking official of the Interstate Commerce Commission says that his client will ask for a public hearing to rebut allegations of wrongdoing, including a charge that he tried to.persuade a witness to lie in a Justice Department inquiry into the official'salleged ties with organized crime.

title: Soviet Junior Team Wins
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 4 (AP)The Soviet Union scored twice in each of the first two periods and defeated Sweden, 52, in the championship game of the Junior World Cup of hockey tournament last night.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A jury of eight men and eight women was selected yesterday in Camden to decide the fate of Harry De La Roche Jr., the 19yearold military college student from Montvale charged with murdering his parents and two younger brothers during the 1976 Thanksgiving weekend.

title: Miss Bellamy Lets Council Know Her Touch Will Be a Firm One
description: The City COtnicil held. its ceremonial first'meeting Of the new year yesterday, and there was evidence in several ways, large and small, that the widely proclaimed winds of change were blowing through the stately council. chamber in City Hall.

title: Islanders, Rangers Win
description: The Islanders beat ParclubiCe, the touring Czechoslovak team, 83, last night and the Rangers downed the North Stars, 53, The Nets defeated the Suns. 11583. Details on PageD14.

title: Crown of Hungarians Flown to Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI)  The Air Force flew Hungary's crown of St. Stephen from Fort Khox to Washington today, starting it on its homeward journey.

title: Four Stark Cast In Ashanti Film
description: Michael Caine, Omar Sharif, Peter Ustinov and Telly Savalas have been signed by the producer GeorgesAlain Vuille for Ashanti, to be filmed on location in Africa and the Middle East starting in April. Richard Sarafian will direct the adventure film.

title: CARTER AND SADAT ASK ROLE FOR PALESTINIANS IN DETERMINING FUTURE
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 4  President Carter met with President Anwar elSadat here today and then read a prepared statement in which he said that the Palestinians should be enabled to participate in. the determination of their own future.

title: Enthusiasm and Confusion Greet Plan on Steel Prices
description: The reference. prices proposed by the Carter Administration to limit imports of lowpriced foreign steel were greeted yesterday with a mixture of enthusiasm and confusion in domestic steel industry circles, while importers worried about potential damage to their business.

title: F.D.A. Urges Labels on Hair Dyes Telling Consumers of Cancer Peril
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday proposed new labeling for hair dyes to warn consumers that some,products contain an ingredient that causesAccording to the new proposal, dyes containing, the.suspect chemicals, known as 2,4 diaminoanisole, or 2,4DAA, and 4methoxymphenylenediamine, or 4MMPD, would bear the following statement on the label: Warning: Contains an ingredient that can penetrate your skin cancer, in animals. The agency also proposed that posters be mounted in beauty salons to alert customers to the possible cancer hazard.

title: International Team of Specialists Finds No End in Sight to 30Year Cooling Trend in Northern Hemisphere
description: An international team of specialists has concluded from eight indexes of climate that there is no end in sight to the cooling trend of the last 30 years, at least in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey announced that 10,000 invitations to the Jan. 17 Inaugural Ball were being mailed out to a cross section of people in the state to assure broad participation in the social events signaling the start of his second term.

title: NEW YORK POST MOVES UP TIME FOR FIRST EDITION
description: The New York Post is going to press earlier with its first edition and is now available on some midtown newsstands by 9:30 A.M. The afternoon daily has also cut out its final edition and will no longer publish daily closing prices for the stock market.

title: Publishing: Century Of Sandburg.
description: CARL SANDBURG was born 100 years ago today. His centenary is being marked With tributes and seminars at collegei and libraries around the country. Perhaps his poems will be discussed in classrooms. If so, he would have been pleased. For he used to say that a writer needed only a few things in life: to stay out of jail, to get a little loving at home and to get what he wrote published.

title: P.L.O. Blames U.S. In Slaying in London
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5The Palestine Liberation Organization said today through its press agency that it would hold the United States indirectly responsible for the assassination yesterday of Said Hammami, its represents, tive in London.

title: Gifts From Foundations and Trusts Help Fund to Aid Neediest Cases
description: Gifts from 500 donors to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday totaled $27,849.15, sending contributions over the $800.000 mark.

title: 9 AMEX SPECIALISTS IN OPTIONS INDICTED BY NEW YORK STATE
description: Nine options specialists on the American Stock Exchange were charged yesterday with filing fictitious market transactions and falsifying business records, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Maker Donates $17 Million Vaccine Facilities to Salk Institute
description: One of this country's major pharmaceutical makers, in a move to get out of the vaccine business, has donated its vaccine research and production facilities, assessed at $17 million, to the private Salk Institute of Biological Studies in San Diego.

title: About Real Estate
description: The excavators are stirring the earth again for a new apartment house on the east side of First Avenue between 70th Street and 71st Street. They were last seen there four years, ago just when the bad times started, as Amir Manocherian out it.

title: Dow Off 8.66 As Market Dips 3d Straight Day
description: Investor skittishness snuffed out an early rally yesterday to send the stock market abruptly lower for a third straight session.

title: Treasury Denies Bar on Aid to City But Sees Merit in Proxmire Stand
description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal yesterday denied a published report that he had told New York City officials to draw up a financing plan based on local sources without additional assistance from Washington.

title: Priest Sentenced to Eight Years
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 5 .,(UPI)A Roman Catholic priest was sentenced yesterday to eight years in prison on his guilty plea to falsifying citizenship documents and selling them to illegal aliens. The Rev. Luis Hernan Avevedo, 49 years old was sentenced by United States District Court Judge Woodrow Seals. He was accused of selling false identification packages, sometimes for as much as $2,500. Federal investigators said that as many as 70 aliens may have been involved.

title: Notes on People
description: School board officials in Hartsdale, N.Y., in Westchester County, will meet Tuesday to decide whether to take legal action against Betty Furness, NBC consumer reporter, for serving an alcoholic beverage to underage high school students in a program on teenage drinking. Miss Furness. who apologized to the school officials yesterday, servea a 30proof strawberryflavored concoction called a Malcolm Hereford's Cow to the children, 12 to 14 years old, at a taping last Nov. 28. She asked the children, students at Woodlands High School, if they would drink the sweet, milklike Cow at home in preference to Scotch. The children said they would. Miss Furness said they had proved her pointthat such drinks posed a danger to children. A spokesman for the New York State Liquor Authority said that serving the children was a clearcut violation of state law. Heublein Inc. of Hartford, which makes Cows, said it had been misrepresented and was also considering filing suit. The tasting was broadcast 13 in New York City.

title: Major Objectives of New Chairman at Amex
description: With'the installation of a new chairman at the American Stock Exchange this week, completing a cycle of changed administrations at Wall Street's three major securities institutions over the last 18 months, the way may be paved for some fresh initiatives to improve the health and status of the investment business.

title: Carter's Mideast Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Carter is giving the Israelis and the Egyptians the 5050 treatment. He confuses Prime Minister. Begin on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, and confuses President Sadat on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. The following week, he reassures Mr. Begin to the dismay of Mr. Sadat and vice versa. But he has a purpose.

title: Restaurants
description: SINCE it opened just about three years ago, II Monello, .op Second Avenue between 76th and 77th S.treet, has become one of the city's most highly praised sources of North Italian cooking. If its reputation is somewhat exaggerated, it is at least one of the more solldly dependable outposts of above average food pleasantly and amiably served. The menu holds few surprises in the way of original or unusual dishes, but most of the standards are of high quality and have enough appeal to make Il Monello well worth a visit.

title: Deaths
description: FUDIMLouis M. Beloved husband of Eva. Devoted father of Murray and Jay. Dear brother of Ed, Phil, Bernard and Edith Hager. Cherished grandfather. Services at The Riverside 76th St & Amsterdam Avenue, Friday at 9:45 a.m.

title: Television
The Pop Life
description: AL GREEN has long been one of our most talented and erratic performers. At his best he is a singer almost without peerhis reedy tenor stretches itself along a vocal line with amazing sinuousness, his rhythmic sense has a teasing precision that can bend the beat without breaking it, and his inflections of hitch color the words sensuously.

title: Ethiopia Denies That Guerrillas Have Closed the Asmara Airport
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 5 (Reuters)Ethiopia's acting Information Minister, Baaly Girma, denied today that guerrillas had closed the airport in the besieged Eritrean provincial capital of Asmara with artillery fire.

title: VITTORIO ROSSI
description: ROME, Jan. 5 (UPI)Vittorio Rossi, a journalist and author, died yesterday of heart disease, family members said. He was 79 years old. Mr. Rossi was a correspondent for the Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera from 1938 to 1963, covering stories around the world. He wrote 30 books, most of them adventure and travel stories drawn from his experience as a reporter.

title: Dance: Ara Fitzgerald Performs
description: IT IS EXCITING to see a choreographer take risks beyond the daring inherent in the act of creation itself, but there is a special plea sure in the rare wellmade dance that sets its own limits and succeeds within them, however modest those limits may be. Ara Fitzgerald provided an evening of such dance at St. Clement's Theater Wednesday.

title: President Geisel of Brazil Names Intelligence Chief as His Successor
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5Brazil's national intelligence chief, Gen. Joo Baptista Figueiredo, was named today to succeed Gen. Ernesto Geisel as President in March of 1979.

title: A U.S.State Law Enforcement Committee Is Created
description: NEWARK, Jan. 5The formation of a joint FederalState Law Enforcement Committee was announced today by Robert J. Del Tufo, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, and William F. Hyland. the State Attorney General.

title: Art People
description: ST. STEPHEN'S crown, the 1,000yearold symbol of Hungarian national sovereignty, will be formally returned to Hungary by the United States in a twoday ceremony ending today. The crown, given to the American Army at the end of World War II by retreating Hungarian soldiers afraid that it might fall into Russian hands, was kept here in Fort Knox while our Government waited for signs of thaw in the Communist climate of Hungary.

title: President Geisel of Brazil Names Intelligence Chief as His Successor
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5Brazil's national intelligence chief, Gen. Joao Baptista Figueiredo, was named today to succeed Gen. Ernesto Geisel as President in March of 1979.

title: Peter Wilhousky, Director of Music For Public Schools
description: Peter J. Wilhousky, choral director and music administrator in the New York public schools for 25 years, died Wednesday in the Norwalk Hospital of cancer, after a long illness. He was 75 years old and made his home In Westport, Conn.

title: Letter: On Tuition Tax Credit
description: In your Dec. 15 editorial attack on the attempt to use a $250 tuition tax credit to ease the burden on families with collegebound children you suggest that colleges might simply raise tuition by the full $250, leaving the families where they were in the first place.

title: The Spirit of Isadora Dances On
description: It's like a family, Julia Levien says the Isadora Duncan Centenary Depce Company, which opens the Riverside Dance Festival this year. Altough Isadore Duncan never succeeded in establishing the international dance academies she envisioned, her philosophy and dances have been passed down from generation to genetation by an intimate chain of family members. Fifty years after her death, the youngest dancers in that chain will perform a representative program of Duncan dances tonight through Sunday at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Talks on Sale Of Nets Start With Werblin
description: Arthur Imperatore, the New Jersey trucking magnate interested in making a substantial investment in the financially troubled Nets, met briefly yesterday with David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the new president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, and Mike Burke, president of the Knicks.

title: Carter, at Normandy Beach, Honors Men Killed on DDay
description: PARIS, Jan. 5President Carter trayeled to Normandy todayto a lonely beach and a crowded cemeteryto commemorate the Allied invasion of Europe on June 6, 1944, and pay homage to the thousands of Allied soldiers who died in that assault.

title: Deaths
description: HORWITZLouls D. The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee records Jerusalem of Louis D. Horwitz, devoted colleague and dedicated servant of the distressed, impoverished and uprooted among his people overseas. Formerly as DirectorGeneral of Overseas Operations, he directed services and prodrams aiding over 400,000 men, women and children. He served in welfare and refugee Posts in Europe, North Africa and Israel for over 30 years. The gratitude of those he helped, and the affection of those he worked with will serve as lasting memorials to his honored name. In behalf of the Board, Officers and staff we send heartfelt condolences to his wife Sylvia and his bereaved family. Donald M. Robinson, President Ralph I. Goldman, Exec VicePres.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Up 3 To 216.2 From 213.2 Last Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materialS rose to 216.2 from 213.2 last week.

title: MEDICORP LOSES BID TO BAR HUMANA MOVE
description: A Federal judge decided yesterday to reject a request for a court order to bar Humana Inc., from proceeding with an offer to obtain a majority of the stock of American Medicorp Inc.

title: A Second Storm Hits Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (UPI)As the authorities were assessing damage from the nation's first tornado of the year, a new but weaker Pacific storm brought more showers to southern California today.

title: U.S. Optimistic That Japan Will Halve Its Trade Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A Commerce Department official's coffee mug is emblazoned with the patriotic legend, Be American. . .Buy American, but below, in smaller type, are the words: Made in Janan.

title: Ballet: Balanchine, Robbins and Mortality
description: By Placing Jerome Robbins's The Goldberg Variations and George Balanchine's La Valse on a single program, the New York City Ballet paired two ballets that make dancing a matter of life or death.

title: 45 Years of Pageantry, Magic and Obsolescence
description: Radio City has been a crucial landmark in a city that for years has symbolized elegance and glamour to the rest of the country; every local Bijou and Rivoli, even those built long before the Music Hall, seemed to be a smalltown version of that bigtime palace on the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Behind Its Slogans, P.L.O. Is Worried About Losing a Peace Role
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5Behind the bravesounding slogan of Revolution until victory, the Palestine Liberation Organization is increasingly apprehensive that it will be squeezed out of a Middle, East peace settlement.

title: ADVISER TO BEGIN QUITS TO CAMPAIGN AGAINST HIM
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 5Shmuel Katz, close associate of Prime Minister Menahem Begin, resigned his Government post today to lead a challenge against Mr. Begin by hardliners in his party critical of the Prime Minister's recent policy changes.

title: Senior Citizen on the Beach
description: Gabe Paul, former president of the Yankees; was back in New York yesterday 24 hours past his 68th birthday and out of a job. When he was a 10yearold in Rochester he bought a newspaper, route for $5 and since then he had not been unemployed until last Saturday night, when his resignation from the Yankees took effect. Deeply touched at the sight of a senior citizen on the beach, a dozen or so sportswriters bought him a plate of liver and onions at. Mike Manuche's. It gave the lie to two classic mythsthe stereotype that pictures newspapermen as hardboiled cynics and the legend that the Big Apple is a heartless city. Gabe was frankly grateful.

title: New Man for Criminal Justice
description: On his 47th birthday last Saturday, Herbert Jay Sturz got an unusual present from Mayor Koch. It was the news that he had selected Mr. Sturz as Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justicethe city official who is chiefly responsible for trying to streamline New York's often bewildering billiondollar criminaljustice system.

title: DISTILLATE OIL FOR WEEK FELL 2.3 MILLION BARRELS
description: Supplies of distillate oil decreased to 245.6 million barrels in the week ended Dec. 30, from 247.9 million barrels in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Newly Confirmed Insurance Chief Has a Revised Car Inspection Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5State Senator Albert B. Lewis, Democrat of Brooklyn, was unanimously confirmed as New York State Superintendent of Insurance by the Senate yesterday.

title: 45 Years of Pageantry, Magic and Obsolescence
description: Radio City has been a crucial landmark in a city that for years has symbolized elegance and glamour to the rest of the country; every local Bijou and Rivoli, even those built long before the Music Hall, seemed to be a smalltown version of that bigtime palace on the Avenue of the Americas.

title: They're to Quest of New Audiences for Stravinsky In Tully Hall
description: To many concertgoers, new music is something encountered incidentally in the context of old music, a form of exposure that can sometimes do more harm than good. When John Cage's Renga With Apartment House 1776 received its local premiere this season, for instance, hundreds of outofplace New York Philharmonic subscribers fled their seats only minutes after the music had begun.

title: Movie and TV Panel Created By Carey
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced in Albany the creation of a New York State Motion Picture and Television Advisory Board to encourage the development of both industries here.

title: Deaths
description: DUNCANLaura, formerly of LI, on Jan 3, 1978 in Santa Barbara Calif. Widow of Lorne D. Duncan, who was the past president of NY Credit & Financial Management Assoc. Survivors, a niece Mrs James E. Harvey, Toronto, Canada. A Cousin, Mrs Violet Walter of Palm Desert, Calif. Funeral 10AM, Fri Jan 6, WelchRyce Chapel. Sante Barbara Calif. in lieu of flowers, friends may remember Cancer Foundation of Santa Bambara, 300 W Pueblo St. Santa Barbara, Calif in memory of Mrs Duncan.

title: Art: Swirl of The Golden West
description: THE scene is typical SoHo galleryhigh, white and handsome where nothing stirs save a distant typewriter. The performers are sixteen paintings, eight on canvas, eight on paper, each comprising a broken circle on a white ground. They come courtesy Peter Piagens, woo doubles as an art journalist and who is the author of Sunshine Muse, a brief history of art on the West Coast.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Bringing Insight to Human Resources
description: More than 20,000 people work for New York City's Human Resources Administration, a vast enterprise that manages the city government's relations with a million New Yorkers. The agency's biggest single responsibility is paying 950,000 people their public assistance checks twice each month, correcting their addresses, checking eligibility, adiustine nay levels. hearing complaints.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: FOR Long Island, the, Revolutionary War ended early, with a big victory for the British in the Battle of Long Island, which was fought in what is today Brooklyn. Little wonder, then that there are few monuments to the American Revolution on the Island.

title: For Children
description: WILLIE WONKA AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY, 2 P.M. on Saturday, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn. Tickets, $2.50. mattes: 6364100.

title: Arabs Acclaim Remarks By Carter During Visit But Skepticism Persists
description: CAIRO, Jan. 5Egyptian officials and Arab diplomats here expressed satisfaction today with the statements President Carter made during his brief visit to the Middle East, but they said they were skeptical about the chances of an effective followup.

title: Carolina High Court Rejects Plea Of Wilmington 10 in Firebombing
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 5The Wilmington 10, nine black men and one white woman who were convicted in connection with 1971 racial disturbances, have lost the last round in a legal battle in state courts to overturn their convictions.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 5. (AP)Vietnam as informed the United States that three. Americans held captive in Saigon since October have been released, tte State department said today.

title: Auctions
description: THE second phase of New York's 197778 art auction season begins today with the opening at Christie's and Sotheby's of presale exhibitions of old masters. The auction, at 2 P.M. Friday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, is described by the house as the most important to be held there in five years.

title: Suspect in Slaying Of Sal Mineo Is Set To Return to Coast
description: MARSHALL, Mich., Jan. 5 (UPI)  A Michigan convict who allegedly bragged to cellmates that he stabbed Sal Mineo, the actor, to death two years ago agreed, today to return to California for a murder trial.

title: Officials Divide On Law to Curb Ocean Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A major clash is apparently developing in the Carter Administration over a new law prohibiting the dumping of oil and other hazardous materials within 200 miles of the nation's coasts.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (UPI)About 133,000 commuters were forced to find different ways to get to work today because of dangerous cracks accidentally discovered in the supports of a 40foothigh rapid transit track.

title: No Hope Seen For Music Hall To Stay Open
description: The president of Rockefeller Center Inc. said yesterday that because there is no hope for survival for Radio City Music Hall, the historic tourist attraction must close on April 12. But Mayor Koch, without being specific, suggested that the city might try to lend a hand to the nation's largest theater.

title: Bankruptcy Sale Near For the Fontainebleau
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP)The bankrutpcy sale of the Fontainebleau Hotel will become final Monday unless Ben Novack, the owner, finds a new delaying tactic.

title: Watson Cards 63, Leads by 3
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 5 (AP)Tom Watson, picking up where he left off with his 1977 playeroftheyear performance, ripped out a nineunderpar 63 and took a threestroke lead today in the first round of the $200,000 Joe GaragiolaTucson open golf tournament.

title: When the City Sits for The Camera
description: THE subject was everywhere, Henry James observed of New York when he returned here at the turn of the century after a long absence abroad. That was the beauty, that the advantage: it was thrilling, really, to find one's self in presence of a theme to which everything directly contributed, leaving no touch of experience irrelevant.

title: New Man for Criminal Justice
description: On his 47th birthday last Saturday, Herbert Jay Sturz got an unusual present from Mayor Koch. It was the news that he had selected Mr. Sturz as Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justicethe city official who is chiefly responsible for, trying to streamline New York's often bewildering billiondollar criminaljustice system.

title: I.C.C. Bars 10% Fare Rise Scheduled to Start Today On LongDistance Buses
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (Reuters)A 10 percent rise in the price of longdistance bus tickets, scheduled to go into effect tomorrow, was blocked today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Goldin Won't Process Termination Pay For Another Beame Administration Aide
description: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, refused yesterday to process another terminationpay application by a former Beame administration official because it exceeded the 54day limit Mr. Goldin had established.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: 10 major New York Banks (Selected balance sheet items in millions of dollars: Wednesday figurest)

title: Marshall Field Acts To Acquire Altman
description: Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago department store chain that is locked in a takeover fight with Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Los Angeles, is itself seeking to acquire R. Altman & Company, one of New York's leading retailers, strong trade reports indicated yesterday.

title: ProLaetrile Bill Going to Byrne After senate Approves It,21 to 7
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5The New Jersey Senate approved a bill tonight to legalize the sale and use of laetrile by a vote of 21 to 7.

title: Smithtown Gets Panel on Medical Ethics; Charges There Tie Salesman to Surgery
description: A Committee on Medical Ethics has been formed by physicians in Smithtown, L.I., in the wake of indictments charging that a salesman of prosthetic devices had participated in surgery at Smithtown General Hospital.

title: New Clerk of U.S. District Court
description: Richard Weare of Omaha, a 31yearold court administrator, was named yesterday to be clerk of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Chief Judge Jacob Mishler said Mr. Weare had been chosen unanimously by the judges of the court after a nationwide search. He will administer all functions of the court except its judicial ones, will be paid $40,000 a year.

title: Nuns in Middletown Nursing Home Accused in Audit of Medicaid Abuse
description: A nursing home operated by Roman Catholic nuns in Middletown, N.Y., was accused by the State Office of Health Systems Management of having abused the public trust by using Medicaid funds for such things as grooming two pet dogs and for a gift to the late Bishop of Buffalo.

title: Koch Lets a 2d Official Use a City Car
description: Traveling home late at night by subway is difficult, exhausting and wasteful, the city's Corporation Counsel complained to Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
CHILEAN CHIEF'S RULE REINFORCED BY VOTE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 5President Augusto Pinochet of Chile has scored an important political victory in winning a national vote of confidence, as even his opponents do not deny, despite charges of fraud.

title: Israel's Other Supporters
description: ANNISTON, Ala.Sentiment in our miniature parliament, the Courthouse Barber Shop, has shifted toward Egypt but the shop's prime minister is still a vital element of the Israeli lobby in the United States.

title: Duryea Touches Off First Battle In G .0 .P. Contest to Oppose Carey
description: Attempting to foreclose the New York Republican gubernatorial nomination by a preemptive show of organization strength, the Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea Jr., yesterday touched off the first battle of the prospective contest for the G.O.P. nomination to oppose Governor Carey this November.

title: Secret Service Is Live In a Paris Music Hall
description: PARIS, Jan. 5 (Reuters)American Secret Servicemen protecting President Carter during his visit to Paris have not been as secret as usual. Their walkietalkie exchanges have been heard in a Paris music hall.

title: Cost of Local Business Calls Going Up Today
description: A new billing practice for business telephone calls takes effect today in the New York area, under which local calls exceeding five minutes will be billed according to their length.

title: House Ethics Committee Asks Seoul for Same Access to Tongsun Park Accorded to the Justice Department
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The House ethics committee has asked the South Korean Government to give it the same access to Tongsun Park that Seoul has agreed to give the Justice Department in its investigation of alleged Korean influence buying in Washington.

title: COLLEGE SAID TO ADD TO REASONING ABILITY
description: A team of researchers at Harvard University has concluded that study at the college level has a positive effect on students' reasoning ability.

title: ALLEN P. MULLINNIX
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Rear, Adm. Allen P. Mullinnix, who won the Navy Cross as commander of the cruiser Pensacola in World War II, died here yesterday. He was'79 years old.

title: EMMA RADLEY KOEHLER
description: Emma Radley Koehler, the daughter of William C. Muschenheim, the first operator of the Astor Hotel, died Wednesday at her home in the Wyomissing Park Apartments in Reading, Pa. She was 100 years old.

title: Acrid Gas Cloud Invades Baltimore
RUSSIAN DISSIDENT TO LIVE IN QUEENS
description: Dr. Valentin Turchin, the Soviet computer scientist who lost his research post after publicly defending Andrei D. Sakharov in 1973, arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night, eager to start a new career while still doing what I can for other Soviet dissidents.

title: Stenmark Skis to Cup Mark
description: OBERSTAUFEN, West Germany, Jan. 5 (AP)ThOugh barely able to see through foggedup goggles, Ingemar tenmark of Sweden won a slalom race today for a record 25th World Cup triumph.

title: Cauthen Wins 3, Including Feature at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 5 (UPI)Steve Cauthen rode three straight winners at Santa Anita today, capping his day with a victory in the $25,000 allowance feature aboard favored Barrera.

title: Jury Deliberates for Second Day On Mashpee Indians' Land Claim
description: BOSTON, Jan. 5The jurors in the trial of the Mashpee Wampanoags' land claim suit deliberated for a second day today on the Indians' status as a tribe.

title: Events and Openings
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Mascagnl's CavaHerat Rusticana  and Leoncavailo's Pag??lacci, 8.

title: Koch Names Vera Institute Head As Deputy to Succeed Scoppetta
description: The seventh and last of Mayor Koch's Deputy MayorsHerbert Sturz, who will coordinate criminaljustice matterswas annointed yesterday.

title: COWLES MAY WEIGH SWAP OF TIMES STOCK
description: Cowles Communications Inc., owner of 23 percent of the stock of The New York Times Company, is considering plans to distribute its Times holdings to Cowles shareholders, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Officials Divide On. Law to Curb Ocean Dumping
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 5A major clash is apparently developing in the Carter Administration over a new law prohibiting the dumping of oil and other hazardous materials within 200 miles of the nation's coasts.

title: Koch Names Vera  Institute Head As Deputy to Succeed Scoppetta
description: The seventh and last of Mayor Koch's Deputy MayorsHerbert Sturz, who will coordinate criminaljustice matterswas appointed yesterday.

title: Ethics Panel to Rule On Zuccotti's Work For Housing Units
description: John E. Zuccotti's request for an opinion on whether his law firm can work for housing projects that might have benefited from some of his actions as First Deputy Mayor will be resolved rather promptly, the counsel to the Board of Ethics said yesterday.

title: Homemade Hippari
description: Alexandra Jacopetti had not planned to go into the pattern business, After writing a book, Native Funk and Flash: An Emerging Folk Art, about the street fashion of the 60's that told how the young turned the tough and plain blue jean into denim art, the California weaver and fabric artist had wanted to write another book. This one was to explain why ethnic clothes have survived for centuies.

title: Books: Buyer's Guide to Antiques
description: COLLECTING antiques and art can be great fun, highly rewarding and, it seems, fraught with pitfalls. The subject is as provocative as it is popular today and, well worth a howto book that provides guidelines to those merely furnishing their homes and to others who are timid about making their first purchases at auctions and in galleries.

title: WYATT COOPER DIES; SCREENPLAY WRITER
description: Wyatt E. Cooper, author and wellknown social figure, died of a heart ailment at New York Hospital early yesterday. He was 50 years old and lived at 870 United Nations Plaza.

title: CAREY PLANS TO PUT INCOMETAX CUTS IN EFFECT ON JULY 1
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5The $500 million cut in personal income taxes proposed by Governor Carey, if enacted by the Legislature, would be reflected in taxpayers' paychecks through lower withholding taxes beginning July 1, aides to the Governor said today.

title: A Soccer Franchise For Houston
description: The North American Soccer League completed its membership for the 1978 season yesterday by awarding its 24th franchise to Houston.

title: Treasury Denies Bar on Aid to City But Sees Merit in Proxmire Stand
description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal yesterday denied a published report that he had told New York City officials to draw up a financing plan based on local sources without additional assistance from Washington.

title: Hungary's Ancient Symbol: A Long, Strange Journey
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The account Is terse and undramatic: An old, mudcovered gasoline drum was chiseled open, three muddy, crumbling leatherboxes were removed and the contents were carried to my bathroom where all mud and dirt was washed off. Thus the Crown of St. Stephen came into American hands.

title: U.S. Will Stop Giving 2d Glass of Milk to Needy Pupils
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI)The Agriculture Department announced today that it would stop giving free second helpings of milk at school meals, which are provided for 1.4 million needy children.

title: Screvane Quits OTB Poit
description: Paul R. Screvane, president of the Offtrack .Betting Corporation since 1974, resigned yesterday. Mayor Koch is expected to name Bernard Rome to replace Screvane. Page A16.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (AP)Goteborg, Sweden, Sapporo, Japan, and Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, have maintained their bids to stage the 1984 Winter Olympic Games while a group of French cities have withdrawn.

title: Bill to Allow the Use Of Laetrile in Jersey Is Sent to Governor
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5The New Jersey Senate approved a bill tonight to legalize the sale and use of laetrile by a vote of 21 to 7.

title: Dollar Drops in New York Trading As Dealers Assess U.S. Support
description: The United States dollar declined here yesterday against most foreign currencies amid growing skepticism among foreign exchange experts over the Federal Gov ernment's new policy to prop up the American currency.

title: The Whale Gets Honors at Columbia
description: Friends and lovers of the whales, the controversial but little  known oceangoing mammals that have developed such a following on land, will be gathering at Columbia University this weekend for a twoday celebration of the beasts in word, song, painting, film science and other media.

title: Teacher Is Suspended In PupilHitting Case
description: A fifthgrade teacher was suspended yesterday for allegedly striking one of his pupils at. Public School 113 in Harlem. The teacher, Solomon Dubin of 7 East 14th Street, was suspended for 90 days with pay pending a hearing.

title: Broncos Hosts For Super Bowl
description: DALLAS, Jan. 5 (UPI)  Although Super Bowl XII will be played on a home field of a National Conference Learn, the American Conference champion Denver Broncos will be considered the host club.

title: Advertising
description: A lot of ad agency executives were sticking close to their phones yesterday, hoping for a call from Milwaukee telling them that their shops were in the running for the Schlitz beer account.

title: Police Disperse Pakistan Protests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 5 (Reuters) The police arrested at least 165 people across the country today to break up demonstrations against Pakistan's martiallaw regime by supporters of the ousted Prime Minister,Zulfikar All Bhutto. Attendance at the demonstrations was reported asgenerally poor, however.

title: Farmrail Plan Outlined by Ingram
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5John W. Ingram, president of the Chicago, Rock Iand and Pacific Railroad, outliner as expected today his plan for Farrnrall; consolidation of several roads in the Midwest. in testimony submitted netore the transportution subcommittee of the }rouse Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee. Th plan will be further elaborated in a Department of Transportation hearing to be held in Chicago on Jan: 18 and 19.

title: U.S. to Press Israel on Peace Principles as Next Mideast Step
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5American officials said today that the next step in Middle East diplomacy would consist of seeking Israel's agreement to join with Egypt and the United States, at talks in Jerusalem later this month, on a set of broad principles to govern More detailed ArabIsraeli negotiations.

title: Environmental Officials Insisting On Water. Standards for Barrens
description: TRENTON, Jan, 5State environmental officials refused today to back down on new waterquality standards for the Pine Barrens despite widespread opposition frnm develnners and elected officials.

title: Negotiators Seek to Avert a Building Strike
description: Negotiations continued yesterday in an effort to reach an agreement that would avert a strike threatened for Monday night by 30,000 service employees who work in 2,500 commercial buildings in the city.

title: Stage: Mamet Reinvents Radio
description: WATCHING David Mamet has become virtually a theatrical subspecialty. Five plays  new or reworked  have been put on in the last year; all, have been original and interesting, and several have been extraordinary.

title: WALTER C. SHORTER
description: Walter C. Shorter, a retired vice president and general sales manager of the Union Camp Corporation of Wayne, N.J., a diversified forestproducts company, died Saturday in New York Hospital following a heart attack. He was 75 years old and had lived in recent years in Lexington, Va.

title: LANDLORD IS SUING TO EVICT CONSULATE
description: A Manhattan landlord is fighting a legal battle to evict the Congolese Mission to the United Nations for faildre to make payments on a mortgage he holds.

title: Levi Strauss, Producer of Jeans, Posts 25.8% Rise in Quarter Net
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the jeans maker, yesterday reported profit increases of 25.8 percent for the quarter ended Nov. 27 and 24 percent for the year, with sales up 28 percent in both periods.

title: U.S. DOUBTS ABILITY TO DEFEND EUROPE IN CONVENTIONAL WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  A Government study on the world military balance asserts that neither the United States nor the Soviet Union could emerge a winner from a strategic nuclear war, but concludes that the United States and its allies face problems in defending against conventional attack in Western Europe and the Far East.

title: 4 Approached by Bell on F.B.I. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Justice Department officials said today that Attorney General Griffin B. Bell had asked four persons if they were interested in being considered for the job ot director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but they refused to identify any of the four.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
For the Reel Thing, Come To the Celli
description: IT'S going to be one big ceili (pronounced Kaylee), or soiree might call it a hooleyboth are Irish words meaning partyat the Americana Hotel this weekend, beginning tonight at 6:30. In three ballrooms, 700 young people 8 years old and up will be.doing jigs; reels, hornpipes, planxties and traditional figure dancing, as well as specially choreogaphed story dances. The event, ending Sunday, is oven to thenublic.

title: Desegregation Of Universities Over the South
description: The battle between the Office for Civil Rights in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and a number of outhern states over the manner and pace of desegregation of higher education has all the earmarks of an oldfashioned civil rights donnybrook. It revives some ugly nostalgia from the late 1950's.

title: Deaths
description: STOLINSKYBernard F. 84 Suddenly, on Jan 4, at Teaneck, NJ. An Internationally known industrialist, is mourned and will be deeply missed by his family and a host of friends and business associates. He Is survived by his wife, Fay; son, Irving: a sister, Hannah Herman; two daughters: Jeanne Lawrence and Myra Jacobson; ten grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Services will be from Wieh & Wien, 2030 Kennedy Blvd, JerW en, sey City, on Sunday, Jan 8 at 10:30AM. Shiva will be observed at the family home, 789 Downing St, Teaneck. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Childrens Metabolic Research Foundation will be deeply appreciated.

title: Legislative Group Formed To Push Physical Fitness
description: Because high school athletes in New York City have to train in corridors, because there is no free gymnastics program available'to youngsters in the Albany area, because girls as well as boys need physical training, because Buffalo is afraid of losing the Braves and New York is afraid of losing the Jets, and because Los Angeles outbid New York for the 1984 Olympic Games, politicians and sports officials met, yesterday and announced that hope was just around the corner.

title: Ali Agrees to Fight Norton, Beats W.B.C. Deadline
description: Muhammad Ali has formally filed an agreement with the World Boxing Council to Fight Ken Norton, thereby avoiding being stripped of the heavyweight championship.

title: ShortTerm Rate Rise Threatens To Lift Corporate Loan Interest
description: Shortterm interest rates, after inching upward for several weeks, yesterday reached a point that could start an increase today in the rates banks charge on corporate loans, data released by the Federal Reserve indicated.

title: Stage: Bishop OneActer at Circle Rep
description: ONE OF THE MOST laudable aspects of the Circle Repertory Company's series of latenight productions of oneact plays is that the playsat least the first two in the series, Lanford Wilson's Brontosaurus and John Bishop's current Cabin 12really are oneacts. These are not unfinished fulllength plays or closeups from a larger canvas, but the theatrical equivalent of short stories or character sketches.

title: Dollar Drops in New York Trading As Dealers Assess U.S. Support
description: The United States dollar declined here yesterday against most foreign currencies amid growing skepticism among foreign exchange experts over the Federal Government's new policy to prop up the American currency.

title: Music: Schubert Lieder
description: THERE IS NOTHING quite like a program of Schubert lieder, assuming it's well sung, to make the world seem like a better place. It is not a question of the music, serving as an escape. what Schubert did was to take ordinary !human emotions, as depicted in poetry, and reflect them in terms at once acJcessible and subtle. Just as the composer could treat with equal respect texts by Goethe and much lesser writers, so his music can appeal equally to the musically unlettered and most sophisticated.

title: New Dollars, Old Problems
description: For nearly a year the Carter Administration watched passively as the dollar sagged on world money markets. But on Wednesday, after an appeal from Saudi Arabia's King Khalid, the President changed his mind. With Mr. Carter's encouragement, the Federal Reserve intervened aggressively. buying American currency. Speculators rushed for cover, and by the end of the day the dollar had recovered handsomely. Thursday's dollar news was mixed but the Fed's basic power to buck up the dollar was clear.

title: UAL Agrees to Buy A Rockefeller Hotel
description: UAL Inc., parent of United Airlines and of Western International Hotels, reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel in Hawaii, it was announced jointly by Edward E. Carlson, UAL chairman, and Laurance S. Rockefeller, ownerdeveloper of the resort

title: Newly Confirmed Insurance Chief Has a Revised Car Inspection Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5State Senator Albert B. Lewis; Democrat of Brooklyn, was unanimously confirmed as New York State Superintendent of Insurance by the Senate yesterday.

title: His Wife Gets Headlines in John Warner's Race
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 5Whose husband is Clive DuVal? The Richmond TimesDispatch demanded in a columnist's headline today as John W. Warner, Elizabeth Taylor's husband, became the 11th candidate to announce for the United States Senate seat being vacated next fall by William L. Scott, Republican of Virginia.

title: LOUIS D. HORWITZ, EXAIDE OF JEWISH RELIEF AGENCY
description: Louis D. Horwitz, former director general for overseas operations of the Joint Distribution Committee at its headquarters in Geneva. died Wednesday in Jerusalem. He was 69 years old.

title: New race: Donna Pescow
description: On the surface, it seemed ideal. But in reality, something crucial was missing.

description: In Billlone DAILY AVERAGES

title: Options Trading: A Money Game With Fast Gains, Quick Losses
description: Undoubtedly the most controversial and fast moving investment game in town, options trading has come under increasing scrutiny by the Securities and Exchange Commission and other regulatory agencies.

title: Larson Returns to Tally Decisive Goal for Wings
description: DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP)Reed Larson celebrated his return to action after a fivegame absence by scoring at 4:09 of the second period to give the Detroit Red Wings a 21 National Hockey League victory tonight over Toronto.

title: Carter, at Normandy Beach, Honors Men Killed on DDay
description: PARIS, Jan. 5President Carter traveled to Normandy todayto a lonely beach and a crowded cemeteryto commemorate the Allied invasion of Europe on June 6, 1944. and pay homage to the thousands of Allied soldiers who died in that assault.

title: Shoji Hamada, Renowned Potter; Made Town of Mashiko Famous
description: TOKYO, Jan, 5 (AP)Shoji Hamada, one of the world's great potters, died today of pneumonia in Mashiko, the town he raised to international prominence as a pottery center. He was 83 years old.

title: Reports on Nearby Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supplied by resort owners, Not all lifts operating).

title: ExAtlantic City Postmaster Gets 25 Years for Planning Mail Theft
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 5Gordon F. Lawson, who helped mastermind a $1 million robbery of the Atlantic City Post Office, of which he was postmaster. was sentenced to 25 years in Federal prison.

title: Women Are Singing Out in Support of Women
description: CHICAGOIn stage concerts in cities across the country at a rate of about one a month, on records selling at a rate of nearly half a million dollars a year, in styles ranging from jazz to pop to folk to country, a new breed of performer is making herself heard.

title: Britain RollYourOwn To Cut Cigarette Tax
description: LONDON, Jan. 5One of Britain's major cigarette companies announced today that it would slice 20 percent from the price of one of its brands through tax savingsbut the smoker must complete the manufacturing process himself.

title: Ramones, Doyens of Punk Rock, in the Big Time
description: In a world in which teenage tastes seem gratified by the fancified likes of Queen and Emerson, Lake and Palmer, it's hard not to love the Ramones. The New York punk rockers, who will be at the. Palladium tomorrow night, first burst onto the CBGB's circuit in 1974. By the following year they had established their style. Jostling one another on stage in black leather jackets, torn Tshirts and jeans, they began every song with Dee Dee Ramone, the bass player, bellowing out 1234. The songs themselves were short and aggressively simple, strung together in a mostly uninterrupted chain of howling feedback and twanging dissonance into one mosaiclike, halfhour set.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: If you've got that mustgodowntotheseaagain yearning, Mystic Seaport in Mystic, Conn., is the place to be. In fact, the museum is so popular with landlocked maritime spirits during this deepfreeze season that its current show, Model Making Today, has just been extended to April 1. The exhibition of 40 awardwinning models, ranging from a few inches to four feet, includes clipper ships, steamboats, schooners, a submarine, a Japanese whaling sampan and a French ceremonial barge. Besides looking at the models, visitors can venture onto the docks and board some fullsize ships, such as the, Charles W. Morgan, reported to be the oldest wooden whaling vessel anywhere. Other attractions are a scrimshaw show and a walk through a street from a 19thcentury maritime village. Hours: 9 A.M. to P.M. daily. Admission is $4.50 ($3.50 for the elderly, $2.25 for children). From New York City, take the New England Thruway (Interstate 95) to Exit 90. Information: (203) 5362631.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Celtics Bow, 121111, in Sanders Debut
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 5  A strange anomaly surfaced. in the National. Basketball Association tonight: a coach who showed no emotion. Whether that condition lasts for Tom (Satch) Sanders, the new coach of the Boston Celtics, may depend on how his struggling team responds to his leadership.

title: Duryea Touches Off First Battle In G.0.P. Contest to Oppose Carey
description: Attempting to foreclose the New York Republican gubernatorial nomination by a preemptive show of organization strength, the Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea Jr., yesterday touched off the first battle of the prospective contest for the G.O.P. nomination to oppose Governor Carey this November.

title: Evansville Benefit Suggested
description: INDIANAPOLS Jan. 5 (UP)  Gov. Otis R. Bowen has proposed a postseason tripleheader college basketball program. to benefit the University of Evansville, whose team was killed in a plane crash last Dec. 13. Bowen has sent letters o Purdue, Indiana, Indiana State, Notre Dame, Kentucky and Louisville, inviting them to participate if such a card can be arranged at Market Square Arena, Indianapolis, after the current season ends. The governor suggested proceeds could go into a trust fund for either the school or families of the victims of the 29death crash at Evansville, who included 14 players and Coach Bob Watson.

title: ACCUSATIONS HEARD. IN DE LA ROCHE CASE
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 5The murder trial of Harry De La Roche Jr., the former militaryschool student accused of murdering his parents and two younger brothers in their Montvale home over the 1976 Thanksgiving weekend, opened here today, with the prosecutor asserting that the defendant sought to accuse his brother, Ronald, of the crimes from the moment he led a police officer to three of the bodies.

title: Radio
description: 9:50 A.M., WKCR. Concerti Giossi Nos. 1 and 2; Suite Symphonique; Symphony, for Trombone and Orchestra, Bloch.

title: Metropolitan  Briefs
description: A 22yearold man who, with a companion, robbed, raped and sodomized a Brooklyn College professor last Jan. 27 on a nearly empty Manhattanbound subway train, was sentenced to eight and a third to 25 years in prison. In imposing sentence on the man, Alvin St. Lawrence of 545 West 164th Street, Justice Sybil Keeper of State supreme Court in Brooklyn specified that he not. be eligible for parole until after serving the minimum eight and a third years.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has complained to the Treasury that two Japanese companies, Toray Industries and Kanebo Ltd. are selling nylon broadweaving and warp knitting yarns in the United States for prices that are about 30 percent below the cost of producing the yarns.

title: 50 Appointed to Serve as Jurors To Consider 1978 Pulitzer Prizes
description: The names of 50 editors and educators who will serve as jurors for the 1978 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism were announced yesterday by Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University.

title: Big Board Votes on Trading System
description: The board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange sent the membership a prpsl yesterdy to vote on an amendment to the exchange constitution regarding participation in the proposed intermarket trading system. The system is designed to link exchanges throughout the country via an eleCtronic communications network for trading purposes.

title: U.S. DOUBTS ABILITY TO DEFEND EUROPE INCONVENTIONALWAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5A Government study on the world military balance asserts that neither the United States ror the Soviet Union could emerge a winner from a strategic .nuclear war, but concludes that the United States and its allies face problems in defending against conventional attack in Western Europe and the Far East.

title: If You're Just Wild About Johann.
description: Bach in the morning and Bach on into the night. Bach resounding through the Symphony movie theater and maybe out onto Broadway and 95th Street.

title: U.S. POWER CONSUMPTION HITS RECORD HIGH FOR '77
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI)United States power consumption hit a record high in 1977 and is expected to soar much higher this year, ending a period of slow growth in demand for electricity, the electric utility industry said today.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: A MOVIE about teenalters that is described as a bittersweet story for anyone who ever thought first love would last is obviously not concerned about giving away the plot: boy and girl meet; boy and girl fall lyrically in love; boy and girl part, sadder, perhaps wiser. That is about the shape of the ironically titled, Forever a madefortelevision film that can be seen on CBS tonight at 9.

title: Sales in December By Large Retailers Soared Above '76
description: December sales among the nation's largest retailers soared over 1976 levels, producing doubledigit gains and in several cases recording the biggest monthly advance in years, according to reports issued yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: CHENEYPaul N., on January 4, 1978. Beloved husband of Catherine McKew Cheney. Loved and loving father of Kate and Jim. Devoted son of Helen and the late Teenus. Brother of the late Clinton. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell. Madison Ave at 81 Street Thursday and Friday, 25 PM and 7.9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany Church, Second Ave and 22 Street, NYC Saturday, 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Code Words on Mideast Explained
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Because of the highly emotional and sensitive nature of the Middle East diplomacy, certain words and phrases have taken on extraordinary importance and have become, in effect, code words. Following is a short glossary of some of them: PEACEEveryone in the Middle East negotiations seems to want a just and lasting peace. But there are differences. The Israelis have insisted that in an overall settlement there must be a peace treaty with each of its Arab neighbors and such peace should be more than an end to the state of war and include, for instance, normal diplomatic and trade relations. President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, in effect, has agreed to much of this by going to Jerusalem in November and starting a direct dialogue. Jordan also seems willing, but Syria would apparently do nothing more than sign a treaty. The Arabs, of course, say that in return for peace Israel has to give back land taken in 1967 and agree to oemands affecting the Palestinians. The United States agrees with Israel on the nature of a peace.

description: Alcorn, Matilda

title: PHNOM PENH CHARGES BIG GAINS BY VIETNAM
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, Jan. (UPI)Cambodia charged today that invading Vietnamese troops had pushed to within 50 miles of the capital and had installed puppet administrations in the captured territories.

title: No Hope Seen ForMusicHall To Stay Open
description: The president of Rockefeller Center Inc. said yesterday that because there is no hope for survival for Radio City Music Hall, the historic tourist attraction must close on April 12. But Mayor Koch, without being specific, suggested that the city might try to lend a hand to the nation's largest theater.

title: Mexico to Wait Rather Than Cut Gas Price to U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5The Mexican Government is prepared to wait two or three years to sell its natural gas to the United States rather than lower the price that it is now demanding, according to Jorge Diaz Serrano, the head of Pemex, the state oil monopoly.

title: Deaths
description: MUELLERHermann Berner, age 57, of LI, NY on Jan 3, 1978. Brotherinlaw Ploschan of Frank. Service at The Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ on Sat. at 11AM. Visitation Fri. 79PM
