description: ABOUT 14,000 people die of cancer in New Jersey each year, and many cancer victims, moved by desperation, have shown a willingness to try almost any cure in addition to undergoing the medically recognized treatments of chemotherapy and surgery.

title: Hockey Club Sets Auction
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 (AP)There's good news for fans who want to remember the Baltimore Clippers. The Baltimore Hockey Associates, who owned the team before the demise of the Southern Hockey League, have decided to sell the club's remaining assets at. public auction in order to reduce their losses. Among the items slated to go on the auction block Monday are: 480 pairs of skate laces, 350 pucks, 1,000 hockey sticks, 850 cowbems, and 220 recordings of the Clippers fight song.

title: Short Line. Bus Company Seeking Fare Rise on 18 Intercity Routes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7 (UPI)  The Short Line Bus Company has asked for a rate increase, the New York State Department of Transnortation has announced.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Joan Cook's article about Paterson (Dec. 11) was a welcome one. In Paterson, as in other innercity areas of New Jersey, much fine housing exists at nearbargain prices.

title: A Better Balance in Regional Growth
description: Economists who analyze the health of New England sound remarkably like the sympathetic friends of a man who was hit by a truck a few years ago and now gets along with only a cane and a limp: He's doing amazingly well, considering. The region's six states were dealt a strong blow in the recession of 196970, when tne slumping national economy brought severe cutbacks in defense and aerospace spending, sharply affecting the region's only major economic bright spothightechnology industries.

title: Jean Taylor Schneider Bride
description: Jean Taylor Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Taylor Schneider of Washington, was married there yesterday to Peter McKenney Gibson, son of Bishop and Mrs. Robert Fisher Gibson Jr. of Richmond and Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: POLL FINDS PUBLIC DECLINE IN CONFIDENCE IN PRESS
description: A Harris poll reports that Americans feel more confidence in the country's major institutions and professions, with the exception of the press, which shows a drop in public confidence. the 15 other groups cited by pollsters had a higher percentage of great deal of confidence votes in 1977 than they did in 1976, The Associated Press reported.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: None of the previously missed opportunities for peace in the Middle East have been of a magnitude comparable to the present one. And none of the previous failures had consequences as disastrdus as those that would follow the failure of arriving at a peace agreement at the present time.

title: Languages Get a New Accent at Dartmouth
description: HANOVER N.H. THE 16 students of French in demonstration class whispered and shifted nervously as they waited in Room 101 of historic Dartmouth Hall for their professor to arrive. Suddenly, as though stepping onto the stave of the Comedie Frangaise, thumping a cane, wearing long silver wig, in a full bluevelvet costume with lumpy black pantyhose covering his calves, Dr. John A. Rassias, professor of romance languages and literatures, strode in. Allez, allez allez! he growled, voice rising to roar. Je suis MONTESQUIEU!

title: Modified Limited Hangout, SeoulStyle
description: For a while last fall, it seemed as if there was some thing wrong with South Korea's political hearing. Despite its reliance on American aid, Seoul refused to cooperate with investigations of Korean influencebuying in Washington. With mounting exasperation, Congress passed a resolution of disapproval, 407 to 0. It even came close, surprisingly, to voting an end to aid for Korea.

title: Port Agency Accused of Awarding Contracts With No Public Bidding
description: The New York State Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, charged yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey violated its own regulations by awarding an overwhelming amount of construction and maintenance contracts for the $1 billion World Trade Center without public bidding.

title: If You Plan

description: LAKE CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 7 (UPI)Edith Forkell, the 60yearold Brooklynborn Supervisor for the Town of Kent, has helped elect herself the first woman chairman of the Putnam County Board of Supervisors.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three upstate men suspected of kidnapping an 18yearold woman from Kew Gardens, Queens, for nine hours and raping her after stealing her car were arrested in the Times Square area. The kidnapping victim was with them.

description: The question seems simple enough: In what direction are the New York Knicks headed halfway through Willis Reed's first season as coach? The answer to that question can be determined only by answering other important questions.

title: Baker and Panama
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 The Repub. Roan leader of the Senate, Howard H. pacer Jr. of Tennessee, is facing his first major test on the Panama Canal treaty, and so far he has handled with admirable care and skill.

description: IT is there and it is a controversial piece of art. A construction by Ron Bladen, the sculpture stands boldy in front of the Grand Army Plaza in Manhattan at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 60th Street. Thousands of people.

title: Classics Restored to Peking Library
description: PEKING, Jan. 7 (Reuters)The Peking library, China's largest, has lifted a ban on Shakespeare, Dickens, Mark Twain and other writers,. the Hsinhua press agency reported today. It said the ban on some authors had been imposed by nowdisgraced radical associates of Mao Tsetung.

title: Ad Man Will Direct Red Cross Fund Drive
description: Kenneth Roman Jr., executive vice president of the Ogilvy & Mather ackvertising agency, has been named to head the 1978 fundraising drive for, the American Red Cross in Greatef New York.

title: We Stick To Our Lasts

Though the days when the company sponsored vacations, housing and schools  and supplied town power  have faded, some 2,500 people work in its factories, and it's only a couple of years since Clark's decided to let the Bear Inn have a liquor license.

title: When It Snows on Long Island, a Motorist Is Often Confronted by a Swirling Maze of Regulations
description: When the temperature hovers around freezing or goes below, Long IslanD's motorists face a maze of snowemergency regulations and, in some instances, tickets and fines if they are forced to abandon their vehicles.

title: It May Look Like Tennis, but It Could Be
description: To the slim, grayhaired man in Seat 12, Row D, Section 213 of the $12.50 area of Madison Square Garden, every movement was study in fluid motion.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Inn of the Five Greens, recently opened in Bethpage State Park, seems to have almost everything going for it. It is in the clubhouse of the park, a gray fieldstone Robert Mosesstyle building. The five greens are Bethpage's five colorcoded golf courses.

title: Getting Mileage

For President Carter's nineday, sevencountry tour, the question involved four major issues the Middle East, nuclear proliferation, human rights and Western defense and the answers were mixed.

title: College Football: Important, but a Game
description: Football is as much a part of the American scene in the fall as the multicolored leaves and is welcomed with equal enthusiasm by millions of fans. We should never forget that it is game.

title: Births
description: Dr. William L., Jr. and Dolores Hanson Betsill Joyfully announce the birth of their daughter, Christine December 31, 1977.

title: A Nautical Dream Goes Sour
description: HER name and home port are painted on her stern: Enchantress. Port Jefferson. Less than a month ago she was lying alongside a wharf at the Goat Island Marina in Newport, R.I., like a tired refugee from the 18th century. More than hundred people had gathered there to see the fouryearold brigantine sold at auction.

title: Koch Leaves Gracie Mansion To Live in His Village Apartment
description: Mayor Koch, who has rattled around the 14 rooms of Grade Mansion since his inauguration a week ago, has decided to live in his threeroom apartment in Greenwich Village.

title: Cathedral. of St. John the Divine Embroiled in Dispute Over School Head's Retirement
description: The forced retirement of a popular headmaster has become a lingering conflict for the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan and Dean James Parks Morton.

title: Kevin McNamara And Miss Meehan Plan JulyWedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Meehan of Plandome Manor, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Monica Jane Meehan, to Kevin R. McNamara, son of Mrs. William McNamara of New Milford, Conn., and the late Mr. McNamara. The wedding planned for July.

title: POLITICS
description: IT wasn't too long ago when Long Island Democrats and Republicans, like politicians in other areas, debated over Federal involvement or encroachment in state and local government affairs. Big government, socialism and dictatorial bureaucrats were some of the catch phrases that were thrown around.

title: A Walk To Freedom
description: LONDONTwo days ago I arrived in Britain with my family after a bizarre 6,000mile journey which involved walking, hitchhiking, wading, swimming, hiding, and flying in a variety of aircraft. large and small.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN Ellie Conason and her husband, Emmanuel, opened a tiny crafts shop here in 1953, they were told: You'll never make it in White Plains. The merchandisehandblown glass, handmade ceramics and linens, and specially designed flatware and chinawas sleek, contemporary and almost always functional. R was considered avantgarde.

title: New Dean of Dance Puts Spotlight on Performance
description: PURCHASE AS JACQUES D'AMBOISE steps in this week as Dean of Dance at the State University College of New York at Purchase, the appointment perhaps can be regarded as one more stride in the college's attempt fulfill its mandate as the university system's center for performing and visual arts.

title: If You Go
description: to Saba you'll first have to get to St. Martin 28 miles to the northeast. KLM flies directly from New York;

title: 5 Ambassadors to China Leave For 2Week Visit to Cambodia
description: PEKING, Jan. 7 (Agence FrancePresse) The Ambassadors in China of Sweden, Finland, Denmark, Tanzania and Iraq left here today for a twoweek visit to Cambodia.

title: Florence, Despite Its Riches, Was a Hell to Dostoyevsky
description: Most travelers would relish a lengthy stay in Florence, but at least one found such a visit to be an imprisonment in hell. I discovered this recently when, having crossed the Ponte Vecchio on my way to the Pitti Palace, I came upon plaque over a doorway in a nonaescript Florentine building. With my limited knowledge of Italian I made out that Fyodor Mikhail Dostoyevsky had lived there in 1869 while writing his novel The Idiot. I didn't believe it. Dostoyevsky, the Slavophile, the writer whose themes stem from Russian locales, a working resident of Florence? knew that he had spent some time outside Russia escaping his debtors, but Florence seemed an unlikely city for this tormented man.

title: Carol Bellamy Vows She'll Be Noticed
description: Carol Bellamy, the new City Council President and the first woman elected to citywide office in New York, moved into City Hall last week, and while she was overshadowed by the mediagenic new Mayor, she served notice that she expected to get some attention of her own.

title: RICHARD C. WENZEL
description: The Rev. Richard C. Werzel, associate pastor of St. Benedict Joseph Labre Church, Richmond Hill. Queens, died Wednesday in Brunswick Hospital Center, Amityville. L.I., after a long illness. He was 4R years old.

title: What Do Consumers Really Like? Try Specialty Shops, FastFood
description: The fourmember urban family that lived in reasonable comfort with an income of less than $16,600 six years ago will need about $27,500 this year to continue living in the style to which it has become accustomed, as a result higher prices and taxes. It sounds onerous, but since incomes have also risen, the family should continue live in comfort, economists say.

title: POLITICS
description: WHEN Joseph A. LeFante moved in 1976 from Assembly Speaker to United States Representative, it looked like the beginning of another long career for another Hudson County Democrat.

title: Dear Poet and Comrade
description: THE story is told of Carl Sandburg, in his late years, preparing backstage for a musical recital and finding it a little difficult to bend down and tie his shoelaces. His wife, Lilian Steichen, did so for him. Do you see that woman down there tying my laces? he remarked to a few friends nearby. If it wasn't for her. I'd still be a bum today.

title: Antiquaire Keeps Faith With Elegant Past
description: NEW ROCHELLE IN 1970, Luce Klein and her husband, Arthur, a dramatist who heads Spoken Arts, a company that produces and distributes recordings to educational audiences, bought a 1920's vintage National Bank of Westchester building iu the heart of downtown New Rochelle. They have just completed renovating the building.

title: Officials in Dispute Over 200Mile Ocean Jurisdiction Agree to Seek a Single U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  Highranking diplomatic, defense, intelligence and environmental officials have agreed to ask President Carter to create an interagency group to work out a single, Governmentwide policy on this country's offshore jurisdiction.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The man with the tape recorder showed up, as usual unannounced. It was the afternoon of New Year's Eve, which is always a gloomy time in a newspaper office where, more than any place I can think of, it's all too clear that time will never be stopped. There's always the next edition. The man came to the point immediately.

title: DINING OUT Can Reliable Sources Be Wrong?
description: WHITE PLAINS IF the truth must out, we were disappointed by Gregory's. Recommendations had come in from what the intelligence services call usually reliable sources. Though the two evenings there produced quite acceptable food, there were only a few real triumphs, and they were balanced by a couple of failures.

title: Suffolk Klein: A Winner Perhaps at a DeadEnd
description: HUNTINGTON  A junior high school teacher in Long Island's Suffolk County recently asked her ninthgrade students to name the Mayor of New York City. Ed Koch, they called out.

title: Alice W. Emmons Is Fiancee Of Robert Francis Connery
description: Mr. and Mrs. George B. Emmons of South Salem, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice, Wetherill Emmons, to Robert Francis, Connery, son of Mrs. John F. Connery of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Connery.

title: Gerontology Comes of Age
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN Arlene Mevorach, Southern California housewife with three adult children, decided in midlife to go to college, she explored a number of career fields and finally chose one that had barely existed when her own children went to college: gerontology..

title: Do Steel's Problems Go Beyond Imports?
description: The nation's beleaguered steel corporations drew their Wagons in a circle last year against an attack by lowprice importers. They called for help with mass layoffs, shutdowns and loud lobbying effort. The Carter Administration, after some misgivings, rode to the rescue.

title: ALEXANDER D. RICHARDSON, FORMER ORGANIST, AT 81
description: Alexander D. Richardson, a former organist at Radio City Music Hall and later with the New York Philharmonic, died Friday at Columbus Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 545 East 14th Street.

title: Quebec May Use Trudeau's Threat As Political Tool
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 7 The Quebec goyernment has withheld any strong reaction to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's statement last weekend that he would use force to prevent an illegal separation of this Frenchspeaking province from the rest of Canada but his threat may be used as ammunition against him by Quebec officials.

title: Maturing the New Students of Wine
description: ONCE considered esoteric and slightly effete, wine these days is literally and figuratively on everybody's tongue. Wine has become a big business and, if the present rate continues, wine education is going to be a big business, too.

title: Borg Downs Vilas in 2 Sets; Connors Also Reaches Final
description: It figured After all the medical reports, a controversial roundrobin and the fuss over who's No. 1, it has come down to Bjorn Borg against Jimmy Connors in the final of the Grand Prix Masters tennis competition.

title: By Jeep to the Jungle Ruins in the Yucatan
description: You're not thinking of going into the jungle like that? demanded the little woman in the internationalorange rain parka. The other members of the party waiting for our drivers in the parking area behind the Hacienda Uxmal pressed around me to stare (as the woman's accusing finger directed) at my nearly naked feet. Embarrassed, curled up my bare toes, but, of course, they were still clearly visible, snarled in the heavy leather thongs of my homemade sandals.

title: Tracy Caulkins Breaks Two Swim Records
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 7 (AP)American women swimmers, led by 14yearold Tracy Caulkins, who broke two United States records, dominated the opening events in the first United States women's international meet at Brown University tonight, winning 16 of the first 18 places in six events.

title: 2 Die in Illinois Plane Crash
description: MARION, Ill., Jan. 7 (UPI)  Two men were killed last night in the crash of their airplane in a soybean field less than two miles from the Williamson County Airport. The coroner, James Wilson, said the pilot had told the airport tower ne was having mechanical trouble shortly before the crash. The plane hit a tree before crashing and burning.

title: Gadfly StingsVermont and E.P.A. into Action Against Lead Poison
description: BENNINGTON, Vt.Some people see their lives as Greek tragedy, while others see themselves cast in a Faustiam struggle between good and evil. Either role is easy to imagine when the gloom of a Northern winter descends on the New England hills.

title: ENCOUNTER A French Lesson ht Human Relations
description: We decided on France (after a month at Oxford) rather than Scotland or Wales in order to have a totally different experience, devoid of English. My husband and children spoke no French at all and were apprenhensive, but I looked forward, at long last, to using my high school, indeed, my college, French. And although it had been many years since I struggled through The Hunchback of Notre Dame and The Red and the Black, had I not loved the language and did I not love it still? There would be no trouble at all.

title: The Portent of Pisa
description: Two items of cheer for the new year: The leaning tower of Pisa did not lean any farther in 1977, and Venice has apparently stopped sinking. Pisa's perilously inclined bell tower will not crash to the grounda collapse the world has been waiting for since the thirteenth centuryand Venice will not disappear beneath the sea. At least not in 1978. Rejoice at a micrometer less movement toward disaster, a miraculous escape from a watery death.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Leopold Stokowski once put it simply but profoundly, in the oracular tone that his rhetoric assumed whenever he addressed himself to the public on great matters: Music is voice. What is it saying? In those few syllables the late conductor does more to explain the roots and reasons of music than many authors of music appreciation books have accomplished in thousands of words. For music begins and ends with the human voice, though there may. be a great deal of unvocal or even antivocal activity along the way. This is one of those usually unspoken assumptions that musicians accept but that young people beginning the study of music sometimes are allowed to overlook. Trust this: Any music book for children or adults  that does not start by emphasizing the preeminence of the voice is to be viewed with suspicion.

title: Mrs. Moser Downhill Victor Again
description: PFRONTEN, West Germany, Jan. 7 (AP)Annemarie ProellMoser of Austria won her second World Cup downhill ski race in two days today, once again defeating her American rival, Cindy Nelson, and. took a commanding lead in her quest for a sixth sixth World Cup title.

title: Amex: New Chief, New Indictments
description: A signal to the world that the Amex and the city both mean business. With those words, Mayor Edward I. Koch opened 1978's first day of trading on the American Stock Exchange last week. pounding a golden gong with a rawhide mallet. By his side was Arthur Levitt Jr., also celebrating his first day in office, as Amex chairman. The crowd on the trading floor cheered, but a question hovered in the background: Will New York be able to keep the Amex in the city?

title: Investors Try, Try Again
description: Astockbroker summed up his recent experience, which reflects that of many investors: I made money with my Steuben crystal, Haitian paintings and general Americana. I fought hard to keep even with my stocks and bonds. There was signal success for those who bought gold, stamps, orangejuice futures and for those in real estate, including homeowners.

title: Vance Sees Irish Minister
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 7 (AP) Secretary of State Vance conferred with Foreign Minister Michael O'Kennedy of Ireland at Shannon Airport today during a stop on his way from Budapest to the United States. In a 90minute discussion, the two men discussed Northern Ireland, the Middle East, southern Africa and EastWest relations.

title: Graham, U.C.L.A., to Face Van't Hoff in Net Final
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) Topseeded Tony Graham of the University of California, Los Angeles, won two matchei today and gained a spot in tomorrow's singles final of the National Collegiate tennis tournament at the Mission Hills Country Club.

title: Israeli Cabinet Reported Split
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 7 (UPI)The Israeli raaio reported today a sharp rift in the Cabinet of Prime Minister Menshem Begin over proposals for a crash program to establish four new settlements and 20 outposts south of the Gaza Strip within days.

title: Brendan Gill, Here in Westchester
description: BRONXVILLE BRENDAN GILL, the urbane drama critic for The New Yorker, is almost as hard to catch up with as the White Rabbit in Alice in Wonderlandhe's usually late for one or another important engagement.

title: New Jersey
description: New Jersey, which has been lagging behind its neighboring states, is expected to bounce back more rapidly this yearwith a little help from Atlantic City. State economists expect the Opening of gambling casinos to stimulate housing, highway and business construction as the state prepares for a new influx of tourists. A study indicates that $900 million will be spent on casino construction by 1987, according to Adam Broner, executive director of the New Jersey Office of Economic Policy.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: It was hard to tell which end of the dollar was up  or down  last week. The currency markets were in turmoil as traders tried to assess the impact of a joint Federal Reserve BoardTreasury declaration that a major rescue operation was being mounted for the dollar.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt is still early in the game, but Eleanor Holmes Norton, the new chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, thinks she has found a way to dissipate its chronic backlog of 130,000 cases in two or three years.

title: FOOD
description: THE Encyclopedia of Fish Cookery, written by A.J. McClane and with photographs by Arie de Zanger (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $35), was sixyear project that had its beginnings about 50 years ago. That was when Al McClane, now editoratlarge (and formerly fishing editor) of Field and Stream, first dropped some bait into the water. The event is described in the book:

title: McArdle Replaces Low as Chief Aide For Environment
description: Mayor Koch replaced another top Beame administration official yesterday, naming Francis X. McArdle, an official of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, to succeed Robert A. Low as Commissioner of Environmental Protection.

title: Suit Puts Consumers In the Driver's Seat
description: ALMOST 1,400 Connecticut residents will soon be getting letters from Attorney General Carl R. Ajello telling them how to take advantage of their share of $40 million.

title: West
description: When Philip Morris Inc.'s Miller Brewing Company started construction of a brewery near here recently, there was an incongruous witness present. With a squad of press agents nearby, Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr. was officiating at his first aroundbreakine ceremony.

title: ConneCticut to Let Studetzts, 16, Quit High School Early
description: Connecticut high school students as young as 16 years old will be able to quit school and, by passing two examinations, still earn an equivalency diploma under a program approved by the State Board of Education.

title: A Constitutional Question
description: IONC E saw a political cartoon from the days of Andrew Jackson's struggle with the Bank Of the United States. The Bank is personified by Squire Biddle, rocking on his own front porch. Much later, General Motors ran a series of advertisements setting forth the inner soliloquies of a man who had been born in the year that saw the origin of that great corporation, and who, in the ads, would stand in front of car dealers' windows musing on all that had happened to the two of them in the years in which he and General Motors were growing up, sort of together.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON Amfleet Outshining Erratic Metroliners
description: FIGURES just released by Amtrak show an ontime record of only 27 percent for the extrafare Metroliners running every hour between New York and Washington.

title: Modest Proposals For the Board Of Legislators
description: THE Westchester County Board of Legislators will convene tomorrow for its 19781979 legislative session. These 17 elected officials will have a great opportunity to adopt amendments to the rules of the Board that will greatly improve its abil ity to meet the problems facing Westchester and the public's ability to evaluate the performance of each legislator.

title: A Tour of New Designs and Old Treasures in Israel
description: What is the special magnet that attracts people of all races and creeds to this ancient land? Despite the occasional hazards, the flow of curious, eager and interested visitors continues to increase at a rapid rate. I feel that basically it is an interest in the architecturebut not the literal definition of the word.

title: Events Today
description: Brooklyn Botanic Garden: films on plants, 1 and 3 P.M.; tours of the garden and poinsettia display, 2 P.M.; 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: The Island's Raccoon Population Is Rising And So Is the Damage
description: The sound of garbage cans falling to the ground in the night, the pitterpatter of little feet across your attic floor and the smoke that fills your living room when you try to use the fireplace could all, be signs that you have raccoons on the premises.

title: Home Style
description: A new year. One sure to bring questions and problems to tenants new to apartment life. And new questions and problems for those used to renting. Block and neighborhood associations, senior citizen centers and other local groups can frequently help tenants with specialized problems in their neighborhoods. But here are larger agencies one can turn to for answers.

title: Children's Books Depicting Blacks, While Rising, Are Still Only 1 in
description: The percentage of children's trade books depicting black characters has doubled in the last decade, but such books still constitute only about one out of every seven published, according to study conducted at the Graduate School of Education of Harvard University.

title: Best Sellers.
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1.400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Courses for Elderly Are Thriving
description: EDUCATION for the elderly_ has arrived. After a growth in the firsehalf of the 1970's that saw the the number of colleges and universities offering courses for retirementaged students multiply 25 times, roughly a fifth of the 3.300 institutions in the nation now do so. Of these, a majority are twoyear community or junior colleges, but statesupported and private colleges and universities are following the lead. In addition, countless noncollege organizations are starting programs, and most adulteducation or continuingeducation programs have provisions, such as the gold pass, that provide special privileges for the elderly..

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: BUBBLES, by Beverly Sills. (Warner, $2.50.) Bubbles Silverman, the Jewish girl from Brookyn who made it big on the opera stages of the world, but who has had her share of personal tragedy, tells her life story in characteristically candid, unpretentious style. A best seller in hardcover.

title: After a Year, Griffin Bell Has Satisfied Some Skeptics
description: WASHINGTONNone of President Carter's Cabinetlevel appointees had a harder time winning Senate confirmation than Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, and except for Bert Lance, none has generated more controversy office. Mr. Bell is still going through a rough period onthejob training. 'This has been some year for me, he says. Somebody ought to write a primer on how be an Attorney General. I never did find one.

title: Women's Basketball: It's Improving With Age
description: In 1899 they wore. pantaloons and the nine players on each side of women's basketball teams were forced to root themselves in areas of the court from which they could either pass or shoot.

title: HOMEMAKERS ON L.I. LEARN OLD CRAFTS
description: Nearly 100 housewives worked busily m the big, cheerful meeting hall of the 5yosset Coinniunity Church on a recent Wednesday morning as. the Syosset Day Chapter of the Nassau County Homemakers Council held its weekly classes in handicrafts and culinary arts.

title: Freestyle Skiing Takes Turn for Safety
description: Remember wham publications across the land carried photographs of skylarking skiers doing somersaults at American ski areas?

title: NEW FACES OF 1978
description: Will ailing American Motors finally drop its passenger car business this year? All Detroit awaits the answer as Gerald C. Meyers, 49, settles in as the unabashedly ambitious chief of the smallcar specialist. TheJeeri ap pear the company's best hope for survival.

title: Pros Aim at Maintaining Quality of Dog Handlers
description: Rthisiders have been admiring the knowledge and skill of Ted Young Jr. for more than 25'years. So dog owners have the most to gain when the slim, softspoken pro takes time out frofn a heavy schedule to say: Running around. the ring and getting the blue ribbon is a very small part of being a protessional handler.

title: CAVALCAE
description: In New York City, the lights went out one night in July as Consolidated Edison lost power for 25 hours. The city stayed afloat on choppy fiscal seas, and the Concorde finally landed after noisy debate. Nationally, these were some of the biggest developments:

title: A Critic of Schools Starts One Herself
description: OAKLAND, CALIF. FOR a dozen years I've made my living as a critic of schools. In 1976 circumstances backed my husband, who has also put in his time as an educational critic, and I into a less detached role. Our elder son, David, then 5, had just finished a year in a private kindergarten program near our home here, and we were faced with finding a school. The neighborhood public school and the private schools left something to be desired.

title: Amateur Smuggler
description: DWIGHT WORKER, a young American, comes clean in the first sentence of this cautionary tale, written in collaboration with his wife. went to Peru to smuggle cocaine in November 1973, he says.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today Middle Island, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle Island, L.i. Special working hunters, special jumpers, Equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: French Reds to Focus Campaign Against Socialists in March Vote
description: PARIS, Jan. 7The French Communists, opening their national conference today, spelled out their strategy for the legislative elections in Marchto run hard against their Socialist former allies in the first round and leave the door open for a possible coalition in the second round a week later.

title: Eiffel Tower Evacuated in Fire
description: PARIS, Jan. 7 (Reaters) Tourists were evacuated from the second level of the Eiffel Tower when fire broke out today in a control panel. No one was injured.

title: Widows World: No Time to Cry
description: THE quickest way to end a widow's tears, a quartet of Garden State business leaders asserts, is for her to sit down at her husband's desk and get to work.

title: Anne Carhart Plans Bridal in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. George M. Carhart of East Northport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne. McDonnell Carhart, to Jesse Carl Downing 3d, son of Dora Downing of Washington, and the late Mr.,Downing Jr. The wedding is planned for September. miss Carhart is a student at Marymount College of Virginia. Her father is a vice president and director of personnel at B. Altman & Company in New York.

title: A Dose of Hot Medicine in Colorado
description: In Eagle, Alaska, one does not speak of winter until the mercury shrinks below zero. Should it drop to merely 30 below, YOU talk about the mild winter.

title: Ruth Doig Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Ruth Doig to James Thomas Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Murphy of the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew T. Doig of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September.

title: Winding Up The Nation's Economic Mainspring
description: Capital spending by business is the key stable longterm growth in the capitalist economy. Private investment is thus the height of public virtue, creating wealth, while consumption wastes it. Government largely neutral in this process, although government too can destroy wealth by excessive regulation, as many people say it often does in the United States.

title: Prophetic Bombs
description: Spain is changing now. Franco is dead, and his system is being dismantled. The Spain of Francoist legend  holy Spain, crusading Spain, solitary, grandiose Spain  is fading. The pentup hunger for serious investigation of the Civil War may finally be satisfied. The Francoist version satisfied only his followers, and deepened the national uneasiness. All this lends significance to the publication of Herbert Southworth's exacting, detailed account of the very symbol of those atrocities, the bombing of Guernica, on April 26, 1937.

title: The Shrinking Computer Cozies Up to the Customer
description: Minicomputers are just about the fastestgrowing industry in the world today. They were first marketed in 1965. Last year shipments worth more than $2.5 billion went to customers, who couldn't seem net them fast enough.

title: TV VIEW
description: The National Geographic Society has never been totally compatible with television. Too often, the Society has found itself dangling between the demands of solid substance and what the trade calls entertainment values. During its final years on commercial television, the longlived series of Na tional Geographic specials seemed mired in silly entertainment concepts, usually taking the form of some physically demanding quest or expedition. Applecheeked youths were seen sailing strange craft across deserts or climbing steep and supposedly dangerous mountains (skeptical viewers had to wonder how, if the task was indeed so dangerous, the cameraman frequently managed to get to the intended goal first to record the thrilling final moments). All of this adventure footage was then overlayed with embarrassingly inflated narration and a soaring musical track that always seemed to be signalling nothing less than a parting of the Red Sea.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND The Door to Bedlam
description: WE ARE getting back into routine and there is even chance that the beds will be made. For these several weeks just past when holidaying was in order. the house got a little out of hand.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The American Numismatic Society, one of the largest coin museums in the world, has acquired its first example of the rare United States 1804 dollar from the Chase Manhattan Bank Money Collection through a special loan/gift arrangement.

title: Author's Query
description: For biography of Margaret C. Anderson, founding editor of the Little Review, I would like letters by and about her.

title: Marketing's Stars: Beer and Cigarettes
description: In the recordbreaking number of new products that poured into the marketplace last year two categories had the greatest impactlight beer and light (that is. lowtarl ciearettes. There were also numerous new products for consumers increasingly aware of health needs; coffee extenders, spurred by high coffee prices, and fish products fried in batters, inspired by the success of the Arthur Treacher fastfood chain.

title: The Nation.
description: A Boston jury found last week that tribal consciousness is only a sometime thing  at least in legal terms for the Wampanoag of Mashpee, Mass. Consequently, the future of the Indian claim to 11,000 acres, almost all the undeveloped land in the booming Cape Cod resort town, is now very much in doubt.

title: Purcell Installed in Nassau
description: Francis T. Purcell was sworn in on Friday as Nassau's fifth County Executive at ceremonies in the State Supreme Court Building in Mineola, L.I., attended by 500 oeonie. Mr. Purcell, formerly the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, was elected last November after a bitter fight within the county's Republican Party. He succeeded Ralph G. Caso of Merrick, also a Republican.

title: Wanted: A Coherent Economic Policy
description: By his replacement of Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and his nomination of James T. McIntyre Jr. as budget chief, President Carter has shown his determination to run things his way. But a coherent economic policy has yet to emerge from the White House.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY Tombstone Artisans: A Family Affair
description: IT all began for Ralph Ardolino on that Sunday in 1928 when his father decided to take the steamship Mary Patton from the Battery in Lower Manhattan to Long Branch.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Seeks New Members To Fight Blacks Recent Setbacks
description: In his first major move to revitalize the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the organization's new head told a conference of local chapter officials yesterday to bring in two million new members to help fight recent setbacks for black people.

title: The Housing Quandary of Workers With the Corporate MoveOuts
description: Five years ago when her job with the Continental Oil Company was transferred from Rockefeller Center to the new corporate headquarters in an office park outside of Stamford, Mrs. Bogert was already thinking of leaving her Jackson Heights neighborhood where she didn't feel safe anymore.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayAmerican Spaniel Club's 61st specialty show continues in Holiday Inn Jetport, Routes 1 and 9, Elizabeth, N.J.; 723 dogs; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: North Wins, Off Field Counts More
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 7The least important part of the Senior Bowl game today was the score, the North defeating the South, 17;14.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 7 (AP)Three tons of nitroglycerin blew up today in a small building at a dynamite factory, killing two men and injuring 37, officials said.

title: RothWinsP.B.A.Opener Defeats Taylor, 222192
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP)Mark Roth defeated Leo Taylor, 222192, in today's final game of the first stop on the winter tour of the Professional Bowlers Association.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: A Minnesota Super Bowl
description: To the Sports Editor: After every National Football League season, the nation's press reports that the Minnesota Vikings are going south and melting in Dallas, New Orleans, Miami or Los Angeles.

title: Martin H. Weisburd, Microbiologist With New York Health Department
description: Martin Harold Weisburd, a research microbiologist with the New York City Department of Health for the last 11 years, died Thursday of an apparent heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 38 years old.

title: Their Last Road Together
description: FAR HILLS, N.J., Jan. 7 (AP)Bob Hope and the late Bing Crosby were named today as recipients of the 1978 Bob Jones Award for distinguished sportsmanship in golf. The awards will be presented Jan. 28 in San Francisco after the 84th annual meeting of the United States Golf Association.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The picture of a highrise apartment building overshadowing a twostory house that illustrated the article New Push for Apartments in Suburbs: How Many, When? [Dec. 18] tends to oversimplify an extremely sensitive issue.

title: $4.40 Great Above Takes Paumonok. at. Aqueduct
description: Eddie Maple made a oneday round trip from Florida pay off yesterday by guiding Sigmund Sommer's favored Great Above to victory in the 69th running of the Paumonok Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Talmudic Temptations
description: Chaim Grade is a major author in what has tragically become a minor language, Yiddish. In just one generation, its practitioners were decimated by the Nazi Holocaust, the cultural deprivations of the Soviets and the unyielding pressures of assimilation wherever Eastern European Jews have settled. As a secular art form, Yiddish literature has had a rich but brief life. Its three pioneering geniuses  Mendele Mocher Sforim, Sholom Aleichem, and Isaac Leib Peretz  were still writing well into this century; now only a handful of Yiddish authors survive.

title: 198th Legislature Convenes Tuesday
description: THE first session of the 198th New Jersey Legislature will begin at noon Tuesday. Very little pomp and circumstance are expected.

title: The World
description: The Communist monolith theory is under heavy fire in Southeast Asialiterally. Skirmishes between Cambodia and Vietnam have grown. into fullscale battles, with Vietnam, charging Cambodian aggression, occupying as much as 400 square miles of Cambodian territory. Reports based on American monitoring of battlefield radio signals said last week that thousands of soldiers and civilians had been killed or wounded. Cambodia broke relations with Hanoi on New Year's Eve.

title: Aquarium Occupants To Move Temporarily
description: BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP)About 280 sea creatures will be removed from the giant ocean tank at the New England Aquarium because of a crack in one of the viewing windows.

title: Headliners
description: For months, the couple had been leading items in tne gossip columns, but there is also potential political significance in the divorce settlement reached last week by George and Cornelia Wallace. The Alabama Governor plans to run for the United States Senate this year, and in his conservative state a divorce still draws many frowns. I'm not concerned about that, he said, insisting that his main worry is intrusions into his personal life. The Wallaces were married for seven years. Under the settlement, reached just before the case was to go to trial, Mrs. Wallace will receive a lump sum of $75,000 in alimony, a piece of lakefront property and household goods.

title: V.A. to Train Doctors in Geriatrics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)With 13.3 million veterans of World War II in or nearing their 60's, the Veterans Administration today announced a new program to train doctors in caring for those veterans special medical problems.

title: Emile Pollak, 63, Defense Lawyer For Nazi Collaborators in France
description: MARSEILLE, France, Jan. 7 (AP)Emile Pollak, one of France's bestknown trial lawyers, died here last night of lung cancer. He was 63 years old.

title: JOHN W. BRUMBAUGH,
description: John W. Brumbaugh, a patent attorney in New York City for more than 30 years died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, while skiing near his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENING novices who received holiday gifts of exotic plants may be feeling a bit overwhelmed with the responsibility of taking care of a fine Norfolk Island pine or a Christmas cactus that is already beginning to drop its blossoms. In fact. a few may even feel panicky.

title: Southwest
description: In 1962 the Texas Industrial Commission set as its goal the creation of 802,250 in 15 years. At the end 1977 the goal had been met 111 percent. That's an example of how the the Texas economy gallops along, accumulating blue ribbons and outclassing the nation in economic vitality.

title: Nigeria Seeks New Curb on Rhodesia South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 7 Nigeria is initiating a new African move for tougher Security Council action against the whiteminority Governments of Rhodesia and South Africa.

title: South Korea Floating Idea of Meeting With Carter
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7In the wake of the decision to turn over Tongsun Park to United States authorities, South Korean officials are carefully floating the idea of a possible meeting between President Carter and Park Chung Hee, the South Korean President.

title: The Region
description: Austerity Is the continuing fotecast for New York City but things apparently are looking up for the state. In a reversal of three years of retrenchment, Governor Carey in a State of the State message before a new session of the legislature last week offered a politically pleasing $750 million cut in taxes, larger than had been expected.

title: Stimulative Tax. Cut Endangers Budget Goal
description: WASHINGTON The pressures of fullemployment politics have forced President Carter to shelve, probably until a second term (if he seeks and wins one) his ambitious plans for broadscale tax reform in favor of a $25 billion tax cut, a package that reflects both in size and emphasis the probusiness priorities of Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal.

title: Teaching Children to Deal With Conflict
description: STAMFORD; CONN. ON a recent afternoon at Northeast Elementary School, Heather Giancola departed from the customary routines and selected four children in her thirdgrade class to act out a puppet show based on a story they had been reading.

title: Can We Have Our Energy And Burn It Too?
description: In all the debate over energy policy, one fact has gone largely unnoticed: The United States quietly learned to conserve energy during 1977 by using it a bit more efficiently than it had the year before. In fact, 1977 was the seventh consecutive year for such an improvement.

title: Sarasin Enters Connecticut Gubernatorial Race
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 7  United States Representative Ronald A. Sarasin, the favorite Of the Republican party hierarchy in Connecticut to oppose Gov. Ella T. Grasso in November, formally joined the race for the gubernatorial nomination today and vowed to hold the line on taxes.

title: Growing Up on Skates
description: NORWALK ALMOST before he could walk, Craig Duddy, who is now 7 years old, knew how to skate. It's hardly surprising. Craig is the grandson of Leo Skidd, owner of Crystal Ice Rink in Norwalk.

title: GEORGE BURNS, 84; EXFIRST BASEMAN
description: KIRKLAND, Wash., Jan. 7 (AP)George Henry Burns, a former major league first baseman who got the first hit in Yankee Stadium in 1923 and was the American League's most valuable player in 1926, died today in the intensivecare unit of Evergreen Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Cardinals Are on Verge of a Breakup
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, one of the finest teams in the National Football League until overcome by injuries and dissension last season, may be breaking up. The explosion is expected to be touched off this week with the departure of Don Coryell, the most successful coach in t'he franchise's 57year history:

title: Around the Nation
description: ROCKPORT, Ind., Jan. 7 (AP)  Four hundred to 500 striking coal miners stormed a nonunion loading dock on the Ohio River tonight, firing guns and se:ting off dynamite that ignited some fireti, the Indiana state police reported.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Seventyfive years ago, Joseph Conrad published his novel Heart of Darkness, which described the journey and selfdiscovery of a Belgian in the Congo, and had much to say about European civilization. Arthur Reel, artistic director of Drama Committee Repertory, has determined that, despite the novel's complexity, ought to be staged, since its theme is relevant for us today. His adaptation, the first such attempt, is currently playing at the Drama Committee's 20th Street theater, through this month, with alternating casts. (See Theater)

title: Regulations Issued By H.E.W. to Help The Handicapped
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has issued regulations to bar Federal funds to anyone who discriminates against the handicapped.

title: Athlete Quits Working Hard and Discovers Fun
description: When I was a child, I thought as a child, played as a child. But when I grew up, I gave up childish things. and beCame an athlete.

title: Terry Humphries Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James L. Humphries of Rome, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terry Evelyn Humphries, to Porter Nelson Siems, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard. A. Siems of Baltimore. A June wedding is planned.

title: Beauty
description: Rites of the body have traditionally been a California thing, and many of the country's eating and keepingfit fads have been born in Los Angeles and its environs.

title: Memphis Becomes A Weekend Mecca For Presley Fans
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 7 (AP) Souvenirs by the ton, 30 hours of uninterrupted Elvis Presley movies and a trip to his grave turned Memphis into a Mecca for fans of the singer this weekend.

title: HENRY ClIAFETZ, 61; WRITER AND EDITOR
description: Henry Chafetz, a writer, editor, publisher and antiquarian book dealer, died Thursday night of cancer at New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 525 East 86th Street.

title: INTERVIEW
description: YONKERS THE poster in the Rev. Joseph Martin's seminary office depicts a priest and reads God Knows What He Does for a Living. As if in reply, a stack of records stands by the door: The Father Martin Songbook and Peace, Love and Joy.

title: Music in Review
description: Piotr Paleczny, a Polish pianist who appeared in New York last season as soloist with the Polish Radio National Symphony Orchestra, gave his first New York recital Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY Saturday Night QuestA Table for Two
description: AS a regular reader of Westchester Weekly, I have enjoyed Guy Henle's Dining Out column, followed with pleasure his peregrinations through garlicky pt, tough and tender scaloppine, and powdery zabaglione, and worried along as he decried an occasional wine list or suffered a fatty duck a l'orange. But what amazes me most about these culinary adventures is the apparent ease with which he gets into the places he writes about.

title: New York State's Banking Overseer
description: She has been in charge of the most important state banking department in the country for only six months. It is still early in the game and she faces the test of her first legislative session, but Muriel F. Siebert has been getting high marks in office.

title: Homemakers Who Learn and Teach
description: NEARLY 100 housewives worked busily in the big, cheerful meeting hall of the Syosset Community Church on a recent Wednesday morning as the Syosset Day Chapter of the Nassau County Homemakers Council held its weekly classes in handicrafts and culinary arts.

title: Midwest Rail Merger Intentions
description: The bankruptcy petition filed by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad put the question of the future of the Middle West's railroads at the top of the agenda last week.

title: For Children, the Sound of Art
description: AT the Saturday morning Junior Museum Break at the Princeton University Art Museum, 4 and 5yearolds sit spellbound before the works of Italian masters like Salvator Rosa or Francesco Botticini.

title: A Super Week for New Orlwans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 7The principals, the 86 athletes from Dallas and Denver, arrive here in the Crescent City late on Monday and that will signal the start of Super Bowl week, six days of assorted bedlam leading to the game next Sunday in the 71,000seat Superdome.

title: AN EXILE IN HIS OWN CITY
description: On this day, of all days, John Lindsay has a right to be gloomy. Outside his office window, the rain, swept by vicious winds, has left Rockefeller Center deserted.

title: Samoa: Visited and Reported
description: IN 1925 Margaret Mead said goodbye to her husband and family in the railroad station in Philadelphia. She was starting for Samoa, to investigate to what extent the turmoil associated with adolescence in her own society was biologically, and to what extent culturally, determined. She was 23 years old and weighed 98 pounds; she had never been aboard a ship, spoken a foreign language, or stayed in a hotel by herself. She took with her a picture of her teacher at Columbia University, Franz Boas.

title: POLITICS Apposites And Opposites In Hartford
description: HARTFORD IF Schopenhauer were alive and well and in Connecticut today he would say that Hartford's Democrats, more than most men, have .the proclivities of porcupines. Their gregarious tendency drives them together and their quills drive them apart again.

title: Pendulum Politics In New Rochelle
description: IT is hardly news when political control of a Westchester city changes from Republican to Democratic, or even the reverse. But when the pen dulum swings back and forth three times in six years, well, that's New Rochelle.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said the United States would endorse a limitedchoice referendum for Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip to help them determine their political future. The referendum would not include the choice of an independent Palestinian state, Mr. Carter said, but the Palestinians could vote on whether they would align themselves with Jordan or proceed with a plan for international administration of the two regions, occupied by Israel since 1967. The President suggested that the referendum proposal would bring broader Arab participation in the EgyptianIsraeli negotiations. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: 4 LongTerm Congressmen Say They Will Not Seek ReElection
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)  Four veteran Congressmen announced this week that they would not seek reelection.

title: Combating Delinquency
description: APROFESSOR at the University of Stockholm returned from a crosscountry trip through the United States. Asked by an American friend what had impressed him the most, the professor replied, Sod.

title: Boat Industry Is Keeping a Wary Eye on Energy
description: While marine industry leaders appear confident that 1978 will emerge as fine year, all is not exactly smooth sailing. The industry still is wrestling with the aftereffects of the energy crisis. Inflation is pushing the prices of boats to new heights. And some feel that boating needs a boost to capture a better share of the booming recreational market.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: FOR readers of a certain age  I have in mind those who, like myself, first came to modern poetry (and to the criticism written to defend and elucidate it) in the years just after the Second World War  the publication of Allen Tate's Collected Poems 19191976 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) is an event that stirs a good many memories and associations. Scarcely 20 years had passed since the appearance of his first books in 1928  the year of both Mr. Pope and Other Poems and Stonewall Jackson: The Good Soldier yet in those first years after the war Mr. Tate already seemed a venerable survivor of several lost worlds. The Nashville of the Fugitives, the New York of the young Malcolm Cowley and Kenneth Burke and E.E. Cummings, like the Paris of Gertrude Stein and Ford Madox Ford, had receded into the mists of literary legend. As with so much else in those days, the war seemed to have slammed the door shut on what had preceded it. The aspirations and achievements, the lived literary experience of the 20's and the 30's, were suddenly (or so it seemed) transmuted into subjects for the college curriculum. Writers who had read The Waste Land and Ulysses and The Cantos on their first publication now reemerged as academic curators of an esteemed but still disputed literary tradition.

title: It's Now Safe for Young Adults and Governments
description: Scott MacNell

title: Television That Invites A Response
description: STAMFORD, CONN. WHO says televisionviewing has to be a passive experience? Not long ago, a small group of preschoolers sat crosslegged on the floor in front a closedcircuit television set at the Early Learning Center here. Suddenly the screen came alive with the image of a medieval knight who looked as if he got dressed the kitchen. He wore a colander as a helmet and carried a lid from a garbage can for his shield. The camera focused on the figure of a little prince, also costumed by a hardware store, who sat, weeping profusely, over his throne.

title: Alicia Rockefeller Fiancee of Mark Dayton
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alida Davison Rockefeller. to Mark Brandt Dayton, son of Bruce B. Dayton of Minneapolis and Mrs. Lee MacPhail of New York.

title: AIRLIFT TO ETHIOPIA SEEN AS SOVIET TEST
description: The Soviet airlift of arms to Ethiopia appears to have been part of a large exercise designed to test the Soviet Air Force's ability to move supplies and troops to northeast Africa and the Middle East, according to United States and Atlantic alliance analysts.

title: St. John's Defeated By Georgetown, 7261
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)John Duren scored a careerhigh of 27 points to lead 15thranked. Georgetown to its eighth straight victory tonight with 7261 decision over St. John's.

title: A $750 Million First Shot in Albany's Legislative Battles
description: Governor Carey learned his first lesson about state budgets the hard way. As a Brooklyn Congressman challenging Republican incumbent Governor Malcolm Wilson 1974, Mr. Carey repeatedly charged that Mr. Wilson was hiding a fat surplus he said ought to be spent for the people.

title: GARDENING
description: NOW that the leaves are off the trees, the outlines of their branches can be seen. They make fascinating sculptures against the sky. Many handsome tree outlines can be seen easily along the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, which becomes the Hutchinson River Parkway as it threads its way through Westchester County.

title: Food for Thought at Super Bowl: Just How Much Can 75,000 People Eat?
description: Buy me some peanuts and cracker jacks. I don't care if I never come back.

title: Author's Query
description: A critical edition of Tess of the D'Urbervilles by Thomas Hardy is in preparation for The Clarendon Press. The editor would be very glad to hear from anyone who knows of the location of the holograph manuscript of the Explanatory Note to the first edition of Tess.

title: Political Shifts Leave Arts Budgets Unsettled
description: WITH political control shifting in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the Island's cultural institutions face the new year with uncertainty. Uninsulated against changing political fortunes, yet dependent upon politicians for financial support, leaders local museums, libraries, professional and community orchestras, theaters and dance groups are somewhat apprehensive as a new administrator takes over the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development (and its $600,000 budget), and the now Republicancontrolled Suffolk Legislature sets about filling an unpublicized position of arts coordinator, ironically created by last year's Democratic majority.

title: BRIDGE
description: Alook back at the year 1977 suggests that the United States now dominates the international bridge scene. After two decades of playing second fiddle to Italy at world championship level, the Bermuda Bowl final in Manila turned into an allAmerican battle. Two Los Angeles players, Bill Eisenberg and Paul Soloway, retained the title they had won against Italy the previous year in Monte Carlo; and two Dallas experts, Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman, added the Bermuda Bowl title to the world pair title they already owned. The Italians were on the sidelines since the Swedes beat them easily in the European Championship.

title: Bowie and Charlie
description: Bowie Kuhn, the tallest and most impeccably tailored commissioner baseball ever had, has postponed until Jan. 17 a hearing on the sale of Vida Blue by the Oakland A's. There have been hints that he might be disposed to approVe the transaction if the terms were altered so the Cincinnati Reds gave Charlie Finley less cash than the $1.75 million they agreed to pay him, and made up the difference with players more valuable than.

title: Kenneth Crawford Towe, ExHead Of American Cyanamid, Was 84
description: Kenneth Crawford Towe, former chairman and president of the American Cyartamid Company, died Friday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 84 years old and had lived in Greenwich for 40 years.

title: Islanders Stop Barons On 4 Goals in 2d Period
description: Islanders Stop Barons On 4 Goals in 2d Period

title: U.S. Officials Cool to Idea
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Administration officials said that while no proposal had been received from. the South Korean Government about a meeting between President Carter and President Park, was unlikely that Mr. Carter would welcome such an encounter.

title: Letters: Winter Magic In Yellowstone Park
description: To the Editor: The recent spate of stories dealing with the glory of winter in such diverse places as Italy's Positano, Lapland, Montauk and Yosemite (The High Sierra Without Traffic, Travel Section, Dec. 18) prompts me to reveal my secret wintry ShangriLaYellowstone National Park.

title: Connoisseur of the Sensual
description: IT is far more difficult to make a work of art from a beautiful subject than from an ugly or mundane one  at least it seems to have been so for the visual artists of this century. Photographers in particular grasped this lesson early, for since Paul Strand trained his lens on a blind beggar woman in 1916, the tragic, the objectionable and the banal have become the special purview of the camera. Only artists like Lewis Hine, Walker Evans and Diane Arbus, who recorded precisely these kinds of subjects, have been allowed into the pantheon of the present generation photographers who, in emulation of this early work, document with relentless dedication America's raw rural landscape, its highways and gas stations, its suburban shopping centers, its mental hospitals, its drug addicts and its derelicts. Increasingly, the content employed by the photoar.tist overlaps with that of the photojournalist. Today the boundaries between documentary and art photography have all but disappeared. Consequently,. it comes as quite a shock to see pictures that aspire so unabashedly to high art, that are so conspicuously beautiful, as Edward Weston's nudes.

title: Connecticut
description: One day last October Connecticut reported proudly that its rate of unemployment had dropped below 6 percent of the labor force for the first time in three years. For many people in the southeastern part of the state, however, the announcement had the ring of irony. For the day before, the Electric Boat division the General Dynamics Corporation, which is building the Trident submarine at its Groton shipyard, began laying off 3,000 engineers, accountants, draftsmen and others the company said were surplus to its needs.

title: Something of a Folk Hero
description: IN the early pages of Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s classic,The Age of Jackson, one finds this comment on Andrew Jackson's accession to the Presidency: The people called him and he came, like the great folk heroes, to lead them out of captivity and bondage. In the subsequent debate, which Schlesinger provoked, the meaning of both the people and captivity and bondage received a variety of interpretations, but like the great folk heroes on the whole did not.

title: African Tribalism a Bar to Unity
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 7  Some weeks ago, President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia spoke at the wedding of one of his ministers. With words addressed to his nation, he praised the young couple for their progressive intermarriage, which, he said, should set a standard for young Zambians. Both bride and groom were black. Their Marriage was not interracial but intertribal; the bride was a Lozi, her husband, a Bemba.

title: Princeton Tops Harvard; Penn Wins 4th Straight
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 7  The Princeton University basketball team demonstrated that it is still a power to be reckoned with in the Ivy League as it defeated Harvard, 8364, tonight at Jadwin Gym.

title: Fingers Make a Comeback in Math
description: MOUNT VERNON. N.Y. TINY fingers were pounding rhythmically on wooden desk tops. At the blackboard in a firstgrade class at the Holmes School 6yearold Brad Shanks was adding a lengthy column of digits and having no discernible difficulty. He even had an impish grin on his face.

title: GARDENING The Beauty of Nature au Naturel
description: NOW that the leaves are off the trees, the outlines of their branches can be seen. They make fascinating sculptures against the sky. Many handsome tree outlines can be seen easily along the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, which becomes the Hutchinson River Parkway as it threads its way through Westchester County.

title: For One Horse Breeder, Less Is More
description: GOSHEN THEY make wonderful pets. They are gentle and cuddly. They can ride comfortably in the back seat of an averagesized car and can sleep in a doghouse.

title: White Hats Now Cover Gandhi Friends and Foes
description: NEW DELHIPicture a land almost the size of Western Europe, with deserts, snowy mountains higher than the Alps, and tropical fishing villages lined with coconut palms. The range of its people's eating habits is as wide as the difference between a Norwegian breakfast and a Greek dessert, and they speak a dozen basic languages and hundreds of dialects. Though predominantly Hindu, it has nearly as many Moslems as Pakistan, which is one of the world's largest Islarhic states, and more Sikhs than the United States haS Jews. Such a land is India, a country so diverse Unit one of the principal tasks of its rulers, ever since the= Moghul emperors 400 years ago, has been simply holding it all together.

title: MISUSE OF US. FUNDS IS LAID TO COLLEGES
description: A widespread pattern of sloppy bookkeeping and alleged misuse of Federal research funds, involving hundreds of millions of dollars, has been disclosed in a series of audits of colleges and universities around the country by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The article Giving Help to the Gifted [Dec. 11] is welcome in its recognition of a serious problem that has been ignored for too long.

title: After Verdict, Mashpee Hopes for Home Buyers
description: MASHPEE, Mass., Jan. 7This is Happy Day, Selectman George A. Benway Jr. said this morning as he walked into his real estate office in this quiet Cape Cod town of 4,000 people, where real estate development, once the major industry, has been at a standstill since August 1976, when the Mashpee Wampanoag Indians filed suit for all the town's undeveloped land.

title: Midwest
description: The legions of unbridled optimists in the Middle America of Sinclair Lewis's novels a halfcentury ago would be strangers here today. They were the prophets of opportunity unlimited, onward and upward, of bigger and better. Every village could be a metropolis and every nonetter a millionaire. 111eIr areams were as unbounded the prairies they gazed upon.

title: Dur Bet's Basic Black Cocker Spaniel Victor
description: ELIZABETH, NJ., Jan. 7Dur Bet's Basic Black gained the winner's bitch award today in black cocker spaniel competition at the American Spaniel Club's 61st specialty in the Holiday Inn jetport. She represents six generations of Elizabeth H. Durland's 19year breeding program and is owned by Catbi Doar of Dallas.

title: It Goes
description: WASHINGTONHigher education, which often follows the combined influence of fads and the dollar, has now attached itself to energy, a subject which entered the popular lexicon only in the aftermath of the 197374 Arab oil embargo and price increases.

title: IN BRIEF
description: For the nation's auto makers, 1977 was a year of mixed results. Sales were up 6.1 percent but imports rose 38 percent, and in the last two months of the year the Big Four experienced a surprising sales slump, wmcn some analysts feel might hurt in 1978. In the year's last 10day reporting period, General Motors managed a modest 1.9 percent increase over yearearlier figures while Ford's sales were off 0.4 percent. Sales at Chrysler and American Motors fell 32.3 percent and 44.4 percent, respectively.

title: CRIME
description: James McClure is a oneayear man. Each year since 1972, when he came forth with The Steam Pig, one of his novels about Lieut. Tromp Kramer and Sgt. Mickey Zondi has been published. Kramer is a South African cop, and Zondi is his Zulu assistant. From the beginning the series has been characterized by an insight into South African culture: its apartheid, its speech patterns, its people. As detectivestory writing, too, the books have adhered to a high standard. McClure has given us, in effect, a series of exotic procedurals marked by fine writing and careful plotting.

title: House Grooms Itself for Television and Debates Who'll Hold Cameras
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Amused observers used tocall them the Bobbsey Twins: Two elderly Congressmen, dozing side by side every afternoon in a House chamber heavy with stale air and, often, staler words.

title: Farms, Food and Fair Play
description: WASHINGTON Bob Bergland, the first Secretary of Agriculture in modern times to pay direct subsidies to the nation's farmers, found himself being burned effigy by angry Oklahoma wheat farmers last month, while in Georgia farmers formed parades of tractors to dramatize their protest against the squeeze on farm income when President Carter visited his hometown of Plains at Christmas.

title: Big. Credit Demand With Rising Rates
description: Almost with a snap of the fingers, the credit markets old assuranceeven cockiness has disappeared.. Arthur F. Burns, whose wizardry seemed to produce lower interest rates in an expanding economy in 1976, somehow'couldn't make the trick work twice.

title: If You Go
description: to Mexico's Labna Valley, take your umbrella. Although June through September is the official rainy season in the Yucatan, a downpour at any time of year should be no surprise. February, March and April, the driest months, are the best time for a visit.

title: Big Banks Still Await Loan Surge By Business
description: The nation's moneycenter banks, tired watching from the sidelines while the smaller regional banks are scoring with business loans, are eager to get into action this year. We're the lender of last resort, a New York bank economist quipped wryly, alluding to the slow growth of business loans at the big New York and Chicago banks in contrast to the regional institutions.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: James F. Fixx has found salvation. It came to him, not in the flash of a mystical vision, but gradually, during months of pounding his sweaty, aching feet on rural roadways and indoor tracks.

title: Legacy of a Pioneer In the Nassau Police
description: AT 3 P.M. on Christmas Day, 1967, Kay Reilly drove her boyfriend's red sedan onto the entrance ramp of the Meadowbrook Parkway in Baldwin, just a mile from the home her father had bought 40 years before.

title: Plan Ahead for Garden of Delights
description: WITH winter's bluster at our backs, it's time for the parttime Westchester farmer to sit down and plot out this year's vegetable garden. The first step is to draw a diagram of the layoutpreferably northsouth, to gain the full benefit of the sun. But that's just the beginning.

title: ART
description: HUNTINGTON AT 30 years of age, Katherine Lochridge, who was recently named the new director of the Heckscher Museum, is one of the youngest museum leaders in the country. Although she is alive with dynamic ideas for the future of the Huntington museum, she is still respectful of the reputation, prestige and programs established at the institution by Eva Gatling, the retiring director.

title: 2 Colleges Open Their Doors to the Retarded
description: ROCHESTER THE uneven parallel bars are Myra Guntrum's forte. Recently she has mastered a dozen basic gymnastic skills, has learned to swim and has become an excellent bowlershe is even learning to keep score. But what I like best of all, she said, is the college kids I work with and all the new friends I've made.

title: DINING OUT Unpretentious Chinese Fare
description: SOUTH NORWALK FOR more than 20 years, Winston Deng has been cheerfully dishing out ample portions of CantoneseAmerican food in the same small, unpretentious restaurant near the railroad overpass in South Norwalk. The food is as unpretentious as the decor. Of the five great regional cuisines of China, Cantonese is possibly the most delicate. All too often delicate translates into bland, and such for the most Dart is the case at the Good Earth.

title: Amy E. Goodfellow Married
description: Amy Erickson Goodfellow, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Guy F. Goodfellow of Chestertown, Md., was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Kief Plum. mer, son of. the Rev. and Mrs. William M. Plummer of Port Republic, Md.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: I THINK it's good for a critic occasionally to like novel against his will, or even against his principles. It proves that there is still a certain amount of mystery in the form, a human element that remains unanalyzable.

title: In Montclair, StillLifes and Recent Acquisitions
description: THE Montclair Art Museum has become widely known for its astute ability to use its own holdings to its best advantage. It frequently presents exhibitions of its works, which are richly diverse in periods and styles, especially of American art; also, it often constructs a display around some of its possessions: combining them with examples borrowed from other institutions.

title: Impoundment of a Brigantine Aborts Dreams of Voyages of Nostalgia
description: Her name and home port are painted on her stern: Enchantress. Port Jefferson. Less than a month ago she was lying alongside a wharf at the Goat Island Marina in Newport, R.I., like a tired refugee from the 18th century. More than a hundred people had gathered there to see the fouryearold brigantine sold at auction.

title: Tyler Casey Engaged To Joseph M. Arnote
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul Casey of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tyler Casey, to Joseph Martin Arnote, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Martin Arnote of River Vale. N.J.

title: Robert Jerome Canning Marries Rita Harmuth
description: Rita Curley Harmuth, widow of Joseph T. Harmuth Jr., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Jerome Canning. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony in St. Catherine of Siena Roman, Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: Woman in Brooklyn Is Found Murdered In Ransacked Home
description: A 56yearold woman, who had lived alone since her husband died a month ago, was, slashed and stabbed to death late Friday night or early yesterday, apparently by a burglar who had forced open a window of her groundfloor apartment near Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Proposed Labor Center Prompts Controversy in North Carolina
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 7 North Carolina's colleges and universities offer dozens of special short courses and programs for businessmen and farmers who want to become better at their work.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Floyd Rice, a Raiders linebacker, before Oakland played the Denver Broncos for the American Conference championship: After we beat the Broncos, I'm going to get a can of orange pop, turn over and empty it. Slowly.

title: Realty News
description: I. T. T. Domestic Transmission Systems Inc., a subsidiary of I. T. T. World Communications Inc., has leased 28,600 square feet at One Whitehall Street and 12,000 square feet at 630 Third Avenue in recent transactions.

title: Deana Rose Bride Of Eliot Halperir
description: Deana Ellen Rose, a trial lawyer with the Federal Maritime Commission in Washington, was married yesterday to Eliot Jules Halperin, who is of counsel to the San Franciscobased law firm of Graham & James in its Washington office.

title: A New Book For Young Widows
description: FOUR years ago, Rae Lindsay's life was manicured as neatly as the lawns in this Bergen County community. The wife of an advertising executive, the mother of three young children and a fledgling author working on her second book, she had much going for a woman still in her mid30's.

title: CARTER BACKS VOTE BY THE PALESTINIANS BUT HE BARS A STATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7The United States would endorse a limitedchoice referendum for Palestinians living on the West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip on their political future, President Carter said last night. But, he added, the choices would not include an independent Palestinian nation.

title: INTERVIEW A Teaching Senator
description: TIMING is important in politics, as Francis X. Herbert, a newly elected State Senator can attest. Up for reelection to the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders in 1976, which everyone considered a Democratic year, Mr. Herbert was defeated despite an impressive record.

title: Linda Ann DePatie Sets August Bridal
description: The engagement of Linda Ann DePatie to Robert Cottrell Buffum Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clark DePatie of Ridgewood, N. J., and Quonochontaug, R. I., parents of the bridetobe. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Buffum of Weekapaug, R.I., and Englewood, Fla.

title: U.S. PREPARES TO REPLACE PHILADELPHIA PROSECUTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)  The Justice Department tonight confirmed published reports that it was preparing to replace David W.
