Marston, the United States Attorney for Eastern Pennsylvania, a Republican who has successfully prosecuted two of the state's most powerful Democrats recently.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSMargaret Ann(Young), In Cambridge, Mass.January 4. Beloved wife of Dr.James Luther Adams. Devoted mother of M.Eloise Adams, Bethesda, Md., Elaine Miller, Madison, Wisconsin and Barbare Kraig, Oak Park, III. She is survived by 7 grandchildren,,James, Kenneth, Stephen, and Katherine Miller, Robert, Michael and TheodoreKralg. Memorial services Sunday, January 8, at 2:30PM at ArlIng ton St.Church, Arlington & Boylston Sts., Boston. In lieu of flowers make donations In her memory to Hospice of Massachusetts Inc. c/o Jo Dorr, 16

title: Saigon: Traduced and Abandoned
description: FRANK SNEPP drove Nguyen Van Thieu to his getaway plane in the last days of the war in Vietnam.

title: PROBLEMS OF A PROBLEM SOLVER
description: Just a few steps down the hall from President Carter's Oval Office is the study where he likes to read in the stillness of evening or early morning against a musical background of Beethoven or Bartok. It is an ample, rather formal room, furnished in brocades.

title: Courting Business in the Tristate Area
description: The economic doldrums gripping much of New York State appear to be lifting but the prospect is still far from bright. From Buffalo to Beth. page the worry is over jobs. In the Western tier the economy is trying to recover from such blows as the trimming of 40 percent of production at Bethlehem Steel's Lackawanna plant, eliminating 3,500 jobs. On Long Island, a cutback ordered by the Government in the production of F14 jet fighters by the Grumman Corporation could mean the loss of thousands of jobs.

title: Back to Basics Has Its Pitfalls.
description: WASHINGTON IN the last few years, there has been a marked trend back to basics in the schools. Generally, this trend has been wholesome, with added attention being paid to howto subjects, and the oversold innovations of the last 10 to 15 years are receiving careful review.

title: U.S. Group Meets Peking Aide
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 7 (Reuters)  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping held talks in Peking today with a visiting American Congressional delegation led by Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, the Chinese press agency Hsinhua reported.

title: An Old Theater Set's Look Alike
description: Tim Mawson, a young British bookseller, lives in a charming Tudor cottage of the sort commonplace in 18th Century England.

title: New Trio Projects Unanimity
description: The names of Julian Olevsky, violinist, and Paul 01e4ky, cellist, are familiar to many followers of chamber music, and the different spellings of these two cousins names have never caused any great problems. Now, however, theywith the violinist's wife, Estela Kersenbaum Olevsky, pianisthave formed an ensemble and complicated matters by calling it the Olewsky Trio.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: In an apparent landmark deCISIOri to August 1977, Judge Jack B. Weinstein ruled in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that the Central Intelligence.

title: Coal: The Last Chance for the Crow
description: CROW AGENCY, Montana  The history of the American Indian is a tale of Paradise Lost, and that of the Crow tribe is no exception. The former warriors of the Great Plains, who acted as scouts for the United States cavalry while other Indians resisted the white advance, were rewarded in 1851 with 58.8 million acres of rolling grassland in eastern Montana. By 1868 that vast preserve had been reduced to 8 million acres, and by the 20th century it had shrunk to 2.3 million acres, more than threequarters of it now owned or leased by nonIndians..

title: Kathy Kornreich Wed
description: The marriage of Kathy Ann Kornreich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew R. Kornreich of Greenwich, Conn., to Samuel G. Weinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Weinberg of New York, took place yesterday evening. Rabbi Maurice David performed the ceremony at the Plaza. The bride is an insurance executive with the Kornreich Organization, of which her father is president. Mr. Weinberg is executive vice president of Weinreal Properties Inc., a real estate investment and financial services concern. His father is president of that organization.

title: Bricklayers on L.I. Planning to Protest Pay Cut in Contract
description: EAST MEADOW, L.T., Jan. 7  Rebellious bricklayers are planning a protest march and a court fight as a start in their effort to break a new contract that cuts pay and fringe benefits 14.5 percent.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Ethiopia Lifts Curfew
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 6 (UPI) Ethiopia's Marxist Government today lifted the allnight curfew its had imposed in Addis Ababa as a result of continuous violence there. The restrictions were relaxed for the Ethiopian Orthodox celebration of Christmas.

title: The Foreign Invasion Of the U.S Economy
description: PERTH AMBOY, N.J. They aren't making copper here anymore. The oncesprawling Anaconda Company copper smelter that stood for nearly a century is being reduced to a pile of rubble by bulldozers. But the gloom that had beset this depressed industrial town of 38,000 people since Anaconda laid off nearly 1,000 workers and shut down 18 months ago has been slowly lifting. New hope, jobs and money are coming in to turn the tide for Perth Amboy, in the words of officials in the Mayor's office. The bearers good news are foreign investorsin this case from Canada.

title: A Fond Look at the Kewpie Craze
description: WHITE PLAINS FROM the early 1900's to the end of World War II, a strange creature captured and clung to the American imagination. Loosely resembling a fat, naked baby, it had oversize eyes, a pug nose, a nearly bald head crowned with a vertical topknot, and stubby webbed hands. its mouth was fixed in a permanent smile, and tiny wings sprouted from its shoulders.

title: Separate but Equal Is Still a Dream in South Africa
description: SOWETO, SOUTH AFRICA THE symbol of revolution in South Africa is an empty classroom. A year and a half ago, highschool students in this black ghetto marched out of their dusty schoolyards in a protest demonstration against the white authorities that threw the country into turmoil.

title: Hidden Meanings
description: THE first thing to do is to find a hiding place. That is of primary importance, because if the police have told us once, they have told us a dozen times, each time they have come to ask us if we'saw anything unusual on the day the neighbors were burglarized. They have said that the burglaralarm systems were not foolproof, no matter what the cost; that. the dog's barking was not sure protection, that the lights plugged into automatic timers were not enough, that the deadlocks alone would not do. They keep saying: If they want to get in, they will. And they want to. And they do.

title: Laura Hart Fiancee Of R. D. Cole, Actor
description: Laura E. Hart, daughter of Janey Hart of Washington and Mackinac Island, Mich., and the late Senator Philip A. Hart of Michigan, has become engaged to Robert D. Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin B. Cole of Fair Lawn, N. J.

title: 400 Houses Reported Destroyed In Soviet Georgian Earthquake
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (Reuters) A strong earthquake that shook Soviet Georgia this week destroyed 400 houses and dam aged thousands of others, the labor daily Trud reported today.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. end Mrs. George Kimmelman of Fort Lauderdale, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y., are happy to announce the engagement of their daughter Marcia to Melvyn Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Lewis of BaysIde, N.Y.

title: ISABEL E. CALLVERT
description: Isabel E. Callvert. a contribuling editor of Gourmet magazine since 1971, died Friday at Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 136 East 56th Street.

title: Tedd Joselson Made It Without Contests
description: So far, Tedd Joselson has had everything a young pianist could hope for. While in his teens, he struck up a friendship with Arthur Judson, the influential concert promoter, under whose tutelage he prepared a dozen recital programs. By the time he was 20, and still a student of Adele Marcus at Jui'Hard, Mr. Joselson had already given solo and concerto performances across the country. At 21, when he made his Philadelphia Orchestra debut, conductor Eugene Ormandy called Mr. Joselson a rare and exciting talent and advised RCA to offer him a recording contract. In the four years since then, the critics have been so enthusiastic about Mr. Joselson's playing that a few have gone on record saying that he could be the next Horowitz.

title: Alumni Colleges Sprout in Summer
description: MARGARET CONNET, Dr. Willard Weary and Marlene Lassman all graduated from the University of Chicago and went their separate ways. Last June. Mrs. Connet, a childdevelopment consultant in her native Olympia, Wash.; Dr. Weary, now a Dallas surgeon, and Mrs. Lassman, a housewife in Winnetka, Ill., were all back on the campus for their university's third annual Alumni College.

title: Smaller Cars Get Harder to Loue
description: DETROIT It may be the way they look. It may be the price tag. But Detroit's cars aren't selling as robustly as they had been. A growing number of automobile executives and investment analysts are predicting a year of no growth in sales and profits and possibly some slippage. Why? Some cite scaleddown models that cost more. Another reason may be that consumers are turning to other needs.

title: Michigan Tech's Hockey Displas Offensive Look
description: Michigan Tech's offensive, display in the 13th annual Great Lakes invitation Tournament was the highlight of college hockey durine the holidays.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: PARIS  Politically connected, financed through mysterious holding companies that may hide ownership links with members of the royal family, a new wave of Saudi Arabian entrepreneurs has graduated from the dromedary directly to the jet. Decisions are made quickly, worldwide, on the basis of personal trust. The style is smooth, sometimes flamboyant, inevitably surrounded by the aura of great wealth.

title: MidAtlantic
description: Here in one of the major pillproducing areas, where manufacturers make enough uppers, downers and antiacids to change the national psyche, no one has yet compounded a potion for the Middle Atlantic region's industrial dvsnensia in coal and steel. The complaint of the somewhat paunchy manufacturing midsection of the Eastern Seaboard is a common one of old agereduced efficiency and productivity. But at the moment the doctor is out.

title: Getting Acquainted With Japan: Homestay, Study and Travel
description: Now I must explain to you the bath, Kohei Ishizu, my Japanese host, said in careful English at the conclusion of the first evening meal in his home.

title: The Retired Badge of Courage
description: THE major conclusion of a study of 50 retired South Jersey police officers is that the public's respect for law and legal authority has sharply declined. This has caused an increase in crimeespecially violent crimeand in the fear of crime.

title: Nancy Brenner Fiancee Of David Katz, Physician
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morton R. Brenner or White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Brenner, to Dr. David Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Katz of Glencoe, Ill. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Editors Choice
description: AFTERIMAGES, by Arlene Croce. (Knopf, $12.95:) A collection of passionate and informed pieces on the dance by The New Yorker's critic.

title: U. S. and Hungary Planning to Discuss Better Trade Ties
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 7 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance agreed today to open talks aimed at ending American tariff discrimination on imports of Hungarian goods.

title: One of Hollywood's Most Celebrated Lost Scripts
description: LOS ANGELES It was the high point of my professional life, a creative frenzy for nearly 12 wonderful months, said Walter Newman. He was talking about Harrow Alley, his 172page script about the Great Plague in 17thcentury England. I found out I didn't fear death, that I could grin at it. I found out it didn't really matterthis sounds so ordinary as long as you do not have an unlived life every day.

title: ART VIEW
description: The beginning of a new year is as good a time as any in which to catch up on unfinished business, especially if it is the kind of business (as in this case it is) that promises some unfamiliar pleasures. More than two years ago there was published an unusual book of art criticism under the title, The Flow of Art, which consisted of a sizable selection of the essays and reviews of Henry McBride, who died in 1962 at the venerable age of 94. The book, published by Atheneum, was edited, with an introduction, by Daniel Catton Rich, who himself died shortly thereafter, and it also contained an excellent essay about McBride, originally written in 1947, by Lincoln Kirstein. I had intended to write about The Flow of Art at the time of its publication, but circumstances prevented my doing so. Now word has come from M.H. Miltzlaff, McBride's literary executor, that another and perhaps even more important volume of his writingshis lettersmay be in the offing, and this has served as a spur to return to the subject. For Henry McBride was a figure of considerable importance in the modern history of the arts in this country, and too few peopleincluding some who regard themselves as informed on art mattersnowadays even know the name. His is the kind of career that illuminates, and with remarkable good humor, an entire era.

title: Notes: EgyptIsrael Tour Planned
description: Officials of a major supplemental airline and a charter tour operator were optimistic last week they they would secure approval for the first combined package tours to Egypt and Israel. The tours would link the two countries in one travel package for the first time and create the first direct air link between them.

title: Speaking Out For Big Oil
description: John Eldred Swearingen seems to get places earlya master's degree at 20, a director of the Amoco Production Company at 31, president of the parent company, Standard of Indiana, by 39, and chairman and chief executive officer by 42. Now, at 59, this energetic oilman has just become chairman of the American Petroleum Institute, and while his role as chief spokesman for the nation's oil industry is largely symbolic, his new position may nonetheless pose some of the toughest challenges of his professonal life.

title: Cool Intellectual In Hot Dispute
description: WASHINGTON The eye of the energy industry is on James Rodney Schlesinger, sometimes arrogant, occasionally ingratiating and always intellectually imposing.

title: Listerine and Other Methods
description: FOR as long as man has been on this planet, infectious diseases have crippled and killed him, altered his patterns of living, determined the outcome of his wars and influenced his art and religion. The modern story of mankind's struggle to control infectious disease can be exciting and dramatic, and each year it attracts a number of authors.

title: The Middle Class Is (Check One) Better Off, Worse Off Than Before
description: WASHINGTONTalk about the plight of the middle class, long a fixture of dinnerparty conversation, is likely to surface in the halls of government in the early days of 1978.

title: Carter Visit Last Week May Have Made Things Worse
description: PARISGeorge Marchais's speeches about France's centerright Government are predictably full of attacks against the Opponents of the working class. But the Communist leader has lately been applying the same rhetoric to his erstwhile Socialist allies. With less than three months to go before elections that were expected to change the course of postwar French history, the increasingly bitter dispute on the left has whittled away what once looked like an insurmountable lead. Even if the left emerges with a majOrity, there. are serious doubts that the Sobialists.

title: Long Island This Week
description: ALBERTSONWatercolors by Keith Hoffman; through January; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours call CH 87363.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: Deane Carson's denunciation of corporate social responsibility, Companies as Heroes? Bah ! Humbug! (Dec. 25), is sad, shortsighted and as bleak as Russian winter.

title: Tom. Swift And His Econometric Model
description: Here we go with a brainteasing assortment of economic stumpers: How much investment in plant and equipment will the clay and glass industry make this year? What's the story with sales of mediumsized trucks? How about the Treasury bill rate? Farm inventories? What's going to happen to the fourth quarter if the United States goes to war in the second?

title: DIET LINKED TO DROP IN BLOOD PRESSURE
description: High blood pressure in some overweight persons can be dramatically lowered simply by dieting away excess pounds and without taking pills, according to a new study reported by Israeli researchers.

title: Trances Walsh Wed in Jersey To Bank Aide
description: The Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Frances Cornelia Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. nWalsh of New Vernon, to Robert Lincoln Cummings 3d, son of Robert L. Cummings of Laurel Hollow, L. L, and the late Dorcas Oakley Cummings.

title: 654 WERE KILLED IN 1977 IN U.S. AIR CARRIER CRASHES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)The number of American air carrier accidents recorded last year was the lowest in history, but the collision of two jumbo jets in the Canary Islands pushed the total number of fatalities to a record 654. according to the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Mass Transit MerryGoRound
description: LOOKING at the public transportation plight of Connecticut's larger citiesthe current problems and possible solutions we find we are dealing with situations that are common throuehout the country.

title: In a Class With Ibid
description: It is time someone wrote a biography of Anonymous, who has been around for all these centuries without acclaim, except, say, in the 7volume Dictionary of Anonynious and Pseudonymous English Literature by Samuel Halkett. Willard R. Espy (well known as the author of The Game of Words: An Almanac of Words at Play') has concocted a humorous Life and Works that graciously leaves room for other biographers, those who may care someday to praise Anon for such immortal writings as the old English ballads, the Norse sagas, Beowulf and the Nibelungenlied.

title: PepsiCo Hits New Spot: Valhalla
description: ON an empty 36acre tract of land in Valhalla, PepsiCo recently held groundbreaking ceremonies for a 69,000squarefoot building. It will be no ordinary building. Some of its most important occupants will be batches of soda sampled and tested, wines to be decanted carefully, vending machines to be showered to judge their durability and something called a highperformance liquid chromatograph that knows almost as much about smells, tastes and your nose and tongue, and can make far more sense out of what it finds.

title: What's Doing Around FORT MYERS
description: THE AREA  Fort Myers, with a yearround population of 35,000, is the hub of southwest Florida's Lee County, fastest growing in the country. With an average winter temperature of a little Over 73 degrees, the region is a center for tourism, a haven for refugees from the frozen north.

title: Andrea Scharfman Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Saul Scharfman of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Sue Scharfman, to Nathan David Schulman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schulman of Rego Park, Queens. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Ice Skater Is Stable
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 (UPI)A professional ice skater, who fell on his head and was knocked out doing stunt before an audience of 10,000 last night, escaped serious injury and was in stable condition today. David Comb,33 years old, lay on the ice unconscious for 20 minutes at the Los Angeles Forurri before paramedics arrived and rigged a special harness to move him to an ambulance. Comb hit his head on the ice while attempting a forward flip.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Me, Tarzanus, the following memoir of life in the Roman Empire, was discovered after the seventh installment of public television's I, Claudius by archeologists excavating Alistair Cooke.

title: Miss Manger, S. A. Welsh 3d Plan to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Julius, Manger Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Margery Bullitt Manger, to Stanley Alexander Welsh 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Welsh Jr. of Devon, pa.

title: 600 People at Funeral Services Of Slain Officer in Brooklyn
description: More than 600 people, including several hundred police officers, attended funeral services in Brooklyn yesterday for Police Officer Ronald S. Stapleton, who died of bullet wounds of the chest and stomach after he was found critically wounded in a parking lot of a bar during off duty hours:

title: INTERVIEW
description: DARIEN I'M fiercely independent. said Barbara A. Keating. I like to make my own decisions and I get my beck up when somebody tells me I have to do somethine.

title: AdPeeipns Upset By High TV Prices:
description: Have prices for primetime network television gone too high? The networks say no, that they are merely catching up with costs. But the effect on advertisers has been enormous. For the short term tney nave scaiea aown many mar-keting plans, settling for less advertising frequency. For the long term, many have ended automatic media selection.

title: SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
description: Earth's aura is the atmosphere  a fragile envelope of assorted gases, water vapor and suspended particulate matter that keeps us alive while alternately entertaining us with sunsets and cloud formations and trying to flatten us with hailstorms, hurricanes and tornadoes. Young's purpose is not to tell us everything we always wanted to know about the atmosphere (which, in truth, would make a rather short book, largely devoted to weather prediction and control), but to tell us everything we ought to know about the atmosphere. She tells us, for example, about ozone, a molecule consisting of three oxygen atoms stuck together. Confusingly, ozone has figured as both hero and villain in recent battles over air pollution. In the upper atmosphere, a layer of ozone gas absorbs large amounts of ultraviolet radiation from the sun; without this natural radiationshield, life on the earth's surface would be impossible. Yet near that surface, a buildup of chemical pollutants can lead to the production of ozone, which is harmful to living beings that come into direct contact with it. If you have trouble understanding why ozone up there is good for you while ozone down here is bad, you willhave even greater trouble understanding why the propellant from our aerosol cans poses a serious threat to the good ozone but not to the bad ozone. Louise Young takes the time to explain why  just as she takes the time to explain how rainstorms form, and exactly what a dew point is, and how the solar wind affects us, and why some scientists think the world is getting dangerously warmer, while others think it is getting dangerously cooler. Her word pictures are both lucid and evocative; in telling us more than we originally wanted to know about the atmosphere, she leaves us wanting still more.

title: How Beetleboards Put the Bugs Into Advertising
description: Charles E. Bird, the Los Angeles marketing consultant whose brainchild it is, likes to think of the treatment as Bug spraythe coats of hectic lime, orange, purple and blue that go on the Volkswagens before the advertising decals are applied.

title: In Milford, Education Is a Family Affair
description: MILFORD IN 1916, when the world was at war, a tenuous peace cloaked this tranquil town on Long Island Sound. And Samuel and Harris Rosenbaum, two immigrant brothers from Russia who had worked their way through Yale by tutoring students for highschool and collegeentrance examinations, decided it was time for their academically oriented family to open a school.

title: A Poet Writes for the Stage
description: Kenneth Koch, the poet (The Art of Love), has written a play called The Red Robins, based on his novel of the same title. The new work, which is being billed as a visual, poetic and theatrical event, starts a threeweek run on Tuesday at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street. Allen Ginsberg, Mr. Koch's friend and fellow poet, recently discussed the play with him. Their conversation follows.

title: Snow Regulations: A Maze for Motorists
description: WHEN the temperature hovers around freezing or goes below, the Island's motorists face a maze of snowemergency regulations and, in some instances, tickets and fines if they are forced to abandon their vehicles.

title: Sutton Among 6 in Subway Who Protest Alleged Police Beating of Rider
description: Six New Yorkersincluding former Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattanhave protested what they say was a beating by the police on Friday night in the IRT subway at Grand Central.

title: CHESS
description: Whenever you adopt an aggressive, ambitious defense that involves postponing castling for the sake of positioning pawns and pieces for counterattack, it is necessary to analyze at every move your opponent's possibilities for sacrifices that create stunning attacks. You can never count on anythins happening in slow motion.

title: Rabbi Takes Fund Post
description: Rabbi William Berkowitz, spiritual leader of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan and author and lecturer, has been elected national president of the Jewish National Fund of America. Rabbi Berkowitz, who succeeds Meyer Pesin as head of the fund, has served as an honorary vice president for the fund and has been a member of its board for several years.

title: Dance: Diane BoardmanTroupe
description: At their best Diane Boardman's dances are renderings of the music to which they are performed, as detailed as some bright mosaic. At worst, they are onejoke dances without a joke.

title: The Activist Edelmans Find an Active Life Upstate
description: CHATHAM, N.Y.  I remember thinking, upstate New York, that's the pits, said Marian Wright Edelman, descrill(ng her first reaction to the news two years ago that her husband, Peter B. Edelman, had accepted an appointment as director of New York's State Division for Youth. Today she speaks differently, because she has learned to like it.

title: When in Doubt, Cache as Cache Can
description: THE first thing to do is to find a hiding place. That is of primary importance, because if the police have told us once, they have told us a dozen times, each time they have come to ask us if we saw anything unusual on the day the neighbors were burglarized. They have said that the burglaralarm systems were not foolproof, no matter what the cost; that the dog's barking was not sure protection, that the lights plugged into automatic timers were not enough, that the deadlocks alone would not do. They keep saying: If they want to get in, they will. And they want to. And they do.

title: Norton: True or False
description: In a flourish of apparent conformity, Muhammad Ali has CoMplied with the World Boxing CounciLedict that he defend the world heavyweight title against Ken Norton sometime before his first Social Security check arrives. Not only do I agree to defend my tige,, the champion's letter explained, but have already signed a contract witirTop Rank Inc. for :Stich title defense. And the W.B.C. has accepted the champion's pledge. But the semantics of that letter are as slick as Ali himself. And the intrigue surrounding the AliNorton negotiations is as slippery as Bob Arum, the Top, Rank promoter who is masterminding either the most fabulous finances in boxing history or a flagrant fraud.

title: STAMPS
description: To produce a lot more stamps on a sheet of the same size that is now being used could be a way of saving money. To find this out, the United States Postal Service is putting on sale this Wednesday and Thursday, in five test cities, an experimental diminutive 13cent stamp.

title: SADAT BARS ISRAELIS AS SINAI SETTLERS
description: CAIRO, Jan. 7President Anwar elSadat has declared that Egypt and Israel are in complete agreement on the principle of total Israeli military withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula, but he stressed that Cairo would not allow any Israeli iattlers to remain on recovered territory.

title: South
description: The South basks in the warmth of its economic sun. Last year was bright and the 1978 forecast is brighter. Still, there are storm cloudsinflation, energy shortages, a higher minimum wage, a push for more unions, a lag in farm pricesbut most Southern businessmen seem to be solidly optimistic, probably more optimistic than businesmen in general.

title: Corporate War in Hartford
description: Stephen B. Kaye, left, chief counsel for SCM, which has brought suit against Xerox, for whom Stanley D. Robinson, right, is chief counsel, in court at Hartford.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN cutting thin strips of wood, metal or plastic, it is often difficult to get a smooth cut because even finetooth saw blades tend to grab and the thin material tends to bend (in the case of metal) or splinter (in the, case of wood). One of the easiest ways to solve this is to sandwich the material being cut between two scrap pieces of plywood or wood.

title: DINING OUT
description: RESTAURANT devotees are mostly conservative people. If they try many places, it usually is not because of and sense of adventure or joy in confronting tia unknown; it is simply to find a couple of decent places at which to eat. And when they find them, they are usually content to stay with the familiar and the comfortable.

title: U.S. Arms Industry Provides Guns and jobs
description: WASHINGTON When Jimmy Carter was a candidate he saw the efforts of previous administrations to sell arms abroad as unsavory, and cynical. If elected, Mr. Carter promised, his Administration would sharply reduce the sale of weapons overseas.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today Porsche Club or America ISOmile T.S.D. rally; start at Howard Johnson's. Route 112 at Exit 64 of Long Island Expressway, Medford, L.I. Registration: 9 A.M.; first car off 10:01.

title: Evelyn Beebe Is ti'D'ed at Sea
description: Evelyn Lucretia Beebe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Beebe Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Pine Orchard, Conn., was married yesterday to Rocky Steven Hubert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hubert of DeKalb, Tex. The Episcopal ceremony was performed aboard a sailboat off Rose Island, near Nassau, the Bahamas, by the Rev. Murillo Bonaby of Nassau.

title: How to Help the Beginning Reader
description: FIVETHOUSAND bumper stickers ride the highways of Idaho with the message: Read to Your Children 15 Minutes Day. On the Idaho airwaves, radio and television personalities repeatedly ask: Have you read to your child today?

title: John A. Celentano Sr., a Lawyer And Banker in Jersey, Was 76
description: John A. Celentano Sr., a leading lawyer and banker in Clifton, N. J., who was the municipal magistrate there from 1946 to 1962, died Thursday of a heart attack in his home at. 371 Grove Street, in Clifton. He was 76 years old.

title: Two Conductors Plan Offbeat Events
description: It is still early enough in the New Year to feel positive about the future, to be full of good intentions and to respect the idealism of others. One can applaud, for example, the efforts of Joseph Eger to get his Symphony of the United Nations (SUN) onto the international circuit and to be glad that they will be taking part in a Middle East festival in Jerusalem on April 26,27 and 28.

title: Portuguese Airline Strike Ends
description: LISBON, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Cabin crews of Portugal's TAP airline called off their strike over pay today three and a half hours after walking off the job. A union statement said sufficient agreement had been reached with management for members to return to work.

title: PEOPLE
description: As of last Tuesday, a strict dress and conduct code was imposed upon the 1,200 members, various employees and guests of the 109yearold, Chicagobased MidAmerica Commodity Exchange. Violations carry a $25 fine.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: It is now nearly 20 years since the descending spiral of the new Guggenheim Museum first made its contribution to the New York scene. Harsh things were said about Frank Lloyd Wright on that occasion. The new building was an affront to Fifth Avenue, a slap in the face to art, an egomaniacal contraption more conducive to vertigo than to concentration.

title: A Musical Banquet to Savor in Westchester
description: THE monthly calendar published by the Council for the Arts in Westchester is an invaluable source of information about who's doing what where, but sometimes it can also give us a clue to tascinating cultural innovations in the county. For instance, most college orchestras are doing well if they can prepare and give three different programs over the course of the academic year, yet the council's January bulletin listed three concerts in as many weeks by the orchestra at the State University College of New York at Purchase.

title: Dylan: My Film Is Truer Than Reality
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. Boh Dylan is the almost unchallenged leader of American popular music or at least of white American popular music. He is our preeminent former folkie and presentday rockandroller, an evocative and mystical poet, a moving composer and an electrifying performBut he has never been content with all that. He has written a novel, published a book of his writings and drawings, appeared in two films about himself and acted a fictional role in a third, and continues to enlist his services in behalf of controversial political causes.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Legend is more potent than reality and yet nowhere is the search for reality to match the myth more apparent than in the case of Isadora Duncan. No American artist continues to inspire more curiosity and interest throughout the world than this famous dancer born in San Francisco a century ago.

title: INSURANCE CONCERNS RATE THE BEST RISKS
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 7 (UPI)Ever wohder whom auto Insurance companies consider the best risks?

title: Lora J. Barnes Engaged To William Keller Glass
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Barnes of Natchez, Miss., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lora Julie Barnes, to William Keller Glass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Glass of Darien, Conn. and New York.

title: Schools Feel Impact of Graying Population
description: WHEN the students at George School, a private secondary institution northeast of Philadelphia, return for classes in the fall of 1979, they will find the same reassuring surroundings of years past the venerable Main Building, the historic Quaker Meetinghouse and tiny Neshaminy Creek bubbling its way through the rolling hills of the 300acre campus.

title: Food
description: Whenever one travels for mostly gastronomic reasons, it is inevitable that some dishes will be indelibly etched in the mind. Others will demand a few bites and then be forever lost to memory. On a recent trip through Italy, we sampled.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DART EUROPE (Dart). Antwerp Jan. 15, Copenhagen 17 and Dublin 18; sails from Global Marine Terminal, N.1.

title: DICK PORTER DEAD AT 46; LEAD SINGER OF INKSPOTS
description: SEDALIA, Mo., Jan. 7 (AP)Dick Porter, lead singer of the Inkspots singing singing group for the last nine years,. died of a heart attack yesterday in a Sedalia motel room. He was 46 years old.

title: Newark, The Lively Melting Pot
description: IN late 1976, when I told my friends and family that I was moving from suburban Bergen County to Newark, there was general agreement that I was crazy. Most everyone I spoke to was convinced that Newark was a place to ignore, if possible, and to avoid moving to at all costs.

title: Odermatt Winner of Giant Slalom
description: MONT STE. ANNE, Quebec, Jan. (UN)  Josef Odermatt., a 25yearold from Switzerland, continued on course today in his bid to win the ]97S world professional skiing championship.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today Porsche Club or America ISOmile T.S.D. rally; start at Howard Johnson's. Route 112 at Exit 64 of Long Island Expressway, Medford, L.I. Registration: 9 A.M.; first car off 10:01.

title: The Vicereine From Chicago
description: IWONDER how much our perceptions of books about women  even those in the past  have been radically changed by the ripple effects of the women's movement To me Mary Curzon seems an unsatisfactory subject for a full length biography because she appears as such a passive participant in her own life. Judged, not just by the harsh standards of the 1970's, but in her contemporary context, the confluence of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, she was a reactive woman rather than an active one. She derived her ideas and her attitudes almost entirely from her controversial husband and, as a social figure, apparently preferred to play a role she was given than to create one for herself.

title: Miss Stefanik Wed To Albert Appleton
description: Dorothy Ann Stefanik, director of personnel for the New York City court system, was married yesterday to Albert Francis Appleton of New York, special assistant attorney general and executive assistant with the State Attorney General's office.

title: Investors in With Municipals
description: For the investor, 1977 may well have been the year of the tortoise. The lowly taxexempt municipal bond, a plodding type of security sold to raise funds for schools, streets, sewers and such, won the race as the best investment of 1977.

title: Pro Football: You Play Because You Want to And Not to Get Rich
description: I'll guarantee you I didn't play pro football for the money. One of the most aggravating things is the constant barrage that we're moneyhungry. Since we have a very brief career it's true to an extent, and all of us want to do well financially, but there's not enough money to maze a man go through what you go through to achieve excellence in professional football. There is not!

title: CAMERA
description: Although the miniaturization of electronic components, and the perfection of small, highefficiency flash tubes and improved batteries, has permitted the production of compact flash units that weigh only a few ounces, more and more photographers still prefer the classic headandhandle flash unit of the socalled potatomasher type.

title: Tips on Sawing, Touchups and Roof Repairs
description: WHEN cutting thin strips of wood, metal or plastid, it is often difficult to get a smooth cut because even finetooth saw blades tend to grab and the thin material tends to bend (in the case of metal) or splinter (in the case of wood). One of the easiest ways to solve this is to sandwich the material being cut between two scrap pieces of plywood or wood.

title: Chiang Nominated for President Of Taiwan in March Elections
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 7Prime Minister Chiang Chingkuo was nominated for President today by Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang Party. The elections are scheduled for March and no opposition is expected.

title: 20 Under Par Wins in Mesa
description: MESA, Ariz., Jan. 7 (UPI)Bob Risch of Diamond Bar, Calif., shot a oneunderpar 70 in the final round today to win the $25,000 Mesa Centennial open. RisCh scored a total 20underpar 193 for the tournament and earned top prize money of $2,500.

title: Florida Prison Head Seeks End To CigaretteMaking by Inmates
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) Florida is planning to stop having its prisoners manufacture 4.5 million packs of cigarettes a year at state expense for free distribution to other inmates, according to a state official.

title: THE GRAND CENTRIC OF THE CONCERT HALL
description: Vladimir Horowitz performs no more than 20 times each year, only on Sunday afternoon at 4, and only in places he likes. He does not play in Denver because he finds the altitude disagreeable or in St. Louis because he thinks the acoustics of its hall compare badly with those of his bathroom. He does not play in Poughkeepsie, where the public is not musical enough, or in Montana or Idaho, which he has no desire to see. He does not play in Europe because he dislikes flying long distances and, although he would like to visit Japan, the mere thought of getting there casts a pall over his large, extraordinary face. You fly Friday and arrive on Saturday, he says, as announcing a funeral. You have to stay 10 days to be right again and that scares me.

title: Vivian Half in Bride Of Dr. David Harnett
description: Vivian Paula Halfin, a fourthyear medical student at the New York University School of Medicine, was married last night to Dr. David Serjeant Harnett, who is serving a combined internship and residency in psychiatry at the Tufts New England Medical Center in Boston.

title: Sports Today
description: John Jay at Medgar Evers, 5 P.M. (RadioWNYC, 5 P.M.)

title: Social Structures Were Created in the European Image
description: The decision in the Mashpee Indian land suit case has raised a perplexing question of contemporary Indian affairs: What exactly is a tribe of Native Americans? How, after almost four centuries of conflict, dislocation, and intermarriage, can the existence of a tribe be fairly determined?

title: SELECTION
description: AND I've met a great many writers, most them unpublished, quite a few slightly published, and a, handful actually published. And they are, all of them, a fascinating lot.

title: Joan Smith Fiancee Of Richard Meyers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Smiith of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Ellen Smii.h, to Richard N. Myers of Clark, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Myers of Manasquan, N.J. Plans have been made for a June wedding.

title: Warm Spell Slows Skiers & Momentum
description: WARM and wet weather over the holiday season has slowed the start of what had been anticipated as a local ski boom of major dimensions this year.

title: Design
description: Some of the reasons for falling in love with California are light, space and the easy availability of the pleasures of outdoor living. Not for nothing did the expression laid back originate there.

title: Wall StreetFor Better or Worse?
description: After six years of turmoil, the longsought but illdefined national market system may finally be under way. With brokers plagued by sharply reduced profitability and merging with increasing rapidity, and with investment bankers hit by a decline in corporate underwritings, Wall Street is being forced to change.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: LAKE PEEKSKILL THERE is music for cooking, music for waiting in, the dentist's office; music for daydreaming, music for partying, music for riding in elevators, music for waking up, music for falling asleep.

title: Actress Tatum O'Neal Riding High for Movie
description: Suddenly thrust into. an equestrienne's rolea strange one for heras star of a new M.G.M. film, International Velvet, Tatum O'Neal has been forced to take a crash course in riding.

title: The Tenants And the Torch: A Whodunit That Galvanized A Building
description: It started with a small blaze in a cornpactor room.

title: Coast Areas Gird for Oil Finds at Sea
description: THE first drilling for oil and gas off the New Jersey coast is not scheduled to begin until March, but the state and coastal counties are speeding plans to deal with the onshore impact.

title: What Koch Plans For the City Schools
description: AT a recent hearing on proposed changes in the governing of the New York City school system, the city's new Mayor, Edward I. Koch, introduced Herman Badillo, a former Congressman and one of his Deputy Mayors, as the man in charge oeducation in my administratidn.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Robert Browning: Philosophy and Faith.

title: Like Carter, Potomac Power Is Ambiguous
description: WASHINGTON There are no wall posters in Washington with obscure metaphors to divine clues to shifts power, but figuring out who is in charge here may be just as difficult as it is in Peking. The problem is not the shortage of information, but the excess and the contradictions.

title: Worrying About the Pension Gap
description: Many financial analysts and bankers are in cold sweat over whether the nation's largest corporations have set aside enough assets to coverthe pensions they have guaranteed their employees. In the past the workers carried much of the risk. But the Employee rceurement income Security Act of 1974 transformed pensions from gratuitiespayable to employees at company's discretionto liabilities with a potential claim on up to 30 percent of a company,'s net worth.

title: Taking Charter Flights Read the Fine Print
description: For about a year and a half now, vacation travel by chartered plane has been available to the Americans masses. It's time for a look at some of the problems encountered, the directions in which charter travel seems to be heading and some of the advantages and pitfalls for consumers.

title: The Muppet ShowVeddy Much At Home Abroad, Thank You
description: Made for audiences in two countriesEngland and the United StatesThe Muppet Show is rare among such ventures: it is a solid hit in both places. Indeed, playing as it does in nearly 100 other countries in a variety of languages, Jim Henson's puppetvariety show is possibly the most popular contemporary television program in the world. Not bad for a network reiect.

title: INTERVIEW An Author's View of What Happened to Hoffa
description: LESTER VELIE, the 69yearold Ukraineborn, Wisconsinraised, Great Neckbased roving editor of Reader's Digest, is roving more than usual these days.

title: Knicks Defeat the Kings, 10093
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 7The Knicks, who seem to win a few and lose a few, continued a threeweek road trip tonight against a National Basketball Association team that may he the next to announce a coaching change. The. New Yorkers squared off agains the Kings and Coach Phil Johnson, who to the West Coast in which they did have lost their last six games on a trip not win a game.

title: Reforming the Regulitory Agencies
description: WASHINGTON Our Government in Washington now is a horrible bureaucratic niess, Jimmy Carter charged frequently during his Presidential campaign, singling out, particularly the wasteful, inefficient and duplicative regulatory agencies.

title: ART
description: NEW HAVEN VIEWS of the land have always exercised a particular allure in art but scenes of the sea have had a special magnetism for their dramatic impact and magnificent hresence.

title: Kundera on The Novel
description: THE following has been adapted from the November/December 1977 issue of the English magazine Index on Censorp.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORTRecent works by members of the art faculty, through Jan. 26. Housatonic Community College, 610 Barnum Ave. Secondfloor student lounge, Monday through Thursday 8 A.M. to 10 P.M., Friday 8 to 5.

title: If You Go
description: to St. Kitts, there is no direct jet service at this time, except for charter flights. Prinair, LIAT and Winair link the island to four jet gatewaysthe Virgin Islands, San Juan, St. Martin and Antigua.

title: Alfred Fitt, U.S. Lawyer, Weds Lois Rice, College Board Executive
description: The marriage of Lois Dickson Rice, a vice president of the College Entrance Examination Board, to Alfred B. Fitt, general counsel of the Congressional Budget Office, took place yesterday in Washington. Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Annunciation at Episcopal Church House. He was assisted by the Rev. John D. Verdery, headmaster emeritus of the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn.

title: HENRY Z. PERSONS
description: Henry Z. Persons, president for 16 years of the First Vermont Bank and Trust Company, died yesterday in the Brattleboro, Vt., Memorial Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Brattleboro.

title: Paul Croarkin Fiance Of Marjorie Maguire
description: The engagement of Marjorie Anne Maguire to Paul Cornelius Croarkin, son of Mr. end Mrs. Neil Croarkin of Westport, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Reeves Maguire of Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORDShowaoat. I uesaay to bunday, through Jan. 22. Opens 6:15 P.M., dinner at 7 P.M., show at 8:30 P.M. Sundays one hour earlier. $16 to $18. Reservations. An EVening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Adolph Behrenberg, 63, Pastor Of a Church in Jersey 35 Year:
description: The Rev. Dr. Adolph H. Behrenberg, for 35 years pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Metuchen, N.J., died Dec. 30 in a Plainfield (N. J.) nursing home. He was 63 years old. His residence was at 260 Woodbridge Avenue, Metuchen.

title: Hartford Symphony Spotlights One of Its Own
description: HARTFORD THIS season's guest roster at the Hartford Symphony has its fair share of international superstarsAndre Watts, Itz hak Perlman, Vladimir Spivakov and Lorin Hollanderbut at the orchestra's next concert the soloist will be one of its own.

title: JAVITS ACTS TO SAVE ALBANY's AID TO CITY
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, seeking to apply pressure on Governor Carey for sustained state aid to New York City, urged yesterday that any bid for Federal loan guarantees or other aid from Vashington be presented jointly by the city and the state.

title: If You Go
description: to Glenwood Springs by car, check driving conditions ahead of time. Road reports are given by the Denver radio stations, along with ski conditions.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Is Westchester County failing the elderly? An unnecessary phaseout of the Ruth Taylor Geriatric and Rehabilitation Institute (formerly the County Home) in Hawthorne has been proposed by the county government. The projected date is December 1979, but the number of patients there already is being reduced.

title: Bruce Duncan Moir And Elizabeth Wells Plan August Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Shippen Wells of West Boylston, Mass., have Made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Cheney Wells, to Bruce Duncan Moir, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Russell Moir of Bronxville, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Marijuana at Sheriff's Stolen
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP)Just outside the Monroe County sheriff's office, thieves cut the lock on a truck and stole 10 bales of marijuana. The marijuana was supposed to be under armed guard but apparently was not when the theft occurred Tuesday, deputies said. The marijuana was seized Nov. 23 by Key West police officers who suprised six men as they transferred it from one truck to another.

title: FranceAmerique Is Celebrating 150th Year of Newspaper Career
description: Like the community it serves, FranceAmerique, the French weekly newspaper in the United States, tends to keep a low profile. The 10member staff almost let the paper's 150th anniversary go by unnoticed, but the paper is currently observing the birthday  or rather that of the first of its predecessors.

title: Sarah Albert To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Talbot Jones Albert 3d of Faliston, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Elisabeth Albert, to John Aulton Hayes Jr., son of Mrs. John N. Gore of Wilmington, N. C., and the late Mr. Hayes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The former Virginia Tech assistant football coach who administered the punishment drill to Bob Vorhies just before the freshman fullback died last November has commented on the case for the first time since shortly after the incident.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: New frontier. This is not science fiction. That legend is writ large on the cover of a justpublished paperback, above the picture of a giant metal ship whizzing through outer space. The book's title Colonies in Space'; but the caption, as well as the picture, could just as appropriately appear on two other newly released softcover volumes, Space Colonies and The High Frontier.

title: Television This Week
description: 10 A.M. (2) LAMP UNTO MY FEET. The Rise of Christian Art. A halfhour of highlights from the Metropolitan Museum of Art's current exhibit of European works from the third to 17th centuries.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I.Dawn was bitterly cold, the windruffled waters of Shinnecock Bay slate gray, and wonderedas I have so many times in recent yearswhether the pleasures of lurking in a duck blind may not be overrated.

title: Snow Helps, But Ski Industry's Future Is Cloudy
description: On the face of it, there's nothing wrong with the nation's $3 billion ski industry that a little snow won't cure, and this season the cure has been in plentiful supply. After a disastrous 197677 season, when snow sometimes seemed no more than a memory and an endless chain of empty lift chairs looked like treadmill to bankruptcy, bookings at Aspen and Vail are now running ahead of the record 197475 season. Moreover, the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, not exactly known for a philanthropic approach to business, cast large vote for the sport's future by agreeing last week to acquire the Aspen Skiing Corporation at $45 a share, more than twice the highest price at Which the stock had ever traded.

title: The Right to Frisk: Pros and Cons
description: THE New Jersey Supreme Court ruled recently that the proliferation of pistols in modern society and an anonymous tip are sufficient reasons for New Jersey policemen to stop and frisk people.

title: The Tourist's Return
description: Now that President Carter is home from his sevencountry trip, the White House staff will undoubtedly labor to explain that there really was a firM rope of logic and national interest that tied it all together. But the best answer he himself might give to the question of how hesummed up the achievements of those nine days would the world out he one simple sentence: I saw a there.

title: Big Labor Counting on Congress and Import Curbs
description: Organized labor will fight its biggest battles this year not on the picket lines but in Congress. The bargaining calendar is light: By spring the nation's 500,000 rail workers will have a new contract or be threatening to strike. The construction trades, as usual, have spring contract expiration dates, and by summer the Post Office workers will be in negotiation.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, Franklin and Fremont Streets, BloomfieldA Hatful of Rain. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Feb. 4). $2.9044.90; students and the elderly, $1.90$3.90. (201) 9297662. Bloomfield College (Westminster Theater).

title: A REIGN OF WAR IN THE LAND OF SHEBA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia. Once, Gibbon could write, Beset on sides by foes, the Abyssinians slept for a thousand years forgetful the world by which they were forgotten. Today, both Abyssinia (now Ethiopia) and its foes have stirred. The Ethiopian Empire, which after China and Egypt, is the third oldest nationstate, is grave danger of dismemberment.

title: City Ballet Performs Episodes And La Source, by Balanchinc
description: So wide is George Balanchine's range within his own very Personal artistic vision that it is no surprise that he could come up with such dissimilar ballets as La Source. and Episodes.

title: The Wondrous Music Of Angelus at Chartres
description: It is amazing how ignorant supposedly intelligent people can be. Here we were, my wife and I, allowing four hours to visit Chartres with its magnificent cathedral. We were well aware of its incredible beauty, yet we arranged a mental timetable that did no honor to one of the greatest structures of Christendom.

title: Students: The New Debtor Class
description: ALMOST unknown a decade ago, student loans are becoming one of the fastestgrowing and most controversial issues in American higher education. With inflation straining university budgets, tuition charges rising and traditional financial resources dwindling, colleges are increasingly looking to loans to finance education. More than $5.5 billion in borrowed money is already outstanding, and a virtual explosion is anticipated in the years ahead. Many experts fear, though, that student loans are beginning to exert a social influence that far outstrips their original purpose.

title: Castaldo Vows To Stay Till Ousted
description: City Manager Vincent R. Castaldo of Yonkers paused as he strode toward his office, thought for a minute, and responded with the year and the month in which the electrification project had been completed. He said that while he didn't have the company's name on the tip of his tongue, Ray, in Public Works, would know. Turning again in midstride, the City Manager reminded his aide about a section of the City Hall system that wasn't working. He described the malfunction in precise terms, and returned to his office, where he munched on a piece of chocolate cake, talked and answered telepliones.

title: Donald Woods: Apartheid on Collision Course With Black Anger
description: LONDONSouth Africa today is ruled by fearthe fear of the ruled and the fear of the rulers. The rulers are fearful because they area a minority, and their fear is increasing because they perceive that the hatred of them by the majority is increasing.

title: Watson Leads Tucson Golf by 2 Strokes
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 7A motorcycle snaked its noisy way toward the Catalina Mountains today, its roar bouncing off the mesquite hushes and saguaro cactus and surrounding Tom Watson as he putted e on the fourth hole.

title: Fashion
description: It can't be stereotyped or pinpointed. California fashion design is as varied as it is unclassifiable. Ever since Adrian constructed his graphic suits and dresses for HollywooD's leading ladies in the 40's and Rudi Gernreich aired his barebreasted swimsuits in the 60's, West Coast avantgarde designers have done pretty much what they felt like doing.

title: Trial Opens for ExPartner of Judge Meicorella
description: Keaseth Kass, former law partner or Judge Anthony 3. Mercorella of the Bronx Civil Court, went on trial last week on charges of taking money from undercover agents, seeking to buy a bar and turning some of the money over to employees of a city agency who helped process the license.

title: INVESTING
description: Here is the situation: Your Aunt Emily in Peoria has died, and you have inherited  instead of the stuffed elk's head you expected  the tidy sum of $20,000.There is one stipulation in her will, however. The money must be invested, immediately in some form of securities.

title: Econonfists Predicting Good Gains In Profits
description: Corporate profits will rise by 5 percent to 12 percent over last year's blockbuster when profits first passed the $100 billion mark; leading analysts predict. The size of the gain varies primarily with the individual analysts doubts over Congressional action on President Carter's proposed $25 billion tax cut and the energy program, trade regulations and Governmental action to cut employment through job stimulus.

title: GOVERNOR CONFIDENT OVER VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Jan. 7 Some major problems, among them a shortage of potable water on St. Thomas, increasing crime and a paucity of Government operating funds, face the new Governor of the United States Virgin Islands. Puerto Ricanborn Juan Luis.

title: Dibble, ExLion, Is I11
description: ROYAL OAK, Mich., Jan. 7 (AP)Dome Dibble, former wide receiver for the Detroit Lions, was in stable condition today after suffering an apparent heart attack, according to officials at Beaumont Hospital. Dibble, 48 years old, a native of Adrian, became ill Wednesday after playing paddleball. Dibble was a defensive end at Michigan State in 1951 when he was drafted by the Lions and switched to offense.

title: Still Reforming the Criminal Code
description: After more than a decade of toil and trauma over the shape of Federal criminal law, the Senate is nearing final action on the Criminal Code Reform Act. There the bill sits. high on the agenda for the returning Congress, backed by an odd alliance of Senators ranging from Edward Kennedy to Strom Thurmond. Even the House, where the issue has been long dormant, has appointed a subcommittee to consider it, raising hopes for enactment this year.

title: Andrea Rhodin, Paul E. Tebbets To Wed in June
description: Andrea Wolfe Rhodin, a writer with the International Monetary Fund in Washington, and Paul E. Tebbets, program officer at the Rand Corporation in Washington, plan to be married in June.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The first week of the new year was a rocky one for several sectors of the American economy. The big new Social Security tax bite became evident for many workers and their employers in the first paychecks of 1978. Investors endured another discouraging period in the stock market. And those involved in foreignexchange trading had to cope with sharp swings in the quotations of many currencies just before and after the United States made its momentous commitment at midweek to intervene actively and substantially support the value of the dollar.

title: The Raccoon Moves In
description: THE sound of garbage cans falling to the ground in the night, the pitterpatter of little feet across, your attic floor and the smoke that fills your living room when you try to use the fireplace could all be signs that you have raccoons on the premises.

title: Sister Elizabeth Teresa Counihan Of Mt. Augustine Apostolic Center
description: Sister Elizabeth Teresa Counihan, program director of the Mount Augustine Apostolic Center and Retreat House on Staten Island, was killed Dec. 30 when she was hit by a streetcar in downtown Vienna. She was, 38 years old and lived at the center.

title: High Winds Close Athens Airport
description: ATHENS, Jan. 6 (Reuters) All flights to and from the Athens airport have been canceled or diverted because of galefotce winds in the area, an airport spokesman said today. A few planes from abroad that tried to land gave up and were diverted to tither countries.

title: Political Contributions by Con Ed Assailed as a Cost to Stockholders
description: A Long Island consumer advocate has criticized political contributions by the Consolidated Edison Company and vrious telephone officials, asserting that Consolidated Edison had charged its stockholders $4,000 for administering such contributions.

title: Questions/Answers
description: NORFOLK ISLAND PINE

title: Los Angeles Cossack
description: Joseph Wambaugh, a former policeman who writes about cops on the planet of Los Angeles (The Choirboys, The New Centurions, The Blue Knight), has created a detective, Andrei Mikhailovich Valnikov, who is almost as touching, variable and bravely idiotic as Nabokov's Professor Pnin. A burly man with wild cinnamon hair and slouchy walk, Valnikov lives on Russian vodka, Chaliapin, and Boris Godunov. Like Pnin, Valnikov is utterly displaced. The son of a captain in the Czar's last army, Valnikov was born and reared in Los Angeles. But he dreams of Petrograd, nightingales raspberry bushes, wounded rabbits in the Siberian snow. Absentminded and incorrigibly oldfashioned, Valnikov drinks tea at the stationhouse among an army of coffeedrinking cops. He has been thrown out of homicide and transferred to Hollywood dicks, after fighting with a pathologist at the morgue.

title: Cambodia's Casualty Reports Pinpoint Battle Areas
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 7Cambodia asserted today that its troops had destroyed five Vietnamese divisions since September and had killed or wounded about 30,000 Vietnamese soldiers.

title: Her Father's Daughter
description: ELEANOR Marx was the youngest of Karl Marx's three daughters and a great tragic heroine of the international socialist movement. public life a tireless speaker and union organizer, she established a contact with the British working class and with its political organizations that her father had never achieved. In her private life she was involved a situation that might have provided a theme for the dramatic genius of Ibsen, whose work Eleanor Marx did much to introduce to the Englishspeaking public. Yvonne Kapp has written a very long and immensely detailed scholarly biography that does full justice both aspects of Eleanor's difficult life.

title: Fast Food: Family Guide To the Best In 4 Counties
description: THERE is no denying the popularity of fast food these days. Almost 70 million Americans eat at fastfood restuarants at least twice a month. Some call it madness, and in recent years we have seen the rise of the fastfood addict, the person who has become spiritually attuned to the prepared hamburger and reconstituted onion rings. Others see the popularity of fast food as an indicator of a changing life style, as an escape from kitchen drudgery.

title: MARKETS Dow Tumbles Below 800 Mark
description: Shock waves went through the stock market last week as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 37.68 points in a virtual free fall to finish at 793.99, its lowest level in 27 months.

title: Saba: Gingerbread in the Caribbean,
description: I didn't realize how rare tourists are on Saba until my second night on the island. I was sitting at the bar at Scout's Place, chatting with the patrons and listening to Pauline Paul on the Voice of Saba. At the end of the evening news and commentary, Miss Paul announced the names of visitors to the islandan accounting manager from Curacao (who was staying overnight), a drug store owner from North Adams, Mass., (in from neighboring St. Martin for a day trip) and me (who will be dining tonight at Captain's Quarters). A bit startled but glad for the reminder, checked my watch, excused myself and went off to have dinner.

title: Watertown Is Debating if It Wants 2d Division Stationed at Ft. Drum
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 7Stationing a full Army division at Fort Drum near here could more than double the population of this small city in northern New York, send 7,000 new children to its schools and require the construction of 15,742 housing units for military personnel and their dependents, according to a locally commissioned study.

title: Flight Attendants End Strike
description: OAKLAND. Calif., Jan. 7 (Reuters) Flight attendants for Trans International Airlines, one of the world's largest charter air carriers, ratified a threeyear contract today. ending a fourmonth strike. Denise Rosso, a spokesman for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said the pact had been approved by a 2to1 margin. The new contract was the same as the one rejected by the attendants last month, she said. The airline had continued operating on a limited basis.

title: Campaign '78
description: WASHINGTON  The President's back in town, tired and resting up from a grinding, grueling global marathon that resembled nothing so much as his determined pursuit of the office he now holds.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Ignorance of the law is sheer folly for antiques collectors and may result in serious consequences. In fact, under two unrelated Federal laws, Government agents are empowered to confiscate antiques, and, on at least one recent occasion, that did happen.

title: St. Kitts: Mountains and Sea
description: Wheels are spinning at the new casino. The championship golf course has had its first championship tournament. Charter flights are landing at the jet strip. There no longer seems to be any reason not to tell you about my place in the sun. the island of St. Kitts. This.

title: Robert Ashley Offers a New Work
description: For well over a decade Robert Ashley, the experimental composer, has been involved in amalgams of music, sound, words and theater. The elements shift from year to year, with on or another sometimes fading away almost altogether. But with Private Parts, an hourlong work in progress that he presented Friday night at the Kitchen, Mr. Ashley has all of them in balance. The result is a work of rare elegance and emotional energy, although perhaps the word energy is a bit too overbearing for something so quietly mystical 4nd inten.:ely personal.

title: Terry Martin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Martin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terry Lynn Martin, to Graig Butler Skinner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Skinner Jr. Both families are of New Canaan, Conn. Miss Martin, a graduate of the University of Connecticut, and her fianc, president of Home and Industrial Insulators Inc. of Springfield, Mass. plan to be married next April 1.

title: The Artist as Millionaire
description: A few years ago a young painter, ballet dancer or violinist would have been crazy to embrace his high calling in hopes of becoming a millionaire. That's not true in the elite arts today, as lavish fees descend like rain from heaven on superstars who satisfy the public's craving for artistic celebrities. Dancers have made the most spectacular advance, from nearserfdom before World War II to the multithousand dollar fees per performance which a handful of superstars now command. The rise to riches of a number of American avantgarde painters is almost as striking, and although a few divas, charismatic conductors and virtuoso instrumentalists have always been handsomely rewarded, never before have so many of them been able to dictate princely terms.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Look Up and Live: Will Campbell, Southern Baptist minister

title: College That Offers A Second Change
description: ROSE MARY SUCKINS has done everything from cleaning offices at night to working as a community worker, and the cares of her 55 years are mirrored in her worn but pleasant face. Terri Lomax, 25, fashionably dressed and bubbling with the enthusiasm of youth, is a supervisor, in a temporary adolescent girls residence.

title: New Better Business Chief Is. Consumer Oriented
description: James J. Lack, then Suffolk County Consumer Affairs Commissioner, boarded the Washingtonbound Allegheny Airlines flight at Islip's MacArthur Airport and chose a seat in the first row, close to the front cabin bulkhead. The man behind him had already placed a bag beneath Mr. Lack's seat, so the stewardess took Ma. Lack's briefcase to the carryon lugaave compartment.

title: Dock Agreement Said to Help Port of New York
description: The agreement reached late last year between the International Longshoremen's Association and Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping associations will narrow differences in costs for operations in the Port of New York and other ports, according to a study by the New York State Assembiy Subcommittee on City Management.

title: Rhodesia Imposes Strict News Censorship Rules
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia; Jan. 7 (AP)The white minority Government imposed new censorship regulations today, prohibiting foreign and Rhodesian journalists from reporting anything but the official version of events in the fiveyearold guerrilla war.

title: Fathers Help Out In Deliveriing Caesarean Babies
description: BRIDGEPORT AFTER having spent weeks learning about. and, preparing for a natural childbirth, Patricia and Michael Sidoti were disappointed when Mr. Sidoti wai:suddenly sent from the delivaiyrooin because an unexpected complication brought about the necessity of a Caesarean birth. Their second child also,:required a Caesarean delivery and 6nce again Mr. Sidoti had to pace the waiting room.

title: Brighter Economy But Fiscal Stress
description: Good news for Mayor Koch. New York City's economy is healthier than it has been any time in the last 15 years which is not saying much when the catastrophe of the last 15 years is considered, but it is saying something. It may be only a temporary pause on the way to new depths, but the city's plummeting economy has stopped plummeting.

title: Two Cheers for an Import Plan
description: The reference price system that was presented last week by the Carter Administration as its main response to the drive by the domestic steel industry for protection against lowcost imports has left a state of confusion and uncertainty as to its effects.

title: Yogi Berra: At Bat in Montclair
description: Dressed in an informal, yellow La Coste alligator shirt, brown pants and loafers, he sits amid arrays of trophies, photographs of him with other great Yankees of the past and present and a bust of him wearing a baseball cap.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: What might you think if you were approached by someone who claimed to have definite and final proof that Anne Hathaway had written the works of Shakespeare? You might edge away and remember a pressing engagement on the other side of town, might you not? Well, allowing for rhetorical exaggeration, that was my first instinctive reaction when Maynard Solomon came to me five years sago with evidence that he felt solved one of music's most famous riddles: the identity of Beethoven's Immortal Beloved, the unsterbliche Geliebte to whom the composer wrote an almost deranged love letter on July 6 and 7, 1812. After more than a century of research and speculation, was it likely, I asked myself, that the enigma could ever be unraveled? And was it likely that the object of Beethoven's passionate interest would turn out to be, not one of more than a dozen candidates who had been proposed by scholars in the past, but a previously unsuspected married woman named Antonie Brentano?

title: Callaghan's Visit to India Points Up a Complex LoveHate Relationship With the British
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 7Prime Minister James Callaghan's visit to India is focusirig new attention on Adtain's curious relationship with the vast and ancient land that it used to regard as the jewel in the crown of its empire.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Never before has a new concept in banking been so widely hailed as Electronic Funds Transfer  a system that,in effect transfers dollars not by check or currency but by electronic impulses linked to electronic ledgers.

title: Carol Vinograd Wed to Dr. Rufus Bausell. Jr.
description: Carol Judith Vinograd, an educational diagnostician at the Terry Children's. Psychiatric Center in New Castle, Del., was married yesterday to Dr. Rufus Barker Bausell Jr., editor and publisher: of Evaltiation and the Health Professions, a journal.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: The life of Herbert Bayard Swope seems less a subject for biography than for the fantasy of a novelist. No one could have led such an existence in real life. Swope was: one of the great reporters of World War I America, scooping rivals with impunity; executive editor of The New York World in the golden age of bigcity journalism; multimillionaire and leading citizen, if not creator of Cafe Society; confidant of presidents, statesmen, authors, financiers. If Sw4e and the Pope had stood together on the balcony at St. Peter's, one could imagine the old joke come true: Who's that guy with Herbert Bayard Swope?

title: Booming Takeovers: What Good Do They Do?
description: Takeover fever has gripped the land. But unlike the last time, when in the late 60's conglomerates took advantage of high stock prices and put together deals based on stock swaps, American corporations are shopping the stock market for bargains, paying hard cash for solid companies with depressed prices.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Fugene O'Neill's A Touch of the Poet is a good play and a deceptive one. I'm afraid it has deceived director Jose Quintero and his company at the Helen Hayes sorely.

title: Like Many Others, the Nutrition Select Committee Left Its Mark
description: WASHINGTONAnybody who's against steaks and hamburgers, icecream, butter and sugary cupcakes, or pickles and sauerkraut was bound to make enemies. So, last weekend, when one of the oddest legislative beasts ever to be born on Capitol Hillthe Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needsfinally expired, it was lamented more by some than by others. Its admirers and its critics disagree about whether the committee deserves credit or blame for its nearly 10 years of trying to reduce the hazards of under and overnutrition. But few deny it had impact.

title: HOME CLINIC Tips on Sawing, Touchups and Roof Repairs
description: WHEN cutting thin strips of wood, metal or plastic, it is often difficult to get a smooth cut because even finetooth saw blades tend to grab and the thin material tends to bend (in the case of metal) or splinter (in the case of wood). One of the easiest ways to solve this is. to sandwich the material tieing cut between two scrap pieces of plywood or wood.

title: Charting a Course Toward Local Control
description: EARLY in 1977, the Shepaug River was declared eligible for inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic River System. On Nov. 1, an adhoc committee appointed by the First Selectmen of Roxbury, Washington, Morris, Warren and Litchfield issued its report. Has that report advanced, stopped or only blunted the thrust toward final inclusion?

title: FOOD
description: AMERICANS are cookie crazy. The mania for what copywriters refer to as the ultimate edible has led to cookie corners in shopping centers and cookie bars at the local movie theater, giving chocolatechip fanciers an opportunity to outmunch the popcorn crowd.

title: Latter TO THE EDITOR
description: I am a trucker, proud of it, and damned tired of reading articles that denigrate truckers. Robert Sherrill (Raising Hell on the Highways, Nov. 27) may be partly right about fatigue, but it's not the major cause of accidents. I've worked those 100hour weeks myself, but never took a pill or considered taking one. What about salesmen or tourists who drive just as long without stopping? Most accidents are caused by fourwheelers who do dumb things like cutting in front of you while you are trying to leave enough room between vehicles in order to stop.

title: National Economic Survey
description: Let me first of all remind you of the obvious. The great mass of the population is living much better than it ever lived before, said John Maynard Keynes in the depths of the Great Depression. What Keynes could say then can be said with far less fatuousness now: the great majority of Americans never lived so well.

title: Six Children Are Found Slain
description: ROCKFORD, I11., Jan. 7 (UPI)  Six children were found slain in their apartment here today and their father was charged with murder.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Let's all wish the Oxford University Press a happy 500th birthday. It was in the year 1478 that an migr printer from Cologne named Theodoric Rood set up a press in the university town of Oxford and ran off his first book, a commentary on the Apostle's Creed entitled Expositio. Sancti Heironymi in Symbolum Apostulorum.

title: Tough Task in Implementing Crippled Energy Plan
