description: When Congress finally approves what's left of the President's energy program, it will only be a beginning. A myriad regulations, policy initiatives and legal battles will be required to shape t'e plan's provisions, which in some cases are only generalities.

title: Baker Reports a Panamanian Concession on the Canal
description: PANAMA, Jan. 7 Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the minority leader, left for Mexico today after having apparently persuaded the Panamanian Government to accept an amendment to the Panama Canal treaties providing for the United States right to defend the canal after the year 2000.

title: World Cup Soccer Group Prepares for Seedings
description: The Organizing Committee of the World Cup will meet in Buenos Aires on Thursday, with the primary item on its agenda the seeding of two nations. Argentina and West Germany already have been seeded to head Groups I and II; respectively, for the draw that will take place on Saturday to determine the firstround matches.

title: Books of The Times
description: NATURAL SHOCKS. By Richard Stern. 260 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $8.95.

title: MARRERO WILL GET STATE HOUSING POST
description: Victor Marrero, who was dropped as chairman of the New York City Planning Coinmission by Mayor Koch, will be appoibteAd by Governor Carey today to head the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: HOWARD STEPHENSON, 84; IN PUBLIC RELATIONS FIELD
description: Howard P. Stephenson, who practiced and taught public relations and wrote a Handbook of Public Relations that has been translated into 13 languages, died Friday in Portland, Ore., where he had been living and teaching at Pacific University. He was 84 years old.

title: INSTRUCTION
description: These are some of the programs being offered this winter that incorporate new psychological approaches to skiing:

title: Ousted Minister Returns to Pulpit
description: WESTFIELD, Jan. 8A Baptist minister who was temporarily barred by a judge from preaching after five deacons charged in a suit that he had slandered parishioners and neglected his duties, returned to his pulpit today and led an emotional worship service.

title: New Newspaper, The Trib, Goes on Sale in New York
description: The Trib, a new morning New York City newspaper, began publication today.

title: Senators Are Flocking to Panama for Tour of Duty
description: PANAMA, Jan. 8  Codel Baker is gone, but Codel Goldwater lingers on, and the world's largest travel agency, sometimes thought of as the State Department, is getting ready for Codel Sparkman and Codel Cranston.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch from Seattle published last Tuesday misrepresented the position of a Seattle investment banker on a proposal for a school tax. The banker, Robert Yeastings, actually said that he would not oppose the levy.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Harry M. Smith, a managerial consultant and founder of Educational Consultants Inc., died Saturday of a heart ailment at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: 800 Joined Marcoses On New Year's. Eve
description: MANILA, Jan. 8President Marcos and his wife, Imelda, celebrated New Year's Eve with a party for 800 people at the presidential palace. Amohg the guests was Cristina Ford, estranges wife of Henry Ford 2d. is staying with Mrs. Marcos in the couple's private 18thcentury villa near the palace.

title: Alexander D. Calhoun, 79, Banker And ForeignEconomics Specialist
description: Alexander D. Calhoun, who retired in 1963 as a senior vice president of First National City Bank, now called Citibank, died yesterday in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Borrowing by Norway Presents a Problem
description: Norway, a toprated oil exporting country that nevertheless expects to run a balanceofpayments deficit in 1978, wants to raise a sizable amount of ready cash in the international capital markets this week. Its borrowing will hand investors an intriguing problem in floating exchangerate finance.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Ken Holtzman, the forgotten but expensive man on the Yankee pitching staff, is preparing for another season of sitting in the bull pen. From his home in Lincolnshire, Ill., Holtzman said that the Yankees had spoken to him just once this winter; Cedric Tallis, the general manager, had called.

title: Holy Cross Tops Army, 7876
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8Michael Vicens made two free throws with one second to play to give Holy Cross a 7876 victory over Army today in a college basketball game that was played before a capacity crowd of 3.200 at the West Point Field House.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UPI)Chicago has become the major distribution center for heroin in the United States, according to local and Federal investigators quoted in The Chicago Tribune.

title: Koch Administration Takes Over, First Tentatively, Then Definitely
description: As you can imagine, the only topic of conversation at City Hall last week was the new Mayor, Edward I., Koch, who froze his first night in Gracie Mansion but who has been going like a house afire since. After the near stupor of the final Beame days, it was a zany week downtown as Koch & Company  first tentatively and then emphatically  took occupancy of City Hall.

title: Advertising
description: Richard K. Manoff Inc. is about to be acquired by a British agency. That's the first Monday morning eyeopener. The second, which is not quite as exciting, is that BBDO International has acquired still another special ad shop. It's that Bruce Crawford; he's going wild.

title: Associated Press
description: MAKING ROOM: Adrian Dantley of the Lakers looking for room after getting rebound during action against the Pacers yesterday in Indianapolis.

title: South African Journalist Urges West to Put Pressure on Vorster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Donald Woods, the banned editor who fled South Africa on New Year's Eve, urged Western countries today to adopt stronger measures against the South African Government to force it to change its racial policies.

title: Rock: The Ramones
description: THE RAMONES are a joke. At first they are funny. The earnest dumbness of adolescent pop has Always been a source of both conscious and unconscious humor, and the Ramones, with their identical urnforms of black leather jackets and blue jeans,. their aggressively inane lyrics, and their insistence on the most banal instrumental patterns, take a broad swipe at this dumbness. But satirical treatments of dumbness invariably degenerate into the real thing if they are pushed to extremes, and the Ramones are nothing if not extremists.

title: Philharmonic: Rare Concert by Horowitz
description: VLADIMIR HOROWITZ played the Rachmaninoff hird Piano Concerto yesterday afternoon in Carnegie ball, and it was a close encounter of the third kind. Or maybe the fourth.

title: Mimi Shorr Is, Married To Lloyd D. Schwalb
description: Mimi Shorr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Shorr of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lloyd D. Schwalb, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Charles Schwalb of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the New York Hilton Hotel by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel of Temple EmanuEl.

title: Jersey Town Seeks to Block U.S. On Site for JobTraining Facility
description: Special to The New York Times LAKEWOOD TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 6Officials of this Ocean County community said today they would go ahead with a lawsuit to prevent the Federal Government from opening a Job Corps center nere aespue vernal assurances trom Federal aides that they would not impose the facility on the. community over the opposition of local residents.

title: Lord Carver Visits Mozambique
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Jan. 7 (Agence FrancePresse)  President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique continued talks here today with Britain's negotiator on Rhodesia, Field Marshal Lord Carver. They met for two hours yesterday. Mozambican statement said the talks were about a transfer of power to the black majority in Rhodesia.

title: For the 2 Teams, An Unnatural Event
description: All around him, the other members of the Denver Broncos were celebrating the American Conference championship that qualified them for Super Bowl XII, but Craig Morton frowned in concern.

title: Eileen R. Korey, a Reporter, Wed to Robert Gary Kaplan
description: Eileen Ruth Korey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Korey of Merrick, LI., was married yesterday to Robert Gary Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kaplan of North Bergen, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Burton Cohen, a cousin of the bride, at the. Oceanside (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Thais Fear to Return to Border Village Assaulted by the Cambodians
description: NON SAOAE, Thailand, Jan. 4The silence in this large village hard by the Cambodian border is so deep that if an occasional dog left behind when the in, habitants fled rustles through the leaves, the sound is heard a long way off.

title: List of Student Defaulters Shows 40% From Texas and California
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)Out of every five students who defaulted on federally guaranteed loans in the last 10 years, two came from California and Texas, according to the Federal Office of Education.

title: Limits Formally Proposed on Bank Lending Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Comptroller of the Currency today proposed a formal interpretation of the law that places a limit on lending by national banks to foreign governments, their agencies and statecontrolled entities.

title: 5YearOld Philippine Martial Law Builds Personal Power of Marcos
description: MANILA, Jan. 8When President Fer: dinand E. Marcos presided over the annual Armed Forces Day celebration here recently, he and his wife, Imelda, sat in twin antique gold throne chairs. The highbacked chairs are with the presidential couple wherever they appear in the Philippines these days and have become a widely recognized symbol of the five years of martial law under Mr. Marcos.

title: New Legal Effort to End Job Discrimination
description: Experts who have monitored job discrimination in this country think that a program soon to be initiated by the Equal Employment Opportunity. Commission may be the most important law enforcement effort ever undertaken in the field.

title: AnotherView On Equality
description: THE sports year of 1977 had miniscandals in horse racing, boxing and televised tennis, violence on the field, the rink and the court, quarrels in the clubhouse and rioting among spectators. Just at the end, thoueh. a female sportswriter contended in court that she could not cover the World Series for a weekly, magazine unless she had access to dressing rooms. Move over, John Peter Zenger, and make room for Melissa Ludtke, Sports Illustrated's Joan of Arc.

title: Letters
description: As chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Proxmire wields great power to swing Congress one way or the other..A few statements made by him recently have led some New Yorkers to regard him as an angel of vengeance eager to pulp the rug from under us when Federal assistance to the city runs out on June 30 next. Actually, this is less than likely.

title: Connors Beats Borg in 3 Sets in Battle for No. 1
description: In the showdown of worldclass tennis, the final match of the Grand Prix Masters yesterday, the wcIldand 18,590 screaming fans at Madison Square Gardengot what it had been waiting for: a player to call No. 1.

title: Transfer of PovertyAid Power to City Hall Raising Plenty of Flak, Badillo Reports
description: The most dramatic thing the Koch administration did in its first week, Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo said yesterday, was to make poverty, jobtraining and model cities programs directly answerable to the Mayor.

title: Baby Born in Antarctica
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 (AP)A boy was born yesterday at an Argentine Army base in Antarctica, and officials here say it was the first birth on the continent.

title: A Criminologist's View Of Women Terrorists
description: Last fall, a prominent West German industrialist named HannsMartin Schleyer was kidnapped and murdered by a band of terrorists. The leader of the suspected group is a 27yearold women, Freiderike Krabbe, who once studied sociology and psychology.

title: Israelis Tell of a Threat
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 8 (Reuters)The Belgian police found a homemade rocket launcher aimed at the Israeli Embassy here, Israeli sources said. A witness said the device, made of two tubes about four inches in diameter and about six inches long, had been found on a wall across the road from the embassy. The witness said wires connecting the tubes to a bat. tery had been disconnected.

title: A Problem on the Slopes? It May Be All in Your Mind
description: It used to be bend the knees; now it's bend the mind.

title: Getty Aluseum Ponders How to Use Its $800 Million
description: MALIBU, Calif., Jan. 6Posthumously, J. Paul Getty will be spending more money on art than anyone since the Medicis, perhaps more money than anyone ever did. And in the spectacular museum that he built here but never saw, his trustees have begun to decide how the money will be spent, in a way, they say, that will not disrupt world art markets.

title: VIETNAMESE DRIVEN OUT, CAMBODIAN RADIO SAYS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 8 (AP)Cambodia said today that it had driven the Vietnamese out of its Svay Rieng Province, the Parrot's Beak area that has had the heaviest fighting in the border dispute between Cambodia and Vietnam. Vietnamese radio said the Cambodian report was fabricated.

title: Love Thy Enemies List
description: WASHINGTONBert Lance sent me a friendly note the other day from Calhoun, Ga. In a firm hand, he wrote: The Bible says, Love those who despise you.  In that spirit of forgiveness, he sent holiday greetings. my friend Bert is the only politician who has compiled an enemies list for the purpose of loving those on it. But he's wrong about me: Far from despising him, I salute the President's best friend in awe, wonderment and gratitude. Consider his current contributions:

title: Sabres Topple Bruins, 53
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 8 (AP)Ron Schock's second goal of the season on a short shot late in the second period proved to be the winner tonight as the Buffalo Sabres defeated the Boston Bruins, 53, in a National Hockey League game.

title: U.S. Revises Antiterrorist System, But Some Question. Preparedness
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Carter Administration quietly reorganized its procedures for combating domestic and international terrorists last October, but Congressional critics and Government specialists still feel that the United States Government is ill prepared to deal with major attacks of terrorism.

title: Small Accountants Sue Institute, Sayinglts Rules Cut Competition
description: A group of small and mediumsized accouittlog firms has filed suit against the Aperican Institute of Certified Public Accountants, charging that the selfregulatory changes adopted recently by the trade organization are unlawful and will decrease competition in the accounting profession.

title: Susan Hirschhorn, A.M. Klebanoff Wed
description: Susan Hirschhorn and. Arthur M. Klebanoff, both of New York, were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home by Rabbi Herbert Weiner of Temple Israel in South Orange. N.J. Mr. and. Mrs. Isidor S. Hirschhorn of West Orange, NJ., and Mr. and Mrs. Michael Klebanoff of Key Biscayne, Fla., and Verona, N.J., are the parents of the couple.

title: Sick Call Spotlights Ethics of Professional Tennis
description: It was a loophole. That's what Ray Benton, the tournament director, finally called it yesterday. So did David R. Foster, the chairman of the board of the ColgatePalmolive Company, sponsor of the Grand Prix Masters tennis competition.

title: Ancient Jewish Community in Iraq Near Extinction
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan, 8 (Reuters) One of the world's oldest Jewish commu nities could be on the verge of dying.

title: Heirs of H. L. Hunt Preparing to Battle Claimant to Estate
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 8 (UPI)Dozens of lawyers representing the estate of H. L. Hunt, the late oilman, prepared today to defend the vast fortune he left from a woman who says she married Mr. Hunt 52 years ago and bore him four children.

title: Commodities
description: To say that silver was one of the most vexing futures to trade last year would be a gross understatement. Despite all the bullish fundamentals, especially the sagging dollar, the price of silver bullion went nowhere in 1977.

title: General Atomic Seeking Removal Of Judge in Suit Against Gulf Oil
description: In a surprise move, the General Atomic Company last week petitioned the New Mexico Supreme Court to halt a case now underway in Santa Fe in which the plaintiff alleges that the Gulf Oil Corporation, one of General Atomic's owners, conspired to fix uranium prices in this country.

title: 11 FROM YOUTH GANG ARRESTED BY POLICE
description: Eleven members of a Brooklyn youth gang were captured yesterday by a special police unit as they tried to seize a tenement in the Williamsburg section for a headquarters by terrorizing its residents into flight, the police reported.

title: Radio
description: 7:369 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto for Viola d'Amore and String Or. chestra in A, Vivaldi; Three Pieces for Harpsichord, Duphly; Sonata for Flute and Harp in D, Vinci; Harpsichord Concerto in D, Haydn; String Trio in B, Schubert; Immovable Do and Mock Morris, Grainger.

title: CARTER IS OPTIMISTIC ON JERUSALEM TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Carter Administration has expressed optimism in the last 24 hours over the chances for Israel and Egypt to reach agreement on a set of principles to guide further Middle East negotiations when political talks resume in Jerusalem on Jan. 16.

title: Deaths
description: AHLEFELDT  Christion William Benedict (Bent). Beloved husband of Alefte Ahlefeldt (nee Moltke). Died suddenly at his home on Parker Hill Road in Springfield, Vermont,on January 6, 1978. He Is also survived by several nieces and nephews living in Denmark. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Friends who wish may make donations in his memory to the Wingfield Hospital Building Fund.

title: VotingDate Action by Anderson to Be Signal On Possibility of G.O.P. Contest With Duryea
description: Whether the State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, is serious about running for Governor and whether there will be a Republican primary fight for the usually welldisciplined party's gubernatorial nomination should be clear within the next few weeks.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: WEDNESDAY

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 8 (AP)The supervisor of National Football League officials says there's no question Denver fumbled on the 2yard line in last week's playoff game, but officials on the field did not. see it, The Oakland Tribune reported today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ONEMAN HARVEST The prolific Bernard Malamud is today's guest as the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., near Lexington Avenue, opens the second, half of its season. The writer is best known for The Fixer, his novel of an oppresseu JCW in Czarist Russia, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award and became a film, with Alan Bates as the victimized protagonist.

title: Commodities
description: Silver prices, which traditionally move with gold, did not do so in 1977. Traders, however, detect some bullish signs that may lift silver prices this yeam. Para D6

title: Stage: Premiere For Middle Ages
description: STAMFORD, CONN. THE PRINCIPAL APPEAL of The Middle Ages, which is having its premiere at the Hartman Theater, is the large opportunity to watch Swoosie Kurtz exercise her particular comic brilliance.

title: DR. R. W. SENGSTAKEN, 54, A NEUROSURGEON ON L.I.
description: Dr. Robert W. Sengstaken, the chief of neurosurgery at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, LI., died of a heart attack yesterday in his home, 1 The Rise, Woodbury, L.I. He was 54 years old.

title: Reckoning In Namibia
description: The United States and its Western allies may soon be in another diplomatic confrontation with South Africa. This time the issue will be Namibia (Southwest Africa), the huge, mineralrich country that South Africa has administered for years but has been told by the United Nations to leave.

title: 16 Free on Bail in a Marijuana Case
description: PORTLAND >Ore., Jan. 8 (UPI)Sixteen of 17 men accused of possessing several tons of marijuana with intent to distribute it were freed on $5,000 bail each over the weekend. The 17th suspect in the case, Allan W. Pressman, 28 years old, of Seattle, remained in custody under $50,000 bail. The 17 suspected smugglers were arrested after a land, sea and air raid on a yacht and farm on the Oregon coast near the town of Bandon on Dec. 31. The marijuana, valued at $17 million, was later burned.

title: De Gustibus: Vegetable Pasta
description: It is said that most trends in food in America begin on the East Coast and go west to California. An exception is a distinct novelty that has appeared over the oast three or four years at greengrocers.

title: TEST OF ALTERNATIVE TO METHADONE IS SET
description: 750 Patients to Participate in the Treatment With the Substitute Found Encouraging Elsewhere New York City's Health Department is starting a federally supervised largescale test of at least 40 weeks on a drug alternative to methadone, following very encouraging results elsewhere.

title: U.S. SCUTTLES PLAN FOR I.R.S. COMPUTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Carter Administration has halted the development of a nationwide, $850 million computer for monitoring taxpayers that has been opposed as a threat to privacy and civil liberties.

title: New Man, New Aims At OTB
description: Bernard Rome, the Republican businessman who is expected to be elected president of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation on Wednesday, hopes to stimulate growth with a better deal for horseplayers.

title: Associated Press
description: SEARCH FOR GUERRILLAS: Rhodesian security forces at rainy checkpoint stopping sightseers from entering the Lake McLwaine Park yesterday after receiving reports of guerrilla activity in the area, 12 miles from Salisbury.

title: Scouts Report On Super Bowl
description: Football scouting is much like playing chess in that the ability to assess and then exploit strengths and weaknesses can determine the outcome of a game. Scouts are important to a football coach because they provide this crucial information.

title: U.S. Officials Fear Strike of Coal Miners Could Continue Into February
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Misjudgments by each side of the pride, determination and possibilities for compromise by the other have woven a web of snags that now seem likely to extend the monthold, strike of 160,000 Appalachian and Middle Western coal miners into February.

title: Panel Suggests Rescue Plans For Radio City
description: Voicing optimism that Radio City Music Hall could be kept open despite its huge deficits, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak announced yesterday the formation of a rescue committee consisting of representatives of government, business, labor and cultural groups.

title: Severe Drought Appears at an End As Rain and Snow Fall in Far West
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8It is raining and snowing over much of the Northwest today as it has been off and on, since late fall.

title: Television
Lawyer to Urge Park to Testify For Legislators
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Jan. 9The American lawyer for Tongsun Park said today that he would recommend to his client and to the South Korean Government that Mr. Park testify before joint closeddoor sessions of the three Congressional committees now investigating charges that Korean agents attempted to corrupt United States officials.

title: Bridge:
description: The biggest team game in the world is the Grand National, which last season attracted an entry of almost 8,000 teams. And the biggest segment of that entry, year after year, is provided by District 3, the administrative area of the American Contract Bridge League covering New Jersey, Westchester and the Hudson Valley.

title: U.S. SCUTTLES PLAN FOR I.R.S. COMPUTER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Carter Administration has halted the development of a nationwide, $850 million computer for monitoring taxpayers that has been opposed as a threat to privacy and civil liberties.

title: Seattle Cocker Best of Spaniels
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 8Ted Young Jr. of Rocky Hill, Conn., has captured the bestinshow trophy nine times in the American Spaniel Club's history of national showsmore than any other handler. And tonight in the Ho;iday Inn Jetport, Young won the top honor again i a field of 718 dogs. The total included 389 cockers in all three varieties and Young won with Ch. Tabak's Tidbit of Wynden, CDX, a superlative black cocker spaniel bitch. Young also has taken the futurity 15 times at this prestigious show.

title: Spanish Cartoonist Gently Humbles the High and Mighty
description: MADRID, Jan, 8Spain's transition from dictatorship to democracy has found an elfin chronicler, a cartoonist named Peridis, who has gently reduced politicians from loftiness to human scale.

title: Iowa's New Law on Bribery Bars Any Gift to Officials, Even Coffee
description: DES MOINES, Jan. 8Gov. Robert D. Ray of Iowa says the state's new antibribery law is so tough that if my wife cooks me a dinner and then talks about capital punishment or some other issue, we both could be in violation.

title: Walter O'Malley In the Sunshine
description: LOS ANGELES Winter has laid an icy hand on McKeever Place, back of the old leftfield stands, and there is nothing much,for city kids to do but watch the new snow blacken under soot. In colder winters long ago, a magic sounded. You threw a rubber ball against a dun brick wall and calculated how many months and weeks and days would have to pass before Jackie and Duke, Furillo and Preacher,. Campy and Pee Wee marched hnmw again to Ebbets Field. like heroes.

title: Sports Guide
description: From the time their mascot, Pete the Penguin, died of pneumonia in their first season, 196768, the Pittsburgh Penguins have played hockey with something less than verve, with very few exceptions. Now they are changing a bit, and when they face the Rangers at Madison Square Garden they will attempt to throw their weight around.

title: Computer Study of NBA. Teams
description: The table at the right introduces a computerized teampower rating system developed by The New York Times to evaluate the relative strengths of squads involved in roundrobin league play. In this case, the system has been used to evaluate the 22 teams in the National Basketball Association through games of Dec. 31.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Skateboard fanatics, there's no need to moan that winter snows will ruin your fun. Now there's the Ski Board to make your favorite pastime an allseason sport. Take your skateboard and remove the wheels. Attach a fiberglass Ski Board to the front axle and another to the rear axle. They look like miniature skis, turned up at the front and the rear, but they're much wider. This allows you to razzledazzle down a ski slope much the way you'd maneuver down the street. Ski Boards may even cause you to perfect your regular street technique, since snow is more slippery than asphalt. You'll need pair, with each board costing $17.95. At Scandinavian Ski Shops.

title: U.S. ABILITY TO END DECLINE OF DOLLAR. DOUBTED IN EUROPE
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Jan. 8As the world's central bankers converge here today for their monthly closeddoor discussions at the Bank for International Settlements, skepticism appeared to be increasing about the ability of the United States to arrest the dollar's steep decline. Renewed selling put the American currency on the defensive again last week. It was apparently related to a belief that the intervention measures announced in Washington Wednesday could not be effectively employed.

title: 76ers Top Celtics, 9491
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 (AP)Lloyd Free scored a gamehigh 20 points today to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 9491 victory over the Boston Celtics in a National Basketball Association name.

title: American Jewish Leader Leaves Israel for Visit to Sadat in Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Rabbi Alexander Schindler, chairman of the American Conference of Major Jewis,h Organizations, left today on his warjo confer with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Michalak Bows With Jerseyans
description: SATURDAY NIGHTS concert by the New Jersey Symphony at Millburn High School marked the subscription concert debut or Thomas Michalak, the orchestra's new music director.

title: Galesburg Hears the.Voice of a Native Again on Sandbur s 100th Birthday
description: GALESBURG, Iii., Jan. 8They celebrated Carl Sandburg's 100th birthday this weekend in this prairie city; the home of his memory.

title: SCHLESINGER SAYS JACKSON WILL HELP END GAS DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, a key figure in the impasse over natural gas pricing, has agreed to begin a new effort to break the deadlock, Secretary of Energy. James R. Schlesinger said today.

title: Heidi Sims Fiske, Dr. C. R. Steinman, Professor, Marry
description: Heidi Sims Fiske, a vice president of Institutional Investor Systems, was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Robert Steinman. an associate professor of medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. The ceremony was performed at the Country Club of Brookline, Mass., by Rabbi lenjamin Riidaysky of Hingham,. Mass. and the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger of the Episcopal Church of tile Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Robert Francis Fiske of Brookline and the late Mr. Fiske. She graduated from Radcliffe College and studied at Yale University and the University of Munich in Germany. She is also director of the InStitutional Investor Institute and of conference programming and is a contributinc, editor to the company's magazine, Institutional Investor:

title: Landry, Staubach: 2 Businessmen At the Pinnacle
description: DALLAS Roger Staubach has mischief on his mind. He is walking toward the sideline to confer with his coach, Tom Landry, and he knows what Landry is about to tell him. But Staubach has other ideas. He is ready for fun. The victory over Denver is assured. Now, in the closing seconds of the last regularseason game. it is play time.

title: Lowenstein, Citing Wellington, Formally Enters the Race for Koch's Congressional Seat
description: Saying It's like coming home, Allard K. Lowenstein formally announced his candidacy yesterday for the Manhattan seat in the House of Representatives that Mayor Koch quit to move into Ctiy Hall.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Jan. 8 (UPI)The French Government has opened its campaign for crucial March national elections with a program promising something for nearly everyone in an attempt to head off a strong challenge from the left.

title: Koch and Goldin Bar Any City U. Construction Pending New Master Plan
description: Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin have blocked further City University construction for the time being, by calling first for a new master plan covering all phases of higher education.

title: Unlocking the Canal Treaties
description: Since the ambitions of some Republican contenders for the White House have created so much trouble for the Panama Canal treaties, it seems only just that the ambitions of another should now be pointing the other way. Senator Howard Baker's remarks, during a visit Panama last week, may give the treaties just the push they need to win Senate support this year.

title: Saudis Said to Be Bolstering Forces Near Israel
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 8The desert kingdom of Saudi Arabia, proudbf Its warrior traditions, is reported to have set about modernizing and expanding its army in the north, near Iraq, Jordan and Israel.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: South America, West Indies, Etc. MORMACLYNX (Amer. Rep.), Rio de Janeiro Ion. 27, Buenos Aires 29 and Montevideo Feb. 1; sells from 23rd St., Brooklyn.

title: The Challenge of Educated Trout
description: CARLISLE, PA. At Letort Creek, staked to the stream bed, was a sign reading: Spawning Area. No Wading or Fishing. And then there appeared something that would gladden any fisherman: nearly a dozen heavybodied brown trout, some with their dorsal fins and backs out of the water, holding in the current. These were big, husky males, and occasionally they dashed at one another in roughhouse territorial combat. Lightcolored scrapes on the gravel bed showed where hen, or female, trout had been depositing their eggs.

title: A Parish in Brooklyn Honors Departing Priestas Brother
description: On Putnam Street in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, people like to talk about their miracle of the bellsthe French bells that were discovered and renovated in the tower of Our Lady of Good Counsel.

title: Superlatives at A.T. T.  for Good and Bad
description: Telephones are its trade, but the most conspicuous thing about the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is its size. It is, in fact, the biggest corporation on earth. There is more of it than anything else, a very ereat deal of it being people.

title: His Troupe Pays Tribute to Eglevsky
description: WHEN the ballet world loses a great dancer, it does not necessarily lose his spirit of inspiration. Nowhere was this more apparent than in the outstanding performances offered Saturday night in Hempstead, L.I., by the Eglevsky Ballet Company in tribute to its founder, Andre Eglevsky, who died last month.

title: Timbuktu's Magic Is All in Its Name Not in Its Mud Huts
description: TIMBUKTU, Mali'In Africa (a quarter of the world) men's skins are black, their hair is crisp and curled, and somewhere there, unknown to public view, a mighty city lies, called Turnbuctoo, Thackerav wrote more than a hundred years ago.

title: BEGIN CABINET BARS MORE SETTLPIENTS IN ISRAELIHELD SINAI
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 8Mindful of the sensitivity of the impending negotiations between Israel and Egypt, the Cabinet today rejected plans for establishing new settlements on Israelioccupied areas of Sinai.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Tracy Caulkins, 14, Sets 3 Swim Records
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan 8The first international swimming competition strictly for women ended here tonight with Tracy Caulkins, a 14yearold Nashville girl, emerging as the heroine after breaking three American records.

title: LEGISLATORS FOCUS ON ECONOMIC UPLIFT RATHER THAN SOCIAL
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8For the New York State Legislature, 1978 promises to be the year of economic development, a year in which words such as profit, incentives and business will be uttered often and with the utmost respect.

title: Events Today
description: DO YOU TURN SOMERSAULTS? by Aleksel Arbuzov; directed by Edwin Sherin; starring Mary Marin and Anthony Quayle; at the 46th Street Theater; 6:45.

title: What the Road Ahead Looks Like in Auto Racing
description: Ladies and gentlemen, start your engines. There is enough fuel for another season of auto racing.

title: They Give HearttoHeart Reassurance
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6Lee Stacel, a Los Angeles stockbroker, had heart surgery six and a half years ago. Like so many people who have suffered massive coronaries. Mr. Stacel spent.

title: COURT ORDER INCREASES AID TO BLIND AND DISABLED
description: A State Court of Appeals order means that aged, blind and disabled poor people in New York State may get about $12 million more a year in state and local government homerelief supplements, according to the American Jewish Committee's legal advocacy program for the aged.

title: Watson Wins at Tucson
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 8A $2 pail of golf balls that Tom Watson invested in on the practice tee this morning helped straighten out his driving; and on the final hole of the $200,000 Tucson open golf tournament he picked up a par while Bobby Wadkin's suffered a bogey.

title: Two Are Held in Theft of Rifles. And Assault on Fort Dix Guards
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 8 (AP)Two civilians are to be arraigned tomorrow on charges they assaulted two Army guards here and stole their M16 rifles, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Bristow Reigns at Dart Board
description: LONDON, Jan, 8The best players in the country were four deep at the bar for breakfast pints yesterday morning and nobody seemed to worry about hurting his chances in the fourth British open darts championships.

title: Politics and Indira Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 8A year ago, just before Indira Gandhi called the election that brought her down and reversed the course of Indian history, the Congress Party was strong and unified and it, and she, seemed nearly invincible. Now, upon the former Prime Minister's open break with the regulars, splitting the ranks into two factions, the party is weak and In disarray and Mrs. Gandhi, who last January was being called the world's most powerful woman, is widely ridiculed as scarcely more than the leader of a motley third party in Indian politics.

title: Santucci Installed as District Attorney Before 1,000
description: John J. Santucci was installed yesterday as Queens District Attorney at a ceremony attended by more than 1,000 people.

title: Mrs. Meir Leaves Hospital
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Former Prime Minister Golda Meir has returned home after spending a week in a hospital here heceuse of fatigue, a spokesman for the Beilinson Medical Center said today. The 79yearold Mrs. Meir left the hospital unnoticed on Friday, he said.

title: Police Departments in Some Areas Hire the Elderly to Do Paperwork
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI)A num. ber of the nation's police departments are hirihg the elderly to dci paperwork so that officers can spend more time fighting crime, Justice Department officials said today.

title: A 30Proof Lesson
description: A minorleague barroom brawl has developed in the Westchester town of Greenburgh following a visit by Betty Furness to the local high school. Miss Furness, who is now consumer affairs reporter for NBCTV, served a group of 12to14yearolds a strawberryflavored beverage that contained 15 percent alcohol; the scene of the children drinking from paper cups appeared on the Today show and on a local newscast.

title: Government Predicts Healthy 1978 Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (Reuters)The United States economy will continue to grow at a healthy rate this year and industry generally will flourish, the Commerce Department said in its Industrial Outlook for 1978. Real economic growth should be about 4 to 5 percent, a bit below the expected 6 percent gain for 1977, but above the historical average and better than most other major industrial countries will be able to achieve.

title: ROSE HALPRIN DIES; LEADING U.S. ZIONIST
description: Rose Halprin, one of the leading American Zionists of her time, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: M'GOVERN ARTICLE CITES EFFECT OF EAGLETON ISSUE
description: Senator George McGovern was quoted yesterday as saying that the Eagleton affair had not only destroyed his chances of winning the 1972 Presidential election but also wiped out his chances of winning another nomination for the Presidency in 1976, according to United Press International.

title: CON ED RATES IN 76 LED BIG SUPPLIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Consolidated Edison Company has the highest rates for electricity; makes the most charitable contributions and was cited for the most air pollution violations of any of the nation's 100 largest electric utilities, according to a study of the utilities performance during 1976.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 8:00(9)110E:key: Philadelphia Flyers vs. Montreal Canadiens.

title: Other Sandburg Events
description: GALESBURG, Ill., Jan. 8Following are other events to be held at Knox College this month in connection with the Carl Sandburg Centenary:

title: Severe Drought Appears at an End As Rain and Snow Fall in Far West
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8It is raining and snowing over much of the Northwest today as it has been off and on, since late fall.

title: VETO BY ONE HOUSE IS BEFORE HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Supreme Court has a fresh opportunity to resolve a controversial question with broad implications for the Federal system: Can a single house of Congress constitutionally block proposed action by a Government official or agency?

title: DeficitRidden Conrail Faces Full Audit by G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.. 8Conrail, the Northeast rail system that provides virtually ;all of New Jersey's interstate railfreight. service, will apparently undergo an investigation by the General Accounting Office.

title: 5YearOld Philippine Martial Law Builds Personal Power of Marcos
description: MANILA, Jan. 8When President Ferdinand E. Marcos presided over the annual Armed Forces Day celebration here recently, he and his wife, Imelda, sat in twin antique gold throne chairs. The hiehbacked chairs are with the nresidential couple wherever they appear in the Philippines these days and have become a widely recognized symbol of the five years of martial law under Mr. Marcos.

title: Miller and Morton Reach a Peak in Denver
description: DENVER All the Denver Broncos needed in 1977 were a coach and a quarterback. After the 1976 season there was a players revolt. Twelve veterans, including Lyle Alzado and Billy Thompson, two defensive standouts, publicly declared no confidence in John Ralston, who was then both general manager and coach. The players wanted someone else.

title: N.H.L.Gets Its Piece of TV Action
description: The National Hockey League, unable to break into network television's big three, once again is forging its own TV trail. We're out on the street selling our commercials now, Don Ruck, vice president of the league, said of the 50station independent network formed by the N.H.L.

title: Why N.B.A. Teams Succeed at Home
description: In the National Basketball Association, one themeapart from an outbreak of violence  has insistently played itself out from court to court and city to city. No coach has missed it, no player or fan; it is the inescapable fact that the team playing at home wins more often than the team on the road.

title: First Egyptian Tourist Finds Israelis Friendly
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 (UPI)sThe first Egyptian tourist here says he is having a grand time in Israel.

title: SCHLESINGER SAYS JACKSOVVILL HELP END GAS DEADLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, a key figure in the impasse over natural gas pricing, has agreed to begin a new effort to break the deadlock, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger said today.

title: Lawyer to Urge Park to Testify For Legislators
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Jan. 9The American lawyer for Tongsun Park said today that he would recommend to his client and to the South Korean Government that Mr. Park testify before joint closeddoor sessions of the three Congressional committees now investigating charges that Korean agents attempted to corrupt United States officials.

title: College Player Threatens Suit
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 8An Oklahoma State University football player threatened today to file in Federal court a classaction suit charging the National Collegiate Athletic Association with a conspiracy to violate the civil rights of the N.C.A.A. athletes throughout the United States.

title: Flu Patients Advised Not to Rush Recovery
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UPI)Persons who have the flu could help others by staying home until they are certain they have recovered, a doctor advises.

title: Associated Press
description: BY THE FOOT: Randy Manery of the Los Angeles Kings watched as a shot by Dan Maloney (7) of the Red Wings bounced over his foot for goal during play yesterday in Detroit.

title: The Spread Is the Point
description: Once, it has been recorded, a bookmaker was delighted to pay off. His name was Bob Martin, and about 20 years ago he was in big trouble. Martin and three of. his colleagues had been arrested for making book in Washington, D.C. The police gathered their evidence by putting a spike microphone into the wall of a room where Martin was. taking bets. His lawyer argued that since the spike had been driven past the midpoint of the wall, it constituted an unwarranted invasion of the premises.

title: Rising Wave of NarcoticsRelated Deaths Prompts West Berlin Government to Start Drug Program
description: WEST BERLIN, Jan. 8Before Ingo Miner gave himself the fatal injection, he wrote a farewell note to his mother. I know you want to help me, the 15yearold high school student said, but there is nothing anyone can do any more.

title: Ira Levin, Readying His New Play, Sends a Gift to Neediest Cases Fund
description: Ira Levin, the author and playwright Who has a new work Deathtrap, being prepared for production on Broadway next month, took time out to remember Ikie 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He dispatched a check for $100 and an, accomoanving not. he said:

title: IRISH FORCE WITHDRAWAL OF SOME BRITISH AGENTS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Several British intelligence agents have been recalled from duty in Belfast over the weekend after the Provisional Irish Republica.n Army broke their cover.

title: News Summary
description: Israel's Cabinet rejected plans for establishing new settlements in Israelioccupied areas of Sinai, a few days before IsraeliEgyptian negotiations are to start. But the Cabinet Secretary, Aryeh Naor, said ministers had agreed to extend agricultural lands and to encourage additional settlers to move to existing Israeli communities in northern Sinai and at the southern tip of the Sinai on the Red Sea. It also was reported that 30 members of the ultranationalist Gush Emunim, or Faith bloc, had moved into Israelioccupied Arab lands near Shiloh on the West Bank to form the nucleus of a controversial new Israeli settlement. [Page A1, Column 6].

title: State Tax Receipts Go Over $100 Billion, Rising 13.2 Percent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan: 8 (AP)For the first time, states took in more than $100 billion in taxes in the year that ended last September, the Commerce DepartAnent said today. The 50 states collected a total of $101 billion in the fiscal year 1977, an increase of 13.2 percent over the $89.3 billion collected the year before. Sales and gross receipts taxes were the major tax revenue sources, amounting to $52.4 billion, or 51.8 percent of all state tax revenue. State individual inCome taxes, the secondlargest source, totaled $25.5 billion, almost 19 percent More than in 1976.

title: The Mayor and the Schools
description: Mayor Koch believes that the New York City public schools cry out for better management, requiring a drastic reform. He believes further that because his budget provides most of the school's $3 billion budget and because he alone has a citywide mandate for improving education he should have direct control of the schools, through a chancellor who would be his choice and his employee.

title: The Case for Public Service Jobs
description: Should government become the employer of last resort for the nation's jobless? In a recent essay on the OpEd page, Prof. John Garraty of Columbia offered a classical freeenterprise analysis of the question and urged the Federal Government to get out of the jobcreation business. His thesis should not go unchallenged. Professor Garraty points out correctly that technological progress has rendered many jobs obsolete. Demand for unskilled labor is declining. The skills of former factory workers do not often match manpower needs the growing service sector. These problems are compounded each year by the entry into the market of millions of young people, many of them urban minorities, who are illprepared for jobs of any kind.

title: Judge to Hear Fraud Suits Against Army Engineers
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 8A complex series of lawsuits by landowners along the Ohio River, which carry allegations of fraud and misrepresentation in landbuying practices against the Army Corps of Engineers, is scheduled to open here tomorrow, with Judge Thomas J. Lydon of the Federal Court of Claims presiding.

title: Market Place
description: For many years Wall Street hes been preoccupied with capital gains as the best method of making money in the market. Brokers and analysts have thus emphasized priceearnings ratios, assigning the highest such ratios to the companies with the best earnings growth.

title: Billie Jean King Talks: Comeback and Other Battles
description: There are zipper scars across Billie Jean King's kneecaps, the most recent only a year old, and there is the shadow of a Wimbledon two years ago when she told the world, in her ebullient California twang, that she wasn't going to play the big ones anymore. Not long ago there was the dark possibility that she was too old (she is now 34) and too scarred to be the perpetualmotion tennis machine that she had been for years.

title: Assad Tells Interviewer Sadat's Gesture to Israel Destroyed Peace Effort
description: President Hafez alAssad of Syria has told an American interviewer that the moves by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt toward direct talks with Israel destroyed efforts for peace which were on the way to being fruitful and amounted to a shift from the proces of peace to capitulation.

title: THE REV. HENRY WINGBLADE
description: The Rev. Dr. Henry Wingblade, the president of Bethel College and Seminary in St. Paul from 1941 to 1954, died in that city on Dec. 30 after a long illness., He was 94 years old.

title: 1978 Super Circuit
description: Jan. 915Birmingham (Ala.) International Indoor.

title: Study Says Failure To Reach Arms Pact Would Weaken U. S
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Failure to reach agreement on the terms of a new SovietAmerican strategic arms accord could give Moscow a 50 percent advantage in missiles and bombers in the 1980's, according to a report released today by Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: Sports Today
description: La Salle at Hofstra. S P.M.; Robert Morris at St. Francis, S P.M.

title: Nets, Loughery Battle but ose, 9998
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 8Torn Henderson's 15foot jump shot at the buzzer gave the Washington Bullets a 9998 victory over the New Jersey Nets today, but the show belonged to Kevin Loughery, the losing coach.

title: Getty Museum Ponders How to Use Its $800 Million
description: MALIBU, Calif.,, Tan. 6Posthumously, 1.1. Paul Getty will be spending more money on art than anyone since the Medicis, perhaps more money than anyone ever did. And in the spectacular museum that he built here but never saw, his trustees have begun to decide how the money will be spent, in a way, they say, that will not disrupt world art markets.

title: 3 World Track Marks Fall
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP)Houston McTear set a world indoor record in the 60meter dash and Mike Tully soared to a world amateur polevault mark last night in the Muhammad Ali invitation track meet, the first indoor meet of the 1978 United States season.

title: JEROME I. HYMAN
description: Jerome I. Hyman, former law secretary and librarian for the Supreme Court Appellate Division, Second Judicial Department (Brooklyn), died Saturday at St. Johns Hospital in Queens after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Jersey Symphony, Under New Baton, Hailed as Opening a New Era
description: MILLBURN, Jan. 8Shouts of bravo and a standing ovation marked the start of what many people agreed was a new era: or the New Jersey Symphony last night. as Thomas Michalak, the orchestra's new music director, conducted for the first. time since being named to his postlast fall.

title: The Great HarvardStanford M.B.A. War
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.There are now in America some 360 schools more or less accredited by more or less official accrediting organizations to confirm more or less real Master of Business Administration (M.B.A.) degrees on more or less qualified graduates. In the past decade the M.B.A. has become a golden union card to access to the world's best entrylevel business jobs. For over 50 years the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration reigned supreme: the West Point of Capitalism from whence issued each year several hundred elite zealots out to fulfill the dictum that an army of rabbits commanded by lion is better than an army of lions commanded by a rabbit. According to 85 business school deans recently polled by MBA magazine, the Stanford Graduate School of Business is now on top.

title: Super Bowl a Cultural Phenomenon in Prime Time
description: If Jesus were alive today, he would be at the Super Bowl.

title: Bud Goode. Assesses the Teams
description: Bud Goode of Los Angeles is a statistician who began computer studies of professional football teams 15 years ago. Now, 10 National Football League teams use his service.

title: TV: Nabors in Variety Gig
description: THIS MORNING at 9 o'clock, WCBSChannel 2 unveils a new MondaythroughFriday variety show called The Jim Nabors Situ., Mr. Nabors once played a primetime series character named Gomer Pyle, a countrycousin type given to gulping drawls of Howdy! or Golly! Before getting into the dreary specifics of his new debut, however, it is necessary to examine the broader context of early morning programming on the flagship stations of the major networks.

title: United Press International
description: FATHER HELD FOR KILLINGS: Simon Nelson at hearing in Milwaukee Saturday where he waived extradition on charges of murdering six children. His estranged wife Ann, returned to family home in Rockford, Ill., with her lawyer.

title: Stenmark Fakes 5th Slalom in Row
description: ZWIESEL, West Germany, Jan. 8 Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden is going to lose a race some afternoon this World Cup skiing season, but it hasn't happened yet and it didn't happen today.

title: Handel's Opera Toro Is Sung in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. THE John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts began its second annual Handel Festival yesterday afternoon with a commendable concert performance of the composer's opera Poro, in what was apparently its first American performance. The festival is under the direction of Stephen Simon, who used to present Handel rarities with his Handel Society of New York.

title: New U.N. Chief Of Refugee Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 8Poul Healing, who took over last week as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, says he never expects to see the day when the refugee problem disappears. There will always be refugees, but what is not understood and what encourages me is that they are not always the same people year after year looking for help, he observed recently atter his election by the United Nations General Assembly.

title: O, Say, What Have They Done to The StarSpangled Banner?
description: Perhaps the time has come to start booing The StarSpangled Banner. Not the poor old national anthem itself, but those tasteless miscreants who sing it at televised sports events, demolition derbies, hogwrestling contests and other cultural gatherings. The anthem has become a sort of national booby prize, awarded. to popular and unpopular singers, on what grounds it is not always easy to imagine. Certainly an ability to sing the notes in tune and in time is rarely a consideration.

title: Chess:
description: When Boris Spassky fell five points behind after 10 games of his final candidates match with Viktor Korchnoi in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, it seemed he was finished. But then he won four games in a row to trail by a close 76 What happened to the apparently invincible Korchnoi?

title: 10,000 Pay Homage on Presley Birthday
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 8They came from all over the country, about 10,000 of them, the men favoring leisure suits and sideburns, the women beehive hairdos, purple eyelids and tight stretch pants, to pay homage to their hero, Elvis Aaron Presley, who would have been 43 years old today.

title: Saudis' Investments, Gold and Currency Put at $55 Billion
description: JIDDA, Saudi. ArabiaThe gold, overseas investments and convertible foreign currencies owned by the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency have risen.in value to well over $55 billion, according to informed estimates made in business circles here.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Why are the commissioners of the major sports so stubborn about resisting television reploys as an aid to officials?

title: Breathin Tokens': A Timely Collection
description: The poems in Breathing Tokens, the. new book of 118 poems by Carl Sandburg thg his daughter Margaret chose from his manuscripts and that Harcourt''race Jovanovich is releasibg to coincide with. the centenary of Sandburg's birth this weekend is not a collection that will change the contours of his work. They retain the same strengths and weaknesses.

title: BEGIN CABINET BARS MORE SETTLEMENTS IN ISRAELIHELD SINAI
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 8Mindful of thtl sensitivity of the impending negotiatiofis between Israel and Egypt, the Cabinet today rejected plans for establishing new settlements on Israelioccupied areas? of Sinai.

title: The N.C.A.A. Feels the Heat
description: ATLANTA The powerful police arm of the National Collegiate Athletic Association is undergoing a severe investigation by a Congressional subcommittee. But the members of this 723college organization, the major governing body of American intercoilegiate sports, seem much more concerned with other matters as they gather for their 72d annual convention here this week.

title: LunchProgram Supplier Assails U.S. Pay Delay
description: John Krauss Jr. runs a meatprocessing company in Jamaica, Queens, that supplies food for the federally subsidized Summer Food Service Program for children, but he is beginning to think he should find another customer for his bologna sandwiches.

title: Koth Visit to Highlight Meeting of Legialaturo Today
description: ALBANY, Jan: 8The New York State Legislature will open for business this week with the consideration of bills to amend a controversial section of the state's auto insurance law and to revise Civil Service regulations to ease the transefer of state employees from one job to another.

title: Minnesota Program Encourages Better Energy Use
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 5Declaring that the waste of limited energy resources has placed us on a collision course with disaster, Minnesota officials have begun implementing what they hope will be a comprehensive program to assure more efficient use of energy.

title: SADAT APPEARS POSITIVE ON SUGGESTION BY CARTER
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 8 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat said today that he could accept a fiveyear transition period leading to selfdetermination for Palestinians.

title: Credit Markets Face a 1978 Test
description: The credit markets this week face their first real test of the new year as $880 million of taxexempt bonds and $515 million of corporate and foreign bonds are brought to market.

title: F. HARRY BROWN, 69, AIDE OF BOOKOFMONTH CLUB
description: F. Harry Brown, executive vice president of the Bookofthe Month Club, died Saturday at his home after a short illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 241 Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan.

title: Outdoors: Watching Birds in Winter
description: SUFFERN, N. Y. Whatever vestigial notions I had held that bird watchers were all little old ladles wearing tennis shoes were quickly dispelled when Bruce B. Edinger and I walked through Kakiat County Park and began the ascent of Sherwood Path into the southern end of HarrimanBear Mountain State. Park.

title: Pinochet Says Vote Enhances Role
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 8President Augusto Pinochet, head of the Chilean military junta, said in an interview published here today that he had moved ahead of the other junta members as result of the national vote of confidence given him last week.

title: INDOCHINA CONFLICT SEEN AS PROXY WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's adviser on national security affairs, said today that the VietnameseCambodian conflict was the first instance of a proxy war between China and the Soviet Union.

title: Panel Suggests Rescue Plans For Radio City
description: Voicing optimism that Radio City Music Hall could be kept open despite its huge deficits, Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak announced yesterday the formation of a rescue committee consisting of representatives of government, business, labor and cultural groups.

title: CANAL TRUTH SQUAD PLANS A 5DAY BLITZ
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9A group of prominent conservatives, including senators, representatives and retired military leaders, announced plans today for a fiveday crosscountry blitz by a Panama Canal Truth Squad aimed at Senate rejection of the new Panama Canal treaties.

title: N.A.A.C,P. TAKES SIDE OF THE OIL INDUSTRY IN ENERGY STRUGGLE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The N.A.A.C.P. has broken with the Carter Administra-don and allied itself with the oil industry in the current battle over energy legislation.

title: TV: Salesmanship Scrutinized
description: Last week, in one of those increasingly typical televisionbycommittee projects, NBC News stuffed a massive amount of information about medicine into three very uneven hours of prime time. Tonignt at tu, tne same news organization narrows its sights considerably to look at several aspects of American salesmanship'. Produced by Karen Lerner and.with Edwin Newman as host, Land of Hype and Glory turns out to be a modest essay, admirably content to be little more than pertinent and diverting.

title: National Opera Institute Awards Mark Medium's Growth in U.S.
description: The National Opera Institute held its first Annual Awards Evening on Sunday night at the Manhattan School of Music and gave five citations for outstanding service to American opera.

title: GROUP REBUTS CRITICS OF HARP SEAL KILLING
description: A delegation of Canadians who support the hunting of harp seals, an industry that has been the target of several environmental and animal welfare groups, initiated a rebuttal campaign yesterday by asserting at a news conference in New York City that the seals were killed humanely and in numbers that permitted the species to grow. The latter assertion was challenged by an environmental group.

title: Music
description: Wriycim. Eine Kleine Nachtmusik, Mozart; Piano Concerto No. 4, Rubinstein; Symphony in 13 minor, Franck.

title: French Seek to Add Safeguards To Nuclear Pact With Pakistan
description: PARIS, Jan. 9The French Government said today that it was seeking to alter its contract to supply a nuclear reprocessing plant to Pakistan in order to insure that the installation would not produce pure plutonium, which could be diverted for use in nuclear weapons.

title: Protestants Pull Out of Ulster Talks
description: LONDON, Jan. 9Protestant leaders today pulled out of interparty talks on the future of Northern Ireland's government, complaining of meddling remarks by Prime Minister John Lynch of Hip Ppnilhlir of Trpland.

title: Carey Asks $48 Million More for This Fiscal Year
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9GOverndr Carey today asked the Legislature to appropriate an additional, $48 million for government. costs between now and April, when the state's new fiscal year begins.

title: Garda and Velez Rated in the Lead Of Large Field Seeking Badillo Seat
description: A political freeforall has developed in the South Bronx as nearly a dozen present and former officeholders struggle for the seat in the House of Representatives that Herman Badillo occupied for five years before resigning to become Debuts Mayor.

title: House Unit Is Insistent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9A senior attorney for the House ethics committee asserted today that the committee would direct Tongsun Park to testify in open session and without restrictions on questions if he returned to the United States.

title: HIGH COURT REFUSES TO EASE PRESS CURBS IN CRIMINAL TRIALS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Supreme Court refused today to consider challenges to the constitutionality of two court orders that limited news coverage of criminal trials in Ohio and South Carolina. It avoided a ruling in a thira, similar case from Pennsylvania by sending it back to the lower courts on procedural grounds.

title: Letters
description: It is clear that. The Times and the Carter Administration's philosophy on how to help working America send their children tocollege differs sharply from Mine. Tani tired of hearing that all paths lead to Washington.

title: Beverly Sills Will Retire in 1980 To Be Codirector of City. Opera
description: Beverly Sills, the Brooklyn soprano who became a star of the New York City Opera, the Metropolitan and many other leading international companies, will retire as a singer in the fall of 1980 and become codirector of the City nnnra. The artist's decision was announced yesterday aiternoon Dy John S. Samuels, chairman of the City Opera and New York City Center, and Julius Rudel, the company's director. Mr. Rudel will remain as codirector.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Supreme Court declined today an opportunity to decide whether current income tax laws unfairly discriminate against married couples while rewarding wage earners whn live together but remain single.

title: 20Year Research Effort Planned For Compiling Edison's Papers
description: WEST ORANGE, Jan. 9A major research effort to compile and publish the voluminous papers of Thomas A. Edison was announced here today by officials of Rutgers University at the library of the Edison National Historic Site, where the inventor did some of his work.

title: CHARLOTTE GOLDWATER
description: Charlotte Von Der Heyde Goldwater, who served in the Navy as a WAVE lieutenant in World War H and later was with the Veterans Administration,, working with community and service organizations, died Saturday in Chapel Hills, N.C., after a long illness. She was 60 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Grace Acquires Rentlt
description: W. R. Grace. & Company announced Cu! acquisition of RentIt Inc., a private supplier of equipment for rental and sale to the oil, petrochemical, industrial and construction industries, for an unannounced number of shares of Grace common stock. RentIt wil operate as a unit of Grace's Energy Services division.

title: Citified Handcrafters
description: Calvin Klein liked their wood bangles, combs and hair pins so much he put them on his models In his last collection. And Stephen Burrows liked them, too.

title: Adele Strauss Allen, a Founder Of Auxiliary at French Hospital
description: Adele Strauss Allen, a civic leader who helped found the Women's Auxiliary of the French Hospital in 1914, died yesterday at University Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at the Peter Cooper Hotel, at 130 East 39th Street.

title: Brooke Settlement Upheld
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., Jan. 9 (AP) Remigia Brooke's motion for a new trial in her divorce from Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, was denied today. Middlesex Probate Judge Lawrence Perara heard arguments on the motion and then upheld the divorce settlement reached last May. Under that settlement, Mrs. Brooke received $18,000 a year in alimony, medical and life insurance coverage and the couple's homes in Newton and St. Martin in the French West Indies. A divorce decree was granted on Dec. 15 and becomes final in June.

title: N.A.A.C.P. to Propose Government Job Program
description: Because President Carter has failed to move forward adequately against unemplopient, particularly with a public works program, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People plans to submit its own economic proposals that would emphasize government as the employer not of last resort but of first resort, Benjamin L. Hooks, the association's executive director, said yesterday.

title: Bratlis
description: HALPR INRose. The Officers and members of the Zionist Organization of America mourn the passing of Rose Halprin, one of America's foremost Zionist leaders, a past president of Hadassah and former chairman of the American Section of the Jewish Agency. She devoted a lifetime to tireless service In behalf of Zionism and Israel and was a vital force In the Zionist movement. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: Harsh winter weather gripped most of the nation yesterday and sent the New York metropolitan area a representative samplean arctic cold front with driving snow and winds that gusted up to 55 miles an hour.

title: French Socialist Denies Carter Assailed Red Links
description: PARIS, Jan. 9The French Socialist leader, Francois Mitterrand, has strongly denied that President Carter expressed concern to him about his party's attempts to form an alliance with the Communists.

title: Edie Beak: From Grey Gardens to Reno Sweeney
description: Picture me upon your knee, Just tea for two, and two Tor tea

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx charged that the insurance industry had for the most part abandoned the Bronx and that nearly half of the Bronx property owners who sought propertyinsurance coverage were rejected by the industry. An insuranceindustry spokesman called the charges unwarranted.

title: Old Acquaintances Don't Forget Their Annual Gifts to Neediest
description: The New Year season is traditionally a time when old friends are in the list of supporters of the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Dr. Cesare Frugoni of Italy Dies
description: ROME, Jan. 9 (AP) Dr. Cesare Frugoni, a physician whose patients included Guglielmo Marconi, the inventot of wireless telegraphy, and Mussolini, is dead at age 96. doctors said last week.

title: Old Acquaintances Don't Forget Their Annual Gifts to Neediest
description: The New Year season is traditionally a time when friends in New Jersey, as well as elsewhere, are in the list of supporters of the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
