description: For periods ended Nov. 30, unles. otherwise indicated. (N) indicales stock; is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over.thecounter. 1977 1976

title: A Day Amid 500,000 Who Create e Hubbub Of Grand Central
description: In a single day, about 500,000 people pass through Grand Central Terminal, to use it as a shortcut to other points, in midtown, to patronize its more than 100 shops and services or to board or disembark from 447 trains.

title: U.S. Penalty Cut In Steel Dumping By the Japanese
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Treasury, taking it's final action in a case that had focused attention on the increasingly bitter trade dispute between America and Japan, today cut in half the punitive duties it. had recommended against five Japanese steel producers.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED BY KOCH AND CAREY ON PLEA FOR U.S. AID
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9Mayor Kocn, Goivrnor Carey and other top state and city officials reached agreement here today to press the Federal Government for guarantees for longterm bonds for New York Cityand not simply an extensionof the shortterm loans that began in 1975. The shortterm, or seasonal, loan program is scheduled to expire in June.

title: Hope Fades for Cambodian Refugees in Thailand
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Jan. 4With Cambodia's cities emptied of their populations, which have been regrouped into rural communes, a barren, sandy piece of flatland outside this Thai border town may be the largest Cambodian town in existence. More than 7,300 people wait in a refugee camp here for new homes to be found for them.

title: Westway TradeIn
description: The shakiest possible basis on which Mayor Koch could choose Westway over its mass transit alternative is the argument that the 4.2mile interstate highway project for the Lower West Side of Manhattan will proviae significantly greater employment and other economic benefits for New York City than will massive rehabilitation of the bus and subway system.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The CocoaColi Company plans to enter the plastic packaging and film products field through the proposed acquisition of Presto Products, for stock valued at about $46 million.

title: Deaths
description: FIALPRIN,Rose L. The World Zionist Organization Executive deeply mourns the passing of one of the major figures in The Zionist Movement. An architect In the building of the State of Israel. With her election to The Jewish. Agency Executive. In 1946; Mrs. Halprin participated actively at The National and International Negotiations which led to the establishment of the State of Israel. She served as Chairman of the JewishAgencyAmerican Section for 8 years and was also National President of Hadassah from 193234 and again from 194751. Mrs. Halprin participated in World Zionist Congresises and meetings of the General Zionist Council for many years. Deeply concerned with relations between Israel and The Jewish Community in the Diaspora especially in The US and with the future of Jewish Education she made major contributions in these areas, both here and In Israel. Since 1968 she has served  with distinction as chairman of the World Jewish CongressAmerican Section and as. a member of the General Council of The World Zionist Congress. Her Wide knowledge keen and analytical mind and fearless ad vow, of Zionist Goals were semimal Influences In the education of Countless Zionists. A gifted orator who combined the Intellectual and the emotional, the inspirational and the informative, she will be most sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her children, Ruth & Lawrence, her grandchildren and her sisters and brother and loin with  them in their sorrow. Josef Almogi, Chairman World Zionist Organization Executive Charlotte Jacobson, Chairman American Section Isadore Hamlin, Executive Vice.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
An ExCongressman Cleared of Bribery
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 9The Federal Government dropped a bribery prosecution today against former Representative Edward A. Garmatz of Maryland after it announced at the outset of his scheduled trial Here that a main prosecution wit1 ness, Edward J. Heine Jr., the president of United States Lines, had created false documentation to support the bribery charges.

title: High Court Bars Tax Deduction On Pro Football's TV Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)The Supreme Court, acting in a brief order, without opimuli, agreed with the Federal Government today that television contracts with football teams were not a depreciating asset. It ruled against the Atlanta Falcons minority owner, E. Cody Laird, who had sought to claim tax deductions from the club's share of revenues from National Football League telecasts.

title: CAPTAIN SAYS INCIDENTS ON CARRIER ARE JUVENILE
description: MAYPORT, Fla., Jan. 9 (UPI)A series of destructive incidents on the 80,000in:ifcarrier Saratoga are not acts of sabotage but little juvenile things, the ship's skipper, Capt. Charles B. Hunter, said today.

title: Soccer Gets New Foilnat 6 Divisions
description: Phil Woosnam, the commissioner of the North American Soccer League, announced yesterday the realignment of the league's 24 franchises to provide what he called excellent television marketing opportunities.

title: HIGH COURT REFUSES TO EASE PRESS CURBS IN CRIMINAL TRIALS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Supreme Court refused today, to consider challenges to the constitutionality of two court orders that limited news coverage of criminal trials in Ohio and South Carolina. It avoided a ruling in a third, similar case from Pennsylvania by sending it back to the lower courts on procedural grounds.

title: Howe, 49, an AllStar 27th Time
description: HARTFORD. Jan. 9 (AP)Gordie Howe, now 49 years old, was among nine players added today to the World Hockey Assbciation allstar team by Coach Bill Dineen of the Houston Acros.

title: Talks Pressed to Avert Building Workers Strike
description: Union and management negotiators continued bargaining talks early today in an effort to work out a new agreement that would avert a strike threatened for this morning by 30,000 service employees at 2,500 commercial buildings in New York City.

title: SADAT AND SHAH OF IRAN CONFER TWICE AT ASWAN
description: CAIRO, Jan. 9President Anwar elSadat pushed ahead today with his campaign to garner support for his Mideast peace initiatives by receiving the Shah of Iran at Aswan.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CONCORDIA SKY (Concordle). Les Palmas Jan. 21, LImauol Fcb. 1, Beyrouth 2 and Latakia 4; sails trom Pt. Newark, N.J.

title: Korchnoi and Spassky Draw
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 9 (UPI)Boris Spassky and Viktor Korchnoi today drew the 16th game of their chess match to determine who will challenge the world champion. The 17th game will begin today. Korchnoi leads, 8 to 7. The first player to reach 10 points wins the right to challenge the champion, Anatoly Karpov, later this year.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Brazen Blinky Wants a License
description: One of boxing's most notorious scoundrels, Francis (Blinky) Palermo, has filed an application with the Pennsylvania Athletic COmmission for a manager's license. Insteacr of Blinky, perhaps Brazen would now be a better nickname. For. the Pennsylvania commission to grant Blinky Palerrno a manager's license would be like a law school hiring Richard Nixon as an ethics professor. But strangely, the commission chairman, Howard McCall, sounds symnathetic to Blinkv's case.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: CORSONRobert S., The officers of the United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign and its Furniture, Bedding and Allied Industries Division note with profound sorrow the untimely passing of a distinguished communal leader who served outstandingly as chairman of the industry campaign. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife Judith and the other members of the bereaved family.

title: Bridge:
description: Psychic bids have long been out of favor with the experts for a variety of reasons. When partner is deceived, there may be a disaster. When partner is not deceived, the opponents are liable to complain about an improper partnership understanding.

title: Death
description: ilIERNDenis J., January 7, 1978 son of the late Denis & Mary Ann Ahern. Mass of the Resurrection Wednesday, 9:30 AM Our Lady of Peace RC. Church. Reposing at the Chapel of Joseph G. Duffy, 9th St betwn 4th & Sth Ave, Bklyn.

title: Panamanians Stage Rally in Zone On the Anniversary of 1964 Riots
description: BALBOA, Canal Zone, Jan 9 (AP)Thousands of Panamanian demonstrators marched into the Canal Zone today. A student leader told them Panamanians would act in whatever means necessary if the United States Senate did not approve the Panama Canal treaties 1 within three months.

title: A Proposed Revision in Labor Law Assailed by Chamber of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that the proposed revision of labor laws would force naive or unwilling workers into unions and would eventually. triple union membership.

title: KITIMAT PIPE LINE PLANS TO RENEW APPLICATION
description: The Kitimat Pipe Line Ltd., announced today that it would reactivate its application before the Canadian National Energy Board to build a tanker terminal at Kitimat, British Columbia, and a crude oil pipeline to Edmonton, Alberta.

title: Market Place
description: In CB radio language 10:34 means emergency; 10:37 means send wrecker; and 10:38 means send ambulance. At this point, manufacturers might be forgiven if they sent all three messages.

title: Fed Member Worried by Rate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Charles Partee, one of two Federal Reserve Board members who dissented in last Friday's split decision to increase the discount rate, said today he was concerned about the risks it meant for the American economy. And he said he felt it wouldn't have too much effect in helping the dollar.

title: Deaths
description: FILEPaul. The Officers & Members of The Amalgamated Clothing & Textile Workers Union, AFLC10, mourn the passing on Jan. 9, 1978 of their esteemed colleague, manager of the union's affiliates, the Cleaners & Dyers Joint Board. His contributions to the welfare of Cleaning & Dyeing Workers In this area for over 40 years will be long remembered. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. A funeral service will be held on Wed., Jan 11, at 12 noon at Jeffers Funeral Chapel, 188 St & Hillside Ave, Queens. Murray Finley, President Jacob Sheinkman, Secy Treas Sol Stetln, Sr Exec VP William DuChessi, Exec VP.

title: Events Today
description: OLD MAN JOSEPHAND HIS'FAMILY, directed by Robert KAlfin, starrino Lou Gilbert and the Colonnades Theater Lab, at the Chelsea Theater Center of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at 8.

title: BEGIN WINS BACKING FOR HIS PEACE PLAN
description: JERUSALEM Jan. 9 (Reuters)Prime Minister Menahem Begin won backing for his Middle East peace plan from his rightwing Herut Party today. But Government ministers appeared still sharply split over whether new Jewish settlements should be set up on occupied Arab land.

title: Jan. 16 Deadline on Flood Loans
description: The Small Business Administration announced yesterday that applications for loans to cover losses from last November's flooding must be submitted by Jan. 16. Persons in Queens, Staten Island and Rockland County affected by the Mooing may apply for aid through four S.B.A. offices; 201 Varick Street in Manhattan; 777 Seaview Avenue on Staten Island; 12055 Queens Boulevard in Queens, and 8 Maple Avenue in Spring Valley, N.Y. Up to $10,000 is available in personalproperty disaster aid, $50,000 in home loans, and $500,000 in business loans.

title: State Department Cautious
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The State Department declined today to endorse Mr. Brzezinski's view that the conflict between Cambodia and Vietnam was a proxy war between China and the Soviet Union.

title: News Summary
description: France is attempting to change the terms of its contract to supply a nuclear reprocessing plant to Pakistan to insure that plutonium, which could be diverted for use in nuclear weapons, will not be produced. The Government had dented for months that it was trying to change the contract. A statement from the Foreign Ministry said that modification of the reprocessing plant had been proposed to Pakistan last September. Nuclear proliferation was one of the topics discussed by President Carter and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing in Paris last week. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: 20Year Research Effort Planned For Compiling Edison's Papers,
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 9A major research effort to compile and publish the voluminous papers of Thomas A. Edison was announced here today by officials of Rutgers University at tiie library of the Edison National Historic Site, where the inventor did some of his work.

title: 10 Soviet Officials to Visit U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  Ten members of the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet Union's top parliamentary body, will arrive here Jan. 22 for an 11day visit to the United States. The Soviet group's visit is in response to an invitation extended last year by the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and the Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd.

title: Women Fear Interference By N.C.A.A.
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 9The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women, which is seven years old, and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which is 72, may never join forces. But for this week, at least, they are closer than. ever because both are in conventions in the same city for the first time.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STARDUST Starting. today, two midtown stores are offering free diversions for browsers and shoppersone a pictorial history of Thais before its new production at the Metropolitan Opera, and the other a zodiac showcase that will include free horoscope readings.

title: Israeli Government Submits New Budget, Sees Cut in Inflation
description: TELAVIV, Jan. 9Introducing the Begin Government's first national budget bill in Parliament, Finance Minister Simha Ehrlich predicted today that prices would rise by about 30 percent this year.

title: Stock Exchange Aide Optimistic About State Economy
description: NEWARK, Jan. 9Dr. William C. Freund of Millington, senior vice president and chief economist of the New York Stock Exchange, forecast today a much brighter economic future for, the State of New Jersey.

title: Advertising
description: Tampax Inc., which took a strong stand against allowing feminine hygiene products to advertise on television, is itself bowing to competitive pressure and is already using TV in two test markets. By the middle of this month, its commercial wilt De in the New York market, and from there it will roll out to the rest of the country.

title: Dancers Play Let's Pretend For Robbins
description: In Ma Mere L'Oye (Mother Goose), which entered the New York City Ballet's winter repertory Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater; Jerome Robbins asks his audience, Let's pretend.

title: CITY HOSPITAL CLINICS TO UPGRADE STAFFS
description: New York Plans to Have Trained Physicians Replace Interns and Residents in a Year

title: Miller's Fortune Estimated at $2.4 Million
description: G. William Miller, the newly designated chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has a private fortune of at least $2.4 million, consisting mostly of stock in Textron Inc., the company he has headed for nearly a decade.

title: Two Countries Exchange Charges
description: BANGKOK,. Thailand, Jan. 9 (AP)Cambodia reported today that it had dealt Vietnam a defeat in the border war between the two countries, but Thai intelligence sources said Vietnamese troops were entrenched well inside Cambodia.

title: Penguins Conquer Rangers
description: If you'd had the choice last, night of staying home and watching the Montreal Canadiens, Stanley Cup champions, play the hot Philadelphia Flyers on television, or braving 20degree temperatures to watch the Rangers take on the Pittsburgh Penguins, what would you have done?

title: P.S.C. GRANTS LILCO A $59.7 MILLION RAISE
description: MINEOLA,. LI, Jan. 9The State Public Service. Commission granted'the Long Island Lighting Company a rate increase of $59.7 million today, which will increase the bill of the utility's average customer by 8.4 percent.

title: Dale Livingston, Baritone, Offers Strauss Group
description: Dale Livingston's recital of songs and arias in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night was a tasteful if essentially modest affair. The baritone, who made his 1Itw York debut in 1972, has a somewhat dry, nasal voice that is fairly limited in terms of sheer tonal allure, but he wisely chose material that seldom required him to go beyond his most effective range.

title: Deaths
description: BROWNF. Harry Schocken Books Inc & the Schocken family In Israel & The United States mourn the passing of our beloved friend counselor. He has enriched our lives by his, high integrity, his quiet good humor & his unfailing wisdom.

title: Gei.mans Said to Seek A Takecver of Budd
description: Gilbert F. Richards, chairman of the Budd Company, prepared last night to fly to Paris as reports circulated in Wall Street that a major European companybelieved to be West German was negotiating to take over the automotive supplier.

title: MRS. GANDHI APPEARS BEFORE INQUIRY PANEL
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi finally appeared today before the judicial commission that is investigating her government. But she sat quietly before the bench while her lawyers gave arguments challenging the demand that she testify.

title: Stenmark Runs Streak To 6 With Slalom Victory
description: ZWIESEL, West Germany, Jan. 9With an air of inevitability, Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won the World Cup slalom race here today, his sixth victory in six slalom and giant slalom races this season.

title: Retailers Are Told Sales Will Dip This Year From 4th Quarter High
description: Consumer buying of general merchandiseclothing, appliances, furniture and the likewill dip from the unexpected high level of the 1977 final quarter, merchants attending a national convention were told here yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee on Palestinian RightsMeets at 10:30 A.M.

title: NewarkBased Coalition Stresses Need for VHF TV Channel
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9A Newarkbased coalition told 11 Federal appeals court today that it was unfair for New Jer, y, the nation's most densely populated state, not to have a very, high frequency commercial television channel of its own.

title: Zuccotti Returns Extra Severance Of $9,600 to Goldin With a Letter
description: Former First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti yesterday returned the extra severance pay he received under a change in city rules adopted only a few days before he left the administration of former Mayo Abraham D. Beame.

title: Leonard Silk; Dollar's Ills Real or Fancied?
description: Economics Is full of fallacies, some of them pathetic.

title: CHASE AND CHEMICAL JOIN PRIMERATE RISE
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, Chemical Bank and several smaller banks yesterday joined the move initiated Friday to raise the prime lending ratethe interest they apply big corporate borrowersto 8 Percent from 7.75 percent.

title: Shah's Nephew Ordered to Trial
description: NEVADA CITY, Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI)Darius Pahlavi Hillyer, a nephew of the Shah of Iran, pleaded not guilty today to charges of assaulting two police officers after a highspeed auto chase in November. Judge Frank. Francis of Nevada County Superior Court ordered. Mr. Hillyer, a 20yearold college student, to go on trial March 14 on two felony counts of battery.

title: CONTROVERSIAL OFFICIAL ON I.C.C. STAFF DISMISSED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that Robert L. Oswald, a controversial highranking staff member, had been dismissed effective Wednesday.

title: Moscow Denounces Brzezinski's Views About  Proxy War
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9The Soviet press agency Tass took issue today with an assertion by Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's adviser on national security affairs, that fighting between Vietnam and Cambodia represented the first case of a proxy war between China and the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Penalty Cut in Steel Dumping By the Japanese
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The Treasury, taking its final action in a case that had focused attention on the increasingly bitter trade dispute between America awl Japan, today cut in half the punitiVe duties it had recommended against five Japanese steel producers.

title: Making the German Locomotive Pull
description: The measures needed to lift the industrial democracies out of their deepest and longest recession since the 1930's have been the subject of a dialogue of the deaf between Washington and Bonn. A new international study forecasts reduced growth and rising unemployment for Western Europe in 1978and perhaps for some Arne to comeunless West Germany, Japan and the United States soon adopt expansionary measures. How can Bonn be brought to accept this reasoning?

title: Kentucky Routs Auburn For 11th Straight, 10177
description: AUBURN, Ala., Jan. 9 (AP)Jack Given scored 25 points, and Truman Claytor and Rick Robey combined for 37 points to lead Kentucky to its 11th college basketball victory without loss, a 10177 triumph over Auburn tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: DE LA ROCHE JURORS TOLD OF FINGERPRIN1
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 9A fingerprint allegedly belonging to Harry De La Roche Jr. was found on the sixfoot metal cabinet where the body of his 15yearold brother Ronald was hidden after the youth was shot to death, tingerprint. expert for the State Police testified today.

title: Alaska Asks Government to Clean Up Junk Abandoned in Wilderness
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 9 (AP)The state wants Washington to clean up mountains of Federal junk that have piled up over the years.

title: Parks to Him Are City's Gems
description: Gordon J. Davis. whom Mayor Koch appointed yesterday to be Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, spent his last two summer vacations in the New York City parks. And we were no different from anybody else who couldn't get away from the city, the 36yearold lawyer said during a break in proceedings of the City Planning Commission, of which he has been a member since 1973. He and his wife, Penny, live what he describes as a crowded but in terms of public service a very rewarding life.

title: Deaths
description: PIVARElairie. Beloved Mother of Carol Miller & Stuart Pivar. Dear', sister of Anne Baker, Vivian Yatlin, Murray, Jack & Jules Lesser. Cfferr._ 'shed grandmother of Janice, Kenneth & Jeffrey Miller & Marlorle, , Amy & Nancy Pivar. Services today 12 noon ar Gutterrnan's, 8000 Jerk cho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: News Summary
description: France Is attempting to change the terms of its contract to supply a nuclear reprocessing plant to Pakistan to insure that plutonium, which could be diverted for use in nuclear weapons.. will not be produced. The Government had denied for months that it was trying to change the contract. A statement from the Foreign Ministry said that modification of the reprocessing plant had been proposed to Pakistan last September. Nuclear proliferation was one of the topics discussed by President Carter and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing in. Paris last week. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: An ExCongressman Cleared of Bribery
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 9The Federal Government dropped a bribery prosecution today against former Representative Edward A. Garmatz of Maryland after it announced at the outset of his scheduled trial here that a main prosecution witness, Edward J. Heine Jr., the president of United States Lines, had created false documentation to support the bribery charges.

title: A Pittsburgh Publisher Says That He Withdrew Investment in The Trib
description: Richard Mellon Scaife, a Pittsburgh suburban newspaper publisher, said yesterday that he instructed his lawyer to withdraw a check for $200,000 that was to have been invested in The Trib, New York City's new morning newspaper.

title: Robert Murphy, Diplomat, Dies
description: Former Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, the career diplomat credited with planning the Allied invasion of North Africa in World War 11, died yesterday at his home at 1009 Park Avenue. He was 83 years old and had been ill since suffering a stroke last November.

title: A Pittsburgh Publisher Says That He Withdrew Investment in The Trib
description: Richard Mellon Scaife, a Pittsburgh suburban newspaper publisher, said yesterday that he instructed his lawyer to withdraw a check for $200,000 that was to have been invested in The Trib, New York City's new morning newspaper.

title: 7 Largest Shipbuilders of Japan Showed 37.9% Drop in Tonnage
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (AP)Production of Japan's seven largest shipbuilders in 1977 dropped 37.9 percent in tonnage from the preceding year, the Shipbuilders Association of Japan reported today.

title: Paraguay Reported Ready to Allow Group to Visit for Rights Inquiry,
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 9 (AP)President Alfredo Stroessner has decided to allow the first onthespot investiga. tion of human rights in Paraguay by an outside group, according to the news. naoer Ultima Hora.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Thursday reported incorrectly that the Advertising Club had folded. The Advertising Club sold its Park Avenue building but its 250 members now have privileges at the Women's Republican Club and a membership drive is under way.

title: A Family That's GlidingThrough Show Business
description: There are moments when the Fenton family of Detroit seems to be lifted from a Grated Hollywood script.

title: Stage: Mary Martin in Do You Turn Somersaults?
description: If Do You Turn Somersaults? was intended as a vehicle for Mary Martin's return to Broadway after 10 years, she should have taken a bus.

title: MARION RICE KIRKWOOD, 90; WAS STANFORD LAW DEAN
description: Marion Rice Kirkwood, who served as a faculty member of the Stanford Law School from 1912 to 1922 and as dean of the law school from 1922 to 1945, died Sunday at a convalescent hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 90 years old.

title: Cowboys and Broncos Touch Down
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9The actors for Sunday's Super Bowl game, the Dallas Cowboys and the Denver Broncos, arrived here late today prepared and ready to kick off tomorrow.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Thursday reported incorrectly that the Advertising Club had folded. The Advertising Club sold its Park Avenue building but its 250 members now have privileges at the Women's Republican Club and a membership drive is under way.

title: A Leaky Concorde Turns Back
description: An Air France Concorde jetliner with 35 passengers and crew aboard developed an oil leak and returned safely to Kennedy International Airport with one engine shut down yesterday, officials said. The jetliner had departed at about 11 A.M. and about 45 minutes later, over Gander, Newfoundland, the pilot radioed that he was returning to Kennedy. It landed safely at 2 P.M.

title: New York Is Redefining Its Budget In Effort to Narrow Financial Gap
description: Struggling to recompute its budget closer to balance, New York City is trying to redefine what it means by expense items in the capital budget. As now defined, those items are estimated to total $643 million.

title: Dollar Gains With U.S. Aid: Gold Also Up
description: United States Government actions and gestures designed to bolster confidence in the dollar helped the American curren cy gain ground yesterday in foreignex-, change trading overseas and in New York according to The Associated Press.

title: Buddy GuyJunior Wells Blues Pitted Against Son Seal Sound
description: The last few months have been goad ones for blues lovers, with Radio City Music Hall's Blues Show and the Foghat Blues Tribute particularly outstanding events.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Whitecollar crime is a disturbing phenomenon whose dimensions are often obscured by Secrecy, but some newlyreleased statistics compiled by the Internal Revenue Service shed fresh light on the incidence of tax evasion by highincome professionals such as lawyers, doctors and executives.

title: Appellate Court Upsets 11 Police Payoff Convictions
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court overturned yesterday the bribery convictions of 11 police officers who had been accused of having taken part in the collection of $20,000 a month from gamblers in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The court cited lack of corroborating evidence from witnesses.

title: FILIPINOS IN 11.S.ASSAIL 441 TRAINEE PROGRAM
description: DURHAM, N.C.A group of Filipino agricultural trainees working in the United States under a program spansored by the National 4H Council and the Government of the Philippines have signed a protest statement contending that the program provides no training but instead is a cheap labor scheme that has had some of the trainees working 12 to 14 hours a day under bad conditions for three months without a break. The trainees, mostly young men in their 20's, have been joined in their protest by a group of North Carolinians calling themselves the Support Committee for the 4H Trainees.

title: U.S. and Japan Pressing for Accord in Trade Dispute
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9Amid a stream of bilingual news conferences and bilateral lobbying sessions, Japanese and American officials opened a new round of workinglevel discussions here today in an effort to settle, at least for the moment. their continuing trade dispute.

title: Notes on People
description: A terse threeline statement distributed yesterday by Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, announced the separation of Hamilton Jordan, President Carter's top aide, and his wife. Nancy. The Jordans. both 32 years ma, saia in tne statement: we have decided to separate. We know that our friends and families will understand and respect our mutual decision. Neither would discuss the reasons for the separation. Asked if the pressures of Washington had been too much for the marriage, Mrs. Jordan replied: I love working in politics. I enjoy Washington and my work and politics. Mrs. Jordan has been a fulltime volunteer working with the President's wife.

title: Polish Leader Announces a Gradual Economic Plan To Bring the Price of Food Into Line With Its Costs
description: WARSAW, Jan. 9Edward. Gierek, the Polish Communist leader, proposed today that gradual steps be taken toward ending imbalances between rising wages and stationary prices and curing other economic ills.

title: M'GIURE WILL APPOINT: WOMAN AS A TOP AIDE
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, who took office Jan. 2, and has been quickly putting his imprint on the Police Department, said yesterday that he would appoint a woman to be a deputy commissioner.

title: Brezhnev Is Reported to Be III; Talks With Japanese Aide in Doubt
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (UPI)President Leonard I. Brezhnev is suffering complications from a fourweek illness and may not receive Japan's Foreign Minister, Sunao Sonoda, Japanese sources said today.

title: Balanchine Sonatine Danced in a New Idiom of Costuming
description: Times change. Ballets do, too. when George Balanchine created a pas de deux called Sonatine to open the New York City Ballet's 1975 Ravel Festival, It seemed very much a niece d'occasion.

title: Miller Beer Case Comes to a Head: Light Isn't Lite
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Beer manufacturers may use the term light to identify or advertise their lowcalorie products without violating the trademark of the Miller Brewing Company for its Lite beer, under a ruling of the Supreme Court.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk discusses some apparently fallacious logic that appears in discussions of the relationship between the weakness of the American dollar and the state of health of the domestic economy. Page 51.

title: For Wage Subsidies To Help Fight Unemployment
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassThe United States is a schizophrenic society when it comes to Rrovidihg employment for everyone willing and able to work. If one were to listen to our July rhetoric, one would think that the United States was the ultimate work ethic society.

title: Major British Oil Find Just a Nuisance for Landowner
description: A major oil strike during the Christmas holidays makes the field under his Wytch Farm the biggest onshore field ever discovered in Britain. Though it is nothing to compare with the vast reservoirs under the North Sea, it is still worth more than $1 billion at current prices.

title: CLEVELANDERS ARE URGED TO SUPPORT PEOPLE MOVER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Federal public transit officials, thwarted in their efforts to begin a demonstration people mover in Cleveland because of resistance by the Mayor there, have told local officials to line up behind the $50 million project or risk losine it.

title: Deaths
description: McPHERSONSarah. On January 1, 1978. Survived by daughter,: Clara Reiss and grandchildren, Robert and Yvonne Reiss.. Memorial service 3:30PM Saturday, January 14, at Community Church Chapel, 40 E.35 St., NYC.

title: Lions Oust Hudspeth, All Of His Aides
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 9 (UPI)The Detroit Lions today dismissed their head coach, Tommy Hudspeth, and his eightman coaching staff. The move confirmed rumors that started at the conclusion of the National Football T rpatilar season.

title: Giant Lottery Aids Catholic Churches in Pennsylvania
description: MORTON, Pa., Jan. 9 (AP)Roman Catholic churches in eastern Pennsylvania, financially pressed by rising costs, have joined in a giant lottery to raise money.

title: FRENCH AMBASSADOR TO NAZI BERLIN DIES
description: PARIS, Jan. 9Andre FrangoisPoncet, who was France's Ambassador in Berlin during Hitler's rise to power and who warned repeatedly and futilely about Germany's rearmament, died yesterday at his home here, it was learned today. He was 90 years old.

title: Earthqpakes a Constant Concern For People of Soviet Central Asia
description: TASHKENT, U.S.S.R.  One of the prebccupations of life in Soviet Central Asia, is earthquakes. Here in the capital of Uzbekistan a major temblor in 1966 destroyed 35 percent of the mudhut buildings that predominated in the city then. In Dushanbe. the capital of neighboring Tadzhikistan; the autehorities have only recently begun building quakeproof structures higher than four stories.

title: BYRNE DRAFTS PLAN FOR 70,000 NEW JOBS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9Governor Byrne will propose in his State of the State mes. sage tomorrow to the incoming 198th Legislature a new economic strategy designed to provide up to 70,000 new jobs annually and to revitalize New Jersey's Urban renters.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED BY KOCH AND CAREY ON PLEA FOR U.S. AID
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9Mayor Koch Governor Carey and, other top state and city officials reached agreement here today to press the. Federal Government for guarantees for longterm bonds for. New York Cityand not simply an extension, of the shortterm loans that began in 1975. The shortterm, or seasonal, loan program is scheduled to expire in June. The Governor and the Mayor continued to disagree, however, on state aid for the city, which Federal officials said should be increased to ease the city's financial problems.

title: :About New York
description: The 9:15 morning express bus swings away from the curb at its terminal point in Fresh Meadows, Queens, to start its journey to Manhattan and 1rwin Rawitz's seat is empty. This brings a measure of miler to ins tnenas wno have just boarded and taken their own regular seats, because Mr. Rawitz, who gets on at the'next stop, three blocks away, is unhappy when strangers preempt his seat, the one with the leg room on the right side of the aisle, just behindthe middledoor well.

title: Interpreter Explains Polish Slips
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Steven Seymour, whose interpreting slips dominated much of the news during President Carter's visit to Poland, today discussed what happened, to savein his wordssome poor interpreter in the future from such.embarrassment.

title: Music: Recital Of Poem Songs By Miss Steele
description: It seems reasonable to ask that an art song adds to a poem something that is not.already there. Otherwise (assuming the poem is any good) the music is superfluous. It can even get in the way, which is what happens in many of the. American songs Janet Steele sang Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. including seven new ones.

title: Sports Today.
description: Knicks vs. Trail Blazers, at Portland, Ore. (Television  Channel 9, 11 P.M.) F.D.U. at Pace, 8 P.M.; William and Mary vs.Rutgers at Piscataway. N.J., 8 P.M. Princeton at Seton Hall, 8 P.M. (Radio WVNJ, 8 P.M.).

title: Kent State Coach Ousted
description: KENT, Ohio, Jan. 9 (AP)  Rex Hughes Jr., basketball coach at Kent State University for 3% years, was dismissed today and replaced by Mike Boyd, an assistant.

title: Orange Juice Prices Soar as Frost Is Reported in Florida
description: Reports of a frost in Florida sent frozen orange juice futures soaring yesterday on the New York Cottcn Exchange. The unrestricted spot January delivery, which goes off the board next Tuesday, jumped 23.50 cents a pound to close at $1.215.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 9 (AP)Foreign journalists have begun submitting routine', dispatches on Rhodesia's fiveyear guerrilla war to, military censors.

title: Study Backs U.S. Nuclear Posture
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9A Congressional report said today that the United States would retain the ability to inflict devastating retaliation on the Soviet Union in the mid80's despite Soviet missile advances.

title: Molin TooBusay Winning ToWatch Borg, Connors
description: Jon Molin, a tall, slim tennis player with wide shoulders and a long reach, didn't watch Jimmy Connors and Bjorn Borg battle for $100,000 in the Grand Prix Masters final on Sunday. He was too busy playing for $500 in the final of the Eastern men's championship at Stadium Tennis in the Bronx.

title: A Power Line Protest is Peaceful
description: LOWRY, Minn., Jan. 9 (AP)Protesters who oppose the construction of a power line across an area of rich farmland faced a large contingent of state troopers today and offered them plastic carnations and cookies while the troopers stood by to protect construction crews. ne protest was peacerui, temperea by a temperature of 20 degrees below zero and a stiff wind that dropped the windchill factor to 50 below zero.

title: FakeBomb Attempt To Rob a Bank Fails
description: Four gunmen wired a realisticlooking bomb to an assistant manager of a branch office of a bank in Brobklyn at 9:30 A.M. yesterday and told him to take money from the branch or the bomblike devicewinch turneaout to be a fakewouldbe detonated, according to detectives of the police majorcase squad, which investigates bank robberies.

title: People and Business
description: Charles W. Robinson, who was Deputy Secretary of State in the Ford Administration, has joined Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, the securities firm, as vice chairman and member of the executive committee. He will concentrate on investment banking operainns.

title: A Day Amid 500,000 Who Create Hubbub Of Grand Central
description: 4:38 A.M.In the dark and chill, a solitary figure taps on the glass door of the rain entrance to Grand Central Terminal at 42d Street. Inside, a policeman shouts. The station is closed.

title: James Tuite's Notebook
description: Strangely enough, Sonny Werblin's first acquisition as president of Madison Square Garden may be a race track in New Jersey, where the entrepreneur staged his most recent success.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP)Steve Cauthen did not ride a winner last weekend at Santa. Anita. The 17yearold Cauthen, whose mounts earned more than $6 million in 1977, was shut out Saturday and yesterday. But Cauthen remained the lop jockey at the current Santa Anita meeting with 17 victories, one more than Darrel McHargue.

title: STOCK PRICES DROP FIFTH DAY IN A ROW AMID RATE WORRIES
description: The pellmell plunge of stock prices continued unabated yesterday in the markets fifth consecutive decline of 1978 amidst renewed Wall Street fears of rising interest rates. Trading volume was heavy. The markers bestKnown barometer, the Dow Jones industrial average, told the story vividly. The bluechip indicator dropped 8.93 points to 784.56, thereby sinking once again to its lowest level in more than two years.

title: Deaths
description: HALPRINRose L. The Officers. Members of its governing bodies and staff of the World Confederation of United Zionists record their profound sorrow at the passing of Its Honorary Life President and former. CoChairman, Rose L. HaIrwin an early pioneer in the Zionist movement, ranking among the coarchitects of the State of Israel. A founder of the World Confederation of General Zionists at the Zionist Congress In Basle, 1946 she sparked its reorganization In London in 1958 as the central world Zionist body espousing the platform of nonaffiliation with political parties in Israel. Elected as cochairman together with Dr. Israel Goldstein she played a decisive role in rallying a million members into the ranks of nonpolitically aligned Zionist organizations in 35 communities thruout the world affiliated with the World Conte:Jere tion. Our heartfelt condolences to her surviving family.

title: Debt of Consumers Shays Big Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)Consumers installment debt in November showed its biggest increase in seven months, with most of the gains in auto loans. the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Vast Delaware Busing Is Ordered
description: WILMINGTON, Del:, Jan. 8 (UPI) Federal Judge Murray Schwartz issued a desegregation plan today affecting threequarters of Delaware's public school students, ordering Wilmington students bused to the suburbs for nine years and white suburban pupils bused to the city for three years.

title: MANAGER OF HUGHES HOTEL IS REPLACED IN LAS VEGAS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9  James Wadsworth, a Las Vegas, Nev., lawyer who became manager of Howard R. Hughes's Landmark Tower a year ago, resigned today to return to his law practice.

title: U.S. Interrogators Said to Agree Not to Press Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 10 Interrogators from the United States Department of Justice have agreed not to press Tongsun Park on whether current top members of the South Korean Government, including President Park Chung Hee, had any role in a plan to influence Congress, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: New Findings Raise Hope for Saving American Chestnut
description: A resurgence of hope for restoring the American chestnut tree, the giant of earlier forest, has emerged in reports of new findings by forestry specialists from the United States, France and Italy.

title: Walter Kiernan,75, Retired Columnist And Commentator
description: Walter Kiernan, whose newspaper column, One Man's Opinion was circulated for many years by International News Service and who used the same title in later years fccr his news broadcasts after 1943, died Sunday in Daytona Beach, Fla., where he had been living in retirement. He was 75 years old..

title: Grounded Oil Tanker Being Aided
description: BRISTOL, RI., Jan. 9 (AP)A barge was moved alongside the tanker Achilles shortly after noon today to unload the ship's 40,000ton cargo of heating oil, according to the Coast Guard. The 712foot ship, owned by the Newport Tankers Corporation of New York, went aground in Mount Hope Bay just east of here about 9 A.M. A Coast Guard spokesman said that theie anneared to be no snillane.

title: Hold That Sunset at Radio City
description: If Radio City Music Hall really closes after the Easter show, it will be a little like closing New York. There are few places where everyone can touch the city's legendary glamour and feel its magic; Radio City has been that place for millions. In the 46 years since it opened as part of the Rockefeller Center complex, it has become aspecial symbol of New York.

title: Retrospective Of Stravinsky Is Presented
description: The Performers Committee for TwentiethCentury Music has a tradition of presenting onecomposer retrospectives at Columbia University's McMillin Theater that dates back to 1967. But the group's Stravinsky concert Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall was its midtown debut, and it was a pleasing success. There was a good crowd on hand.

title: Zuccotti Returns Extra Severance Totaling $9,600
description: Former First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti yesterday returned the extrs severance pay he received under a change in city rules adopted only a few days before he left the administration of former Mayor Abraham D. Beame.

title: State Formally Asks 2d Infantry Division To Move to Ft. Drum
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9Governor Carey today formally invited the Army's Second Infantry Division to relocate to Fort Drum when it returns from Korea,. and sent President Carter an 87page report explaining why the facility near Watertown, N. Y., would be a good place for the divisibn to call home.

title: Interpreter Explains PolishSlips
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Steven Seymour, whose interpreting slips dominated much of the news during President Carter's visit to Poland, today discussed what happened, to savein his wordssome poor interpreter in the future from such embarrassment.

title: Dr. Mary Lou Triumphs In Handicap at Aqueduct
description: Tartan Stable's Dr. Mary Lou took command at the top of the stretch and extended her lead to win the $25,000 Cee Zee Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4yearold daughter of Dr. FagerParm, ridden by Mike Venezia, carried 107 pounds and was timed in 1:48 4/5 for 1 1/16 miles.

title: NotSoCandid Camera in the House
description: After spasmodically debating the issue over three decades, the House of Representatives finally appears willing to relent and allow its proceedings to be televised. (That will mean a lot of television. In 1977, the House sat for 881 hours and 37 minutes, five hours per legislative day.) Yet the decision to admit television is being made in a way that muddles the underlying issue and that puts the convenience of the House ahead of the needs of the public.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Panel Criticizes Attacks in County Jails
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)A state commission has charged that New Jersey citizens jailed in county prisons may be assaulted, liomosexually raped, become addicted to drugs or contract diseasesa situation that has remained unchanged since 1850 when a similar report was made.

title: CITY HOSPITAL CLINICS TO UPGRADE STAFFS
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation plans to imprOve care in its outpatient municipal hospital clinicS by staffing them with fully trained private physicians instead of with young residents and interns who are still in training.

title: French Seek to Add Safeguards To Nuclear Pact With Pakistan
description: PARIS, Jan. 9The French Government said today that it was seeking to alter its contract to supply a nuclear reprocessing plant to Pakistan in order to insure that the installation would not produce pure plutonium, which could be diverted for use in nuclear weapons.

title: INSIDE
description: Talks continued in an effort to avoid a threatened strike this morning by 30,000 service workers at 2,500 city buildings. Page 25.

title: Sammy Fain Opens Lyricists
description: The Lyrics and Lyricists series, an annual event at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. since 1970, began its eighth season Sunday evening with a chance of perspective. Instead or having lyricists comment on and illustrate their own work, the series this season will have composers discuss lyricists with whom they have worked.

title: Around the Nation
description: CALIFORNIA: Malibu Beach Colony residents filled sandbags against high tides

title: Itta Plans New Effort For Skin Moisturizer
description: In 1974 the Doak Pharmacal Company retained John Paul Itta. Inc. to do advertising for the Formula 405 Skin Moisturizer line. The marketing plan the agency came up with was just too rich for the Doak blood, so the client split with the agency.

title: Accounting Firms to Change Name
description: Haskins & Sells, one of the largest accounting firms in the United States, and Deloitte & Company, one of the largest accounting firms in Britain, announced yesterday that each firm would change its name to Deloitte Haskins & Sells on May 1. The name change does not involve a change in the organization of the two firms, a statement said, but simply reflects a joint international relationship that has existed between the two firms for more than four decades. The combined name is already used in most countries in which the two firms maintain joint offices.

title: California Standard and Texaco In a Pact With Nigerian Concern
description: Texaco Inc. and the Standard Oil Company of California announced that an agreement has been completed with the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (N.N.P.C.) with regard to the terms and conditions governing the acquisition by N.N.P.C. of a 55 percent equity ownership in three producing fields and several oilmining leases offshore from Nigeria.

title: Beverly Sills Will Retire in 1980 To Be Codirector of City Opera
description: Beverly Sills, the Brooklyn soprano who became a star of the New York City Opera, the Metropolitan and many other leading international companies, will retire as a singer in the fall of 1980 and become codirector of the City Opera. The artist's decision was announced yesterday afternoon by John S. Samuels, chairman of the City Opera and New York City Center, and Julius Rudel, the company's director. Mr. Rudel will remain as codirector.

title: Raises for Judges, Legislators and Cabinet Aides Passed by Legislature on the Last Day of Its Season
description: TRENTON. Jan. 9Pay raises for state judges, legislators and members of the Governor's Cabinet won final legislative approval today. The measures, passed by the Assembly in its final session before its term ends tomorrow, went to Governor Byrne. who is expected to sign them.

title: Opera: Mauro Makes Met Debut
description: Ermanno Mauro, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut Friday night in Leoncavallo's Pagliacci, is no stranger to New York audiencesas a leading tenor with the New York City Opera, he sings frequently at Lincoln Center.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: LISTENING TO BILLIE. By Alice Adams. 215 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Questionable Acts Of Mounted Police Reported in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 9The Government reported today a series of questionable or illegal acts by the security unit of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, which is already under investigation by two special commissions in connection with related incidents. special to The New York Times

title: West Point Rites Held for Cadet Who Died of Gunshot Wound on L.I.
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP)As more than 300 cadets stood at attention, Charlie Pendleton's coffin was lowered into the frozen earth here today at the cemetery of the United States Military Academy.

title: Crewmen of Indian Freighter Rescued by 3 U.S. Navy Vessels
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 9 (AP)Three United States Navy ships joined forces to rescue 43 crewmen from a burning Indian freighter in the Mediterranean, the Navy said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan 9 (AP)Steve Cauthen did not; ride a winner last weekend at Santa Anita. The 17yearold Cauthen, whose mounts earned more than$6 million in 1977, was shut out Saturday and yesterday. But Cauthen remained the lop'jockey at the current Santa Anita meeting with 17 victories, one more than Darrel McHargue.

title: Nebraska Court Stays Executions
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 9 (UPI)  The Nebraska Supreme Court today stayed for 90 days the execution of a convicted murderer, Erwin Charles Simants, and two other men on Nebraska's death row, Richard Dean Holtan and John Edward Rust. They were scheduled to die in the electric chair late this month. It was the second time the Nebraska court had granted the three men stays.

title: Morning
description: 8:00(4)You Don't Have to Be Fat

title: Associated Press
description: LANDRY LANDING: Tom Landry, coach of the Dallas Cowboys, wearing a halfsmile as he arrived in New Orleans last night to get ready for Super Bowl XII.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to Tne New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent P. Box 5193, Church Station, to Naw. York, N.Y. 10249 orStreet to these agencies:

title: The Now York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: Harsh winter weather gripped most of the nation yesterday and sent the New York metropolitan area a representative samplean arctic cold front with driving snow and winds that gusted up to 55 miles an hour.

title: Fed Moves Stir A Sudden Surge In Interest Rates
description: Interest rates shot upward yesterday, propelled first by the Federal Reserve's surprising increase in the discount rate and later by the central bank's moneytightening moves in the open market.

title: Coping With Colds And Flu
description: RIGHT NOW as you are reading this, some 30 million Americans are sneezing, coughing, blowing, shivering or otherwise enduring the miseries of man's most common illness, the cold.

title: Met Says It Bought Rare Ivory Plaque
description: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art has revealed itself as the actual buyer of an extremely rare ninthcentury ivory plaque, sold to a London dealer by Sotheby's last month for a record auction price of $470,000. The plaque, thought by Its former owner to be simply an interestingly carved piece of old wood, is hailed by the museum as one of the major art finds of the century.

title: Letters
description: To THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Careers
description: The human eye, a durable but delicate part of the body, is the province of two highly trained groups who do not always get along but nevertheless work together. They are optometrists and ophthalmologisttwo professional specialties often confused.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Tirol if George? No, the new Mayor isn't printing his own moneyalthough with city finances the way they are, he might like to. There's a place called Treasure Mart that doesn't print money (that's still a Federal monopoly) but does substitute celebrity pictures for that of George Washington on the $1 bill. Celebrities (Peter Falk, Mick Jagger, Farrah FawcettMajors, Jimmy Carter and hundreds others) can be had for $3.95. If you think you're also celebrity worthy of being immortalized, it will cost you a small photograph and $8.95. Allan Elsner's Book Shop at 247 East 57th Street and Stationery Plus at 1496 Third Avenue (84th Street) are among the places one can orderallow at least a week. Or telephone 6798533 for more information. If you're wondering whether it's legal, apparently it is because the bill isn't defaced. The picture is pasted onbut so cleverly you can't tell.

title: WELFARE ROLLS FALL TO EIGHTYEAR LOW
description: New York City's welfare rolls, which peaked in 1972, have declined to the lowest level in almost eight years, the Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: Rangers Rally To End Bruins Home Skein, 32
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10A combination of hard skating, playing the man and superb goaltending by Doug Soetaert enabled the New York Rangers to rally tonight and stun the Boston Bruins. 32.

title: WELFARE ROLLS FALL TO EIGHTYEAR LOW
description: New York City's welfare rolls, which peaked in 1972, have declined to the lowest level in almost eight years, the Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: O'Leary of U.S. Trust Not Apprehensive on Shift at Fed
description: The news that Arthur F. Burns, an economist, was to be replaced, by G. William Miller. an industrialist, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board came as a surprise and disappointment to James J. O'Leary, vice chairman, of the United States Trust Company, as it did to most of his colleagues in the vineyard of financial and business economics. But, unlike some others, Mr. O'Leary does not harbor any of the apprehension about the change expressed by some other financial experts. In fact, in quite another respect, Mr. O'Leary sees a personal and professional benefit possibly resulting from it.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is a zoo sandwich?

title: J. LINCOLN MORRIS, 69; A CORPORATE ATTORNEY
description: J. Lincoln Morris, a corporate attorney, died Sunday of a heart attack at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old and lived on Dune Road in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Beaths
description: ROTHBERG-Wendy and Ricky Roth berg (Nee Bernstein) announce the birth of their son Jordan Scott, 81bs7 oz, on January 10, 1978. Grand parents are Marvin and Rhoda Bern stein of Woodmere, NY and Phil and Irma RoMberp of Hallandale, Flori da

title: Helping Japan Solve Its Economic Problems
description: ANN ARBORWashington has been telling Tokyo to spend more in the hope that such spending would remove a large Japanese balance-ofpayments surplus and help the recovery of the world economy.

title: Steingut Moves for Gubernatorial Primary in June
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10In an abrupt step sure to open up a new round of political infighting, Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut moved tonightwith Governor Carey's supportto change the date of this year's gubernatorial primary election from September to June.

title: Bourne and Gillies Score Twice Each
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Jan. 10The New York Islanders, playing in an emotional daze that followed the trading of two of their favorite teammates, won a hockey game tonight, but their hearts were not in it.

title: Guber and Gross to Stage Musicals at Jones Beach
description: JONES BEACH, L.I., Jan. 10Lee Guber and Shelly Gross, owners and producers of Music Fair Enterprises, will succeed Guy Lombardo in producing musical attractions this summer at the Jones Beach Theater, the Jones Beach State Parkway authority announced yesterday.

title: Wes Siders Unite Against Hotel to Force Test of Prostitution Law
description: The community people made this possible, Sgt. Roy Wagner of the Police Morals Squad was saying. Nobody seemed to care. It's not what the police did, though we hope we contributed to their success. The community did a great job. A fantastic job. It's an encouraging sign that the people are not going to retreat and abandon the city.

title: Air Fare for Carter Is Figured at $182,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)The cost of flying Air Force One is $2,337 an hour, a military aide said today. Based on that figure, the total air fare for President Carter's sevennation trip would be over $182,000.

title: U.S. and Korea Approve Terms For Questioning of Tongsun Park
description: SEOUL, South Korai, Wednesday, Jan. 11The United States and South Korea have concluded an agreement on procedures that paves the way for the questioning of Tongsun Park, the Korean rice dealer, on charges that he ran a secret Korean operation to improperly influence actions of the United States Congress.

title: Greenburgh Accepts Apology by NBCTV
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 10The Greenburgh Board of Education voted unanimously tonight to accept apologies offered by NBCTV and its reporter, Betty Furness, in connection with last month's telecat in which Miss Furness had some Woodlands High School students sample a new, sweetened alcoholic beverage.

title: Shipping Bureau Voyage: From Broad to Broadway
description: The American Bureau of Shipping is setting off on its own voyage this year, all the way from 45 Broad Street to 65 Broadway. It bought the 21story midblock building, which runs from Broadway to Trinity Place, from the American Express Company last year for $2.5 million. Now the building in the midst of a total renovation.

title: Blacks Protest Robeson
description: FIFTYSIX black writers, artists, educators and religious and political leaders have protested James Earl Jones's oneman show, Paul Robeson, as a pernicious Perversion of the essence of Paul Robeson. The play, written by Phillip Hayes Dean, is scheduled to open at the LuntFontanne Theater on Jan. 19, after a 15week out-of-town tour.

title: Beaths
description: ALLEN-Adele S.Inee StraussIon Jan uary 9 after a long Illness. Widow of Harry N. Allen. She Is survived by her cousins MrsAxone and Carel Van Heukelom of Amsterdam, Hol land. Funeral private. In lieu of flow ers contributions may be sent to the American Red Cross.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Indira Gandhi was ordered today to testify about her controversial 21month emergency rule of India. The former Prime Minister said later that she had not made up her mind whether to comply. J. C. Shah, a retired Supreme Court Chief Justice who constitutes the single-member commission investigating the emergency period, rejected arguments on legal procedure by Mrs. Gandhi's lawyer and ordered that she be examined.

title: Lost in Translation
description: The heart goes out to Steven Seymour, the hapless translator who misrendered some of Jimmy Carter's inconsequential rhetoric into Polish on the President's arrival in Warsaw on New Year's Eve. For Mr. Carter's reference to the Polish people's desires for the future, Mr. Seymour offered lusts; for Mr. Carter's departing from Washington, he used abandoned. He was nalcute( widely and now, pained, finally steps forward to explain how he had been kept shivering in a freezing rain for three hours at the Warsaw airport before he was shown the President's arrival statement, a bare minute before delivery.

title: Court Allows More Challenges of E.P.A. Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The supreme Court ruled today that pollution control procedures ordered by the Environmental Protection Administration, unlike strictly numerical emission standards set by the agency, were not subject to the limits Congress set for challenges in the courts.

title: Beaths
description: MC KENNAJames F., Msgr. On January 8, 1978. Pastor of St. Peter and St. Paul's Church. Bronx, N.Y. Dear son of the late James J. and Nora. Brother of Mary Van Cure and the late Joseph. Reposing at the Convent of St. Peter and St. Paul. 839 St. Ann's Avenue, Tuesday, 129PM. Reposing Wednesday, 128PM In the Church. Mass of the Eucharist Wed. nesday at 8PM. Funeral Mass Thurs day. at 10AM. Mass will be offered by Terrence Cardinal Cooke. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Omit flowers.

title: Mexican Plans for Model City Result in Chaos and Misery
description: LAZARO CARDENAS, Mexico--Outside the gates of the $1 billion Sicartsa steel complex, the streets of this model urban development remain unpaved, and ragged children carry buckets of water from commual taps to precarious wooden shacks balanced on the banks of the Balsas River.

title: East Germany Shuts Office Of West German Magazine In Retaliation for Articles
description: EAST BERLIN, Jan. 10East Germany closed the office of the West German news magazine Der Spiegel here today in retaliation for its publication of an attack on East German conditions.

title: Robert D. Murphy, Diplomat, Dies at 83
description: Former Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, the career diplomat credited with plan ning the Allied invasion of North Africa in World War H, died Monday at his home at 1009 Park Avenue. He was 83 years old and had been ill since suffering a stroke last November.

title: A Judge Rules for Coed Sports
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 10 (UPI)A Federal judge has ruled that Ohio and Federal regulations outlawing coeducational sports teams are unconstitu tional.

title: PrizeWinning Editor Is Shot Dead In Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 10 (AP)Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, an editor known for his outspoken opposition to the dictatorship of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, was shot to death today in downtown Managua.

title: UNION PROBLEM HAMPERS TRIB ON ITS SECOND DAY
description: The Trib, New York's new morning newspaper, ran into circulation difficulties on its second day of publication yesterday when nine of the 28 distributors in the metropolitan area refused to accept newspapers from trucks driven by nonunion personnel.

description: Enthusiasts from the metropolitan area eager to win major titles at the start of 1978 have plenty of opportunities this week.

title: More Soviet Workers Air Protests
description: MOSCOW. Jan. 10A small group of disgruntled workers held a second news conference for Western correspondents today to press their protests against alleged persecution of those who complained about corruption and other wrongdoing on the job.

title: Thousands Complain of No Heat
description: Henry MacBride, who at the age of 83 has long known the indignities of poverty and old age, spends his days bundled in sweaters next to a small electric heater. Frost etches the cracked windows of his cramped groundfloor apartment. and dry, stale almost suffocatingneat flows from his :las ranee.

title: The New York Times/Larry Morris
F.A.A. Tests on the Concorde Raise Safety Question
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Federal Aviation Administration has questioned whether the Concorde airliner meets its safety standards and is undecided about approving it for purchase and operation by the domestic carriers within the United States.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Tuesday, January 10, 1978

title: EGYPTISRAEL TALKS OPEN IN CAIRO TODAY
description: CAIRO, Jan. 10Egypt is entering talks here with Israel tomorrow on military aspects of a Middle East settlement. determined to press for clarification of Israeli seriousness about maintaining settlements in the Sinai Peninsula after a troop withdrawal.

title: North Carolina Pardon Weighed
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 10 (UPI)Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. said today that he would announce within two weeks his decision on whether to pardon the Wilmington 10. With the ruling of the State Court of Appeals last week, this case has exhausted its appeal in the North Carolina courts, he said. Accordingly, I think this is an appropriate time for the Governor to make a decision. The Wilmington 10 is a group of civil rights workers convicted in the 1971 racial violence in Wilmington.

title: 49ers Name McCulley as New Coach
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (UPI)The San Francisco 49ers dismissed Coach Iten Meyer and his staff today and named Pete McCulley, receiver coach of the Washington Redskins, to coach the National Football League club for the next three years.

description: With some of the leading rimers in precious metals taking to the sidelines yesterday, the recent sharp gains in gold, silver and platinum futures appeared to run out of steam.

title: Israeli Settlers in Sinai Uneasy on Future
description: YAMIT, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, Jan. 9Iris Golan of Yamit, formerly Iris Goldfisher of Rockville Centre, is alternately anery and perplexed.

title: 2 Russians Are Off to Join 2 in Space
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10Two experienced Soviet astronauts rocketed into space today to dock with a Salyut 6 research station and join a crew that has been aboard the orbiting station since docking with it last month.

title: Arctic Storm Holds Much of the Country in Its Grip
description: The severest arctic storm of the season gdpped much of the country .yesterday. Freezing temperatures and icy winds gusting to 50 miles an hour beset travelers throughout the New York City area and forced the shutdown of Aqueduct Race Track, but at least New Yorkers could take some comtort mat tney mu not live in Buffalo, Chicago or Cleveland. What one meteorologist called a real gopd arctic outbreak caused power shortages and cutbacks from Michigan to the Carolinas. The New York State Power Pool, including the Consolidated Edison Company, channeled surplus power to the affected areas, where shivering residents depleted local power supplies with heaters and stoves.

title: Spruille Braden, Former Official Of State Department, Is Dead at 83
description: Spruille Braden. former Assistant sec retary of State for American Republic Affairs, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los An geles, where he had been visiting friends. He was 83 years old and lived at 320 Eait 72d Street.

title: Cavaliers Game Put Off
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 10 (UPI)The National Basketball Association game scheduled for tonight between the Golden State Warriors and Cleveland was postponed because of bad weather, the Cavaliers announced. The contest tentatively has been rescheduled for March 27, at the Coliseum.

description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLO, Italy, Jan. 10 (AP)Gaetan. Boucher of Canada won the men's 500meter race for sprinters in record time today in the opening event of a twoday speed skating competition. Boucher was clocked in 38.14 seconds in a race tnat counts toward the Dal Vit Trophy. The previr

description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) ann o unc ed yesterday that it has become a partner in Kitimat Pipe Line Ltd., which is attempting to build a tanker terminal at Kitimat, British Columbia, and a crude oil pipeline in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: Portrait of the Artist as a Furry Creature
description: Once upon a time, there was an author and designer named Edward Gorey. In the beginning, when he was relatively unknown, he contented himself with vintage raccoon. A decade or so later, in the mid60's, the vintage raccoon had gone the way of the Stutz Bearcat, and Mr. Gorey was wearing a contemporary enuivalent.

description: The Rev. Dr. Roy G. Ross, who was a leading figure in the founding of the National Council of Churches and general secretary of the organization from 1952 to 1963, died Sunday at a nursing home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Budd Refutes Damage Suit
description: Budd Company, the auto industry ,suppllier, said yesterday that a $19 million damage suit brought by Michael Fogle, a former vice president at a Budd subsidiary who alleged that he had tried to report illegal company bribes, was wholly without merit and would be vigorously', defended.

Barons Send Center, Merrick, in Return
description: In an effort to sharpen their offense, the New York Islanders sent J. P. Parise, an aging left wing, and Jean Potyin, a defensiman, to the Cleveland Baron yesterday for Wayne Merrick, a 25-year-old center with knee problems, and a player to be named later.

title: U.S. May Ask Brezhnev Pledge To Limit Use of Disputed Bomber
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The United States, in an effort to resolve one of the thorniest issues in the strategicarms talks is preparing to ask Leonid I. Brezhnev for a letter promising not to deploy a controversial Soviet bomber for potential use against this country.

title: More City Sacrifices
description: The Secretary of the Treasury came to New York for a private meeting with Mayor Koch yesterday and told the Mayor that the city would have to make additional sacrifices before Washington would consider a financing plan.

description: CROSS THE RHINE from Germany into France and, miraculously, sauerkraut becomes choucroute, wurst becomes saucisson, and the winewell, the wine becomes one of the finest, and least known, in the world, the great white wine of Alsace.

title: Spinks Blowing Up A Storm in Training
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.It wasn't the greatest day for training to fight Muhammad Ali and in the middle of a Catskills blizzard Leon Spinks was warning people to keep away from him. I get aggravated easily, said the 24-year-old 1976 Olympic lightheavyweight champion who still looks like a light heavyweight although his weight is up over 205 pounds and he is challenging Ali for the world heavyweight title Feb. 15 in Las Vegas, Nev. I get mean all the time, said Spinks on Monday. You touch me, I get hot. I'm quicktempered when I'm in training.

title: Best Buys
description: VIOLENT WEATHERflooding fields and curtailing harvests in Californiahelped start the New Year on bleak note for budgetconscious New Yorkers.

title: The Tragedy of Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The private diplomatic reports coming into Washington these days from Cambodia are increasingly somber. They speak of the planned massacre of tens of thousands of people and of a systematic effort by the Cambodian Government to wipe out the upper and middle classes. The Carter Administration now trying to come to grips with wnat is apparently an appalling human tragedy.

title: Outgoing Jersey Senate Mandates Silent Meditation in. Public Schools
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10The outgoing State Senate gave final legislative approval today to a measure mandating a daily period of silent meditation in New Jersey's 2,500 public schools.

description: TRENTON. Jan. 10Whatever the accomplishments of his second four years in office. Governor Byrne seemed determined to ascertain in his State of the State message today that these accomplishments would not be won through the bitter confrogations with the State Leeislature that marked his first term.

title: A Threatened Strike in 2,500 Buildings Averted by Pay Rise of $35 Over 3 Years
description: Service employees and building owners reached agreement on a new contract early yesterday, averting a strike by 30,000 workers at 2,500 commercial buildings in. Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: Six Cities Receive Federal Grants To Test a TeenAge Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Six cities won Labor Department grants of more than $15 million each today to test a program that guarantees jobs to all teenagers who want to work and who stay in or return to high school.

title: PREDICTION ON LABOR LAW CRITICIZED BY MARSHALL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)Labor Secretary Ray Marshall today criticized as uninformed a prediction by the United States Chamber of Commerce that a Housepassed labor law revision would force 60 percent of the nation's labor force into unions.

description: The following tables summarize some of the key findings of the reading achievement tests given in May 1977, as reported by the New York City Board of Education.

title: Nygaard: MozartA la Grieg
description: COMPOSERS like to tinker with other composers music. Even the best of them have done so, with Mozart rescoring Handel's Messiah and Schoenberg orchestrating a Brahms quartet. However honorable their reasons and however successful, such actions are suspect.

title: News Summary
description: Italy's Government is fighting to survive amid widening street violence and Communist demands that have threatened to topple the 18-month-old Christian Democratic Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti. The Communists touched off the political crisis last month by demandinab direct participation in a new unified government to replace the minority Christian Democratic administration. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Fed Acts to Tighten Money As More Banks Lift Prime
description: The Federal Reserve tightened money another notch yesterday, and more major banks, including the Bank of America, the nation's largest, raised their prime rates to 8 percent to make that rate universal among the 20 biggest banks in the nation.

title: Canada's Unemployment of 8.5% Is Highest Since the Depression
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10Unemployment in Canada rose to a new postdepression record of 8.5 percent In December, up onetenth of 1 percent from the previous month. the Government announced today.

title: How Grade Level Shows Performance
description: Grade equivalent or grade level is used to show a student's perform ance in relation to a national norm, i.e. in relation to that of other stu dents.

title: An Editor Silenced
description: Pedro J. Chamorro Cardenal, the director of Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper, was gunned down with automatic weapons at the wheel of his can in Managua yesterday. For 30 years, he had been an outspoken critic of the dynastic dictatorship of the Somoza family. He had been tried and imprisoned by courtsmartial on several occasions for his opposition activities. Why he alone, among all the Government's opponents, was allowed intermittently to express another view is something of a puzzle. But he did, with distinction, and was honored two months ago with Columbia University's Maria Moors Cabot Prize for distinguished journalistic contributions to the advancement of interAmerican understandng. It is hard to believe that his opposition, and the increasing recognition abroad which that role afforded him, did not figure somehow In his murder.

title: 2 Nearby SchoolsSimilar in Many VVays but So Different in the Test Results
description: Public Schools 34 and 110 are just a few blocks from each other on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Both draw pupils from virtually the same neighborhood, both have high attendance rates and both conduct federally financed remedial reading programs. But in readingskills tests conducted last year, one of the schools showed great gains and the other great losses.

title: NEW YORK BATTERED BY ICY, STRONG WINDS
description: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr.
