description: Music

title: Discomfort at Grade Mansion
description: The domestic plans of Mayor Koch remain unclear, but, as he said over the weekend, he is uncomfortable in Gracie Mansion, rattling around in its large empty spaces. He may or may not decide to continue to make his home in his accustomed and rentcontrolled threeroom Greenwich Village apartment, leaving the mansion untenanted except, perhaps, on evenings when late meetings are scheduled there.

title: Jersey Senate Orders Silent Meditation in Schools
description: TRENTON. Jan. 10The outgoing state Senate gave final legislative approval today to a measure mandating a daily period of silent meditation in New Jersey's 2,500 public schools.

title: Change in Utilities Divisor
description: The Dow Jones average for the 15 utility stocks and the 65stock composite average will give effect to the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company's distribution of onehalf additional share of common stock for each share held. beginning with the averages printed today. This changes the divisor for the 15 utilities to 3.695 from 3.799 and for the 65 stocks to 7.549 from 7.590.

title: United Press International
description: EARTH AND MOON, photographed by Voyager I spacecraft on its way to Saturn and beyond. Earth, at bottom, was 7,25 million miles away when the picture was made. Photo was first of its kind taken by a spacecraft in flight.

title: Notes on People
description: BRITISH newspapers have begun a wave of speculation about the romantic life of 17yearold Prince Andrew, the second son of Queen Elizabeth II, after he invited a visitor to the royal family's hnme in Norfolk in eastern England. Kirsty Richmond, a classmate at Lim.donstoun, the private school that Prince Andrew attends in Scotland. The Daily Mail described Miss Richmond as the only girl whom the Prince has taken home to mother. A spokesman at Buckingham Palace said, They are just school friends.

title: Jersey Expects to Charge $550,000 to Investigate a Casino Applicant
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 10Joseph P. Lordi, chairman of the Casino Control Commission, which will regulate casino gambling at this resort city, said today that New Jersey would charge Resorts International at least $550,000 to investigate the company's qualifications for casino license.

title: Jersey Plans to Charge $550,000 To Investigate Casino Applicant
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 10Joseph P. Lordi, chairman of the Casino Control Commission, which pill regulate casino gambling at this resort city, said today that New Jersey would charge Resorts International at least $550,000 to investi gate the company's qualifications for a casino license.

title: Broadway to Hear Sound of Musicals
description: SINCE SEPTEMBER, only one new musical comedy, Liza Minelli's The Act, has opened on Broadway, while others have been canceled, postponed or closed on the road. But as the theater season enters its second half, Broadway once again is humming with the sound of musicals.

title: TV Networks Plan ShortSeries Tests
description: BETWEEN now and and next April, 15 or 20 new network television series will be introduced in prime time, virtually ail of them for limited runs of four to cix weeks.

title: Flight Attendants Strike Alitalia
description: ROME, Dec. 10 (UPI)A 16hour strike by Alitalia flight attendants to protest disciplinary action against several col. leagues stopped most national and European flight of the airline. Alitalia said its intercontinental flights functioned on schedule.

title: Black Air Force General to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Gen. Daniel James Jr., the Air Force's first and only black fourstar general, will retire on Feb. 1 for medical reasons, the Pentagon announced today. A veteran of Vietnam air battles, the general last month left his post as commander of the United StatesCanada North American Air Defense Command after experiencing heart trouble.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1978

title: Yanks
description: HERTFORD, N.C., Jan. 10Jim (Catfish) Hunter narrowly escaped injury today while watching a fire at an oil company storage area in which an exploding tank sent a circular metal lid hurtling toward a crowd of onlookers.

title: Israeli Settlers in Sinai Uneasy on Future
description: YAMIT, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, Jan. 9Iris Golan of Yamit, formerly Iris Goldfisher of Rockville Centre, is alter nately anery and perplexed.

title: Private Lives
description: HAD HE felt an epiphany coming on, he might have been able to time it better. New Year's Eve, after all, has no other discernible purpose. How nice it would have been for such a seizure to coincide with the falling of the ball down Times Tower, like an aspirin tablet in the esophagus of history. Doctor, says the Old Year my minutes leak and my months ache. Take two Lombardos, my son, and call me after the football game.

title: Beaths
description: HALPRIN-Rine L. The World Zionist Organteation Executive dealY mourns the passing of one of the me ter figures in The Zionist Movement. An architect in the building of the State of Israel. With her election to The Jewish Agency Executive in 1446, Mrs. Halorin participated es rivets, at The National and Interna tional Negotiations which led to the establishment of the State of Israel. She served as Chairman of the Jew ish AgencyAmerican Section for years and was also National Pres ident of Hadassah from 193231 and again from 114751. Mrs. Hearin Partitipated in World Zionist Con gresses and meetings of the General Zionist Council for many years. Deeply concerned with relations be tween Israel and The Jewish Com munity in the Diaspora especially in The US and with the future of Jewish Education she made =dor contribu tions In these areas, both here and in Israel. Since 1968 she has served withdistinction as chairman of the World Jewish CongressAmerican Section and as a member of the Ge neral Council of The World Zionist Congress. Her Wide knowledge keen and analytical mind and fearless ad vocacy of Zionist Goals were semi mat influences In Me education of Countless Zionists. A gifted orator who combined the Intellectual and the emotional, the inspirational and the Informative, she will be most sorely missed. We extend our deep est condolences to her children, Ruth & Lawrence. her grandchildren and her sisters and brother and loin with them in their sorrow.

title: Hungary Ponders Where to Keep Recovered Crown of St. Stephen
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 8Hungary is taking no chances regarding the safety of the Crown of St. Stephen. Four soldiers stand at all times around the relic, which has been given a provisional repository in a hall of the Parliament Building, on the Danube. The doors of the hall are sealed after each change of guard.

title: NEW CHARGES MADE ON GRUMMAN MOVES IN F14 SALES TO IRAN
description: Legal maneuvers in a multimillion-dollar damage suit have turned up new charges of questionable activities relating to the payment of agents fees in the 'sale to Iran of 80 F-I4 interceptor planes built by the Grumman Corporation.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 2 Schools, Alike in Many Ways but Different in Test Results
description: Public Schools 34 and 110 are just a few blocks from each other on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Both draw pupils from virtually the same neighborhood, both have high attendance rates and both conduct federally financed remedial reading programs. But in readingskills tests conducted last year, one of the schools showed great gains and the other great losses.

title: Abortion Opponents Tactics
description: When the United States Supreme Court legalized abortion five years ago, on Jan. 22, 1973, none of us who had struggled so long for abortion rights could have predicted that this issue would soon polarize the nation.

title: Riklis to Ask Cash Dividend
description: Based on anticipated earnings from operations of RapidAmerican Corporation last year, its chairman and president, Meshulam Riklis, said yesterday he intends to recommend to the board of directors that cash dividends be resumed on the common stock in 1978. The last one was 12 cents in April, 1975.

title: U.S. SAYS THAT EXXON APPLIED OVERCHARGES
description: DALLAS, Jan. 10 (AP)The Department of Energy alleged today that the Exxon Company U.S.A. overcharged its customers by $3.3 million through violations of federal price controls.

title: Cards in Turmoil
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (UPI)Bill Bidwill, owner of the St. Louii Cardinals football team, cut off communications today with Coach Don Coryell, who is seeking to get out of a contract that rims through 1980.

title: An Eating Tour Of N.Y.'s Bars
description: Anyone who has ever stuffed his or her face in the name of dinner at cocktail party must have noticed by now the free hors d'oeuvre appearing in most New York bars during cocktail hour. Just look for a flurry of stabbing forks and you're bound to fmd a DUNK spread with platters and bowls containing often tasty but (be warned) thirstinducing foods, or at least a steam table filled with the ubiquitous meatball or chicken wing.

title: About Real Estate
description: The J. P. Stevens building at 1185 Avenue of the Americas was sold this week in yet another indication of the ?? midtown office market.

title: T.W.A. Withdraws Its Offer For 64% of Medicorp Shares
description: Trans World Airlines yesterday withdrew its offer for 64 percent of the common stock of American Medicorp Inc.

title: Israeli Exports of Diamonds at High
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Israell exports of polished diamonds reached high of more than $1 billion last year, the Ministry of Industry and Commerce announced today. In 1976, exports were worth just under $700 million. The United States was the main customer, taking $321 million worth last year, compared with $217.4 million in 1976. Diamond polishing (all stones are imported) is Israel's largest foreign currency earner apart from citrus fruits.

title: Mondale, on a Tour of 7 Western States, Hears Indian Woes
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan. 10Vice President Mondale began the first full day of his listen and learn tour of seven Rocky Mountain states this morning by hearing leaders of the large Southwestern Indian tribes demand that the Carter Administration resist all Congressional efforts to abrogate Federal land grant treaties signed with the Indians.

title: Chess:
description: The stonewall variation of the Dutch Defense has always been considered suspect because it abandons control of the important black squares in the center. Only Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, got long use out of it (from the late 1920's to the early 1950's), adapting himself to its difficulties with an uncanny virtuosity.

title: Court. Backs a State Adoption Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Supreme. Court ruled today that states need not give the father of an illegitimate child the right to veto an adoption even though the natural father had not been found to be an unfit parent by the courts.

title: Retail Sales Down 0.7% in December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Retail sales declined in December even though the Christmas season was stronger than the holiday period the year before, the Commerce Department said today.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Sometime, in the not too distant future, a woman in South America is going to do her horseback riding on a burgundy suede English riding saddle, with 18karat gold stirrups. The blinders for her horse will be oval leather patches, with a double C embossed in the center.

title: Federal Magnetism Draws Law Firms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer &. Wood is one of the most distinguished in the New York bar. For years it main tained a small hideaway here for visiting firemen, but last March the fiim opened a fullfledged Washington. office for the first time.

title: U.S. May Ask Brezhnev Pledge To Limit Use of Disputed Bomber
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The United States, in an effort to resolve one of the thorniest issues in the strategicarms talks, is preparing to ask Leonid 1. Brezhnev for a letter promising nat to deploy a controversial Soviet bomber for potential use against this country.

description: TOKYO, Jan. 10The chief United States delegate to the current bilateral trade talks with. Japan signaled today a change in strategy, away from the previously tough public stance and toward accommodation with America's chief Asian ally,

description: Where does the Hostess Twinkle taste come from? How did bubble gum come to taste like bubble gum? And where can something be gotten that tastes as good as freshsqueezed oranze iuice?

title: 2 Russians Are Off to Join 2 in Space
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10Two experienced Soviet astronauts rocketed into space toclay to dock with a Salyut 6 research station and join a crew that has been aboard the orbiting station since docking with it last month.

title: Parker Pen's 3d Quarter Profit Of $6.4 Million a 37.9% Advance
description: The Parker Pen Company reported yesterday profit increases of 37.9 percent for the third fiscal quarter to Nov. 30 and 46.3 percent for the nine months.

title: Earthquakes Sign Player
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan, 10 (AP)Paul Child, the leading scorer for the San Jose Earthquakes, has signed a oneyear contract with the North American Soccer League team. The Earthquakes also announced today the acquisition of Ian Wood, a defender, from the Minnesota Kicks, in eXchange for a firstround draft choice this year.

title: 2 Are Indicted in Scheme To Get Pay for Teachers Who Had NoShow Jobs
description: The head of a continuing education program and the chairman of the board of a daycare center were indicted yester day on charges of stealing more than $34,000 from the New York City Board of Education through a scheme involving pay for noshow teaching jobs.

title: Michelle Ford Shatters Aussie Freestyle Mark
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 10 (UPI) Michelle Ford, the 15-year-old swimmer from Sydney, broke the Australian 400meter freestyle record by sixtytwo onehundredths of a second today in an international meet.

title: Dividends

description: Soon Americans may buy milk the way they buy soft drinksthey'll find the nonperishable milk on the grocer's shelf, store it in the pantry at home, and when they want a glass of milk several months later, open the vacuumpacked carton and serve.

description: Outgoing

title: Black Air Force General to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)Gen. Daniel James Jr., the Air Force's first and only black fourstar general, will re tire on Feb. 1 for medical reasons, the Pentagon announced today. A veteran or Vietnam air battles, the general last month left his post as commander of the United StatesCanada North American Air Defense Command after experiencing heart trouble.

title: Excerpts From the Text of Governor Byrne's State of State
description: In the past four years we have come through some of the most difficult times in our state's history. They have been times of crisis, times of turmoil and dispute, but. times of remarkable achievement.

title: Six Cities Receive Federal Grants To Test a TeenAge Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Six cities won Labor Department grants of more than $15 million each today to test a program that guarantees jobs to all teenagers who want to work and who stay in or return to hieh school.

title: PAUL L. STOVALL

title: A ROCK GROUP HELPS NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: A black and white rock group known as the Average White Band, extremely popular here and abroad, won an out standing award in its field. The ensemble decided it wanted to share the award with the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: EGYPTISRAEL TALKS OPEN IN CAIRO TODAY
description: CAIRO, Jan. 10Egypt is entering talks here with Israel tomorrow on military aspects of a Middle East settlement, determined to press for clarification of Israeli seriousness about maintaining settlements in the Sinai Peninsula after troop withdrawal.

title: 60 Minute Gourrnet
description: IN COOKING, as in most things in life, everything is relativeincluding flavors and cooking times. In that this column is dedicated to the proposition that excellent foods can be prepared in less than an hour, it is evident that some dishes cook tar quicker than others. It is also obvious that the end results of some dishes may be more sophisticated than others, more elegant than others and better suited to the finest of wines. And guests who have been chosen with special care.

title: Dollar Louver, Gold Advances
description: The dollar drifted lower against most foreign currencies overseas and in New York yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: ThreeHorse Spill, Chill Greet Yonkers Opening
description: YONKERS, Jan. 10In subfreezing temperatures and snow flurries, Yonkers Raceway opened its 156night harness-racing season tonight. A turnout of 6,557, betting $1,188,150, looked on, wisely staying indoors to avoid the chilling gusts tnat reacneo 3540-40-miles per hour. In the most recent comparable openerJan. 1, 1975  9,606 attended.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration has given approval for Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the developer of the polio vaccine, to conduct tests on humans of a drug that, might arrest multiple sclerosis.

description: WHITE. PLAINS. Jan. 10The Soviet Union and Pepsico signed an agreement tnday designed to double the number of Pepsi bottling plants in the Soviet Uninn and substanially increase the evel of Stolichnaya vodka imported here in return by the beverage company.

title: Princeton Tops Seton Hall After a 31Year Pause
description: SOUTH ORANGE, NJ., Jan. 10 Princeton University took an early lead and went on to defeat Seton Hall Uni versity, 7058, tonight in the first meet ing between the state foes in 31 years. Princeton shot Si percent from tne floor, with Frank Sowinski scoring 21 points and Bob Roma 18, to pace the attack. Randy Duffin had 16 points and Greg Tynes 15 for the Pirates.

A mirror image of the Black Forest region of Germany which it faces across the Rhine River, Alsace's towns are virtually Grimm's fairy tale set pieces. Although adorned by embroideries of window box gardens and the lacy black wrought iron tradesmen's signs that are more ally associated with Germany or Switzerland, eaters of any nationality are bound to be tempted almost erywhere they turn.

Under pressure both from West European governments and Wall Street to stabilize exchange rates, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board announced their joint intention to intervene in foreign currency markets in the dollar's defense. Armed with a fresh line of foreign credit, the tea proppea up its sagging value with respect to the German mark and Swiss franc by buying dollars.

It was Portland's 40th straight homecourt victory, 22 this season.

But the report concludes that no prosecutions were possible because virtually all the alleged offenses took place more than five years ago.

The cars were built from mid1974 to May 1975 and distributed throughout the world, the company said. Volkswagen said that owners would be notified about the necessary inspections and possible repairs after Jan. 23.

description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 (AP)The Israeli Parliament approved today the building of three new potentially controversial settlements on the occupied West Bank of the Jprdan River.

description: ROME, Jan. 10Italy's 18-month-old minority Government is fighting for survival under the combined pressures of mounting street violence and a demand by the Communist Party for direct participation in goverment affairs.

description: WASHINGTON, Jatv 10Federal marshals today arrested three principals of Lloyd, Carr & Company a major commodities dealer with offices in Detroit, Boston, Chicago, San Francisco, and other cities, on charges of criminal contempt in connection with irregular prac- tices in selling London commodity opiions to the Arnetican public.

title: N.A.S.L. to Draft Schoolboys, Too
description: Besides college seniors the North American Soccer League announced yesterday that it would hold a draft for high school and junior college players who will graduate in June.

description: The Toronto Blue Jays. picking first, made Mike Lebo, a catcher from Middletown, Pa., their top selection in baseball's annual winter draft of amateur free agents yesterday.

title: Informality and Children Rein in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10The swearingin ceremonies for the new Legislature filled the Senate and Assembly chambers with a happy informality today and turned both houses into a big playground for dozens of hookyplaying children on holiday to watch their parents or grandparents take legislative office.

title: People and Business
description: The Lockheed Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of its former chairman, Robert W. Haack, from the aerospace company's board of directors. Mr. Haack was named Lockheed chairman in February 1976 after disclosure that the company had paid $22 million in bribes to foreign governments.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood is one of the most distinguished in the New York bar. For years it main tained a small hideaway here for visiting firemen, but last March the firm opened a fullfledged Washington cffice for the first time.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IF THERE'S one thing that everyone has in common, its aging. Some people accept it with grace, some apply humor to ease the sting. others have a hard time of it and still others fight it every inch of the way.

title: Housing Secretary Promises New Effort To Help Smaller Cities Get Federal Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)The Department of Housing and Urban Development, responding to smalltown concerns that its policies were oriented too much to big cities, is creating a study group to look into the development problems of rural areas and smaller communities. Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that, while the agency was focusing its resources on distressed big cities, she had set a March 1 deadline for recommendations to improve the department's performance with rural areas and smaller cities and towns.

title: Four More for Cooperstown
description: Voting for the Baseball Hall of Fame is in its last week, which means that in the immediate future there will be a marked increase in three kinds of letters in the daily mail. There will be letters soliciting votes for various candidates, letters asking why Chuck Klein or Hack Wilson isn't enshrined at Cooperstown, andwhen this winter's returns are inletters disagreeing with the voters choices. Some of the letters are strident and probably settdefeating. For example. there has been an aggressive campaign for Gil Hodges going on for several years now, insistent, hardsell electioneering that may have turned off a good many voters who might otherwise have included Gil on their ballots. And afterward when the dissenters write. they seldom criticize the electors as prejudiced or incompetent or both. More often, they attack the unoffending player who has been chosen for beatification, vilifying him in terms usually reserved for triple ax murderers:

title: Captain Who Quit Loses Court Fight With School

He was expellet from school for having allegedly spoken abusively to the coaches.

title: Violin Concerto For Isaac Stern

He has composed a Violin Concerto for Isaac Stern, and dedicated it to him. The work had its New York premiere last night Hi Carnegie Hall, where Stanislaw Skrowaczewski conducted the Minnesota Orchestra.

description: James J. O'Leary, vice chairman of the United States Trust Company, is not apprehensive about the upcoming BurnsMiller change at the Federal Reserve and, in fact, sees a personal and professional benefit possibly resulting from it. Page D3.

title: Dr. Walter Murray, 67, Professor At Brooklyn College, Civic Leader
description: Dr. Walter 1. Murray, a professor of education at Brooklyn College, author and civic leader, died yesterday at Queens Hospital Center after a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 14315 170th Street, Springfield Gardens, Queens.

title: Avoid Emotionalism Over Canal Treaty, Byrd Urges Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10The Senate majority leader, Robert. C. Byrd urged today that the nation not be carried away by emotional jingoism about ratifica4 tion of the Panama Canal treaty but said that widespread public opposition assured that there would be no political credit, no political mileage for Senators who voted for it.

title: Carter News Parley On Television Today

title: 6 IN TAIWAN PLEAD GUILTY TO BEING COMMUNIST SPIES

title: JOHNRAE EARL
description: JOHNRAE EARL; CHICAGO. Jan. 11 (AP)Johnrae Earl, a veteran Chicago newspaperman who for several years held fulltime copy-editing jobs at two newspapers, died yesterday. He was 59 years old.

title: Ranger Matlack Charges Bonus Default by Mets
description: A simmering dispute between Jon Matlack and the Mets over $150,000 in bonuses has popped into the open and will land before Commissioner Bowie Kuhn today for an informal conference that also Is being disputed.

title: Fither Denies Killing 6 Children
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Jan. 11 (UPI)Simon Peter Nelson told a judge today that he was not guilty of killing his six children. While he stood before the judge, the children, aged 3 to 12, were buried in graveside service a few miles away. Mr. Nelson was arraigned before Judge Philip Rheinhard of Winnebago County Circuit Court was held without bond.

title: Dollar Continues Retreat Against Major Currencies

Unemployment, apparently, has not been frozen on a 7 percent plateau since spring. The unemployment rate, according to new data, has been falling rather steadily for the last year and dropped in December to 6.4 percent, the lowest level in three years.

title: Dismissal of Five Minority Aides By Legal Aid Society Is Criticized
description: One Chinese and four Hispanic law graduates have been dismissed from the, criminal defense division of New York City's Legal Aid Society after failing the bar examination, while four whites who also failed have been offered other jobs in the organization as they prepare to take the examination a second time. Whether we view it as a conscious act or unconscious act, the end result turned out to be racist, Michael Russek, president of the union that represents the 600 staff lawyers of Legal Aid, said yesterday. He said the union and the five law graduates who were dismissed were contemplating legal action against the society, which provides free legal assistance to poor people.

title: New Jersey Briefs

The increase would raise a typical customer's bill by 9 percent, according to a Bell vice president, J. Kenneth Loolian, who testified at a Board hearing in Newark.

Belloni of Federal District Court set sentencing for Feb. 21. Miss Brown, 30 years old plead- ed guilty to the robbery last YeD. i or a Wilsonville branch of the National Bank of Oregon and carrying a firearm in the robbery. I am a member of a revolutionary organization known as the George Jackson Brigade, Miss Brown told the court.

description: ATLANTA, Jan. 11The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for women modified today its approval of full athletic scholarships. It reorganized into three divisions and permitted full scholarships only in Division I, the major group.

description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan, 11President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France arrived in this former French West African colony today for a fourday visit in which French officials hope to rally black African support for his efforts to stem the growth of Communist influence on their continent.

title: Two Aboard Soyuz Joim Comrades in Space Stationl
description: MOSCOW.- Jan. 11Two Soviet astronauts docked their spaceship with a research station high over Siberia  today and crawled through the hatch to en; brace two comrades who docked their craft with the station a month ago. Jubi- lantly, all four squeezed a round of *toasts of cherry juice from plastic tubes to celebrate the first such multiple linkup in the history of space flight.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The State Department announced today that 15 nations that export nuclear technology had agreed do a code of safeguards to insure that the exports would not be used for military purposes.

description: IHAVE. HAD ambivalent feelings about television for some time past and would have mentioned it before. if only John J. O'Connor, television critic for The New York Times, hadn't beaten me to half the punch. The half he beat me to was the nice side, the good SIM, trUiL 4b. pect of television for which I must regularly be grateful. A few months back Mr. O'Connor remarked, in effect, that television had accomplished a sort of timewarp miracle: It has made us all the contemporaries of our children.

With Wallace Shawn's acclaimed adaptation of The Mandrake going full steam ahead at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, still another Machiavelli play is due tomorrow, and will run through Jan. 30, at the Nameless Theater, 125 West 22d Street. Clizia, a 1520 success with its lively picture of Renaissance Italy, is reportedly another rowdy comedy, Machiavellistyle. with impetuous lovers, avaricious old men and wily servants. Catherine Ruello has directed the new production, which also has original music by Lynda Kaplan.

title: Mass for Braden Tomorrow
description: A funeral mass for Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, who died Tuesday in Los Angeles, will be performed tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, near Madison Avenue. In place of flowers, the family asked that contributions be made to the American Heart Association. Friends may visit from 4 to 7 P.M. today at the Frank E. Campbell funeral home at Madison Avenue and 81st Street.

title: The Heart of the Matter
description: A dozen issues are on the, table. But events since Anwar Sadat went to Jerusalemthe drama and the disagreementhave made it clear that peace in the Middle East depends essentially on the resolution of one central question: the future of the Palestinians. Difficult as the problem is, facing it is an important step forward. Not so long ago a Prime Minister of Israel said there was no such thing as a Palestinian Arab. And many of us, supporters of Israel, have wished the problem away in similar fashiondenying the existence of the Palestinians or saying that responsibility for them rested with the Arab states.

title: Cape Town Blacks Are Warnet Their Shacks Will Be Demolished
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 11 (AP)The South African Government warned black squatters outside Cape Town today that it would soon start demolishing their shacks, a move that could leave more than 10,000 people homeless.

title: ASSAILANT FATALLY SHOT BY TEXAN HOTEL VISITOR
description: A security director from Texas shot and fatally wounded one of two men who tried to rob him at knifepoint in his room last night at the New York Hilton Hotel, the police said. The other assailant fled.

title: MIDEAST PEACE DRIVE A STRAIN ON LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11Lebanon is struggling to preserve its fragile traditional neutrality in the Middle East in the face of President Anwar elSadat's peace drive, which has divided the Arabs and heightened tensions here.

George Pearson, said the first increase in 21 monthn was prompted by higher costs of newsprint production components.

Social Security for All
description: Social Security taxes are going up this month, starting a decade of increases that will eventually triple the contribution demanded from many. But as Prof. Lincoln Bloomfield of M.I.T. pointed out in our Letters column yesterday, the members of Congress who voted for the latest hikes will be unaffected. The legislators and- more importantall civilian employees of the Federal Government do not belong to the Social Security system.

title: ReadingTest Scores Deplored by Mayor
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that reading test scores released by the Board of Education on Tuesday, which showed that six out of 10 students in public elementary and junior high schools were reading below the national average, are tragic proof of the need to improve the leadership structure of this city's school system.

description: To construct a camera obscura, you need a dark room. Block off all the light with curtains or black plastic. Cut a hole in the wall if the roomn has no windows (and if your landlord won't sue you), or in the black plastic if you're blocking out the light, about four inches in diameter so that light can pass through.

description: The socalled heart law, which makes it possible for New York City policemen and firemen to retire at threequarters pay if they develop any heart ailment during their term of employment, was sharply attacked by Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: City Ballet: Other Dances
description: AS PERFORMED by the New York City Ballet, Jerome Robbins's Other Dances has always had a serene and impish glory all its own. The duet, set to six piano pieces by Chopin, was created for Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov of American Ballet Theater, who gave it a decidedly earthier cast. Now, nearly two years after its premiere, the dance has more to do with air and light.

title: Backgammon:
description: The first few moves in backgammon are the formative stages of the game, during which both sides should develop their positions quickly by getting men into play and making key points. Knowing which points are most valuable to own is essential: The 5point is the most strategically valuable point; next and approximately equal in importance are the 4point and the 7point (the bar point). The diagrammed position is taken from the early, developmental stages of a game. X has already made his bar point. He rolls a 32, an excellent numberhe can make his 5point with it by playing 8/5, 7/5.

title: A City's EnergySaving
description: WASHINGTONThe small city of Davis, Cal., offers a good example of what a community can do on its own to save energy. With a population of about 33,000 Davis is set amidst the lush farmlands of the northern central valley. It is both the home of a major campus of the state university system and a residency for office workers in nearby Sacramento, the state capital.

The truck was carrying printing plates for the 6,000circulation morning newspaper yesterday and was on its way to presses 23 miles away. The 113-yearold Herald is normally printed in Union City on presses owned by Brown-Thompson Newspapers.

She fearsnot necessarily in the following ordermurderers. rapists, pursesnatchers, flashers and all of the seamy types who take advantage of rushhour crowds to rub up against women. Nowhere has this been more dramatically in evidence than in the design of FM tuners, where recent refinements now provide satisfactory sound even where FM reception had been marginal or outright impossible.

So it is notable that the Carter Administration has brought an enlightened voice of reason to their harassed world of health warnings, induced guilt, and threatened social ostracism. That voice was heard recently as President Carter's top adviser on health, Dr. Peter G. Bourne, addressed the Tobacco and Smoking Research Committee of the American Cancer Society on the issue of smoking and health.

title: NEW &
description: If your New Year's resolutions include a vow to stied extra pounds and tone up sagging muscles, you can bring a little color into those situps by luxuriating on a quilted, brusheddenim exercise mat. It comes in an assortment of print patterns with solid borders (the one shown here is a sailor's knot in blue and white); the side flaps extend out. The mat, when fully opened, measures more than six feet. It's also a portable traveling companionon a plane or train; use it as a neck roll or a blanket wrap and when you've reached a vacation spot, stretch out by the side of the pool. The mat is at Accents, 1250 Lexington Avenue; $40. (There's no name on the store so it's important to remember the address.)

title: Film: 'Sasquatch' Roams Northwest:Monster Search
description: "SASQUATCH" is the kind of pseudoscientific silliness that manages to discredit itself entirely, thanks to an approach that might best be labeled simulated-verit. It begins with some hyperbole about Bigfoot, a.k.a. Sasquatch, who would allegedly be the most important anthropological find of our time if anyone could bag him. Then it turns up some "authentic" footage of the creature that has been examined and pronounced The Real Thing by "scientists." After that, we even see a computer making a composite sketch of Bigfoot, based in part on this very same footage, and are expected to marvel at the similarity between the two images.But the movie then disintegrates into a long and tedious account of an expedition to track the monster through the Pacific Northwest to his lair, and the search-party personnel are so appallingly actorish that they throw any semblance of seriousness to the winds.In addition to Josh, an old mountain man who whistles "Swanee River" and is accompanied by his faihful mule, there are also a bumbling cook who is kidded about his culinary skills but is always praised for his coffee. There are a skeptical reporter from New York City, a dog tracker, an Indian guide, "one of the most distinguished anthropologists in the world," and an expedition leader who puffs thoughtfully on his pipe and speaks alternately of the beauty of nature and the gravity of this mission.There is also Sasquatch himself, a pointy-headed fellow in a Kong suit, who is seen throwing papier-Mach boulders a few times and whose presence is often represented by "Jaws"-type music and rustling branches. Sasquatch isn't on camera long and, of course, he isn't captured. But this expedition, we are told, "will provide volumes of information to stimulate more-extensive exploration."Actually, the only interest in the Bigfoot phenomenon that "Sasquatch" is likely to generate will be in Hollywood, if by some outlandish fluke the movie becomes a hit. This seems unlikely, unless the market for poorly shot nature footagethe movie is padded with endless shots of furry little scamps twitching playfully for the camerais more sizable than seems possible. Indeed, the animal shots are so repetitive that, when the print at the first show at the Embassy 46th Street Theater inadvertently included two versions of the same reel, it took a benumbed audience quite a while to realize it was watching the same grizzly bear scuffle all over again.

title: Australian Leads in Sailing
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 (Reuters) Carl Ryves of Australia sailed Tide Teaser to victory in the opening race of the Etchells22 Class world yachting championship today. Martin Visseer of Austialia, in Thunder Egg, was second in the 12mile event, held on a rough ocean course. Only four of the 16 American yachts entered finished in the first 20. The top American yacht was Orient Express, skippered by the defending champion, David Curtis. He was 12th.

title: 2 Start Terms in Nuclear Protest
description: EXETER, N.H., Jan. 11 (AP)Two persons arrested in a 1976 attempt to occupy the Seabrook nuclear-power-plant site to protest the construction surrendered to the authorities today to begin serving threemonth jail terms. Kevin Hopkins, 26 years old, of Loudon, and Mary Gregory, 47, of Keene, turned themselves in at the Rockingham County Superior Court. They had been out on $500 bail each pending appeals of contempt-ofcourt findings for having violated an injunction against trespassing on the Seabrook site in August 1976.

title: Nicaragua at a Glance

There are three distinct geographic regions: the populous western lowlands, a large central highland and a Caribbean coastal plain.

title: Stage: A Flea In Hartford's Ear
description: WHAT is it about a door that can unhinge an audience into laughter? Behind that doorif this is a French bedroom farce such as Georges Feydeau's A Flea in Her Ear'may lurk an apparently cuckolded husband, a jealous wife, a nosy valet or the elusive answer to a cavalcade of duplicities and mistaken identities. The door itself becomes a punch line. Close it suddenly at the precise moment that someone almost spies a secret on the other side and the result can be a grand slam of cavorting comedy.

title: Indiana Is Defeated By Minnesota, 7562
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 12 (AP)  Mychat Thompson scored 21 points and blocked seven shots as Minnesota defeated 18thranked Indiana, 7562, in a Big Ten game tonight.

title: Restaurants
description: HEE SEUNG FUNG, the Chinatown restaurant more popularly known as H.S.F., has for years been a favorite spot not only for aboveaverage Cantonese and Hong Kong cooking, but most of all for its wonderful dim sum dumpling tea lunch. Four months ago, a second H.S.F. opened on Second Avenue between 31st and 32d Streets, and it is a far cry from the lively and lusty original. Called only H.S.F., with no mention of the longer full name, the new East Side outpost offers a gleaming, polished and handsome interior that comes as a surprise after seeing its drab and anonymous exterior with a horrible red-and-white lighted plastic sign.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: SMITHMildred Cushing. Aged 78, of 631 Main Ave, Bay Head, New Jersey, formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of Charles F, mother of Berry C Smith. For further information contact the Van Hise & Callagan Funeral Home, 812 Arnold Avenue, Pt Pleasant, N.J. Memorial funeral services will be held at St Paul's United Methodist Church, Bay Head, Saturday, January 14, at 1 PM.

title: North Bergen Mayor Penalized
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12 (AP)  Mayor Peter M. Mocco of North Bergen was suspended from the practice of law for one year today on disciplinary charees of making a series of mis- representations on legal documents. The New Jersey Supreme Court handed down the disciplinary action. against Mr. Mocco, who was said to have signed the names of business associates on a mortgage without their permission and signed the name of his brother, Joseph Mocco, as notary public.

title: British Judge Backs Right to Air Race Views, Stirring Bitter Debate
description: LONDON, Jan. 12  Since last Friday, Britons have been gripped in a nationwide controversy over the stand taken by a criminal court judge that all people regardless of their views should have the riEht to speak out on racial issues.

title: Aid Is Sought for Owners of Indian Lands
description: A move to get Small Business Administration aid for the holders of land that has been claimed as tribal property by upstate New York Indians has been started by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: A Correction
description: In the recipe for kugelhopf published in The Living Section last Wednesday, it was not made clear that the raisins should be worked into the dough right after the butter has been added.

title: BLACKOUT LOOTING CASES BRING MANY CONVICTIONS
description: Most of the criminal cases growing out of the widespread looting in Manhattan in the blackout the night of July 1314 have resulted in convictions, the office of District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau reported yesterday.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 12Firebombs, believed to have been placed by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, exploded at eight commercial targets in Belfast at dawn today, destroying four businesses and badly damaging the others.

title: Recital: Edward Auer
description: CERTAIN works are regarded as offlimits by most pianists simply because they strain technical powers to the utmost. Other works, not necessarily easier to play acurately, are held in awe because they demand exalted musicianship, emotional breadth and artistic maturity. Edward Auer, who gave a piano recital Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, performed both sorts of pieces with notable success.

title: Stock Market, in Token Advance, Shows First Gain for This Year
description: The stock market produced a token rally yesterday, mainly reflecting some strength shown by the dollar in late dealings in. Europe, to show its first gain of 1978.

title: Superdorne a Bottomless Pit for Taxpayer Funds
description: NEW ORLEANS  If each of the 70,000 or so spectators at Sunday's Super Bowl in the Superdrome were to leave behind a quarter on his colorcoded seat, the money would just about cover the interest Oarges being paid per day by the Dome's operators.

title: Jobless Rate: Elusive Statistic
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The good news reported yesterday by the Bureau cit Labor Statisticsthat there was a steady improvement in the unemployment picture in 1977, contrary to the earlier impression of highlevel stagna-

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Renaissance Band on North Shore Sunday
description: The North Shore Community Arts Center will take on the sound of a festive 16thcentury European village Sunday with the appearance of the New York Renaissance Band. Music for a village wedding, a battle, the court of Maximilian I and other pieces will be performed by the four-year-old hand. The senter is at 236 Middle Neck Road in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Art: Souvenirs From 30's and 40's
description: WHEN Fernard Lger arrived in this country in 1940 as a refugee from a defeated France he did not come as a stranger. It was his fourth visit to the United States. As late as 1938 he had painted a decoration for Nelson A. Rockefeller. and altogether he felt at home in what he called this young country that hasn't even had to shave, as yet.

title: BASIC MONEY SUPPLY CLIMBED $4.1 BILLION IN WEEK ENDED JAN. 4
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply had climbed $4.1 billion in the latest statement week, It was one of the largest increases in the last year.

title: Bridge
description: An expert seldom doubles an opposing contract of three notrump, and when he does so he is hardly ever motivated by sheer greed.

title: Art People
description: Hess may get Met job.

title: NEW RIOTING ERUPTS IN NICARAGUA CAPITAL
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 12  New disurbances broke out today after some 30,000 people attended the funeral of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, the outspoken newspaper editor and opponent of the Somoza Government who was slain here Tuesday.

title: Andretti Sets Track Record
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Tan. 12 (UP!)  Mario Andretti, a fourtime Formula One Winner last year, toured the 3.5mile Autodrome in a track rec- ord 1 minute 48.12 seconds today during practice runs for the Argentine Grand Prix Sunday, opening event of the 1978 auto racing season. Andretti, of Nazareth. Pa., was driving a John Player Lotus.

title: Lincoln Center Gives Belly Dancing A Whirl
description: Naima Dalel, who will participate in The Great GreekMideast Music and Belly Dance Spectacular tonight. See Page C24.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: KnicksNets Suit Postponed
description: The Knicks lawsuit against the Nets for failure to meet their indemnification payments was postponed for a third time yesterday, until Feb. 24 in order to give Arthur Imperatore, a New Jersey trucking magnate, more time to decide whether he wants to purchase a substantial part of the financially troubled Nets.

title: Marcus Schloss &
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered hearings yesterday against Marcus Schloss & Co. Inc., a New Yorkbased seeurities firm, in connection with alleged violations of the antifraud provi, sions of the Federal securities law. The commission charged the firm and a former employee with disseminating public reports of transactions that gave a mis. leading appearance to the market for certain options on the Chicago Board Options Exchange.

title: Wholesale Prices Indicate Quickening Inflation Pace
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Government reported today a quickening in the pace of inflation at the wholesale level in December, mainly reflecting the biggest rise in food prices in sefen months.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
PHILIP P. GEIGER
description: Philip P. Geiger, a founder and partner for the last 43 years in Willis & Geiger Inc., makers of outdoor sportswear, of Manhattan, died Wednesday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 60 years old and lived in Harrison, N. Y.

title: Clerks Out But Big A Resumes
description: Aqueduct limped back into operation on a limited basis yesterday, even though its 500 mutuel clerks refused to cross the picket lines of striking maintenance workers.

title: Keyworth of Broncos Receives Death Threat
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12  A threat was made today on the life of Jon Keywcrth, the fullback for the Denver Broncos. It came three days in advance of the Super Bowl game that will match Keyworth's team against the Dallas Cowboys for the championship of the National Football League.

title: Fire in Mobile Home Kills Five
description: PHENIX CITY, Ala., Jan. 12 (UPI)Five persons died today in a fire that swept through a mobile home and several rooms that had been added to it. Three of the victims were children:, Jim Ward, chief of the volunteer fire department in nearby Ladonia, said that the building was engulfed in flames by the time firefighters arrived. He said that the cause of the fire was unknown...

title: The Truth About Powwows
description: Mention of a powwow brings to mind the made-for-Hollywood image of whooping Indians, with feather headdresses cascading down their backs, hopping around a circle in a frenzied war dance.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Shearson Hayden Earnings Fell By 45% for the Second Quarter
description: Earnings of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. for the second fiscal quarter ended last Dec. 31 declined 45 percent to $1.3 million, or 30 cents a share, from $2.4 million, or 66 cents a share, the brokerage firm announced yesterday. Revenues for the period rose 9 percent however to $48 million from $44.1 million.

title: Man Here Hunts Quarterbacks
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12  Harvey Martin, right end on the Dallas Cowboys defensive team, earns his living by springing upon the other team's quarterback and driving him into the ground like a peg. He had completed his first season as a professional football player when the Cowboys picked Too Tall Jones, a twotime allAmerican at Tennessee State, as their first choice in the college draft. Martin, who grew up in the Dallas area, was in a bar when a stranger approached him, hand outstretched. I want to meet you now, the stranger said, because you'll be gone when Too Tall Jones takes your job. They call Harvey Martin The Smiling Assassin but he does not smile when he recalls that courtly greeting. I iust stared at him, he says. but it ate

title: NEW YORKERS BLOCK 3STATE HOUSING IDEA
description: New York State's delegation to the TriState Regional Planning Commission yesterday blocked the adoption of a controversial housing plan that would require the construction of lowand moderate-income housing in the suburbs.

title: Dayan and Pope Discuss Mideast
description: ROME, Jan. 12  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel met with Pope Paul VI today and they discussed the future of Jerusalem and peace moves in the Middle East.

title: Don Gillis, 65, Composer Who Produced NBC Symphony Shows Under Toscanini
description: Don Gillis, composer and former producer of the NBC Symphony radio broadcasts under Arturo Toscanini, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Columbia, S.C., where he was composer in residence at the University of South. Carolina and chairman of the media arts department. He was 65 years old.

title: Stage: Rosmersholm
description: IBSEN'S ROSMERSHOLM is a powerful and beautiful work, but it is a difficult play. Until close to the end it is mostly revelation and hardly any action. And when the action does come, it is poetically stirring but dramatically unworkable.

title: Levitt Asserts City Mar Not Need Any More Seasonal U.S. Loans
description: Under increasing pressure to lend state pensionfund money to New York City, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the city might not need any seasonal loans, and he proposed eight alternative financing plans that do not include the Federal Government.

title: N.C.A.A. Realigns Football
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 12  The National Collegiate Athletic Association finally voted today to reorganize Division I into two parts for football but stopped short of limiting the more elite group to 79 major colleges. That group, Division IA, could wind up with ps many as 130 members.

title: Sonny Rollins Plays at Carnegie
description: The career of Sonny Rollins, the bearded tenor saxophonist, has been studded with so many periods when he disappeared from the music scene for a year or two for reflection and renewal that even he has come to believe that he still vanishes every few years. That, he says, is why he is giv- ing a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. (Pickets at $6.50, $7.50, $8 and X$8.50 are available at the box office, 2477459.)

title: Human Rights and Good Intentions
description: The year 1977 was the year that human rightsnot freedom, not defense against Communism, but the ways in which other 2overrmients treat their citizensbecame a central theme in American foreign policy. Jimmy Carter came to Washington railing against the, cynical, manipulative. ways of the NixonKissinger era, and proclaiming that he was going to put people first. But 12 months the White House have shown just how difficult it is to make good on good intentions. Some cases in point:

title: FIRE IN MACY'S IS LINKED TO PUERTO RICAN REBEL
description: A small flash fire, reportedly set by a Puerto Rican terrorist, broke out in a ninth floor service area of Macy's department store at Herald Square yesterday afternoon, causing minor damage to a pile of couch cushions.

title: Gross Retains F. Lee Bailey in Move for a New Trial
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12  F. Lee Bailey, the noted criminal lawyer, today joined the defense staff of Nelson G. Gross, the former New Jersey Republican chairman who is seeking a new trial of a 1974 conviction on the ground that Federal marshals became involved romantically with women members of the jury during the trial.

title: Bruins 6, Kings I
description: BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP)  Gregg Sheppard, back in the lineup after missing 25 games because of a knee injury, scored three goals tonight in leading the Boston Bruins to a 61 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in the N.H.L..

title: Profits of Kaiser Aluminum Rise Sharply
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a sharp upturn in profits in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31 with sales last year exceeding the $2 billion mark for the first time. Net income for the quarter was $30 million, or $1.48 a share, in contrast to a loss of $2.3 million for the final quarter of 1976.

title: Mondale Says Carter Will Seek To Ease Farm Land Limitation
description: PULLMAN, Wash, Jan. 12Vice President Mondale today told Westerners unhappy over the 160acre limitation on ownership of federally irrigated land that the Carter Administration would seek to modify the regulations many of them are objecting to.

description: WHEN Philemon Holland introduced Mr. Anonymous to English readers in 1601, he cloaked him in Greek costume in tribute to the word's Greek derivation. Now comes Willard R. Espy, one of our most delightful spinners of whimsy. to concoct a biography of the legend-

title: SOVIET FLU PROMPTS CALL FOR PLAN IN U.S.
description: BETHESDA, Md.. Jan. 12  A group of public health experts recommended today that a vaccine be prepared against a type of influenza that recently spread across the Soviet Union and could reach the United States this winter or spring.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: ALTHOUGH Horace Greeley, the 19thcentury newspaper editor, politician and reformer, advised thousands of young men to go West to seek their fortunes, he chose to remain in the East to farm and to further his own ambitions in what was then the tiny village of Chappaqua in rural Westchester County.

title: Empress, at a Dinner, Has to Cope With Protesters
description: A sea of policemen last night kept apart two opposing groups of demonstrators, each numbering more than a thousand, while the Empress of Iran addressed a celebritystudded audience In the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Martin Trapp, Former Executive With Benton &
description: Martin Anthony Trapp, a former vice president and associate media director of the advertising agency of Benton & Bowles Inc., died Tuesday of cancer at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived at 146 Grove Street in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Tongsun Park Accord Shows U.S. Agreed to Limit Scope of Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Jan. 13 The United States traded a chance to press Tongsun Park for evidence about President Park Chung Hee and the Korean Government here for access to him and his eventual return to the United States, documents and interviews have disclosed.

title: Physician to Be Honored
description: Dr. Thomas C. Chalmers. president of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and dean of its School of Medicine, will receive the Israel Humanitarian Award tomorrow night at a dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel under the auspices of the medical division of the Greater New York Committee for Israel Bonds. Last summer, Dr. Chalmers led a delegation of physicians to Israel, The award is in recognition of his dedicated and inspiring leadership in the effort to foster Israel's growth and progress.

title: Fellowship for Former Mental Patients at Miami Home
description: MIAMI, Jan. 10  Susan has been in and out of mental hospitals for years, but now she is 30 years old and her parents will not take her back home. So, after her last release she moved into a rundown boarding house, where she found plenty of roaches, few friends and nothing to do.

description: The dollar rose significantly ins New York yesterdayafter initially dropping in Europe and then recovering somewhat as the Federal Reserve intervened to check earlier sharp declines on European and Asian money markets, The Associated Press reported.

title: Prague Court Rebuffs Appeals By 3 Human Rights Campaigners
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 12 (AP)  The Czechoslovak Supreme Court today turned down appeals by three human rights activists sentenced to prison in October for crimes against the state, the press agency Ceteka reported.

title: PRICES FOR BONDS RECOVER SLIGHTLY
description: The credit markets, registering one of their very few gains of the last seven weeks, recovered slightly yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's sharp decline.

title: Ford Recalling 4,900 Trucks
description: DETROIT, Jan. 12 (UPI)Ford Motor Company today announced the recall of about 4,900 Ford trucks that may have cracked fan blades that could break apart while the engine is running. A Ford spokesman said no accidents or injuries have been reported as a result of the defect in some Cseries mediumchity trucks manufactured from 1972 through Dec. 5, 1977, with 361, 389- or 391cubicinch gasoline engines and automatic transmissions. Owners will be advised by mail of what to do.

title: Grain Workers Undaunted By Elevator Blast Deaths
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12  Towering 165 feet above the cold dark waters of the Calumet River on Chicago's South Side, Cargill Inc.'s grain elevator was a great, gray concrete tube silhouetted alone against a paler gray sky. There was no sign ofmotionaroundi t the other day except yellow corn pouring from a high spout into the belly of a red river barge.

title: DOLLAR'S INSTABILITY LINKED BY PRESIDENT TO ENERGY PROBLEMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  President Carter today attributed the current instability of the dollar to the nation's continuing appetite for imported oil and the failure of Congress to adopt his energy program.

title: Medieval Jewish Music Sunday on L. I
description: Music of the medieval Jews, featuring 12thcentury chants that were discov. ered a few years ago in Cairo, will be performed Sunday at 3 P.M. by the New World Consort in the Freennrt Memorial Library, Ocean Avenue and Merrick Road in Freeport, L.I. The music was found in the Cairo Genizah, where old or torn papers that con- tained sacred writings received ritual burial.

title: Deaths
description: McCALLSusan A. The Board of Directors of McCaffrey and McCall. Inc.. records with deepest sorrow the passing of Susan A. McCall, wife of David 8. McCall. Chairman of the Board. We extend our heartfelt symoaths, to David McCall and members of the family.

description: Mayor Koch intends to sign an executive order today raising the pay of 2,100 top and middlemanagement city executives by $3,000 to $7,000 a year.

title: Stein Plans Westway Hearings
description: Andrew W. Stein. the Manhattan Borough President. announced yesterday that he would hold hearings on the Westway on Jan. 25 and that he would invite Governor Carey and other interested officials to testify.

title: Asia House Unveils Riches of a Lost Empire
description: FOR most of us, the history of the Sasanian Empire is not familiar intellectual territory. From the third century of the Christian era until the middle of the seventh, writes Prudence Oliver Harper, curator of ancient Near Eastern art at the Metropolitan Museum, the Sasanian kings ruled over a realm comparable to that of the emperors of Rome and Byzantium. Yet Rome and even Byzantium live for us in a way that the Sasanian Empire does not. It once included all of what is now Iran and Iraq, parts of Armenia, Georgia, Afghanistan and southern Central Asia, and even extended into Egypt, yet apparently no clear picture of its life and thought has so far been construed  even among scholars who have made this their principal field of study.

title: Large Fishing Craft Are Taking On a YachtLike Look
description: There has already been a decade of progress in larger fishing craft, and it appears likely to continue. About 10 years ago custtumbuilt sports-fishermen dominated the offshore scene. Rapid strides have been made in the development of stock boats, and they seem to be pouring off the production lines.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 12 (AP)  The Australian 800meters champion, John Higham, scored the biggest victory of his career tonight when he defeated John Walker of New Zealand, the world recordholder for the mile, in the International Games.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 12, 1978

title: Publishing: Taking a Chance on First Novels
description: PUBLISHING wisdom goes that it is harder to succeed with novels than nonfiction books, and that fewer first novels are surfacing on publishers lists because they are risky costly and ignored. But the better part of wisdom, some publishers believe, is to ignore the conventional wisdom. The other wisdom is just to follow your instincts and heartbeats.

title: De La Roche's Confession
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 12  Harry De La the Jr. held a pistol to his sleeping her's head for 15 minutes before he ally shot him and then proceeded to 1 his mother and two brothers, a police eveant today quoted the 19-year-old ? military student as having confessed to him.

title: Dr. DeMarco Fined As Board in Jersey Cancels His License
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12The State Board of Medical Examiners revoked the license today of Dr. Peter T. DeMarco of Pind Hill, and fined him $20,200 for gross malpractice in causing a hepatitis outbreak by using unsterilized needles.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Opposes Fuel Code for Trucks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The N.A.A.C.P., which this week turned its attention to economic issues by embracing a policy of energy deregulation, has also taken a stand against proposed fuel economy standards for trucks, the organization announced today.

title: J. P. Morgan and Chemical Corp. Report Earnings Up for Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday earnings increases of 1.5 percent for the final quarter and 7.7 percent for all of last year while the Chemical New York Corporation made a 5.4 percent gain in fourthquarter earnings and 14.2 percent for the year.

title: U.S. Calls on Italians to Reduce Influence of Communist Party
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The United States, seeking to prevent Communist entry into the Italian Government, said today that Italy's Communist Party did not share democratic values and interests, and urged Italy and other West European countries to reduce Communist influence.
