description: Friday MUSIC FOR ROCKLAND

title: McGuire Promotes 3 and Names Woman as Deputy Commissioner
description: Moving quickly to reshape the high command of the Police Department. Robert J. McGuire, the new Police Commissioner, has selected three field commanders for promotion to the rank of chief and has filled two of the four vacancies on the deputy commissioner's level.

title: Music: Da Capo Players
description: THE DA CAPO Chamber Players brought together a well-contrasted group of pieces to play in the concert they gave at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night in the first of a series of three appearances the ensemble is making under Carnegie Hall sponsorship this season.

title: SUSAN WALL, 35, DIES; ADVERTISING COPYWRITER
description: Susan Alder Sydney McCall, advertising copywriter and wife of David B. McCall, chairman of the McCaffrey & McCall advertising agency, died Wednesday night in Mount Sinai Hospital after suffering a stroke at home on Monday. She was 35 years old and lived with her husband in New York and Cannel, N.Y.

title: Carter Assails Moscow on Ethiopia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  President Carter accused the Soviet Union today of unwarranted interference in the SomaliEthiopian fighting over the Ogaden border area and urged talks to end the conflict.

title: Barons 6. Sabres 3
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Cleveland Barons scored four goals in the final period tonight and defeated the Buffalo Sabres. 63. in the N.H.L. Rick Hampton tied the score at 33 with 2:01 of the final period remaining and Jean Potvin scored what proved to be the winning goal at 5:48, taking a pass on the right point from Dennis Maruk and beating Don Edwards with a long slap shot.

title: The Pop Life
description: FOR the last few years, those of us who attend popmusic concerts regularly have noticed a decline in the numbers of whites a, concerts by black artistsand of blacks at concerts of white artists. Of course, there's no way to prove that scrt of observation in the absence of statistical studies carried out over several years. But the perception remains a strong one: concerts appear more scgreguted than they used to be.

title: Dr. Chauncey D. Leake Dies at 81; Pharmacologist and Administrator
description: Dr. Chauncey D. Leake, an inteniationally known pharmacologist, medical historian and administrator and a prolific writer, died Wednesday in San Francisco, where he taught at the University of California Medical School. Dr. Leake was 81 years old.

title: Mrs. Klein Says State Is Helping In Resettling of ExMental Patients
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  Ann Klein, the Commissioner of Human Services, said todayin response to reports about mistre:tment of farmer mental patients in boarding honrs that since 1975 the patients had been offered help in resettling upon them discharges from hospitals.

title: Fatal Utility Explosion
description: One electrician suffered fatal burns and a second was severly injured yesterday in the explosion of a circuit breaker in a nower substation in Fairfield. Conn. The explosion occurred at the substation on Unguowa Road, just off Route 1, cutting off electrical service to 2,800 residential and commercial customers of the United Illuminating Company for up to six hours. Joseph Ellis, 57 years old, died at Bridgeport Hospital seven hours after the explosion. George Stein, 53, was reported in fair condition.

title: Broadway
description: Your Cat Is Dead! will come here again, going into previews at the Promenade Theater on Feb. 1. James Kirkwood its author, says he is delighted by this; ht also says he has taken three characters out of the old second act and rewritten much of the play. We thought we had a big hit when we came to New York the last time, Mr. Kirkwood said, but we were not greeted so warmly, and it was very hurtful. Then, he said, A Chorus Line, for which he and Nicholas Dante wrote the book, came along and took much of the hurt away.

title: WeatherModification's Future
description: WASHINGTON  On July 12, 1946, Vincent J. Schaefer, a General Electric Company laboratory assistant, exhaled deliberately into a three-cubic-foot deepfreeze unit that he had lined with black velvet. His breath made a tiny cloud. Then he scattered a handful of dry ice into the box. Magically, a beautiful little snowstorm appeared, its delicate crystals making minuscule drifts on the velvet. This culminated many experiments that he and the Nobel laureate chemist Irving Langmuir had made to uncover the mysteries of precipitation.

title: ES. AND JAPAN OPEN TWODAY DISCUSSION OF TRADE PROBLEMS
description: TOKYO, Jan. 12Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special trade representative, opened two days of critical talks with Japanese officials here today with the aim of settling a series of major trade issues between these two economic superpowers.

title: Film Forum: The Last Days of Allende:Guzman Documentary
description: "THE Battle of Chile," which opened yesterday at the Film Forum, is an admittedly biased, pro-revolutionary film that raises more questions than it can easily answer. Though it is fabricated of facts, it seems to skirt issues. It is monotonous and long, but it is an important, profoundly disturbing work. It makes one wonder if there is such a thing as a truly revolutionary film form, or if revolution exists only in the eye of the beholder.The film is a three-hour-and-10-minute, two-part documentary on the last months of the democratically elected, pro-Marxist regime of Chilean President Salvador Allende Gossens, who reportedly committed suicide during the right-wing military coup that overturned his Government in September 1973. The film was directed by Patricio Guzmn, a young Chilean, and assembled in Cuba by him and his Chilean associates from some 20 hours of footage smuggled out of Chile after the coup. "The Battle of Chile" is not an easy film to watch, not because the events it details are so sorrowful, so inevitable, which they are, but because the film itself is so studiously impersonal.Mr. Guzmn has done nothing less than photograph the conflicting forces of contemporary history and found, when he emerged from the darkroom, that the forces of contemporary history are so faceless there's very little to distinguish one side from the other. The only thing that gives point and direction to "The Battle of Chile" is Mr. Guzmn's Marxist interpretation of the events, but this interpretationrelying, as it does, on the age-old conflict between proletariat and bourgeoisie as well as on the exploitation of a poor nation by a rich onedoesn't do full justice to the Chilean tragedy as we know it to be.The country we see in this film looks like a playground for mischievous gods, the result, I suspect, of the director's conscious decision not to appeal to bourgeois sentimentality. The film is virtually one long, unbroken montage composed of scenes of mass demonstrations, either pro- or anti-Allende, of people chanting slogans or marching with banners that contain slogans, of press conferences, of union meetings, of rallies of every description. Everyone is anonymous, even the subject of periodic man-in-the-street interviews.The effect is to depersonalize history to such an extent that even the documented interventions in Chilean internal affairs by agencies of the United States is made to seem remote, a tide of history, something for which no one need take personal responsibility. I doubt that this is the way Mr. Guzmn intended his film to be taken, and, indeed, I doubt that is the film's effect in other parts of the world where simply the mention of the Central Intelligence Agency is enough to cause cold sweats. Revolutionary films cannot be all things to all people.I assume that the filmmakers must regard the late Dr. Allende as some kind of hero, though, because we see him here only as part of an official background, not as a character but as a personage, in newsreels on state occasions, even he remains remote. And because he was not a very imposing man physically, the movie appears to make him a less dynamic, heroic figure than he really was.In "The Battle of Chile," President Allende appears to be a sort of weightless symbol, whether surrounded by aides or as the central figure at mass rallies, where he was adored. His fate, the film seems to say without wanting to, was as much the result of the failure of his supporters to inform and protect him as it was the victory of the enemies who conspired against him.No matter how one reacts to "The Battle of Chile," it is undeniably an epic. It is also depressing in the way it keeps trying to make complex events seem simple. There's a scary moment at a pro-Allende rally where the thou-stands of assembled workers are instructed, "Jump if you are not a fascist." Just about everybody starts bobbing up and down on cue, as if that, after all, was what the battle of Chile was all about.The film will be shown at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 and repeated there next week, Thursday through Sunday, at the same time.

title: Koch Plans to Increase Salaries Of 2,100 City Executives Today
description: Mayor Koch intends to sign an executive order today raising the pay of 2,100 top and middle management city executives by $3,000 to $7,000 a year.

title: Foster Care Program Is Called A Dumping Ground for Children
description: The chairman of the Mayor's Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect said yesterday that foster care has become a dumping ground for children and called for more emphasis on counseling and other efforts to keep families together.

title: Penguins Tie Flyers, 44, On Kehoe's Goal in Third
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (UPI)  Rick Kehoe scored the tying goal early in the third period and the Pittsburgh Penguins later killed of two Philadelphia power plays tonight to preserve a 44 tie with the Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

title: OldFashioned Winters
description: Whatever happened to our oldfashioned winters? asked Thomas Jefferson 200 years ago, and people have been asking the same question ever since. As a venture outdoors makes plain, the answer, now as then, is, Not much. Over the years, winter hasn't changed a great deal. When the weather records are averaged, decade by decade, they show little variation. One of the longest continuous records, for New Haven, Conn., shows only about three degrees temperature difference between the coldest and warmest decades since 1780.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Koch Gives Toia 2 Additional Jobs
description: Philip L. Toia, the city's Deputy Mayor for Finance, yesterday was given the additional posts of Health Services Administrator and chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Purdue 7970 Victor
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 12 (AP)  Jerry Sichting scored 20 points in the second half, leading Purdue to a 7970 Big Ten Victory over Wisconsin tonight.

title: Ellen R. Hill Is Married To Peter C. Simon Jr.
description: Ellen R. Hill and Peter C. Simon Jr. were married yesterday in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations by Rabbi Judah Nadich of the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Valentine A. Fallon, Retired Editor Of Elizabeth Daily Journal, at 88
description: Valentine A. Fallon, who retired in 1959 as executive editor of The Elizabeth (N.J.) Daily Journal, died Monday in Alexian Brothers Hospital, Elizabeth, after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived at 12 Algonquin Place, Elizabeth.

title: Everyone Gets Into the Act
description: Avantgarde performances are generally intimate affairsa solo or a few people huddled together in a loft, wor!dng oat their ideas in minimally spare surroundings.

title: At the Movies
description: HAMBURG is a very strange place, Karen Black, just back from two weeks in the great German seaport, was saying the other day. It's so very white and so very serious. You never see any black or brown faces. Everyone wears glasses and vests and carries briefcases. The men all wear cravats. They also smoke pipes.

title: Henry Ford Tours His Operations in Land of Apartheid
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Jan. 12  When Henry Ford 2d toured his company's Struandale automobile plant here today, Vapi Mzongwana was too busy fixing trunk locks, door handles and windshield wipers to pay much attention.

title: Connors Defeats Orantes In a Challenge Match
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 12 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors defeated Manuel Orantes, 63, 6-4, in a challenge match tonight, the first of three with a $90,000 total purse.

title: Marijuana Tied To Brain Change In Monkey Tests
description: A prominent brain researcher said yesterday that his experiments on two rhesus monkeys trained to smoke the equivalent of one marijuana cigarette a day, five days a week for six months, had found what appeared to be microscopic but permanent changes in brain anatomy. The scientist, Dr. Robert Heath of Tulane University, has reported similar findings before but with far higher doses.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: IN the first contract of its kind, a former Secretary of State has agreed to serve as adviser and consultant to a television network for five years at a reported price of about $1 million. The terms call for one news special each year, and the first effort, running for 90 minutes, can be seen on NBC tonight at 9:30.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12  Because trials would have led to disclosure of national secrets, 40 to 60 crimes by Americans ranging from outright murder to major espionage have not been prosecuted, Senator Joe Biden, a member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said last night in a speech at Stanford University.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Precious Metals Futures Tumble, Orange Juice and Potatoes Climb
description: Prices of precious metals futures turn bled yesterday on three adverse developments, which also depressed most foreign currencies and steadied interest rate markets.

title: The U.N. Today
An Interview With Somoza's Foe, Now Dead
description: On Nov. 22, Charles W. Flynn, an aide of Edward I. Koch's, and Robert E. Wilson, a freelance journalist, interviewed Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, the editor and publisher of La Prensa of Managua, an outspoken opponent of Nicaragua's dictator, Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, in Mr. Charnorro's office. Mr. Chamorro was shot to death in downtown Managua Tuesday. Excerpts from the interview, translated from the Spanish by Leda Gancio and John Eagleson, follow.

title: CONFESSION
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 12Harry De La Roche Jr. held a pistol to his sleeping father's head for 15 minutes before he fatally shot him and then proceeded to kill his mother and two brothers, a police lieutenant today quoted the 19-year-old former military student as having confessed to him.

title: Ghanaian Poet Comes Home
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.  He used to think of the State University Center here as an impossible placethe cold winters and the vast campus. But when he was in solitary confinement in his native Ghana, Kofi Awoonor found himself dreaming of Stony Brook as only a poet can dream.

title: Republican Joins Nine Democrats In Bid for Koch Seat in Congress
description: A lone Republican, S. William Green, announced his candidacy yesterday for the 18th Congressional District seat, the one left vacant by Mayor Koch and sought by nine Democrats.

title: CALIBER TRIAL OPENS ON FRAUD INDICTMENT
description: State Senator Joseph Galiber, DemocratLiberal of the Bronx, and three other men went on trial yesteday on Federal charges that they had carried out a fraudulent scheme to sell a building to a federally financed drugrehabilitation program.

title: Horowitz to Return to Carnegie
description: Vladimir Horowitz, who played at Carnegie Hall last Sunday as piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic in a benefit concert for the orchestra will return to the hall next March for a pair of Sundayafternoon recitals. The program will be the same for the two events, which are scheduled for March 12 and 19. It will include Mozart's Sonata in C (K. 330), and Liszt's Sonata in B minor, along with works by Faure, Rachmaninoff and Chopin.

title: Betty Cook: Woman Becomes a Power in Powerboats
description: And now there is one more sport in which the dominant male has been dislodgedoffshore powerboat racing, and the driver who became the first woman to win the world championship is 54 years old.

title: Board Revokes DeMarco License And Fines Doctor for Malpractice
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12  The State Board of Medical Examiners revoked the license today of Dr. Peter T. DeMarco of Pine Hill, and fined him $20,200 for gross malpractice in causing a hepatitis outbreak by using unsterilized needles and syringes.

title: 35 Firemen Overcome by Tear Gas In Blaze at Capital Police Office
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)  Clouds of tear gas released in a fire at the District of Columbia police headquarters today forced the evacuation of the building and overcame at least 35 firefighters.

title: Gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund Pass $900,000 With a Month to Go
description: The 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $900,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $15,169.80 from 300 donors. The overall figure for the campaign, which will continue through next month, now stands at $902,482.66 from 8,075 contributors.

title: President Concedes Urging Bell to Speed Prosecutor's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  President Carter acknowledged today that he had telephoned Attorney General Griffin B. Bell to ask him to expedite the removal of a Republican United States Attorney in Philadelphia but denied that he had done so because the prosecutor had investigated Democratic officials there.

title: F.T.C. to Rule on Flaw in Some Ford Engines
description: WASHTNGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission will announce tDmorrow that the Ford Motor Company must provide relief for the owners of 2.7 million compact and subcompat cars with piston and other engine flaws, informed sources said today.

title: Two East Germans Flee to West
description: HANOVER, West Germany, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Two brothers aged 23 and 17 escaped to the West across the heavily mined and guarded East German border during the night, the West German border police said today.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Cheeks should be made payable to,The New York limes Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: A Dancer Returns From the Past
description: Twentyfive years ago John Martin, then dance critic of The New York Times, described her as heroically lyric in both movement and physical beauty. Spare, tall, serene, May O'Donnell has retained that heroic essence throw a career mat spans several generations of dance, starting with the early days of Martha Graham There is much to rememberand much to do, as well, for in her late 60's Miss O'Donnell is now hard at work with a fresh new company of her own, which will be seen tonight, Saturday and Sunday at Brooklyn College's Gershwin Theater.

title: 2 Held in Scalping Of Super Bowl Tickets
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 (AP)  Two men have been arrested for allegedly trying to sell $30 Super Bowl tickets for $200 apiece.

title: Two for the Road Married Movers
description: Jeff Sexton drives a tractortrailer or, as they say on citizens band radio, an 18wheeler. But the partner who rides in his rig, who shares his passion for crosscountry trucking along with his aversion to truckstop cooking, is not just another good buddy. She's his wife. And she's not just along for the ride.

title: Utility Denies Liability For Blackout Losses
description: A Consolidated Edison spokesman said yesterday that letters had been sent to 19,000 customers who filed damage claims after last July's blackout, telling them that the events which led to the system blackout are ones for which the company is not liable under the law.

title: U.S. Group Visiting Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 12 (Reuters)A United States Congressional delegation led by Representative Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of Nassau, arrived here today for a fourday visit. Besides talking with Singapore leaders, Mr. Wolff and some) of the other delegates will take part in a conference of American narcotics coor. dinators based in Asia.

title: British Treasures Film Is Shelved by NBC
description: ATWO HOUR documentary on the British royal collections is, temporarily at least, a casualty of the fierce audience-popularity ratings competition among the three networks. NBC, which purchased the program from the BBC last summer with intentions of airing it this season, has set the film aside because it promises to have limited audience appeal in the United Sttates.

title: Hanoi Says It Won't Budge From CambodiaWithout Talks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 12  Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister, Vo Dong Giang, strongly indicated today that Vietnam would not move from its present occupation of significant areas in Cambodia unless the Cambodian Government agreed to negotiate on the conflict between the two former allies.

title: A.&P. Votes Dividend Of 5c, Ending Doubts
description: MONTVALE, N.J., Jan. 12 (UPI)Directors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company voted the regular 5-cent-a-share quarterly dividend on common stock today payable Feb. 15 to holders of record Jan. 27.

title: President Concedes Urging Bell to Speed Prosecutor's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  President Carter acknowledged today that he has telephoned Attorney General Griffin B. Bell to ask him to expedite the removal of a Republican United States Attorney in Philadelphia but denied that he had done so because the prosecutor had investigated Democratic officials there.

title: Neapolitan Pianist Plays With a French Accent
description: It takes a mature musician to play in the United States. A tour of your country can be very dangerous for a career. It is, for one thing, a physical drain. For another, your country is acquainted with the greatest musicians. New York audiences have heard much more of great music making than any other place. Only London, Vienna and Salzburg can be considered musical centers of similar importance.

title: jazz: Double Image
description: WHEN Double Image, a quartet built around David Samuels and David Friedman, each of whom plays both vibraharp and marimba, was first heard at Stryker's a year ago, it was a provocative, unusual group with fresh, distinctive sound in its use of brith the blend and the contrast of vibraharp and marimba.

title: About Real Estate
description: To look at it, nobody would know the troubles that 205 Sea Breeze Avenue has seen. Here is a sixstory elevator building on a breezeblown thoroughfare in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, separated from the water by a park.

title: Dorothy Hamill Sparks Ice Capades
description: THE ICE was barely off the sidewalks of New York when Madison Square Garden spread the stuff on its floor Wednesday night for the opening of the Ice Capades, which will be gliding about through Jan. 22.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS ACCUSED OF BEATING PALESTINIANS
description: BIR ZEIT, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Jan. 12 (AP)  Bir Zeit University officials here formally complained to Israeli authorities today that Israeli soldiers had beaten two Palestinian Arab students. The charge was supported by two British professors.

title: British Firemen Vote to End Strike
description: BRIDLINGTON, England, Jan. 12 (AP)  Britain's 33,000 firemen voted overwhelmingly today to end their nineweek strike and accept a 10 percent wage increase, which was far below their demands.

title: Auctions
description: THE Kingston Tureensmasterpieces of French rococo silver that were designed by JusteAurele Meissonier, the goldsmith to Louis XVcreated a sensation in....the art auction field on Nov. 8 when they were purchased at a Geneva sale conducted by Christie's for $1,104,000, a world record for silver. The purchase of the 18thcentury pair of soup servers also sparked widespread rumors and questions, most of which were answered this week by Sherman E. Lee, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art. Mr. Lee reported that the Cleveland Museum had purchased one of the tureens and will place both on exhibition next month.-

title: Rivington St. Wine Tour
description: The Lower East Side has always been famous for Its Sundays. The wares from the shops on Orchard Street spill out onto the sidewalks, the delicatessens on Essex Street can't make the pastrami sandwiches fast enough, and the smell of pickle brine is heavy in the air.

title: Independent Democrat Nominated For Carol Bellamy's Senate Seat
description: Martin Connor, a 32-year-old counsel to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt, was nominated last night by Brooklyn and Manhattan Democrats to run for the State Senate seat vacated by Carol Bellamy when she became New York City Council President. A special election for the seat will be held on Feb. 14 in the 25th Senatorial District, covering Williamsburg, Brooklyn Heights, South Brooklyn and, across the East River, the Lower East Side. Other Parties have not made their nominees known yet.

title: New, More Severe Booms Shake Charleston, S.C.
description: New booms shook the area of Charleston, S.C., yesterday afternoon and, according to reports reaching the LamontDoherty Geological Observatory and others, they were the most severe since the first mysterious ones were heard Dec. 2.

title: U.S. Taking Part In Cancer Study With New Jersey
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12  The Federal Government has agreed to participate in a special study of the factors that make New Jersey's cancer mortality rate the highest in the nation, state environmental officials disclosed today.

title: Hughes HotelCasino in Las Vegas Is Sold by Summa Corporation
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Jan. 12  The Landmark Hotel and Casino here was purchased today from Summa Corporation, the Howard Hughes holding company, by the Scott Corporation, which owns and operates the Union Plaza Hotel and Casino.

title: Art: Mel Bochner In Paint and Print
description: THE high point of a rather slow week has been the Mel Bochner package, comprising 14 paintings tied in with the cover story in January's Artforum magazine. At the Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway) are six case= IDSCIlDeti Dy the artist on the walls of one room, while eight pastels, done on piper good enough to eat, hang in another.

title: Koch Gives Toia Two Added Posts: Health Agency and Hospitals Chief
description: Philip L. Toia, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Finance, yesterday was given the additional posts of Health Services Administrator and chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: White HousetoPropose RestrictingVeterans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The Carter Administration plans to send to Congress next mcnth legislation that would curtail the preference that military veterans receive in the Civil Service.

title: Budget Office Urges Overhaul of Military Pensions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  A new Congressional report urges a thorough overhaul of the United States military pension system, which has been criticized for its high cost and which is a controversial and emotional issue.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Japanese Shipbuilding Exports Off
description: TOKYO, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Japanese shipyards won only 241 orders last year, their poorest export performance in 13 years, it was announced today. The figuer was about half the 1976 total, the Ship Exporters Association said. The association attributed the decline mainly to the yen's appreciation against the dollar, which made exports more expensive, and a general recession following the 1973 oil crisis.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Text of the U.S. Statement on Italy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Following is the text of the statement on Italian situation issued today by the State Department:

title: Campaign of Martin Luther King: It Lives On in People He Touched
description: A European journalist asked the other day, Whatever happened to Martin Luther King's movement? That is a hard question. Dr. King has been dead almost 10 years and he would have been 49 years old next Sunday.

title: Henry Ford Tours His Operations in Land of Apartheid
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Jan. 12 When Henry Ford 2d toured his company's Struandale automobile plant here today, Vapi Mzongwana was too busy fixing trunk locks, door handles and windshield wipers to pay much attention.

title: RESERVE REPORT
New Orleans Is Unawed by Game
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12  This festive city does not appear awed by the preparations for the Super Bowl game. To most people here, it's merely the Mardi Gras with football pennants.

title: Fashion: A Look at the Simple Truth
description: When Yves Saint Laurent said about five years ago that all a woman needed to be well dressed was a pair of pants, a turtleneck shirt and a raincoat, he was being simplistic. Still, he hit upon a key aspect of contemporary dressing, as pertinent in its way as Diana Vreeland's comment a few years earlier that the sweater would go down in history as the uniform of the 20th century.

title: Show Is Steering a Bullish Course
description: When the Coliseum's glass and chrome doors open tomorrow at 10 A.M.. the 68th annual National Boat Show will be launched for its nineday run. And while a snowstorm may be on the way, the climate throughout the arena's eight acres of display space is optimistic as exhibitors look for crowds expected to total a record 400.000.

title: HAROLD STONE
description: Harold Stone, former vice president of M. H. Lamston, died here yesterday after a long illness. He founded the variety store chain, which has branches throughout the city and suburbs, with the late Mortimer Lahm.

title: Profits of Kaiser Aluminum Rise Sharply
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a sharp upturn in profits in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31 with sales last year exceed ing the $2 billion mark for the first time.

title: France's Discreetly Feminist Magazine
description: PARIS  A new feminist magazine launched with a slick advertising and promotion campaign designed to dissociate it from the French women's, movement, was on the newsstands here this week. It is F. magazine (F for femmes or feminin), and it has met with unqualified approval from the French press, for its tone is moderate and inoffensive.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Controversy, Mystery Continue On Handling of Begelman Case
description: BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 12Three months after David Begelman was ousted as chief of Columbia Pictures here and one month after his reinstatement in one of Hollywood's most powerful jobs, controversy and mystery continue to surround the flamboyant film mogul.

title: Canedlens 6, Red Whigs I
description: DETROIT, Jan. 12(AP)  Guy Lafleur scored his 29th goal of the season and assisted on another tonight as the Montreal Canadiens posted a 64 victoay over the Detroit Red Wings in the N.H.L.

title: BONN OFFICIAL SAYS LAWYER TOOK GUNS TO GUERRILLAS
description: BONN, Jan. 12  West Germany's chief federal prosecutor said today that a radical lawyer had smuggled into prison the pistols used last October by two terrorists in what the West German Government has officially called their suicides.

title: Management
description: The National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws has run afoul of the Internal Revenue Service in its project on a new Uniform Limited Partnership Act. Limited partnerships are the usual vehicles for tax shelters, and the project has thus raised the concern of the I.R.S. Page D9.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: It's nice to be back home, nice to start a new year. I have a brief statement to make before I answer questions.

title: U.S. WILL JOIN STUDY OF CANCER IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 12The Federal Government has agreed to participate in special study of the factors that make New Jersey's cancer mortality rate the highest in the nation, state environmental officials disclosed today.

title: U.S. Calls on Italians to Reduce Influence of Communist Party
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The United States, seeking to prevent Communist entry into the Italian Government, said today that Italy's Communist Party did not share democratic values and interests, and urged Italy and other West European countries to reduce Communist influence.

title: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossetl
description: JOURNEY INTO THE PAST: Shoppers at the Bergen Mall in Phramus looking at items from the turth of the century to the late 60's at Nostalgia exhibit. Items for sale included dolls, phonographs, radios and juke makers.

title: Precious Metals Futures Tumble, Orange Juice and Potatoes Climb
description: Prices of precious metals futures turn bled yesterday on three adverse developments which also depressed most foreign currencies and steadied interest rate markets.

title: EVIDENCE DISMISSED IN THE PINERO CASE
description: Virtually all the evidence in an armedrobbery case against the playwright Miguel Pinero and two other men was ruled inadmissible yesterday by a New York State Supreme Court justice who held that the arrest of the three defendants was patently illegal and that they were subsequently denied their constitutional rights.

title: Bill Miller Checks In
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The newly appointed chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, G. William Miller Jr., has been in Washington this week wondering how he got here and where he's going in 78. A lot of other people are wondering the same, but he seems amiably relaxed.

title: Patricia D. Hemingway, Author And Restaurateur in New York
description: Patricia Drake Hemingway, author and restaurateur, died Wednesday at Memorial SloanKettering Hospital in New York. She was 51 years old and lived at 14 Sutton Place South and Bridgewater, Conn.

title: Music: Kubelik Leads Bruckner's Ninth
description: RAFAEL KUBELIK, beginning the second week of his sixweek guestconducting engagement last night with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher T4211 addressed himself to a character- istically serious and weighty program. The Czech musician's temperament lends itself to the more grandiloquent works of the orchestral repertory, and his concert on this occasion divided itself between Haydn's Symphony No. 99 in E flat and Bruckner's unfinished Ninth.

title: Convertibles Keeping Families Afloat
description: Boat manufacturers don't need a crystal ball to convince them that there is a significant trend toward boats tailored for multiple use. Sales statistics are beginning to demonstrate that boats in the 16- to 26foot class, which offer convertible features or can be used by the entire family, are among the fastest movers.

title: EUROPE IS BATTERED BY SEVERE WEATHER
description: LONDON, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Storms and gales battered Europe today, hitting hardest at Britain where at least 18 people died.

title: Egypt aid Israel Strive at Talks To Minimize Dispute on Settlers
description: CAIRO, Jan. 12  Egypt and Israel sought today to minimize their dispute over the Jewish settlements in the Sinai Peninsula, with their chief military officials expressing confidence that the differences were being narrowed. me Egyptian War Minister and the li Defense Minister appeared togetherat an outdoor news briefing betweeen sessions of the Military Committee, which is in its second day of talks here. They are heading delegations that convened here yesterday to discuss military aspects of a peace settlement. Today, the two sides put forth and compared their conflicting programs for an Israeli military withdrawal from Sinai, as well as for a system of security guarantees for both countries.

title: People and Business Nash Is Vice Chairman of Amex
description: Jack Nash, president and director of Oppenheimer & Company, a leading investment banker, was elected yesterday as vice chairman of the American Stock Exchange's board of governors.

title: VANCE WOULD ACCEPT CANAL PACT CHANGES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance is appealing to the Senate not to try to amend the Panama Canal treaties, but only to attach understandings, or interpretations, if it feels it must altei the documents.

title: Senator Lee Metcalf Dies at 66; Montana Democrat Had 3 Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Senator Lee Metcalf of Montana was found dead today in his apartment in Helena. The cause of death was not given, but he had been in ill health.

title: Physician to Be Honored
description: Dr. Thomas C. Chalmers, president or the Mount Sinai Medical Center and dean of its School of Medicine, will receive the Israel Humanitarian Award tomorrow night at a dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel under the auspices of the medical division of the Greater New York Committee for Israel Bonds. Last summer, Dr. Chalmers led a delegation of physicians to Israel. The award is in recognition of his dedicated and inspiring leadership in the effort to foster Israel's growth and progress.

title: Lighter Beached to Save Her
description: New York harbor's last steampowered lighter, a 65year-old cargo vessel, was lifted onto a deserted pier in Brooklyn yesterday for safekeeping while funds are raised to restore her rusting hull.

title: Food Bought for School Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI)  The Agriculture DOartment bought a total o. 10.7 million pounds of beef, chicken find turkey today for donation to school lunchrooms. (Midi& said that they had snera 577.34 million for an assortment of food including 1.1 million pounds of cannecl beef, 2.7 million pounds of fro en chicken, 1,14.000 pounds of cooked frozen chicken and 3.57 million pounds of bulis froxen hamburger.

title: Carter Assails Moscow on Ethiopia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  President Carter accused the Soviet Union today of unwarranted interference in the SomaliEthiopian fighting over the Ogaden border area and urged talks to end the conflict.

title: Desai Denies India Eases Nuclear Policy
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 12  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai reiterated today India's objections to full international inspection of its nuclear installations.

title: Notes on People
description: A handwritten thankyou note has gone from President Carter to Steven Seymour, the interpreter who stirred criticism when he gave a different connotation to some of the President's remarks at the Warsaw Airport on Dec. 29. Don't let the exaggerated criticisms disturb you, the President wrote to the 31-year-old Mr. Seymour. Those who analyzed your translation say that the errors were minor. You helped to make my visit to Poland very enjoyable andsuccessful. Thanks! The note ended: Your friend, Jimmy Carter. Mr. Seymour, a freelance interpreter who is paid S150 a day, had translated the President's interest in the Poles desires for the future into their lusts for the future. When Mr. Carter said he left the United States, Mr. Seymour translated it to abandoned the country. Mr. Seymour said that he had had some difficulty because he had not had an advance text of the President's remarks and he had to stand in the freezing rain waiting for the President's plane to arrive. He said that he was proud of what I had done under difficult situation.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Times incorrectly reported Saturday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had charged C. Gerald Goldsmith, former president and chairman of the Intercontinental Diversified Corporation, with embezzlement and personal use of the proceeds. In fact, the S.E.C. charged Mr. Goldsmith with violating Federal securities laws by diverting company funds into a political payoff scheme in the Bahamas and by failing to disclose his interczt in stock sold to Intercontinental. The S.E.C. complaint said that a substantial portion of the diverted funds was paid into a bank account controlled by Mr. Goldsmith, but it did not allege personal use of those funds.

title: Neediest Cases Gifts Pass $900,000
description: The 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $900,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $15,169.80 from 300 donors. The overall figure for the campaign, which is in its sixth week and will continue through February, now stands at S902.482.66 from 8,075 contributors.

title: Tennessee Governor Embroiled in Dispute Over Press Negativism

title: The Social Costs of Social Promotions
description: The: back-to-basics movement in public education has a new recruit, Mayor Koch's administration in New York City. In a recent interview, Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo expressed the desire to end the practice of social- Dromotionsautomatically advancing students each year regardless of achievement. His motivation parallels that of state and local governments elsewhere to reverse the downward spiral in education achievement and to restore the credibility of the high school diploma. It is a welcome initiative, but it must be pursued with caution. The diagnosis is far simpler and cheaper than the cure.

title: New Sports Tabloid Cuts Back
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP)The Philadelphia Journal, the sportsoriented tabloid that began publication here last month, is selling less than half of its 100,000 circulation goal, according to its publisher, Pierre Peladeau. He said that the paper, which hit the streets Dec. 5, was selling between 40,000 and 47,000 copies each day. As a result, The Journal has sliced it's 200,000 daily press run to 70,000 copies.

title: The U.S. NorthSouth PoorMouth

Rare is the politician, for example, who cannot hark back to threadbare beginnings or barefoot ploughing behind a mule. It is mostly an exercise in hyperbole, and Southerners tend to compete, well because traditionally the South is rich in material from which to work. So, it is amusing to find the North these days trying to best the South in a poormouth contest.

description: john N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, had his furlough from prison extended to Jan. 27, yesterday by the Justice Department. Mr. Mitchell was released from the Federal prison sOvlaxwell Air Force Base in Alabama ozi Dec. 28, originally for tests to determine if he needed an operation to replace his arthritic right hip. He was to have returned to prison this Sunday but the'aortic problem developed. Mr. Mitchell, who is serving one to four yearS in the Watergate conspiracy Icoverttp, is eligible for parole in June. Dr. Palumbo said Mr. Mitchell would enter Georgetown University Hospital en- Jan. 24 for an operation for the aortic problem. The physician said Mr. Mitchell's chances for recovery were excellent. That still leaves the hip problem, which might require a further exof the furlough.

title: New Movie, 'The Duellists,' Is Set During Napoleonic Wars
description: "The Duellists," the first major film to open here this year, may well remain one of the most dazzling visual experiences throughout all of 1978. The movie, set during the Napoleonic Wars, uses its beauty much in the way that other movies use soundtrack music, to set mood, to complement scenes and even to contradict them. Sometimes it's almost too much, yet the camerawork, which is by Frank Tidy, provides the Baroque style by which the movie operates on our senses, making the eccentric drama at first compelling and ultimately breathtaking."The Duellists," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater, is an adaptation of a Joseph Conrad story, "The Duel," which I haven't read. It's the first feature film by Ridley Scott, a young English director whose previous experience appears to have been entirely in the making of television commercials (though this doesn't show) and it was written by Gerald Vaughan-Hughes, whose work is also unfamiliar to me. However they collaborated, the result is a film that satisfies not because it sweeps us off our feet, knocks us into the aisles, provides us with visions of infinity or definitions of God, but because it is precise, intelligent, civilized, and because it never for a moment mistakes its narrative purpose.This is to recount the bizarre story of how the life of a young French officer named Armand D'Hubert (Keith Carradine) comes to be dominated by the obsession of a fellow officer, Gabriel Feraud (Harvey Keitel), who believes that D'Hubert has somehow impugned his honor. It begins in Strasbourg in 1801, the year Napoleon comes to power, and continues for the next 15 years, throughout the Emperor's rise, fall and brief comeback as the two men accidentally meet in the course of various campaigns, each meeting culminating in a duel that D'Hubert cannot gracefully deny.Though Feraud is clearly mad, there is no way that D'Hubert can avoid the challenges within the code of honor that defines the professional life of each. At Strasbourg, they fight with sabers, at Augsburg with what looks almost like broadswords. Once they meet on horseback. Another time pistols are the weapons. Every time they meet, each pares a little more off the other. It's as if they were whittling each other down to the bone, though the ending, which is a perfect short-story ending, makes it apparent that Feraud's obsession has had the effect of tempering the spiritual strength of the other man.I assume that it's to the credit of Mr. Scott, the director, that after we once get over the shock of seeing Mr. Keitel and Mr. Carradine in the uniforms of Napoleonic Hussars, we never again see anything anachronistic about these two most contemporary of American actors in such strange surroundings. They are splendid and are never once upstaged by such high-powered English acting talent as Albert Finney, Alan Webb, Robert Stephens, John McEnery, Meg Wynn Owen, Edward Fox and Jenny Runacre, who appear in supporting roles. Cristina Raines, a young American actress ("The Sentinel"), is charming in the small but important part of Mr. Carradine's young wife.What one carries away from the film, though, is a memory of almost indescribable beauty, of landscapes at dawn, of over-crowded, murky interiors, of underlit hallways and brilliantly sunlit gardens. It's not a frivolous prettiness, but an evocation of time and place through images that are virtually tactile, and which give real urgency to this curious tale. It's marvelous."The Duellists," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a half-dozen duelling scenes of explicitness as well as grace. They are bloody and brutal and absolutely essential to the point of the film.

title: Clark Air Base Story Revised
description: MANILA, Jan. 13 (AP)The United States Air Force said today that Airman William N. Guidera had been shot in the leg on sentry duty Wednesday night at Clark Air Base when his weapon discharged as he fell into a ditch while chasing an intruder. An earlier report from a base spokesman had said the airman, 18 years old, was wounded during a scuffle with two intruders. Them was only one intruder, the intruder did not shoot the security policeman, and there was no scuffle for the gun, the spokesman said today.

If no action is taken within that period, the sale will be automatically allowed.

title: New York City's Intellectual Life in the 30's
description: I have been asked often by younger writers what New York was like in the 1930's as comparedlo the present. The 30's have had a magic fascination for later generations, like all periods that incubated extreme movements and decisive changes in history. usually answer off the top of my head that we were all broke, that we were lifted momentarily by false hopes, that we enjoyed both the benefits and the disadvantages of being out of the mainstream of the culture, and that I was a kid, which meant that I looked at the whole situation from the perspective of someone who still had his way to make and saw it as a painful but adventurous way of learning and growing up.

title: The Region
description: Democratic governors in the tristate region sound more and more like closet Republicans. Last week, in his State of the State message, Governor Byrne emphasized industrial development rather than social spending for New Jersey, echoing the approach taken by Governor Carey a week earlier in New York. Both governors want to reduce unemployment and increase tax revenues in a region that increasingly has lost industry and population to the Southern and Southwestern states. Connecticut's Governor. Elia Grasso is expected to take a similar approach when she reveals her legislative program next month.

title: A HOUSE OF NOBILITY
description: The following translation is part of a letter sent by Le Corbusier to a client in 1925: Madame: We have dreamed of building you a house which is sleek and harmonious a box of good proportions, and which is not prone to multiple accidents, which create artificial or illusory picturesqueness that rings badly under the light and only adds to tumultuous surroundings. . . . And don't think that this sleekness is the result of laziness; it is, on the contrary, the result of longripened plans. Simplicity is not easy. To be truthful, there will be nobility in this house raised against the foliage. And if one climbs one story, it is to . . . the high salon, out of the shadow of the forest and to from that high vantage point the magnificent view of the foliage. And also to see sky. And it leaves the domestics downstairs, near the cellar, garage and street. If the domestics are wellhoused, the house will be well taken care of. Salon, dining room, library, etc. are one single room. Oh, yes! the service core! At the very center. Surely! So that it will serve a good purpose, we are making it with cork bricks which isolate it like a phone booth or a thermos. Funny idea! Not so. It is simply natural service traverses the house from the bottom to the top, like an artery. Where then the rooms themselves? The walls at the end, and those of the core, could encased  with storage cabinets. The boudoir oversees the foliage of the big trees and the space of the summer dining room and two staircases permit one to descend. This project, Madame, is not done by the hasty pencil of a designer of offices, between telephone calls. It has been slowly ripened, caressed, during days of perfect calm.

title: Vietnam to Plainfield: A Saga of Hope
description: PLAINFIELD WHEN Tam Van Huynh talks about his voyage from Vietnam to the Philippines in a tiny motorboat, packed from bow to stern with his family and fellow refugees, makes it sound as if it all happened to someone else. His face is dispassionate, his voice detached.

title: Among Other Things, He Fears a GroWing U.S. Involvement

Increased costs (inflation), rising taxes, social security and local school taxes. and the day-to-day need to stay out of debt has placed a tremendous burden on the firefighter's family...The workers are tired of rhetoric, and want and need an increase in salary.

title: BalanchineBallet's First Modernist'First Modernist
description: Si he distinguishing feature of modern art, wrote Andre Malraux, is that it never tells a story. A bit oversimplified perhaps, but truthful enough to serve as a maxim. Still, a curious thing happens when one applies this criterion of modernism to dance. For according to Malraux's dictumone that is routinely accepted in most of the other artsthe first certifiably modernist choreographer would not be Isadora Duncan, Ruth St. Denis or Martha Graham, but rather George Balanchine, the man who most people think of as the standard bearer of the classical tradition in 20thcentury ballet. One needn't turn to Balanchine's newest works, Ballo della Regina, which was unveiled last Thursday, or the upcoming Kammermusik No. 2, in order to illustrate this apparent paradox: In fact, the most vivid demonstration of this irony was an event that occurred tilrrost 20 years agolong before ballet and mOdern dance had arrived at tile sort of rapprochment that characterize% their relationship today.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: SUCH varied harbingers of our lifestyle as Newsweek, Cosmopolitan, Vogue and Ms. are currently proclaiming that a venerable staple Continental experience, the younger lover, is becoming as fashionable among American women as jogging and homemade yogurt  which is rather like saying People Are Talking About Faust. For the perennial urge to turn to young flesh as a source of renewal has always been the privilege of the wealthy and/or powerful, be they distinguished scholars, millionaire shoe manufacturers or famous actresses. So it is not startling to read that Jeanne Moreau, Estelle Famous and Louise Fletcher are married or keeping house with men 12 to 20 years their juniors. What may be indeed novel is that a large new caste of less renowned but equally successful professional women are now empowered to play Sugar Mommy to a generation college graduates, raised on the premises of the 60's liberations, who have ceased to equate masculinity with dominance or aggressiveness.

Now it is stirring to return to June. Every such move is intended to benefit the Governor or the majority party or both.

Hundreds of investors and dreamers played two games a daythe stock market in the morning and bocci or mahjongg in the afternoon.

title: What's Doing in NEW ORLEANS
description: MARDI GRAS The words mean Fat Tuesday, as in excessive, a day to feast and riot before beginning the sacrifices of Lent on Ash Wednesday. Mardi Gras, or simply the madness, the most common appellation for Carnival in New Orleans, falls this year on Feb. 7, but the season begins in earnest 10 days before, on Sunday, Jan. 29, with parades in the neighborhoods and parties before, during and after the parades.

title: A Former G.I. Returns to the Bavarian Alps
description: There are two Garmisches. One is the G.I. Garmisch, gem of the United States Armed Forces Recreation Center's Bavarian empire and still a bargain paradise for the military and their dependents in a decade when the dollar buys less and less in West Germany's solid Deutschemark economy. But there is also the German Garmisch, or, ratner, the merged communities of GarmischPartenkirchen, long the most famous and popular of Bavaria's winter and summer mountain resorts. Less of a bargain perhaps, but certainly more of an escape abroad, the German Garmisch is a spectacular wedding of Bavarian good nature with Olympian mother nature in a paradiselike setting of mountains, valleys and lakes unspoiled and, if anything, enhanced by the integration of G.I. Garmisch.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Amedal commemorating the Battle of Saratoga medal was recentlyissued for members of the American Bicentennial Commemorative Soci- etv. title: TV VIEW
description: It is easy enoughas countless instant experts insist on demonstratingto watch British television for a few days and reach the smug conclusion that it is as bad as, or perhaps worse than, its American counterpart. But, over the long haul, the center of this thesis simply won't hold. The fact is that, at least occasionally, British television aims a little higher. In this country, for instance, the promising concept of a limited series is frittered away on dramatizations of such secondrate novels as Aspen, Seventh Avenue or 75 Park Avenue. Meanwhile, the British give both themselves and American public television The Spoils of Poynton by Henry James or I, Claudius by Robert Graves or, coming up next month, Anna Karenina by Tolstoy. There is a clear and unquestionable difference.

title: SELECTION
description: THE ancient Greeks defined sexual passion as disease: something that strikes from without and touches a source of human need so deep, so hungering that the rational and humane faculties are rendered helpless before the mad, distorting behavior that follows upon the attack, and are literally held abeyance while the passion plays itself out, leaving the victim to recover as best he can. Homer's description of the love of Paris for Helen is defined within these terms. Helen touches in Paris his capacity for sexual love; once touched, that capacity suddenly realizes itself as a hunger of the soul; expressive life is now given to that which might have remained inchoate forever; the hunger flares up in Paris and burns steadily within him; it is all light and heat of such a high order that it is as though all other forms of love he has ever known become dim and cold in memory; this light and heat are allconsuming; Paris is soon addicted, given over to the hungry need; in time, Helen herself  the object, the cause, the origin of the hungry, burning need  becomes less real than the need itself; the hunger now has a life of its own, a life filled with stubborn power. At this point the nature of the force becomes clear: it is antisocial, fixed on itself, obeying internal laws that conflict with the laws of associativeness.

title: Architecture The Hand Of the Master
description: The work of Le Corbusier, the great SwissFrench architect who died in 1965, seems often to be the paradigm of modern architecture  cold, harsh, strong, utterly rational. But no mind so brilliant as Le Corbusier's could fit neatly into a category; and, in fact. there were other sides to the architect and his vision. He could be curious, tentative, and playful as much as he could be arbitrary. His built works do not always reveal these traits, but his drawings and sketches often do  they are richly picturesque, sometimes with lush colors; they often have witty asides scrawled in the margins, and, above all, they make it clear that his designs did not spring fullblown from his head, but were created by a slow, anguished process.

This movement allows the edge of one board to rub against the edge of another, causing the noises (in a few cases it may also be the sound of a board rubbing against nails.)

title: Newspaper Bombed in Zambia

Inge officials with three County Execu. tiyes and their staffs is not an economy Move, We need to get government closer to the people, not further away. title: Fashion Things for Spring
description: Spring 1978 fashion means relaxed and uncontrived clothes. And, with this move away from costume, accouterments become important. The new spring accessories are as soft and often as humorous as the clothes they accompany: long leather belts that can be wrapped around and across the body in unconventional ways; a pair of bare, tinystrapped sandals with delicate ties at the ankles; a casually knotted necktie worn with a big blousy shirt; an unfitted squarecut vest to slip over almost anything; ruffled petticoat or two to perk up warm weather skirts; or a couple of wooden combs in loosely tied hair. They're all part of the same fashion mood  easy does it with a personal touch.

title: The Administration Is Trying to Rip Off a Stripe
description: WASHINGTON1n 1865, Congress voted to give soldiers who had been disabled during the Civil War priority over civilians when they applied for Government jobs as long as they could demonstrate capacity to handle the work. Then and there, the concept of veterans preference was born. Some form special advantage for exservicemen in joining the Federal Civil Service has been in effect ever since. In addition, all 50 states now have laws that make it easier for veterans to get jobs in their governments and, in many instances, to win promotion thereafter.

What could possibly be left?

title: CARTER'S LONE
description: When Anwar elSadat's Egyptian jetliner touched down on Israeli soil last November, the diplomacy of the Middle East took its most dramatic turn in three decades. For the first time, the two principal protagonists in the region entered into facetoface negotiations, and it was possible that the other Arabs might somehow be drawn into the process. Astonishing as the event itself, the breakthrough had been accomplished without the prior knowledge or even the behind-thescenes influence of Jimmy Carter, despite the enormous attention he had devoted to the Middle East since he entered office. He and his aides were surprised, even hurt, and their feelings were reflected in the comment of the State Department specialist who referred to President Sadat and Prime Minister Menahem Begin as unguided missiles  an admission that the had lost control.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: SHANE STEVENS is a New York novelist whose career has bumped along the usual washboard literary roads. Now he thinks he's written the Big One, the book that will be sold to paperback and movies for sixfigure amounts. We'll wait and see about that, for Mr. Stevens was just putting the finishing touches on his novel still untitled when we last spoke with him. His editor, John Dodds, and others at his publisher, Simon & Schuster, are very optimistic, however. The point is that he intends to put a good percentage of whatever subsidiaryrights dollars he gets into helping other writers; what's more he's already begun, having donated $15,100 out of his $100,000 advance.

title: It's Muted, By Worry
description: WASHINGTON  To carry on war, three things are necessary, said an adviser to Louis XII of France, money, money and yet more money. The advice in 1499 has many supporters in the Pentagon in 1978. But to the Carter Administration and to a large degree Congress, the maxium is implausible. To carry on war, or simply to maintain adequate defenses, they seem to agree that mony, money and more money for the Pentagon is out of the question. In the budget that he will submit next week, President Carter is expected to ask for $126 billion in defense spending, $4 billion less than Secretary of Defense Harold Brown requested, but still 8 percent more than the Pentagon received for the current year. What is unusual the decision to keep a lid on military spendingAdministrations often spend less than the Pentagon would likebut the relative nondebate on an issue that traditionally has pitted hawks against doves and stirred emotional arguments. It is a trend that has been developing for several years. Since the Vietnam war, the traditional guns versus butter argument has become fairly muted, and even traditional liberals and doves have not made an issue of defense spending.

title: Haste, Waste and Virtue at Sea
description: Virtue is not always virtuous. Many members of Congress must have felt very good when they voted, in last month's Christmas rush, to extend the nation's prohibitions against the dumping of oil and other hazardous substances out to 200 miles from American shores. But as the Carter Administration argued in vain, the legislationcombined with the unilateral extension of our coastal fishing zones in 1976goes a long way toward encouraging and legitimizing other prohibitions in the waters up to 200 miles from other coasts. Like prohibitions on the passage of American military vessels, perhaps even certain commercial ships. The United States has been struggling to preserve the principle that any interference with activity in the open sea should occur only by international treaty and not, as in clearly coastal waters, by the actions of individual states. Congress muddied the waters.

title: Canadian Theater Is Enjoying A Vaissance

Tomorrow evening, the Phoenix Theater presents One Crack Out, David French's vignette of rough doings in a pool hall. And later this season, the American National Theater and Academy (ANTA) will offer David Freeman's biting portrait of middleclass family life, You're Gonna Be Alright, Jamie Boy. Both plays typify the realistic bias of the new Canadian drama, its commitment to Canadian subject matter and its concern for people never before represented on the stage.

title: Italy: Coping With Chaos
description: ROMEItaly is being disrupted by strikes and disorders; extreme rightists and leftists clash almost every day with a mounting toll of casualties; terrorism is endemic; the police are manifestly unable to maintain order; a weak Government seems about to yield to an authoritarian opposition party. To a surprising number of Italians, the turn of events seems disturbingly familiar. A stock remark frequently heard these days is: This is 1922 all over again, only this time in red instead of in black. On the surface, there are similarities between the present and the convulsive months before Mussolini's Blackshirts marched on Rome 56 years ago, but the historic parallel should not be labored. The Italy that was stumbling into the nationalof rule by charismatic and unprincipled Duce was a predominantly rural country. Much to its own surprise, it had just emerged as one of the victors in World War I, only to be snubbed by the more influential winning powers. The Italy of today is a leading industrial nation. It has made an impressively quick recovery from the ravages of World War H, but was unable to overcome ancient imbalances and flaws its socioeconomic structures that Fascism had papered over.

Trans World Airways, a subsiary of Hilton International, withdrew its offer for partial control of Medicorp, W. T. title: CLOSE ENCOUNTERS  WITH A RISING STAR

Richard Dreyfuss has done this scene 14 times already, and from take one through take 19 his reading has been virtually identical  same inflections, same rhythms, same curve of rising intensity. When I mention it, he's amused. Of course the reading doesn't change, he says. That's the easiest thing for an actor to do. It's like telling a carpenter, Gee, you drove that nail right into the hole.

title: Their Power Was Evident in Last Week's Talks
description: TAKASAKI, Japan When Toshiji Matsumoto, a Japanese farmer here, sent his daughter Michiko off to a distant place called California the other day, he made her take along a parasol because he had heard that it never rains there. Mr, Matsumoto, who raises rice, vegetables and dairycows, was simply protecting his teenage daughter's future. In Japan. suntans on women are still generally considered disfiguring, especially by farm folk and especially before a marriage can be arranged. Such thinking provides a peek into the seemingly mysterious perceptions that dominate much of life in Japan, particularly in the dwindling rural areas. These populated pockets, which seem much farther from Japan's sprawling cities, than the maps indicate, have become the focus of international attention during the dispute between Japan and its trading partners, primarily the United States.

title: The World
description: Robert Strauss could not have sounded more cheerful if the Dallas Cowboys had breezed through the Super Bowl. The ebullient Texan, winding up six months of tough negotiations, described the new trade agreement reached last week with Japan as having redefined the economic relations between our two great nations. Maybe. Mr. Strauss undoubtedly extracted significant concessions from the Japanese, whose multibilliondollar trade surplus has been a destabilizing factor in international economic relations. But whether they were as sweeping as described has yet to be proven.

title: H.E.W. versus SlowMotion Suicide

His proposed new campaign against cigarette smoking is the strongest position taken by a high Federal official since the famous Surgeon General's Report of 1964, linking smoking and serious diseases. It is by no means as stern a program as it might be. But, after years of Government waffling, it is welcome evidence of a renewed commitment to health.

Outdoors Exposition
description: There will be no encyclopedia salesmen, no hawkers of magic kitchen gadgetsdust sports equipment and information. So promise the promoters of the World Fishing and Outdoor Expo, which starts Wednesday. The show is geared to outdoors types in the metropolitan area, with information on nearby spots to hunt, fish and camp. It will run through Sunday, at Rockland Community College's field house in Suffern, N.Y. (Exit 14B of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway).

title: NONINDUSTRY GROUPS JOINING TRUCK FIGHT
description: DETROIT, Jan. 15An already heated battle between the. automobile industry and the Federal Government over proposed fuel economy standards for lightweight trucks and vans is developing into a confrontation with the Carter Administration over two key domestic priorities jobs and energy conservation.

title: Seven Are Killed, 10 Hurt in Fires In BedfordStuyvesant Tenements
description: At least seven persons were killed and 10 others injured yesterday in fires in two tenements about a mile apart in the BedfordStuyvesant section in Brooklyn.

description: The police and utilitycompany officials have offered the following suggestions for homeowners without electricity.

title: DR. EPHRAIM CROSS, 84, LANGUAGE PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Ephraim Cross, a professor emeritus of Romance languages at City College, died of cancer yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years pld and lived at 215 West 98th Street and in Greenport,

title: 2 Killed, 2 Beaten in Florida Sorority House
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)A clubwielding attacker crept into sorority house at Florida State University early today and beat four young women, raped one of them and then strangled her and another, the police said.

title: Ice Storm Victims on Island Find Heat in School Building
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 15My wife said she wanted to do something different this weekend, Joseph D. Didonato said. This is not what we had in mind, though.
