description: One of the most complex and contentious court cases in the history of photography is now in the hands of a jury of nine women and two men.

title: Events Today
description: ONE CRACK OUT, written by David French; directed by Daniel Freudenterbers stars Kenneth Welsh, Al freeman Jr. and lent Garr; a Phoenix Theater Production at the Marynnunt Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, 6:45.

title: Hialeah Opens Today, Its Future Bright Again
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 15  Seattle Slew's scheduled return to the races here has been delayed by a fever. Little matter. Even Slew, horse of the year, wouldn't have been the star of tomorrow's openingday program at Hialeah Park. The best bet of the day will be the elegant race track itself.

title: porting Gear
description: Warmth is the best countermeasure for a cold winter day when something inside you says to go outside ekd ski, fish, hunt or hike. And what become frozen first? Usually your feet.

title: Miss Goolagong Victor
description: HOLLYWOOD, FIa., Jan. 15 (UPI)Evonne Goolagong, playing in her first indoor tournament in nearly two years, defeated Wendy Turnbull, 62, 63, in 50 minutes today to win the Florida tennis tournament, a stop on the women's pro tour.

title: Sir Harold Wilson Sees a Threat To NATO in Alliance of Leftists
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Former British Prime Minister Sir Harold Wilson has warned that the growing alliance between Socialists and Communists in European countries could pose a threat to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: SMALLER CLASS HELD AID TO POOR READERS
description: Reducing class sizes in upper graces of elementary schools might be a way to fight problems of reading difficulties, Stephen R. Aiello, president of New York City's Board of Education, suggested yesterday.

title: Poland's Economic System, Despite Tinkering, Still Drags
description: WARSAW, Jan. 12Not long ago, in a small town in western Poland, a young man hit on a new, economical way of growing highquality mushrooms. Singlehanded'v, he set up the operation, acquired buyers in West Germany and France and hired some retired women to pick the crop parttime. Apart from the pickers, he was the entire enterprise.

title: World Cup Soccer Slate
description: Here are the kickoff times for the World Cup soccer matches in Argentina:

title: Blazers Top Celtics
description: ROSTON. Jan. 15 (AP)Lloyd Neal and Dave Twardzik combined for 12 points in overtime today as the Portland Trail Blazers overcame the absence of their center, Bill Walton, and scored a 107103 victory over the Boston Celtics in a National Basketball Association game.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 16, 1978

title: Hockey Clubs Thrive on Stats
description: Who is the most important person on a National Hockey League club? Perhaps the statistician.

title: Italian Pair Upset
description: TOWSON, Md., Jan. 16 (UPI)Unseeded George Hardie and Eric van Dillen made it a losing day for the Italians tonight as they scored upset victories over Adriano Panatta and Paolo Bertolucci in the first round of the $100,000 Baltimore international indoor tennis tournament.

title: JOHN J. O'CONNOR
description: John J. O'Connor, founder, publisher and editor of Yankee Trader Newspapers, a group of weekly publications on Long Island, died last Thursday during a family gathering in Sur Loup, France. He was 59 years old and lived at 153 Quaker Lane, Setauket, L.I.

title: JERSEY MOONSECT HEAD ASSAILS DEPROGRAMMERS
description: The director of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church in New Jersey said yesterday deprogrammers were mercenaries who preyed on the fears of the parents of church members.

title: Lloyd, Carr President  Held Prison Escapee
description: BOSTON, Jan.16 (AP)The president of the Lloyd, Carr commodities option firm, which is accused of defrauding its customers, is really a prison escapee who hat left a trail of aliases and convictions across the United States, Federal officials said today.

title: Dollar Off in Europe
description: The dollar was down slightly against most other currencies yesterday in foreignexchange trading in Europe but was generally higher in New York as last week's fluctuating rates gave way to cautious trading, The Associated Press reported. The price of gold, meanwhile, which often increases during times of political or financial uncertainty, reached its highest level in more than two years in London. It sold for $175.65, up from Friday's $173, and the highest London price since April 3, 1975. when it reached $176.375 an ounce. In Zurich, gold also shot up from Friday's $172.625 to late sales at $175.175 an ounce.

title: HUGE PROFITS LINKED TO A MARCOS AGENCY
description: MANILA, Jan, 14The National Grin Agency. which President Ferdinand E. Marcos empowered to import all grain into the Philippines, has reportedly made as much as $100 million in the last three ears by keeping the price of wheat artificially high and misusing cheap credit supplied by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: TV: Alan Arkin Stars in a Drama Set in an Asylum
description: The terrible way of life in a hospital for the criminally insane, a situation out of Kafka by way of Solzhenitsyn, is told in The Other Side of Hell, a fictional drama to be shown at tonight on NBCTV. The story takes almost three hours to tell, but it is a gripping one, well told, that generally fills most of its time suitably.

title: Letter: On Pension Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Compensating for a Childhood in Germany
description: Dear Mary, It was when German terrorism had again made the headlines that you askedafter a powerful industrialist had been abducted and eventually killed; a chief federal prosecutor had been assassinated; a plane had been hiiacked, grounded on some desolate airstrip in Somalia. the hijackers eventually shot to death by German commandos; Ulrike Meinhof, at one time leader of the terrorist Red Army Faction, had been found hanged in her cell in StuttgartStammheim, West Germany's most secure prison, and Andreas Baader, coleader of the Red Army Faction, along with two other terrorists in the same prison, had died violent deathsit was then that you asked me what it all meant. was German, you said, could I help you understand. And so, let me try.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1978

title: For Reds in the Italian Government
description: ROMEThe patience, perseverance and caution with which the Italian Communist Party worked for months to reach the July 1977 agreement are well known.

title: KOCH SET TO IMPOSE FREEZE ON HIRINGS, CUT APPROPRIATIONS
description: The Koch administration will impose a limited freeze on hiring and cut the funds of every department to help close a budget deficit for next year that is now projected at close to $500 million, according to persons familiar with the financial plan now being drafted.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 16, 1978

title: ExPort Authority Treasurer Plunges to His Death as Inquiries Go On
description: Alexander Leslie, who recently retired as treasurer of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey after admitting irregularities in his expense account, plunged to his death last night in an apparent suicide.

title: About New York
description: There is no such thing as a tavern in grief. But Reif's bar, a temptingly dingy and odiferous workingclass place on East 92d Street had to put up a sign after the police told what had happened to Mike Russek.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
WOMAN AGREES TO SETTLE SUIT AGAINST HUNT ESTATE
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 16 (UPI)A former Atlanta woman agreed today to accept an outofcourt settlement and drop a Federal suit in which she contended that she once was married to the late H. L. Hunt while he had another wife and family.

title: Maloney of Rangers Out 4 to 6 Weeks
description: Dave Maloney, the Ranger defenseman, sprained his left knee in practice on Sunday and will be lost to the team for four to six weeks.

title: ExOfficer Sentenced to 4 Years In Death Despite Jurors' Regrets
description: Former Police Officer Thomas Ryanthe first New York policeman ever convicted of committing homicide while on dutywas sentenced yesterday to as much as four years in prison despite affidavits from seven jurors saying they had been mistaken in convicting him of criminally negligent homicide.

title: Attacks on Sorority Sisters in Tallahassee Were the Latest of Several on Women in Florida
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 16A stockingcapped killer who bludgeoned two sorority sisters to death and severely battered three other women students at Florida State University with a club has left this small Southern capital in a state of shock and dread.

title: British Firemen Return to Work
description: LONDON, Jan, 16 (Reuters)Britain's 36,000 firemen returned to work today after a bitter nineweek strike. The firemen failed to win their battle for 30 percent raise on their $124 weekly wage. They settled for 10 percent now and parity with the average British skilled workmanexpected to be around $190in November 1979.

title: Virginia Pope, 92, Fashion Editor Of The Times 22 Years, Is Dead
description: Virginia Pope, the fashion editor of The New York Times from 1933 to 1955, died yesterday morning in her borne at 419 East 570Street. She was 92 years old and had suffered a stroke three years ago.

title: Recital: Gwyneth Jones in Debut
description: Gwyneth Jones sang her first Metropolitan Opera Marschallin last month, a generally superior performance that was weakened only by a pervasive blandness and lack of deep penetration of the character. Last night at Carnegie Hall, the Welsh soprano made her New York recital debut with program of lieder that reaffirmed the good impression she had made in Strauss's opera and also suggested that blandness of temperament is one of the problems she will have to overcome if she intends to go on to the higher levels of song interpretation.

title: Brooklyn School Integration Plan Is Facing a Fight
description: State Education Commissioner Gordon M. Ambach tentatively approved yesterday most aspects of a New York City Board of Education proposal to increase racial integration in five Brooklyn junior high schools through such measures as voluntary student transfers and interschool dramatic productions.

title: Reactions to Jobless Rate: incredible and incredible
description: The unexpected announcement by the Bureau of Labor Statistics that unemployment dropped sharply last month to 6.4 percent of the civilian labor force is being challenged as implausible by some of the country's leading economists and manpower experts. The reliability of the new employment and unemployment figures has an important bearing on whether and how much economic stimulus, including President Carter's proposed tax cut, will be needed to keep the economy moving toward full employment.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 16 (Reuters) Australia's Max Walker took seven wickets today to give his side a 14run firstinnings lead over the world team on the third day of the first World Series cricket match for professionals. However, at close of play the world team had rallied to hold the Australians to 13 for two ,in their second innings.

title: Customers of Lilco Enjoy Electric Security Blanket
description: HICKSVILLE, LI., Jan. 16The phone at Elsie Ludwig's bedside rang at 6:20 Saturday morning. The call was a sununonsto the Hicksville complex of the Long Island Lighting Company, where Miss Ludwig, a 32year veteran, normally works in the propertyrecords department.

title: Park Termed Unlikely to Implicate More in Congress
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 17 (UPI)Assistant Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said today that no criminal indictments against present American legislators are likely to grow out of the questioning of Tongsun Park here.

description: Ballet, George Balanchine told the British critic Arnold Haskell in 1934, should be the ideal form of entertainment.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. I6The Internal Revenue Service revoked today two rulings that have permitted American oil companies to avoid several billion dcllars of United States income taxes on their foreign profits.

title: JERSEY INQUIRY AIMS AT SPECIAL SCHOOLS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 16The State Commission of Investigation said today it had found abuses and improprieties in the $26 million a year state program for the education of physically and mentally handicapped children.

title: FOUR INCHES OF SNOW FORECAST FOR STATE
description: While power was restored yesterday to thousands of New Jersey households that had been without heat or electricity as a result of a severe weekend storm that toppled trees and power lines, the state's major utilities braced for another storm today.

title: Congressmen, Visiting Home, Find Social Security Is Leading Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The 95th Congress comes back to work this week after visiting constituents angry about Social Security, apathetic about energy and doubtful about President Carter's abilities.

title: Kuhn Allows Met Bonus For Matlack
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn told the Mets and Jon Matlack yesterday he would not disapprove the settlement they retched last week on the bonus money owed the pitcher because of his trade to the Texas Rangers.

description: STAMFORD, Conn.Do you believe God has a mission for you? said the Question on the printed sheet.

title: Advertising
description: Cablevision of Odessa, Tex., became an affiliate of Home Box Office this year, and James R. C. Baker, its general manager, is really expecting a leap in businessespecially after the advertising.

title: Opposing A Prison at Lake Placid
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.The plan to convert the Olympic dormitories that will be built soon at Lake Placid, N.Y., into a Federal prison for young men is depressing. Perhaps it is the symbolism. When the young athletes from every nation depart, some with medals and honors, their place will be taken by other young men brought there in chains and caged.

title: W. L. Johnson to Head Cancer Society Drive
description: William L. Johnson, board chairman of the Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation, has been named to lead the 1978 fundraising drive for the New York City division of the American Cancer society.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 16Eddie Giacomin, a favorite at Madison Square Garden in his days as the New York Rangers' No. I goaltender, apparently has reached the end of his playing career after 13 years in the National Hockey League.

title: RATES OF INTEREST INCREASE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as the credit markets began their eighth consecutive week of declining prices.

title: F. Lee Bailey Barred as Counsel In Gross's Plea to Erase Verdict
description: NEWARK, Jan. 16F. Lee Bailey was barred today from appearing as a lawyer for Nelson G. Gross. the former state Republican chairman who is seeking reverSal of his 1974 conviction of illegal campaign fundraising.

title: Tedd Joselson Gives Piano Recital
description: When this reviewer wrote about Tedd Joselson's New York recital debut a couple of years ago, he had the bad taste to be unenthusiastic. Mr. Joselson came with a barrage of supportive notices. particularly from Eugene Ormandy, yet his playing sounded technically ordinary and interpretively uninteresting.

title: Bowl Watchers Put at 90 Million
description: On the basis of overnight ratings for New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, CBS researchers are estimating 90 million viewers for the telecast of Sunday's Super Bowl game, the first to be played in prime time.

title: Christmas Mail Set Record
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI)Christmasseason mail reached an alltime high of 8.5 billion pieces but was handled just as fast as it was in 1976 and at lower cost to the government, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar reported today.

title: Books of The Times New Gunfighter in Town
description: And what, may we ask, is a literary politician? According to Mitchell S. Ross, who dropped out of college at the age of 19 and began writing The Literary Politicians shortly thereafter, literary politician is one who has chosen to practice politics by writing books. And lest you think immediately of Eric Hoffer or George F. Kerman or Michael Harrington or even Bobby Seale, let it be known that what further marks the corps of literary politicians that Mr. Ross has selected for analysis is variety, fecundity and influence.

title: HOW TO ASSIST THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Sta tion, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

Many taxpayers obligingly attach these forms, known as information documents, to their returns when they mail them to the Inertial Revenue Service.

description: YOUNG AT ART New Yorkers have a choice tonight between two classical programs played by young musicians of organizations that have won high critical endorsement for purpose and performance.

description: The injury that Guillermo Vilas suffered in the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden 10 days ago has been diagnosed as a severe inflammation of the ligament in his left ankle, and he's been ordered to rest four to six weeks.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16 (AP) Danny Roundfield scored 5 consecutive points and Earl Tatum got 6 in overtime as the Indiana Pacers sent the New Jersey Nets to their seventh straight loss, 120112, in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: Lungfish May Provide Clues to Life on Land
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 16A leading heart and lung specialist has spent much of the last 25 years studying the African lungfish, an ancient and primitive creature that lives in shallow lakes and rivers where it can breathe through gills like a fish and lungs like a man.

title: Missing Abzug Aide Cost Her 290.5 Votes
description: In a battle in which every vote might count, Bella S. Abzug presumably lost 290.5 weighted votes in her close contest with Carter Burden for the 18th Congressional District Democratic nomination because her campaign manager, Assemblyman lark Alan Siegel and his wife were in California on legal business.

title: ALBANY COMPROMISE SOUGHT ON INSURANCE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16The Republican majority in the State Senate temporarily suspended its drive to repeal a controversial inspection requirement for automobile insurance today while giving the Carey administration time to work out a possible compromise.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 16Vietnam's chief delegate here took exception today to recent remarks by Zbignlew Brzezinski, the President's national security adviser, characterizing the CambodianVietnamese border fighting as a proxy War between China and the Soviet Union.

title: Man Held in Jersey Slaying
description: WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 16 (AP) Authorities used blood hounds yesterday to track a suspect in the fatal shooting of a Monmouth County man here. Frank J. D'.Agostino, 29 years old, was arrested in connection with the murder.

title: Walter L. Terry 2d, 68, Justice In State Supreme Court Since 72
description: Walter L Terry 2d of Walton, N.Y., a State Supreme Court justice, died Saturday in Delaware Valley Hospital, Walton, after being in a coma from choking on meat in a restaurant. He was 68 years old.

title: SADAT MAY VISIT U.S. TO PRESS CAIRO VIEW
description: CAIRO, Jan. 16Wellplaced Egyptian sources said today that President Anwar elSadat might decide to visit the United States to press his peace initiative if EgyptianIsraeli political discussions, due to open in Jerusalem tomorrow, did not make what he considered to be satisfactory progress.

title: Sharon Hass Is Married to Charles Chernick
description: Sharon Lee Hass, who is in her final year at the Hofstra University School of Law, was married yesterday to Charles Mark Chernick, a New York lawyer. The certmony was performed at the Park East Synagogue by Rabbi Arthur Schneier.

title: KOCH SET TO IMPOSE FREEZE ON HIRINGS, CUT APPROPRIATIONS

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Labor Department announced emergency action today to reduce worker exposure to a cancercausing substance called macrylonitrile, which is widely used in making synthetic fiber and a broad range of other products.

title: Big Greeting in Dallas
description: DALLAS, Jan. 16 (UPI) The Dallas Cowboys, greeted by 14,500 fans in 35degree weather, today showed they were not as unemotional and computerized as they had been portrayed.

title: ANXIETY OVER RATES HELPS STOCKS FALL 9TH TIME IN 10 DAYS
description: Fears of rising interest rates helped to send stock prices lower yesterday as the market recorded its ninth loss in the first 10 sessions of 1978.

description: Theater

title: Newark's Council President Rules Out Bid for Mayor
description: NEWARK, Jan. 16 Earl Harris, the President of the City Council, ended speculation today that he might provide a serious challenge to Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's bid for a third term in May by announcing that he would seek reelection to the Council. His decision leaves Mr. Gibson without a strong rival in the state's largest city.

The agency named in the report was the Energy Research and Development Administration.

description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived here this evening and went straight into informal talks with Prime Minister Menahem Begin and Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan in preparation for the opening tomorrow of a new round of Middle East peace talks.

title: Service Today for Judy Lamb
description: A memorial service for Judy Lamb, a film and casting director in New York for many years, will be held at 11 A.M. today at the Public/Newman Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Miss Lamb died Dec. 21 in Grosetto. Italy. From May 1975 to July 1976 she was with the casting department of the New York Shakespeare Festival. She then went to Paramount Pictures, where she cast Handle With Care, First Love and Looking for Mr. Goodbar. She left no survivors.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Internal Revenue Service revoked today two rulings that have permitted American oil companies to avoid several billion dollars of United States income taxes on their foreign profits.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The Supreme Court affirmed today a decision upholding South Carolina's use of a teachertesting system that disqualified 83 percent of the black applicants but only 17.5 percent of the whites.

title: The Queen Elizabeth 2 Sails on Her Longest, Most Luxurious Cruise
description: The world's largest active passenger ship, the Queen Elizabeth 2, eased out into the icy Hudson River last night to begin the longest and most luxurious cruise of her career, a 90day journey that will take her 1,400 passengers to 28 ports in the Pacific.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article published yesterday incorrectly identified a Federal agency that, according to a General Accounting Office investigation, waged a campaign against a California state initiative to limit nuclear power. The agency named in the report was the Energy Research and Development Administration,

title: Knicks Hurt on Road By Traveling Infraction
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 16Seldom does a 48minute National Basketball Association game hinge on one play, but as far as Coach Willis Reed and Butch Beard are concerned, a crucial traveling call against Bob McAdoo dearly cost the New York Knicks in their game against the Seattle SuperSonics last night.

title: Around the Nation
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 16 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit today temporarily blocked a Federal judge's decision that mandatory busing was no longer necessary in the Dayton, Ohio, school system and ordered that busing to achieve racial integration be continued until it rules on the issue.

title: Senate Panel Opens Hearing Today In Insurance Discrimination Study
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 16Irma Carroll, widowed after 28 years of marriage, decided to switch auto insurance companies when Geico closed its local office in Raleigh, N.C. So she went to Sears, Roebuck & Company. asked a saleswoman how much Allstate auto insurance would cost and was told about $189.

title: Violations Are Laid to Waterhouse
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 16 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Price Waterhouse & Company allowed two corporate clients, now defunct, to make false and misleading statements to public investors for two years.

title: 2 Young Foreign Playwrights Are Introduced in Double Bill
description: Howard Brenton. whose Weapons of Happiness was produced recently at Britain's National Theater, is one of a number of young leftwing British playwrights who are involved in politics as much as they are in theater. Downstairs

title: Roxane Witke Wed To Andrew Nathan
description: Roxane Witke and Andrew J. Nathan were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father, Paul S. Nathan of New York. The Rev. Georges LaPorte, a chaplain at Columbia University and counsellor at the Community Church of New York, performed the ceremony.

title: People and Business
description: Robert Ellsworth, Deputy Secretary of Defense in the Ford Administration and formerly a general partner in Lazard Frres & Company, the investment banking and brokerage firm, has be. come chairman of the board of St. John International Inc.

title: ExHead of REA Pleads Guilty
description: Tom Kole, the former president of REA Express Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of conspiracy to embezzle more than $100,000 of the company's money.

title: U.S. Denies Shift on Arms to Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The State Department denied today that the Carter Administration had approved a $2 million military training program for Nigeria and that it had decided to cut military aid to Zaire almost in half.

title: Striking Farmers Demand Law for Minimum Prices
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 16Leaders of the national farm strike movement, given their first opportunity to present their case at a Congressional hearing, said here today that they were going bankrupt because of current agricultural prices and demanded minimumprice legislation that would assure them profit.

title: Winds and Rainstorms Pummel California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16Galeforce rainstorms hit northern California today, leaving thousands of homes without electric service, making roads nearly impassable to rushhour traffic and temporarily isolating communities because of toppled trees, flooded roads and mud slides.

title: No French Snails? Quelle Horreur!
description: PARISAs a result of human gluttony, predatory animals and insecticides, the snail is threatened with extinction in France.

title: 'Thunderbolt,' Entebbe Raid In Israeli Film
description: Maybe what's missing is the surprise, or the fear, or the suddenness. Maybe the real-life story is simply too ex???iing to be improved upon. Maybe no film makers of appreciable talent have been tempted to try. But, whatever the reason, there has not yet been a compelling or even serviceable movie treatment of the Israeli rescue raid at Entebbe, even though the event had more of a cinematic feeling than most of the stories one finds on the screen.Thus far, there have been two inept and sluggish television movies spun out of the episode; now there is "Operation Thunderbolt" at the Guild Theater, a dull and propagandistic Israeli-made feature that is in some ways the least successful version of all."They look like Arabs! I don't trust them!" cries a little boy aboard an Air France jetliner, and it turns out he's right to worry about the passengers across the aisle. Their fruitcakes are full of hand grenades and, sure enough, they hijack the plane. Their comrades are a shrill German woman (Sybil Danning) who might better have been cast in "Ilsa& She-Wolf of the SS," and ??? "mad-looking German man, played by Klaus Kinsky, who looks even wilder-eyed here than he did in "Aguirre, the Wrath of God."The terrorists are seen embracing Arab leaders at a brief stopover, and in Uganda they wind up in telephone contact with Yassir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The tattooed forearm of one passenger, a concentration-camp survivor, is shown in close-up, not once, but twice in a row. When the hostages are divided into Jewish and non-Jewish groups, a little boy cries "Mommy. Mommy, why aren't they calling us?" "Because we're not Jewish, darling." she replies. "What's Jewish?" he wants to know, and because there is no direct reply, the segregation process is allowed to serve as an answer.Even Idi Amin, acted buffoonishly by Mack Heath, is heard to complain about the terrorists' sorting out the passengers. It scares him, he says: "You'll make the Jews mad, and when the Jews get mad, the whole world gets mad."There's no reason to expect the movie to deal gingerly with the terrorists. But the real German (played by Mr. Kinsky) was reported to have shown signs of uncertainty and guilt during the ordeal, and the fact that he might have mowed down many of the hostages at the last moment but chose not to lend a not of unexpected humanity to the drama. In the movie, however, the man is nothing more than a cardboard villian, and his death is a real crowd-pleaser. "Kill him!" cried one woman, at a preview of the film. "Scum!" shouted another.Aside from the fact that it is at times disturbingly inflammatory, "Operation Thunderbolt" is objectionable on another score: This is yet another disaster movie that can't manage its mob scenes, There are too many passengers for one director, Menahem Golan, to differentiate gracefuly among them, so he opts for stereotypes and turns the group into an uninterestingly familiar one. Also, the film makers' unwillingness to elaborate on the details of the Israelis' crackerjack strategy robs the event of its most exciting and unexplored aspect.

title: Guard and Reserve Losing Equipment T Units in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)The Army will soon start withdrawing artillery and other equipment from National Guard and Reserve units to strengthen regular United States forces in Europe, creating a conflict between two Carter Administration programs.

title: Operating Earnings Of Chase Rose 41% In Fourth Quarter
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday reported a 41 percent advance in fourthquarter operating earnings. For the year, the nation's thirdlargest banking company reported a 17 percent gain in operating profit, reversing two years of declining earnings.

title: Horszowski and Chamber Group
description: We really must stop exclaiming over musicians who go on performing vigorously into their 80's and 90's. The usual gerontological laws do not seem to apply to people such as Toscanini. Casals, Stokowski, Rubinstein and Segovia. Music and applause evidently have a vivifying power that macrovitamms do not provide. Take, for instance. Mieczyslaw Horszowski, who appeared on Sunday afternoon as guest pianist with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Two Eastman Teachers Play
description: The Eastman School of Music has been providing a showcase for the members of its faculty in Alice Tully Hall for the last two seasons, and on Sunday night the spotlight fell on Charles Castleman, violinist, and Robert Freeman, pianist. Mr. Castleman, a frequent recitalist in New York since his debut in 1951 at the age of 10, teaches in Eastman's string department, while Mr. Freeman is the school's director.

title: Ciccolini Plays the Romantics
description: Aldo Ciccolini, Italianborn but a resident of Paris and a specialist in French piano music, gave a concert in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night. He went somewhat afield in his program, selecting pieces not normally associated with him. The only French work on the program was the Ravel Sonatine. Otherwise there were Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata, Schumann's F minor Sonata, and Rachmaninoff's Sonata in B flat minor.

title: Lance Accepts Atlanta TV Post
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 16Bert Lance, President Carter's first budget director, has accepted a position as a news commentator on an Atlanta television station, it was disclosed here today.

title: Foreign Professionals Find Ways Around Curbs
description: LONDON, Jan. 16Where there's a willor a lucrative gall bladder, housing development or stock tipa determined selfpromoter will probably find a way.

title: Carter Emerging in European Press as WellMeaning Amateur
description: LONDON, Jan. 16The European press has begun to portray President Carter as a generally wellintentioned amateur who has a long way to go. His recent trip abroad seems to have hardened that view.

title: N.Y. Tech Wins 10th
description: Kelvin Hicks scored 17 points, 11 in an 185 New York Tech secondhalf spurt that fashioned a 7853 victory over Hunter College last night. Larry McCarden led all scorers for Tech with 22 points, 14 in the second half. Tech's record is now 101. Hunter, led by Rod Blake's 18 points, fell to 74.

title: 35 Chosen Astronaut Candidates; Six Are Women and Three Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named 35 new candidates to be astronauts in the space shuttle program. Six of the candidates are women, the first chosen for American space activities.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: ITALIAN GOVERNMENT RESIGNS AS 3 PARTIES WITHDRAW SUPPORT;
description: ROME. Jan. 16Itaiy's 18monthold minority Government resigned today in the face of increasing pressure for a Communist role in the Cabinet.

title: 2,085 Copper and Iron Ore Workers Are Granted Special Federal Aid
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 16 (AP)The Labor Department today approved special Federal assistance for 2,085 copper and iron ore workers in Arizona and Missouri whose jobs were eliminated because of increased import competition.

title: Market Place
description: Not long ago, a senior investment officer of a large mutual fund complained to an acquaintance about the commission he had paid to trade 1,000 shares of stock for his personal account38 cents a share.

title: Spending City Money to Save It
description: Mayor Koch has established a new pay scale for city workers in the managerial ranks, mostly following the recommendations of a citizens committee. The committee report, based on a thorough study of the complex system of grading and paying city employees, pointed nut that sound employee relations are impossible when managers earn less than some of the people who report to them, and when employees with needed skills are paid significantly less than they could earn elsewhere.

title: Politics and the Philadelphia Lawyer
description: The performance of President Carter and Attorney General Bell in the matter of David Marston, the United States Attorney in Philadelphia, is alarming. In recent statements, the nation's two top lawenforcemenc officers have possibly jeopardized a promising investigation of political corruption; cast aspersions on an accomplished subordinate, and thrown doubt on their own commitment to keep politics out of law enforcement.

title: GUARD IS CALLED OUT TO AID L.I. RESIDENTS
description: Governor Carey mobilized one National Guard unit and parts of three others last night to help Long Island residents recover from last weekend's ice storm and cope with a storm today that is expected to drop four to six inches or more of snow on the metropolitan area.

title: Official World Champions Will Be Chosen in Tennis
description: PARIS, Jan. 16 (UPI) Tennis is to have an official world champion for the first time, the International Tennis Federation said today.

title: Is There a Real Hell? Stamford Church's Computer Polls Worshipers
description: STAMFORD, Conn.Do you believe God has a mission for you? said the question on the printed sheet.

title: Philippine President Orders Three Companies Sold
description: MANILA, Jan. 16 (UPI) A conglomerate controlled by a close friend of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has been ordered by the President to divest itself of three companies.

title: Blacks Tell Koch Of Lost Progress Since King's Time
description: In proclaiming Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day in New York City yesterday. Mayor Koch said that the legacy of the slain civilrights leader's struggle for brotherhood still glows in the hearts of men and .women of goodwill all over the world.

title: Somoza, at Seaside Home, Belittles Unrest in Capital
description: MONTELIMAR, Nicaragua, Jan. 15At his seaside estate here, where he is convalescing after a heart attack, President Anastasio Somoza Debayle seems untroubled by the political unrest gripping the Nicaraguan capital of Managua 30 miles to the east.

title: Rutgers 75, Lehigh 62
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 16 (AP)James Bailey scored 24 points to pace Rutgers to a 7562 victory over Lehigh at the Rutgers Athletic Center tonight.

title: Vance Arrives in Israel for Talks; Gives Begin a Letter From Carter
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, arrived here this evening and went straight into informal talks with Prime Minister Menahem Begin and Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan in preparation for the opening tomorrow of a new round of Middle East peace talks.

title: Tom Landry: The 12th Cowboy
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16For one embarrassing moment in Super Bowl XII last night, the Dallas Cowboys were penalized for having 12 men on the field. That's not like the computerized Cowboys but that 12th man was more symbolic than embarrassing. Some people in the National Football League believe that the Cowboys always have a 12th man on the field, that Tom Landry provides more of an invisible presence among more of his players than any other coach. Now that Tom Landry has joined Vince Lom bardi, Don Shula, and Chuck Noll as the only coaches with two Super Bowl victories, perhaps he will be appreciated more for what he is than for what he is not. With a face that could not possibly be folded, spindled or mutilated, Tom Landry is not colorful. Instead, he is organized, inventive, decisive and dependable. And perhaps more than anything else, he is consistent. His record proves that. His team has qualified for the playoffs 11 of the last 12 seasons. And the year the Cowboys didn't make the playoffs, they still had an 86 wonlost record. The Cowboys never need to rebuild. Retool perhaps, but never rebuild.

title: Claude Frank Plays Beethoven
description: For most pianists, making a recital program of the last three Beethoven sonatas would he a reckless experiment. For Claude Frank, who did just that Sunday afternoon at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, it is a natural outgrowth of his long and intense association with the composer's piano works.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kentucky Goes to 130, Trouncing Mississippi
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 16 (AP)James Lee and Jack Givens had 9 points during an 110 surge in the second half tonight that helped topranked Kentucky rout Mississippi, 7656, in a Southeastern Conference basketball game.

title: Pirates Free 16 Malaysians
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia. Jan. 16 (AP)Pirates freed 16 Malaysian fishermn after payment of $1,600 ransom, one of the fishermen reported today. Ibrahim Mohamed said the men were fishing in the Malacca Strait off Port Dickson whn eight armed pirates captured them Wednesday night. Four of the fishermen ewre allowed to go home to raise the mony.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Back on Earth As 2 Others Stay Aboard Salyut
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 16Two Soviet astronauts blasted loose from their 19ton research station in space on schedule today. parachuting safely to a snowcovered landing site with the results of experiments they carried out over the past five days with two other spacemen still in orbit.

title: South Africa Begins To Destroy Shanties Of 15,000 Blacks
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 16 (AP)A bulldozer protected by armed policemen slashed through a squatters camp outside Cape Town today, raring about 100 of the flimsy shacks.

title: Eves on Ethics Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The initial testimony by Tongsun Park in Seoul has reaffirmed the conviction of Congressional investigators here that the burden of exposing Congressional wrongdoing in the Korean scandal lies with the 1House ethics committee, not the Justice Department.

title: Stage: Phoenix's One Crack Out
description: One Crack Out is taut, entertaining, well paced and well performed. It is also lightweight, and there would be nothing wrong with that if its author did not seem to think that there was.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSONSAntonia M.D. Wife of late O.Karlis Adamsons, M.D. of Randal Manor, Staten Island, NY, in her 92nd year, on January 14, 1978 in Barrington, Rhode Island. Survived by 4 children, Gaida Adamsons, M.D.. Lalma Lantner, M.D., 0. Karlis Adamsons, M.D. and Roland Janis Adamsons, M.D. Also by 13 grandchildren. Services at DrabbleSherman Funeral Home, 309 Benefit St, Providence, R.I. on January 21, 1978 at 1 PM.

title: HELEN DUDLEY BULL
description: Dr. Helen Dudley Bull, a former professor of Child Development and Family Relations at Cornell University, died Saturday in Pine Rest Nursing Home, Paramus, N.J. She was 91 years old and had formerly lived in a retirement center at Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Englewood Cliffs Resident's Gift To Neediest Recalls an Earlier Day
description: An Englewood Cliffs resident was among New Jerseyans who gave to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: In proclaiming Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day in New York City yesterday. Mayor Koch said that the legacy of the slain civilrights leader's struggle for brotherhood still glows in the hearts of men and .women of goodwill all over the world.

title: GREYHOUND OFFERS CASH TO BUY VEREX
description: The Greyhound Corporation, in a move to diversify further. yesterday offered to pay nearly $84 million in cash for a littleknown mortgage insurance company called the Verex Corporation.

title: A Contest Prize Becomes a Gift To the Neediest
description: The winner of a $1,000 prize in Traverse City, Mich., supermarket lottery requested that the money be sent as gift to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 40Foot Goal by Leach Paces Flyers Past Flames
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP)Reggie Leach's 40foot powerplay goal at 16:45 of the second period snapped a 33 tie and paced the Philadelphia Flyers to a 53 victory over the Atlanta Flames in the National Hockey League tonight.

title: Rome Cabinet Needs Support of Parliament
description: ROME, Jan. 16In the parliamentary system of government, cabinets are forced out when their important legislative initiatives are rejected by Parliament. The Italian minority government that resigned today did so, however, because Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti said he could no longer win such a vote.

title: For Summer, Soft and Casual Are Still Watchwords
description: Calvin Klein's clothes are so subdued it's hard to think of him as a fashion dictator. Still, let him submit a coat with elbow patches, a blouse with scalloped edges, a linen skirt guaranteed to crush, and the fashionable set decides that's exactly what they've been waiting for. Dictator is a nasty word: Call him arbiter.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Vincent J. Anderson, a former police captain in Yonkers, pleaded guilty in Manhattan to Federal perjury charges that grew out of an investigation of $1 million robbery of a Yonkers bank.

title: Mrs. Abzug Presses for Nomination for House seat
description: Bella S. Azbug went to court yesterday to try to prove her contention that she, not Carter Burden, is the legitimate Democratic nominee for the House of Representatives in the East Side 18th Congressional District.

title: Film: Director Makes Debut In 'Best Way'
description: "The Best Way," the French film that opened Sunday at the Cinema Studio is the first feature film by Claude Miller, who has had extensive experience in France as an assistant director and as a production director for such people as Jacques Demy, Jean-Luc Godard and Franois Truffaut. This film, which was released in Paris in 1976, comes to us accompanied by high praise from Mr. Truffaut, who, I assume, was acting in his role as old friend and collaborator and not as critic."The Best Way" is a very small, very earnest movie that has almost everything going for it except a life of its own. It's nicely acted and intelligently composed, but it has no soul that would give it a particular identity. It has the vacant look of a movie made by someone who wanted to make a movie first and then later cast around for a subject.The chosen subject is the relationship between two young men who are counselors at a boys' summer camp near Paris. Marc (Patrick Dewaere) is a strutting, athletic fellow, while Phillippe (Patrick Bouchitey) is, as they used to say before gay liberation, "sensitive." He teaches theater and in the evening he prefers to watch Ingmar Bergman movies on the telly instead of playing poker with the others.One night Marc blunders into Phillippe's room to discover his friend in the full make-up, wig and dress of a drag queen. Instead of telling the others???, Marc simply torments Philippe with the possibility that he might snitch.Mr. Dewaere (the co-star of "Going Places") and Mr. Bouchitey have some trouble making their roles work since Mr. Miller, who also wrote the screenplay (with Luc Beraud) appears ???to change the characters at will in the course of the movie. Philippe, we are given to believe, isn't necessarily a homosexual or even a transvestite. He is quite literally, "sensitive," which isn't quite enough to explain the nonsense of his beloved dress. And, of course, it's the revelation of this kind of movie that the macho Marc haswell"tendencies" toward Phillippe that frighten him.The movie has the air of a 40's problem play recycledthough not very effectivelyfor the 70's. There is, at its center, no problem, only a lot of perfectly capable acting by the two stars and by Claude Pieplu, as the head of the summer camp, and Christine Pascal, as the young woman who loves Philippe, secrets and all."The Best Way" is also one of the first movies I've seen in a long time that can't even be convincing in creating a sense of place. This summer camp has less routine than one of those third-rate public schools in the literature of Evelyn Waugh, and it's never anywhere near as funny???.

title: Berman, Ill, Delays Recital
description: Lazar Berman, the Soviet pianist, is ill with the flu in Moscow and has had to postpone his recital scheduled for next Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. He has also postponed the first few recitals on his forthcoming American tour. As soon as possible, the Fisher Hall program will be rescheduled, and holders of tickets for next Sunday are asked to watch for an announcement. Their tickets will be good for the new date.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Nov. 30 unless other. wise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Dentists, Other Professionals Finding It Pays to Advertise
description: Milford D. Horner Jr. advertises that his office can be found next to Burger King, while Leonard A. Rose says in his ads that he makes repairs while you wait.

title: 2 Couples Hope to Find a Gold Mine In Selling 18Karat Body Charms
description: Six months ago, in a comfortable Queens living room, two young couples mulled over how to get rich quick. Their discussion drifted to past ideas that had made it.

title: Bronx Opera Does Don Pasquale
description: The Bronx Opera brought a charming production of Donizetti's Don Pasquale to the Hunter College Playhouse, last weekend. No gimmicks or campy touches marred Saturday night's performanceone could simply relax and savor the rich humor and sparkling music of this masterfully written opera buffa.

title: GROCER DISARMS GUNMAN AND SHOOTS 3 IN HOLDUP
description: Confronted by three armed holdup men who allegedly invaded his Flatbush store last night and held him, his wife and their 14yearold son at gunpoint, a 45yeaeold Broolyn grocer disarmed one of the gunmen and opened fire, wounding all three suspects, the police said.

title: Virginia 83, Penn State 56
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 16 (AP)Jeff Lamp scored 21 points before he was injured early in the second half tonight as he sparked Virginia's 13thranked Cavaliers to an 8356 romp over Penn State.Lamp, who had 17 points in the first half as the Cavaliers built a 3726 lead, was hurt 3  minutes after intermission when he stole the ball, went the length of the court and injured his ankle as he went in for a layup. The freshman spent the rest of the game on the bench.

title: Gold and Platinum Futures Prices Show an Increase as Silver Eases; Orange Juice and Potatoes Climb
description: All gold bullion futures prices hit new lifeofcontract highs on New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday before trade selling reduced gains to 70 or 80 cents an ounce on the day. The trade selling was well absorbed by a late burst of buying, much of it from abroad.

title: Jews in West German City Tell of NeoNazi Harassment
description: HANOVER, West GermanyThe small Jewish community of this north German city feels it has come under organized attack and harrassment by neoNazis in the last six months In a way that its leaders say has not happened in West Germany since the end of World War II.

title: Man Arraigned in Mineo Slaying
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Cailif., Jan. 16 (UPI) Lionel Williams, who has been accused of the 1976 slaying of the actor Sal Mineo, stood silent in Municipal Court today as he was arraigned on a charge of firstdegree murder. A preliminary hearing was scheduled for Feb. 9. Mr. Williams and his attorney, Robert Harris, waived the reading of the murder charge and did not enter a plea.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New Wit, N.Y. 10249 or to .aese agen??

description: For periods ended Dec. 31. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Hialeah Fans Watch in Comfort While Bettors at Aqueduct Shiver
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 16It never warmed up to more than about 70 degrees, 50,000 pink begonias refused to bloom and a few ingrates grumbled about the high cost of programs and hot dogs.

title: November People Closes
description: The November People, a new play by Gus Weill, openedand closedSaturday night at the Billy Rose Theater. With Cameron Mitchell and Jan Sterling as its stars. it gave 19 previews and one performance.

title: Henry Ford Says Company Plans To Keep South Africa Operations
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 16 (AP)Henry Ford 2d said today that the Ford Motor Company did not plan to pull out of South Africa and that it hoped to expand its operations in the country.

title: Taxi Panel Asks Aid Of Police on Bullies At Airline Terminal.
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, saying it is unable to cope with tough cab drivers who bully other cabbies and fleece customers at the East Side Airlines Terminal, asked the police yesterday to assign undercover men to help its inspectors.

title: Two More U.A. Executives Resign Over Dispute With Transamerica
description: Two senior vice presidents of the United Artists Corporation resigned yesterday, bringing to five the number of top officers of the large motion picture dis1 tributor who have announced their departures recently.

title: Humphrey Buried After Crowds Pay Tribute
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 16Hubert Horatio Humphrey was buried here late this afternoon in the failing light of the prairie winter.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Hitormiss methods used by the Internal Revenue Service to match information documents on interest and dividends paid by banks and corporations with returns from taxpayers are estimated to be costing the Treasury millions of dollars each year in lost revenues. Page 51.

title: Cowboys See Campbell, but Only in Their Dreams
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16The Dallas Cowboys, the new champions of the National Football League following their Super Bowl victory over Denver, are interested in Earl Campbell, the Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Texas, but see no chance of acquiring him through the N.F.L. draft in May.

title: C.I.A. Study Undermines Effort to Cut Arms Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16Officials of the State Department and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency are attempting to stop publication of a new study by the Central Intelligence Agency that contends that Soviet arms exports to the third world rival American shipments, a finding that could jeopardize efforts by the Carter Administration to exercise unilateral restraint in military sales.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: ECUADOR DECIDES ON CHARTER: Voters in Quito going to the polls Sunday to vote on a new constitution. Approved by : 5 percent of the voters, the referendum could lead to a civilian government by July, ending years of military rule. Congressional elections would follow after the stallation of a civilian president in elections set for July 16.

title: McGuire Takes Away Chauffeurs Of Almost All High Police Officials
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire yesterday stripped virtually all high police officials of their personal chauffeurs, a move that will make 23 drivers, all police officers. available for street duties.

title: UNGUARANTEED LOANS TO POORER COUNTRIES BY U.S. BANKS LISTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  American banks have $37.7 billion of unguaranteed loans outstanding to developing countries that do not produce oil, and half the loans are in maturities of one year or less a survey by three bank regulatory agencies showed today.

title: I.B.M. PROFITS ROSE 18.3% FOR QUARTER AND BY 13.4% IN YEAR
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday profit increases of 18.3 percent for the final quarter of last year and 13.4 percent for all of 1977.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Men's Downhill Canceled By Storm in Switzerland
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP) A storm during the night made the course of the men's Lauberhorn downhill unusable, forcing a second cancellation today of the World Cup event.

title: LongDistance Competitors Win A Court Battle Against A.T.& T.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 16The Supreme Court left standing today a decision that could destroy the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's overall monopoly over longdistance telephone service in the Waited States.

title: Election of Philippine Assembly Scheduled for April 2 by Marcos
description: MANILA. Tuesday, Jan. 17 (Reuters)President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines announced today that elections for an interim National Assembly would be held April 2. The elections would be the first since Mr. Marcos imposed martial law in 1972.

title: Dentists, Other Professionals Finding It Pays to Advertise
description: Milford D. Homer Jr. advertises that his office can be found next to Burger King, while Leonard A. Rose says in his ads that he makes repairs while you wait.

title: A Schedule of Events For Inauguration  Day
description: The festivities for Governor Byrne's second and naugural which started last night with a concert at the War Memorial Building in Trenton continue today with a full schedule of event.

title: Notes on People
description: Richard Serra, a 37yearold New York sculptor, has been selected from among nearly 100 candidates to design a major work of art that will serve as the western focal point for Pennsylvania Avenue, the Presidential parade route and major thoroughrare of the nation's capital. Mr. Serra, now working on a huge 77ton cube of solid steel for the National Gallery in Berlin, said yesterday of his new commission: This is the most exciting thing I have ever undertaken. Imagine the Federal Government asking an artist to become involved in urban design. Usually, the may they do it is to call in an artist ??ter the design is completed to dress ??ings up, but the fact that I'm in on ??e plan from the beginning is a welcome innovation. The artist said that be had not settled on a design for his sculpture, but that it would take into account open vistas that include both the Capitol and Treasury buildings, and not only refer to its own internal relationships as a piece of sculpture, but its space and place and the context it's in.

title: Barber Triumphs; Palmer Only 3 Off
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 16Arnold Palmer, with his best performance in three years, gave the golf world a thrill today, but it was Miller Barber, another member of the over40 set on the pro tour, who won the Phoenix open. He did it by sinking a 45foot birdie putt on the final hole.

title: HUGE PROFITS LINKED TO A MARCOS AGENCY
description: MANILA, Jan, 14The National Grain Agency, which President Ferdinand E. Marcos empowered to import all grain into the Philippines, has reportedly made as much as $100 million in the last three years by keeping the price of wheat artificially high and misusing cheap credit supplied by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: U.S.Soviet Hot Line on Space Relay
description: MOSCOW. Jan. 16 (AP)A new hotline space satellite systemmore reliable than cable and highfrequency radio links went into regular service today between Moscow and Washington, the United States Embassy announced.

ITALIAN GOVERNMENT RESIGNS AS 3 PARTIES WITHDRAW SUPPORT
description: ROME, Jan. 16Italy's 18monthold minority Government resigned today in the face of increasing pressure for a Communist role in the Cabinet.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)Inventories of the nation's businesses increased $1.5 billion in November, a gain of about fivetenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Corporation Affairs Cook to Sell Some Grain Assets to Pillsbury
Merrimack 98, Hofstra 89
description: NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Jan. 16Hofstra was beaten tonight. 9889, by Merrimack, the top Division II team in New England. The Dutchmen, now 49, were lead by Alvin Woods with 22 points and Ralph Scozzafava with 20.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: STATE SUES EXAIDE OF BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: Michael Kan, former assistant director of the Brooklyn Museum, was accused yesterday in a civil damage suit by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz as the key figure in a conspiracy to sell fraudulently and to trade $750,000 worth of the museum's primitive art.

title: Containing the Cruelty of the Hunt
description: The annual seal hunt will soon begin on the ice off Newfoundland and while some 180,000 harp seals, most of them pups, will be slain this year, the killing will be as humane as possible. We have resell ations about killing any animal primarily for fur to adorn men and women. But given the fact that the sealers are determined to continue their tradeboth for pelts and for meat, oil and fatwe find it encouraging that they have adopted more compassionate procedures.

title: SAFFIR SAYS NEW TRIB NEVER WAS FOR SALE
description: Leonard Saffir, the editor in chief and publisher of The Trib, said yesterday that the new daily newspaper is not for sale, it never was.

title: HARVEY E. COOLEY
description: Harvey E. Cooley, mayor of Quogue, LI., from 1956 to 1966, died Sunday in Southhampton Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Quantuck Lane, Quogue.

title: Staubach Out of Pro Bowl
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 16 (UPI)Jim Hart of the St. Louis Cardinals was named to the National Football Conference team for the Jan. 23 Pro Bowl Game today, replacing the injured Roger Staubach of the Dallas Cowboys.

title: BELL ACTS TO QUIET CRITICISM OF OUSTER
description: Sends Three Aides to Philadelphia to Evaluate the Effects of His Decision to Replace MarstonWASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell sent three Justice Department lawyers to Philadelphia today to assess whether .his decision to replace David W: Marston, the United States Attorney there, had jeopardized investigations into political corruption in the state.

title: Bridge:
description: A young New York quartet went into the final round of the Tristate Regional Swiss team at South Fallsburg, N.Y., Sunday, with an excellent chance to win the title. The four, Bill Erickson of Port Washington, L.I., and John Rengstorff, Nancy Schwantes and Greg Woods of New York City, needed to win their final match by three international match points to head the field of 98 teams, but they lost by exactly that margin and finished second.

title: BYRNE, IN INAUGURAL, VOWS HELP TO CITIES
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Governor Byrne was sworn in toaav to a second term, and promisel in his inaugural address to devote the next four years to rebuilding New Jersey's cities.

title: Seattle Slew Facing a Slow Recovery From Illness That Nearly Killed Colt
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 17While lesser horses went to work today for gallops, workouts or races, Hialeah Park's most celebrated invalid continued to recuperate from what apparently was a nearfatal illness.

title: More Rebate Than Tax Cut
description: In the flood of economic news that will flow from the White House later this week, great attention will no doubt be called to the President's plan for a $25 billion tax cut. The attention will scarcely be merited. The President himself cannot claim much credit for a tax cut that is necessary to offset increases in taxes already in the works. Moreover, in shaping the tax package, the President has shunned innovation in favor of tradition. He will offer an oldfashioned tax cut designed to solve the oldfashioned problem of unemployment. He could have tried instead for an innovative tax measure that sought as well to conquer inflation.

title: The Arguments Over President Carter's Tax Package
description: Even before President Carter unveils the details of his longcontemplated tax package at the end of the week, it is being dissected and debated in political and economic circles. The dialogue has been building up since Administration sources disclosed the general framework of the proposals a month ago, and the issue may become as controversial as the President's first tax initiative early last yearthe one with the proposed $50 tax refund as its centerpiece and that was subsequently altered and contracted.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In recipes, can lemon or orange extract be substituted for grated lemon or grated orange peel? I get tired of scraping my skin as well as the fruit on the grater.

title: Doctor Pleads Not Guilty to Charge He Sought Gary Reporter's Murder
description: GARY, Ind., Jan. 17 (UPI)A doctor who allegedly tried to hire a man to kill a Gary newspaper reporter has pleaded not guilty to charges of attempted murder and conspiracy to commit murder.

title: HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE LINKED TO BODY'S SIZE
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif, Jan. 17Studies of Indians in the Chilean Andes and of children in Rochester, Minn., have shown that increasing body size, not age, may be the reason blood pressure rises among Americans as they get older.

title: Knicks Lose 4th Straight As Lakers Win, 121108
description: LOS ANGELES Jan. 17 (AP)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 27 points to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 121108 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks tonight. The triumph snapped a sixgame Laker losing streak and increased the Knicks losing string to four, all on the road.

title: Mrs. Humphrey Seems Assured Of Offer of Senate Appointment
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan, 17Muriel Humphrey is almost certain to be offered an interim appointment to fill the Senate seat vacated by the death Friday of her husband. Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: Koch Names Fire Chief Beekman as Commissioner;  He Is Second Black to Head the 10,600Man Force
description: Augustus A. Beekman, an assistant fire chief with 31 years in the department, was appointed New York City Fire Commissioner yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Power Fails at Farm; Cows Milked by Hand
description: COVENTRY, R.I., Jan. 17 (AP)Emile DeGraide has been milking his 60 cows by hand twice a day since the power went off Saturday at his farm here.

title: Storch of Syracuse U. Gets Shubert Chair
description: Arthur Storch, chairman of the drama department of Syracuse University and producing director of Syracuse Stage, has been appointed the first holder of the Shubert Chair in the Theater Arts at the university. The chair, endowed under the will of Milton I. Shubert, honors Sam S.; Lee and Milton Shubert of the theatrical producing family.

title: Moynihan Cites A Federal Shift On Aid to State
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Carter Administration has decided to change the way it reports Federal outlays to the states, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said the new system would show that the Government collected $10 billion more in New York in 1976 than it returned to the state in aid.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: HALF OF New York's taxi drivers may not know their way around, but never yet has there dawned a day when they could not transport ignorance beyond bliss with the greatest of ease and then blithely compound their ineptitude by enjoying the last word, too.

title: Now, Minnesota's New Politics
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Minn.When the nation and the world lost Hubert H. Humphrey, the DemocraticFarmerLabor Party of Minnesota lost its principal founder and leader of almost 34 years. A shock of this magnitude would be adequate to precipitate a small crisis in any political party, but the Minnesota party would have faced a major crisis in 1973 whether or not Senator Humphrey had lived.

title: 1,599 Adults Queried In Times/CBS Survey
description: The latest survey by The New York Times and CBS News is based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 8 to Jan. 12 with 1,599 adult men and women around the United States.

title: Thai Crash Kills Missionaries
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17 (AP)A British missionary family and an Australian missionary family were among 12 people killed in a headon traffic collision in northern Thailand over the weekend, the police said. They said the dead included Ian Gordon Smith, a surgeon, and his wife and two children, and Noel J. Samp. son, a doctor, and his wife and son.

title: Banks Earnings for Quarter
description: For periods ended Dec. 31. IN 1 indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Ex. change, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthe.counter.

title: Public Confidence in the President On Economy Is Found at New Low
description: With President Carter about to make the economy his top priority as he begins his second year in office, public confidence in his ability to cope with the problems of inflation, unemployment and balancing the Federal budget has sunk to new lows.

title: City Rejects an Ultrasonic Roach Killer
description: Like a determined traveling salesman, Bob Brown came knocking on New York City's door yesterday to see if he could stir up interest in his new ultrasonic machine, which he says kills cockroaches and chases rats.

title: DOLLAR STRENGTHENS IN TRADING ABROAD
description: The dollar strengthened yesterday in generally stable money markets in Europe and New York, while gold, which had been climbing as the dollar sagged, dropped by around $2 an ounce, The Associated Press report.

title: A Cool Man to Handle Fires
description: If you're looking for a single word to describe Gus Beekman, it would have to be cool, said a Fire Department official who served for several years with the man picked from the ranks by Mayor Koch yesterday to be New York City's 21st Fire Commissioner.

title: GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST RECALL A TRADITION
description: A number of letters received during the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund refer to the significance of the number 18 in Jewish tradition.

title: Pratt 66, New York Maritime 51
description: An 80 spurt in a fourminute span of the second half broke a 4141 tie and carried Pratt Institute to a 6651 victory over New York Maritime in Knickerbocker Conference game on the loser's court last night. The Cannoneers evened their conference record to 11 while Maritime is 01.

title: Upstate Bull Finds Fame in West
description: DENVER, Jan. 17Here at the National Western Stock Show, the cattle breeders Kentucky Derby, top honors for Black Angus have once again been taken by a New York owner and a New York bull.

title: British, at Rights Court, Defend Birching Custom on Isle of Man
description: LONDON, Jan. 17A somewhat embarrassed Britain found itself cast today as the defender of a custom of a halfforgotten pastthe practice of birching.

title: Bucks 119, Nets 109
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 17 (AP)The Milwaukee Bucks, sparked by 29 points from Marques Johnson and 21 by Junior Bridgeman, built a 19point lead late in the third quarter tonight and went on to a 119109 victory over the New Jersey Nets in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Blacks Who Boycotted Classes Reported Beaten in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 17 (AP)The police slapped and punched some black youngsters who were not in classes today at the start of the 1978 elementary school year in the black township of Soweto, The Star reported.

title: Advertising
description: Standard Brands, a $2 billion corporation in the food and liquor business, verified a hot rumor yesterday. Yes, it is reviewing its 40year relationship with Ted Bates & Company, the most important of its six agencies. The billings come to something like $24 million.

title: ISRAELEGYPT TALKS OPEN IN JERUSALEM IN UNCERTAIN MOOD
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17The foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel opened talks today to seek agreement on the principles of an overall Middle East settlement, reiterating in public their wellknown differences but beginning in private to discuss possible compromises.

title: Coal Strike Held Advance In Industrial Output to 0.2%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)  Industrial output rose just 0.2 percent in December, the Government reported today, largely because of the nationwide coal strike. In November, the gain had been twice the December rise.

title: Storm Halts Big A Card
description: Yesterday's snowfall forced postponement of racing at Aqueduct race track, the fourth racing day lost in the last two weeks. Last week's intense cold and labor difficulties caused Aqueduct to cut its sixday card in half.

title: Penn 87, Richmond 66 Villanova 76, Rider 60
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan, 12 (AP)Kevin McDonald, a senior, scored 21 points to lead the University of Pennsylvania to an 87.66 rout over Richmond tonight at the Palestra. Villanova beat Rider, 7660, in the opener.

title: ISRAELEGYPT TALKS OPEN IN JERUSALEM IN UNCERTAIN MOOD
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17The foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel opened talks today to seek agreement on the principles of an overall Middle East settlement, reiterating in public their wellknown differences but beginning in private to discuss possible compromises.

title: Private Lives
description: WE DIDN'T take the children to the nightclub the other Friday night. Who knows whether children are even allowed nightclubs, although nightclub furniture those tables the size of hubcapsseems to have been pillaged from a kindergarten class in Lilliput, designed for munchkins with credit cards.

title: Bergen County Employees Strike for New Contract
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 17The Civil Service union that represents about 1,000 workers in Bergen County voted tonight to strike tomorrow morning because of a breakdown in contract negotiations.

title: Bond Counsel Ruling Could Raise Deficit For New York City
description: New York City's bond counsel ruled yesterday that the city could not issue bonds to finance some expense items in its capital budget, a decision that could increase the city's deficit for next year by $450 million.

title: Music: Pierrot Consort
description: ALL THE MUSIC performed by the Pierrot Consort Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was written by composers born in Austria. And, except for a Mozart song that was heard first and a Haydn trio that came last, it was all from the 20th century. Naturally, Schoenberg, Berg and Webern were represented. The other composers were Ernst Krenek and Raoul Pleskow, chairman of the music department at the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University, where the Pierrot players are part of the faculty.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses President Carter's tax package, which is being dissected and debated even before its details are unveiled. Page D3.

title: City's Plan to Blow Up Buildings in Bronx Fizzles
description: A New York City experiment to cut the time and cost of razing abandoned slum buildings by using explosives has been killed by community opposition in the South Bronx, where the first test was to have been carried out this week, according to city housing officials.

title: Bronco Coach, After Laments, Finds New Optimism
description: Red Miller was in his Denver Bronco office yesterday afternoon starting work on the 1978 season, but he paused to idled on the defeat of his team in the Super Bowl by the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday.

title: Fashion: Serious About Summer
description: IN THE END there were parrots. One perched on the arm of the mannequin in the slithery summer dress. The second was poised on the shoulder of another mannequin. losing its balance in the course of pirouettes, the second parrot dug in its clawsand Pat Cleveland, the model, shrugged it to the floor. Whereupon all the photographers at Oscar de la Renta's fashion show left their perches along the runway to photograph the parrot.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: There's so much soft sculpture around now that one of these days it's going to be on my nono list, along with cutesy Tshirts. But before it's added to items I'm getting slightly tired of, let me tell you about the rather wonderful soft sculpture people who have been crafted into hand puppets. There is Pagliacci, Madama Butterfly, a maestro, ballerina, Aida, King Lear and several others, so it won't surprise you to know that these Joanne Fox designs are at the Lincoln Center Gift Shop. Each puppet is 24 inches tall, signed by the artist and comes with its own stand. The price? I was afraid you'd ask. It's $95 each, but take a look before you groan.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 17 (AP)Gaylord Perry has confirmed reports he will be traded by the Texas Rangers to the San Diego Padres.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Court Bars Picketing to Enforce Pacts Predating Union Recognition
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. I7A union cannot legally picket a construction site to enforce an agreement made with the contractor before it became the recognized bargaining agent, as it could to enforce a union contract after winning recognition, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: U.S. Spraying Kills Million Birds
description: LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn., Jan. 17 (UPI) About a million blackbirds and starlings were killed last night when Department of Agriculture workers sprayed a roost near Lawrenceburg, officials said today. The roost was estimated to contain about 1,250,000 birds. It was the second such spraying in Tennessee this winter. About 300,000 blackbirds and starlings were killed when a roost near Flintville was sprayed two weeks ago.

title: Port Aide Faced No New Inquiry
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and agencies investigating it said yesterday that they knew of no ongoing inquiries involving Alexander Leslie, the former treasurer, who plunged to his death from his eighthfloor Manhattan apartment terrace in an apparent suicide Monday evening.

title: Bridge:
description: If your opponents climb voluntarily to a contract of five spades or five hearts and then put on the brakes, there are usually inferences to be drawn. If they have used Blackwood, it is safe to assume that the netenoers have two aces. If not, it is likely that they have two quick losers in one suit.

title: 200 Spanish Convicts Wound Selves
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 17 (Reuters) Some 200 inmates of Barcelona Jail wounded themselves with homemade weapons today in an apparent protest against the Government's refusal to grant amnesty to Spain's nonpolitical prisoners. Prison officials said that none of the injuries appeared serious.

title: Italians Open Talks In Attempt to Form A New Government
description: ROME, Jan. 17Italy's President began formal political consultations tonight preparatory to designating a successor to Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who resigned with his minority government yesterday amid insistent Communist demands for entry into the cabinet.

title: Guardsmen Move Quickly to L.I. in Old HurryUpandWait Routine
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 17At 2 o'clock this morning, said Daryl J. Wilson of the Bronx, I got a phone call saying that we were going to come out to Long Island, to help out the people, to clear the roads and move some trees.

title: 65,000 on L.I. Remain Powerless; Plan to Use U.S. Planes Canceled
PRICES OF BONDS GAIN ON FED NOTE ACTION
description: In one of its infrequent gains of the last two months, the bond market advanced in price yesterday after the Federal Reserve moved to inject reserves into the nation's banks by purchasing Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Marcos Tells of Role He Plans After Vote
description: MANILA, Jan. 17 (Reuters)President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that in elections for an interim National Assembly to be held April 2the first in more than five years of martial lawthe President would retain the power to issue overriding decrees.

title: Oil Import Growth May Ease, Too
description: There is an arresting sidelight to the argument that oil supplies will not grow short in the immediate futurethe United States may not import nearly as much oil in the 1980's as the experts had feared just a few years ago.

title: Rise in Aid for New York Estimated at $150 Million
description: The estimated $350 million increase in aid to New York City proposed by Governor Carey yesterday may translate into only $150 million to $200 million for use in closing the city's budget deficit for the next fiscal year, according to knowledgeable analysts.

title: New Storm Strains L.I. Rescue Efforts
description: Repair crews working to restore power to many thousands of Long Island residents were joined by National Guardsmen who aided in battle against new storm. Meanwhile, the homeless in Huntington continued their vigil at a school shelter.

title: Chess:
description: If Boris Spassky never sees the French Defense again, it will be too soon.
