In his final candidate's match with his onetime Soviet compatriot Viktor Korchnoi in Belgrade, Spassky limped to one victory over the French while losing to it three times. This failure, a net minus two points, represented twothirds of the margin by which Korchnoi, who defected to the West two years ago, beat him 10 to 7.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1978

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: AS IN ANY other mtier, if the kitchen is your domain (both professionally and as a hobby), food associations occur as naturally as thought. In preparation for a column on cooking, we were wondering about the possible origins of the dish known as London broil, which English sources assure us is of American inspiration, and then the speculation began. Perhaps there was a restaurant called London in some town or city; perhaps was an English chef or cook who first threw a flank steak on the grill and served it with mushroom sauce.

title: $11.9 BILLION BUDGET PRESENTED BY CAREY RAISES AID TO CITIES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17Offering no new promises, few new programs, Governor Carey today presented an $11.974 billion budget for the 197879 fiscal year that includeddespite the $755 million tax reduction he had pledgeda $680 million increase in aid to localities.

title: Sailor Is Killed on Carrier
description: JACKSONVILLE. Fla., Jan. 17 (AP)A Navy man killed in the crashlanding of a jet plane on the carrier Forrestal Sunday night was identified today as Boatswain's Mate Johnny C. Gill of Nicholasville, Ky. Still missing and presumed dead is Boatswain's Mate Jesse R. Puente, whose wife Suzanne lives in Jacksonville. Ten others were injured and three aircraft damaged in the accident aboard the carrier 50 miles off St. Augustine.

title: Pension Rise Is the Disputed Issue In CurtissWright Work Stoppage
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Jan. 17  Official of the CurtissWright Corporation today that the WoodRidge plant, which the company closed six weeks ago, would not reopen until the unions representing 1.200 idled workers agreed to a new contract with no increase in pension benefits.

title: Film: In Diary Form
description: IN HIS OPENENDED autobiographical films called Diaries, Notebooks and Sketches, Jonas Mekas sa:,,s at one point that he's been told he should he searching for understanding. Instead, he says, I celebrate what I see. The Mekas films recall old friends, lazy afternoons, family reunions, solitude, bull sessions, impromptu parties, moments of sadness and moments of no importance whatsoever.

title: WALTER E. NICHOLSON
description: Walter E. Nicholson, a lawyer active in assisting community organizations in Harlem and Jamaica, Queens, died Saturday at his home, 16329 130th Avenue, Jamaica. He was 58 years old.

title: U.S. Attorney Says Remarks by Carter Could Hurt Corruption Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17David W. Marston, the Republican United States Attorney in Philadelphia, said today that remarks attributed to President Carter could have a devastating effect on an investigation his office was trying to conduct into alleged political corruption. He asked the JuKice Department to affirm that such an investigation was under way.

title: Heliport Is Sought for Battery Park City
description: New York Airways and the Port Au thority of New York and New Jersey asked the city's Department of Transportation yesterday for permission to build a heliport on Battery Park City landfill in downtown Manhattan.

title: IMPORT CURB PLAN ON STEEL APPROVED BY COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 17 (AP)Foreign ministers of the European Common Market today approved a formula that could set limits on the volume and prices of foreign steel exports to the European community.

title: Maple Leafs 2. Blues 2
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (UPI)  Lanny McDonald scored his 26th and 27th goals of the season tonight and helped the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 22 tie with the St. Louis Blues.

title: The U.N. Today
Books of The Times
description: WITHIN THIS WILDERNESS. By Feenis Ziner. 225 pages. W. W. Norton. $8.95.

title: Fla. State 76, Cincinnati 66
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 17 (UPI)Harry Davis's 22 points and good team freethrow shooting lifted Florida State to a 76.66 victory over Cincinnati tonight in the Metro Conference. The Seminoles avenged a 7775 loss to the Bearcats in Cincinnati a month ago, and improved their record to 132. Cincinnati dropped to 95.

title: Deaths
description: GINSBERGDr. Nathan N. Beloved husband of Dora. Devoted lather of Eugene. Cherished grandfather of June. Rhona & Steven. Dear brother. Services 10AM Thursday at The Colonial Chapels of I. J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead.

title: Arkansas 84, Texas A&M 68
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Jan. 17 (AP)Ron Brewer scored 29 points tonight and led Arkansas to an 8468 victory over Texas A & M. The victory gave the Razorbacks a 31 record in the Southwest Conference and a 15.1 season record.

title: Deaths
description: Anziano, Lottie

title: At Russian New Year Party, Few Russians
description: Time marches on, and there aren't all that many royal and noble Russians left. So although Le Bal Blanc, celebrating the eve of the old Russian New Year, was held for its 29th year Monday night, the royal and noble Russians around were few and far between.

title: Bridges, Once a Troublemaker, Takes Place of Honor in Capital
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 17A whip thin man, dapper in blazer and lavender shirt, sharp of eye and disarming of smile, Harry Bridges, that same labor troublemaker whose deportation was so long sought by the Federal Government, talked last night to a most select audience. It included the Secretary of Labor.

title: How Budget in Albany Grew and Grew and ...
description: ALBANY, Jan, 17 (AP)State government in New York is a growth industry.

title: The Chicken: Inexpensive, Elegant
description: TAKE IT from this prophet: If you want to know the name of the best buy among meat and poultry the rest of the year it inevitably will be chicken.

title: Asians Explain Restrictions on Freedom to U.S. Aide
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17Patricia M. Derian, Assistant Secretary of State fr Human Rights, has been listening to the leaders of four Southeast Asian countries explain why they restrict civil liberties. She is winding up her tour of the four nations, which count as America's best friends in this region, visibly unconvinced.

title: Fire and Stormy Neighbors Test a Greek Church
description: The Fire Marshal's Report read: R... L..., age 45, caretaker and singer in the church for 4 months, was sleeping upstairs. He states he saw a young man, white, approx. 2627 years of age, wellbuilt, with straight long hair to his shoulders, running down the alley toward 23d Avenue. He then states that he smelled smoke and tried to get out of the building by the stairway, then exited by the rear window.

title: Albany Panel Criticizes Foster Care
description: New York State spends $255 million a year on foster caremore than twice as much as any other statebut a state commission said yesterday that there was no evidence that our program is any more effective in quickly reuniting foster children with their natural parents or freeing them for adoption.

title: Lime Pies Are Yellow Down in Key West
description: KEY WEST, FLA. San Francisco has its Golden Gate Bridge, Houston has its Astrodomeand then there's Key West, with its Key lime pie.

title: Carey to Seek Break For Bettors at Track
description: Governor Carey said yesterday he would recommend to the Legislature that the state increase payoffs to parimutuel bettors at thoroughbred race tracks by 3 percent. It would be, he punned, something for the bettor.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on sugar last Saturday, it was incorrectly reported that Dr. Leo M. Sreebny, dean of the State University of New York Dental School at Stony Brook, L.I., was calling for health warnings on food containing sugar. Actually, Dr. Sreebny advocates the use of warning labels on sugar packages. It was also incorrectly stated that xylitol, an artificial sweetener, contains no calories. Xylitol does contain calories.

title: Rangers Score 3 in Final Period to Defeat Canucks, 54
description: VANCOUVER, Jan. 17 (AP)Ron Greschner scored twice and Don Murdoch once in in the third perid tonight, completing New York's comeback from a twogoal deficit and giving the Rangers a 54 National Hockey League victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Leo Goodwin Jr. Is Dead at 63; Headed GEICO, Insurance Concern
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) Leo Goodwin Jr., head of a financial empire that includes the Government Employees Insurance Company (GEICO), died Sunday at the age of 63 at North Ridge General Hospital, where he was admitted over than two months ago with cancer.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Taylor of Nuggets Says He's Now a Free Agent
description: Brian Taylor, insisting that he was now a free agent, did not show up last night for the game between his Nuggets team and the Cleveland Cavaliers at Denver.

title: Gold Futures Prices Decline; Copper and Platinum Move Up
description: The long advance in gold futures prices was arrested yesterday as traders with large paper profits decided it was time to convert their gains into cash. Others looked at their charts and thought it was time to stand aside, according to brokers.

title: Transcript of Carey's Budget Message Spelling Out Plans for Reducing Taxes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17Following are excerpts from Governor Carey's budget message presented. to the Legislature today:

title: Citicorp's Earnings Off 17% in Quarter And 5.9% for All'77
description: Citicorp, the nation's secondlargest banking concern, reported yesterday that operating earnings fell 17 percent in the fourth quarter from the yearearlier level and that earnings for all of 1977 dropped 5.9 percentthe first yearly profit decline for Citicorp and its predecessor companies since 1961.

title: STRIKE IN MINES CUTS OFF PENSION CHECKS OF 80,600
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)Pension checks for more than 80,000 retired miners will be suspended because the coal strike that began Dec. 6 has depleted their retirement fund, United Mine Workers officials disclosed today.

title: Pee Wee Hockey: Reflection of BigTime Abuses
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass.As 9yearold Richard Girard Jr.'s slap shot slid past the goalie's stick and into the net, the youngster raised his arms triumphantly and his cheering teammates surrounded and hugged him.

title: 200 Years After Cook Landed Hawaiians Pay Scant Attention
description: Against the faint glow of dawn in the eastern sky, the Resolution's lookout reported the island directly behind the wind. That tropic morning of Jan. 18, 1778, found Capt. James Cook bound northward from Tahiti to reach the latitudes of the westerlies, which he hoped would carry him to North America. The Lords of the Admiralty wanted him to look from the west for a Northwest Passage.

title: International Paper Net Gains 33%
description: The International Paper Company, the nation's largest paper maker, reported yesterday a 33 percent rise in fourthquarter profits, but an 8 percent decline for all of last year because of sharply lower earnings in the first half.

title: MCCARTHY OF YANKS IS BURIED IN BUFFALO
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17Representatives of major league baseball, close friends who were moved to tears and wideeyed grade school altar boys were among the 60 people who came here to mourn Joseph V. (Marse Joe) McCarthy this morning.

title: Stage: A Prayer Opens at Public
description: THOMAS BABE'S A Prayer for My Daughter, which opened last night at the Public Theater, is a strange and compelling play. Two tough New York policemen arrest two suspects in a homicide case and begin a bristling interrogation in a lonely station house. For a few morents it is like a 1970's version of Detective story, but it is soon clear that Mr. Babe has something quite different in mind. It is the interior emotional landecape of his quartet that concerns the playwright.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1978

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Jan. 17, 1978 Petition tiled by:

title: United Artists Taps Albeck for President And Chief Executive
description: Andreas Albeck was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the United Artists Corporation, following.the resignations of the company's top five officers in recent days.

title: URBAN LEAGUE FIGHTS $25 BILLION TAX CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The National Urban League, stepping up its political pressure on President Carter with the release of a renort calling the, condition of blacks in America soniber, today announced its oppoiition to the $25 billion.tax cut contemplated by the President.

title: Nordiques 5, W.H.A. AllStars 4
description: QUEBEC CITY, Jan. 17 (AP)Matti Hagman's second goal of the game, a powerplay tally set up by Marc Tardif's record fifth point of the contest, carried the defending champion Quebec Nordiques to a 54 victory tonight over the AllStars in the sixth World Hockey Association AllStar game.

title: Public Confidence in the President On Economy Is Found at New Low
description: With President Carter about to make the economy his top priority as he begins his second year in office, public confidence in his ability to cope with the problems of inflation, unemployment and balancing the Federal budget has sunk to new lows.

title: School Officials in Dayton Decide To Continue Busing for Semester
description: DAYTON Ohio, Jan. 17 (AP)Busing to achieve desegregation in public schools will continue for another semester, school officials said today.

title: Vance to Discuss Issue
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance announced today that he would visit Turkey and Greece over the weekend on his way back to Washington from the Middle East.

title: Deaths
description: RUBINAugusta (Rubin). 78. Of 391 Mountain Rd, West Hartford, CT. Died Monday at home. Born in New Haven. Ct, she lived in the Hartford area the past 18 years. She was a member of the National Association of Social Workers and was Past President of the Mental Health Assize dation for the State of Connecticut. A graduate of Smith College, she received her MA degree from Rad. cline College. She was a psychiatric Social Worker. Survived by her husband Albert Rubin, MD. three brothers. David of New Haven. Ct. Albert, of Beverly Hills. Calif, and Harold of Hartford. Ct and a sister. Mrs Esther Portnow of New York City. Funeral Thursday 10:30AM at Weinstein Mortuary. Hartford Ct. Interment Memorial Park Cemetery, Hartford.

title: Upstate Bull Finds Fame in West
description: DENVER, Jan. 17Here at the National Western Stock Show, the cattle breeders Kentucky Derby, top honors for Black Angus have once again been taken by a New York owner and a New York bull.

title: Deaths
description: ANZIANOLottie Marla, of Levittown, LI, on Jan 16, 1978. (nee Lindberg). Beloved wife of the late Samuel J. Anzianct, MD. Loving mother of Maria Treacy, Samuel John, Jr., Christina Emru, Domenic, Paul, James & Elisabeth. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Friends may call from 25 & 710PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home Levittown Chapel, 2786 Hempstead Turnpike (2 blocks East of Wantagh Parkway). Mass of Christian burial Fri., 10:30AM. St. Bernard RC Church, Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Meeting Broadcast in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Jan. 17  The opening of the talks today in Jerusalem was broadcast live on Egyptian television and radio, but public interest was much more subdued than during the drama of President Sadat's visit to Israel.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchanoe. (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: U.S. SAYS PHILIPPINES MET RULES ON CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17An AgriculDepartment spokesman said today the $48.5 million in Commodity ?? Corporation credits given to the pines last year had been used ac?? to the rules and in full compli?? with the objectives of the proeram.

title: Angolan Leader Visits Nigeria
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 17 (AP)President Agostinho Neto of Angola has arrived in Lagos, Nigeria, for a fiveday state visit, the South African radio reported.

title: $99 Million Spent by Candidates In Congressional Races in 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Congressional candidates spent $99 million in 1976, which was $25 million more than was spent in 1974, according to data compiled by Common Cause, the publicaffairs lobbying organization.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on sugar last Saturday, it was incorrectly reported that Dr. Leo M. Sreebny, dean of the State University of New York Dental School at Stony Brook, L.I., was calling for health warnings on food containing sugar. Actually, Dr. Sreebny advocates the use of warning labels on sugar packages. It was also incorrectly stated that xylitol, an artificial sweetener, contains no calories. Xylitol does contain calories.

title: Transkei Plans Church Talks,
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 17 (AP)Prime Minister Kaiser D. Mantinzima of the Transkei will meet representatives of the Methodist Church of South Africa to discuss his plans to nationalize the church in the new black state. Chief Mantanzima. a Methodist lay preacher, said last week that he was acting because the South African church had refused to !recognize the Transkei's independence.

title: Fire and Stormy Neighbors Test a Greek Church
description: The Fire Marshal's Report read:

title: BILL RUSSELL
description: Bill Russell, a pianist who played at a number of clubs on the upper East Side during the last 25 years, died last weekend of heart failure. His body was found Monday night in his apartment at 300 W. 55th Street after he had failed to report for work at Onde's, 160 East 48th Street, where he had been playing for the last four years.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)A littleknown official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters earned $352,330 in multiple union salaries in 1976, according to Government records published today by union dissidents.

title: Technology
description: Last week's agreement between United States and Japanese trade negotiators to seek equivalent openness in each other's markets is expected to undergo a severe test in the rapidly growing and highly competitive semiconductor business.

title: SAFE DRIVERS RIPPED OFF BY INSURERS, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)Safe drivers are being ripped off by insurance companies that raise rates based on age, sex and people's neighborhoods, a Los Angeles official told a Senate panel hearing today.

title: Public Confidence in the President On Economy Is Found at New Low
Market Place
description: Indexing, a system by which money managers attempt to structure an investment portfolio so that its performance mirrors that of the Standard & Poor Index of 500 stocks, may be one of the least rewarding investment ideas to come along in some time.

title: Long Islanders Learning to Cope With Cold
description: HUNTINGTON BAY, LI., Jan 17We've gotten most of the women and children out. We're keeping an eye on all cars we don't recognize and checking the homes of the people who have left. We know where everyone is and how they are doing. The speaker was Philip Brown, a resident of Crescent Beach Drive on the fourth day he and a few neighbors had endured no power or heat.

title: MOBIL PLANS TO KEEP ITS BASE IN NEW YORK
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, one of the country's biggest enterprises, has decided to keep most of its headquarters operations in New York City. The decision,

title: About Real Estate
description: Have a macaroon, said Arnold Badner, leaning forward and offering from a can of the rumflavored.

title: Trail Blazers 96, Braves 94
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 17 (AP)Bill Walton scored a layup with six seconds left tonight to give the Portland Trail Blazers a 9694 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: Deaths
description: BIKOFFGladys. Beloved wife of Jonas. Devoted mother of James L., and Helen J. Rubens. Dear sister of William I tleman, M.D. Adored grandmother of Suzanne, Margaret, Nicole and Steven. Services today 1:30 PM at Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza Imp RR Sta.), Great Neck, L.I.

title: Budget for New York Matched  With Others
description: New York State's proposed budget of $12 billion is smaller than a number of other governmental budgets, including New York City's own annual outlay of $13.9 billion and California's proposed budget of $16.2 billion.

title: Carey's Tax Cut Plan Compared to '75 Levy
description: The following table contrasts persona income tax liability for married couples with one income and four exemptions in 1975, and in 1978 under current law, and what it would be under Governor Carey's recommendations:

title: Notes on People
description: THE First National Bank of Chicago has lifted a lien on a 40room house owned by Bert Lance, the former budget director, according to court records made available yesterday in Atlanta. The records showed that Mr. Lance had repaid the bank a S3.4 million loan on Jan. 4 after he received more than $3 million from the sale of his stock in the National Bank of Georgia to a businessman from Saudi Arabia.

title: Private Nursing Homes Charge Bias in Prosecution
description: An association of private, profitmaking nursing homes charged yesterday that Charles J. Hynes, the special New York State nursing home prosecutor, had selectively prosecuted them, in violation of their constitutional rights, for Medicaid abuses that were also common among nonproft homes run by religious organizations and others.

title: Radio Listeners to Query Koch
description: MAYOR KOCH will answer question from radio listeners in a special twohour live call  in program un WODS radio next Sunday from 2 P.M. to 4. The broadcast, which will carry no advertising, will be patterned after the callin program with President Carter on the CBS radio network last March.

title: Atlanta Group Sponsors a Forum on the City's Future
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 17Southern politicians and planners have talked a lot about avoiding Northern mistakes in Southern settings, but in many Southern communities familiar signs of urban trouble already are manifest, and few seem to be looking very far into the future.

title: Theater: The Red Robins
description: The Red Robins looks like an attempt at a latterday Peter Pan but it is not really for children. It will piobably not be for many grownups either, despite a glimmer of charm here and there.

title: in Madrid, a Tapa for Every Taste
description: MADRID Have a nibble of this, a nibble of that, quickly, while standing and sipping cold dry white wine. Try some tiny shrimp, marinated mussels, a bite of Spanish omelet or croquettes of cod. Have a few of the seemingly limitless variety of Spanish olives.

title: Sophomores at City U. in 1980 Will Be Tested to See if They Are Qualified to Advance to Upper Classes
description: Sophomores at the City University will be required to pass a series of competency examinations in reading, mathematics and writing to move to upperclassman status, a university official disclosed yesterday. The requirement will go into effect this September, when the class of 1982 enters the university.

title: Texas Tech 45, S.M.U. 43
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Jan. 17 (AP)Mike Edwards hit a 20foot jump shot as the buzzer sounded tonight and gave Texas Tech a 4543 victory over Southern Methodist.

title: Dance: 3Piece Come as You Are
description: THE unpromising infatuations of male dancers for magical birds, butterflies and even reindeer ought to prepare the average dance audience for almost any unlikely eventuality. However, the improbable duet of Sir Francis Chichester and a figure representing his globecircling yawl Gipsy Moth made Sir Francis seem foolish if not half mad. The piece, Gipsy Miles, was shown over the weekend as part of Come As You Are, a program of three dramatically colored works at 130 West 17th Street.

title: West Germans Rush to Invest in U.S.
description: TROISDORF, West Germany By Bayonne or Long Island City standards, Karl Rost's little factory on Stationweg easily passes muster. Gray, crowded by cars that park on the sidewalk and block the entrance, it is just another smudge of light industry on the outskirts of Cologne.

title: Despite Snow, a Bright Day for Byrne
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17It snowed on Governor Byrne's inaugural parade today but, aside from forcing Mr. Byrne to don a camel's hair overcoat, the weather failed to intrude on the festive atmosphere of the ceremonies or social events.

title: Best Buys
description: THE highest cost ever recorded by the Department of Consumer Affairs for feeding a family of four in New York City was reported yesterday by the municipal agency.

title: OncePowerful Families in the Philippines Lose Heavily Under Government Pressure
description: MANILA, Jan. 14Two of the wealthiest and once most politically powerful families in the Philippines have been forced to relinquish much of their fortunes since President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law five years ago as companies they owned have been stripped away under Government pressure.

title: Earth Tremor Rocks Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 (Reuters)A major earth tremor was felt in western Argentina today but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, meteorological officals said. Preliminary surveys indicated the epicenter was 600 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, roughly in the region of the earthquake in November that destroyed the town of Caucete.

title: Cloudy Outlook At Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17  Two months after the visit of President Sadat to Jerusalem dramatically raised prospects for peace in the Middle East for the first time in 30 years, Egyptian, Israeli and United States negotiators today got down to the task of trying to give shape to that vision. There is agreement among the delegations that the negotiations wil be long, difficult and toughwith inter mittent crises and deadlocks and perhaps prolonged adjournments. Success is far from certain.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Crane Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, as required by law, that Crane had bought 630,800 shares. or about 8.6 percent, of the Zapata Corporation, a natural resources company whose profits plunged 84 percent last year.

title: Turkish Cabinet Confirmed
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 17 (AP)The Government of Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit was confirmed by the Turkish Parliament today by a vote of 229 to 218.

title: Wenzel Captures Slalom
description: ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (AP)Andreas Wenzel of Liechtenstein won his first World Cup ski event today in the giant slalom and earned 25 points. The victory moved him into fifth place in the overall standing.

title: Deaths
description: CRAWLEYLillian (nee Bridges) of Hampton Bays, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died suddenly on January 16, 1978. Beloved wife of the late John J. Crawley. Devoted mother of John J. Jr. and Mrs. R. Crawley Andre of Montclair, NJ. Dear sister of Harold V. Bridges.Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Funeral from Brockett Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, NY. Mass Thursday 11:00 AM, St. Rosalies RC Church. Interment to follow Sacred Heart Cemetery, Southampton, NY. In lieu of flowers those wishing to honor her memory may do so by contributing to Hampton Bays Library.

title: Learsy, New Investor in The Trib, Is Elected Chairman of the Board
description: Raymond J. Learsy, president of Agricultural and Industrial Chemicals Inc., has been elected chairman of the board of The Trib, New York City's new morning newspaper.

title: 2 Malamud Operas Of Blitzstein Given
description: AT HIS DEATH in 1964, Marc Blitzstein was working on several operatic projects, one of them being Tales of Malamud, two oneact operas based on short stories by Bernard Malamud. A number or composers, including Leonard Bernstein, expressed interest in completing the first of the pair. Idiots First, but nothing ever came of it.

title: Kyra Lober Dances Tav
description: THE INWARD IMPETUS of Kyra Lober's dance performance almost made one feel like part of a closedcircuit television audience. The emphasis was so emphatically on the self, its being and states of being that the outside world was momentarily blotted out. But Miss Lober's extreme skill and focus made Monday evening at the Cubiculo less an exercise in selfinfatuation than a quietly voiced personal revelation.

title: Israeli Exuberance Fades but Hope Persists
description: JERUSALEM. Jan. 17While Israeli politicians, a diverse and contentious breed, were giving detailed, even dense, interpretations of speeches at the opening today of peace talks by the Egyptian and Israeli foreign ministers, the ordinary citizens seemed to be standing back, discounting the rhetoric and taking a longer and in some cases more positive look at the prospects for peace, which had seemed nonexistent before the visit to Jerusalem by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Inflation, Philanthropy and $18.75
description: George Adam Smith Goodman relates the story, in this month's Atlantic magazine, of the German lawyer who took out an insurance policy for one million marks in 1903. He paid the premium faithfully and when it matured in 1923, he took the proceeds and boughta single loaf of bread.

title: Greek Defense Chief Makes His Ancestral Village Thrive
description: METSOVO, GreeceDefense Minister Evangelos AveroffTositsas may be a possible successor to Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis, but here in the heart of the Pindus Mountains he is most noted for making Metsovo, population 2.800, the most prosperous village in Greece.

title: Thai Crash Kills Missionaries
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17 (AP)A British missionary family and an Australian missionary family were among. 12 people killed in a headon traffic collision in northern Thailand over the weekend, the police said. They said the dead included Ian Gordon Smith, a surgeon, and his wife and two children, and Noel J. Sampson, a doctor, and his wife and son.

title: People and Business
description: Retired Gen. William C. Westmoreland has been elected to the eightman hoard of Tyco Laboratories Inc., an electronics and industrial complex, headquartered in Exeter, N.H., the company announced yesterday.

title: New Storm Strains L. I. Rescue Efforts
description: Repair crews working to restore power to many thousands of Long Island residents were joined by National Guardsmen who aided in battle against new storm. Meanwhile, the homeless in Huntington continued their vigil at a school shelter.

title: School Aid to Suburban Schools Would Be Cut Under Carey Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17School aid to many suburban districts, particularly in Suffolk and Nassau Counties, would be cut under the new education formula proposed by Governor Carey today.

title: Is It Time for Communists?
description: Alt economically depressed Italy, menaced by a rising rate of crime and political terrorism, is again deprived of a government as well. A weak Christian Democratic Government has fallen and its restoration in the weeks ahead is likely to require further concessions to the nation's large and influential Communist Party. Is it time now, as two smaller parties and some Christian Democrats believe, to admit the Communists into coalition, to make them share responsibility not only for the nation's distress but also for the imposition of unpopular social and economic measures that the situation so plainly requires?

title: KUWAIT TO REDUCE PRICE OF HEAVY CRUDE BY 10C
description: KUWAIT, Tan. 17 (AP)Kuwait said today it was reducing the price of its heavy crude oil 10 cents a barrel, retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: Guardsmen Move Quickly to L.I. in Old HurryUpandWait Routine
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 17At 2 o'clock this morning, said Daryl J. Wilson of the Bronx, I got a phone call saying that we were going to come out to Long Island, to help out the people, to clear the roads and move some trees.

title: Bulls 105, Pacers 104
description: CHICAGO, Jan, 17 (UPI)Artis Gilmore and Wilbur Holland each scored 28 points tonight and led the Chicago Bulls to their fourth straight triumph, a 105104 victory over the Indiana Pecers.

title: Moynihan Calls Carter Aid Shift Boost for State
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Carter Administration has decided to change the way it reports Federal outlays in individual states, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said the new system would show that the Government collected $10 billion more in New York in 1976 than it spent there.

title: St. John's Game Is Postponed
description: The basketball game between St. John's University and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, scheduled last night for the Redmen's gymnasium in Hillcrest, Queens, was postponed because of the snowstorm

title: Many Blacks in South Africa, Despite Job Restraints, Want Foreign Companies to Stay
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 17As the clamor has mounted abroad for foreign companies in South Africa to withdraw because of the country's racial policies, Henry Fond 2d has toured his company's plants, examined their employment practices and declared that Ford will not only stay but hopes to expand.

title: KOCH PICKS FIRE CHIEF TO BE COMMISSIONER
description: Augustu sA. Beekman, an assistant fire chief with 31 years in the department, was appointed New York City Fire Commissioner yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Transcript of Address by Byrne at the Start of His Second Term
description: TRENTON. Jan. 17Following is a transcript of Governor Byrne's Inaugural address today:

title: Prawns in Peking, Mooncake in Canton
description: THE MEN CAN can be liberated from their jackets, said our hostess, Soong Chingling, widow of Dr. Sun Yatsen, the father of the Chinese Revolution, vice chairman and first lady of the People's Republic of China.

title: Notre Dame Tops Manhattan By 8164; Batton Tallies 24
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 17 (UPI)Dave Batton led the way with 24 points and 13 rebounds tonight as Notre Dame romped to an 8164 victory over Manhattan.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Tuesday, January 17, 1978

title: HELEN CORBITT
description: DALLAS. Jan. 17 (UPI)Helen Corbitt, a cookbook author and columnist, died yesterday. She was 71 years old. Miss Corbitt wrote and edited several cookbooks and wrote a newspaper column for The Arkansas Democrat in Little Rock and The Houston Chronicle.

title: CiTY U. SOPHOMORES FACE TESTS ON BASICS
description: Sophomores at the City University will be required to pass a series of competency examinations in reading, mathematics and writing to move to upperclassman status, a university official disclosed yesterday. The requirement will go into effect this September, when the class of 1982 enters the university.

title: Cardinals' Owner Locks Out Coryell
description: If the boss changes the lock on the door to your office without telling you, it's not a good sign.

title: Letters
description: To THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Texas 78. Rice 64
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 17 (UPI)Johnny Moore's early shooting helped Texas open a sizable lead and the Southwest Conferenceleading Longhorns coasted to a 7864 victory over Rice tonight. Moore scored 16 points in the first half, finishing with 20. Tyrone Branyan had 21 for Texas, now 132. Rice is 34.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 (Reuters)The Soviet Union proposed today that the 35state European Security Conference close its review here of the 1975 Helsinki agreements for EastWest cooperation with a general statement affirmling the need for dtente but containing only one sentence on human rights.

title: Dollar's Improved Fortunes Spur Stocks to Best Advances in 1978
description: The stock market, encouraged by improved fortunes of the dollar in world currency markets, produced its best rally of 1978 yesterday.

title: Sampling Maps Pollution's Spread In a Maine Public Water System
description: GRAY, Me., Jan. 17State and Federal officials began taking water samples today in an effort to map the underground spread of at least 10 toxic industrial chemicals discovered recently in private wells and in the town's public water supply system.

title: Experts Dispute Administration, Doubt World Oil Shortage in '80's
description: The following article is based on reporting by Anthony J. Parisi and Steven Rattner and was written by Mr. Parisi.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1978

title: Events Today
description: OLD MAN JOSEPH AND HIS FAMILY, by Romulus Linney based on The Appcryoha; staged by Robert Kalfin at the Chelsea/BAM, 30 Lafayette Street, 2 P.M.

title: A Cook's Dream: Gadgets Galore
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 17To lovers of kitchen gadgetry, Chicago's huge exhibition hall, McCormick Place, would be considered a promised land this week. The 68th semiannual trade exhibition, sponsored by the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, is giving nearly 20,000 buyers of housewares from all over the country an advance look at what will be available in stores this spring.

title: Blue Deal: Hearing Recessed
description: Vida Blue, the seemingly unsalable pitcher who has been involved in controversy that has inspired more words than a Washington filibuster, did not attend Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's hearing yesterday. Some of the 26 people who did wished they hadn't either.

title: Hell Has Now Frozen Over
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 17Fair warning, Patti Dreifuss of the promotional firm called Top Rank Inc., told a reporter over long distance, Ali says the press is welcome at his workout but no interviews, he's not talking.

title: Tax Cut Would Benefit Business And UpperIncome People Most
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17While the $755 million in tax reductions proposed by Governor Carey in his budget today offer something for everyone, including the elderly and the bettor, the largest share of its benefits would go to businesses and to upper and uppermiddleincome taxpayers.

title: New Sound of Britain
description: MUSICAL ELEMENTS, a new chambermusic ensemble, presented the first of six concerts devoted to various geographical areas of new music Monday night at the Truck and Warehouse Theater, 79 East Fourth Street. Despite some reservation about the actual content of the opening program, which was devoted to new music from Britain, the series seems most promising. The players are good, the stage and theater attractive and the initial audience large and diverse. Subsequent programs will offer new music from the West Coast on Feb. 20, Eastern Europe on March 13, Italy on April 3, Israel on May 1 and the Northeast on May 29.

title: Carey's Marvelous New Math
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17  For sheer virtuosity, Governor Carey's $11.97 billion budget presented today seems to have set a new standard, illustrating once again the vast amount of flexibility available to a Governor even when the state's finances are under more scrutiny than ever.

title: HardyHorowitz Fans Rewarded
description: LINED UP 1,000 strong before the Carnegie Hall box office opened at 10 A.M., the fans of Vladimir Horowitz queued up along three sides of the block at one point yesterday, waiting for hours in cold and snow to buy tickets for two March recitals by the 73yearold Pianist.

title: BANKS TO BE MONITORED ON POLITICAL PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The Faderal agencies that keep watch over the nation's banks said today they will use their full legal authority to halt illegal political contributions and other questionable payments by banks.

title: Flynt to Purchase Atlanta Weekly
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 17 (AP)Larry Flynt, the owner of Hustler magazine, pans to buy The Atlanta Gazette, a weekly newspaper, and has hired State Senator Julian Bond as a contributor, it was announced today. In the last month, Mr. Flynt has bought The Los Angeles Free Press and the Plains Monitor, in Plains, Ga. Richard Brown, editor and publisher of the 35,000 circulation Gazette, said that he would retain control of the paper as editor-inchief. Neither he nor Mr. Flynt would discuss the purchase price. Mr. Bond said that his title would be senior editor and that he would be an occasional contributor.

title: Carter And the Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  In his Calendar of Great, Americans, Woodrow Wilson made an observation about Mr. Lincoln which still stands as a fairly good test of American Presidents at the end of their first year in the White House.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Personal Health
description: SINUSESwe all have them and, given our druthers, many of us would gladly send them to Arizona... without us. Each year more than 20 million Americans are plagued by inflamed and painful sinuses, and for some the problem is persistent or recurrent. Frustrated patients who have exhausted the standard repertoire of therapies and are still complaining may be advised by their equally frustrated physicians to move. But to where?

title: Park Testimony Called Essential for Existing Cases
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 18In an unusual statement for a prosecutor in the midst of a criminal case, Benjamin R. Civiletti said yesterday that the testimony of Tongsun Park would prove essential in the prosecution of former officials and private individuals even though it was unlikely to result in the indictment of any present members of Congress.

title: Disruption Over Prayer Bill
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 17 (AP)About a halfdozen people demanding passage of school prayer bill disrupted the Ohio Senate today, then vowed to stay until the Housepassed measure got a hearing in the tipper chamber. The Senate proceeaed with its regular business without acknowledging the protesters. The bill would require public schools to provide up to a minute each day for prayer or meditation.

title: Power Is Still Out On L.I. for 65,000; Airlift Is Canceled
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Wednesday, Jan. 18The Long Island Lighting Company restored power yesterday to more than a quarter of a million residents whose homes had been without heat or light since he ice storm Saturday morning. As state and Federal agencies waited in the wings, the company said it was still working to get power back today to the last 65,000 residents despite new snow, rain and sleet.

title: Some Candidates for F.B.I. Leader
description: WASHINGTONThe single most important appointment still to be made in the Carter Administration, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has correctly noted, will be the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The country cannot afford still another person running the Bureau who does not enjoy the confidence of the American people and the respect of those who serve under him.

title: 1,599 Adults Queried In Times/CBS Survey
description: The latest survey by The New York Times and CBS News is based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 8 to Jan. 12 with 1,599 adult men and women around the United States.

title: Hawks 111, Kings 90
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 17 (AP)John Drew scored 27 points and Charlie Criss added 19 to power the Atlanta Hawks to a 11190 victory over Kansas City tonight. It was the Kings 14th consecutive loss on the road. The Hawks took command at the start as Drew scored 11 points in the opening quarter to give Atlanta a 3123 lead.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
Experts Dispute Administration, Doubt World Oil Shortage in 80's
description: Many energy experts are beginning to challenge the Carter Administration's assertion that the world faces a severe shortage of oil in the 1980's. These experts contend that oil supplies, currently in abundance, may remain adequate at least through 1990, thereby reducing the likelihood of another extraordinary jump in prices.

title: POSTAL SERVICE STUDYING PALLOTINE MAILINGS NOW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)The Postal Service said today that it was investigating the current practices of a Roman Catholic order whose practices led to the indictment of its former chief fundraiser.

title: Why They Tried to Get Humphrey to Wear Glasses
description: Those days when Hubert was Mayor of Minneapolis were full of excitement. I watched from a distance, but would occasionally be drawn into the picture. Hubert had met some of the civil rights experts from Fisk University.

title: Waldheim Describes His Cyprus Talks as Encouraging
description: ATHENS, Jan. 17Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said tonight that the difficult road toward a Cyprus settlement had reached a turning point with the agreement of Turkey to make concrete proposals in two weeks on the main issue in the dispute.

title: New DallasLondon Route Ordered For Braniff Instead of Pan Am
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)The Civil Aeronautics Board, obeying direct orders from President Carter, said today Braniff International instead of Pan American World Airways should have a lucrative new route linking Dallas and London.

title: $19 BILLION BUDGET PRESENTED BY CAREY RAISES AID TO CITIES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 17Offering no new promises, few new programs, Governor Carey today presented an $11.974 billion budget for the 197879 fiscal year that includeddespite the $755 million tax reduction he had pledgeda $680 million increase in aid to localities.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin told his staff, in effect, that anyone who wanted a raise would have to earn it.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLICK TREAT The Kodak Photo Gallery, 43d Street and Avenue of the Americas, is an attractive, free oasis, often neglected by hurrying pedestrians. It also has a new, doubleheader display starting today that should make the showcase a double reward for novices. Spread over the twolevel, corner cubicle is an array of more than 800 photographs cited in Kodak's annual newspaper snapshot contest, an international contest for amateurs. Also exhibited are 50 enlarged color pictures featured in Audubon Magazine.

title: Compromise Hinted on Proposed Truck Fuel Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17Some adjustment may be made in a controversial proposal to require a 30 percent reduction in gasoline consumption by the 1980 models of lightweight trucks, vans and utility vehicles, Joan Claybrook, administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said in a brief interview today.

title: Power Is Still Out On L.I. for 65,000; Airlift Is Canceled
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 17As state and Federal agencies waited in the wings, the Long Island Lighting Company restored power today to more than a quarter of a million island residents, whose homes had been without heat or light since the Saturday morning ice storm. The company said it was still working to get power back tomorrow to the last 65,000 residents, despite new snow rain and sleet.

title: 200 Years After Cook Laned Hawaiians Pay Scant Attention
description: Against the faint glow of dawn in the eastern sky, the Resolution's lookout reported the island directly behind the wind. That tropic morning of Jan. 18, 1778, found Capt. James Cook bound northward from Tahiti to reach the latitudes of the westerlies, which he hoped would carry him to North America. The Lords of the Admiralty wanted him to look from the west for a Northwest Passage.

title: Mondale in Canada for Fuel Talks
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 17Vice President Mondale began a twoday Canadian visit today with talks here on ways to enlarge the exchange of energy sources between the United States and Canada.

title: Psychotherapy: Finding More Shrinks to Fit
description: In response to an article three weeks ago on choosing a psychotherapist, several readers informed The Living Section of new services for those seeking help and contributed additional information on the qualifications of various types of therapists.

title: Byrne, in Inaugural, Pledges Help To Cities and Reports New Pride
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17Governor Byrne was sworn in today to a second term, and promised in his inaugural address to devote the next four years to rebuilding New Jersey's cities.

title: Careers
description: Despite tight budgets in some areas, the museum industry apparently is healthy and growing and so is the number of jobs it provides.

title: Aetna to Report Loss
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced that it would report an estimated aftertax loss of $7.5 million as a result of a grain explosion in Westwego, La., last month. The loss involved primarily workers compensation coverage at the Louisiana grain elevator. The loss, the company said, would not materially affect earnings results either for thefourth quarter of 1977 or the year as whole.

title: Text of the Agenda for Jerusalem Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 (AP)Following is the agenda of EgyptianIsraelf peace talks in Jerusalem, as read to reporters in English by an Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman:

title: Wine Talk
description: THE ROMANS brought the vine to most of the civilized world but it was the monks who preserved the winemaking tradition down through the ages. The great vineyards of Burgundy were tilled by churchmen; some of the great vineyards of Bordeaux still bear church namesLa Mission HautBrion and Pape Clement, for example.

title: Harper & Row Won By Waterman, Getz
description: Waterman, Getz, Niedelman Advertising, one of the largest independent agencies specializing in book adverising, has suddenly becme much bigger. It has been named agency for Harper & Row Publishers Inc., which has an advertising budget of around $1.5 million.

title: Stews to Warm A Midwinter Night
description: Few dishes are more appropriate to the winter season than stew, a somewhat flatfooted and plebian word for what can easily become a preparation of great subtlety and heartwarming appeal. But because they are considered humble dishes, stews all too often are given short shrift from cooks. A perfect case in point is the classic beef stew, burgundian style, better known as boeuf bourguignon and now so much a clich on bistro menus that one hardly thinks of it as distinctive.

title: State of Union Talk Is Set for 9 Tonight
description: The commercial television networks and the Public Broadcasting Service will telecast live President Carter's State of the Union message which is scheduled to begin at 9 o'clock tonight. In the metropolitan area, it will be broadcast on television by Channels 2, 4, 7 and 13, and on radio by WCBSAM, WINS and WNYCAM.

title: ACTING DIRECTOR GETS WILLOWBROOK POST
description: Elin M. Howe, a 31yearold public administration expert, is being named director of New York State's oftencontroversial Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island, a facility a court monitor said yesterday was on a steady uphill climb.

title: Court Strikes Down A Wisconsin Statute Limiting Remarriage
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 18The Supreme Court today struck down as unconstitutional a state law requiring court permission before a man with a legal obligation to support children of an earlier union could marry.

title: Entertainment Leaders Discuss Fate of Music Hall
description: Leaders in the entertainment world offered suggestions at a public hearing yesterday on how to keep Radio City Music Hall open, but their hopes were not raised by a report that the 6.000seat theater had lost $14 million since 1969.

title: Yastrzemski's Mother Dies
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Mrs. Hedwig Yastrzemski, mother of Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox, died last night at Sancta Maria Hospital after a long illness. She was 60 years old. Mrs. Yastrzemski, who was born in New Jersey, lived most of her life in Southampton, L.I. In recent years, she had lived in North Andover, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., With her son.

title: Text of Israeli Cabinet Statement
description: JERUSALEM. Jan. 18 (AP)Following is an official translation from Hebrew of the text of a statement from the Israeli Cabinet issued after Egypt interrupted negotiations here.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE HIGH COST OF LIVING. By Marge Piercy. 268 pages. Harper & Row. $10.

title: High Court Widens Prosecutors' Power In Plea Bargaining
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18A narrowly divided Supreme Court enhanced the pleabargaining power of criminal prosecutors today by ruling that they may threaten a defendant with a second, more serious indictment if he refuses to plead guilty to an initial charge and demands a trial.

title: High Court Widens Prosecutors' Power In Plea Bargaining
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18A narrowly divided Supreme Court enhanced the pleabargaining power of criminal prosecutors today by ruling that they may threaten a defendant with a second, more serious indictment if he refuses to plead guilty to an initial charge and demands a trial.

title: Company Earnings Listed for the Quarter
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherseise Indicated. (N) Iodates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Carter Plans Push For Bill to Create Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  President Carter told a delegation of consumer leaders today that he intended to push strongly for a consumer protection agency bill this year and would back other major consumer initiatives, members of the group said.

title: Theater: An Actor Impersonates Shaw
description: SHE WAS insufferable, Shaw declared of Joan of Arc; she knew everyone's business better than they did themselves. Of course Shaw identified himself with Joanit makes his play about her one of his bestand he was the universal busybody he wrote up for her.

title: Whalers Shift 13 Gaines To Arena in Springfield
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 18The New England Whalers said today that they would play 13 of their final 20 regularseason home games at the Springfield (Mass.) Civic Center. The World Hockey Association team was forced to move after the roof of its home arena, the Hartford Civic Center, collapsed early this morning.

title: The Nest May Be Empty, but the Belongings Linger On
description: GROWN children should not live at home and almost never do. We are light years from the time when it was considered complimentary to have one of them hanging around, unable to break away. Nevertheless, migr offspring are always expecting you to hang on to pieces of themselves in spaces you desperately require for pieces of you. Far from emptying the nest, they leave you with a warehouse of cluttering indispensables with which, obviously, they can dispense long enough to make you beg for their removal.

title: Black College Lauds Iphigene Sulzberger
description: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger was awarded an honorary doctorate of of humanities yesterday by Bishop College of Dallas, the largest private predominantly black college in the Southwest.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COASTING IN Before forming his own company, Bill Evans was a principal dancer and choreographer with the Utah Repertory Dance Theater for eight years. His solo performing several seasons ago at Jacob's Pillow, Mass., was praised by Anna Kisselgoff of The New York Times. Tonight, tomorrow and Saturday at 8 P.M., the dancer is making a rare New York appearance at Pace University, (one block east of City Hall), presenting his Seattlebased troupe in three different programs. Most of the dance pieces are New York premieres.

title: Mysterious James A. Carr Options, Alias and Wealth
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18The smoothtalking man known as James A. Carr was scarcely a pillar of the Boston financial community, but in a matter of months he established himself as a cultured and wealthy businessman who drove a RollsRoyce, lived opulently in a fashionable suburb and ran his own investment firm.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Sedate Leader of Italy's Communists
description: ROME, Jan. 18A recent cartoon In a Roman newspaper showed the secretary general of the Italian Communist Party, Enrico Berlinguer, sitting in an easy chair in a genteel drawing room, in slippers and with a cup of tea in hand, listening with annoyance to the shouts of demonstrating workers in the streets outside.

title: Dollar Remains Steady in Trading Abroad; Gold Price Declines
description: The dollar remained steady on world money markets yesterday as traders waited to see whether President Carter's State of the Union Address today would bring significant developments in energy or economic policies, The Associated Press reported.

title: Nastase Praises Youth
description: TOWSON, Md., Jan. 18 (UPI)Ilie Nastase calls 18yearold Elliot Teltscher the best American player he has met.

title: Soviet Denies Charges
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (UPI)  The Soviet Union admitted today that it was providing military aid to help Ethiopia fight Somalia but denied that Sovietbloc military personnel were taking part in combat operations.

title: Housing Starts Rise 8.2%; Personal Income Up 1.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Housing starts, one of the brightest elements in the nation's economic recovery in 1977, climbed at an 8.2 percent rate in December, compared with November totals, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Dick Barnett Is Cited for Fraudulent Business Practices
description: Dick Barnett, one of the heroes in the Knicks championship season nine years ago, was cited yesterday by the State Attorney General's office for engaging in fraudulent business practices.

title: Deaths
description: Lew, Rosa

title: Canadiens 7, Barons 4
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 18 (UPI)Guy LeFleur had a big game with two goals and two assists as the Montreal Canadians beat the Cleveland Barons tonight, 74.

title: Banks Report Earnings for Latest Quarter
description: For periods ended Dec. 31. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: HEART VALVE DEFECT AND MURMURS LINKED
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 18Many people thought to have innocent heart murmurs may actually have a defect of a major heart valve that causes it to turn inside out, like an umbrella caught in a gust of wind.

title: De La Roche Trial Defense Opens With Testimony From 2 Friends
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 18The defense for Harry De La Roche Jr.. the Montvale teenager charged with murdering his parents and two brothers, opened today with two of his friends testifying that the defendant had indicated to them that he planned to resume his military studies at the Citadel after the Thanksgiving recess of 1976.

title: Ecuadorean Airliner Is Hijacked to Cuba
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Jan. 18 (Reuers)A hijacked Ecuadorean airliner I with 25 hostages aboard flew tonight toward Cuba after refueling at this southern port city a civil aviation spokesman said.

title: Opera: Beverly Sills Is Lead in Thais
description: BEVERLY SILLS and Sherrill Milnes sang the leading roles in Massenet's Thais at the San Francisco Opera two years ago, and that was the production seen last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Thais has been out of the Metropolltan repertory since 1939. There seemed no great public groundswell for a revival. But Beverly Sills is a diva, and divas must have their vehicles. Hence Thais.

title: JOHN LYNG, 72, PREMIER OF NORWAY BRIEFLY IN '63
description: OSLO, Jan. 18 (Reuters)John Lyng, Norway's former coalition Prime Minister and a Foreign Minister, died here today at the age of 72. Informed sources said he had been ill with lung cancer since last year.

title: Adams Hears Heated Testimony In Efforts to Avert a Rail Crisis
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18Brock Adams, Secretary of Transportation, seeking to head off a new crisis in the railroad industry, heard heated testimony today from 26 witnesses representing railroad companies, labor unions, shippers and state officials in the Middle West.

title: A Homeland but No Home
description: There is, sadly, not much novelty in the news that another black squatters camp has been razed in South Africa, leaving 15,000 people homeless on the outskirts of Cape Town. The white South African Government has demolished such settlements before. Nor was there anything illegal about the clearing operation, at least not terms of South African law. The residents for the most part were wives and children of black urban workers with no legal right to live near their husbands and fathers.

title: ETHIOPIAN DENIES USE OF FOREIGN SOLDIERS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 18A member of Ethiopia's military Government said here today that there were no Soviet or Cuban military advisers, instructors or combat troops in his country. He dismissed all statements to the contrary as propaganda inspired by Somalia in an attempt to expand the sixmonthold EthiopianSomali war into a global confrontation.

title: Celtics 130, Bucks 116
description: BOSTON, Jan 18 (UPI)Sidney Wicks scored 35 points and Dave Cowens added 23 tonight to lead a 130116 romp by the Boston Celtics offer the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Rangers 3, Kings 0
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18  Defensernen Don Awrey and Ro Greschner scred goals 59 seconds apart in the first period tonight and goalie Wayne Thomas posted his third shutctit of the season as the New York Rangers won their first game in nearly three years on Los Angeles ice. They defeated the Kings, 30.

title: Notes on People
description: EVER SINCE HE discovered a year ago that he had cancer, there had been some doubt about the political future of Dewey F. Bartlett, Oklahoma's junior Senator. Yesterday Mr. Bartlett announced in Tulsa: I will not seek reelection. My doctor believes that if I did it would be impossible to devote the time and take the necessary treatment to restore my health. With great reluctance I agree with him. The 58yearold Republican, a former Governor of his state, emphasized that he would complete his current term, to which he was elected in 1972. I feel well, he said. My health is generally good.

title: Bridge:
description: Small straws in the wind will sometimes induce an expert to abandon a normal line of play. A fine example is the diagramed deal, played in the Monte Carlo segment of the European Grand Prix for the Philip Morris Cup. The hero was Martin Hoffman. of London, who has the reputation of being one of Europe's shrewdest card players.

title: The Family That Owns London
description: LONDON DESPITE punitive death duties, steep income tax rates and shopping sprees by Arab sheiks, much of the most valuable real estate in this city belongs, as it has for 300 years, to a single English family. Probably the wealthiest private landlord in Great Britain, the Grosvenor family holds title to the 300 choice acres in central London that make up Mayfair and Belgravia. Its properties number no fewer than 30 foreign embassies, including the massive United States Embassy on Grosvenor Square, as well as street after elegant street of gracious, white and creamcolored Georgian and Regency private residences.

title: Chrysler Cut in Australia
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 18 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation plans to dismiss 300 workers from three major plants in the Australian state of South Australia. The cut will reduce the Chrysler work force in South Australia to 4,680, down more than 1,100 from 12 months ago. The job losses are threatening to spark a confrontation with unions, which already are calling for a blockade of the company's plants by workers.

title: News Summary
description: The Middle East peace talks broke up abruptly. President Anwar elSadat of Egypt ordered his Foreign Minister to return home at once from political negotiations in Jerusalem and told President Carter that the talks would resume only if Israel changed its position. The recall raised serious doubts about the future of the peace initiative that Mr. Sadat began barely two months ago by going to Israel. Later, the Cairo radio reported, Mr. Carter called Mr. Sadat and urged him to reconsider his decision. Mr. Sadat reportedly complained that Israel sought land and not peace, but he agreed to allow military talks to resume in Cairo on Saturday in appreciation of Mr. Carter's efforts on behalf of Middle East [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Calendar of Events for the Home
description: Yale University Art Gallery Exhibition, New Haven, Conn.

title: Events Today
description: PAUL ROBESON with James Earl Jones, at the Lunt Fontanne Theater, 7.

title: About New York
description: God did not call Brother Sebastian to wear Dr. Scholl's sandals.

title: Deaths
description: JACOBSHarry L. The Board of Trustees of

title: New Plan on ExMental Patients Set
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18The State Office of Mental Health disclosed plans today to establish, in the next five years, new statefinanced community residences to shelter and provide services for 5,500 patients who have been or will be discharged from state mental hospitals.

title: Measuring Employment  New Method Criticized
description: Some economists are highly critical of the Bureau of Labor Statistics and its commissioner, Julius Shiskin, for accepting and stressing a new measure of the degree of full employment the ratio of total employment, not to the civilian labor force but to the entire population aged 16 or older, whether or not they are looking for work.

title: Nets Drop 9th in Row By 127101
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 18A crowd of 6,428 braved icy roads to come to Rutgers gym tonight with the hope of seeing a DavidandGoliath battle between the New Jersey Nets and the Portland Trail Blazers, the defending champions of the National Basketball Association. And that's exactly what they saw, except for the fact that this time Goliath.won big, 127101.

title: Lights Go Back On for Most of 37,300 StormStruck Families in State
description: Power was restored yesterday to most of the 37,300 New Jersey families who shivered in dark and heatless homes after a second major snowstorm in a week.

title: The U.N. Today
Hanging Art Works: It's a Science
description: HANGING pictures and other art works is a task approached by many with trepidation and mild panic. Too many plaster holes, bruised thumbs and stubborn walls loom in the memory of the home installer, resulting in the pickaspotandbanginanail method of hanging works of art. It is. however, a relatively easy chore to placesafely and effectivelypaintings, photographs or other works of art in the home.

title: Ullman Opposes Plans to Tighten Business ExpenseAccount Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Representative Al Ullman, the chairman of the taxwriting Ways and Means Committee, said today that Congress would not accept President Carter's expected proposal to tighten up on business expense accounts because to do so would cause a loss of jobs in the restaurant and hotel industries.

title: U.S. Appellate Judge Is Expected To Be Nominated as Head of F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18William H. Webster, a Federal appellate judge in St. Louis, is expected to be nominated tomorrow as the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Carter Administration official said today.

title: Deaths
description: HALLRobert S. On January 17. 1978. Age 54, of Malvern, Pe. Husband of Ruth Doane Hall. Relatives and friend are invited to the service Saturday, January 21, at 2:00 PM from the James Dewhirst Funeral Home, 17 3rd Avenue, North Andover, Mass. Interment Ridgewood Cemetery. Friends may call at the funeral home Friday evening from 79PM.

title: DR. RALPH E. BADGER, 88; ECONOMIST AND AUTHOR
description: Dr. Ralph E. Badger, a leading economist, security analyst, investment adviser and author, died yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: Redskins Drop Allen as Coach For Delay in Signing Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) George Allen, whose philosophy of trading draft choices for proven veterans helped the Washington Redskins reach the playoffs in five of his seven years as head coach and general manager, was dismissed tonight.

title: Transamerica
description: The Transamerica Corporation, whose operations range from insurance to motion picture distribution, reported yesterday record fourth quarter net income of $39.9 million, or 60 cents a share, up 51 percent from $26.4 million, or 44 cents a share in the 1976 final quarter.

title: CARTER CALLS SADAT, URGES FURTHER TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  President Carter telephoned President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today to urge him to keep the negotiations with Israel going despite the sudden recall of the Egyptian delegation to the Jerusalem talks.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The superintendent of the Coxsackie State Correctional Facility was replaced and procedures to control rebellious inmates were tightened.

title: Court Order Halts a OneDay Walkout By Bergen County Civil Service Union
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 18Bergen County's largest Civil Service union struck for most of the day today before agreeing to comply in late afternoon with an order by a State Superior Court judge to return towork immediately.

title: Arrogance In Power
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18Back East, people tend to think of Jerry Brown as an engaging young man, a philosopher politician who does not pretend to have the answers but asks deep questions about government and society. That image helped him win the five Presidential primaries he entered in 1976. It makes some political handicappers see him as a serious threat to Jimmy Carter in 1980.

title: Executive at City College Resigns Amid an Inquiry Into Lobbyists' Finances
description: Robert F. Carroll Jr. resigned yesterday as vice president for public affairs of City College in the midst of an investigation of funds allegedly missing from a national education lobbying group of which Mr. Carroll had been an official.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the business/finance section in some editions of The Times yesterday incorrectly stated the operating earnings per share of Citicorp for the fourth quarter of 1976. The banking concern reported earnings of 88 cents a share for that period.

title: Design Notebook
description: FOR ALL its architectural glories, the City of New York does not have a at reception room, the sort of formal hall in which visitors are greeted with pomp and circumstance and where proper ceremonies can be held. It would be unthinkable, of course, to spend the money to create such a place in today's economic climate, but there is a room that could serve the purpose perfectly. The city already owns it and it is just behind City Ball.

title: EAST COAST BUSTS REMAIN A MYSTERY
description: For generations, inhabitants of widely scattered regions, from Moodus, Conn., to the mouths of the Ganges have been alarmed by strange booming sounds.

title: Home Beat
description: E Is for Expensive

title: S.E.C. Head Urges Independent Boards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed today that corporate boards be filled almost exclusively by independent directors, but he opposed Federal legislation to require companies to implement the changes he recommends.

title: Rangers Bidding High For Swedish Express
description: The competition for the services of two hockey players known as The Swedish Express, Anders Hedberg and Ulf Nilsson, has reached the playoff stage. With the New York Rangers having outbid seven other National Hockey League teams with an offer of $475,000 apiece a year for two years, the competition has been reduced to the Rangers versus the entire World Hockey Association.

title: PAINE WEBBER PROFITS FELL 75.6% IN QUARTER
description: Paine Webber Inc., holding company of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., a leading securities firm, yesterday reported for its first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 net earnings of $962,000, or 10 cents a share. This represented a drop of 75.6 percent from the $3.9 million, or 65 cents a share, earned a year earlier. Revenues of $75.4 million increased 14.1 percent form $6.6 million.

title: State Audit of the Finances of Montclair Schools Asked By League of Women Voters, but Aides Defend System
description: MONTCLAIR, Jan. 18The League of Women Voters of MontclairGlen Ridge has called for a state audit of the Montclair public school system, charging that an inordinate number of bills, amounting to $171,000, had not been paid last year and were improperly rolled over into the new school fiscal year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Civil service Commission yesterday gave back a job to a former Mercer County road supervisor who was convicted of extortion.

title: CABINET ACTS QUICKLY
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18  President Anwar elSadat's abrupt recall of the Egyptian delegation was sharply criticized by the Israeli Cabinet late tonight as an extreme move that proved that the Egyptian Government deceived itself that Israel will submit to demands it has never considered feasible.

title: New Booklet Lists 3,000 Political Plums
description: What do the following New York City jobs have in common: coal handler in the Department of Purchase, dietary aide in the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, cook in the sheriff's office, institutional tailor in the Department of Social Services, gauge keeper for the Board of Water Supply and monuments officer for the Landmarks Preservation Commission?

title: Coliseum Roof Collapses At Hartford Civic Center
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 18Under a heavy blanket of ice and snow, the huge flat roof of the twoyearold Hartford Civic Center's coliseum collapsed at 4:15 this morning, raining havoc on the $70 million convention and shopping complex that was meant to be the centerpiece of the city's resurgence.

title: GARDENING
description: THE SEED catalogs are already well thumbed and dogeared. Indeed some seeds from early orders are beginning to trickle in. Yet the snow lies like white icing on the gardenan analogy more than apropos in this year of ice storms.

title: Hoiby, Composer, in Piano Recital
description: MUSICIANS who both composed and performed were not rarities in earlier centuries. In fact, before the middle of the 19th century it is hard to name, offhand, composers who did not enjoy reputations as firstrate performers, if not virtuosos. In the last 100 years or so, however, the two crafts have become so specialized that such dual careers are the exception.

title: DR. JOSEPH N. SCIALABBA
description: Dr. Joseph N. Scialabba, a former president of the Kings County Surgical Society, died Monday in Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 409 Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

title: Boom in Orange County, Calif, Brings Corruption With It
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 17 When an architect and a county supervisor were recently charged in an alleged $200,000 bribery plot involving land development, it apparently surprised few people in Orange County. After all, 42 other public officials and political workers in the county have been charged with criminal offenses in the past three years.

title: Scientists Plunge Into Lobbying For More Medical Research Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18In a city where the lobbyist is ubiquitous, distinguished scientists who would normally consider the practice demeaning have been wending their way through the halls of Congress and past some doors of the White House to gladhand and backslap for more Federal funds for basic medical research.

title: Waldheim Is Visiting Austria
description: VIENNA, Jan. 18SecretPryGeneral Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here today from Athens for two days of talks with Austrian officials following an effort to revive talks on the Cyprus' conflict. Officials said Mr. Waldheim would see Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and Foreign Minister Willibald Pahr as well as chief executives of United Nations organizations here.

title: N.J. Track, Reopening, Thinks Big
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Jan. 18 With tons of piled snow forming a backdrop, the Meadowlands opened its 172night 1978 harness racing season tonight in blustery, subfreezing weather.

title: Democratic Mayors Open Seminar
description: I'm the new guy on the block, Mayor Koch said yesterday as he welcomed the National Conference of Democrat Mayors to a twoday seminar on urban problems at the Americana Hotel.

title: A Classy Mob Braves the Weather for Lenox Hill
description: IT JUST goes to show. Give New Yorkers a challenge and they'll slush through it. Who would have thought that some 700 men and women, many of them in evening dress, would have braved Tuesday night's snow and rain just for charity?

title: Meditation In Jersey
description: The socalled silentmeditation bill has passed both houses of the New Jersey Legislature and now awaits Governor Byrne's signature. If it is adopted, we can expect that other state legislatures will consider such bills of their own. New Jersey's legislation, which would institutionalize mediation or silent prayer in schools, may or may not be constitutionalthis remains to be seen. But it is certainly immoral. As an atheist and parent, I am deeply troubled by the effect such a law would have on my children.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M. WNCN. Spanish Dance No. 6, Granados: 5 Polonaises, C.P.E. Bach; Polonaise No. 3, Chopin; Concerto Grosso in B Minor, Boyce; Academic Festival Overture. Brahms.

title: Deaths
description: RUOMETSKYJacob, HancockDirigoAdelphi Lodge 23 F.&A.M. mourns with deep sorrow the loss of It's esteemed Life Member. Services 12:30 Thursday. Jan 19 at Sinnickson's Funeral Home, 203 Main St, Center Moriches, L.I.

title: Marston Action Reported Delayed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18  The four lawyers asked by Attorney General Griffin B. Beal to recommend a replacement for United States Attorney David W. Marston have been told to stop their search, according to sources close to the panel.

title: Koch Scolds Aides for Canceling An Explosive Razing in the Bronx
description: Sizzling with anger, Mayor Koch yesterday publicly scolded officials of his administration who, without consulting me, canceled an experiment in which explosives were to be used to demolish an abandoned South Bronx school.

title: Fast Foods Sell School Lunches in LasVegas
description: LAS VEGASIn addition to its casinos and cabarets, its reputed links with organized crime and its neonlighted garishness, Las Vegas is developing a reputation for the fastfood lunches served in its public high schools.

title: One State Budget, Three Priorities
description: Governor Carey's budget message reflects his three priorities for 1978: to help revive New York State's economy by encouraging private employment; to help New York City in its struggle for Federal assistance to avoid default on its obligations; to help himself get reelected.

title: DISTILLATE SUPPLIES FALL TO 234.9 MILLION BARRELS
