description: Supplies of distillate oil were off sharply to 234.9 million barrels in the week, ended Jan. 13, down from 242.3 million barrels in the previous week and reflecting the extremely cold weather across the country. Inventories of distillate are 67 million barrels ahead of last year at this time, hoWever, when weather conditions were more severe.

title: China, in Apparent Gesture of Support, Sends Official to Cambodia
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 18In what appeared to be a gesture of support for Cambodia in its border conflict with Vietnam, China today sent the widow of the late Prime Minister Chou Enlai on a visit to Phnom Penh.

title: A Jerusalem Hotel Lobby Breaks Into Bedlam as the News Arrives
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18There was pandemonium and consternation tonight at the Jerusalem Hilton Hotel, site of the EgyptianIsraeli peace talks, when the news came that President Anwar elSadat had ordered his delegation to return to Cairo.

title: Home Improvement
description: New Products That Make Do ItYourself Jobs Easier A NEW INTERIOR storm window kit that has been introduced by Reynolds Metals Company, Richmond, Va. 27003, differs from most other doityourself storm windowsit has an aluminum frame that is completely indenendent of the window frame. It can be taken off and stored, over the summer, or whenever the storm window Is not needed. The frame members, with either a silver gray or white finish and in either six or eightfoot lengths, are cut to the size with a hacksaw and then joined at the corner with special brackets.

title: Deaths
description: BACKERGerald. The United Federation of Teachers mourns Mc untimely passing of our beloved colleagUe, Gerry Backer, long time UFT representative for district 23, Brooklyn, and member of our Executive Board Gerry, a scrapper in good causes all his life, fought his own battle against a long Illness with great courage and unfailing good cheer, sustained by the wife and family he adored. We share their loss and offer our heartfelt condolences.

title: 75 Years Later, Marconi Feat Is Relived
description: MULLION, England, Jan. I8The Poldhu Hotel's spectacular clifftop lounge crackled with radio messages from five continents today as wideeyed schoolchildren looked at the jumble of electronic gear and listened to the babble of foreign voices.

title: Coliseum Roof Collapses At Hartford Civic Center
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 18Under a heavy blanket of ice and snow, the huge flat roof of the twoyearold Hartford Civic Center's coliseum collapsed at 4:15 this morning, raining havoc on the $70 million convention and shopping complex that was meant to be the centerpiece of the city's resurgence.

title: FRANK JOYCE PEARSON
description: Col. Frank Joyce Peatson, who retired in 1951 as Deputy Chief of Staff, First Army, Governors Island, died last Saturday in Veterans Administration Hospital here after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 360 First Avenue.

title: Inquiry on Schools for Handicapped In Jersey Finds Appalling Abuses
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18The state commission of Investigation opened public hearings today on abuses involving the spending of state money by private schools in the education of handicapped children, with one commissioner saying he found some of the testimony appalling.

description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantIc

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON The last thing visitors see before entering the office of Michael Pertschuk, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, is this ornately framed quotation from Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations:

description: MULLION, England. Jan. 18  The Poldhu Hotel's spectacular clifftop lounge crackled with radio messages from five continents today as wideeyed schoolchildren looked at the jumble of electronic gear and listened to the babble of foreign voices.

title: News Summary
description: The Middle East peace talks broke up abruptly. President Anwar elSadat of Egypt ordered his Foreign Minister to return home at once from political negotiations in Jerusalem and told President Carter that the talks would resume only if Israel changed jts position. The recall raised serious doubts about the future of the peace initiative that Mr. Sadat began barely two months ago by going to Israel. Later, the Cairo radio reported, Mr. Carter called Mr. Sadat and urged him to reconsider his decision. Mr. Sadat reportedly complained that Israel sought land and not peace, but he agreed to allow military talks to resume in Cairo on Saturday in appreciation of Mr. Carter's efforts on behalf of Middle East peace. title: The Message From Cairo
description: Open diplomacy is often risky, television diplomacy riskier still. President Sadat has had his mind on the omnipresent cameras at every step since his dramatic flight to Jerusalem in November. He knew then that to succeed in suddenly extracting the venom from 30 years of bitterly hostile relations he would have to convince skeptical publics in Israel and the United States of his good faith. But the process of public diplomacy he began generated predictable protestations of virtue from the Israeli side. It may not have been inevitable that the initial expressions of personal admiration and good will would degenerate into pedagogic lectures and expressions of pique, but the risk was nevertheless considerable. The issues that divide Israel from the Arabs are too intractable and the demands of Israeli domestic politics are too confining for Mr. Sadat to have received the sudden and equally dramatic countergestures that he evidently expected and that he felt he needed in order justify his own.

title: U.S. Aide Visits Camps in Thailand
description: LAMSING, Thailand, Jan. 18Patricia M. Derian, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, visited the Vietnamese refugee camps here today in preparation for testifying in Washington on an Administration proposal for a longterm program to allow further Indochinese refugees into the United States.

title: Fast Foods Sell School Lunches in LasVegas
description: LAS VEGASIn addition to its casinos and cabarets, its reputed links with organized crime and its neonlighted garishness, Las Vegas is developing a reputation for the fastfood lunches served in its public high schools.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1978

title: Stocks Continue to Rise Sharply; Dow Up 7.28 for 2d Straight Day
description: The stock market contined to advance strongly yesterday, with takeover situations, natural gas issues and a variety of technology stocks leading the way.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Washington & Business
description: Michael Pertschuk's plans for the Federal Trade Commission after a year of transition are of deep concern to both consumers and business; he says that he intends for his commission to send the message that the basic role of business is to serve the consumer. Page D5.

title: Goodman at Carnegie
description: FORTY YEARS and one day after Benny Goodman and his orchestra played the first jazz concert ever held in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Godman returned to the hall on Tuesday evening to mark that precedentshattering event. As he had in 1938, he brought with him a full band and some guests but, aside from Mr. Goodman, the only performers who returned after 40 years were Lionel Hampton, the vibraphonist, and Martha Tilton, the singer.

title: YIELD ON U.S, NOTES AT A TWOYEAR HIGH
description: The Treasury sold $3.25 billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 7.55 percent, the highest rate of return for such securities in more than two years.

title: Family Money
description: THANKS to regulations, that went into effect with the new year or will become effective in the next few months, the millions of Americans who are members of federally chartered credit unions face potentially higher returns on their savings and potentially lower mortgage rates.

title: Aqueduct Card Halted After Jockeys Protest
description: Aqueduct canceled the last six races on its racing program yesterday after jockeys had complained of variations in the texture and consistency of the racing surface in the first three races.

title: STOCK VOTING POWER HELD CONCENTRATED IN A FEW INVESTORS
description: The power to vote stock in the nation's largest corporations is concentrated in fewer than two dozen institutional investors, the majority of them banks, according to a new study by the staff of Senate subcommittee.

title: Pop: Geraldine Fitzgerald
description: GERALDINE FTTZGERALD, who began her cabaret career three and a half years ago at Reno Sweeney, is singing her street songs there again, at midnight only, after her performance in Touch of the Poet at the Helen Hayes Theater. At her opening on Tuesday evening, two of her three musicians were marooned by the snow in Connecticut, but, with only Stanley Wietrzychowski, the pianist, she carried on undaunted, unflappable and totally exhilarating.

title: U.S. Appellate Judge Is Expected To Be Nominated as Head of F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18William H. Webster, a Federal appellate judge in St. Louis, is expected to he nominated tomorrow as the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Carter Administration official said today.

title: Sound
description: FOLLOWING last week's report on innovations in turner design, it may be appropriate to review some quality factors in tuner performance. A tuner Is the part of a sound system that pulls in radio sigmats, and it doesn't matter whether it comes as a separate unit oras in the case of socalled receiversit is combined with the amplifier. Our sole concern here is with FM reception, because under current conditions only FM transmits music in stereo and with sufficiently wide frequency range to qualify as high fidelity. There is some talk about upgrading the technical quality of AM broadcasts, and proposals for methods of transmitting stereo signals on AM have been filed with the Federal Communications Commission, but hopes for improving the often dismal quality of AM are still nebulous.

title: Disks: Crosby in the Sennett Era
description: NO MATTER what collections of Bing Crosby's songs may appear in the wake of his death, this set, which was not intentied as a tribute or memorial (he died iust before it was released), will retain its individuality. It is made up of excerpts from the sound tracks of the six tworeel shorts that Bing made for Mack Sennett in the summer of 1931, plus one song he sang as an unbilled player in Reaching for the Moon, a 1930 feature starring Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and Bebe Daniels. The Sennett films were shot just before Bing began the CBS radio series in the fall of 1931 that made him a radio star and then a movie star.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18. (AP)The American Motors Corporation will switch from Volkswagen to General Motors fourcylinder engines at the start of the 1980 model year, A.M.C. said today. The company said the switch was a lower investment solution in a tie of substantial capital demand. A.M.C. also said the change resulted from the need for a substantial volume of smaller engines.

title: Black College Lauds Iphigene Sulzberger
description: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger was awarded an honorary doctorate of of humanities yesterday by Bishop College of Dallas, the largest private predominantly black college in the Southwest.

title: D. JOHN LYNCH
description: LEESBURG, Va., Jan. 18 (UPI)D. John Lynch, an internationally known equestrian instructor who coached the 1968 American Olympic team, was killed today when his car was hit by a truck. He was 73 years old.

title: A Jigsaw To End All Puzzles
description: IMAGINE THIS: An Oriental potentate with bottomless coffers and a positive passion for puzzles sends one of his underlings on a search for the perfect jigsaw. In country homes in England, in the poshest apartments on Park Avenue, and in those secret societies known only to puzzle people, his emissary hears the same words, and so he travels to a town with a mellifluous name on Long Island, enters a dingy white stucco building whose bottom floor contains bar and an establishment that, according to its sign, makes SIGNS, climbs the stairs to a dark second floor corridor, and there, past a door emblazoned with the sign of the seahorse, finds what he has sought throughout the world.

title: Brazil's Oil Reserves Up
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18 (AP)Brazil's proven oil reserves were 1.11 billion barrels as of Dec. 31, 1977, an increase of 27.1 percent from a year earlier, Petrobras, the state oil monopoly, announced today. Petrobras attributed the increase mainly to a 137 percent increase in off shore reserves.

title: About NewYork
description: God did not call Brother Sebastian to wear Dr. Scholl's sandals.

title: Frederick E. Crockett, a Member Of Mm. Byrd's Polar Expedition
description: BEVERLY FARMS, Mass. Jan. 18 (UN) Frederick E. Crockett, a member of Adm. Richard Byrd's first South Pole expedition, died Tuesday. He was 70 years old.

title: CABINET ACTS QUICKLY
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18  President Anwar elSadat's abrupt recall of the Egyptian delegation was sharply criticized by the Israeli Cabinet late tonight as an extreme move that proved that the Egyptian Government deceived itself that Israel will submit to demands it has never considered feasible.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Criticized by His Talent Unit for Bypassing It
description: The head of one of Mayor Koch's talent search committees sharply criticized the Mayor yesterday for appointing Anthony Ameruso as Transportation Commissioner after the committee had rejected him as unqualified.

title: Remarks by Begin at the Dinner for Participants in Jerusalem Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 (AP)Following are excerpts from the text issued by the Government Press Office of the toast delivered in English by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel at a dinner last night for participants in the IsraelEgypt peace talks in Jerusalem.

title: Legal Aid Society Rehires 5 Dropped For Failing Exam
description: One Chinese and four Hispanic law graduates who were dismissed from New York City's Legal. Aid Society after failing the bar examination were told yesterday they could continue working for Legal Aid while they prepared to take the examination again.

title: An Avowed Homosexual Sues Army; Calls Discharge Unconstitutional
description: DENVER, Jan. 18 (AP)An avowed homosexual has filed suit against the Army, which he says discharged him because of his sexual preference.

title: HENRY H. KESSLER, 81, NEWARK ORTHOPEDIST
description: Dr. Henry H. Kessler, an orthopedic specialist and a pioneer in the development of services and prosthetic equipment for the disabled, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark at the age of 81.

title: Fueled By Fire
description: THERE has apparently been a great deal of confusion in the minds of many people who own houses or apartments equipped with fireplaces, especially those who suffered loss of powerand heatduring the recent storms that buried the Northeast in a shining coat of ice during the past week.

title: SOL GOICHBERG
description: Sol Goichberg, a mandolin player, died in New York Hospital Tuesday of leukemia. He was 69 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N. Y. Mr. Goichberg recorded Vivaldi mandolin concertos with the New York Sinfonietta, and he was music director and arranger for the New York Mandolin Orchestra.

title: DECISION BY SADAT CAUSES CONFUSION
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18The United States and Israel were startled tonight by Egypt's abrupt decision to recall its delegation from the peace talks, just as progress toward agreement on an American compromise plan on the principles for an overall Middle East settlement was being reported.

title: Sun Said to Seek Control of Becton By Buying Shares
description: The Sun Company is quietly buying up shares of Becton, Dickinson & Company, the huge New Jersey healthcare concern, in a takeover deal that may involve as much as $400 million, wellplacect industry sources said yesterday.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Zenith Swiss Unit
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (UPI)The Zenith Corporation said today it would write off its investment in a Swiss watchmaking subsidiary. Zenith Time S.A., and this will result in a charge of about 40 cents a share against fourthquarter 1977 earnings. Zenith acquired the Swiss watch business in 1971. The company said it has been losing money and represents less than 3 percent of Zenith's sales. The company expects the Swiss operation to continue and is negotiating with Swiss investors interested in buying it.

title: Red Wings 4, Rockies 4
description: DENVER, Jan. 18 (UPI)Andre St. Laurent and Dale McCourt scored goals in the third period to help the Detroit Red Wings rally and tie with the Colorado Rockies, 4.4, tonight.

title: People and Business
description: MasseyFerguson Ltd., of Toronto, announced yesterday the appointment of John A. McDougald as chairman, a post that has been vacant. Mr. McDougald, who is 69, continues as chairman of the executive committee. He also is chairman and president of the Argus Corporation, a holding company that owns 3 million shares, or 16 percent, of MasseyFerguson stock.

title: Obituary 10 -- No Title
description: MOOREAdelaide L. Suddenly on January 18, 1978, loving wife of the late William M., devoted mother of William M., Jr., also survived by grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 1 West 190th Street. Funeral Mass Saint Nicholas of Tolentine Church, Saturday 10 A.M. Interment private. Visiting Thursday 79 F.M. and Friday 25 and 79 P.M.

title: JAPAN OFFERS TARIFF CUTS AT WORLD TRADE PARLEY
description: GENEVA, Jan. 18Japan became today the first of the Big Three at the world trade negotiations to make a formal offer of tariff cuts and other concessions in the drive to widen the channels of international commerce.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the business/finance section in some editions of The Times yesterday incorrectly stated the operating earnings per share of Citicorp for the fourth quarter of 1976. The banking concern reported earnings of 88 cents a share for that period.

title: Dubious Delights of Fast Food
description: To an adult who is hardly a fast food fan, Len Fredrick's products in Las Vegas high schools seemed superior to their commercial counterparts.

title: Military in Philippines Reports Heavy Losses by Separatists
description: ZAMBOANGA CITY. the Philippines, Jan. 18 (UPI)Moslem separatist forces have suffered heavy casualties in a major battle with Government troops in the southren Philippines, site of a fiveyear insurrection, military reports said today.

title: Italian Communist Chief Renews Demand for Role in Government
description: ROME, Jan. 18The leader of Italy's Communist Party met with President Giovanni Leone today and forcefully renewed his party's demand for entry into the Government.

title: LEDERBERG IS NAMED ROCKEFELLER U.HEAD
description: Prof. Joshua Lederberg, a cowinner of the Noble Prize in 1958 for work on the organization of genetic material in bacteria, has been named president of Rockefeller University, succeeding Dr. Frederick Seitz, who is retiring.

title: Ohyama Plays at Y
description: THE Young Concert Artists series concert Tuesday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association turned out a bit differently from what had been originally planned. In the short run, the inclement weather cut down on the crowd, although not as much as one might have anticipated. But before the snow and rain fell, the program had already been changed.

title: Islanders Turn Back North Stars, 52
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 18The sinking North Stars and the rising Islander allstars matched orbits for 60 minutes tonight at Metropolitan Center. When the uneven contest ended, four of the five New York players named to the Campbell Conference AllStar, squad had scored 11 points, including four goals, to help send Minnesota to its eighth straight defeat, 52.

title: Two British TV Directors Set Up Shop in U.S.
description: TWO former television directors of the British Broadcasting Corporation, Michael Gill and Adrian Malone, both with impressive credits, have teamed up to form their own production company, MaloneGill Inc, That might be deserving of little notice but for the fact that they have established their partnership in the United States.

title: Alton Carter, President's Uncle, 89
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 18 (AP)Alton Carter, President Carter's uncle and the oldest member of the Carter family, died today at the age of 89.

title: In Texas, a Director Shouts Nyet, Nyet!
description: Houston GALINA VOLCHYEK is standing in the darkened 21st row, betiding, arms flailing, and two fingers scissoring a halfsmoked ApolloSoyuz brand filter cigarette made by the Philip Morris Yava factory in Moscow.

title: The Big Space: How to Live Up to It
description: MAYOR Koch isn't the only one who gets nervous rattling around in a lot of new space. Karen Fisher does, too. She got used to it, after two years. We'll just have to see about the Mayor. Maybe somebody will show him how to warm up Gracie Mansiongaudy up the walls with some bright colors. texturize it a bit, bring in some trees, zone it verticallyso he won't have to schlep back to the Village every night to be cozy.

title: A Little Bach by Fox
description: AT THE END of his recital in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum on Tuesday night, Virgil Fox asked the audience to tell the museum directors that he had an electronic organ with 600 speakers and that he would like to bring it to the Great Hallthe vast entrance hall  and play fullblooded Bach on it there.

title: Survivor of Ancient Sea Is Joining Endangered List
description: SOCORRO, N. M.In a small, tearshaped pond just to the lee of the Socorro Mountains lives a colony of water creatures who are about to become the first species of crustaceans put on the Federal Government's list of endangered species.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders.
description: The New York and the American stock. exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Canadians Hostile at Unity Hearings
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 18The ballroom of a hotel here resounded last night to cheers, boos and epithets, and when the evening was over one federal commissioner had been reduced to tears and the others were grimfaced.

title: Backgammon:
description: The 1978 World Championship of Backgammon, sponsored by Philip Morris International, was held at Paradise Island in Nassau, Jan. 1015. This annual backgammon event attracted the world's best active players, including a large and strong European contingent. Under the supervision of Lewis Deyong, tournament director, more than 400 players competed for better than $200,000 in prizes.

title: APPEALS COURT BARS SCHOOLS HIRING PLAN
description: The chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, has temporarily barred the New York City Board of Education from issuing certificates of competency to prospective teachers and supervisors pending a challenge to the legality of this littleknown method of hiring publicschool personnel.

title: Precious Metal Futures Weaken As Traders Await Carter Speech
description: Precious metals futures moved lowe yesterday as many traders took to the sidelines to await the President's State of the Union Message, allowing a little local trade and commission house selling depress prices.

title: LONGER SERVICE IS URGED FOR MILITARY RETIREMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Gen. George S. Brown, the nation's top military officer, conceded today that the ostly and controversial military retirement system would have to be changed to require longer service than 20 years.

title: Letters
description: The Hers article [Dec. 29] was delightful! I agree heartily. Why should anyone, male or female, look dull and uptight for eight hours daily? If men look like men while working, what's wrong with women looking like women while working? Those books are an insult to intelligence. Keep hammering

title: Music: Bostonians Give Premiere of Oratorio
description: MICHAEL TIPPETT wrote A Child of Our Time, his oratorio in behalf of the underdogs of this world, in 1939 at the outbreak of World War II in Europe. It is conceived on a grand scale, as befits its epic subject, and in its New York premiere last night at Carnegie Hall, the Boston Symphony under the direction of Colin Davis struggled mightily to turn conception into breathing reality. That they did not entirely succeed did no dishonor to anyone, including the 72yearold composer, whose humane intentions could always be discerned even when the music itself lapsed into commonplaces.

title: Transcript of Egyptian Statement on Halt in Talks
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18 (AP)Following, in official translation from the Arabic, is a transcript of the statement broadcast today over Cairo radio and television by Egypt's Information Minister, Abdel Moneim elSawi:

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1978

title: 15 Leading American Jews Plan a Dialogue in Egypt on Religion
description: Fifteen leading American Rabbis and Jewish laymen are due to travel to Cairo next week at the invitation of the Egyptian Government to initiate a historic Phase of interfaith relations.

title: Boyle Has Physical Examination, Forcing Delay in Jury Selection
description: MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 18 (UPI)W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers who is on trial for the second time on charges of plotting the murder of his union rival, was taken from the courtroom today for a physical examination, forcing a delay in selecting a jury.

title: Ullman Opposes Plans to Tighten Business ExpenseAccount Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Representative Al Ullman, the chairman of the taxwriting Ways and Means Committee, said today that Congress would not accept President Carter's expected proposal to tighten up on business expense accounts because to do so would cause a loss of jobs in the restaurant and hotel industries.

title: U.S. TO KEEP QUOTAS FOR STEEL IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)President Carter has decided to maintain existing quotas on imports of socalled specialty steel products, following an eightmonth study, the White House announced today.

title: Profiting From Crisis
description: A few years ago, I attended a meeting at the goldandglass offices of the Agnelli Foundation in Turin (it is the Italian equivalent of the Ford Foundation) to discuss crises of Modern capitalism. As the various intellectuals Giovanni Agnelli had convened rambled on about various tears in the social fabric, Mr. Agnelli assumed a baleful expression. Finally, he turned to a neighboring participant and said (I translate roughly from his courteous Italian): Feh! You are all innocents. There's good money to be made in a crisis.

title: F.T.C. Sets Minority Hiring Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18The Federal Trade Commission disclosed today that it had reserved 17 percent of its job openings for minorities in a plan that overhauls the agency's appointment practices for job classifications paying $15,000 or more a year.

title: Mrs. Mandela's Trial Recessed
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Jan. 18 (Reuters)The trial of Winnie Mandela, a black nationalist leader and wife of Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned black leader, on charges of breaking a Government banhing order was adjourned here today until Feb. 9, when the magistrate is scheduled to deliver his verdict.

title: FILES SHOW F.B.I. RIFT WITH WARREN PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)Relations between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Warren Commission were so bad that the bureau spied on the panel's investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy and the panel suspected the F.B.I. of concealing old links with Lee Harvey Oswald, newly released files disclosed today.

title: World News Briefs
description: STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 18 (Reuters)The European Court of Human Rights cleared Britain today of charges that its security forces in Northern Ireland had tortured suspected members of the Irish Republican Army. But the tribunal voted, 16 to 1, that there was evidence the British security forces used inhuman and degrading methods of interrogation from August to October 1971.

title: Questionable Protection
description: CHICAGO  For every automobile America's free economy sells in Japan, that nation's governmentmonopoly economyJapan, Inc.  sells one hundred automobiles in the United States.

title: Defense Chief Creates New Civilian Post in Move to Bolster Policy Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Defense Stcretary Harold Brown, seeking to strengthen the Pentagon's policy role within the Administration, is reorganizing his top civilian command amid some internal friction.

title: U.S. Expresses Concern to Chile At Exiling of Political Opponents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  The United States has expressed deep concern to the Government of Chile because of the exiling of 12 leaders of the opposition Christian Democratic Party, the State Deoartment said yesterday.

title: BankAmerica's Operating Profit Up
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that operating earnings rose 16.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1977 and 17.6 percent for the full year.

title: Hers
description: DAN WAKEFIELD, the novelist who developed the idea for a new television series called James at 15, resigned from the show last week because the network would not tolerate a euphemistic reference to birth control in an episode depicting the young hero's loss his virginity. Mr. Wakefield wanted the boy to ask the girl if she was responsible before intercourse. This formulation is really a euphemism for two much more common euphemisms that have echoed in the ears of girls for generations: Is it safe? and Are you prepared?

title: 12,000 on L.I. Still Without Heat or Power
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 18Long Islanders awoke this morning to find that warming temperatures and a heavy rain had washed away most of the thick layer of ice that last weekend crippled electric service to nearly onethird of the Island's three million residents. By late today, all but 12,000 residents had heat and lights.

title: Crosby Golf Carries On as Usual
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 18One of the oldest tournaments on the pro tour starts here tomorrow when 336 golfers tee off on three courses in the n37th Bing Crosby National ProAm. This year, however, the event will be held without the founder's presence for the first time.

title: Market Place
description: The mysterious halt in trading in the shares of Becton, Dickinson & Company has raised questions as to whether the interests of individual shareholders are being served.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have purchased a summer place that has a small attic that we would like to turn into a sleeping loft. We were planning to insulate the ceiling to keep It cooler in the summer, and then put up paneling. However, we have been told that if an attic is not heated, it is not a good idea to insulate the ceiling. Is this true, and if so, can we still put up paneling and then use on air. conditioner up there?Mrs. G. T., New York City.

title: Wooing Africa Toward Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 18The enthusiastic reption given President Valery Giscard taing m the Ivory Coast last week erscores the remarkable degree of tical and economic influence France exercises over many of its former African colonies. But despite the political success of the Ivory Coast trip and the fat contracts President Giscard d'Estaing brought back for French industry, his visit also exposed limitations of the more agressive policy France is pursuing toward Africa and of the country's hopes of ??aintaining a privileged position in its onetime possessions there.

title: Carter Calls for Help to New York by Local Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  President tarter has written the Senate Barking ommittee that local parties in New ark had significant responsibilities in my plan to meet the city's fmancing eeds to avoid bankruatcy.

title: Vida Blue's Forgotten Factor
description: In all the hearings that Bowie Kuhn has held on the Vida Blue sales, the commissioner always speaks of the best interests of baseball. He never speaks of the best interests of Vida Blue, the victim of the best interests baseball. But while the commissioner deliberates over the recent trade of the 28yearold lefthanded pitcher to the Cincinnati Reds by Charles Q. Finley for $1.75 million and a first baseman named Dave Revering, Vida Blue is equally concerned with the commissinner's annulment of his 1976 sale to the New York Yankees for $1.5 million. The night of that deal, Vida Blue signed a threeyear contract with the A's for a total of $515,000 and a promise from Charles 0. Finley that he would not be dealt Within an hour. Charles 0. Finley sold Vida Blue to the Yankees in a transaction apparently dependent on the signed contract. Because of that alleged fraud by the A's owner, Vida Blue has filed litigation in a California state court that is the forgotten factor of the commissioner's current hearings. If he wins his court case, Vida Blue would be a free agent and his sale to the Reds would be academic. And if he wins, the best interests Vida Blue would finally have been served.

title: Archdiocese Purchasing Complex With Medical School and Hospital
description: The Archdiocese of New York has agreed to purchase New York Medical CollegeFlower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals on Manhattan's Upper East Side, thus giving Roman Catholics their first medical school in the New York City region.

title: N.Carolina Wins No.14; 24 for Ford
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 18 (UPI)North Carolina's Phil Ford scored 24 points, 8 in the final four minutes, and the Tar Heels defeated North Carolina State, 6964, tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: U.S. Agencies Resist Environmental Limits Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The State Department is leading an embryonic movement by several Federal agencies that oppose the recommended application of the National Environmental Policy Act to all international activities of the Government.

title: Mrs. Moser Is Beaten
description: BADGASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 18Evi Mittermaier of West Germany won the Silver Jug downhill race today, with Annemarie ProellMoser, the favored Austrian star, finishing second.

title: Playing Catch22 With Mr. Kuhn
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has muffed another chance to improve CubanAmerican relations. Last year President Fidel Castro lobbed an easy one to him by inviting the New York Yankees to visit Cuba. it seemed a natural: the historic titans of baseball visiting the baseballmad island at a time when CubanAmerican relations were thawing. Senator McGovern reported that Castro was eager to welcome the Yankees, the Carter Administration liked the idea, and the Yankee management was all for it. But not Mr. Kuhn. He concluded that the trip would give the Yankees an unfair advantage over other teams in recruiting Cuban playersif and when such players were allowed to play for pay in this country. So Mr. Kuhn vetoed the Yankee trip and ruled that only an allstar team could play in Cuba. Now he has even broken off negotiations on a proposed allstar game to be held in Cuba in March, His reason: the Cubans are unwilling to give assurances that they will allow their star players to be recruited by our profes sional teams. Catch22: the Yankees can't go because they might recruit too many Cubans; an allstar team can't go because no Cubans can be recruited.

title: Home Above the Tracks
description: WHEN Murray Packer leaves his apartment in the morning, he often finds an unassuming commuter leaning against his front door, reading a newspaper while waiting for a train to Grand Central Terminal, a 45minute ride away.

title: A Report on Ski Reports: Old Adjectives to Prevail
description: WEST DOVER, Vt., Jan. 18There's no need for manmade snow in the Northeast for the time being.

title: C.F.T.C. Never Saw Books of Lloyd, Carr
description: Although companies selling the highly speculative options on commodities traded in London came under Federal regulation 13 months ago, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission was unable even to look at the books of Lloyd, Carr & Company, a commission spokesman said yesterday.

title: 240,000 Ford and Mercury Cars Face Recall on Emission Control
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Nearly a quartermillion 1975 Ford and Mercury automobiles will be recalled to correct a faulty emission control system, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: California Youth Puts Neediest Ahead of Himself
description: A California high school student who works parttime in a local newspaper office had been saving to buy a telescope, but decided instead to send another contribution to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: CODD IS TURNED DOWN ON PENSION REQUEST
description: The trustees of the Police Pension Board ysterday rejected an application by former Commissioner Michael 3, Codd for a $46,600 a year taxfree serviceconnected disability pension.

title: Connors Receives Another No. 1 Vote
description: DALLAS, Jan. 18 (AP)Bob Briner, executive director of the Association of Tennis Professionals, said today that Jimmy Connors should be rated the No. 1 player in the world. He criticized the rating system proposed by the International Tennis Federation.

title: Koch Criticized by His Talent Unit On Choice of Transportation Chief
description: The head of one of Mayor Koch's talent search committees sharply criticized the Mayor yesterday for appointing Anthony R. Ameruso as Transportation Commissioner after the committee had rejected him as unqualified.

title: Deaths
description: DOWNEYEdna H. (nee Hughes) Jan 17. 1978. Beloved wife of William J., loving sister of May H. Stuart, Loretta H. Hughes and the late Virginia H. Walsh. Reposing 25 & 79 PM Wafers Funeral Home, 2597 Grand Concourse near 192 St. Mass of Christian Burial. St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church, Friday 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Listening to the World
description: Back in the days of the Trylon and Perisphere, a really suberb console radio came with everal shortwave bands. To impress the novice, the dials were marked London, Berlin and Moscow'with not too much fiddling the voice of Benito Mussolini, Josephine Baker or Maurice Chevalier could be brought into an American living room.

title: Gunfire Reported in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Lebanese Christian militia units and Pa'estinian guerrillas exchanged artillery fire in southern Lebanon during the night. travelers from the area said today. The intermittent firing, which stopped at dawn caused no casualties.

title: Horowitz Fans Irked
description: CARNEGIE HALL'S management and some frustrated fans of Vladimir Horowitz were at odds yesterday in appraising the handling of Tuesday's sale of a total of 4,500 tickets to two March recitals by the pianist. The figure had been set by management as the limit to be sold.

title: INSURANCE OFFICIALS BACK RATES DETERMINED BY SEX
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)Differences in insurance rates on the basis of sex were defended by industry representatives today in testimony before a Senate subcommittee.

title: Fliers Safe After Navy Jet Crash
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 18 [AP]A Navy jet attempting to land at a nearby base crashed into San Francisco Bay near the Bay Bridge this morning, but the two Navy fliers on board parachuted to safety, the Coast Guard reported. The two unidentified fliers were plucked from the bay waters by a Coast Guard cutter 10 minutes after the crash,a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: CAIRO TALKS STILL ON
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18President Anwar elSadat today ordered his Foreign Minister to return home immediately from Israel, where talks on political aspects of a peace settlement started yesterday, and he informed President Carter that the talks would resume once Israel changed its position.

title: Advertising
description: Robert S. Niedelman, president of Waterman, Getz, Niedelman, is smiler. He smiles like a guy who is no longer in hock to the orthodontist or is very happy in his workprobably the latter.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP)At least 20 persons were injured today when one of Boston's newest underground trolley cars skidded into the rear of a second car stopped at downtown Arlington Street Station in the system's first crash.

title: Shooting Heard in Madrid
description: MADRID, Jan. 18 (Reuters)Gunshots were heard early today near the office and residence of the Spanish Prime Minister, Adolfo Suarez. His bodyguard was placed on an alert, but an official spokesman said no bullets had hit the building.

title: Some Pipelines Found to Carry Slurry Cheaply
description: A Congressional research agency has concluded that on some routes, specifically from Wyoming to Texas and from Tennessee to Florida, delivery of groundup coal through slurry pipelines could he cheaper than by railroad.

title: Koch Suspends 2 Antipoverty Pacts
description: A new city policy barring Federal job funds for antipoverty programs whose board members have been convicted of jobrelated crimes was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Republic Steel. Reverses Decline As 4th Quarter Net Climbs 63%
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer and the first in the industry to issue its 1977 financial results, had a sharp reversal in the fourth quarter with earnings up 63 percent following three poor quarters. For the full year, the Clevelandbased company's profit was down 37.9 percent, according to yesterday's report.

title: Notes on People
description: In a short court appearance in Chicago yesterday, Mark Rudd, a former leader of the radical Weathermen, pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the 1969 Days of Rage demonstrations. lie was fined $2,000 and placed on two years probation. Mr. Rudd, 30 years old, was a leader of the Columbia University student uprisings in the late 1960's. After being at large for seven years, he surrendered to the New York authorities last September and charges against him. in New York were dropped. In Chicago yesterday he pleaded guilty to two counts of aggravated battery filed during the four days of demonstrations in October 1969, in the city's Loop and Near North Side areas. He will be allowed to serve his probation in New York and pay his fine later.

title: The Future Of Dollars
description: LONDONThe dollar is still extremely vulnerable and the foreignexchange market continues to be nervous and highly volatile.

title: Urban League's Report: Black Poverty Undefeated
description: A young white man went, the other day, to visit a black man who was supposed to know something about race in America. The white man was sent by an organization that doubted that institutional racism was a major factor in American life any longer. The black man became enraged at the organization's premise and delivered himself of some strong opinions. Then, as he was leading the visitor out, he swept his hand toward a vast sea of desks in his workplace, all of them occupied by white people.

title: Mental Patient Steals Ambulance And Injures Brooklyn Pedestrian
description: A 28yearold mental patient allegedly escaped from St. Vincent Hospital in Greenwich Village yesterday morning, jumped into an ambulance and took a terrified blind woman on a wild noontime ride to Brooklyn that ended only after the vshicle reportedly swerved onto the sidewalk at Flatbush Avenue and Cortelyou Road and gravely injured a 60yearold woman.

title: What Energy Crisis?

Neuman thinks about energy policy, but we do know that close to half those recently polled by The New York Times and CBS News believe that the energy crisis is a figment of Jimmy Carter's Imagination. Such is the state of public Indifference that members of Congress on vacation couldn't find anyone back home who much cared whether or not an energy bill passed this year.

title: Amendment in New York Is Proposed to Establish Permanent Primary Day
description: ALBANY, Jan, 19In a move to end the perennial legislative parlor game over when New York voters should go to the polls for primary elections in major contests in the state, the Democratic leaders of the Senate and the Assembly today announced their support for a constitutional amendment that would establish a permanent June primary for all elections

Lewinter of Fair Lawn is on a teaching assignment in Rome, but while back briefly over the holidays, he found time to cnotinue a yearsold practive with a contribution to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Webster. the Federal appellate judge in St. Louis who was nominated today to become the next Director of the Federal Eureau of Investication, quickly promised to carry out his duties as the nation's top law enforcement official within the framework of the Constitution.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 19Egypt's decision to suspend political discussions with Israel in Jerusalem was derided as a mere maneuver today by Syrians, Iraqis and other Arabs who oppose the peace initiatives of President Anwar elSadat.

title: Reception for a Fresh Immortal
description: When Eddie Mathews checked into the Waldorf Towers, there was a bit of flap at the desk because his brotherinlaw had made the reservation in his own name, August Busch. No, Mathews kept explaining, he wasn't August Busch, he was the brotherinlaw and the reservation was meant for him. They went over the ground a few times before he was allowed to register and go upstairs, where he was joined by his wife, Liz, up from her farm in Virginia. They had just got to sleep when the phone rang. The room's previous occupant, a voice said, had left behind a valuable package of diamonds and a security officer was coming up to search for it. It's midnight, Mathews said, but soon three men in plainclothes showed up. They went through the motions of searching dresser drawers, and closts without convincing Ed or Liz that they were looking for diamonds. They figured we were in under false names, Eddie said yesterday, to rob the joint, I guess.

title: Mich. State 60, Purdue 51
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 19 (AP) Michigan State slowed the tempo of play in the second half tonight against Purdue, and the strategy helped the Spartans gain a 6051 victory in a Big Ten game.

title: About Real Estate Nassau Construction Is Catering to Demand
description: ROSLYN, L.I.  When the Nassau County Boy Scouts put 27 acres of land on the market a couple of years ago they had a number of offers from builders, The successful bidder was Eli Lieberman.

description: Mayors of several American cities expressed disappoin ment and even dismay last night that President Cartor had not paid more attention to uban problem in his State of the Union Address.

Gibson knocked down a cinder block wall sealing the entrance to a burnedout structure at No. 2 Stratford Place and announced the start of a $3 million rehabilitation housing project for lowand middleincome people.

title: Killian to Run Agairkst Gov. Grasso; Says She Avoids Making Decisions
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 19Connecticut's Lieutenant Governor, Robert K. Killian, formally declared today that he was in the race to unseat his boss, Ella T. Grasso, as Governor, and he criticized her for what he said were long, intermittent lapses in leadership.

title: Hartford CaveIn Still a Mystery
description: Why did the 1,400 tons of steel that spanned the roof of the Hartford Civic Center's coliseum suddenly collapse on Wednesday, just hours after 5,000 people had been in the building?

title: From Press Card to Gold Police Shield
description: On her desk were three bouquets of flowers from wellwishers. In her purse were her shiny new gold shield and her key to the executive elevator. And in her lefthand drawer was her green plastic water pistol, which she smilingly picked up and waved, but did not fill with water.

title: Stage: Old Man Joseph
description: IN A SEASON apparently emphasiains myths and legends, the Chelsea Theoter Center has now turned to the New Testament Apocrypha in a play by Romulus Linnev entitled Old Man Joseph and His Family. As Mr. Linney indicates in a program note, his sources are gospels and folk stories about familiar biblical figures.

title: At Rainbow Grill, Magic's in the Air
description: The magician Milbourne Christopher had just made the audience at the Rainbow Grill ogle and ooh as he burned a dollar with an unlighted match, turned a boiled egg into a shot of Scotch, passed a handkerchief through a solid broom handle and told a woman in the audience that the city she was thinking of was Budapest and the fellow on her mind was Bernie.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. The Pacific Telephone Company yesterday notified the California Public Utilities Commission that it will ask for a rate increase of $471 million. L. Reed Waters vice president for regulatory matters, said the company has been unable to keep pace with inflation.

title: John D. Rockefeller 3d Wills $10 Million in American Art to San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19John D. Rockefeller 3d announced here today that on his death the American art that he and Mrs. Rockefeller had collected would pass to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

title: Is There Opera Beyond the Met? You Bet!
description: IF YOU FIND the Metropolitan Opera sold out or the ticket prices too rich for your wallet, don't despair, you can still hear some Wagner or Puccini, Mozart or Verdi on weekends. Just look around town and in the suburbs. This weekend six productions are being offered where opera or lightopera buffs might derive nourishment, entertainment or both.

description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Jan. 19 (AP) Jim Richards, head basketball coach at Western Kentucky for the last seven years, said today that he had asket the university to relieve him of coaching at the end of the season. Richards asket for assignment to another position. His team's wonlost record is 78 this season, and it is tied for first place in the Ohio Valley Conference at 31. Richards's career mark with Western Kentucky is 9378.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Economic growth, mainly reflecting a reluctance of businessmen to restock their warehouses, tapered off to an annual rate of 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter, the slowest pace of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: Bruce C. Ratner, a 32yearold law professor who has specialized in consumer rights, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Koch as Consumer Affairs Commissioner.

description: SAN JUAN. P.R., Jan. 19 (UPI)Bombs knocked out electrical service to large sections of San Juan today, including the Isla Verde international airport, in a new wave of sabotage against the stateowned light and power company.

title: Argentine and Chilean Leaders Meet Over Territorial Dispute
description: BUENOS AIRES. Jan. 19President Jorge Rafael Videla conferred privately for five hours today with President Augusto Pinochet of Chile in an effort to solve a dangerous conflict over maritime sovereignty at the southern tip of South America.

title: Egypt Waits for New U.S. Moves; Vance Is Due to Visit Sadat Today
description: CAIRO, Jan. 19Egypt waited today to see what role the United States would play in trying to mend the ruptured peace negotiations with Israel after the Egyptian delegation's departure last night that left the Jerusalem political talks in limbo. Several Egyptian officials hoped privately that the Americans would become more active as a broker in the critical new phase. While conceding that they were surprised by President Anwar elSadat's decision to recall Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kamel, the officials defended the move as necessary to challenge what they called Israeli intransigence at the talks.

title: Books: Who Built What, but Not Too Recently
description: THE JACKET COVER of Who's Who in Architecture has a handsome color photograph of the John Hancock Tower in Boston, the shimmering glass tower by Henry I. Cobb of I.M. Pei & Partners that has been so much in the news lately. The picture cheats a bit, because it suggests to the reader that this is a book very much concerned with the latest things, but the fact is that this biographical guide to architects sputters and almost dies somewhere in the early 1950's.

title: U.N. Group Asks Special Session Of Assembly on SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19  The United Nations Council for Namibia has agreed to call for a special General Assembly session in April to push for independence for SouthWest Africa, which is known here as Namibia.

title: KOCH NAMES LAWYER AS CONSUMER CHIEF
description: Bruce C. Ratner. a 32yearold law professor who has specialized in consumer rights, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Koch as Consumer Affairs Commissioner.

title: Art People
description: ONE of the more idiosyncratic people on the European art scene is Tom Phillips, who is known to audiences all over that continent as painter, printmaker, composer and fabricator of a most curious series of books.

title: Telpak Rates Are Raised by F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission today ordered phone line rate increases ranging from 33 to 97 percent to go into effect for the major news wire services next Monday.

title: Rail TonMileage Gains 0.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Associa tion of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 13.4 billion tonmiles. 0.5 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadoings in the same period totaled 364,290 cars, 5.2 percent below last year.

title: Blast Near U.S. Bank in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan, 19 (Reuters)Bombs exploded early today near the Americanowned owned Discount Bank in central Paris and in a suburb, wrecking a van and shattering windows. At a fire in a Paris school at the same time, the police said, they found pamphlets swearing revenge for the death of the urban guerrilla leader Andreas Baader in a West German prison last year.

title: Auctions
description: NEW YORK, long overshadowed by London as the place to buy old masters at auction, emerged as a major center for such paintings last week. Two highly successful sales, at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, last Friday, and Christic, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue and 59th Street, the day before, attracted the largest number of American and European professional buyers and collectors seen anywhere at such sales in decades.

title: Ballet: Parisian in America
description: NEW YORK CITY Ballet's welcome mat is extended so infrequently for visiting guest stars that it is in nearmint condition. Ghislaine Thesmar of the Paris Opera Ballet, however, has been invited to plant her pretty foot upon it twice in two years, which is a record, and is establishing something of a personal repertory with the company. One of her most successful pieces has been Jerome Robbins's In G Major, in which she was partnered Wednesday evening by Peter Martins at State Theater.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 20, 1978

title: 96% of Taxpayers Promised Cuts; Rise in Jobs for Youth Planned

description: NOT all books are Invented between sips of Perrier at posh restaurants frequented by the publishing biggies. description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 19President Carter has made a quietly eloquent philosophical State of the Union Address. It is marked by an emphasis, not always central last year, on domestic rather than foreign affairs, but it was not the kind of speech that is likely to move this Congress in its present mood.

title: CARTER SAYS ENERGY, ECONOMY AND PANAMA ARE 1978'S PRIORITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Calling for a new partnership between those who lead and those who elect, President Carter tonight listed his Administration's priorities for 1978 as a strong energy bill, a coordinated economic program and Senate approval of the Panama Canal treaties.

description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 19 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today summoned United States Attorney David W. Marston of Philadelphia to Washington to discuss the Carter Administration's plans to dismiss him.

title: Mexico, Upset at U.S., Awaits Mondale's Visit
