title: AUBREY (DIT) CLAPPER; PLAYED 20 YEARS IN N.H.L.
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Jan. 20 (AP) Aubrey (Dit) Clapper, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame who played 20 seasons in the National Hockey League with the Boston Bruins, died today. He was 70. He had been in ill health and confined to a wheelchair for several years after suffering a stroke.

title: 18 INCHES COVER L.I.
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan, 20Long Island, which just yesterday fully recovered from an ice storm that knocked out power to perhaps a million residents, was staggered again today by a storm that dropped 18 inches of snow over much of the Island. Some areas measured wind gusts of 60 miles an hour.

title: Guardsmen Are Called
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 20  A bitter storm with snow accumulations in southwestern Connecticut approaching the record of 16 inches set on Feb. 9, 1969, virtually paralyzed the state today.

title: Deaths
description: PERKINSJames M., of East Hampton, L.I age 75, died suddenly January 19. in Sodthampton Hospital Graduated Williams College 1924 became artist reprcsentative in field of advertising. Nev York City. He and late wife Catherine operated antique gallery in Amaganseft. Funel at arrangements private.

title: U.S. Scraps a Plan To Relax Standards On Highway Work
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Federal Highway Administration, in response to safety advocates, has withdrawn a proposal for lower roadbuilding standards that were to have been part of a program to reclaim old roadways.

title: Soccer Matchups Drawn
description: ZURICH, Jan. 20 (UPI)Liverpool, the defender, will meet Benfica of Lisbon, twice the winner, and Ajax Amsterdam will clash with Juventus of Italy in the quarterfinals of the European Champions' Soccer Cup, according to the draw made today. The matches will be played March 1 and 15.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: U.S. Moves to End Fraud in the System Of Grading Meats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)The Department of Agriculture moved today to eliminate fraud in the Federal meat rating system and to provide consumers with more accurate information about the meat they buy.

title: A Fall in the Snow
description: How bizarre to see her kneeling there in the street. An old, frail woman fallen in the mounting snow at Broadway and 86th, where the Hudson River wind adds a sting to winter. She struggles for her dignity and her footing and then gives up. Too proud to cry for help, she kneels there, winter's sudden cripple, like the city around her.

title: HardHit Schools Turn to Marketers
description: In 1975 Centenary College in Hacketts. town, N.J., faced a declining enrollment and a mounting deficit. Today its admissions of new students have soared 83 percent, and the school is in the black. The reason for the turnaround? A marketing consultant.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: At the rather late age of 54, Jay Anson, a mildmannered New York documentary film writer, decided to write his first book: The unlikely subject: the true story of a haunted house on Long Island, Although he suffered a severe heart attack midway through the writing, Mr. Anson persevered, and is now on his way to becoming a rich man.

title: Burden Seeks to Void Ballot Crucial to Mrs. Abzug
description: Carter Burden said yesterday that he would press in court tomorrow a lawsuit aimed at invalidating a crucial batlot cast in last Sunday's Democratic nominating convention for the 18th Congressional District seat on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Adventures in the New World
description: IN the New World of the Americas, the men (and the scant number of women) who became naturalists or archeologists frequently kept theirchances for immortal reputations firmly in mind. When Linnaeus, who dominated 18thcentury botany, began name plants after his colleagues, one American honored exclaimed that he now belonged to a species of eternity. His graceful phrase gave Joseph Kastner the title for his history of what he calls the Romantic Era = roughly 1750 to 1850 of North American natural history. Romantic the period certainly was: naturalists had their hands full locating and classifying what one described as a thousand different kinds of birds and beasts of the forests which have never been known neither in shape nor name neither among the Latins nor Greeks nor any other nations of the world.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTONThe mood here last week was upbeat, both in the latest economic data and in the series of annual messages from the White House to the American peoplequite in contrast to recent sentiments in the stock market, the foreignexchange markets and the publicopinion polls.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPDThe General Accounting Office called today for strengthening the role of the Environmental Protectcion Ageny in guarding the public against radiation hazards.

description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP)Taisez Vous led nearly all the way in winning the $52,700 El Encino Stakes by 3I/2 lengths before a crowd of 35,770 at Santa Anita today.

title: Girl Scouts Are Tracking New Course
description: SLEEPING out in a freezing drizzle in January? It seems that some things haven't changed since the founding of the Girl Scouts 66 years ago. There were the four tents, splashes bright green and orange among the browns of the winter woods in Mountain Lakes Park in North Salem.

title: Caputo Reports On Inquiry of Korean; Caputo Reports On Inquiry
description: WHITE PLAINS FOR 13 hours over two days earlier this month, Representative Bruce F. Caputo sat with others in the starkly furnished office of the municipal prosecutor in Seoul, listening for discrepancies in the testimony of Tong Sun Park, the South Korean businessman accused of seeking to bribe American Congressmen.

description: New Yorkers awoke to a chipchop, clinkclunk syncopated symphony of metal meeting asphalt yesterday as New York City and its citizens began digging through hardpacked snow and layers of ice toward terra firma.

description: NASCAR has reactivated its Grand American Division, with races open to 1968 to 1978 steelbodied models of Americanmade passenger car productin sedans and Americanmade compact sedans with an original wheelbase of no less than 107 inches.

title: CARTER RETURNS TO PLAINS FOR HIS UNCLE'S FUNERAL
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 21President Carter returned home to Plains briefly this morning to join his family and former neighbors at a simple funeral for Alton Carter, his 89-year-old uncle who originally brought the Carters to Plains in 1904.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: More than two years have passed since the Securities and Exchange Commission invited registered American corporations to disclose voluntarily any questionable foreign payments or practices. Hundreds of companies carried out investigations, aided by external auditors and special legal counsel, and as of Dec. 1, 1977, some 370 companies had reported having made a total of $745 million of such payments.

title: Poll Shows Most in California In Favor of Farm Land Over Homes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 (AP)In sharp reversal of the public mood that Set off this state's housing boom of the 1950's and 60's, Californians today overwhelmingly favor stricter control of urban sprawl, according to to Mervin D. Field a poll taker.

title: Once In a While, Greenery Has Surprises
description: possibly the most exciting aspect of growing house plants is unexpected flowers. They usually come as quite a surprise. In fact, novice gardeners do not realize that, given the right circumstances, most indoor foliage plants will bloom. Picture the wife running to the door to greet her husband, Darling, guess what? Our spider plant is going to have a baby. The couple hurry together to the glassed porch, and sure enough, the two-year-old hanging plant has a tiny white flower on a previously unnoticed runner. In a matter of days, the flowering stem develops into a true spider baby.

title: Mental Health: A Doctor's View
description: HE timely commentary (Dec. 4) by Joan R. Berns brings to public attention an issue that is in the forefront of the controversy over criteria for the confinement of the mentally ill for evaluation and treatment. That is, how can we understand and resolve the philosophical differences between those who serve society as protectors of civil liberties and those who serve that same society as therapeutic facilitators?

title: Indonesian Troops Raid Student Rally

title: 'Open-Housing' In Clinton Township
description: FOR as long as it has been a part of New Jersey, Hunterdon County regarded itself as a rural enclave in the western part of the state, a long way from the suburban counties closer to Newark and New York City. But a decision handed down earlier this month in Hunterdon County Court may alter that perception and the reality that created it.

title: Gail Chem Betrothed to Roger Thompson
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Chern of Lancaster. Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Sandra Chern, to Roger Sherman Thompson, son of Patricia .I. Thompson of New York and Wayne Thompson of San Diego.

description: Charles Dippolito stood in the middle of Broadway and 168th Street beneath the noonday sun yesterday and directed plows and dump trucks in snowremoval operations.

title: Princeton 91, Hofstra 67
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21Frank Sowinski scored a careerhigh 27 points and Princeton defeated Hofstra, 9167, tonight. Sowinski, scoring mostly on outside jump shots, hid 17 points in: the first half, and helped. the Tigers to a 4326 lead.

title: It's Carter's Budget, but Congress May Impose Its Own Ideas
description: WASHINGTON - Tomorrow's release of President Car ter's first real budget, after weeks of debates, appeals and ritualistic leaks, will be seized on as the occasion to comment .on his Presidency. It will be measured against his many promises and goals and will tell much about how an Administration of militant outsiders has learned to cope with, submit to or subdue the inertia and momentum of Washington.

title: European Drug Companies on a U. S. Buying Spree
description: If the United States sneezes, said. Louis von Planta, chairman of CibaGeigy Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, we catch cold.

title: Coaches Must First Be Teachers
description: I read Dave Nelson's article (A Coach Finds More Agony Than Ecstasy, Jan. 1) and was dismayed to see how a coach in a chameleon approach, could base his relationships with his players, to quote Nelson, on the bottom linewinning or losing.

title: IceDamaged Trees: Wait for a Thaw
description: THOUSANDS of homeowners who looked out of their windows last week and saw trees weighed down with ice touching the ground, seemingly in imminent danger of splitting, were probably ready to rush out with smudge pots, braces or hotwater sprays in an attempt to solve the problem. Those who did were mak- ing a mistake, according to William R. Oberholtzer, senior agent for the Bergen County Extension Service.

title: Special Schools For Gifted Children
description: WHILE New Jersey educators, politicians and others have been discussing the educational needs of our gifted and talented children for the last century, thousands upon thousands of New Jersey's children are being challenged in the academically excellent schools of Regis, Fordham Prep, Horace Mann and many other New York City facilities.

title: Peru President's Niece Arrested,
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (UPI)An assistant hank manager from Lima, Peru, arrested on charges of trying to smuggle $2 million worth of cocaine into the United States, was identified yesterday as the niece of the President of Peru, Gen, Francisco Morales Bermudez. Olga Morales Bermudez de Reyna, 41 years old, was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport on Jan. 10 by custmos agents who said that they had found 11 pounds of pure. cocaine in false bottoms of her suitcases.

description: MONTREAL, Jan. 21 (UPI)Guy Lafleur scored two goals tonight and the Montreal Canadiens extended their unbeaten string to 15 games with an 81 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: TV VIEW
description: Original dramatic productions going beyond the formula aspirations of the average made-for-TV movie are hardly commonplace these days. Three in a single week, therefore, tend to create the illustion of a rare festival and, in a miracle sensible scheduling, they are being presented on consecutive nights. Of course, two are on public television. The audience cannot expect too much from the commercial networks in these days of hyperthyroid ratings anxiety. any case, the lineup is as follows: The Defection of Simas Kudirka on CBS: tomorrow night at 9; Damien on Channel 13, Tuesday at 8 P.M., and Verna: U.S.O. Girl on Channel 13, Wednesday evening at 9.

title: U .S . Aides Report Main Snag in Talks Is Palestinian Issue
description: ATHENS, Jan. 21The main issue holding up an IsraeliEgyptian agreement on the principles for a Middle East agreement is the question of which Palestinians would be permitted to participate in negotiations to determine the future of the Palestinians, American officials said today.

title: Janet Stroup Is Affianced
description: The Rev. Dr. Dudley J. Stroup and Mrs. Stroup of Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Barbara Stroup, to Dr. Paul Jeffrey Fox, son of Mrs. Paul H, Fox of Stuart, Fla., and the late Mr. Fox.

title: Highlights of the Tax Message
description: Tax Cuts: The President proposed $33.9 billion in tax cuts in 1979, of which $23.5 billion would go to individuals, $8.4 billion to business, and $2 billion would come in lower excise and payroll taxes. The cuts would be offset by $9.4 billion in new revenue measures, mainly by repealing deductions for sales, gasoline and personal property taxes and by curtailing deductions for medical expenses and business entertainment.

title: Duran Settles Title On Knockout in 12th
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 21Roberto Duran knocked out Esteban DeJesus at 2 minutes 32 seconds of the 12th round today to gain the undisputed lightweight boxing championship.

title: POLITICS
description: MAYOR Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark is such an oddson favorite to win reelection to his third term in May, it is almost impossible to get anyone with any kind of political base to oppose him.

title: WILMINGTON 10 RULING GOES ON TV TOMORROW
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 21Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. has asked for a halfhour of evening television time Monday to announce his decision on pardoning or cutting the sentences of the socalled Wilmington 10, the black activists serving long prison terms in the firebombing of a grocery store in racial disturbances seven years ago.

title: Karen Gail Eliason Sets August Bridal

title: Cape Cod in Wintertime: A Place Forgotten by the Outside World
description: Sprays of sleet pepper the windshield and dance along the empty street on the drive through the lateafternoon darkness of a winter Provincetown on Cape Cod. Commercial Street. the main drag along the seafront, shows no sign of life save for shop and roominghouse signs swinging wildly in the gale. This is Cape Cod unrecognizable from its clamorous summertime people jam, winter scene forgotten by the outside world.

title: Beauty; Paris: Doing What Comes aturally
description: PARIS. Forget meticulously curled hair, generously mascaraed eyes and perfectly devised face shading. The young women of Paris are changing the face and facts of beauty this season.

title: Home on the Range
description: HE mythical last cowboy has made his final ride across the pages of American literature so many times that the path is becoming a shade worn. I personally have discovered and recorded him a halfdozen times and Larry McMurtry has made career of it  to say nothing of William Eastlake, Max Crawford, Edwin Shrake and J. Frank Dobie; he has ridden off into the Sunset so often that he's in danger retina damage.

title: MUSIC
description: ALL of us who live in Westchester County are gratified by the influx of major international artists appearing with our county orchestras and in the many community concert series. But there are also Westchesterbased organizations that deserve our attention.

title: Horses and Burros Killed
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP)Thirtythree wild burros and seven wild horses have been shot to death near the CaliforniaNevada border east of Susanville, the Government reported yesterday. The. Bureau of. Land Management has of- fered a $1,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible. Another $500 reward has been posted by Wild. Horse Organized Assistance, a private organization. Thebodies were discovered by a trapper who reported the finding to a game warden.

description: Mary Catherine Menk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl William Menk of Glen Ridge and Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Mirton Jerome Manning of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Charles Dolan.

title: `Pantaloon, Or an Opera By Any Other Name .
description: when Robert Ward and his librettist, Bernard Stambler, made an opera out of Leonid Andreyev's He Who Gets Slapped, they discovered that the constant reference to , the protagonist as He became rather as embarrassing when set to music. So they gave the character the name Pantaloon. Partly for this reason and partly because commedia dell arte elements were inserted in the opera that were not in the original play, Mr. Ward and Mr. Stanibler decided to call their creation Pantaloon. As such it had its premiere in a Columbia University Opera Workshop production in 1956.

title: Flights of 90Plane Navy Fleet Suspended Pending Crash Inquiry

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan 21  After six years of conscientious trying, Lawrence Nganga, a 26-year-old Kenyan high school graduate, has finally obtained what he considers a serious job.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Emphasizing the need to increase private investment to keep the economy growing, President Carter today unveiled a multifaceted corporate tax package that calls for acrosstheboard tax cuts and a variety of incentives to spur business spending.

title: GARDENING
description: IT WAS at once dazzlingly beautiful and destructive. As sunlight turned the icecovered twigs to glistening crystal, one could almost forget the jumble of broken branches that lay beneath the trees. Not only did last week's ice storm result in discomfort for thousands of Long Islanders who were without electricity and heat; it also left tangle of damaged trees and shrubs and a massive cleanup task.

Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Tavern-on-the-Green.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2IWhen California's voters accepted the idea in 1960, nothing like it existed anywhere, but now 40 other states have similar commissions.

description: Frazier. Dickson, a former copy editor at The New York Times and The New York Herald Tribune and a founder of the New York unit of the Newspaper Guild, died of lung cancer at New York Hospital yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: Janet Malone Marlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McKenzie Martin of Wilmington, Del., and Russell Owen Jones of Chadds Ford, Pa., were married yesterday at the Greenhill Presbyterian Church in Wilmington by the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. John Baiz of Pittsbureh. The brideeroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jolui Paul Jones of Wilmington.

title: Oil Tax Credits
description: The leeway the United States permits its multinational oil companies to credit foreign tax payments against domestic tax obligations has been the subject of debate for two decades, and particularly so since the big price rises of four years ago substantially increased the sum of money involved. Last week, the Internal Revenue Service issued major decision revoking two previous rulings that allowed such credits for payments in Saudi Arabia and Libya.

title: If You Go...
description: . . .to Cape Cod in winter, bear in mind that the Cape Cod Canal, at the beginning of the Cape, is a convenient spot to stop and plan your, route. At the Bourne traffic circle, about 70 miles south of Boston and roughly the same distance east of Providence, keep on the north side of the canal heading toward the Sagamore Bridge and look for picnic areas and parking areas where you can relax and watch the ships pass by.

title: 2 Tie for First Place In World Cup Downhill
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 21 (AP) Austria's Josef Walcher won his second downhill here in 24 hours today, but had to share the victory this time with West Germany's Sepp Ferstl.

title: Assorted Characters
description: NIHILISM is the romance of the times: nothing so certifies the advanced sensibility of the contemporary novelist as giving his characters a glimpse of the void. Lost in the middle of life, Richard Rhodes's fourth novel begins, he was a surgeon. But Thomas Haldane is that rarest of species in recent American fiction: a grownup man with work to do, work he does not abandon at the first hint of the absurd. A gynecologist, Haldane is by trade a knower of secrets (the title comes from the Hippocratic oath); a resident of Kansas City, as prosaic city as the continent offers, he nevertheless understands its mysteries. His best friend is a dealer of doublewide mobile homes, but neither man is a fool or grotesque..They are making do.

title: Around the Nation
description: CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 21 (AP)A tentative agreement on a new contract be tween the Canton Board of Education and striking school employees fell apart today when a judge refused to become involved in the settlement.

title: Kentucky Five Beats Mississippi State, 7565
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Jan, 21. (AP)Jack Givens scored 21 points, 13 in the first half, to help. the University of Kentucky overcome a slow start, and the Wildcats fended off a rally late in the game by Mississippi State to score a 7565 triumph in a. Southeastern Conference game today.

title: Carter Again Defers Large Foreign Aid Increases
description: President Carter has decided to postpone for a second year American initialives in economic aid for the world's poor nations that he promised in 1976 campaign and again last year, according to Administration officials.

title: 8 Held in Ski Lift Ticket Forgery
description: WARREN, Vt., Jan. 21 (UPI)The authorities have uncovered a new kind of forgery at the Sugarbush Valley ski area counterfeit ski lift tickets. The police said they had arrested eight persons for forging the tickets. A stamp allegedly used in the forgeries was left at a Waitsfield ski lodge and used by a number of people, the police said. The eight are to appear in court Monday.

title: New College Kicking Rules May Alter Football Strategy
description: College football coaches may not be quick to order a field goal attempt next season because a revision in the rules by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee has made the attempt for 3 points less attractive.

title: I.F.STONE INTERVIEWS I.F.STONE AT SEVENTY
description: I.F. Stone has just turned 70. He wasthe past tense is just a little sada newspaperman for more than half a century. For almost two decades, in I.F. Stone's Weekly, he ran a oneman, onewoman Washington newsletter with his wife. He once called it the journalistic equivalent of the oldfashioned poppamomma grocery store. During the fight against the Vietnam War, he became something or a join nero to the young. A movie about The Weekly by Jerry Bruck Jr. was shown at the Cannes Film Festival in 1974 and it has been reshown several times recently on Public Broadcasting Service. At 70 most people dwell on their past, but when The New York Times Magazine asked Stone interview himself, the portrait that emerged was of a man passionately concerned with his future, on earth, not in heaven.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE thriving thrift shoponce sleazy storefront lined with steel racks and open binshas become as elegant as its designer labels. Second Hand Rose now buys her secondhand clothes in boutique settings, with tryon rooms, yet.

title: Navy Criticized on Cost of Planes In Secret Memo by Defense Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Defense Secretary Harold Brown and his staff have circulated a secret memorandum that strongly accuses the Navy of spending too much money on combat planes and says bluntly that the Navy situation not improving.

title: Detroit 87, St Peter's 77
description: DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP)Jolin Long scored 26 points tonight and the University of Detroit defeated St. Petees, 8777.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Several years ago it would have been possible to maintain an air of hipness about contemporary movies if you were familiar with the films of Godard and Ozu, if you knew what a freezeframe was and you either subscribed to auteurism or sniffed haughtily at the merest mention of the word. Today that's not enough. Auteurists, who once threw bombs, now are the conservatives. Godard continues to work, though we see the results infrequently. Ozu has been as widely distributed as is probably possible in a country that is, essentially, non-Japanesespeaking, while Andy Warhol appears to have given up moviemaking, more or less, to concentrate on the serious business of partygoing.

title: DINING OUT; A Fine Restaurant in Fort Lee; ** Cafe Trilussa
description: TOO many restaurants these days are interested more in their looks than in their food. English pubs, Irish pubs, Western saloons, Gay 90's, Roaring 20'stake your pick; the themes vary, but the food rarely does.

title: Ideas &
description: Over the past half dozen years, the Supreme Court has several .times upheld the princliile of plea bargaining without making clear what acts are permissible in the name of the process. Last week, in a decision that enhanced the power. of criminal prosecutors, the Criurt specified one kind of action that is legal.

title: Councilman Says He Will Be in Building Set for Demolition Test

description: AFUNNY thing happened to group of academicians on their way to organizing a panel discussion of The History of the Ghost in America. No ghost would ma- terialize. That is, no ghostwriter responsible for some of the more memorable words uttered or written by contemporary politicians would come forward to discuss the highly specialized art.

title: The Nation; In Summary; Bell Goes Back To the Bench for An F.B.I. Chief; Joshua Trumpets And Marston Falls; Truth Squad Marches On; One Small Step For Womankind; A Better Way By the C.I.A.?; Clyde Haberman and Caroline Rand Herron; Sally K. Ride; possible astronaut.
description: For more than a year his other methods had failed, so the Attorney General decided to rely on the Bell system in selecting a new director for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. That meant no more search committees or formal background checks, but rather his own knowledge of people and the advice of friends. It was not surprising, therefore, that Griffin B. Bell, for 15 years Federal judge, settled last week on another Federal judge, William H. Webster of St. Louis.

title: Flow Some Neighbors on L.I. Weathered the Week
description: A week before, a warm house, Elvis Presley's records spinning on the phonograph and a few drinks with neighbors would not have seemed so luxurious a celebration at the Huntington Bay, L.I., home of John and Linda Ryan. But, on Friday night, the Ryans and their friends reveled in the simple pleasures of light, music and warmth that they had gone without, off and on, for the preceeding seven days.

title: Tax Cut Urged on Incomes Below $100,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  President Carter's proposed tax measures would reduce the Federal income taxes owed by almost everyone with an income below $100,000 a year. People with incomes above that would pay more taxes than they do now.

title: HIGHLIGHTS; Who Runs America? Some Answers From a Senate Committee
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, thanks to the number of personal trusts and pension funds it manages, is the major stock voice in at least 27 of the nation's major corporationsmore than any other bank. Yet the four biggest voices in J.P.Morgan & Company, Morgan Guaranty's parent, are sounded by other New York banks.

title: Prosecutors Sought Felony Case Against Kleindienst, Records Say
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  Internal documents from the Watergate special prosecutor's office show that staff lawyers there originally wanted to seek 13count felony indictment against Richard G. Kleindienst, the former Attorney General, after they concluded that he.and other senior Justice Department officials had] ied under oath.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 21 (UPI)Bill Coleman defeated Johnny Petraglia, the favorite, 237 pins to 191, and won the $125,000 Showboat invitation professional bowling tournament today. It was Coleman's first P.B.A. victory and made him eligible to compete in the Tournament of Champions in April.

title: The Added Value of Having a Driver's License
description: Almost everywhere today a drivees license is required for operating a motor vehicle. In recent years, however, it has become much more than a license to drive. It is one of the most widely ac- cepted forms of personal identification and is increasingly accepted as reference for cashing personal checks far from home, as a bail bond for minor offenses and even as authority for physicians to transplant anatomical organs if the licenseholder dies.

title: Corporate Shootouts Over Brand Names
description: Prehistoric Egyptian wall paintings show field workers placing their marks on the flanks of cattle. Roman pottery manufacturers were putting their brands on products in 35 B.C., the first recorded commercial trademarks.

title: Begin Says Cabinet Will. Make Decision on Talks
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 21Prime Minister Menahem Begin said tonight that his Cabinet would decide at its weekly meeting tomorrow whether to send a delegation to Cairo to resume meetings of the EgyptianIsraeli Military Committee.PARIS, Jan. 21 (Reuters)Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel said in an interview published today that Egypt was trying to create a climate of tension at the Middle East peace talks in order to put pressure on Israel.

title: MUSIC
description: MODERN music, said John Philip Sousa, reminds me of a pot of eels worming in and out. America's March King did not have too many kind words for jazz either, which he predicted will endure just as long as people hear it through their feet instead of their brains. John Philip loved more than marches, though, and his touring band programs were a happy mlange of favorites from the symphonic, opera and concert fields.

title: Joan Herrick Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Taylor Harris of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Harris's daughter, Joan Alexandre Herrick, to Frank Edward Barnes 3d, son of Mrs. Paul Keller of Smithfield, N.C., and the late Dr. Barnes Jr.

description: IF New Jerseyans had to pay state taxes at the same rate imposed on their neighbors in New York State, their annual payments would rise by a whopping 40 percent.

title: Voluntary Social Security Asked.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP)Repre. sentative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California. has introduced a bill that would make participation in the Social Security System voluntary. Mr. Wilson said in a statement that his proposal would make it posscible for an individual to decide each year whether tocontribute to a private retirement fund rather than to Social Security. The bill is to he referred to the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: DELAY ON REFUGEES TROUBLES THAILAND
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 21Officials here are becoming concerned that the slow movement of the more than 100,000 Indochinese refugees to countries of permanent asylum is leading regional gov.....ments to adopt measures to halt the inflow.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The attack in the Jan. I issue on the income tax deserves a brief rebuttal. The question is which tax serves New Jersey best in raising needed revenues and in carrying out the court's mandate on thorough and efficient education.

title: CRIME
description: Computers cannot think, they say. But the. line is getting narrower. We now have chess-playing computers and computers that compose music and computers that extrapolate the future: In addition, smart operators can make computers dance a merry, and illegal, tune, as a recent New Yorker series demonstrated. Naturally sciencefiction writers have embraced the subject, and there have been many books  and at least one gripping film, too about the subject of thinking computers. Now comes THE ADOLESCENCE OF P1 by Thomas J. Ryan (Macmillan, cloth, $8.95; Collier, paper, $4.95).

description: In a review in The New York Times Book Review in 1973, the novelist James Conaway said of The Onion Field, one of the books mentioned by James J. McInerney, a member of the Three Village School Board, as being objectionable:

title: Promises, Promises
description: AND if elected, promise. . . .  In years when a Governor is to be elected, political skirmishing starts with ripe tomatoes; the brickbats come later. Wise candidates inflict only wounds that will heal by election time. After all, today's adversary may be tomorrows muchneeded supporter.

title: Abortion and TeenAge Pregnancy
description: CINCINNATIIn seeking common giound on the divisive issue of abortion, most people seem able to agree at least on this: Abortion is not desirable in and of itself. Even those who are generally favorable to abortion tend to present it as an .unattractive but sometimes necessary solution to problems.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: ART
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR SOME people would have us believe that prints are a lazy man's art. They believe that artists make prints in more lackadaisical moments, when they are not hard at work on a more important painting or sculpture, and that art lovers look at prints when they are feeling phlegmatic and do not want to be too seriously engaged by an art work. Prints, these detractors hold, do not have the energy, stamina and endurance of other kinds of art.

title: Own Your Own Island
description: If you have a burning desire to own your own island, you had better hurry and buy now, for the world is shrinking fast and the supply is dwindling.

description: Surrounded by the swift waters of the East River, New York City's prison complex on Bikers Island was once viewed as a junior Alcatraza place of no escape. But last year 39 prisoners broke out, and four of the escapees are still at large.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 21 (Reuters) Abu Dhabi, a Persian Gulf country where Moslem laws give men total control of their wives property, has opened a bank for women only.

title: Racquetball's Welcome Return
description: RACQUETBALL is finally corning home, and no one could be happier about it than Joe Sobek. Mr. Sobek is the squash and tennis pro who invented the sport in 1950. He saw it spread throughout the Middle West and the West, but not the Northeast, where he originated it.

title: New Handicap System a Boon for. Weekend Sailors
description: Move over, Ted Turner and Lowell North. A new handicapping system for offshore yacht racing is about to be launched that is expected to make the weekend sailors production yachts competitive with the hot, custom racing machines.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayKnoll Farms, Suffolk Avenue, Brentwood, L. I. Special working hunters, novice jumpers, pleasure horses, equitation. 9:00 A.M.

title: Snow and IceA Staggering Week
description: IT was a bad week. The worst snowstorm in a decade howled into the state after a rare ice storm had cut like knife through suburban and rural areas. The ice storm killed electric power for 600,000 people after iceladen trees crashed through lines feeding their homes. Power was restored over a threeday period.

title: A Man Held Incompetent for Trial Is Charged With a Second Murder
description: A Bronx man who three years ago was found mentally incapable of standing trial for murder in the forseeabie future has been charged with a second murder.

title: What Makes a Star? Howard Hawks Knew Best of All; In what was probably his last interview, the late Howard Hawks reminisced about the making of Westerns and comedies and actors and actresses the camera loved.
description: Howard Hawks, who died last month at the age of 81, was not only the director of such classic American films as Twentieth Century, Bringing Up Baby, To Have and Have Not and Red River. He was also a nurturer of screen talent, eliciting unexpected and brilliant performances from some of Hollywood's biggest stars as well as from unknowns.

title: ZeroBase Budgeting: It Made a Difference
description: WASHINGTONThe Commerce Department had its wrist slapped. The Environmental Protection Agency got high marks but complained of being suffocated by paperwork. The Pentagon saw a difference but couldn't quite pinpoint it.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Tile Nastase, upon defeating Elliot Teltscher, an 18-year-old University of California, Los Angeles freshman, in the first round of the $100,000 Baltimore indoor tennis tournament: Forget about Jimmy Connors. He is the best player I've played in the United States years. Put him in the Davis Cup, put him in the World Cup, put him in everything.

description: When you have finally passed through the populous areas of western Suffolk County, and the concrete expanse of the Long Island Expressway begins to live up to its name, you begin/o see them.

description: The Citicorp Center, the cantedtop tower on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, created something of a special problem during and after the snowstorm. Snow and ice kept forming 60 stories above ground, on the 130foot top that slants skyward at a 45degree angle, resembling the top of a clarinet.

title: France and Spain Also Involved
description: RABAT, Morocco King Hassan II of Morocco sent a message to Cairo last week, underscoring his country's role as one of the few public supporters of Egyptian diplomacy in the Arab world. His ties with Egypt might be useful in resolving a conflict of his own, a struggle with Algeria for dominance in a strategic corner of northwest Africa.

title: Home Style.
description: Buying a house in the suburbs? A townhouse in the city? A condominium at the shore?

title: AROUND THE  Garden
description: JOAN LEE FAUST

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE old electric toaster is showing signs of breakdown, to which it is entitled after working for 26 years. It has been an efficient twoslice toaster, but I wish had chosen a different time to show its age. There has been a rash of break- downs around the house lately, and has all underscored a dependence on gadgets and mechanical devices that had always denied.

title: Toward a Palestinian Settlement
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The temporary breakdown of the .Middle. East peace talks gives us more time to think about the thorniest issue, the Palestinians. We have fallen into the habit of dividing foreign ,regimes and political forces into radicals aria monerates. This is a misleading habit, for the same. people. who tend toward moderation in one set of circumstances can become radicalized when the situation changes. Nowhere is this more true than in the Middle East.

title: Timothy Smith, Cynthia Wilkes Wed in Georgia
description: The marriage of Cynthia Merle Wilkes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Wilkes of Lyons, Ga., to Timothy Graham Smith took place yesterday at the First United Methodist Church in Lyons.

title: Sharing Italy's Anxieties
description: PARISWhile Washington seems primarily worried about Communists entering the Government in Rome, Italy's European neighbors with a closer view of the situation see a much bigger, more intractable problem. Italian society is disintegrating. Not only the economy, but the state apparatus, the relations of social groups, the capacity of government, have moved beyond paralysis to decay.

Authors pictures are becoming more revealing. The average photograph on the dust iacket used to show the writer looking thoughtful, perhaps histrionically thoughtful, or smiling. implied that the novelist had pondered long and hard to write the book or that he or she was happy to have got it published.

The strike vote was reversed after President Francisco Mo- rales Bermudez offered to discuss its main demands for higher pay and the reinstatement of several thousand workers fired after a general strike last July.

William Miller's personal financial affairs, as well as his philosophical leanings, in preparation for deciding whether he is fit to serve as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. title: Rich Child, Poor Child
description: IN our conscious experience as adults, wealth and .power appear to shape our lives mainly as constraints on what we are able to do, or as resources for action. But they affect us in the most profound way before we are old enough to do much of anything, and not simply by creating differences in economic opportunity. At an early age, society becomes part of our internal environment: our dreams, fantasies, ideals, intentions, our conceptions of ourselves, our assumptions about what the world has to offer and what we can expect from it.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Real economic growth in the United States slowed in the fourth quarter to aeasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.2 percent, the Commerce Department reported. A year ago the nation's total output of goods and services had risen at a percent rate.... The department had some more encouraging news: The number of housing starts leaped 8 percent in December to a yearly rate of nearly 2.3 million units. That was the largest increase in almost five years. .. In addition, personal income expanded 1.1 percent in the last month to seasonally adjusted annual rate of $1.62 trillion, according to the department, and the Federal Reserve Board announced that factories operated at 83 percent of capacity in December....

Donovan, son of Mr. and Mrs. ,Nrthur W. Donovan, also of Scarsdale. Miss Boker and her fianc graduated from the University of Rochester. She is teaching high school in Prince Frederick, Md., and studying for a master's degree in remedial reading at Loyala College in Baltimore. Mr. Donovan is working for a Ph.D. in geology at Johns Hopkins University.

title: The Quest for a Safe Neighborhood
description: Safety is a doorman, a brightly lighted street, familiar faces on a block or being six feet tall. To some it materializes in the form of a policeman, others it is the feeling of being at home on a street, the belief that, never having been mugged, you lead a charmed life, or the certainty that you can outrun anyone who attacks you.

Harvard University, when it gave him an honorary degree, hailed him as discoverer of the most significant mathematical truth of this century, incomprehensible-to-laymen, revolutionary for philosophers and logicians.

Mr. Garrison is one of five candidates running in a special election April 15 to succeed Mayorelect Ernest Morial on the state's Fourth Circuit Court of Appeal.

title: Prophet in the Mode
description: W1LLIAM IRWIN THOMPSON wants people to think big. Instead of worrying about tomorrow, he would prefer them to worry about all of human history. He would like them to give up their small preoccupation with paychecks, marriages or personal mortality in order to speculate about the influence of sunspots on civilization, or to consider a curious analogy he suggests between the lifecycle of cultures and the initiatory stages of the lumined yogi. Widescreen thinking is close to myth, is soultalk, Thompson asserts, apparently forgetting that one can also see the world in a grain of sand, as William Blake once wrote.

description: LOOSE CHANGE, by Sara Davidson. (Pocket, $2.50.) The story of three women, sorority sisters at Berkeley during the 60's, who fell under the spell that turbulent time but then broke free and struggled to achieve identities of their own. A poignantmemoir that makes us ponder the recent past.

title: Many Old Priorities Were Not the Main Crime Problems
description: WASHINGTON - Anyone rereading J. Edgar Hoover's testimony at the last appropriations hearing that he attended could logically conclude what he considered in 1971 to be the chief threats to the Republic. His Federal Bureau of Investigation agents had tracked down more military deserters (17,885) and investigated more stolen car cases (30,599) in 1970 than ever before in the bureau's 47year history, he said. The Communist PartyU.S.A., he warned Congress, remained under the complete control and domina. tion of the Soviet Union, and therefore posed a menace to the security of our country.

title: Time for Reflection
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21As a general rule in this city, nothing is ever quite as good or as bad as the prevailing mood of the moment. This is Murphy's Second Law, and the wild swings of opinions on, the Middle. East suggest that Murphy had a point.

The former West Side member of Congress, who had lost acrimonious printery fights for United States Senator and Mayor in the last two years, managed to win the Democratic nomination for Congress in the lath District on Manhattan's East Side last week. But she had to go into court and survive a recount to do it.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Marvelous times. It looks as if 1978 is going to be fantastic year along Publishers Row. Encouraged by the near3 millioncopy sales that both Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind have racked up in soft cover, as well as the bestselling performances of such hardcover books as The Silmaril- lion, The House of Merlyn and Gnomes, almost every paperback house is planning to expand its list sciencefiction and fantasy publications. Last year percent of all book titles issued in the United States fell into that rather metaphysical category. The way things are going, the percentage should be considerably higher this year.

title: Carey Says Funds Should Be Retained By Olympic Lottery
description: ALBANY. Jan.. 21Governor Carey has proposed that the special nationwide Olvmpic lottery established last year be permitted to keen most or its proceeds to help maintain Olympic facilities in Lake Placid. The future of the Olympic lottery has been uncertain because of doubts that its proceeds would go for their intended purpose. lottery, the regular state lottery can siphon off up to 75 percent of the proceeds from the Olympic lottery if the state game does not reach its anticipated $127 million in revenue in the next fiscal year. That estimate. which was arrived at optimistically when nowstabilized lottery revenues were pouring in, has now been lowered to around $95 million. Revenues this fiscal year are projected at $90 million.

The beautiful shade trees have long been a tradition at the Hartford campus, but in spite of considerable efforts to save them with all available rescue measures, the elms have succumbed to Dutch elm disease.

title: Notes: Hotels Fight 'Relative Competition
description: America's innkeepers are a beleaguered lot. Beset on all sides by. problemsinflation, mounting costs, the energy crisis and Jimmy Carter's assault on the threemartini lunch' they've managed to keep a stiff upper lip. But now another enemy has come to the forethe ubiquitous friendly uncle who annually invites the family to spend their vacation at his condominium on the beach in Florida or at his second home in the mountains of Vermont.

title: What's Doing in LAKE PLACID
description: THE SCENE - Two years before the opening of the XIII Winter Olympics (at 2 P.M., Feb. 13, 1980), Lake Placid is holding a dress rehearsal. Olympic fen. vor, some confusion and some controversy are in the frosty air in this tiny Adirondack Mountain village (population 3,000), and its pace, usually leisurely In the wintry months, nas quickened, The face of Main Street is changing, with new construction, Olympic Tshirts and souvenirs on display in shop windows, new restaurants opening, athletes In training and Olympic executives and hardhat construction workers bustling everywhere. The word is out that now is the time to come to see the sites of the 1980 Winter Olympics; realistically, few except officials, athletes, the press and V.I.P.'s will be able to find accommodations in the village during the actual games.

title: Phipps Duo Gains Final
description: The team of Gene Scott and Dinny Phipps of New York reached the final of the United States open court tennis doubles championship along with the team of Jim Burke and William Vogt Jr. of Philadelphia yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club. Scott and Phipps defeated Phil Stockton and Chuck Libby of Boston, 62, 62, 62. Burke and Vogt triumphed over Chris Ronaldson of Australia and Peter Clement of Philadelphia, 65, 64, 63.

title: The Result Was the President's State of the Union Message
description: WASHINGTON  What Pregident Carter asked from the people who helped prepare his State of the Union message was not precisely consonant with his usually lowkeyed oratorical personality. He said he wanted to be able to give it forcefully, James Follows, his chief speechwriter, said. He wanted more applauselines than is generally his style.

title: A New Showcase For the New American Actor
description: After 48 years in the theater, and at an age when most people are content to reminisce before the fire, Robert Lewis has decided to ignore a lifetime's education in the pitfalls of show business and to found his own theater company. To lead off his first season, Mr. Lewis, a round, nata, voluble sprite of 68, has corraled Maureen Stapleton and led her off to Westchester to star in The Club Champion's Widow, a new play by John Ford Noonan which starts performances Tuesday night on the campus of the College of New Rochelle. There, in the college's Arena Theater, Mr. Lewis hopes to demonstrate during the next two years his fierce conviction that American actors are the equals of any in the world.

title: The following article was written by Irvin Molotshy, Shawn G. Kennedy and Roy R. Silver.
description: 0 NE day last week, when hundreds of thousands of Long Island residents were without heat and electricity after the ice storm felled thousands of power and telephone lines, the members the Nathan Hale Unit of the Senior Citizens of Huntington gathered as usual for their daily lunch and conversation at the former Village Green School.

title: A Regal Package of Art from Britain
description: LONDON Like it or notand I think you'll like itthis Royal Heritage series of richly colored and cultured hourlong films that begins Friday evening at 9 on Channel 13 seems all set to become yet another Old .World invasion of America on the grand scale. The English are busy colonizing again, but softly, softly.

title: Realty News

title: The Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA - Seventyfive years ago, Lincoln Steffens wrote in McClure's magazine that technically the political boss of Pittsburgh did not rob the town because that was not his style, and besides it would be a carelessly unnecessary way in Pennsylvania. Of the large city on the opposite end of the state he wrote that though all municipal governments are more or less bad, Philadelphia is simply the most corrupt and most contented.

title: DINING OUT; Informality With a Special Touch; **Raffles
description: LITTLE things do mean a lot. When someone mentioned, in passing, that frenchfried sweet potatoes were served at Raffles, in Roslyn, certainly caught my interest. A restaurant that bothers with a special touch like that might be worth recommending. I was not disappointed.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF; THE MASKS OF ORTHODOXY; SOMERSE1 MAUGHAM; I GREAT ASCENTS; PARALLEL BOTANY; A znu) WATCHER'S ADVENTURES IN TROPICAL ASIERICA
description: The sting of death and the vic tory of the grave held pre-emptive dominion over early Puritan life. And so it is surprising, or at least paradoxical, to find that in the very seats of death, in the graveyards of one isolated county of Massachusetts, a lively And sometimes comic spirit smed and even smirked in the crude masks cut into the slate headstones of Calvinism's dour elect. This is what Peter Benes found in the course of his painstaking and ingenious research for this brilliant monograph on a neglected native folk art form.

title: Capitals 5, Penguins 2
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (AP)Jim Bedard stopped 43 shots, Gerry Meehan scored two goals, and the Washington Capitals defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 52, tonight.

description: Considering that we're living in Queens, said John Paluszkiewicz, a musician who was digging out his car yesterday at Jewell Avenue and 108th Street in the Forest Hills section, we're doing better thin 1 expected.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 21 (UPI)Michelle Ford left a sickbed tonight and bettered her world record for the 800meter freestyletfn the New South Wales state swimming championships.

title: United Artists Executives Write Their Own Script
description: How's this for a movie script? More than a quarter of a century ago, two men take over a deficitridden corporation and restore it to profitability. As the years pass, they first take the company public and then sell it to a conglomerate.

title: U.S. Aide Goes to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Tan. 21 (Reuters)Assistant Secretary of State Alfred L. Atherton Jr., continuing American efforts to seek peace in the Middle East, returned to Israel today from Cairo. He said he would meet with Prime Minister Menahem Begin and Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan this evening to brief them on the talks held in Cairo yesterday between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Richard Meier Weds Katherine Gormley
description: Katherine Gormley, an architect with Johnson/Burgee Architects, was married yesterday to Richard Meier, principal of Richard Meier & Associates Architects. Rabbi Bruce Goldman and the Rev. John Scorzoni, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. C. James Gormley, in Plymouth, Mass.

title: Jane L. Detra, A Banking Aide, Becomes Bride
description: Jane Louise Detra and Robert Newton Davenport Jr. of New York, who are with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York were married yesterday in Trucksville, Pa. The Rev. E. Lee Brehm performed the ceremony in the United Methodist Church. Mr. and Mrs. R. Newton Davenport of Lehighton, Pa., the bridegroom's parents, were married in the same church in 1942.

title: Ali Spars With Women in a TV In
description: Muhammad Ali's views on getting old, dying, women's roles, woman as temptress, his previous marriage, racial separation and his money will be heard today and next Sunday in a series of two interviews by Alice Travis on the program For You ... Black Woman. The heavyweight champion was interviewed in his Chicago home for these broadcasts, which will be seen from 1:00 to 1:30 P.M. on WABCTV/Channel 7.

title: ...And Vietnamese Refugees Are Still Fleeing
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  This is the monsoon season off the coast of Vietnam. On the South China Sea and the Gulf Siam, waves are high and the rains are heavy. Yet fishing boats loaded with those who want to leave Vietnam still set out for shores as distant as Australia, three to six weeks away. The refugees do not set out in ignorance of the risks the sea, the possibility of capture by Vietnamese authorities or the hostile reception that awaits them. All have listened American and British broadcasts in Vietnamese and know that boats are pushed back out to sea, passing ships refuse stop for them, transit camps are primitive and the wait for permanent haven is often interminable.

title: Taiwanese Murderer Executed
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 21 (UPI)A Taiwanese sailor convicted of murdering two fellow crew members after he lost $2,500 gambling with them in a Untied States port was executed today by a firing squad, official sources said,

title: Dispute Over Illinois Divorce Law Puts Property Settlements in Doubt
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 21  Illinois residents seeking divorces face more than the usual confusion, and the 7,000 who obtained them in the last three months may find their property settlements unsettled.

title: Rafael KubelikConductor/Philosopher
description: In his 49 years as a conductor, Rafael Kubelik has tasted adversity, especially in America, but he long ago.learned to counteract the bitter brew with adversity's sweet milk, philosophy, in Friar Lawrence's consoling words to Romeo. I have worked all my life very much in trouble, the towering, blueeyed Czech conductor told a visitor the other day in the Park Avenue hotel where he and his wife, the former soprano Elsie Morison, were settling in for his current sixweek, 22concert engagement with the New York Philharmonic. But I am philosopher. I go my way as an artist and I know my conscience. I don't regret one single thing. What one does, one always does in good faith.

Mr. Carter laid out a list of what he called tax reforms that included crackdoWn on deductions for business en-

description: PARIS  The French couturiers are in a state of lastminute panic today: Skirts don't have hems, shoes and hats have to be coordinated, seating charts aren't completed and anybody who has anything to do with the haute couture and its whole extravagant process can count on no sleep for the next two days.

description: WHEN Bill Warner of Norwalk, the owner of a golf course, got together with 15 friends three years ago and decided to organize a crosscountry ski club, he was surprised to find he was the first in the state to do so.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Jan, 21Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda said in his annual policy speech today that the Japanese Government was determined to increase imports of foreign industrial and farm products to reduce its huge trade surplus.PEKING, Jan. 21 (Reuters)China's universities will enroll research students this year for the first time in more than a decade, according to the official Chinese press service. The students will engage in scientific study and teach in universities after graduation.HONG KONG, Jan. 21 (Reuters)Chairman Hua Kuofeng, the Chinese Communist Party leader, has accepted an invitation to visit France, the Peking radio reported today. The radio, monitored here, said the invitation from President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France by the visiting French Prime Minister, Raymond Barre.TOKYO, Jan. 21 (UPI)President Kim II Sung of North Korea met with a visiting Soviet official for the first time in years yesterday and agreed to receive Kremlin decoration.SINOP, Turkey, Jan. 21 (UPI)All five occupants of a United States military transport plane died when it crashed near the Black Sea coast, a Turkish spokesman said today.MEXICO CITY, Jan. 21Vice President Mondale heard a warning today from Norman E. Borlaug, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, about the consequences mankind faced if world food production did not soon increase.

title: Sardinia Chooses to Plunge Into the Mainstream of Tourism
description: All the other large Mediterranean islands are legendary in some way. Crete gave the world the bull dancers and the story of the Minotaur. Corsica contributed Napoleon, plus some fascinating French gangsters. Sicily sent wave after wave of hardworking immigrants to America, not to mention the concepts of Mafia and Omerta. Majorca played an important role in the history of Spain and has been a popular tourist destination for 50 years.

title: Union Carbide Is Pressed on Move to Danbury
description: The Suburban Action Institute has asked the Federal Government to force the Union Carbide Corporation to guarantee that affordable housing will be available to its minoritygroup employees when it moves Its headquarters from Manhattan to Danbury, Conn.

description: Over three decades ago I came to regard snowshoeing as a poor man's endeavor.

title: Against Forced Takeovers
description: MELVILLE, N.Y.As a citizen and chief executive officer of a corporation listed on the New York Stock Exchange, I am concerned at the growing trend toward forced takeovers of public companies. Considerable research convinces me that the takeover game, as currently practiced, is harmful to our freeenterprise system and, notwithstanding the appearance of considerable premiums being paid, the shareholders of target companies frequently are shortchanged.. Moreover the style of the takeover, which carries with it an atmosphere of surprise and force, is out of harmony with gocd business practice.

title: The State of Mr. Carter's Country
description: The state of our Union, says Jimmy. Carter, is sound. Not because Jimmy Carter has been President for a year but because the American, people are confident, hardworking,, decent and compassionate, and because their economy and military establishment stand strong, Now that the boys are borne from Vietnam and the zealots are out of the White House, he concludes, there is no great cause or crisis'io divide us or to invest our leaders with heroic mandates. So this is the time to oil the Machine of government and to replace some malfunctioning parts, to tend to some unfinished business and to prepare for the foreseeable future so that no new crisis willoireilthelm us. Not a bad reading, we suspect; Of the Ainerican mind.

Survived by three sons, Ira R., Jerome B. and Melvin; one sister; six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Services at Schwartz Bros Funeral Home, 11403 Queens Blvd and 76 Road, Forest Hills Monday 1:45 P.M. Interment Mt. Neboh Cemetery.

description: LONDON, Jan. 21 (Reuters)The International Planned Parenthood Federation, which usually works for population control, has become concerned over conditions in large areas of central Africa where an unusually high number of couples are unable. to have children.

title: Joe McCarthy
description: When Tommy Henrich was rookie with the Yankees, Joe McCarthy told him: They're making sucker out of you with that outside curve. I want you to lay off it. A week or 10 days later, McCarthy said: Tommy, I told you to lay off that pitch. Now, either you lay off it, or you'll learn to hit it in Newark.

title: 8 Development Projects Within New York City Backed by Estimate Board
description: Eight New York City economic-development projects competing for financing under a new program of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development have been approved by the Board of Estimate.

title: Italian Victor in Luge
description: IMST, Austria, Jan. 21 (Reuters)paul Hildgartner of Italy won the world Inge championship today with an overall time of 1 minute 22.26 seconds. Vera Sosulya of the Soviet Union won the women's event in 1:13.0.

title: The Woman and the Lady
description: AYOUNG woman in Philadelphia has fallen on hard times. Her father has been murdered and the petit bourgeois comfort of her life swept away. It is 1910. She hAs had syphillis, been addicted morphine and one eye is gone. She has gone with men for money. Someone puts her in touch with a gentlewoman in Boston and they correspond. This as7 tonishing book, winnowed from material in the Schlesinger Library of Radcliffe College, is one side of the correspondence of Maimie Pinzer and Fanny Quincy Howe. For 12 years, across class lines, from another corner of the cosmos, what did the fallen  as Mamie Pinzer would have been called  have to say to the eminent? Everything.

title: Promises, Promises
description: ALTHOUGH it has been mercifully quiet in the political area since early November, the new year, with its induction ceremonies, brings a (mercifully) brief re. minder of the rhetoric, the promises, the charges and countercharges, the innuendos and the whisperings all of which cause the opening line of Kipling's Recessional''The tumult and the shouting dies'to keep running through our mind.

title: The Sensible Philosopher
description: A. J. Ayer is Professor of Logic at Oxford and also a Sir, having been knighted, no less, for his services to the march of. mind. That his recherch feats in epistemology should have carried him to a title is fitting, because Ayer is worldly in between being cerebral and the one extant English philosopher of whom an autobiography was he expected. He has been successful at philosophy though not, if he is to be judged technically, as successful as his brash and brilliant start in the subject 90 years ago promised that he would be. More to the point, he has philosophized not exclusively in print, or for the advantage o_f other philosophers, but impromptu before the masses, having long been the token thinker to whom the mediamen turn when their programs are in want of a little intellectual bite and discrimination. Ayer is widely appreciated as a fluent source of humane, sensible opinions; he is widely known too for the reassuringly democratic way he goes about his leisure: he can't be the only professional philosopher who enjoys watching soccer, but he has somehow managed to be the only professional philosopher whom everyone knows enjoys watching soccer. Such proofs of sociability have made his keen rationalism more palatable, and he has enlisted many progressive lobbies for the liberalization of British mores.

title: Nun's Attacker Is Sentenced
description: Thomas Lamar Brown, 25 years old, of Jersey City, convicted last month of beating and robbing a nun and then shoving her down a flight of stairs, has been sentenced to four to six years in state orison. Mr. Brown had been out of pri- son four days before he mugged, the nun, Sister Marcellena Bozzondesh of Brooklyn, at a Port Authority Trans Hudson railroad station in Jersey City last July. The nun was beaten because she had refused to give up her purse, which contained about $4 in cash.

title: PEOPLE
description: A decade ago the ABC television network was a poor third behind CBS and NBC in the ratings race. A decade ago Fred Silverman was midway through a career in programming at CBS that brought it a series of shows with the highest ratings on the air.

title: MARKETS
description: Wall Street wore a mantle of white as last week ended with a severe snowstorm, causing the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange open Friday at noontwo hours late. The Dow Jones industrial average, for its part, finished the session 776.94, showing a token gain from the previous week's close at 775.73.

title: N. F. L. Turnover: Anything Goes
description: Beyond the sideline boundary of the Washington Redskins bench area, the teenager was harassing game official. Suddenly the official spun, pointed at the teenager and yelled at George Allen, the Redskins coach, Is he a member of your staff? George Allen innocently shook his head, explaining that the teen - ager must have been planted there by the Philadelphia Eagles, but the official was not soothed. Keep him quiet, the official said, or it's 15 yards. No, the teenager was not exactly a member of George Allen's staff, merely a member of his family Bruce Allen, his son. But rather than acknowledge that to the official, and be penalized 15 yards, George Allen pretended that his son was a stranger. Anything to avoid a 15yard penalty. Somehow that incit dent seems to typify the current turnover in National Football League coaches. Any thing goes.

title: Connors Beats Gerulaitis and Faces Borg in $125,000 Final Today
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Jan. 21This is where it began for Bjorn Borg last year, when he finally showed he could handle Jimmy Connors.

title: Most College Freshmen in Poll Shun Liberal Label
description: The nation's firstyear college students are less willing to identify themselves as liberals in their attitudes, according to survey that also showed that the spectrum of political philosophy was slowly shifting to the left and that what is now considered middle of the road used to be left of center.

title: Rockland Hospital Supplies Begin to Run Out in Wake of Storm
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 21Nearly 90 nurses at Nyack Hospital in Rockland County who were unable to report for work yesterday because of the snowLstorm got in today, but hospital supplies were beginning to run out.HARTFORD, Jan. 21Connecticut began recovering today from its heaviest snowfall in nine years and Gov. Ella T. Grasso said the pace of recovery was so swift that it would not be neessary to go ahead with her planned declaration of a state of emergency.

title: Local Residents Oppose the Regional Planners
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  Its supporters see the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission as model superagency transforming a wasteland empty marsh, polluted waterways and huge garbage dumps just beyond the Lincoln Tunnel into an attractive gateway to New Jersey.

title: APPOINTMENT TO HINT AT VORSTER'S INTENT
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 21With Government leaders joining other whites in a mass migration to beach resorts from early December until well into January, South Africa tends to start its year slowly. But already there are signs that the growing racial discord of the last two years will continue in 1978.

description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: Music in Review
description: Wind quintets play a fairly specialized repertory, and the result is that there can't be too many that make their living through concertizing alone, apart from college residencies and such like. Thus for all the passing pleasures of the Paramount Quintet's formal New York debut last Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall, it would be hard to imagine its members making a sustained concert career as a unit.

title: Talks Stopped, For How Long?
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt impatient with routine diplomacy. The last thing he wanted when he launched his peace initiative two months ago was for negotiations to bog down over semantics. Each time the momentum has slowed, he has reverted to the dramatic - inviting Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel to Egypt at ChristmaS, requesting a sudden meeting with President Carter this month and last week, abruptly suSpending negotiations in Jerusalem and calling his Foreign Minister home.

title: Bimini: Boats, Marlin And an Inn That Hemingway Enjoyed
description: The Biminis are for boaters, for fish erfolk, and for travelers who just like funky little islands. In this string of cays, which cover about 10 square miles in the northwestern Bahamas, only the long narrow island called North Bimini is well populated (about 1,800 people), and the best way to get thereif you don't have a boatis by small amphibian plane from Miami. The plane is story in itself.

title: THEY TRY HARDER
description: 0 ne of the most popular American pastimes these days is belaboring the Japanese. Scarcely a day passes now without public warning from some American politician, businessman or union leader as to the dire consequences that will ensue if Japan does not mend its ways and cease to sell so many goods in the United States.

title: Dances of Miss Pier And Martha Bowers
description: Nostalgia is definitely in, both with audiences and choreographers who enjoy exercising the style of another time. One would guess that Virginia Pier had not been born when Veronica Lake first flexed her diminutive charms, but she has managed to cap- ture the feeling of her comehither allure and by extension that of all tough, romantic 40's movie heroines who suffered rather than switch to duller man.

title: East Germans Finesse the Mess Next Door By Buying It
description: Imagine how the East Germans must have felt. It was 1973 and, about to win their long battle for admission to the United Nations, they had spent $800,000 for a Park Avenue mansion as a home for their delegation. Perhaps they knew then, or perhaps they did not realize until later, that their nextdoor neighbor was an eyesore.

title: Philippine Abduction and Killing
description: MANILA, Jan. 21 (Reuters)A wealthy Philippine businessman, Antonio Limjoco, has been kidnapped and an architect friend killed by gunmen in Pampanga, about 50 miles north of Manila, the police reported today. A Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, John G. Devine, the new head of the Connecticut Office of Federal Bureau of Investigation, was incorrectly reported in last Sunday's Connecticut Weekly to have said that two F.B.I. agents were involved in illegal wiretapping with the New Haven police department. In the same article Mr. Devine was accurately reported to have said that he had not had time to study the charges against the agents and therefore was not prepared to comment on them.

title: ALL THE PR
description: JIMMY CARTER, July 12,1976.

title: Country Stories
description: FREDERICK MANFRED'S novel, Green Earth, is a rich oasis of healing in a day when suspense and murder are so much the order amusement in our reading. Besides being the tale the Englekings and the Alfredsons, pioneers in the early part of this century in the far Midwest, the book is a ragbag of country stories and sayings. All the barnyard talk is here, but somehow the familiar overused fourletter words are seldom needed. And the beddings, the birthings (one goes wrong waterhead child), the courtings, the denials, are here, but not in the customary modern sinister vein. takes a while to get accustomed to. This is a long book which never gives out in boredom. Continuously yields a new vignette or incident, as the lives of Ada (Ma) and her bright firstborn son, Free, are worked out.

title: Banjos by the Dozens, Players For the Fun
description: AMITYVILLE REMEMBER the classic old songs, the ones wrapped in the mirthful nostalgia of the good old days? Songs like Five Foot Two, Eyes of Blue, Varsity Drag, Baby Face, Alabama Jubilee, Sweet Georgia Brown'? well they are still being heard around the Island, for they are the basic repertory of the Long Island Banjo Society.

title: Insurance Agent Is Found Slain, In Howard Beach Office Building
description: A Queens agent of the Prudential Insurance Company of America was found dead in the lobby of an office building housing a branch of the company in the Howard Beach , section yesterday. The body bore head wounds from a blunt instrument and a metal bar was found nearby, the police said.

title: A Guide to Bargains in Designer Dresses
description: TIME was when the fashionable New Jersey woman eschewed the plain trappings of the discount stores. Now many women, the rich and the poor alike (but especially the rich), are flocking to the labels-for-less emporiums.

title: S. W. Norcia Fiance Of Martha E. Whelan
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Whelan of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Martha Elizabeth Whelan, to Stephen William Norcia, son of Mrs. Clint Parish of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late William Norcia. A wedding in Anril is planned.

description: Mrs. Samuel W. Fishman of Vergennes, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Audrey Marcia Fishman, to Andrew DeJongh Franklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. DeJongh Franklin of Washington, where the future bridegroom's father is a special assistant for business liaison to President Carter.

title: Evolution: Explosion, Not Ascent
description: The aphorism natura non facit saltum (nature does not proceed by leaps) is usually attributed to Linnaeus, the founder of modern taxonomy. One hundred years later, in the 1830's, Charles Lye11 used it as the cornerstone for his reformulation of geology. He transferred the timeless order and majesty of Newton's cosmos to the earth's history itself and postulated a stately world of slow, steady and gradual change without direction.
