title: Early American Abstract Art on Show
description: Although the word Synchromism doesn't yet come trippingly off every artworld tongue, it's showing signs of revival. The first American avantgarde mode of painting to get attention in Europe, more than 60 years ago, Synchromism, a coinage out of Greek for with color, was one of the earliest attempts to structure pictures solely of color and abstract shapesand now the increasing interest in early American modernism is bringing it back into focus.

title: Sara Kelsey Fiancee Of Kenneth Raisler
description: Sara A. Kelsey, a lawyer with the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, and Kenneth M. Raisler, an Assistant United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, plan to be married in Washineton in June.

title: MEDICAL FEES RISE IN WORKMEN'S CASES
description: The New York State Workmen's Compensation Board has announced a 13 percent increase in the medical fee schedule that regulates insurance reimbursement rates for doctors treating workmen's compensation and nofault insured patients.

title: Illinois St. 81, Indiana St. 76
description: NORMAL, Ill., Jan. 21 (AP)Billy Lewis, a senior, scored 25 points and Ron Jones, a sophomore, scored 18 as Illinois, State defeated Indiana State, 81776, today. The loss was the second in a row for Indiana State after the team had won its first 13 games.

title: Millrose Games: Offtrack Tales of Past
description: They will begin arriving on Thursday by plane, train, bus and car. One pole vaulter probably will show up minus his poles. At least one high jumper will complain about the layout of the runway. And more than one coach will worry whether a night in the Big Apple will sour seasonal profits.

title: Nicola C. Seibert Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elvin Seibert of Millbrook, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nicola Christina Seibert, to Peter Draper Coddington, son of Mrs. William D. Coddington, also of Milibrook, and the late Mr. Coddington.

title: Weizman to Address Dinner
description: Ezer Weizman, Defense Minister of Israel and the chief architect of its air force, will speak at a dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on Feb. 4 marking the opening of a yearlong celebration of that nation's 30th anniversary. The announcement was made by the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds.

title: New Chief of New York Detectives Plans Improvements in His Bureau
description: New York City's new chief of detectives said last week that changes would be made in the detective operation, once the Police Department's most prestigious branch but now fragmented and demoralized by recurring controversies.

title: Neil Tod Hauck Fianc Of Ann Frances Banks
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard V. Banks of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Frances Banks, to Neil Tod Hauck, son of William Hauck of Wantagh, L. I., and the late Mrs. Hauck.

title: N. Carolina 85, Maryland 71
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jari. 21 .(AP)PhirFord, a guard, scored 23 poMtS today to lead the University ot'North Carolina to an 8571 victory over Maryland. in an Atlantic Coast Conferenoe basketball game.

title: Soviet Dooms Drunken Driver
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (Reuters)A truck driver who killed eight persons while drunk has been sentenced to death, the tradeunion newspaper Trud has reported. The paper said the driver, Valentin Shimko, had been drinking wine all day before running into a line waiting for a bus last June 7.

title: Blood Supply Better, But More Is Needed
description: The Greater New York Blood Program, the major supplier of blood  to hospitals in New York City, New Jersey, Long Island and seven counties in the Hudson Valley, reported yesterday that scores of people had gone to its center at 310 Last 87th Street to donate blood.

description: WALTER KERR

description: HARTFORD

description: FRANKLIN

title: Holy Shroud to be Displayed At Catholic Cathedral in Italy
description: TURIN, Italy, Jan, 21 (AP)The Holy Shroud, venerated as Christ's burial cloth, will be put on public display later this year for only the fourth time this century, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Turin said today.

title: Carter Plan for Helping Bronx Due Next Month
description: Jack Watson, the White House aide who is coordinating plans for Federal Assistance for the South Bronx, said last week that the main elements of a strategy to revitalize that blighted section would be in place by early February.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: STAPLE gun is a handy tool that can be used for many different jobs around the houseupholstering, putting up ceiling tile, securing small wires, installing insulation and vapor barriers, etc.but also has other uses that owners of these multipurpose tools often don't think about.

title: Why Lilco Isn't Underground
description: MINEOLA THE vulnerability of the Long Island Lighting Company to severe weather was never more evident than when more than one million people, or onethird of the Island's population, were without electrical power at the height of last week's ice storm. And since 90 percent of the utility's lines are above ground and continue to be exposed to the whims of nature, as well as manmade disasters, the utility and its 890,000 customerseach representing 3.4 personsremain as vulnerable as they were before the storm, despite the restoration of service at the cost of several million dollars and thousands of manhours.

title: Headliners
description: Time hasn't subdued Harry Bridges, the justretired president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union. The fiery unionist, branded an undesirable alien and Communist by the House of Representatives and the target of attempts by three Presidents to have him deport. ed, cheerfully told an audience at the National Portrait Gallery last week that 95 percent of the evidence against me was absolutely true. But, said the 76-year-old Australianborn Marxist, I didn't happen to be affiliated with the Communist Party. Even so, Mr. Bridges admitted accepting Communist aid during the general strike which closed down San Francisco for three days in 1939. We wasn't fancy, he said, we'd take money from anywhere. Mr. Bridges also had no apologies for his conduct as a union boss. Talking about the 1961 modernization and mechanization contract that reversed a centuryold tradition of union resistance technological change, and pushed other unions into similar accommodation, but which cost thousands of jobs, he said: In classical Marxist terms it could be called a sellout.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 22, 1978

title: Robin B. Stone Sets Nuptials
description: The engagement of Robin Barbara Stone to Gary Lee Sellers has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stone of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the on of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Sellers of New Orleans.

title: U. S. Is Urged to Approve Tennis Tour of Cuba
description: The Association of Tennis Professionals has asked the State Department for permission to send a team of players to Cuba for a goodwill tour.

title: Miss Licata, Librarian, Wed to William Marano
description: Leonora T. Licata, chief librarian at the American Paper Institute in New York, was married yesterday to William J. Marano, project administrator of the Clean Fuels Institute at the City College of New York. The Rev. Richard M. Lewkiewicz performed the ceremony in the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: 2 Doctors Advise Influenza Victims To Avoid Hospitals
description: Individuals who get influenza and have no other chronic medical problems should not be admitted to a hospital unless complications develop, according to a medical journal report by two public Health Service doctors.

title: Spain PardonS Basque Guerrillas Who Killed Premier With a Bomb
description: MADRID, Jan, 20 (Reuters)The Spanish Government today pardoned the Basque murderers of Prime Minister Luis Carrero Blanco, who was killed by bomb in 1973.

title: R. A. W aller to Wed Ellen Lurie, Student
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Lurie of Hartsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Susan Lurie, to Robert Allen Waller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Waller of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: The Ultimate in Track and Field Is Knowing You Did Your Best
description: There is no freer, no purer, no more elegant athletic competition than track and field. It is more than just man against man, more than just man against the elements, more than just a romp on the green. It is the intensity of competition unfettered by special protective clothing, special equipment, a ball or a net. It does not require brute strength as much as finesse and timing. It is not artificial; it is perhaps the most natural of all athletic contests.

title: A Company That Feeds on Fast Food
description: CHICAGOA fast two cents Is better than a slow dime, says S. Thomas Clements, a vice president of the MarlinBrower Company.

title: A Man of Many Parts
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVER

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE weather outside may be frightful, but as far as the book business is concerned, it might as well be spring. Though it is still January, the spring book season - which runs from February through June - is now upon us. With the publishers chorusing their usual optimistic spring song, the critics practicing their sour notes and the public lending half an ear, we'll forge ahead with a rundown of the highlights of the season.

title: Search for a Just Society
description: 11 NTIL fairly recently Jewish socialism stood the center of Jewish secular life in both Europe and the United States, radiating a strong moral and social energy. It drew upon strains of mes- sianism that had become secularized; it expressed a yearning for a solidarity with oppressed classes and peoples that, alas, they did not always care to reciprocate; it released a hunger among many Jews for breaking out of the passivity of their traditional past; it became intimately entangled with the brief, sometimes brilliant flare of Yiddish culture during the early decades of this century.

title: From Eastern Europe: A Book and a Man
description: GEORGE KONRAD'S first book, The Case Worker, was a fictive essay built withblocks of grotesque realism: the daily horrors of the lives of, the poor and helpless, the deficient, abandoned, crazed and rejected. It ended with a few pages of litany and prayer in which the narrator, a welfare worker as a Christfigure, invited his clients to his office: let all those come who want to; one of us will talk, the other will listen; at least we shall be together. A powerful work, The Case Worker seemed blend of the Miller of Tropic of Capricorn, the Celine of Deafh on the Installment Plan, the West of Miss Lonelyhearts and the Sartre Nausea. Its thesis was that our urban culture grows more vacant of humane values in proportion to our power to proceis masses of people through, a machinery designed to give them wellbeing. Because its hero knows that there's limit to what one can suffer (thoughnone to the creation of suffering) he resolves the dilemma by dedicating himself to the insane and idiotic. The idiot child, the ultimate test of The Case Worker, knows nothing of his sacrifice. Ideologically, such sorrowing pessimism must have been shocking to the archons of a totalitarian socialist society, which both enslaves through its dogma of progress and is enslaved by it as well.

title: Suspicion Festers in Prison Deaths of German Terrorists
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Jan. 17Three months after the deaths in Stammhelm Prison here of three West German terrorist leaders, doubts remain about what the Government has said were suicides rigged by the victims to look like murders.

title: Births.
description: Chuck and Amy Lee (nee Schwartz) Spielman of Manhasset, N.Y., happily announce the birth of Laura Anne's brother Eric Matthew, born 1/16/78. The proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Schwartz of Great Neck, N.Y., Palm Beach, Fla,, and Mr. and Mrs. Irving Spielman of New York City; proud great grandparents are Mrs. Frances Schwartz Of Miami, Fla., and Mr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Spear of klaiertdale, Fla,

title: `Nuclear Dump Debate Heats Up in Carlsbad, N.M.
description: CARLSBAD, N. M.Carlsbad, already famous for its spectacularly beautiful limestone caverns, is about to become known for a few more holes in the ground.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHILE the big party season may be on the wane for many of us, as far as the partyrental professionals are concerned this is merely the time to move the punch bowl to the back of the storage area.

title: A Woman's Turn to Serve
description: LARCHMONT ENTERING the highechelon male establishment of the Eastern Tennis Association does not frighten Barbara Williams. As the first woman to be elected president of the organization, which governs the sport in the New YorkNew Jersey-Connecticut area, Mrs. Williams said:

title: Judging the F.B.I.
description: Some Monday soon, the top brass of the Justice Department will gather for its weekly staff lunch, someone will say, Judge, and three heads will turn. Attorney General Bell is a former Federal Appeals Court judge. So is Solicitor General Wade McCree. And so is William Webster, the Administration's new choice to be Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The fact prompts a lawyer friend to raise a question. Without meaning the slightest criticism of Judge Webster, he asks: it healthy for the Administration so frequently to raid the Federal judiciary for executive branch appointments?

title: Bulls and Bears In North Salem
description: THE five speculators had never laid eyes on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange before last Monday. A few months earlier, few of them had ever heard of ticker symbols, tender offers, shortselling or split shares. Yet these high school students came into a market windfall, although they'll have a hard time spending it.

title: Legal Building Blocks
description: WITHIN the next few months, the Legislature will have to decide whether or not to move the University of Con necticut Law School from its present inadequate facilities on West Hartford's Asylum Avenue to largely unused buildings at the old Hartford Seminary campus two miles away.

title: Freeing Foster Children for Adoption
description: COREY is a gentle and athletic 12-year-old who lived in six foster homes before he was 7. Although adoption was encouraged, Corey was a hyperactive black child considered difficult to place. He has lived in a children's home since 1972, but says he would like to be adopted.

title: CETA Spells Action in Morris
description: ONE of the goals of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA), passed by Congress in 1973 to reduce unemployment, was the correlation and coordination of effort between prime sponsors and the educational community. Under the eve of John E. Radvany, deputy assistant commissioner in the division of vocational education, New Jersey Department of Education, the interaction between this agency and Morris County exemplifies that goal.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFE THEATER, Franklin and Fremont Streets, Bloomfield'A Hatful of Rain. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Also, Krapp's Last Tape and The - Zoo Story. Sundays, 2 P.M. (through Feb. 19) $2.9044.90; students and the elderly, $1.9043.90. (201) 4297662. Bloomfield Col lege, Westminster Theater.

title: Mary O'Neill Engaged
description: Mrs. John P. O'Neill of Short Hills, N.J., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Mary Moore O'Neill, to Wayne Spencer Natunen, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Oliver Natunen of Summit, N.J. Miss O'Neill is a daughter also of the late Mr. O'Neill.

title: Bigger Prizes May Give Pro Bowl Changed Style
description: Apart from watching the world's best football players perform their skills, fans who tune in tomorrow night's 28th annual Pro Bowl game (Channel 7, P.M.) may see some spontaneous mayhem on the part of spirited defensive players like Isiah Robertson, Cliff Harris or Bill Bergey.

title: Park Ave. Druggist Is Shot 3 Times:, He May Have Wounded Assailant
description: A 60-year-old pharmacist working alone in his store on the Upper East Side yesterday afternoon was shot three times by a man in his 20's who apparently was looking for drugs, the police reported.

title: Albany Study Questions Benefits of Offshore Oil
description: An 18month study released last week by New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation says that environmental risksespecially oil spills that could disrupt profitable recreation and fishing industries might outweigh any economic and energy benefits from drilling for oil and natural gas off the Eastern Seaboard. Offshore drilling has been one of the; most controversial environmental issues the region has faced. Although 10 oil companies paid a total of $1.1 billion to the Federal Government in 1976 for leases to drill in the Atlantic, no drilling has been done yet.

title: Lenore Engdahl in Piano Recital
description: THOUGH the unsuitability of the piano at Carnegie Recital Hall has long been apparent, it is rare to hear its deficiencies exposed as glaring as in Lenore Engdahl's recital Saturday afternoon. In fact, one was left with a clearer impression of the piano than of the olaver.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Two basic strategies underlie President Carter's package of tax cuts and tax reforms that would add up to a net tax reduction of $25 billion for individuals and businesses if Congress accepts it. One strategy (the one that is explicit in the President's tax message to Congress) is economic: a plan designed to keep the economy. moving uphill at a moderate pace of 4 to 5 percent a year, so that unemploymept would come down to between 51/2 and 6 percent by the end of 1979, almost two years from now.

title: Youths Get Surprise Instead of Getaway
description: BORDENTOWN, Jan. 22 (UPI)When two teenagers jjumped into their getaway car after allegedly robbing a; motel of $2,000 this weekend, the police said, the two youths received quite. a surprise, Instead of their driver, they. found a state trooper sitting behind the wheel, according to the police.

title: New York's Best Public Schools Defy Racial Stereotyping
description: The best public school in New York City has (choose one): (A) An almost totally white, mostly middleclass student body, and a traditional curriculum that stresses the basics.

title: ArmsSale Planners to Propose Jet,Deal for Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Government officials, who are in the last stages of putting together the Carter Administration's armssales program for this year, are preparing .a proposal for the first sale of American fighter aircraft to Egypt.

title: Staten Islanders, With Complaints About City, Help Each Other Dig
description: Staten Islanders, many of them convinced they were the forgotten borough of the storm cleanup as well as the largest iceberg in New York Harbor, spent yesterday digging each other out of their snowbound homes and cars while bracing themselves for the floods they knew were sure to follow.

title: Stow Wengenroth Is Dead at 71; Artist Was Known for Lithographs
description: Stow Wengenroth, one of the nation's leading lithographers, died yesterday of emphysema at the Addison Gilbert Hospital in Gloucester, Mass. He was 71 years old and had lived since 1974 at 25 Parker Street in Rockport, Mass.

title: Jersey Is Losing Medicaid Money
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22New Jersey is losing tens of millions of dollars in Federal assistance for its Medicaid expenses because of an outdated reimbursement formula, according to an analysis prepared for a coalition of 204 members of Congress from 16 Northeastern and Middle Western states.

title: FORTUNE TELLERS SEE PROFITS IN NEW YORK
description: The elliptical, lighted white sign in the, storefront window at 403: East 70th Street promises that Mrs. Stella will tell your past, present and future. What the, sign neglects to say is that Mrs. Stella may also be hazardous to your wealth.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Aside from all the pregame activity, the Super Bowl itself seemed to go on and on. Was it really much longer than most football games?

title: Dismissal of Marston Draws Attention To Pattern of Corruption in Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21The involvement of President Carter in this week's dismissal of David W. Marston as the United States Attorney here has focused new attention on Pennsylvania politics, which has been marked in recent years by scores of corruption indictments and convictions reaching from the policeman on the street to the United States House of Representatives.

title: Senior British Aides Predict Accords This Year :in Southern Africa
description: LONDON, Jan: 22 The belief that this will be the year of decision in southern Africa has taken hold at the highest levels of the British Government. Senior ministers have concluded that for better or worse, arrangements for the transfer of power to black governments in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa are likely to be completed well before the end of 1978, ending more than a decade of dispute and delay;

title: TV: Roots: One Year Later Examines Impact of 8Day Special
description: A SENSE OF DEJA VU hangs over Roots: One Year Later, a David L. Wolper production that ABCTV will be showing at 8 tonight. Although it purports to be an examination of the impact or Roots, last year's eightday television epic made from Alex Haley's prize-winning tracing of his family tree, One Year Later is really an hourlong trailer, a blurb in the best tradition of a film we have all already seen.

title: Some MidwestRailroad,s Find It Pays to Diversify
description: CHICAGOThe recently. .publicized problems of the railroad industry in the Middle West are certainly not, new ones. In fact, perennial Management headaches led most of the region's ran companies to diversify into other business years ago. Now those moves are paying off as the prospect of slimmeddown rail system becomes highly likely,

title: TV: Defection of Simas Kudirka
description: UT of a truelife incident involving the defection of Lithuanian sailor from a Soviet ship in November 1970, Bruce Feldman has fashioned an intermittently interesting script that recapitulates that painful incident: ,The Defection of Simas Kudirka, which CBSTV will carry tonight from 9 to 11.

title: Sadat's Drive And Its Result
description: CAIRO, Jan. 22After nine weeks of hope and drama starting with President Sadat's visit to Jerusalem; the Middle East appears to have reverted to its customary state of deadlock and tension. Israel and the most accomodating of

title: HUMPHREY RECALLED IN GIFT TO NEEDIEST
description: The memory of Hubert H. Humphrey was evoked by a contributor to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, who said the late Senator's name meant many good things to many people.

title: Old Tennis Balls Get New Life
description: Almost every sportinggoods outlet, department store and pro shop offers pumps to restore the pressure to tennisball cans, injectors to revive dead tennis balls and other devices for keeping tennis balls fresh and lively. The prices range from less than $2 to as much as $40.

title: Miss Wenzel Wins, Increases Cup Lead
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Jan. 22 (AP) Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein won the women's World Cup slalom race today and increased her lead to 25 points over Annemarie ProellMoser of Austria in the overall standing after 12 races.

title: Other N.B.A. Games
description: BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP)The Seattle SuperSonics built a 6149 lead at halftime behind the. shooting of Gus Williams and John Johnson, then held off a Boston rally In the third period and triumPhed, 103.92, over the Celtics today.

title: Budget Office, While Guarding the Federal Purse, Also Plays a Key Role sub on Major. Policy Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22James R. Schlesinger, the Energy Secretary, wanted to build a billionbarrel oil reserve by 1983 instead of 1985, the present tar- get. But the Office of Management and Budget challenged the proposal, arguing. to President Carter that there was no need for such an acceleration and that the additional spending would aggravate Mr. Carter's budget management problem, already substantial.

title: Police Roar Into 1920's Speakeasy And Capture a Moment of Nostalgia
description: BERGENFIELD, Jan. 22The police raised a speakeasy operating. in the Bergenfield Library today, bringing simulated cries of concern from some of the town's leading citizens, who were dressed as flappers and their beaus and seemed to have danced and romanced out of the pages of a John Held Jr. sketchbook.

title: The President Goes Fishing
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 22 (AP) President Carter, who is spending the weekend off the Georgia coast, went fishing today with two friends from this island community, Carlton Hcks, an optometrist, and Jim Bishop, a lawyer. The President, ,who is staying at the Musgrove Plantation;. an estate owned by the tobacco heir Smith Bagley, plans to return to the White House tomorrow night.

title: SAMUEL J. RAPPAPORT
description: Samuel J. Rappaport, a specialist in realestate lam/ for 40 years, died Thursday at Long Island Jewish Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Baldwin Harbor. L.I.

title: ORDAIN HOMOSEXUALS, CHURCH REPORT SAYS
description: A special study group of the 2.6-millionmember United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. has recommended that the church adopt a policy that would permit the ordination of practicing homosexuals who otherwise meet requirements for the clergy.

title: Syria and Libya Sign Accord
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 22 (Reuters). Syria and Libya signed an agreement on economic cooperation here last night that proovides for the creation of a joint investment company with $100 million in capital, officials said. The agreement also provides for cooperation in the fields of industry, agriculture and trade.

title: Watson, Floyd Are Leaders In Crosby Golf by a Stroke
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 22The cavalry charge is a hackneyed description of a closelybunched field in a golf tournament, but the jam at the end of the third round of the Crosby National ProAm today was created when the leaders spun around and started galloping in full retreat over the last few holes.

title: Leo Burnett Shifts TopLevel Officers
description: Howard C. Shank, 56 years old, has been named president and chief .operating officer of the worldwide  Leo Burnett Company as,C. R. (lack) Kopp, 56, moves up to chairman but remains chief executive.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Trans-Atlantic

title: Bayi Talks: His Sport, His Culture
description: EVER since he burst onto the international scene in 1972 by running his first mile in minutes 52 seconds, Filbert Bayi has been a source of fascination in track and field. He was Tanzania's first competitivesports treasure. When it came to setting a fast pace in middledistance race, nobody did it better than Bayi.

title: 72% in Israel Back Settlements in Sinai
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 22A majority of Israelis are opposed to the idea of returning Israeli settlements in northern Sinai to Egyptian sovereignty even though they would remain under Israeli administration, according to a public opinion poll published here today.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1978

title: `Normal Monday Due as Snow Hangs On
description: Armies of commuters. were .urged: to forget cars; take publie transportation and leave early this morning to get to work through the. remnants of the decade's biggest snowstorm in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Illinois Man Guilty in Father's Death
description: EAST ALTON, Ill., Jan. 22 (UPI)A real estate dealer frpm Bethalto, Ill., was convicted last night of killing his father with poisoned doughnuts in a plot to acquire his property. George W. Hanei, 56 years old, was accused of giving his father, Herman, doughnuts containing thallium, a metallic substance used for killing rats.

title: Knicks Triumph, 143-141 n Overtime
description: DENVER, Jan. 22Willis Reed got thrown out of the game, Dan Issel of the Nuggets made a foul shot with two seconds to play in the fourth quarter, Earl Monroe did not get free when it counted. And it all helped the Knicks beat Denver, 143.141, in overtime today and end a five-game losing streak.

title: Complacency on Abortion: A Warning to Women
description: At a weekend teachin to commemorate the fifth anniversary of the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, an overflow crowd of 350 women were urged to rejoin the abortion struggle or see their rights further eroded.

title: L.I. Jewish Community is Still Hopeful on a Mideast Peace Accord
description: EAST MEADOW, Li, Jan, 20The smartly dressed woman meeting her grown daughter from Manhattan in front of Waldbaum's superniarket here said she believed that President Anwar elSadat of Egypt was still sincere in seeking peace with Israel.. A student at East Meadow High School said the same thing. So did the young man in charge of periodicals at the East Meadow Public Library and the middleaged president of the East Meadow Jewish Center.

title: Yokohama uietly Becoming japan's  Second Best City
description: YOKOHAMA, JapanIt may occur toddy, tomorrow or in. a few week's.. Perhaps it already happened yesterday But one of these days a farmer will move into town, a baby will be born or two newlyweds will settle here. At that moment, quietly and without fanfare, Osaka will be displaced for the first time in almost three centuries as Japan's second largest city.

title: Bruce Stephen Graeber Marries Judith D. Ross
description: Judith Deborah Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Ross of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Bruce Stephen Graeber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Isacque Graeber of Forest Hills, Queens. The ceremony was performed at the Cotillion caterers in Brooklyn by Rabbis Norman Twersky and Menachem Rottenbere.

title: KOCH FIELDS QUERIES IN RADIO BROADCAST

title: Entremont in Dual Role With Vienna Ensemble
description: PHILIPPE ENTREMONT, the French pianist, has been building a parallel career as a conductor in recent years. Like most pianists with such ambitions, he has been moving into the new field cautiously, concentrating for the most. part on doubling as soloist and conductor in 18thcentury keyboard works. Mr. Entremont appeared in that duel capacity yesterday at Alice Tully Hall with the Vienna Chamber Orchestra, whose music director he became in 1975.

title: Mr. Carter's Economic Refrain
description: The proposal for a $25billion tax cut is vintage tiscat policy; designed to shore up the economy late this year but not to tackle inflation at the same time, as it might have. The pledge to shrink the size of the Federal Government and to chase the holy grail of the balanced budget is a hoary :proPositiOn. The stabs at. tax reform resemble those of his predecessors and are mere shadows of the sweeping,changes once proMised. And the talk misguided regulation as .a major source of inflation has enchanted college sophomores for decades.

description: Farmers in south Georgia are as hospitable as those elsewhere, or more so. Thus, there is always chance that a visitor politely asking permission will be able to hunt quail. Without good dogs, however, such hunting is bound to be difficult and probably will not be very successful.

title: Departing Prosecutor Denies Report on Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (UPI)David W. Marston said today that he had no plans for the immediate future and that he would not run for lieutenant governor of Pennsylvania.

title: Medical Camps. Set Up in India To Treat Remote Tribal Villagers
description: AMARKANTAK, IndiaA couple and their 10-year-old son, all suffering from serious ailments, have trekked here from a remote jungle village for their first visit to a doctor in their lives.

title: Advertising
description: Burger King, the country's second largest fastfood chain, on Friday started a major attempt to buy the love of young America with $4 million worth of plastic gimcracks and gewgaws, and .a magic king named Burger.

title: Gerri Griffin Sings Gospel
description: GERRI GRIFFIN, whose used to be featured in Bubbling Brown Sugar and is now on her own as a cabaret artist, has the vocal equipment and finesse to do something really memorable. Her roots are in gospel music, and when she wants to call on that kind of power, it is there in abundance. But much of the time she restrains her big voice and negotiates melodic twists and turns softly, with an easy, fluid grace. Her control of dynamics is impressive, and she blends superbly with her backup singers, especially in her duets with Wayne Garfield.

title: Philharmonia Virtuosi Perform
description: THE Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York under the direction of their conductor, Richard Kapp, gave the second of their three Alleluja concerts yesterday afternoon at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association. The rather unusual title for this series apparently rerers to tne IIICKname of Haydn's Symphony No. 30 which concluded the program. Or perhaps the Virtuosi are simply in a celebratory mood because their new record, Greatest Hits of 1720, is the country's bestselling classical disk at the moment.

title: Vance Expecting Israel and Egypt To Renew Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance returned today from an overseas trip expecting Egypt and Israel to resume negotiations within a week to 10 days despite their recent sharp words.

title: Bridge:; Stayman's Team ?; In Swiss Team Title ?; North Jumps to Three Spades
description: A quintet headed by Sam Stayman of New York andincluding George Tornay, Saul Bronstein, Jean Prosnitz, all of New York, and Michael Rosmarin of Roslyn,, L. I., led the field of 34 teams into the final session of the _Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton Hotel last night.

title: The Criteria? Your Needs
description: Take a moment to evaluate your needs. Will you need lessons? All Y's and most clubs offer them. Expect to spend about $10 per hourly lesson.

title: 2 Watchung Churches Sign an Ecumenical Covenant
description: WATCHUNG Jan. 22The leaders of a 131-year-old Roman Catholic Church and an interdenominational Protestant congregation signed an agreement tonight to share their facilities, prayer services and scholarships for the next year:

title: Dr Ryan and .Respii
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Ground Rules for Offshore Oil
description: The House of Representatives will have an opportunity this week to help resolve an issue it has ducked for too longthe regulation of oil and gas development in the waters off shore.

title: LaVerne Muto, Editor, Wed to Stephen Levine
description: The marriage of LaVerne Dagras Muto, daughter of Mrs. William Dagras of Cullom. Ill., and the late Mr. Dagras, to Stephen Samuel Levine, an architect in New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., took place yesterday at Windows on the World at the World Trade Center. Appellate Court Justice Milton Molten performed the ceremony.

title: Critic's Notebook: A Great MovieIf It Comes Out
description: FROM A Star Is Born to Gable and Lombard, the woods are thick with movies about movie stars. But it's unusual to find Hollywood exploring its own power to hold moviegoers in thrall, or examining the complicated effects that hero worship can have on a fan. September 30, 1955, which stars Richard Thomas and centers on the death of James Dean, explores this unexpected subject so intelligently, and yet so comfortably, that it will surely turn out to be one of the best films of the year; if Universal ever releases it. But that's an other story.

title: CENSUS PROJECTIONS SHOW HOUSE CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)If population patterns shown in a Census Bureau study released today continue; nine seats in the House will have to be reapportioned after the 1980 official census, move that would give more seats to Sunbelt states while dropping three of New York's.

title: California Democratic Activists Seek More Power in Party Affairs
description: MILLBRAE, Calif., Jan. 22A thousand California Democratic activists met here this weekend to urge party reforms that would give volunteer workers like themselves more power at the expense of the elected officials who now control party affairs.

title: FOUR FIREMEN INJURED IN BLAZE IN ENGLEWOOD
description: ENGLEWOOD, Jan. 22 (AP)An apartmentbuilding fire yesterday forced at least 32 families into subfreezing weather and kneedeep snow.

title: Snow Brings Red Ink to Businesses
description: Sunday is always the big day for the merchants on Orchard Street, the heart of Manhattan's Lower East Side discount district. But not yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: FIRST NORTH AMERICAN TCHAIKOVSKY PIANO COMPETITION WINNER'S CONCERT, Carnegie Hall, YOURI EGOROV, pianist, Alice Tully Hail, Lincoln Center, 8.

title: The Water. Board and Its Many Upstate Tributaries
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20New York City's Board of Water Supplywhich Mayor Koch wants to abolish as an oldstyle, political plum tree that ficuts his drive for fiscal austerityincludes a littleknown network of jobs that reaches far beyond the limits of New York City.

title: U. S., AFTER A LAPSE, BEGINS ENFORCEPIIENT OF BANK SECRECY ACT
description: WASHINGTONThe Treasury Department, after six years of inactivity, has begun to enforce the Bank Secrecy. Act, hailed by many at the: time- of its enactment in 1970 as a crucial weapon in the fight against whitecollar crime.

title: French AntiGermanism
description: PARISHas antiGerman feeling in France reached a point of critical intensity? Certainly less so than in Italy, where there is a much stronger wave of antiGermanism. Indeed, it is ques- tionable whether there is any such wave in France. The majority of the press, both in Paris and even more so in the provinces, has resumed the balanced tone it had abandoned for a . moment early last fall. Even the most emotionally critical Parisian newspapers now also publish reasoned articles. Radio and television and publicopinion pollslikewise. confirm. that FrancoGerman relations are not heading toward a crisis.

title: ITALIAN REDS PRESS BID FOR CABINET ROLE
description: ROME, Jan. 22The Communist Party held thousands of mass rallies and small. of meetings up and down Italy today to press its deniand for direct participation in a national emergency government.

title: yes Are on ormn
description: MANHASSET, L.I.

title: FREDA UTLEY, 79
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Freda Utley, a journalist, author and lecturer on the Far East and on Communist politics, died yesterday after a stroke at Georgetown University Hospital . here. She was 79 years old.

title: BAM Theater to Open With Devil's Disciple
description: George Bernard Shaw's The Devil's Disciple will open the BAM Theater Company's second season on Feb. in the Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Export Ban on Monkeys Poses Threat to Research
description: Hundreds of biomedical research projects using rhesus monkeys as standins for human beings will probably have to be stopped or cut back drastically after April 1, when India, the world's largest supplier of the monkeys, says it will stop exporting them.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In a recent article it was noted that the principal chefs of a kitchenthose known as chefs de cuisinesometimes refer to their colleaguesthose who work as pastry chefsin a disparaging manner. They call them kitchen chemists because most of the ingredients used in any good patisserie are, for very sound and logical reasons, weighed carefully befors they are turned into genoises, prtits fours, assorted gateaux and so on.

title: Deaths
description: ALGERMartin Joseph, age 87, of Tucson, Arizona and Lake Placid, N.Y. on January 20th alter a long illness. Survived by a daughter, Sybil Alger Pickett of Bronxville, N.Y., a son, Martin J.Alger, Jr. of Watertown, N.Y., 7 grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. Memorial service in Tucson at a later datell. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to the St.E11zabeth of Hungary Clinic, Tucson, . Arizona.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Jan. 22 (Reuters)Leaders of France's Gaullist Party, in government for the last 20 years, today closed ranks as opinion polls predicted a leftwing victory in the general elections in March.Former Prime Minister Jacques Chaban Delmas and the man who helped to defeat him in the 1974 presidential elections, Jacques Chirac, the present Gaullist leader, shook hands publicly today at meeting of 1,500 party officials.

title: Sarbu in New York Violin Debut
description: EUGEN SARBU'S New York debut Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was an extremely satisfying affair. Mr. Sarbu is a 27-year-old Rumanian violinist who has studied with, among others, Ivan Galamian and Nathan Milstein, and has won a number of noteworthy competitions. His recital was accompanied with deferential skill by Gordon Back.

title: Many Women Are Displeaed By LegaI victory; Separate but Equal; Something Different; Did I Hurt You?
description: The latest skirmish in the sports battle of the sexes could lead to girls going to the mat with boys in scholastic wrestling, to female tackles on football teams and to coed basketball squads.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 3 Pianists Qualify for Moscow
description: THREE YOUNG pianists, including a Brazilian woman student at Juilliard, qualified yesterday at Town Halpin the final round of a tryout for the Moscow Tchaikovsky Competition, to be held in the Soviet capital in June. The contest for young pianists is held every four years, The first North American International Tchaikovsky Competition in New York was sponsored by the department of music and music education of New. York University, starting Jan. 13 with 20 competitors.

title: Nancy Ann Kraner Is Bride Of Henry Silverman, Banker
description: Nancy Ann Kramer of New York was married yesterday to Henry R. Silverman, chairman of the Silverman Equities Corporation, investment bankers. Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Temple EmanuEl in Purchase, N.Y., performed the ceremory: in New York at the home of Gladys Rackmil.

title: HERMAN SWARZMAN
description: Herman Swarzman, a founder and president of Rainbow Shops, a chain of 36 women'swear retail stores in the New York City area, died Thursday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 75 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Iona at Fairfield, 7:30 P.M.; Morgan State at Fairleigh Dickinson, 8 P.M.; Vermont at Hofstra, 8 P.M.; Gannon at St. Francis, 8 P.M.

description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting. Quail in Carter Country
description: DAWSON, GA.

title: Jewels Is Danced
description: DO EVEN very fine ballets outlive their time? It is hard to think this question would have to be asked of Jewels, the 1967 ballet by George Balanchine that became an instant hit and remained the New York City Ballet's perennial sellout over the past decade.

title: MARGARETT M'KEAN
description: Margarett Sargent McKean, sculptor, artist and collector of works of art, died Saturday at a nursing home in Manchester, Mass. She was 85 years old and lived in Pride's Crossing, Mass.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1978

title: Transit Talks: 50Cent Fare at Stake
description: Transit negotiations in New York City, due to begin next month, will have dou??edged significance this year because of their bearing on bus and subway operations and the future of the 50cent fare, and because of their potential effect oh the city's bargaining with its unions.

title: Market Place
description: Consolidated Edison; which shocked the investment. world. in April 1974 when it eliminated its 45cent,quarterly dividend, has since restored, the payout; at a higher rate, and may increaSe the dividend again tomorrow..

title: Borodin Piano Trio Makes Local Debut
description: FOR MANY YEARS the Borodin Piano Trio has been one of Russia's most celebrated chamber ensembles but in the West it has been known only by reputation and through recordings. Since Rostislav Du- binsky, also once first violinist of the Borodin Quartet; and Luba Edlina, the trio's pianist, are husband and wife, they never received permission to per,. form together outside the Soviet Union:

title: Month's Supplies Brought by Capsule To Orbiting Salyut
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (UPI)The Soviet Union accomplished the world's first unmanned space supply mission today, docking a shuttle capsule to an orbiting space laboratory occupied by two Soyuz 26 astronauts.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY Trans-Atlantic

title: Steering a Middle Course
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The budget that President Carter sent to Congress today reflects the political calculation that the success of his Presidency, especially by 1980, will ride primarily on the performance of the economy rather than on his sticking strictly to his campaign promises.

title: CARTER ASKS $500 BILLION BUDGET; SEEKS HIGHEMPLOYMENT ECONOMY AND OFFERS FEW NEW PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Carter sent his first budget to Congress today, presenting a $500 billion plan for 1979 that emphasized the limits to what Government could do to cure social problems.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23Controversial regulations to protect 500,000 acres of the Pine Barrens became effective this afternoon. The state's Environmental

title: Copters Supply Cape Town Tankers
description: CAPE TOWNWhen Spanish crewmen alioard the Frenchregistered supertanker Esso Flandre decided to buy ,a medicine ball to keep in trim on their sixweek journey from Le liavre to Abu Dhabi, they didn't wait for the next port of call. Instead, they radio telephoned a ship's chandler here and had him send one out by helicdpter.

title: GOLD ADVANCES $2 AS DOLLAR SLUMPS
description: The price of gold jumped $2 an ounce or more in major bullion trading centers yesterday, while the value of the dollar continued to decline in Europe and New York, The Associated Press reported.

title: $500,000. Harness Race Set
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 23Meadowlands Race Track today announced dts plans to stage the world's richest harness race, the $500,000 Meadowlands Pace, on Aug. 3 for 3-year-old pacers.

title: More Hair Dyes Linked to Cancer
description: Four additional ingredients of hair dyes; have been shown to cause cancer in animals in feeding tests sponsored by the National Cancer Institute, according to testimony before Congress yesterday.

title: Senate in Albany Votes to Change Auto Photo Rules
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23After weeks of attempts at compromise, the Republicancontrolled State Senate voted today to repeal a controversial State Insurance Department requirement for photographic inspections of automobiles being insured for theft or damage.

title: Begin Assails Cairo Press Hatred
description: JERUSALEM, Jan, 23Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that the Israeli military delegation would not return to Cairo for negotiations until the Egyptian press ceased its hatred and incitement to hatred against the Jewish people.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: SOFT TREASURE Amish quilting is spotlighted today through Feb. 10. Twenty rare specimens of the craft, representing the handiwork of Amish women in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Kansas, are displayed at the Manhattan Savings Bank, Madison Avenue at 47th Street. The exhibition also offers photographs of Amish settlements and various artifacts. Hours are 8:30 A.M. to 3 P.M., Mondays through Fridays.

title: $301,000 JOB PROGRAM IS SUSPENDED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday tne suspension of another antipoverty program grant, this one a $301,000 youth employment program operated by the Central Queens Community Corporation.

title: Social Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Carter's budget for the next fiscal year places increased emphasis on Government aid to disadvantaged young people.

title: Weeb Ewbank Goes to Canton
description: He always looked more like a grandfather than a football coach. Sometimes he even acted more like a grandfather. And perhaps that was Weeb Ewbank's secret. In one of Joe Namath's first trainingcamp practices with the New York Jets in 1965, the $427,000 quarterback let go a long pass that spiraled far downfield beyond Don Maynard and spun off the grass. Incomplete. In his waddling walk, his green baseball cap tilted on his round head, Weeb Ewbank approached his celebrated rookie and said softly: You don't have to show me your arm. If you couldn't throw, you wouldn't be here. Joe Namath nodded. But it wasn't until the Jets were about to astonish the Baltimore Colts, 167, in Super Bowl III that Joe Namath realized what Weeb Ewbank had meant to his development as a quarterback.

title: I.T.Q. Changes Its Game to Regai ower in Tennis
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.. Jan. 23The International Tennis Federation, in an attempt to overcome a loss of power and prestige, has shifted tactics to strenghten its position with players and tournament promoters.

title: Highlights of Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Following are the highlights of President Carter's budget for the fiscal year 1979:

title: Summer Programs Set at State Theater
description: The Nederlander Organization, theatrical corporation that owns or operates 18 theaters in the United States, has leased the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center for eight weeks each in the summers of 1978 and 1979. It has also taken an option for the same periods in 1980 and 1981. The agreement was made with the City Center of Music and Drama, which operates the State Theater.

title: Burden Says Miscount Was Involved in Nomination
description: Attempting to overturn the nomination of Bella S. Abzug in the 18th Congressional District, Carter Burden charged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that mathematical miscount as well as the unauthorized vote of an enrolled Liberal Party official had cost him the nomination.

title: Israeli Settlers Plant Trees at Ancient Shiloh Site
description: TURMOS AYYA, Israeli - occupied West Bank, Jan. 23The handlettered sign in Hebrew on the narrow road winding through this small West Bank Arab village said: To the ceremony.

title: New York First In Federal Aid To States in 77; Three States Move Up; How 3 States Compare; Jersey Figures Explained; How Othe\b}b} States Compared
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21New York State ranked first among the 50 states in Federal dollar aid received in fiscal 1977 and sixth in per capita Federal aid, according to preliminary figures obtained from the Treasury Department.

title: N.B.A. AllStar Coaches Skip AbdulJabbar
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar, Elvin Hayes and John Havlicek will not be in the National Basketball Association AllStar game Feb. 5 at the Omni in Atlanta. The three perennial allstars were passed over in the balloting by the fans and in selections by the conference coaches.

title: Philip Sporn, Electrical Engineer; Led American Power Company
description: Philip Sporn, the former president of the American Power Company and one of this nation's foremost contributors to the field of electrical engineer died yesterday morning on his way to work in Manhattan. Mr. Sporn, who served as a con- sultant to American Power, was 81 years old and lived at 320-East 72d Street.

title: Payton Run Gives N.F.C. 14-13 Victory
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP)Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears recordbreaking runner, pounded in for a 1yard touchdown with 7 minutes 37 seconds left in the game to cap Jim Hart's methodical march that carried the National Conference to a 1413 victory over the American Conference tonight in the National Football League's Pro Bowl game.

title: Liszt Sonata Is Performed By Smetona
description: Vytautas Smetana, a 22-year-old pianist from Cleveland, proved his talent most successfully in the most difficult of the pieces he played in his recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. This was the Liszt B minor Sonata, to which the young artist brought considerable imagination. He was not afraid to slow down or speed up without authorization in the score, in order to stress dramatic content. The results are often persuasive and striking. He met the technical challenges of the Liszt piece well if not with the greatest facility.

title: Stockton Upset In First Round
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (UPI)Tim Gullikson upset the defending champion, Dick Stockton, 36, 76, 64, in the first round of the $225,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championship today.

title: LID ON DOLLAR PURCHASES OF GOLD TO LAPSE JAN. 31
description: PARIS, Jan. 23 (UPI)-7-The world's richest countries have agreed to let an accord lapse on Jan.. 31 that limits the amount of gold they could buy with their surplus dollars; the International Monetary Fund confirmed today.

title: $6 Million Rise Asked For Weather Services
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Federal weather services, which have come under sharp criticism from the public recently because of tardy and inaccurate storm forecasts, are to .receive $210 million in the coming fiscal year, an increase of $6 million.

title: Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 23To celebrate its first year as part of the Federal budget process. the fledgling Department of Energy will increase outlays by 14 percent over the spending level inherited last year from its predecessor agencies.

title: Genet's The Maids Looks at Pain
description: THE MAIDS, by Jean Genet. Production design and direction by Christopher Martin, translation by Bernard Frechtman. At C.S.C. Repertory, 136 East 13th Street.

title: Theories on Man's Dark Deeds Come Out by the Light of the Full Moon
description: To generations of poets and songwriters, tonight is something special for young lovers. There will be a full moon, and earth's nearest neighbor will reveal itself in all its luminous splendor.

title: TOP INDUSTRIALIST KIDNAPPED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Jan. 23A Belgian baron who is one of Europe's leading industrialists was kidnapped near the Arc de Triomphe today after his chauffeurdriven limousine was trapped in an elaborate ambush.

title: Greek Agrees to Talks With Turkish Leader
description: ATHENS, Jan. 23 (AP)Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis has accepted an invitation from Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey to discuss the disputes between the two countries, including the Cyprus issue.

title: Debate Over Pollution Disrupts Country Town in Brazil
description: ANGATUBA, BrazilThe fresh smell of country air dominates this small agricultural and cattleraising community of 5,000 inhabitants, where pine and eucalyptus trees crown the gentle, rolling hills and where corn, rice and beans overflow in the green valleys.

title: Edward S. Pinney, 82, Law Partner
description: Edward Stevenson Pinney, who had been associated for 55 years with Cravath, Swaine & Moore and was a partner in the law firm for 43 years, died Sunday at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: Diana Kacso and Michael Blum in Piano Showcase
description: Two Juilliard. School products who shared first prize in the first North American International Tchaikovsky Piano Competition were provided with a showcase for their talents last night at Carnegie Hall. Before a sizable audi- ence, Diana Kacso performed Liszt's Sonata in B minor and Michael Blum took the solo role in Tchaikovsky's Concerto No. 1 in Bflat minor. The National Orchestral Association, conducted by David Gilbert, accompanied Mr. Blum in the concerto.

title: Ralph E. Winslow, 76, Architect And Former Rensselaer Teacher
description: Ralph E. Winslow, an architect and engineer who taught architecture at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., from 1930 to 1953. died Jan. 14 in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 7 years old and lived at. 10 Forest Park Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: American Indian Loses Appeal Over Alleged Slurs by Teacher
description: The Appellate Division of the Second Judicial Department yesterday ordered an American Indian woman seeking to retain custody of her daughter to send the child back to public school, where teachers, she said, made disparaging remarks about Indians.

title: Notes on People
description: Harold E. Stassen, the perennial officeseeker, is gearing up for yet another campaign. The former threeterm Governor of Minnesota and fourtime unsuccessful candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination said that he would seek the Independent-Republican endorsement for the seat in the United States Senate now held by Wendell Anderson, a Minnesota Democrat. Mr. Stassen, who is 69 years old, has lived near Philadelphia for the last 17 years. He had sought the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Pennsylvania twice.

title: Youri Egorov, Cliburn Contestant, Plays Romantics
description: YOURl EGOROV, planIst. At Alice Tully Hall.

title: TIMBERNIEN FIGHTING MORE REDWOOD AREA
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23Timber industry officials are opening a new offensive against pending legislation to enlarge Redwood National Park, asserting that the move will be inordinately costly and the money could be put to better use on urban parks across the nation.

title: Miscount Involved In Nominating Vote, Burden Tells Court
description: Attempting to overturn the nomination of Bella S. Abzug in the 18th Congressional District, Carter Burden charged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that a mathematical miscount as well as the unauthorized vote of an enrolled Liberal Party offidial had cost him the nomination.

title: Dr. Edward Sampson, Professor at Princeton And Geology Authority
description: Ur. Edward Sampson, professor emeritus of geology at Princeton University, who was a specialist in economic geology, died yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 86 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Abortion Foes Protest in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 23 (AP)Behlnd banners proclaiming, March for Life, thousands of antiabortion demonstrators walked past the White House and up to the Capitol today to push for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortions.

title: JACK O'CONNOR DIES, WRITER ON HUNTING
description: Jack O'Connor, a stylish writer on hunting, guns and the outdoors who was arms and ammunition editor for Outdoor Life magazine for more than 30 years, died of a heart attack aboard the S. S. Mariposa on Friday as it was returning to San Francisco from a threeweek cruise to Hawaii. He was 75 years old.

title: Spain Bans Pictures Of Nudes on Theaters
description: MADRID, Jan. 23 (Reuters)Spanish theaters and cinemas will no longer be allowed to display pictures of nudes outside their buildings, according to royal decree published today.

title: Bias Against Homosexuals Banned By Koch in All Mayoral Agencies
description: Mayor Koch banned municipal discrimination against homosexuals yesterday, fulfilling a pledge he had made on his first working day at City Hall.

title: Horses on the Skids, but Big A Reopens
description: Aqueduct's winter thoroughbred meeting, a frostbitten venture that had begun looking like Napoleon's retreat from Moscow, finally got back into fullscale operation yesterday.

title: Sumo Wrestling Has judge That Never Blinks
description: TOKYO, Jan. 22The new year's first sumo wrestling tournament ended here Sunday, and, as usual, nine stonefaced judges presided over the matches. Eight of the judges were human: They were the ones who blinked.

title: ExBuyer for Drexel Burnham Indicted in Kickbacks
description: A former employee of Drexel Burnham 8r-Company, an investment banking firm at 60 Broad Street, was indicted yester. day on Federal charges that he accepted $50,000 in secret kickbacks to defraud his company of $200,000 on its purchases of computer paper;stock forms and other paper products.

title: The Middle East, Without Chutzpah
description: We are hearing a good deal about chutzpahgall and arrogancein the Middle East these days. President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin are suddenly discovering great streaks of impudence and villainy in each other's diplomacy. And as usual they look sideways to the United States for a ceasefire signal. They may yet get it because of a special brand of American chutzpah. Americans, who needed only 13 years to face up to shift of sovereignty over the Panama Canal, are shocked, annoyed and frustrated to find Egypt and Israel unable to draw a sovereign border for themselves in the interminable time of eight weeks.

title: Deaths
description: ARNOLDJohn 5.On January 23, 1978 Of Bayshore, L.I. Beloved busband of Patricia. Devoted father of John, Penny, Brian, Christopher, Mark, Kenneth, Matthew and Daniel. Also survived by his sisters Marydale Pappas, Ellen Cotterell and Nina Zipperer. The family will receive friends at the George C. White Funeral Home, 364 East Main St., Bayshore Hours 2.5, 79. Funeral service at St. Patrick's RC Church, Bayshore, 10 a.m. Thursday. Interment St. Marv's Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Patrick's School.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A United Press International article published in The Times Jan. 17, referred erroneously to two companies as being defunct. They are Continental Mortgage Investors of Boston and Coral Gables, Fla., a real estate investment trust and the National Telephone Company of Hartford, Conn. Both, while involved in Chapter X bankruptcy proceedings, continue to do business.

title: Arts and Humanities
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23Whichever Government agencies might have felt shortchanged by today's Federal budget, the /kits and Humanities Endowments were not among them. These two independent Government agencies that oversee the money were each allotted an increase of about $25 million for the fiscal year 1979.

title: DE LA ROCHE ANUS LIES IN QUESTIONING
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 23Harry De La Roche Jr., the 19-year-old former militaryschool student charged with having murdered his parents and two younger brothers in their Montvale home in November 1976, acknowledged two lies during intense crossexamination today.

title: Saudis Grow Polished in a More Assertive Role Abroad
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaThe leaders of this enormously wealthy oil state are growing increasingly practiced and confident in the more assertive role they have assumed in Middle Eastern and world affairs in the last few years.

title: Reasoner Is Offered Post at CBS As Fight Arises on ABC Contract
description: Harry Reasoner is likely to be the next person featured in television's accelerated game of musical chairs if he can resolve a contractual dispute with ABC News.

title: Carey and Leaders in Assembly Differ on Increases in Student Aid
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23A brewing controversy over how to increase state aid to college students has put public colleges at odds with private colleges and, more surprisingly, has put Governor Carey at odds with highranking members of the Assembly, which is controlled by his Democratic party.

title: Neediest Cases Draw Support Despite Storm
description: New York City and much of the East Coast are still digging out after last week's snowstorm, but supporters of the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund still remember the problems of many in the metropolitan area.

title: The Man in the Red Coat
description: At Miami the car rental company failed to deliver. Your car is at the airport, said the computerized woman on the phone. We were at the railroad station.

title: Cynthia Gregory Rejoins American Ballet Theater
description: Cynthia Gregory, a former principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, will return to the company next Monday. She will appear with the troupe at the Dorothy Chandler Pavillon in Los Angeles. Miss Gregory resigned from the company last November, on the ground it had been unable to find her a suitable ballet partner. She had previously resigned in December 1975 and rejoined the company year later.

title: Carolina Governor Shortens T erms For. Wilmington 10 in Firebombing
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 23Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., hoping to skirt a political minefield in his home state and pointedly rejecting the criticism of those from outside, affirmed his belief tonight in the guilt of the Wilmington 10, but reduced their sentences to make them eligible tor parole over periods ranging from four months to two years.

title: Copiers Supply Cape Town Tankers
description: CAPE TOWNWhen Spanish crewmen aboard the Frenchregistered supertanker Esso Flandre decided to buy a medicine ball to keep in trim on their sixweek journey from Le Havre to Abu Dhabi, they didn't wait for the next port of call. Instead, they, radio telephoned a ship's chandler here and had him send one out by helicopter.

title: Volcano Erupts in South Japan
description: KAGOSSIMA, Japan, Jan. 23 (Reuters) The Sakurajima volcano at the southern end of Kyushu, Japan's southern main island, erupted twice today. No casualties were reported. The volcano, on a peninsula opposite Kagoshima, has now erupted 10 times this year.

title: Text of Koch's Order Banning Bias
description: Following is the text of Mayor Koch's executive order banning discrimination against homosexuals in mayoral agencies:

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Charles G. Nelson, a policy analyst at the Department of Energy, died yesterday at Georie Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 36 years old. Dr. Nelson formerly of the political science faculty at the University of Missouri, studied at the Institutes de Science Politique in Paris and had a doctorate in polTca; science from Indiana University. He survived by his wife, Beverly, and daughter, Barbara.

title: New York May Get More U.S. Education Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23New York City and New York State can expect some additional financing for educational programs, housing and economic development in fiscal 1979, Brad Johnson, head of the New York State office here, said today after a preliminary study of President Carter's proposed budget.

title: Soviet Straining In Quest for Oil
description: TYUMEN, U.S.S.R., Jan. 18The Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, is about to enter a period of growing hardship and expense in developing its vast petroleum reserves to meet the soaring need for energy.

title: Andreotti Meets Reds Amid Labor Show of Power
description: ROME, Jan. 23Italy's powerful labor unions reminded Rome today of their political weight and social grievances by staging a twohour general strike here.

title: Burden Says Miscount Was Involved in Nomination
description: Attempting to overturn the nomination of Bella S. Abzug in the 18th Congressional District, Carter Burden charged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that mathematical miscount as well as the unauthorized vote of an enrolled Liberal Party official had cost him the nomination.

title: Michigan Court Overturns Order That 20 Disclose How They Voted
description: LANSING, Mich., Jan. 23Reversing two lower courts, the Michigan Supreme Court today upheld the rights of 20 persone to keep their votes secret in a case involving the disputed Ann Arbor mayoral eleCtion last April.

title: Eight Associates Of Barnes's Given Heavy Sentences
description: Prison sentences flinging up. to 30 years were imposed yesterday on eight men convicted of participation in a major narcotics ring headed by Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, who was sentenced last week to life in Olson.

title: Funds to Help Pregnant TeenAgers: An Idea Emerges and Gets in Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Last April, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., saw some statistics on teenage pregnanciesone million, one of every 10 female teenagers, get pregnant every year.

title: SECTIONS OF QUEENS ARE STILL UNPLOWED, BOROUGH HEAD SAYS
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, denouncing a poor level of performance in New York City's snow cleanup, charged yesterday that some areas of Queens, particularly in the north and east, were still unplowed late on the third day after a 13.6-inch snowfall.

title: On of City's ighestRanking. Women Takes It in Stride
description: During the Koch-for-Mayor campaign last fall, she was known as the pregnant one, and photographers had a field day snapping her bulging silhouette from the side. It looked as though she might give birth any minute, before the end of the successful Koch campaign that she had helped run.

title: Congress Lauds Budget in General, But Some Reservations AreVoiced
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Except for few claims of vindication because President Carter was effectively admitting that he would not balance the budget by 1981, Congress reacted for the most part today with bland general praise for Mr. Carter's budget.

title: 55% IN POLL HOLD VIEWS IN DR. JASCELEVICH CASE
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 23Renewing their efforts to have the coming murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich moved out of Bergen County, attorneys for the surgeon today cited the results of a poll showing that 55 percent of 478 adults surveyed by telephone had an opinion a sto the guilt or innocence of the doctor, with 45 percent of those polled believing him to be definitely or probably guilty.

title: Signs of Progress Are Reported in. Coal Strike Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)Contract talks aimed at ending the 49day coal strike moved to a critical stage today as union and industry negotiators appeared to be narrowing their differences over major issues blocking a settlement.

title: Corporation Affairs Delta Orders 5 Lodkheed TriStar Jetliners
description: LONDON, Jan. 23, (Reuters)The British Government will not give the Chrysler Corporation's subsidiary here more than the $19 million promised earlier to fund losses for 1977, Industry Secretary Eric Varley told Parliament today.

title: Taxes &
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Congressional critics last year forced accounting firms into the public eye to defend their auditing performance against charges they had been remiss in examining the books of large corporations.

title: $301,000 JOB PROGRAM IS SUSPENDED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday the suspension of another antipoverty program grant, this one a $301,000 youth employment program operated by the Central Queens Community Corporation.

title: Carter Picks Tax Cut OverBalancedBudget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The first budget for which President Carter assumes full responsibility pictures an economy that may well be needing further tax cuts beyond the one proposed for later this year to keep the economy on a high growth trajectory.

title: KENNECOTT REDUCES COPPER 11C A POUND
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's leading copper producer, announced yesterday that it was rolling back the price of copper to 61  cents a pound from the 63 cents the industry had set last December in an effort to recover its profitability.

title: 55 M.P.H. Speed Limit Saved Lives in New York
description: The highway fatality totals for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut dropped by almost 4,500 people between 1974 and 1977 because motorists generally observed the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit and got into fewer accidents, according to reports from state highway and police officials.

title: Bias by City Against Homosexuals Is Banned by Koch
description: Mayor Koch banned municipal discrimination against homosexuals yesterday, fulfilling a pledge he had made on his first working day at City Hall.

title: CARTER BUDGET MESSAGE AND SOME PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Following are the text of President Carter's budget message to Congress and excerpts from a summary of proposals for the fiscal year 1979:

title: Budget Summary
description: This budget is the product of nearly a year of wideranging policy review and of systematic zerobased budget review of ongoing programs and new proposals. It contains significant changes in the allocation of the Federal Government's budget resources, particularly over the longer run. Tax reform proposals will affect both the amount and the source of funds available, while major proposals in highpriority areas such as energy, welfare and defense account for large proposed changes in budget outlays.

title: DaytonHudson Set to Buy Chain; King's Is Sought by W. R. Grace
description: Two major retailing mergers were proposed yesterday, involving exchanges of stock totaling more than $420 million.

description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: CARTER ASKS $500 BILLION BUDGET; SEEKS HIGHEMPLOYMENT ECONOMY AND OFFERS FEW NEW PROGRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.. 23  President Carter sent his first budget to Congress today, presenting a $500 billion plan for 1979 that emphasized the liniits to what Government could do to cure social problems

title: Antitrust Suit Stirs Heavy Berkey and Kodak Trading
description: The weekend antitrust suit victory of Berkey Photo Inc. over the Eastman Kodak Company unleashed heavy trading and sharp price movements yesterday in the shares of both companies.

title: Justice Dept. to Examine Marston's Ouster
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23A ranking Justice Department official said- today that the department would, examine :the circumstances involved in the removal last week of David W. Marston as United States Attorney here.

title: Renz Group: Early Music And Brawls
description: The stage of Alice Tully Hall was transformed on Sunday night into a reasonable simulation of medieval castle's rumpus room. Under a great tapestry, seemingly depicting Orpheus tickling his lyre, stood tall candelabra. Musicians and dancers drifted amiably in and out, entertaining a goodly asseml blage. Afterward, if all went as advertised, there were flagons of mead in the lobby, and brawls.

title: Aide Says Ford Knew of Alleged Korean Bribery and Ordered Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23ForMer President Ford was personally informed in 1975 that United States Congressmen were suspected of having taken South Korean bribes and he ordered an investigation by the Justice Department,

title: A's Move ToDenver Put Off
description: DENVER, Jan. 23 (AP)A Denver oilman, Marvin Davis, said today that time had run out and that he had broken off negotiations with Charles 0. Finley to purchase the Oakland A's baseball team and move the team here. The club will remain in Oakland.

title: Neediest Cases Draw Support Despite Storm
description: New Jersey and much of the East Coast are still digging out after last Week's snowstorm, but New Jersey supporters of the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund Still remember the problems of many of the destitute.

title: About Newyork
description: Consider age, that last frontier, A brand new world to be explored. What undiscovered wealth is here? What treasured memories are restored?

title: Begin Assails Cairo Press Hatred
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that the Israeli military delegation would not return to Cairo for negotiations until the Egyptian press ceased its hatred and incitement to hatred against the Jewish peonle.

title: Miss Thesmar Is Guest Star At City Ballet
description: Jewels is George Balanchine's tribute to three cultures he has known intimatelythose of France, the United States and Russia. Throughout the New York City Ballet repertory are scattered individual works that celebrate each part of .that heritage, but the trio of plotless ballets that constitute Jewels is a particularly eloquent tribute. Ghislaine Thesmar, the gueSt artist, made a welcome, if unexpected, appearance in Emeralds Sunday evening at the State Theater and showed a remarkable feel for the dramatic undertones of the ballet.

title: Mrs. Loeb Leaving Job of Caring ForNewYorkDiplomat Families
description: After 12 years as head of the New York City Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps, Frances Loeb will no longer have to worry that New York's 35,000member fcreign diplomatic community is properly cared for.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1978

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A United Press International article published in The Times Jan. 17, referred erroneously to two companies as being defunct. They are Continental Mortgage Investors of Boston and Coral Gables, Fla., a real estate investment trust and the National Telephone Company of Hartford, Conn. Both, while involved in Chapter X bankruptcy proceedings, continue to do business.

title: Becton Accuses Sun Of Illegal Purchases
description: Becton, Dickinson & Company, the big New Jersey hospital supplier, yesterday accused the Sun Company of having acquired a 34 percent stake in Becton through a series of secret and illegal purchases.

title: Losses Shut Franconia College
description: FRANCONIA, N.H., Jan. 23 (AP)Franconia College, an experimental liberal arts school in New Hampshire's White Mountains, closed abruptly today after 15 years of fighting financial problems and, attacks by conservatives.

title: EXCITY COLLEGE EXECUTIVE IS INDICTED Iii FRAUD CASE
description: Robert F. Carrell Jr., who resigned last wee's as a vice president of City.College, has lien indicted en grand larceny charges and will surrender today to the Manhattan D'strict Attorney, Mr. Carroll's lawyer said early this morning.

title: The Ways of Americans, Through Vietnamese Eyes
description: Soon a carefully measured additional 7,000 Indochinese refugees will added to our melting pot. The.boat people, as they are called, have fought hunger, illness and the sea for many months in a Struggle to stay afloat while In search of a welcome mat. Safe havensafe haven. Sounds warm, inviting and worth the trip. But what does it really mean? Those who mapped out their escape routes and rationed gasoline months in advanee obviously gave a lot thought to whom and what they were running from. Only now will they begin to learn whom and what they have run to.

title: Soviet Five Caps Trip
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.; Jan. 23 (AP)The Soviet Union national basketball team wound up a fivegame swing through the United States with a 9170 victory over the University of Connecticut tonight. The Russians return home tomorrow with a 41 record, including victories over U.C.L.A., Brigham Young and Providence, and a loss to Kansas State.

title: Advertising
description: Ted Bates & Company, citing irreconcilable Policy differences with the new management of. Standard Brands; has decided to resign the business rather than go through a reevaluation Competition with other agencies.
