title: Watson overcomes. Crenshaw in..Playoff
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23Playing on his favorite and most familiar golf course, Tom Watson won the 37th Bing Crosby National ProAm tournament today on the second playoff hole when Ben Crenshaw took bogey and Watson sank a 3foot putt for a par 3.

title: Gerard in Florida Hospital
description: MIAMI, Jan. 23Dr. Mark J. Gerard, the Long Island veterinarian who has been indicted in New York horseswitching scandal, is a patient at the Doctors Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. According to friends, the 43-year-old veterinarian is suffering from cardiac insufficiency, and the hospital said today that he was admitted last Monday.

title: July Is Set for Completion Of Trade Talks at Geneva
description: GENEVA, Jan, 23The United States agreed today with the nine member nations of the European Common Market and with.Japan to set July as the target date for winding up the ambitious tradefreeing negotiations known as the Tokyo round of talks, which have achieved virtually nothing sinoe they began in 1973.

title: Futures of Platinum And Gold in Surge
description: Prices of precious metals futures advanced sharply yesterday, with all gold and platinum deliveries posting life-ofcontract highs. -

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can pass pension legislation that forces an employer to provide more money and earlier vesting than he had promised .in a contract with nonunion employees.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23To preserve the outdoors and promote a cleaner environment, President Carter has proposed a modest net increase of $93 million in spending in the next fiscal year, with most of the new money marked for new scenic and historic areas and the reclamation of lands used for strip mining.

title: Steering a Middle Course
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The budget that President Carter sent to Congress today reflects the political calculation that the success of his Presidency, especially by 1980, will ride primarily on the

title: Around the Nation
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23Former Mayor Peter F. Flaherty today announced he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Pennsylvania. Mr. Flaherty made his announcement in Market Square, an outdoors park, in 7degree temperature.

Banks List Earnings
description: For periods ended Dee. 31. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) over-the-Counter.

description: BONN, Jan. 23 (AP)The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, sent letters to the heads of governments of North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries, warning them against the introduction of the neutron bomb, West German and riATO officials confirmed today.

title: Panel Stands by Its Dietary Goals But Eases a View on Eating Meat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Senate Nutrition Committee, in a second edition of its controversial report Dietary Goals for the United States, today stood by its original contention that Americans can increase protection against killer diseases by eating less animal fats and more fruits, vegetables and whole grain cereals.

title: Paris Openings: A Different Audience New Emphasis
description: PARIS, Jan. 23As long as there are women willing and able to spend $2,000 for a little evening frock, the couture will march on.

title: Ensemble Offers the Dances Beloved by Good Queen Bess
description: As noted by the English divine Thomas Fuller, Queen Elizabeth had a keen eye for dancing gentlemen. But when she was asked to take a look at a particularly good dancing teacher, she replied, Fish, he is a professional!

title: Resolution in House Warns Seoul U.S. Aid Hinges on Park Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23A resolution Insisting that the South Korean Government provide the House ethics committee with testimony from Tongsun Park; the South Korean, businessman and lobbyist, and from a former Ambassador to Wasfiington, Kim Dong Jo, and other officials was introduced in the House today, with full support from Democratic and Republican leaders.

title: Soviet Straining In Quest for Oil
description: TYUMEN, U.S.S.R., Jan. ISThe Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, is about to enter a period of growing hardship and expense in developing its vast petroleum reserves to meet the soaring need for energy.

description: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation announced yesterday that new laboratory testshad confirmed the state's 1976 finding that lake Ontario fish contain dangerously high levels of a carcinogenic pesticide, Mirex.

title: Mr. Koch in Quest of a Billion
description: Mayor Koch has now developed a fouryear projection of New York City finances to guide the Federal Government as it debates the extent of its help. Mr. Koch dares to be candid: The city's prospects are even more clouded than they appeared to be; major efforts on all sides will be needed to avoid default.

title: Workers for Supermarket Chains In 3 States Approve New Contract
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Twenty thousand clerks, cashiers and other workers for three major supermarket chains in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a new threeyear contract, thus avertinr a possible strike.

title: Science
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Carter Administration's first independent,budget calls for a modest increase in the Federal Government's financial support for scientific and technological research and development, with much of the rise to be spent by the military.

title: Warning From NATO Aide
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 (Reuters)The Secretary General of NATO, Dr. Joseph M.A.H. Luns, said today that the Soviet. Union was conducting a relentless, longterm buildup of military strength that, he said, presented an ominous threat to Western countries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's investigation into two explosions at Northeast Utilities Millstone I nuclear power plant in Waterford, Conn., tound that the company's actions after the explosions complied with Federal regulations, and that company personnel did all that was required, the commission said.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 24, 1978

title: Jersey Assailed on Flood Control; Safety Standards Called Inadequate
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23New Jersey, the nation's most densely populated state, has undertaken virtually no flood control construction projects and stands defenseless against repeated flooding, a special commission reported today after a twoyear study.

title: Jack Oakie, Film Buffoon, Is Dead; Played Napolini in Great Dictator
description: Jack Oakie, who appeared in more than a hundred Hollywood movies, mostly as the goodnatured, somewhat dimwitted buffoon, died yesterday in Northridge, Calif., apparently from an aortic aneurysm. He was 74 years old.

title: Events Today
description: BLACK. BODY BLUES, a play by Gu; Edwards; directed by Douglas turner Ward; presented by the Negro Ensemble Company; at the St. Marks Playhouse. 133 Second Avenue, 7:30.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: 11976 results included extraordinarY gain.

title: CANADA OPENS PARLIAMENT; EARLY ELECTIONS FORESEEN
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 23After a monthlong Christmas vacation, the Canadian Parliament reconvened today to face critical problems of the economy and national unity in what is regarded as a prelude to new national elections this year.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 23 (Reuters)The Somali radio asserted today that ethnic Somali forces had penetrated the strategic mountain city of Harar in the Ogaden region and were fighting in the streets as Ethiopian Government jets attacked them.

title: glood Supplies Still Critically Low In New Jersey and Nassau County
description: New Jersey's blood supply remained critically low yesterday, and officials- of major blood .banks continued their appeals for donors, especially those with types 0positive and 0negative. The situation was equally serious on Long Island in Nassau County, although the crisis was reported ended in New York City and Connecticut.

title: A Belgrade Balance Sheet
description: Quietly as the snows, the Belgrade conference resumed work last week after a month's recess. Its task to review the 1975 Helsinki accords on Security and Cooperation in Europethe terms of detente by which longdivided continent is trying to live together and grow closer aeain.

title: Injury Danger Is Cited In CrossCountry Skiing
description: Two Dartmouth doctors have found that crosscountry skiing may not be as safe as participants generally be- lieve.

title: WQXR Phone Festival to Benefit Philharmonic Will Begin Feb. 23
description: A fourday Phone Festival, to raise money for the New York Philharmonic will be broadcast on radio stations WQXRAM and FM beginning Thursday morning. Feb. 23, and continue through- out theweekend. Most of the time for the stations regular programming, will be preempted for recording of the Philharmonic in concert and interviews with wellknown music figures.

title: East Bloc Nations in Oil Project
description: WARSAW, Jan. 9Poland, East Germany and the Soviet Union are cautiously embarking on a highly unusual joint offshore oil exploration project in the Baltic Sea that could serve as a prototype for a broad range of jointventure operations in Eastern Europe.

title: Bridge
description: One of the great figures on the international scene began the New Year well by capturing the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship title at the New York Hilton Hotel on Sunday night. Sam Stayman of New York, after whom the world's second most popular convention is named, was ably supported by George Forney, Gene Prosnitz, Saul Bronstein, all of New York, and Michael Rosmarin of Roslyn, L. I.

title: Vietnam Exporting Peat
description: BANGKOK, Thailand (AP)Vietnam is exporting millions of tons of peat, an organic material used as fuel in industrial and transportation projects, the offical Vietnamese press agency has said. Some of the marshes contain peat that can be used as fuel for cement production.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: British Seek Mency to Aid Films
description: LONDONThe establishment of Government agency to help the ailing British film industry with money and advice was recommended in an official report issued last week.

title: ARABS OPPOSED TO EGYPT ARE EXPECTED IN ALGIERS
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 23 (Reuters)A conference of Arabs opposed to Egypt's peace initiative will convene in Algiers by the end of the month, official sources said here today.

title: Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The proposed new defense budget of $115.2 billion represents an increase of more than 3 percent over the current fiscal year and em1 phasizes the buildup of United States conventional forces in support of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: New Cabinet Lineup in Rome Awaited Eagerly by the Job Seekers
description: ROME, Jan. 23The neighbors of an under secretary in the present caretaker Government are looking out of their windows every morning to see whether his dark blue limouinse is still waiting at the curb.

description: THE LAST COWBOY. By Jane Kramer. 148 pages. Harper & Row. $8.95.

title: Ban on Play Stirs South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURGThe theatrical community in South Africa, until now relatively free of censorship on political grounds, has been shaken by the decision to ban production of Eric Bentley's play about the McCarthy era, Are You Now or Have You Ever Been?

title: Navy Retiring Submarine Nautilus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)Defense Secretary Harold Brown disclosed today that the Navy wopuld retire the Nautilus, the world's first nuclear powered submarine, next year at the age of 25. The end of the service of the Nautilus is one of the changes in the fleet planned under the new ilitary budget made public today.

title: U.S. Officials Belittle References to Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 23United States Government specialists said today that there had been references in the Egyptian press recently that could be interpreted as antiJewish or otherwise prejudicial to Jews but that there did not seem to he any organized campaign as suggested by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel.

title: Budget: Wary Compromise Between Disparate Targets
description: The opening sentence of President Jimmy Carter's budget message to Congress declares that the first complete budget of any new Administration is its most important. And in this first full statement of his Administration's priorities, policies and proposals, Mr. Carter has indeed disclosed his personal struggle to find a compromise between traditional Democratic liberalism and his own fiscal conservatism.

title: TERRY KATH, LEAD SINGER OF CHICAGO, DIES IN MISHAP
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UP1)Terry Kath, lead singer and guitarist for the rock group Chicago, accidentally shot himself to death tonight following Party. the police reported.

title: Care, Speed and Secrecy Mark The Printing Office's Production
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Government Printing Office had a rare day of glory last Tuesday as the first copy of the 1979 budget surged off the presses and was handed to James T. McIntyre Jr., Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Snead, 12 Others Sue P.G.A. Over Exemptions
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Thirteen professional golfers, including Sam Sneed, filed a classaction suit today to force the Professional Golfers Association to restore the lifetime tournamentqualifying exemption they enjoyed before 1970.

title: Market Place
description: Is rescue at hand for embattled Unit; ed States. manufacturers of citizens band radio equipment? If so, it will come at the last possible moment., At present, ther are four major United States manufacturers of which one, Hy Gain, has filed under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: Hussein Criticizes Israelis
description: LONDON, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  King Hussein of Jordan said tonight that Israel's leaders lacked the moral courage to make decisions necessary. to establish peace:

title: MARKET DECLINES ON DISAPPOINTMENT IN CARTER PROPOSALS
description: Disappointment over President Carter's tax .proposals and economic piligram weakened stock prices yesterday in slow trading. .

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Three men, including the brother of reputed New Jersey mob boss Joseph Palerno, were sentenced on charges of transporting stolen United States Treasury checks and stocks across state lines.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: ALLAN C. JACOBSON
description: Allan C. Jacobson, a former manager of the women's wear woolen division of J. P. Stevens & Company, died Sunday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 369 Graydon Terrace in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Alabama Upsets Kentucky
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 23 (AP)Reginald King scored 26 points as Alabama took advantage of turnovers and upset. topranked Kentucky, 7862. in a Southeastern Conference basketball game tonight.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: British Tourism At Record
description: LONDON (AP)Tourists in Britain spent a record $3 billion in the first nine months of 1977, the Under Secretary of Trade, Michael Meacher, has said. The sum was about $97 million more than tourists spent in 1976.

title: Probation in a $2.5 Million Fraud Stirs Controversy on Sentencing
description: Joel Do!kart., a lawyer charged with embezzling $2.5 million, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to five years probation, in accordance with an Appellate. Division I decision that has sparked a great deal of controversy.

title: Highlights of Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Following are the highlights of President Carter's budget for the fiscal year 1979:

title: PROFITS OF DU PONT SHOW A GAIN OF 28% FOR FOURTH QUARTER
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday profit increases of 28 percent for the fourth quarter and 18.8 percent for all of last year.

title: Plane Sales to Israel and Saudis Pose Problems for Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The projected sale of large numbers of the United States most modern aircraft to Saudi Arabia and Israel has raised major policy problems for the Carter Administration in the Middle East and on Capitol Hill, Administration officials said today.

title: Lewis, a Newjerseyan, Is Drafted by Cosmos
description: The North American Soccer League ? is seventh annual draft yesterday, and for the first time it allowed clubs to select high school and junior college players.

title: Egy0tWill Send Missions Abroad To Seek Backing of Peace Stand
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23Egypt is preparing to send missions to the United States, Western Europe and Arab and African countries to seek support for its peace initiative following the suspension of political talks with Israel in Jerusalem.

title: Theories on Man's Dark Deeds Come Out by the Light of the Full Moon
description: To generations of poets and songwriters, tonight is something special for young lovers.

title: Mysterious Xray Pulsar Is Discovered in Milky Way
description: Far out in the Milky Way, a new Xray pulsar has been discovered, throbbing every 3.6 seconds. Three spacecraft in the Earth's orbit have been usd to pinpoint its location and monitor, its Xray pulses.

title: Marston Inquiry Gets Carter View
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  President Carter and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell have told Justice Department investigatori. that at the time- they agreed to dismiss David W. Marston, the United States Attorney In Philadelphia, they did not know that one of the subjects or his investigations was Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania, sources in the. Justice. Department said today.

title: Some Senators, Back in Session, Already Feel Election Year Jitters and Look Ahead to Adjournment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Back from a nearly monthlong holiday, Congress had been in business a scant 32 minutes last week when Senator. Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee posed a auestion.

title: Record $39 Million Award Upheld In Infringement of Autogiro Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Investors who were farsighted enough to detect rising promise in the invention of the autogiro, some as long ago as 50 years, have won a recordbreaking patent infringement award of nearly $39 million from the Federal Government.

title: MORE. AMERICANS SUPPORT SEX EDUCATON IN SCHOOLS
description: Public support for sex education in schools has grown significantly in the last seven years, according to the Gallup Poll. Seventyseven percent of Americans approve of the idea, 16 percent oppose it'and 7 percent have no opinion.

title: Blood Supplies Still Critically Low; Appeals for Donors Are Pressed
description: New Jersey's blood supply .remained critically low yesterday, and officials of major blood banks continued their appeals for donors, especially those with types 0positive and 0negative. The situation was equally serious on Long Island in Nassau County, although the crisis was reported ended in New York City and Connecticut.

title: Reasoner Is Offered Post at CBS As Fight Arises on ABC Contract
description: Harry Reasoner is likely to be the next person featured in television's accelerated game of musical chairs if he can resolve a contractual dispute with ABC News.

title: Moscow Confirms Incident

description: The New York City Board of Education has rescheduled entrance examinations for students in special vocational and academic programs because last week's snowstorm forced cancellation of the original dates. The new schedules are:

title: Tongsun Park Cites 5 Senators, Including Humphrey
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 24Tongsun Park has told Justice Department investihere that he made financial contributions to at least five United States Senators in recent years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Lee Grani's House Toppled
description: MALIBU, Calif Jan 24 (UPI)-A. gust of wind today knocked down a ,frame house being built for the actress Lee Grant in the Point Dume area causing damage estimated at $70,000, sheriff's deputies reported. They said that two workmen had heard the frame structure creaking in the wind, then ran to 'safety just before it collapsed.

title: SOVIET SPY SATELLITE WITH ATOMIC REACTOR BREAKS UP IN CANADA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24A crippledSoviet satellite carrying a nuclear reactor reentered the earth's atmosphere and disintegrated over northwestern Canada today, 12 days after the United States and the Soviet Union had joined in a secret cooperative effort aimed at minimizing possible radioactive. contamina tion and averting public panic.

title: American Airlines Reports Net Rose to a New High Last Year
description: American Airlines, in an unaudited report, announced yesterday that its earnings in 1977 rose to a record of $81.9 million, up from $56.3 million, or $1.97 share, in 1976. Revenues increased to $2.28 billion from $2.01 billion.

title: N.L.R.B. URGES COURT TO CURB J. P. STEVENS
description: Seeks Injunction to Force Textile Company to Halt What It Calls Illegal Tactics to Bar Unionism

title: Minnesota Farmers Harass Surveyors for Power Lines
description: LOWRY, Minn.Scores of farmers and their wives gather nearly every weekday morning these days in the old, twostory fire hall in this snowswept western Minnesota village to vent their anger over the highvoltage power lines for which surveyors are preparing the way across their county.

title: VIC AMES
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 24 (AP)Vic Ames, former member of the Ames Brothers singing group, died yesterday after his car skidded on a patch of ice and struck utility pole. He was 52 years old.

title: Is Silverman Worth It?; News Analysis; Analysts Are Divided; Question of needs; Revenues Over A Billion

title: L.I.U. 81, Pratt 50
description: Steve Lewis, John Nelson Bailey and Kim Malcolm scored 19 points apiece to lead Long Island University to an 8150 triumph over Pratt Institute last night.

title: Califano Asks Emphasis on People Rather Than Cities in Aid to Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has proposed fundamental change in the way the Federal Government tries to help the nation's poor.

title: Supporters of Wilmington 10 Vow to Continue Fight
description: RALEIGH, N; C., Jan. 24Any hope held by North Carolina officials or by the State Department that the case of the Wilniington 10 would quickly fade from view as a result of shorter sentences was dashed today by continued demonstrations and vows to increase national and international pressure to exonerate the prisoners.

title: New York Police Accuse Fire Marshals of Impefring Investigations Into ArsonRelated Homicide Cases
description: The New York City Police Department has charged that a lack of cooperation by fire marshals has impeded investigations into arsonrelated homicides, including the Bronx social club fire that killed 25 persons in October 1976.

title: MRS. ABM AFFIRMED BY COURT IN CONTEST ON HOUSE NOMINATION
description: Bella S. Abzug was reaffirmed as the Democratic nominee for the House of Representatives in the 18th Congressional District yesterday in State Supreme. Court in Manhattan. The action came after weeks of political campaigning by Mrs. Abzug followed by nine days of legal maneuvering against the initial winner, Carter Burden..

title: REPORT ON FLOODING BACKED BY OFFICIALS
description: TRENTON Jan. 24State officials and legislative leaders expressed strong agreement today with a report that New Jersey had not done enough to protect itself from flood damage.

title: TV: From Sputnik to Shuttle on Nova
description: IN 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik into orbit around the earth, and the space race was on. Enough years have passed now to be packaged into a historical account, and this is what Nova, the publictelevision series, will offer on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Pardee, Allen Protege, Signs as Redskin Coach
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Jack Pardee, who coached the Chicago Bears into the National Football League playoffs last season, was signed today to coach the Washington Redskins, the Redskins owner, Edward Bennett Williams, announced. Pardee was signed to a multiyear contract, but the term were not disclosed.

title: Carey Tells Prison Aides to Get   Together in Dispute
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24Governor Carey sought today to break up a namecalling dispute between his Corrections Commissioner and his chief state prison watchdog by ordering them to meet and agree to exchange information before criticizing each other in public.

title: Congress Studies Bill to Require Judicial Scrutiny of Some Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Congress considering legislation to focus judicial light on one of the most secret activities of the Federal Government: the electronic surveillance of people in the United States who are suspected of being involved, directly or indirectly, in intelligence activities for a foreign power.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)Underscoring .a warning that has been in effect since 1970, the Food and Drug Administration today told four million American women who use contraceptive pills and smoke that unless they give up one or the other, they substantially increase the risk of a heart attack or stroke.

title: Perpich to See Mrs. Humphrey
description: MIAMI, Jan. 24Gov, Rudy Perpich of Minnesota planned to meet tomorrow in Florida with Muriel Humphrey, reportedly to offer her the Senate seat left vacant by the death of her husband, Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: SENATE WORD ALLOW APPEAL OF SENTENCES
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 24The Senate Voted overwhelmingly today to allow appeals of prison sentences by either defendants or prosecutors as it got down to serious work on a proposed overhaul of the Federal Criminal Code.

description: ROME, Jan. 24Prime Minister-designate Giulio Andreotti was ostensibly consulting with smaller parties today to explore ways of solving the government crisis, but the significant Contacts were understood to be taking place with the Communist Party in secrecy.

description: The credit markets, nervous about the dollar and concerned about whether G. William Miller will be confirmed as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, resumed their downward course yesterday as they headed toward the Treasury's $5 billion refinancing announcement scheduled today.

description: December sales among the nation's leading retail chains surged 18 percent ahead of the month a year ago and sales during all of 1977 were up 13.7 percent, according to Chain Store Age, a trade Publication.

title: Hanni Wenzel Is Victor in Special Slalom
description: BERCHTESGADEN,  West Germany, Jan. 24 (AP)Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein won a women's speCial slalom on a treacherous course today, widening her World Cup lead to 34 points. American women had theirbest Alpine showing in nine years, finishing fourth, fifth and sixth.

title: Bridge:
description: Shooting is a common activity in tournament play, but he who shoots often discovers, more often than in real life, that his violent departure from the norm has backfired and hurt himself.

She smiled and blushed as photographers rushed over after hearing that it was to be the Hofstra University student's first blond donation.

title: General Motors Ohio Plant Struck
description: EUCLID, Ohio, Jan. 24 (AP)United Auto Workers Local 1045 struck the General Motors Fisher Body plant in this suburb east of Cleveland today in a dispute over work standards, shutting the facility that makes interior trim for Cadillacs. The local authorized a strike in November, setting a January deadline for resolving the dispute through negotiations. The union objects to companyset standards on the quantity of work expected from each employee.

description: Frank C. Arricale 2d, the New York City school systems chief personnel officer, threatened yesterday to suspend spring sabbaticals for- 1,200 teachers by Feb. 1 because of what he termed critical shortage of Junior and senior high school mathematics and science teachers and a serious.shortage of English teachers.

description: Management chages are continuing at the Leo Burnett Company, the pride of Chicago, and spokesman says they have nothing to do with the loss of any past accounts or the threatened loss of Schlitz Beer.

description: SONGKHLA, Thailand, Jan. 23--Mis-, treatment of Vietnamese refugees seeking asylum in southern Thailand is mounting at an alarming rate, in a climate dominated by growing resentment at the continuing arrival of their small fishing boats.

description: CAIRO, Jan. 24A political cartoon in the daily Al Ahram this morning carried a blunt caption under a caricature of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel.

title: Theater: Black Body Blues

The dramatic struggle was marked by its tenseness and its leanness. Mr. Edwards's strength in this evocative play was in conjuring mood this side of menace and in devising enough surprises to envelop us right through the final twist.

title: Holy Cross 82, B. C. 76
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 24 (UPI)Ronnie Perry scored 31 points tonight and Holy Cross rallied from a 16point firsthalf deficit for an 8276 victory over Boston College. Perry and Chris Potter led a Holy Cross attack that scored 54 points in the second half.

title: Saudi Increase In Output Seen By Schlesinger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger said today that Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, planned to increase productive capacity modestly between now and the early 1980's and was not now planning further increases to meet the gains that might occur in world oil demand.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Pension Fund Money Running Out For Fire Dept. in New York City
description: The New York City Fire Department Pension Fund is running out of money and, for the first time, its expenses will exceed its income this year. Unless an agreement is reached soon on additional contributions by the city, the firefighters union, or both, the fund will have to start selling its stocks, bonds and other assets to pay pensions.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: BOC International Ltd., formerly the British Oxygen Company, said yesterday that its offer to pay $43 .a share for 1.8 million shares of Airco Inc. had been so well received that BOC would be willing to buy the entire company at the same price if Airco's board approved the offer.

title: A Thinking Body's Guide to Protein
description: PROTEIN is widely regarded as the most important nutrient, and the average Americannot wanting to stint on a good thingtends to consume far more protein than he really needs. Unfortunately, while packing in protein, most neonle consume too much fat and nos- sibly too many calories, which are the baggage in most highprotein food. Thus, instead of being good to their bodies, they may actually do themselves a disservice.

title: 3 Manufacturers Hanover Officers Testify Before Lance Grand Jury
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 24Three vice presidents of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York testified today before an Atlanta Federal grand jury investigating the financial affairs of former Budget Director Bert Lance.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN NET FELL 78% 1N4TH QUARTER
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the securities firm, reported yesterday a 78 percent decline in earnings for the fourth quarter on a 13 percent gain in revenues. For all of 1977, its net income fell 92 percent on a 15 percent rise in revenues.

title: Private Lives
description: THE PHONE rings at 6 o'clock in the morning. It is a nice woman telling us that school is closed today on account of the blizzard. I have missed the blizzard. I am informationdeprived. I go to the window. Sure enough: New York has been made innocent. Because of the snow, there will be no newspaper delivery, which means that I will not be able to read about the snow, or about what to eat in the snow, or about who went to which snow party wearing what pair of arctic boots and Ultrasuede parka. It will be a long morning.

title: New Jazz Band in Town
description: CHUCK ISRAELS, who organized the 18piece National Jazz Ensemble five years ago to play repertory ranging from Louis Armstrong and Jelly Roll Morton through the bebop era to John Coltrane and Ornette Coleman, as well as new contemporary corhpositions, has formed a 10piece group that has moved into Stryker's, 103 West 86th Street, on Monday evenings.

title: Knicks Vanquish Warriors by 9997
description: It was not difficult to figure out that the Knicks would win last night. After all, the Knicks played at Madison Square Garden and the Golden State Warriors were on the road, and the Warriors have one of the worst road records in the National Basketball Association.

title: New York Announces Another State Lottery
description: A new lottery with a top instant payoff of $5,000 and mail drawings for $1 million as well as lesser prizes will begin Jan. 31, John D. Quinn, the New York State lottery director, announced yesterday.

title: Alampi Says Preserving Farmland Is its Department's No. 1 Priority
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24New Jersey is losing faring to developers at the rate of one every three days and as a result farmland preservation has become the No. I priority in the State Department of Agriculture, the department's secretary, Phillip Alampi, said today.

title: Israel's Settlements in Sinai, Once Disregarded, Now Are a Major Obstacle to Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The sharp dispute between Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt has many causes. But the issue that seems to have aroused the most passion on :both sides concerns Israel's insistence on the right to retain and defend its settlements in Sinai, even after a return of the entire Sinai Peninsula to Egyptian sovereignty.

title: PUPILS IN BROOKLYN SEND NEEDIEST A GIFT
description: Fourth-Graders' Bake Sale Leads to Check for $171 and a Poem Saying We Wanted to Help

title: Two New Vocal Works
description: VOCAL music by Seymour Shifrin and Hugo Weisgall was the main order of business at the International Society for Contemporary Music concert Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Two works received their first performances, Mr. Shifrin's A ,Renaissance Garland (1975) and Mr. Weisgall's The Golden Peacock (1976), both interesting attempts to present old musical material in new contexts.

title: JUNE RHODES GORDON, 87; PUBLICIST AND PARTY AIDE
description: June Hamilton Rhodes Gordon, a New York publicist who managed Democratic women's activities in Alfred E, Smith's 1928 Presidential campaign, and headed her own fashionindustry promotion company in the 1930's and 1940's, died last Thursday at her home in Stewart, Fla. She was 87 years old.

title: Namath Is Retiring From Pro Football
description: Joe Namath, the flamboyant quarter??ck who guided the New York Jets to victory in Super Bowl III and lasted 13 seasons despite a variety of leg ailments, disclosed last night that he was retiring from football.

title: The Noodle: It's Quite a Good Mixer
description: ONE OF the oldest legends in the world that muchvaunted fable that Marco Polo discovered noodles during his travels China, thus spawning a new food and national pastime. That notion is widely poohpoohed in Italy. of course. And one of the most interestine aspects of a visit there last year was a side trip tp the pasta museum in the small town of Ponterlassio. There is an amusing cartoon on display there with a caption that reads, In Peking 700 years ago, Marco Polo saw that even the Chinese eat noodles. In a more serious vein it is pointed out that Marco Polo returned from his visit in 1292 and that noodles Italianstyle were mentioned in a historical document dated 13 years earlier. The fact is that noodles and noodle dishes, whatever their origin, are one of the most welcome miracles of gastronomy, a blessing at tables that know no national boundaries. Think of Italian ravioli and Jewish kreplach, Siberian pelmeny and Chinese won ton.

description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 24(UPI)Dr. James Murphy and Larry Little of the Miami Dolphins testified today for Bubba Smith, a former defensive end, in his $2.5 million damage suit against the Tampa Sports Authority and the National Football League.

description: Under sunny skies and with rising temperatures, New Jersey began making some headway yesterday in dealing with the effects of last week's snowstorm, but slush, potholes, patches.of ice and roads narrowed by shoulderhigh snowbanks continued to hamper traffic.

description: There were only 26 seconds left in last night's game between St. John's and Manhattan when the real action began.

We have all found how easy it is to step on the accelerator, but we have'nt learned :hat we must also apply the brakes. P.11 nations in the Western world have been moving their economics too fast. know you're very unpopular when you say that, but ??s true. description: Juan Mitchell scored 23 points last night to lead Columbia to a 6764 colleee basketball victory over Fordham.

description: WASHINGTONIn the summer of 1975, I was talking with my son Joe about his birthday present. His birthday comes shortly after Christmas, and he has the problem of all children in this situationnot quite having full birthday. I asked him what he wanted.

title: Soviet Wrestlers Rout U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Jan 24 (AP) A United States national wrestling team dropped the first match of its Soviet tour today, 91, to the Soviet national team in Yerevan, Armenia, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. The Americans will also wrestle in an international tournament in Tbilisi, Georgia, this weekend, then in Baku, Azerbaidjan, Feb. 1 and in Moscow Feb. 4.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a series of articles published Dec. 2527 on the C.I.A.'s past relations with news and publishing organizations around the world, Cord Meyer Jr. was incorrectly identified as the C.I.A. official who conveyed to Random House, the book publishers, the agency's concern in 1964 over its plans to publish The Invisible Government, a book about some of the C.I.A.'s secret operations. Mr. Meyer was not in touch with Random House on that matter. The series also reported that Glenn F. Ireton, an American journalist in Tokyo who had worked for the C.I.A., was dead. Mr. Ireton is not dead.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A firstgrade teacher at an elementary school in the Inwood section was arrested last night after breaking into the arsonplagued school with half-gallon bottles filled with gasoline, the police reported.

title: World's Press Enters New Year as Free as Before or, a Bit Freer
description: The press came under new restrictions last year in Africa and South America, but on the whole it was as free or freer on entering 1978 as it had been theyear before.

title: As City Thaws, Snow Crews. Work to Avoid Flooding
description: With temperatures climbing to 37 in midafternoon, the snow and ice in New York City and nearby areas began thawina yesterday.

title: Justice Officials Clear Carter in Marston Removal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Justice Department said today that both President Carter and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell had been cleared of allegations of obstruction of justice or improper conduct in the removal of United States Attorney David W. Marston of Philadelphia.

title: Careers

Henry Clifford of Boyden Associates, a large international re- cruitihg firm, said, for example, that his firm had been placing more and more American banking executives in such posts.

title: Schoolgirls Gain in Sports Equality
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Jan. 24 (UPI)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has notified Oak Ridge schocil officials that girls must be treated the same as boys in interscholastic and physical education programs or the system stands to lose about $750,000 in Federal funds.

title: Ululating Chants
description: CHARLIE MORROW called his solo performance at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Monday evening a night of vision chanting, but itwas more than that. Mr. Morrow is a: composer who has long been interested in American In- dian music and ritual, but he has also ranged more widely, and his presentation Monday included settings for Christian and Hebraic religious texts as well as a variety of chanting procedures.

title: U.S. Aide Would Admit More

Masco said that both offers would be at $175 a share, giving the overall transaction a value of about $43 million. Rieke makese cap seals and gaskets.

title: Jean Rhys: Voyage of a Writer
description: LONDON THERE she sat, as fragile and exotic as an orchid, in the watery light of a London winter afternoon. Jean Rhys was wearing a Jean Muir capedress that flowed from neck to slippers and took the breath away. It was mohair jersey, of an intense, radiant lavender mixed with periwinkle blue that exactly matched her eyes. A young man who met her recently said of those eyes gazing out of a white, powdered face under a fluffy aureole of white hair, My God. They go all the way to China.

title: Phone Executive Shot in Milan
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 24 (Reuters)An executive of an Italian telephone company was shot at least six times in the legs and right arm today, and leftwing guerrillas claimed responsibility for the attack, the police said. The victim was Nela Toma, a 34-year-old engineer and director in the SitSiemens company.

The trial of the 50-year-old surgeon had been scheduled to start next Monday, but the adjournment was granted by Judge Theodore W. Trautwein of Superior Court in Hackensack after the defense said that it needed more time to complete tests on the exhumed bodies.

title: Topics
description: For want of a nail, the shoe was lost; for want of the shoe, the horse was lost. And pretty soon, rider, battle and kingdom .were lost, tooall for want of a horseshoe nail. Charming, but antiquatedwhich is why we welcome a nuclearage version of the refrain: For excess of shoe, the power was lost. It happened at the Tennessee Valley Authority's Browns Ferry nuclear power plant, near Athens, Ga. A worker let a protective galosh fall into a nuclear reactor and it threatened to plug the cooling system on which safety depends. The T.V.A. kept the plant closed for 17 days while it sought proof that the shoe had disintegrated. The total cost was $2.8 million. This modern parable can be read as reassurance about the caution exercised by the nuclear industry. We prefer another moral: The more sophisticated man's inventions, the more damaging his inattentions; or, fate usually drops the other shoe.

Dyson, today defended Governor Carey's taxreduction proposal against charges that it left next year's financial plan in precarious balance, and said the tax cut must not be sacrificed for additional direct state aid to New York City.

description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Metropolitan Correctional Center, which was praised as a model jail when it opened in 1975, must alleviate overcrowding and improve other conditions that violate the rights of inmates.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Negotiations on a propose'd new, contract between the coal industry and union miners, who are now in the seventh week of an increasingly bitter strike, collapsed here today, as union representatives rejected a wage: andbenefits offer and the industry bargaining team left the city.

title: Teaching in Moscow1
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Mr. Goldman, are you a Communist? The rumor is that you are. Several of my classmates assume that if an American criticizes his economy, he must be a Communist. That was one of the many, surprising reactions I encountered last fall at Moscow State University in my course on the United States economy, the first ever taught there by a nonMarxist economist.

title: Notes on People
description: Surgery, to repair an artery in his abdomen was performed on John N. Mitchell, the formerAttorney General, at GeorgetoWn University Hospital in Washington yesterday. At the conclusion of the threehour surgery, Dr. Charles A. Hufnagel, who performed it, said that the 64- yearold Mr. Mitchell had come out of the operating room in good condition. Mr. Mitchell was furloughed last moth from the Federal minimum security prison at Montgomery, Ala., where he has been serving a term for Watergate coverup crimes. The furlough was for an operation to replace Mr. Mitchell's right hip, but physicians at Georgetown found an aneurismweakening in the artery wallof the stomach, and that had to be corrected before any hip operation.

title: The Big German Engine That Won't
description: Chancellor Schmidt of West Germany has now confirmed a reversal of policy that bodes ill for the stability of the West. Hints have come from other German officials before: But now, in his state of the union address to the Bundestag, Mr. Schmidt himself has openly rejected the argument that the West German economic locomotive should pull the weaker economies of Europe out of their worst recession since the 1930's. He indi- cated that no further stimulus to internal demand was feasible and that Germany's dependence on export markets for the sale of almost 30 percent of its gross national product made a higher growth rate impossible during a period of lagging international. trade.

title: KOCH DISBANDS PANEL IN DISPUTE OVER ROLE

title: The Military Pension Muddle
description: The posters may still promise adventure in foreign lands, but military recruiters have something better offer than R and R in Hong Kong. Those who join the armed services can retire after 20 years at half pay, even if that occurs at age 40. As even Gen. George Brown, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledges, however, this cherished perquisite of military life is on its way out. Many members of Congress, including some powerful friends of the military, are unhappy with both the huge cost of the retirement system and the very concept of early retirement. A PreSidential study commission report, nue in March, will probably fuel Congressional cuts in benefits.

description: SCHUBERT'S Die Saone TAWlerin is one of the inexhaustible masterpieces, a. song cycle that demandS of the singer not only great emotional depth, but also the ability to express the deepest feel- ings in a. style that seems ObVIOUS anti almost naive. At times, the story of the miller's apprentice who wins and then loses the miller maid verges on sheer banality, as the poet and Schubert must have shrewdly understood.

description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an. especially fastselling record.

title: KochUnfaze d by Rain or Snow, but Locusts?;
description: Neither snow nor slush nor driving rain stayed Mayor Koch yesterday from the swift completion of two ceremonial visits to city departments.

title: Cancer Institute to Ask Doctors For Data on the Value of Laetrile
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25In a report to be published here tomorrow, Federal officials at the National Cancer Institute say that they are making a special appeal to American doctors to submit evidence, to document reported improvement among individuals with cancer after they took laetrile, the controversial substance that is derived from the pits of apricots and other fruits.

title: Muriel Humphrey lAccepts Appointment to Husband's Senate Seat
description: HILLSBORO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2bMuriel Humphrey was appointed today to fill the United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of her husband, Hubert H. Humnhrev. When she takes the caln or office, probably early next month, she will beccme the first woman to serve in the Senate since Maragaret Chase Smith of Maine lost a bid for reelection in 1972.

title: Home Beat
description: TELEPHONE MEN have seen all, decoratively speaking, but when Bill Miller lifted up his marble fireplace singlehandedly, the lineman working in his apartment was rather surprised. Bill Miller is not a weight lifter. He's the curator of the Jamaica Art Center, a consultant to the New York State Council on the Arts; he teaches history of fashion at Parson's School of Design and 18thcentury civilization at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and he is adept at papiermache. Which is how he made the most realistic looking fake carved marble fireplace that this reporter has ever seen.

title: Pop: Randy Edelman
description: THE SINGERSONGWRITER phenomenon of the early 1970's seems to be giving way, in this latter part ofthe decade, to the phenomenon of the singing songwriter. Professional tunesmiths, no longer content to stay in the background and pick up their royalty checks, have Peen taking to the stage in unprecedented numbers, and the results, mixed though they are, can be quite interesting.

title: Memurial Services
description: HIRSCHFred. A memorial gatherIn will rake place on Saturday, February 4th, at 11 AM at the University of Warwick at Coventry, England.

title: South African Leader Reshuffles Cabinet, Splitting Ministry Dealing With Blacks
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 25 (AP)Prime Minister John Vorster announced a Cabinet reshuffle today in which he moved his Interior Minister to the post of Minister of Black Administration, and left the controversial Justice Minister, James T. Kruger, in his post.

title: Advertising
description: To a Marketing maven, the differences between distilled spirits and wines that. first to mind would be the ones that affect sales.

title: 'Bigtime,' Film Comedy:Music by Robinson
description: THEY DON'T COME much more small-time than "Bigtime," a harmless but also brainless comedy about an insurance swindler who can't do anything right. Eddie Jones, played with an ear-to-ear grin by Christipher Joy, specializes in throwing himself in front of cars and then collecting damages. But he does this so uninterestingly that the screenplay must also throw in pizza-guzzling Mafiosi, a hot $100,000, a love interest who looks and sounds as if she ought to have a wind-up knob between her shoulder blades and a lot of white folks who are venal enough to make Eddie look positively heroic by comparison.The only character of any interest is the mob's white-suited "Negro' Representative," an amusingly incompetent Superfly type played nicely by Roger E. Mosley, the actor who starred in "Leadbelly."The best that can be said for the soundtrack, which is by Smokey Robinson, is that it's genial and innocuous and at least it isn't disco."Bigtime" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), perhaps because Mr. Joy ogls a couple of buxom women and perhaps because of a few lines that are only marginally risqu.

title: Backgammon:
description: To celebrate its official opening last Tuesday, the Park 65 Backgammon Club held a gala cocktail party, with Tim Holland, the club's president. as host. This attractive private club, in the Mayfair House Hotel at 65th Street and Park Avenue, has a select membership of backgammon devotees. Holland, who conceived the idea of Park 65, is one of the outstanding names in backgammon. In the late 1960's, he dominated international competition. He won the World Championship in 1969, 1970 and 1971, the first years that the tournament was held. He is also well known as the author of three books on the game. Although in recent years Holland has not actively pursued the professional backgammon circuit, he still excels at this game and many others. He is an accomplished bridge player and one of the best amateur golfers in the country.

title: Teaching in MoscowII
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.One of the most fascinating aspects of being visiting lecturer at Moscow State University last fall was the opportunity it provided for clo.se contact with Soviet students. I quickly realized that the students in my course on the United

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.Years ago on the moors of northern Scotland watched a peregrine falcon hurtle out of the sky to strike a flying red grouse with incredible precisionthat night the falconer, his wife and I dined on birds gathered by a hunting technique that was developed long before the birth of Christand from that time on all birds of prey have fascinated MC.

title: Incinerator Is Restored
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn granted the Nassau County Town of North Hempstead permission to revive its controversial Roslyn incinerator for 30 days despite his earlier order that be closed permanently on Jan. 11.

title: Russian Winter: Time of Diversion
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 25This may be the only metropolis where people think of snow and crackling crisp cold as blessing, not a curse. A heavy white mantle has been covering the grime of the city since early December, and The Talk of Moscow for days the sun has set in the clear blue sky without the temperature rising above 15 degrees. It's wonderful, said Vasya, a 36-year-old craftsman, the other day: It takes my mind ott au our problems.

title: GRAND JURY ACCUSES CARDBOARD MAKERS OF FIXING PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25A Federal Grand jury today accused 14 corporations that make cardboard cartons and 26 present or former executives with fixing prices for a period of at least 18. years,

title: The Most Honest Quarterback
description: His attorney and manager, Jimmy Walsh, would have preferred that Joe Namath prolong the vagueness of his future as a quarterback but. by being vague, Joe Namath was not being himself. He knew he was going to retire from football. For a few weeks he placated Jimmy Walsh by telling newsmen: I have an idea of what I'm going do, but I don't want to talk about it yet. But on Tuesday night, he talked about it, blurting: I'm not going to play next year. More than all the touchdown passes, more than all the blondes, more than the drinks and all the dim bars, that honesty is what Joe Namath is all about. Historians will cherish his guarantee that the New York Jets would upset the Baltimore Colts in Super Bowl III, but he was not bragging. He was just being honest in his own mind, as the 167 score would attest. Through the years, Joe Namath has been perhaps the most honest athlete of his timefor better or for worse. Earlier in that 1968 season, five interceptions by the Denver Broncos deprived the Jets of an expected victory.

title: The Costs of the Marston Affair
description: The Carter Administration fired the Federal prosecutor in Philadelphia, a Republican, after a Democratic Congressmanwhom the prosecutor was investigatingcalled the President and asked him to expedite the prosecutor's departure. This damning circumstance is not erased but is, indeed, confirmed by the documents just released to support the conclusions of an internal Jus- tics Department investigation about the removal United States Attorney David Marston. The finding that neither Mr. Carter nor Attorney General Bell had obstructed justice was predictable enough. But to a surprising degree, the documents attest to the Administration's responsibility for the harm done to the Federal justice system: A President pledged to selection by merit has effected a political removal, potentially jeopardizing an important and highly visible investigation and hence provoking concern about Federal justice far beyond Philadelphia.

title: ALBANY AGENCY QUITS SUMMER FOOD PLAN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25The New York State Department of Education announced today that it had withdrawn from the controversial summer food program this year because of what it called insufficient Federal funds to operate the nutritional service for needy children.

title: Oakland Transit Pact Reached
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP)A tentative settlement has been reached in two-month-old strike by 1,850 drivers, clerks and mechanics against AC Transit. The membership was expected to vote on the pact Friday. Last weekend the membership rejected a tentative settlement agreed to in negotiations.

title: Koch Says Soskin Is Still in Running For a Realty Post
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Perry Soskin, a realestate man and former New York City housing aide, was still a candidate for a top realestate post in his administration.

title: Carter to Back a Coop Bank Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25In a policy reversal, President Carter has agreed to support legislation to create an im'epentlent national bank for consumer cooperatives, Administration sources said today.

title: Family Money
description: WHEN the American Express Company recently made a curbstone survey of 202 people at four shopping centers across the country, it came up with a not-so-surprising unisex finding. Men are no better informed about credit than women are.

title: Ex-Purser Runs for T.W.A. Board
description: A former Trans World Airlines purser, Fred A. Catalano, has served notice that he is running for membership on the airline's board of Directors. He announced simult aneously that, with other candidates still to be identified, he would sek to take over full operating control of the airline.

title: More Top Leaders Under Attack From Peking's Military
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 25Despite nationwide purge over the last 15 months of followers of China's socalled radicals, the military commanders apparently - believe that the campaign has'not gone far enough and Notes on China that some high otticials in Peking must still be ousted, This is the conclusion analysts here are drawing from a recent series of vehement articles in the army paper, Chiehfang Chun Pao. In sarcastic language, the articles charged that some unidentified senior party members who have managed to survive the political twists and turns were Opportunists.

title: Heavy Rainfall Adds to Threat of Flooding in New York and Suburbs
description: New York City and nearby suburban areas intensified efforts to clear catch basins and drains to ward off potential flooding as heavy rains began yesterday. The rain was expected to continue today, melting much, of last week's snowfall.

title: Grand Jury Is Preparing to Indict In Manhattan Court Bribe Inquiry
description: A Manhattan grand jury is preparing to vote indictments based on an eightmonth investigation into allegations that lawyers have paid bribes to fix cases in the borough in the civil part of State Supreme Court.

title: An Economic Plan Business Ought to Like
description: President Carter has offered the nation an economic strategy for this year and next that is basically cautious, indeed conservative, including a tax cut of some $9 billion for business and a tight lid on new Federal expenditures. Instead of applause in the business world, however, the President's strategy is getting mostly scorn. The complex plan, basically a mixture of tax cuts and tax reforms, is not all that business wantedor that anyone wanted for that matter. Yet it is basically sound; it does not deserve the current sulking in business suites.

title: U. S. Steel Will Join Pennzoil in Drilling
description: The United States Steel Company is planning to join the Pennzoil Company in drilling for oil in offshore Brazil, Pennzoil disclosed yesterday in Houston.

title: Parolee Indicted on Rape
description: A Queens man on parole in a similar case was indicted on charges of having raped and robbed five young women whom he asked at various times to accompany him to meet a priest and provide a character reference for a job program.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectely reported in the Market Place column in The Times Jan. 11 that Berkey Photo Inc. was discontinuing its WilloughbyPeerless stores. The company said its Willoughby store was operating as usual, and its Peerless camera stores have been converted to photo processing stores.

title: Gilbert Verney, Board Chairman Of Paper Mill in New Hampshire
description: PETERBORO, N.H., Jan. 15 (AP)Gilbert Verney, chairman of the board of Monadnock Paper Mills Inc. of Bennington, N.H., died Monday of a heart attack in Miami. He was 73 years old.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 26, 1978

title: Events Today
description: RUCKUS MANHATTAN, directed by David Saunders, Red Grooms, Peter Hutton and the Ruckus Construction Company, and FAT FEET, directed by Mr. Grooms, the Film Forum, 15 Vandam Street.

title: Musetuns That Build Glass Houses
description: IT SEEMS fairly safe to say that there has not been an unbuilt building in New York in years that has inspired as much talk as the planned addition to the Museum of Modern Art did last summer. In fact, one might almost say thtat there has not been a built building in New York for years that has been as talked about.

title: Suit Terms Environmental Agency Lax on Hazardous Waste Disposal
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25The State Public Advocate sued New Jersey's Department of Enviornmental Protection today; charging that the department was not enforcing its rules covering disposal of hazardous waste.

title: Stage: Canadians Produce Troilus
description: OTTAWA

title: Nomenclature
description: It's an old sport to make light of the changes language and title wrought by the women's movement. Just about everyone has had her/his fun with such locutions as Ethel Merperson or personopause, and with such problems as what to call the 138 Americans whom the last Census found to be working as male midwives.

title: Spain Reports 26% Inflation
description: MADRID, Jan. 25 (Reuters)The rate of inflation in Spain was 26.4 percent in 1977, according to provisional figures made public today by the National Institute of Statistics.

title: The President as Orator His Deliberate Style Appears to Run Counter to the Inspiration He Seeks to Instill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 --In his:characteristically softspoken State of the Union Meisage last week, President Carter suggested that, While'he and other elected officials were incapable of 'solving every problem. in the country, they can sometimes inspire. News Analysis .Historically, that has generally been true, but there is a growing concern in this city; both inside and outside the White House, about the relationship between Mr: Carter's lowkeyed rhetorical style and the sort of inspiration to which he ,referred;

title: Television
Saint Laurent Displays Top Form.....
description: PARIS, Jan. 25By the time Yves Saint Laurent finished showing his summer fashions today to an audience that reflected all the fervor of revival meeting, applauding almost every model all the way during her march down the long runway, one conclusion became Inescapable: The Master could have wrapped a telephone book around model and he would have started trend;

title: Archie Wyatt, Worked as Indexer In Picture Library of The Times
description: Archie Wyatt, an indexer in the picture library of The New York Times, died in his sleep Tuesday night at his home in Newark. He was 54 years old.

title: Jacques Buitenkant, A Criminal Lawyer And Union Counsel
description: Jacques Buitenkant, general counsellor Local 32E of the Building Service Employees. International Union for the- last 40 years, died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 1000 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: FRANCE HINTS RETURN TO ARMSCURB TALKS
description: PARIS, Jan. 25President Valdry Giscard. d'staing called today for creation of an international satellite system to monitor the flow of arms around the worlda move that Western diplomats interpreted as paving the way for France's return to armscontrol negotiations without the loss of face.

title: TALKS ON BELIZE FAIL TO RESOLVE DISPUTE
description: LONDON, Jan, 25An intensive new round of negotiations has failed to resolve the longstanding dispute over Bel1 ize, the British colony in Central Ametrea that is claimed by Guatemala.

title: Unions Protest Storm Pay Ruling
description: Leaders of New York State and city municipal unions criticized Governor Carey and Mayor Koch yesterday for their decisions to subtract a full day from the personal leave of employees who did not report to work last Friday because of the blizzard.

title: Q&A;
description: Q I have a precast plastictype shower floor that is stained by mineral and soap deposits. I have tried many solutions, jellies and detergents, but to.no avail. Is there a practical way to clean his surface, and if not, can it be painted?W.B.G., Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: UNIONS FORCED KOCH TO RENEW LOAN PLEA
description: New York City's labor unions refused the role Mayor Koch proposed for them, when the city's financial plan was being put together, forcing the Mayor to request continuation of the Federal seasonalloan program, it was learned yesterday.

title: Appointments Criticized
description: Two organizations representing black and Hispanic employees of the New York City Department of Correction, the Guardians Association and the Hispanic Society, charged that the Koch administration was failing to ap- point minoritygroup members to policymaking posts in the Correction Department and other city agencies.

title: Assembly in Albany Votes to Shift Primary From September to June
description: ALBANY, Jan. 25In a rare show of unity among political opponentsincluding the allies of both Governor Carey and Perry B. Duryea, the leading Rpublican candidate for Governorthe State Assembly passed a bill today to change state and local primary elections this year from September to June.

title: WNYC Director Moves to WHET
description: THE DIRECTOR of the Municipal. Broadcasting System, operator of WNYC AM, FM and UHF Channel 31, WNYCTV, Arnold Labaton, will leave his job tomorrow to take up new duties next week at WNET/13, the publictelevision station that has proposed that it take over the cityowned stations.

title: Cowboys Martin Wins an Award, But Is a Loser on the Disco Scene
description: Harvey Martin was blocked better by New York discotheque doormen yesterday than by offensive tackles around the National Football League last season, and so the highlight of his trip to New York must be holding hands in the rain for five minutes witn Randy White, who is not that close a friend.

title: ARGENTINA REJECTS RULING ON 3 ISLANDS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25Argentina repudiated today an international arbitration decision awarding three disputed islands to Chile, but, according to military sources here, it will not press its claims by armed force.

title: G.A.O. Warns of a Disaster Peril Posed by Liquefied Gas Storage
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The General Accounting Office has concluded that serious storm, an earthquake or a terrorist attack could cause a major rupture in installations used to store liquefied energy gas throughout the United States, causing the deaths of tens of thousands of Americans.

title: Notes on People
description: ANNE and Jack McGuire, the Belfast couple whose loss of three children led to the founding of the Northern Ireland Peace Movement, yesterday gave up their new life in New Zealand and returned home. The McGuires moved to Auckland last year after their cmidren were killed by a getaway car of the Irish Republican Army. Mrs. McGuire's sister, Mairead Corrigan, founded the Peace Movement with Betty Williams, and the two later won the Nobel Peace Prize. But the McGuires gave up New Zealand because, said a friend, Anne has been sick and homesick and wanted to go home and see her mother and the family.

title: ArabIsraeli Cultural Barrier Hampers Efforts to Achieve Accord
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 25The participants in the boggeddown Egyptian-Israeli peace negotiations are attemptingunder quiet pressure from the United Statesto put aside their recent exchanges of invective and find some corn- News Analysis mon ground for renewing negotiations. In addition to the United States, many news commentators here and abroad have been calling for quiet diplomacy and an end to the war, of microphones, as one analyst here described  recent remarks by Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Rape Suspect Seized
description: A member of the Hell's Angels was arrested and charged with raping a 16yearold girl in the Angel's clubhouse on the Lower East, Side. Another rapist got away, the police said, and 11 guns were confisticated in a search of the clubhouse, at 77 East Third Street,

title: Controversial Beame Deputy Mayor Being Considered for Federal Post
description: Lucille Rose, a former Deputy Mayor in the administration of Mayor Abraham D. Beame, who supervised the distribution of tens of millions of dollars in Federal job training funds, is being considered for a job as the United States

title: Marston Criticizes Internal Inquiry on His Removal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25David W. Mdrston, who was dismissed last week as United States Attorney in Philadelphia, said today that the question of whether obstruction of justice was involved in his removal was a legitimate subject for investigation. But he said that the in- quiry, should be handled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a grand jury, not by Justice Department attorneys.

title: The BuiltOn Cost of BuiltIns
description: Lux Prewar bldg, huge 2 BR, 24 hr drmn, w/wbfpl, very reasonable ...

title: Cuba Hits Kuhn Ban On Game
description: A high ranking Cuban sports official expressed surprise yesterday at Bowie Kuhn's refusal to let a major league allstar baseball team play in Cuba and suggested the commissioner must have some undisclosed objection to such game.

title: Gems For Your Tool Box;
description: SHOW ME a home and I'll show you six broken appliances, lock that needs graphite, screw with its head broken off, a chair with a broken leg, a jar that can't be opened and some wood that needs splitting. Brookstone wants to help.

title: Precious Metals Futures Turn Mixed, Copper Declines and Frozen Orange Juice Gains
description: Prices of precious metals futures closed mixed yesterday as a weaker dollar, improved prospects for peace in the Middle East and the decision by some traders to convert recent large profits into cash had a diverse impact on the markets.

title: Miss Wenzel Wins Again
description: BERCHTESGADEN, West Germany, Jan. 25 (AP)Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein, skiing brilliantly in the last race before the world Alpine championships, won her third straight women's special slalom today and retained big lead in the World Cup standing.

title: WARREN HALL
description: Warren Hall, a writer at The Daily News until his retirement in 1971, died Tuesday at the home of, hisson, Richard, in Huntington, L.I., where I e resided. He was 75 years old.

title: People and Business
description: William L. Cary, Dwight Professor of Law at Columbia University and former Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been named to the Public Oversight Board of the Arnericin Institute for Certified Public Accountantsa new selfregulatory apparatus for public accounting firms.

title: TinyBoxes Are Big Hit In London Shop
description: JUST OFF BOND Street in London, a small shop called Halcyon Days has become a mecca for those intrigued by the little boxes knoWn as Battersea enamelsthose tiny objets d'art that bear sporting scenes, or paintings of historic British buildings, or garlands of flowers with tender of philosophical messages.

title: Bloustein to Take Leave
description: Rutgers. University's president, Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, wil take a sixmonth leave of absence later this year, university officials said. hTey said Dr. Bloustein would do research at Oxford University in England on a book he planned to write.

title: They Never Learn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Relax, everybody: Your Department of Justice has just declared the Attorney General and the President innocent of obstruction of justice when they obliged a Congressman under criminal investigation and fired the prosecutor who was bothering him.

title: Archie Wyatt, Worked as Indexer In Picture Library of The Times
description: Archie Wyatt, an indexer in the picture library of The New York Times, died in his sleep Tuesday night at his home in Newark. He was 54 years old.

title: A Flowering Beauty, Despite Its Name
description: IN THIS WINTER of flu, colds and sore throats, one should perhaps hesitate to bring up a medicinalsounding name like streptocarpus. Yet if you are unfamiliar with this delightful family of flowering plants, now is the time to get acquainted. Buy a plant now and the blooming season, which runs eight months or more, will soon be upon it. And it will brighten any indoor garden .without effort. This is also the time to divide old plants if you have them, or plant new ones from seed.

title: President Asks Senate to Ratify 1977 International Sugar Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25(AP)President Carter asked the, Senate today to ratify the 1977 international sugar agreement, saying it would help consumers by guarding against high prices and insuring adequate supplies for domestic needs.

title: THERESE BONNEY, AT 83; A JOURNALIST IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Jan. 15 (AP)Therese Bonney, an American journalist and photographer and Paris celebrity, has died of heart failure at the American Hospital here. She was 83 years old.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 26, 1978

title: Auction Stars of 1977
description: FROM MEISSEN to Mickey Mouse, the world records made in the international auction market in 1977 were most impressive. Banner sales and skyrocketing prices were registered for antiques and colleotibles here, in London, Monaco and Geneva. In the process, many world records were toppled and collecting trends either emerged or were confirmed.

title: Oil Companies Earnings Show an Upward Trend
description: Oil companies yesterday continued to report a mixed but generally upward trend in profits.

title: Notre Dame Wins 13th, Syracuse Captures 14th
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 25 (AP)West Virginia's Lowes Moore scored 40 points, but the Mountaineers couldn't overcome a poor first half, and Notre Dame coasted to a 10382 victory tonight.

title: E. F. HUTTON GROUP NET FELL 40% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: Fourthquarter earning of the E.F. Hutton Group Inc., the parent corporation of E.F. Hutton & Company, declined 40 percent on a 11.7 percent gain in revnues, the company reported yesterday. Earnings for 1977 fell 31.5 percent on a 6.3 percent revenue increase.

title: Adul tCoursesina Crowded Market
description: When the New School for Social Research offered its first courses in 1919, one of the founders, Charles A. Beard who revolutionized interpretation of the Constitution by stressing the economic motives of its frames was aghast to find the school advertising its wares. Good God, he exclaimed, they are selling us like a new brand of cheese!

title: NEW YORK TO APPEAL PROSTITUTION RUING
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that Ilk office would appeal a decision by a Manhattan Family Court judge who declared unconstitution, al key portions of the state law governing (sexual behavior.

title: Fears of a Roof Defect Preceded Collapse at Hartfoid Civic Center
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 25For more than five years, Hartford city officials and business leaders openly expressed doubts about the safety of the huge roof over the Coliseum, the centerpiece of the $70 million Civic Center that was to pull the city back out of two decades of decline.

title: Muriel Humphrey Accepts Appointment to Husband's Senate Seat
description: HILLSBORO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2bMuriel Humphrey was appointed today to fill the United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of her husband, Hubert H. Humphrev. When she takes the caln or office, probably early next month, she will beccme the first woman to serve in the Senate since Maragaret Chase Smith of Maine lost a bid for reelection in 1972.

title: NEW &
description: The handiest thing to have had around the house last week was a snow shovel. But for those who took unexpected plunges into mounds of snow piled on corners, it might have helped If the office papers had been in, a plastic briefcase rather than that expensive leather one. For those stormy mornings, consider this lightweight opaque case thatcan be tucked away with your umbrella. Measuring 12 inches by 16 inches, with a depth of three Inches, it can hold the morning newspaper as well as office work. The briefcase, in white only, can be purchased at Morsa, 182 Hester Street, for $16.

description: New York City and nearby suburban areas intensified efforts to clear catch basins and drains to ward off potential flooding as heavy rains began yesterday. The rain was expected to continue today, melting much, of last week's snowfall.

title: Deaths
description: ABERLEMartha Rosa. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. Age 92. Died Wednesday, January 25, 1978. Mrs. Aberle is survived by her daughter, Vera Ries, her sister, Hattie Gutherman, four grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. Services will be held Thursday, January 26, at 11:15 A.M., at Schwartz Bros. Memorial Chapel, 114.03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Leafs Beat Rangers On 2dWilliams Goal
description: Dave (Tiger) Williams, the National Hockey League's penalty leader, behaved like a gentleman and a goal scorer last night in leading the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4.3 victory over the New York Rangers. Williams's second goal of the game, scored after 1 minute 52 seconds of the third period, proved decisive in the first of four meetings this season between the teams.

title: David L. Cole, 75, Lawyer, Dead; A Noted Arbitrator and Mediator
description: David L. Cole, a lawyer who helped develop arbitration and mediation in an era of labor strifethe 1930's, 40's and 50'sdied at his home in Paterson, N.J. yesterday. He was 75 years old.
