title: Grand Jury Is Preparing to Indict In Manhattan Court Bribe Inquiry
description: A Manhattan grand jury is preparing to vote indictments based on an eightmonth investigation into allegations that lawyers have paid bribes to fix cases in the borough in the civil part of State Supreme Court.

title: Nkomo Tells Condition for Pact
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 25 (AP)Mr. Nkomo said today that the Patriotic Front would accept a ceasefire with Rhodesia only as a consequence of an absolute guarantee of the certainty of independence. He added that the front's liberation forces must provide that guarautee.

title: Conn. Police Checking. Fixing of JaiAlai Games
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Jan. 25 (AP) The state police are investigating the Possible fixing of games at the Hartford jailalai fronton and state prosecutors have been called into the case, state gaming officials said today.

title: Philip Morris Earnings in 4th Quarter Rose by 25.7%
description: Philip Morris Inc., the nation's secondlargest cigarette producer after R. J. Reynolds Industries, reported yesterday that its fourthquarter earnings were up 25.7 percent and for all of 1977 rose 26.1 percent.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP)After a 33year strugrle, the aiiblack 761st Battalion, has been awarded the nation's highest military honors for its combat role in World War II. Without fanfare, President Carter awarded the Presidential Unit Citation yesterday, citing the 761st for extraordinary heroism in action.

title: Carey. Is Grandfather For the Third Time
description: Susan Carey Dempsey, a daughter of Governor Carey, gave birth to a 7pound, 12ounce girl yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital. The baby, named Katherine, is the Governor's third grandchild.

title: Carey Is Grandfather For the Third Time
description: Susan Carey Dempsey, a daughter of Governor Carey, gave birth to a 7pound, 12ounce girl yesterday mornirig at Lenox Hill Hospital. The baby, named Katherine, is the Governor's third grandchild.

title: Advice for Motorists (If They Must Drive)
description: The Automobile Club of New York advised motorists yesterday to avoid all unnecessary driving when roads are icy, slushy or flooded to save themselves time, aggrdvation, and possibly an accident, and it advised those who must drive to observe the following points of safety.

title: DISTILLATE OIL SUPPLIES OFF IN WEEK ENDED JAN. 20
description: Supplies of distillate oil were off sharply to 226.4 million barrels in the week ended Jan. 20, down from 236.4 million barrels the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Hire And Salary

Some critics called it check- book journalism. Others complained that the interviewing had not been skillful enough to extract significant new information.

title: Effort by Massachusetts to Stop Offshore Leases Stalls in Court
description: BOSTON, Jan. 25Hearings got under way in Federal District. Court here today on a request by Massachusetts and number of environmental and fishing groups for a preliminary injunction halting the auction of oil and gas leases on the Georges Bank fishing grounds next Tuesday.

title: Stocks Aided by Improved Profits; Gain in Dow Is Shaved to 0.87
description: as prices edged higher yesterday as investors continued to focus on improved corporate earnings reports for the latest quarter.

title: Home Improvement.,
description: CERAMIC tile, long recognized as one of the most permanent and maintenancefree surfacing materials for home use, has become more popular than ever in recent years. Although a good deal of this renewed interest is because ceramic tiles now come in a wider range of colors, styles and sizes and thus blend better with all types of decorative schemes, most people in the industry agree than an even stronger impetus has been provided by the fact new adhesives introduced in recent years. These make it possible for the do-itypiirselfer to install ceramic tile over most solid and reasonably smooth walls, floors, countertops and other surfaces without messy mortartype cements, and, in most cases, without calling in a professional.

title: Disks: The SaintSaens Third
description: SA1NT-SAENS: Symphony No. 3; Wedding Cake for piano and strings. Daniel Chorzempa, organist and pianist; Edo de Waart conducting the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra. Philips (9500 306).

title: Hers
description: IT IS NO news that many women are defecting from the ranks of civil libertarians on the issue of obscenity. The conviction of Larry Flynt, publisher of Hustler magazinebefore his metamorphosis into a bornagain Christianwas greeted with unabashed feminist approval. Harry Reems, the unknown actor who was convicted by a Memphis iury for conspiring to distribute the movie Deep Throat, has carried! on ohs legal battes with almost be support from women who ordinarily regard themgelves as supporters of the First. Amendment. Feminist. writers and scholars have even discussed the possibility of making common cause against pornography with adversaries of the women's movementincluding opponents of the equal rights amendment and right to life forces.

title: Russian Winter: Time of Diversion
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24This may be the only metropolis where people think of snow and crackling crisp cold as a blessing, not a curse. A heavy white mantle has been covering the grime of the city since early December, and The Talk of Moscow for days the sun has set in the clear blue sky without the temperature rising above 15 degrees. It's wonderful, said Vasya, a 36-year-old craftsman, the other day. It takes my mind off all our problems.

title: Leonard Silk
description: In the past, G. William Miller's nomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board would doubtless have sailed through the Senate Banking Committee and the Senateand probably it will now, though somewhat more slowly, with more on Capitol Hill. A few factors are likely to delay the progress of the Textron Inc. board chairman to his seat at the head of the table at the Federal Reserve Board. One is, of course, the payment of $2.9 million in Iran by Textron subsidiary, the Bell Helicopter Company, to a sale agency, Air Taxi, the owner of which was said to be Gen. Mohammad Khatem, head of the Iranian Air Force and who died in an accident in 1975.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL, AFTER RECORD LOSS, EARNS $19.2 MILLION
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which in the third quarter last year reported a loss of $477 million, the largest loss ever for an American company for a quarter, said yesterday that it had returned to profitability in the fourth quarter.

title: CARTER PLAN OPPOSES A DISNEYLAND NORTH
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25The Carter Administration has moved to resolve an eight-year-old controversy over the proposed creation of a ski resort in the Mineral King Valley, high in the Sierra Nevadas, that conservationists have been opposing.

title: Arson Homicide Inquiry
description: Mayor Koch said that he had asked Herbert Sturz, Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, to look into Police Department charges that lack of cooperation by fire marshals had impeded investigations into arsonrelated homicides, including the Bronx socialclub fire that killed 25 persons in October 1976.

title: Census Data Show Growth Slowing in Partof Sunbelt
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The latest population estimates by the Census Bureau contain hints that growth may be slowing in some parts of the Sunbelt.

title: Cornell Six Beats Princeton
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP)Sixthranked Cornell edged Princeton, 76, in college hockey tonight as a freshman wing, Roy Kerling, scored the winning goal with eight seconds, left in the game. The victory lifted Cornell to a 10-4-1 won-lost-tied mark over all and a 6-4-1 record in the Eatern College Athletic Conference. Princeton dropped to 28.2 and 1-7-1.

title: LIGGETT GROUP PRESIDENT LASHES OUT AT CALIFANO
description: DURHAM, N.C, Jan. 25 (AP)The president of Liggett & Myers's parent company has lashed out at Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, calling him silly ass and saying that'his antismoking campaign could put small tobacco ,companies out of business.

title: Canadians Weigh Damage Claim
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 25  Canada may present the Soviet Union with a damage claim as a result of the disintegration of a Soviet spy satellite over northwestern Canada, an official of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's office said today.

title: ScholarsServants
description: AMHERST, Mass.There are implications for us all in the suggested intention of the Yale faculty to reclaim the power and authority it has recently lost to its own administrators. The suggestion that administrative servants have become masters helps us to put the priorities correctly.

title: STANS REPRIMANDED BY BOARD OF REGENTS
description: The New York State Board of Regents yesterday censured Maurice H. Stans, the former Secretary of Commerce, in connection with his plea of guilty to charges that he violated Federal election laws while serving as finance director of former President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign.

title: A New Kitchen for the Cook, and, a Greenhouse for the Cacti
description: DNA GOLDBERGER delights in cooking the way other women paint or sculpt. It is my creative endeavor, she said. When she isn't cooking for her family and friends, she's cooking for her freezer. Her husband, and her three children when they were growing up, never had to worry about bringing home unexpected guests for dinner: Mrs. Goldberger was always ready.

title: Market Place
description: The Securities and Exchange Commis sion has a tough set of rules governing goingprivate transactions under consideration that some corporate executives fervently wish would apply to surprise tender offers as well.

title: Sound
description: WHEN A PROPER NAME becomes a common noun it usually means that its owner has done something radically new and greatly importnt. Our language casually incorpoates watts, volts, ohms, amperes, oentgens and diesels without even ?othering to capitalize them; and a ?? cent addition to this illustrious compsAy is Dr. Ray M. Dolby, who is sometimes spelled with a small d in the technical literature. In fact, he has .gone beyond nouns and become a verb to wit, dolbyized tape, which puts him on a par with pasteurized milk. And on top of all that, he's alive and well in California.

title: Community Group In Queens Denies Any Wrongdoing
description: The executive director and the chairman of the board of the Central Queens Community Corporation yesterday denied allegations of k mismanagement and fraudulent activity in operating its youthemployment program.

title: Jack Lemmon Returns To Broadway in June
description: Jack Lemmon will return to Broad way in June for the first time in more than 15 years, appearing in a new play, Tribute, by Bernard Slade, author of Same Time, Next Year.

title: Atomic Test Witnesses Tell of Health Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)A group of former military men who witnessed atomic bomb tests in Nevada and the Pacific told a House subcommittee today that they had to live with severe health problems ever since.

title: About New  York
description: In the laboratory, the favorite of Dr. George D. Ruggieri, S.3., is the octopus, the smartest and most maligned invertebrate, which has suffered monstrous fictions but which delights scientists by learning to tell on: flashcard shape from another.

title: Gunman Gives Up Hostage And Plane at Nevada Airport
description: WINNEMUCCA, Nev., Jan. 25 (UPI)A gunman who took an Idaho city official and deputy sheriff hostage, then exchanged them for a pilot and light plane, surrendered today after five hours of negotiations with officers who shot out the tires of the aircraft when it landed to refuel.

title: The Sabotaging of Public Space
description: TO NEW YORKERS crowding into. The Market at Citicorp Center, this delightful potpourri of shops, restaurants and pedestrian space is a lively and useful enrichment of Manhattan's East Side. It is clear that what could have been just one more forbiddingly elegant corporate tower is, instead, a new and very vital part of New York.

title: Carey Ready to Name FundRaiser To Seldom Show Thruway Post
description: Governor Carey is preparing to appoint his leading fundraiser, Louise Sunshine, to a $17,000 seldom show job on the State Thruway Authority despite the warnings of advisers that the appointment would come under heavy criticism.

title: Elusive Commodities Dealer Denied Bail in Florida
description: TARPON SPRINGS, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)A United States magistrate in Tampa denied bail today to Alan Abrahams, who was arrested here early this morning and ordered him sent back to New York in Federal custody to face charges of parole violation. No date was set for the return.

description: DENVER, Jan 25  (UPI) David Thompson; held'to only 8 points'in the first half, scored four in overtime and finished with a teamhigh 34 tonight to rally the Denver Nuggets to a 121. 119 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: BYRNE SAYS FARMERS FACE OFFERS TO SELL
description: TRENTON; Jan. 25-Governor Byrne Warned the state's farmers today. that the gambling casino hotel industry and other developments would intensify pressure on them to sell out, but he emphasized his support of efforts to preserve New Jersey farmland.

title: It Pays to Be a Quarterback
description: The average salary for a National Football League quarterback Is more than $89,000 a year, some $34,000 more than the average for all players, a survey released yesterday by N.F.L. Management Council disclosed.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS SAY PALESTINIANS ARE ARMING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25--Lebanese Christian leaders said today that arms for Palestinian guerrillas were pouring into the ancient Mediterranean port of Tyre.

title: Mitchell Doing Well in Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was reported in good condition and doing well today after surgeons repaired an artery in his abdomen. There is no change, said a spokesman for Georgetown University Hospital, where surgeons removed a large abdominal aortic aneurism from Mr. Mitchell yesterday in a threehour operation. An aneurism is a weakness, or ballooning, of the artery. The onetime Nixon Administration official is serving a prison sentence for obstructing justice and lying under oath in the Watergate coverup case.

description: Jacques Buitenkant, general counsel for Local 32E of the Building Service Employees International Union for the last 40 years; died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 1000 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 25 (UPI)Paul Gardner tapped in a powerplay rebound with two seconds remaining to give the Colorado Rockies a 33 tie with the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: Sony: Grace Bumbry Marks Her 20th Anniversary
description: FROM THE LENGTH and the volume of the ovations that greeted Grace Bumbry every time she appeared onstage at Carnegie Hall last night it was clear that the audience regarded her as not just another singer but an opera star. How- ever, what he soprano did during this recital showed just as dearly that she is not just another opera star but a singer, which is a much rarer and more cherishable phenomenon.

title: The U.N. Today
Donal McLaughlin, 103
description: Donal McLaughlin, who on his 100th birthday on Dec. 18, 1975, told friends that he attributed his longevity to never exerting himself with too much work or ambition, died on Jan. 16 at the age of 103 at the Isabella Geriatric Center in Manhattan.

title: Movie Figures Hear Jack Oakie Eulogized as Genius of Comedy
description: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 25 (AP)Jimmy Stewart, Jackie Coogan, Milton Berle and other celebrities joined a throng of 300 persons at Jack Oakie's funeral today and heard the comedian eulogized as a genius of comedy.

title: Flood Fears Well Up in the State In Heavy Rain and Thawing. Snow
description: Heavy rain and melting snow brought warnings yesterday from Civil Defense officials of possible flooding today in the Passaic River Valley as a result of rivers and streams overflowing their banks.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 25 (AP)Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland left today for Mexico City where he will confer with agricultural officials. title: 'Renaldo and Clara,' Film by Bob Dylan:Rolling Thunder
description: THERE'S an insolence about "Renaldo and Clara," the four-hour film written and directed by Bob Dylan and featuring members of his Rolling Thunder Revue, that is not easily ignored. Mr. Dylan, who has a way of insinuating that any viewer who doesn't grasp the full richness of his work must be intellectually deficient or guilty of some failure of nerve, has seen fit to produce a film that no one is likely to find altogether comprehensible. Yet for anyone even marginally interested in Mr. Dylanand for anyone willing to accept the idea that his evasiveness, however exasperating, is a crucial aspect of his finest work  "Renaldo and Clara" holds the attention at least as effectively as it tries the patience.No knowledge of Mr. Dylan or his history is supposed to be central to an understanding of the film, but it nevertheless trades heavily upon his past. The singer David Blue, playing himself, talks about the artistic climate of Greenwich Village when Mr. Dylan first arrived there, and Joan Baez is rather coyly cast as Mr. Dylan's former lover. Mr. Dylan, even more coyly, is cast as someone other than himself, a very vague figure named Renaldo.As an actor, Mr. Dylan specializes in giving the simultaneous impressions that he isn't really interested in acting, and that he is always acting anyway. Renaldo is thus virtually useless as a character, but his alleged presence in the film does help call attention to Mr. Dylan's obsessive camouflaging of his feelings, a tendency that produces the film's only intelligible conceit. There are only two central characters in the film, a man and a woman, yet their identities are splintered and then parceled out to a dozen different actors.The woman is most frequently played by Sara Dylan, who is now Mr. Dylan's ex-wife, but aspects of her can also be seen in Miss Baez, Ronee Blakley and Helena Kallianiotes. Mr. Dylan, Ronnie Hawkins and Rob Stoner are among the actors who stand in for the man. The two lovers, apparently about to become ex-lovers, are irremediably locked in battle, but the device of fluctuating identities prevents them from ever confronting each other face to face.This technique, not unlike one used by Robert Altman in "Images," is potentially an intriguing one, but Mr. Dylan's love of mystery prevails over his exhibitionism, with disappointing results. Most of the actors here seem to be playing either Mr. or Mrs. Dylan, and all of them slavishly do the director's bidding. But Mr. Dylan's instructiveness, to his actors and to his audience, is incomplete. "Renaldo and Clara" is so personal it borders on being obscure, yet it remains surprisingly deficient in personality. The figure who dominates the film is a man in hiding.Mr. Dylan has always been elusive; that's no mean part of his charm. But his best work, like the "Blood on the Tracks" album released a couple of years ago, has derived its momentum from alternating currents of passion and restraint, from conflicting impulses to repress and to reveal. "Renaldo and Clara" addresses this apparent contradiction so passively, even cold-bloodedly, that it seldom has the urgency it needs. The film is full of connections to be made and riddles to be solved, but it approaches these things so dispassionately that the viewer has little choice but to follow suit.Even though Mr. Dylan makes it clear that he in no way wanted to make a concert film, the footage of him in performance provides not only the film's most electrifying moments but also its most emblematic ones. On the Rolling Thunder tour, Mr. Dylan performed in whiteface, and he is photographed here in tight closeup, singing so ferociously that his sweat melts the makeup; the film's sense of a person at war with a mask is never more riveting than when the camera studies Mr. Dylan's face as he sings. Every detail of these shots is resonant, from the fiery look in Mr. Dylan's eyes to the fresh flowers that someone has apparently been hired to tuck into his hatbrim, just before each show.The film contains more than its share of dead weight, but it is seldom genuinely dull. On the credit side, there are a great many isolated images that have an independent vitality, from the sight of Joan Baez, looking unexpectedly dreamy in a white gown, to the spectacle of Allen Ginsberg, introduced as "without a doubt a very interesting and clever personality," reading his poetry to a bewildered band of middle-aged ladies.It's a pity that the editing of the film, which is credited to Mr. Dylan and Howard Alk, pays so little heed to consistency. Following a pattern of linear thought is clearly not one of the film's concerns, but maintaining a constant degree of intensity should have been; this way, by carelessly commingling very complex and suggestive episodes with very flat and simple ones, the editing continually throws an already befuddled viewer even further off balance. Interludes like the culminating meeting of Mr. Dylan, Mrs. Dylan and Miss Baez, at once quite rarefied and in an atmosphere that is amusingly mundane, and an exceedingly one-note segment devoted to Hurricane Carter, are so incompatible that they simply don't belong in the same movie.

title: Blumenthal Defends Carter's Economic Program
description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, seeking to rebut one of the main points of business criticism of President Carter's newly defined economic program, insisted yesterday that the $60 billion budget deficit targeted for fiscal 1979 did not threaten serious upward pressures on waves. prices or interest rates.

title: Carbide's Net Gain Is Held to 2.9% By ForeignCurrency Translating
description: Foreign currency translations and exchange adjustments depressed the fourthquarter net income of the Union Carbide Corporation, but the company wound up with a slim, 2.9 percent gain, it reported yesterday. It was the best showing of the year, as the preceding three quarters had shown sharp declines.

title: Dance: Phantom Given
description: NOTHING outglittered the 19thcentury Paris opera in talent or intrigue. The whiff of suppressed scandal added to its allure, and Gaston Leroux celebrated the iridescent aura in his novel The Phantom of the Opera: It was a story that irresistibly drew the late James Waring, who frequently blended high glamour with poignant sadness in his ballets.

title: Broadway
description: THE MIGHTY GENTS, which was called The Last Street Play when it was done at the Manhattan Theater Club, will come into the Ambassador Theater on April 13. Briefly, it is about a group of young men, hanging out on a street corner in Newark, who realize that they were happiest when they were members of a street gang called the Mighty Gents. Then they try to resurrect the street gang. Mel Gussow, reviewing that production for The New York Times last May, said. the play was an eloquent threnody to lost, spent youth.

title: Dayan Says Accord on Palstinians Is Within Reach

description: Three paintings previously believed to have been done by Rembrandt himself were instead done by other painters under the Dutch Master's influence, a team of researchers at Yale University has decided.

title: Police Station Bombed in Milan
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 26 (UPI)A police station was bombed here today, causing heavy damage, and other terrorist acts were carried out in Rome and Bologna, the police said. No injuries were reported in any of the attacks.

title: Middle West Battered by Deadly Blizzard
description: A. deadly blizzard hammered the Middle West, the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley into virtual paralysis yesterday. It marooned thousands of people, killed,] snowtrapped motorists and pedestrians and shut down government offices, factoshops and schools.

description: Manhattan's insurgent Democrats, flush with their electoral coup that has put the reform wing of the party in control of City Hall for the first time, celebrated last night at a fundraising dinner in honor of their own Mayor Koch.

title: Gold and Platinum Futures Ebb; Silver Prices Also Decline Slightly
description: Gold and platinum futures fell slightly yesterday after the London bullion price dropped $1.70 to $175.80 an ounce. But silver prices slumped after being unable to stay above the $5 level.

title: Leo Brouwer, Guitarist, To. Make, U.S. Debut

title: Sidney L. Katz, Architect Who Served as Chairman Of Pratt Graduate School
description: Sidney L. Katz, an architect and the chairman of the Graduate School of Architecture at Pratt Institute, died yesterday of a heart attack at St. Francis Hospital in Port Washington, L.I. He was 63 years old and lived on Half Moon Lane in Sands Point, L.I.

title: The Dangers of Cosmos 954

title: Britain to Pay I.M.F. $1 Billion Before Due
description: LONDON, Jan. 26Britain, dipping into its newly built hoard of currency reserves, will repay ahead of schedule $1 billion of its massive borrowings from the International Monetary Fund, Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey said today.

description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Jan. 26The famous Old Harbor Lifesaving Station at Chatham, once the focus of dramatic sea rescues along Cape Cod's treacherous shore, is now itself being rescued. The Government is trying to save it from the encroaching sea and to preserve it as a museum at Race Point in Provincetown.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
Does Civil Rights Include Energy?
description: It is ten years since Martin Luther King Jr. stunned his allies in the civil rights movementand their benefactor in the White Houseby leaping into another pasture of protest to join the opposition to the Vietnam War. His foray into foreign policy raised a basic question about the scope of black political activity: Should civil rights groups concern themselves only with racial equality and social welfare, or should they pursue the sources of inequality and poverty in the total fabric economic and even foreign policies? The question reappeared last week when the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People stepped forward offer what it saw as a black position on energy.

The suspect, Hugh Tracy, was arrested shortly after the battered body of his son, Carl, was found at their apartment at 170 Fenimore Street in the Crown Heights section.

Done with off- white walls, natural, darkwood beams and walls hung with colorful peasant pottery, this provincial, Czechoslovak restaurant on East 75th Street just west of First Avenue offers gracioUs, efficient service and soulsatisfying meals that range for the most part from $3.95 to $9.95.

description: WHATEVER the fate of the weather this weekend, New linrYorkers will find it brightened7in one case gloriously so by two television programs, though they could scarcely be farther apart in 'substance. intent and effect. One, RoYal Fieritage, to be shown tonight at 9 on Channel 13, is a colorful, majestic unfolding of the course of British monarchy seen through the buildings the kings and queens erected, the art works they accumulated, the adornments and possessions they sought for themselves. The other, National Kids Quiz on view between noon and 1 P.M. tomorrow on NBC, is a lightly done, but serious investigation of youthfIll psychological patterns in everyday living. Each program is worth the time invested in it.

title: Notes on People
description: In State Supreme Court yesterday, the divorced wife of Daniel Keith Ludwig, believed to be the world's last billionaire, filed a $10 million damage suit against him, seeking to have set aside a support agreement they made in 1939, two years after their divorce. Gladys Madeline Ludwig, who has been in Harkness Pavilion of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center since March, said in court papers that she was gravely ill and without assets or funds. She said that Mr. Ludwig tricked her into signing their support agreement and that over the years had misled her as to his ability to pay and had concealed his actual net worth. Mrs. Ludwig said that she had lost a kidney and the use of her legs an* left hand, and was suffering from breast cancer and cataracts of both eyes.. Mr. Ludwig's lawyer, who is to make a motion for dismissal, said, Mr. Ludwig has taken exceptionally good care of her throughout her illness.

title: Screen: Slouching Toward Berlin:Made in Exile
description: BERLIN, NOV. 3-11, is a city without sunlight. Mostly it rains. It snows occasionally but it's the kind of snow that is already gray by the time it reaches the cobblestones. Everything is damp, chilled. No winter coats anywhere. People cling to one another for warmth, but there is none. In effect, life is over in Ingmar Bergman's new film, "The Serpent's Egg." What we witness are involuntary twitches, the glazing of eyeballsthe onset of rigor mortis."The Serpent's Egg" is the darkest, most barren Bergman film since "Shame," and the windiest, most banal since "The Touch," full of dark portents that he treats as if they were his privileged information, as if they hadn't been in the public domain for nearly four decades. The film, which opens today at the Coronet, is dispossessed Bergman, Bergman in exile from his native Sweden whose serene political-social landscape has always highlighted the particular terrors of Bergman characters."The Serpent's Egg" is the first film to be made by Bergman after he voluntarily left Sweden to take up residence in Germany following his brush with the Swedish authorities. This information may not be relevant, but it might help to explain the peculiar sense of dislocation within his English-language screenplay, a melodrama that never quite makes any connection to the characters within it.The film, which takes place in Berlin in the week in 1923 when Hitler failed in his first attempt to take power, has the form of a mystery and some of the elements of rudimentary science-fiction, though, with hindsight, we (and Bergman) know it to be science-fact.The two principal characters are Abel Rosenberg (David Carradine), an American trapeze artist stranded in Berlin after his partner-brother has had a minor accident, and Abel's sister-in-law, Manuela (Liv Ullmann), who is separated from Abel's brother. In the film's opening sequence Abel returns to his hotel room to find that his brother has committed suicide for no apparent reason, leaving behind a barely legible note warning of people "being poisoned."In the succeeding days, Abel, who is a somewhat more mysterious character than Bergman may have intended, appears on the edge of an hysteria that has its origins in events that occurred before the start of the movie, as well as in the current events he participates in. Manuela, so beautiful and sweet-natured that we wonder why she and her late husband split up, sings and dances in a sleazy cabaret by night and works from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. several days a week in a whorehouse.While the city is apparently coming apart through apathy and inflation, Abel is losing his grip on reality. One morning he is picked up by a friendly, though menacing, police inspector (Gert Froebe) who suspects him of being implicated in his brother's death as well as in the unexplained deaths of a half-dozen other people he has known. Is Abel going out of his mind? If you know your standard mystery movie, you know he is not, but the explanations that Bergman finally gives us aren't worthy of the mysteries he has tantalized us with.It is Bergman's point that Abel and Manuela, in this week in which they attempt to survive in Berlin, witness the "nesting" of the serpent's egg, the embryo that 10 years later will hatch Hitler, the Nazis, the holocaust, World War II and all the evils we know eventually to have come forth.The audience, unfortunately, is way ahead of the movie's political forecast, which might not be fatal if Bergman's characters provided any particular insights, or interest. They don't.As played by Mr. Carradine, Abel Rosenberg is a wounded creature even before his brother's suicide. He may be surprised to experience anti-Semitism for the first time, but his surprise isn't enough to give the experience dramatic weight in the film.Miss Ullmann's Manuela is an extremely ladylike cabaret singer and part-time whore, and there is something perfunctory about the jazzy cabaret sequences shot in lewd colors and featuring performers in bizarre costumes and makeup. Decadence of this sort is the easiest thing in the world to capture on film, second only to the kind of suspense that can be generated by a horse race in a movieany movie.Bergman's villain, a mad scientist played by Heinz Bennent, is a B-movie creature. He's so rotten he almost seems to be an old friend, though he talks rather better than most villains as he describes the terrible things that will soon come to pass.Is this all there is to "The Serpent's Egg?" it seems to be, but there are indications that despair is really the film's theme, though this despair is made compelling on only a couple of occasions. The opening of the film with the brother's suicide is one of the most sorrowful sequences Bergman has ever done. There's also a fine, ghoulish sequence in which the drunken Abel breaks the window of a Berlin bakery shop, as if to make himself the object of the wrath that German Jews feel toward all Nazis.Mostly, "The Serpent's Egg" is a movie of beautifully photographed weather and handsome period sets and costumes that encase characters who remain as anonymous as the bodies in a morgue. It's dead.

title: For Children
description: THE LIME ORCHESTRA CONCERTS, directed Thomas K. Schuman, with BA bar The Elephant, at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Saturaay, at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. The series includes a second program Feb. 18 and a third March II. Individual tickets range train S3 to 56; subscription for the series Irons S7 to S15. Information: 757-3460.

title: Future Safeguards Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The United States is considering several possible actions directly with the Soviet Union and in multinational channels, to minimize future accidents such as the one that broke up a Soviet satellite over northwestern Canada, the State Department said today.

title: Jazz: Puccini Swings
description: THE CARNEGIE Tavern, the restaurant behind Carnegie Hall on 56th Street, became the Carnegie Hall Cabaret this week. But so far nothing resembling cabaret act has turned up there. In- stead, Michael Renzie, a bearded planist. and John Beal, bassist, play imaginative, lightfingered jazz and, for classical reference in keeping with the location, arias by Puccini as viewed through a jazz prism.

title: C. I. A. SAID IN 1974 ISRAEL HAD ABOMBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Central Intelligence Agency disclosed today that it had concluded as early as 1974two years earlier than previously indicatedthat Israel had already produced atomic weapons, partly with uranium it had obtained by clandestine means.

title: Satellite With Special Telescope Launched in International Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 26 (UPI) A satellite equipped with a special telescope was successfully launched today on a United StatesFuropean space mission that astronomers hope will supply more clues to the origin of stars and planets.

title: Anthony Abbatiello Assails Informant's Fix Charges
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26One of New Jersey's top harness racing figures, Anthony T. Abbatiello, denied under oath today that he had ever fixed a raco or knowlingly raced drugged horses.

title: Baron's Kidnappers, Apparently Not Political, Ask Millions in Ransom
description: PARIS, Jan. 26 (AP)Kidnappers of Baron EdouardJean Empain have provided proof they are holding the Belgian industrialist and have demanded a huge ransom for his safe release, French officials said today.

title: Republicans Criticize Carter's. Tax and Energy Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona, the House minority leader, contended today that President Carter's recommended tax cut was too low and called for a 30 percent across-the-board cut at 10 percent a year for each of three years.

title: A BEGINSADAT ACCORD ON AIMS CALLED NEAR; TRIPS TO U.S. DISCUSSED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Administration officials said today that Egypt and Israel were close to an agreement on principles for an overall Middle East settlement and that tentative plans were being discussed for President Anwar elSadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin to make separate trips to Washington in the next month to confer with President Carter.

title: S.E.C. Outlines Its Plans For One National Market
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Securities and Exchange Commission outlined its plans today for linking the nation's six major stock exchanges, and the over-thecounter market, in a single, highly competitive national market system for trading securities.

title: CHARLES H. SELLS, AT 88; PUBLIC WORKS OFFICIAL
description: Charles H. Sells, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority from 1949 to 1958, died yesterday at his home in Cross River in Westchester County, N. Y., after a short illness. He was 88 years old.

title: H.E.W. SETS OUT RULES ON AID FOR ABORTIONS FOR VICTIMS OF RAPE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Federal Government will help finance abortions for improverished women who are victims of rape or incest provided they or anyone reports the crime within 60 days to a law enforcement or public health agency, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today.

title: Foreign Relations Panel to Send Panama Treaties to Senate Intact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Agreeing to a proposal of the Senate leadership, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today that the committee would not attach amendments to the Panama Canal treaties, but would send the pacts to the Senate floor intact, with recommendations for changes.

title: Suzanna P. Love, Actress, Married to Ulli Lommel
description: Suzanna Potter Love, an actress, and Ulli Lommel of Berlin, a film director and actor, were married yesterday in the Municipal Building.

title: College Art Parley Draws 6,000
description: To the whirring of slide projectors and the rustle of scholarly papers, marathon Widest staged by the College Art Association is under way at the New York Hilton Hotel

title: Hamilton Five's Strong Suit Is Winning
description: When the locker room was vandalized at Alexander Hamilton High School last summer, all that were left were the old junior varsity uniforms, some of which had been around for 12 seasons.

title: RESIGNATION OF SOMOZA DEMANDED BY OPPOSITION
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 26 (AP) The two most powerful opposition political groups in Nicaragua demanded today that President Anastasio Somoza Debayle resign. It was the fourth day of a crippling national strike called to protest the killing of a prominent antiSomoza publisher.

title: Swiss to Vote on Car Ban
description: BERN, Jan. 26 (Reuters)A special Swiss Parliament commission approved: today a ban on the use of private mil for one Sunday a year. The measure is a counterproposal to a student demand. for 12 carfree Sundays a year. The students, by collecting double the required. 50,000 signatureson petitions, have forced a national referendum on the plan.

title: De La Roche Is Found Guilty and Given a Life Term
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 26Harry De La Roche Jr. was found guilty today of firstdegree murder for fatally shooting his parents and two younger brothers in their home in Montvale 14 months ago and was sentenced to life in prison.

title: A New York Youth Center Inspiring Policy in Washington Budget planners cite The Door's program as a model for dealing with teenage pregnancy.
description: All Tina was looking for was a place to stay, but that was hardly all she needed. Her mother, who had abused her since childhood, had thrown her out of, the house; Tina was pregnant and unmarried, wanted no more to do with the young man responsible, and she was deeply depressed, not to mention destitute.

title: Liberal Party Leaders Urge Levitt To Step Aside in Favor of Goldin
description: Liberal Party leaderswho since 1954 have endorsed Arthur Levitt six times as New York State's Comptrollercalled on him yesterday to step aside in favor of the New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

title: New Chief of Fraud Unit Named By U.S. Attorney in Manhattan
description: United States Attorney Robert B. Fiske Jr. has named Jed S. Rakoff to succeed John R. Wing as chief of the business frauds unit in the Federal Prosecutor's office in Manhattan.

title: TourTheater Package to Aid Bouwerie Lane
description: A Bowery walking tour with the Friends of Cast Iron Buildings on Sunday at 1 P.M. will kick off a benefit for the restoration of the Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 the Bowery. The walk will be followed by a performance of the Jacobean comedy by Philip Massinger, A New Way to Pay Old Debts, by the Jean Cocteau Repertory Company.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26 (Reuters) The French Pen Duick VI was first across the finishing line here on the third leg of the round-the-world yacht race today. But she was disqualified from the race because her skipper Sric Tabarly, began the leg from Auckland, New Zealand, last month mirth his racing certificate in doubt. The disqualification is subject to appeal.TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 26 (UPI)The International Olympic Committee's executive committee rejected South Africa's application for readmission and failed to agree on another application from China, Lord Killanin, president of the I.O.C. said today.

title: Byrne Signs Bills Offering Tuition Aid To 15,000 Additional College Students
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26Governor Byrne signed two bills today that will make an additional 15,000 New Jersey college students eligible for state tuition grants.

title: Overseas Kidnappings Spur New York Police Effort
description: Concerned that the rash of kidnappings by terrorists that has plagued other countries may spread to New York City, the Police Department has quietly set up and trained a 70member task force against kidnapping.

title: Stage: Soviet Play in Houston
description: HOUSTON

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP)A Liberianregistered freighter with 26 persons aboard radioed that it was sinking in the Gulf of Mexico today after three tons of explosives blew up in its hold. Search planes found no wreckage or survivors.WASHINGTON, jam 26 (AP)President Carter will make a twoday swing through New England next month and take part in a news conference and two town meeting events, the White House announced today.WASHINGTON, Jan. 26William H. Webster, President Carter's nominee to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is considering the possibility of resigning from three St. Louis clubs that have been charged with discrimination, a bureau spokesman said today.NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (UP1)David Duke, a Ku Klux Klan leader, said today that the organization was recruiting high school students across the country for Klan youth corps.WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Shampoos, lotions and other cosmetics have been found to contain substantial amounts of nitrosamine, the same cancer agent detected in crisp bacon and other cured meats, a scientist testified today.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 26 (AP)The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company struggling to keep afloat in a sea of red ink, acknowledged today that possible rescue effort by the Ashland Oil Company has collapsed.

title: U.S. Productivity Lags in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.26 (AP)  The productivity of American workers rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the final quarter of 1977, marking a sharp slowdown from the third quarter's 5.4 percent increase, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Philippine Day at Asia House
description: Music and dance of the Philippines will be featured in a performance at 2:30 P.M. on Sunday in Asia House, 112 East 64th Street. Reynaldo G. Alejandro, dancer and choreographer, and Priscilla Magdamo, a singer, will be

title: GERALD A. FLEET, 61, A SANITARY ENGINEER
description: Gerald A. Fleet, a sanitary engineer whose W. G. Fleet Associates advised and sold equipment to virtually every watertreatment plant. in Westchester County, died of a heart attack yesterday after jogging at the White Plains Y.M.C.A. He was 61 years old and lived at 9 Midchester Avenue in White Plains.

title: California Agency Yields in Northwest Water Rift
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26California water officials have- unexpectedly waved a flag of truce in a decadesold interstate struggle revolving around the state's dreams of wangling surplus water from the mighty Columbia River, which rushes through Oregon and Washington, huh, dreds of miles away.

title: Big A Set to Reopen
description: Although reports circulated yesterday that the roof had blown off Yonkers RacewaY, the only horse racing canceled in the wet and windy Metropolitan area was at Aqueduct.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Marni Nixon. Is Singing For Herself on Sunday
description: Although it has been more than 13 years since she was a ghost, Marni Nixon is still haunted by her past. Marni Nixon . . . where have I heard that name? people say.

title: G.E.'S 1977 EARNINGS UP TO $1.1 BILLION; SHARE GAINS $4.79
description: QUARTER UP TO $332 MILLION

title: ARMAND J. QUICK, 83; BLOODCLOT EXPERT
description: Developed Key Test That Is Used in Diagnosis Around World

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article In The Times yesterdayreported incorrectly that liquefied. natural gas heats more than half thehomes and commercial establishments in the United States and provides 40 percent of the nation's industrial energy needs. These statistics refer to all natural gas used in the United States, only a portion of which is liquefied.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Philharmonic Sets 2 NewMusic Concerts
description: Prospective Encounters, programs of contemporary music presented in informal surroundings by the New York Philharmonic, will consist of two programs this season, the first on Feb. 3 in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Seventh Street and Third Avenue.

title: KING'S BAY, GA., SELECTED FOR NEW SUBMARINE BASE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 26 (Reuters)King's Bay, Ga., has been selected as the site for a new base for missile submarines now based in Spain, the Navy announced today.

title: The U.N. Today
Blumenthal Answers Critics
description: In a major address here, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal yesterday sought to rebut business criticism of the President's economic program. In essence, he indicated, the business reaction was unfair. Page D3.

title: Irish Music Tonight, Theater Tomorrow
description: The Irish Arts Center will present a program of traditional Irish music and dance tonight at 9 P.M. in the Towerview Ballroom, Roosevelt Avenue and 61st Street, in Woodside, Omens. Tickets are $5. Reservations: 7573191 or 7573318.

title: Middle West Battered by Deadly Blizzard
description: A deadly blizzard hammered the Middle West, the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley into virtual paralysis yesterday. It marooned thousands of people, killed snowtrapped motorists and pedestrians and shut down government offices, factories. shops and schools.

title: De La Roche Found Guilty in Killing Of Family and Given Life Sentence
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 26Harry De La Roche Jr. was found guilty today of firstdegree murder for fatally shooting his parents and two younger brothers in their home in Montvale 14 months ago and was sentenced to life in prison.

title: STRIKE BY TUNISIANS ERUPTS IN VIOLENCE
description: TUNIS, Jan. 26 (AP)A 24hour general strike called today against the Tunisian Government erupted into violent demonstrations in a number of cities and led officials to declare a state of emergency.

title: Javits and Visiting Soviet Officials Clash Over the Shcharansky Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26A news contercnce of Soviet and American legislators erupted into dispute today over Anatoly Shcharansky, a dissiclent arrested in Moscow last year and later accused by the Soviet press of having worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: New York Area Gets Flooding, Winds, Fog and Sun
description: Bizarre weather harried the New York metropolitan area yesterday, flooding roads and delaying thousands of commuters with a twoinch rainstorm and its aftereffects, howling winds gusting at times to 60 miles an hour, dense fog and temperatures that soared to a springlike 58 degrees at 6 A.M.

title: Pakistan Raises Hijacking Penalty
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 26 (Reuters)Hijacking in Pakistan will now be punishable by death, a martiallaw regulation decreed yesterday. An official announcement said that hijackers could face execution or other penalties provided for in martiallaw regulations on serious crimes, such as the chopping off of a hand.

title: RAIN AND HAIL ARE BLAMED IN DC9 CRASH KILLING 72
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Southern Airways DC9 airliner crashed on a highway near New Hope, Ga., last year, killing 72 persons, because extremely heavy rain and hail caused a total and unique loss of thrust in both engines, Federal investigators reported today. The rain and hail caused stalling and major damage to the engine compressors, the National Transportation Safety Board said.

title: Tornado Destroys Marine Homes
description: QUANTICO, Va., Jan. 26 (AP)The Marine Corps says a tornado touched down at Quantico early today, damaging or destroying 21 duplexes. Master Sgt. Bruce Martin said that five persons were treated at the Naval Hospital for gas inhalation or minor injuries, but all were released. He said that 10 duplexes in the Midway Islands complex had been demolished and four damaged beyond repair.

title: WESTCHESTER COUNTY SNARLED BY WEATHER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26High Winds and melting snows created as much disruption in parts of Westchester and Rockland Counties today as the ice storm and blizzard of the last two weeks.

title: The Pop Life
description: DESPITE Emmylou Harris's obvious charms and her popularity, especially among countrymusic fans, this observer has had reservations about her. As a backup singer she is hard to beat, as her work with Bob Dylan, Neil Young and Gram Parsons (another cult hero whose genius escaped this reporter) attested. But her own records seemed to fall just a bit short

title: Donna McKechnie and the Young Poets Number
description: Holding hands like a string of paper dolls, the children filed across the Junior Museum stage at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in a miniature chorus line, led by a tall, darkhaired woman with a dancer's lithely dramatic body.

title: ItalianAmerican Group's Board Levels Charge of Wide Nepotism
description: Members of the board of the Congress of ItalianAmerican Organizations Inc., which operates more than a dozen citywide socialservice programs on a budget in excess of $2 million, have charged that the group's executive director placed at least 12 relatives and friends on the payroll. The board members also contend that most of the ,friends and relatives fo the directors, 62-year-old Mary C. Sansone, are unqualified for the position.

title: If You Love Antiques, This Is Your Season
description: THE 1978 antiques season gets off to a splendid start this weekend with events that will attract thousands of collectors, dealers, scholars and shoppers in search of relics redolent cif everything from a farmhouse in Vermont the Palace of Versailles. Those participating will have ample op- portunity to question art and legal experts on fakes and taxes, to examine Tang tomb guardians, rococo cabinets and Ammi Phillips portraits, and to spend little or lots of time and money on the wares that many of the country's top antiques dealers are exhibiting.

title: Paris: The Dress Has Its Day
description: PARIS, Jan. 26Valentino sent his couture collection from Rome Tuesday afternoon and the word got around. By this morning, his shop on the Avenue Montaigne, where his ready-towear is sold, was filled with the local ladies who shop and lunch. They can buy French couture styles any day. Valentino is a novelty.

title: Concern Over Securities Business Health
description: As stock prices continue falling, concern is growing in Wall Street about the health and the future of the investment business. Neither President Carter's longawaited tax program, detailed last weekend, nor the new benign intervention policy of the United States in the foreigncurrency markets to support the dollar has been able to stem the tide of investor pessimism: The Ad- ministration's tax package, in fact, has been a particularly bitter disappointment for the securities business.

title: House Vote Backs Offshore Oil Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The House signaled in a test vote today that it would pass a controversial measure designed to impose tighter controls on the development of offshore oil and natural gas reserves.

title: People and Business
description: The board of directors of the Becker, Warburg, Paribas Group, a large investment and financialservices firm with headquarters in Chicago, has elected Ira T. Wender president and chairman of the board's executive committee, effective Feb. 1. He is now a senior partner of Wender Murase & White, an international law firm that he founded in 1971.

title: OWEN A. SHEFFIELD
description: Owen A. Sheffield, who retired in 1954 as corporate secretairy of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., the creditrating organization, died Wednesday in Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived at 710 Center Avenue, River Edge, N.J.

title: U.S. Indicts 7 for Stock Fraud in Indecon
description: Seven men were indicted yesterday on Federal charges that they carried out fraudulent scheme to inflate the stock price of Indecon Inc., a company selling computer programming and consulting services.

Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today.

title: PAPER COMPANIES DENY FIXING CONTAINER PRICES
description: Two more of the 14 paper companies accused on Wednesday by a federal grand jury of fixing the price of corrugated cardboard containers issued comments on the charges yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dow Down 9.10 On News of Lag In Productivity
description: The stock market declined along a broad front yesterday as unfavorable economic news and interestrate worries, combined to send the Dow Jones industrial average down 9.10 points to 763.34.

title: Mrs. King Injures Leg
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Billie Jean King strained the hamstring in her right thigh last night and had to default her secondround match to Marise Krum of South Africa in a $100,000, women's tennis tournament.

title: A BEGINSADAT ACCORD ON AIMS CALLED NEAR; TRIPS TO U.S DISCUSSED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Administration officials said today that Egypt and Israel were close to an agreement on principles for an overall Middle East settlement and that tentative plans were being discussed for President Anwar elSadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin to make separate trips to Washington in the next month to confer with President Carter.

title: Chain Buys California Paper
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI)Freedom Newspapers has purchased The Victorville (Calif.) Daily Press, a 12,000circulation afternoon and Sunday newspaper, C. H. Hoiles, the Freedom Newspapers board chairman, announced today. The newspaper becomes the 28th in the Freedom group and its seventh in California. No sale price was announced.

title: Potholes Force Closing of Sections Of Major Roadways in New York
description: Potholes cratered streets and highways throughout the New York City area yesterday, forcing the closing of portions of major roadways and turning even short trips into bonejarring, nerve-rattling, mufflerripping encounters Of the worst kind.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, JANUARY 26, 1978

title: Lina Wertmuller in Plain English
description: Lina Wertmuller had a bad case of the flute. What she meant, of course, was the flu, but flute, with its musical connotations seemed an aptly symbolic and colorful description of her ailment. As she readily conceded, her English is not very good, but in common with the director herself, it has considerable charm. Like Chaliapin, she said about her voice, which was approaching a robust bass, Very sexy!

title: Art: Animals And Man at Yale
description: YALE has prodigious resources. They are owed to more than 250 years of disinterested accumulation on the part of very clever men and women who knew all that there was to know on their subject and were determined to share it with others. At no time and in no one place could these resources be put on view in their totality.

title: New York Area Gets Flooding, Winds, Fog and Sun

title: Advertising
description: Midlantic Banks Inc. of New Jersey has retained Case & McGrath as its agency and Case & McGrath is leading it into television in a big way.

title: Business Leaders Support Carey On Tax Cuts
description: Governor Carey's $755 million taxreduction program won support from business spokesmen yesterday, but ran into sharp criticism from the municipal labor leader Victor Gotbaum.

title: Brown Seeks to Cut Navy's Role in Nonnuclear War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Defense Secretary Harold Brown has tentatively ordered a major shift in strategy that is designed to, reduce the Navy's direct involvement in nonnuclear war by diminishing the role of aircraft carriers.

description: *As reported; not adjusted for transfers of loans to affiliated companies.

title: Editor Tells U.N. South Africa Views Embargoes as Joke
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26Donald J. Woods, a South African editor ,placed under restrictions for his criticism of the Government's racial practices. told the Security Council today that South African authorities regarded condemnations by the United Nations as a joke as long as Western governments continued to protect them from punitive action.

title: G.N.P. (Yawn) at $2 Trillion!
description: It should happen at 2:36 this afternoon, give or take a few minutes. There's no way you'll know it. If you're strolling down the street, it's not something you can see, like an eclipse. You're not likely to feel anything, like an earthquake. It will just happen.

title: U.S. Team Named For Title Skiing
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 26 (AP)Hank Tauber, director of the United States Alpine ski team, announced today the American team that will compete in the 1978 world championships beginning Saturday.

title: Porsche Leads in Monte Carlo
description: MONTE CARLO, Jan. 26 (UPI)Fiat swept the top three places in the first speed section of the Monte Carlo auto rally's final run today, but failed to make much impression on the overall lead of JeanPierre Nicolas and Vincent Laverne, both of France, in a Porsche Carrera. Nicolas and Laverne recorded the fourth fastest time, 9:15, .over the 11mile course and raised their lead to 1:42 over Frenchmen Jean Ragnotti and JeanMichel Andrie in a Renault Alpine.

title: Buerkle and Belger Present Millrose Mile Questions
description: Is Dick Buerkle really far ahead of everyone else in his winter training program? Or is Buerkle, after a world indoorrecord mile two weeks ago, ready to be overhauled by Filbert Bayi, Wilson Waigwa and Steve Scott in tonight's Wanamaker Mile at Madison Square Garden?

description: BASKETBALL

title: At Moscow U., No Blaring Stereos
description: NEW HAVENEach day when returning to Moscow State University I passed through a small, dimlylit guardhouse, flashed my pass and smiled at the jovial redhaired guard we had nicknamed Butterball. I continued through the whirring revolving door and into the towering, imposing building that houses the students and most of the classrooms. I climbed flight of stairs, flashed my pass once more, rode an erratic elevator to the seventh floor, where I nodded to the administratorattendant on the landing. I then walked into the suite of two rooms where we lived for the fall semester.

title: In Soviet Oilfield, Life Can Be Lucrative but Cruel
description: CLUSTER 64, FYODOROVSKOYE DEPOSIT, U.S.S.R.  At 6:50 A.M., when Aleksandr V. Kisdlyov boards the bus and heads for work in the oilfields, there is no hint of dawn in the black Siberian sky. Bundled in their rough, padded coats, he and other oilmen leave the town of Surgut like fishermen setting out from a snug harbor, into a sea of wind and wilderness where the winter daylight comes late and lingers only a few hours, casting a melancholy grayness across the endless flat expanse of scrub, pines and snow.

title: Islanders Defy Leafs Jinx, 42
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 26The Nevi York Islanders finally overcame a jinx tonight by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 42; in Nassau Coliseum.

title: Passman Enters Hospital
description: MONROE, La., Jan, 26 (AP)Former Representative Otto E. Passman, one of several Congressmen linked to the investigation of Korean influence buying, entered a hospital today, saying he was completely exhausted, mentally, physically and emotionally.

title: California Agency Yields in Northwest Water Rift
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26California water officials have unexpectedly Waved a flag of truce in. a decadesold interstate struggle revolving around the state's &earns of wangling surplus water from the mighty Columbia River which rushes through Oregon and Washington, hundreds of miles away.

title: Italian Reds Hold Parley and Insist on a Cabinet Role
description: ROME, Jan. 26The Central Committee of the Italian Communist Party began a twoday conference today by renewing its demand that the party be included in the Government and restating its commitment to an independent form of Communism.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker Taking a Walk Along the East River
description: CITIES have a way of turning their backs on working rivers. So maybe its not surprising thatwith a few notable exceptionsthe East River has been the obiect of considerable indifference. The walkway beside it that gives waterfront to Manhattan's Upper East Side is, for example, left along much of its route to weeds that thrive around the derelict benches and the railings that sag perilously at times out over the fastest moving river.

title: Saving the Life of a Lifesaving Station
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Jan. 26The famous Old Harbor Lifesaving Station at Chatham, once the focus of dramatic sea rescues along Cape Cod's treacherous shore, is now itself being rescued, The Government is trying to save it from the encroaching .sea and to preserve it as a museum at Race Point in Provincetown.

title: Pennsylvania Open Primary Voted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP)The Pennsylvania Democratic State Committee voted today to hold an open primary election, allowing the voters to decide which of the three gubernatorial candidates will represent the party in November Peter F. Flaherty former PittsburghMayor, Lieut. Gov. Ernest Kline and Robert Casey, former state Auditor General, each asked that no endorsement be given. The nominations and recommendations committee accepted their wishes.

title: HOUSE PANEL TO ACT ON U.S. PROSECUTORS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, Democrat of Wisconsin said today that the House Judiciary subcommittee he heads would hold hearings in March on the methods by which United States Attorneys were selected and removed.

title: Dollar Strengthens In Trading Abroad; Gold Is Off Slightly
description: The dollar improved against most major foreign currencies, while the price of gold fell yesterday in trading abroad and here, The Associated Press reported,

title: Overseas Kidnappings Spur New York Police Effort
description: Concerned that the rash of kidnappings by terrorists that has plagued other countries may spread to New York City, the Police Department has quietly set up and trained a 70member task force against kidnapping.

title: South Africa Easing Curbs In Area Nearing Freedom
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Jan. 27Nearly a century after Bismarck claimed this semidesert territory for Germany, the machinery of white domination is being dismantled rapidly in preparation for the birth of a vast, mineralrich African nation to be called Namibia.

title: Two Towering Votes for New York City
description: The dramatic new office towers that I.B.M. and A.T.&T. are about to erect side by side on Madison Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets,, will be significant additions to the New York skyline. That skyline will always be synonymous with the vitality and prestige of the business community. The importance of these new skyscrapers, in fact, lies not in the number of jobs they will provide as much as in their declaration of corporate Commitment to New York City. To build on this scale and at this cost, and with so much quality and style, requires a sense of permanence and of New York as focus. It puts both money and symbols on the line.

title: Former Aide Charges Rep. Flood Sold His Influence for $1009000

title: Boat and Life Jackets From Lost Ship Found
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (UPI)A: Coast Guard helicopter today identified a small boat, four life jackets and other safety equipment as articles from a missing Liberian freighter that apparently exploded and sank in the Gulf of Mexico with 26 persons aboard.

title: Verdict on Blue Put'Off
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday he would have no decision on the Vida Blue hearing until next Wednesday at the earliest. Kuhn said he was still reviewing the more than 12 hours of testimony presented at the twoday hearing involving the trade of Blue from the Oakland A's to the Cincinatti. Reds last month for $1.75 million and a minor league first baseman.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 27Governor Byrne's position on who will be the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate this year was strengthened today when the Hudson County Democratic chairman, Frank J. Guarini, said he would not enter the race for the nomination.

title: 35 From Iraq Jump Jet at Kennedy and Ask Asylum
description: A group of Christian refugees from Moslem Iraq, crying Freedom, freedom, please! rushed from an airliner at Kennedy International Airport yesterday afternoon and asked for political asylum.

title: JoAnne Carner Advances
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) JoAnne Carver, a sevenyear veteran on the Ladies Professional Golf Association circuit, came back from a twohole deficit through 12 holes today and defeated Nancy Lopez, 1 up, in the $105,000 match play tournament.

description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 27  Ohio biased, one newscaster said late last night.

title: Notes on People
description: When President Carter nominated Marion Edey to be a member of the Council on Environmental Quality several months ago, it was predicted that Senate approval of Miss Edey would not come easily. The prediction has proved correct. Yesterday Miss Edey asked Mr. Carter to withdraw her nomination, saying she was satisfied that you have done everything that could be done to secure her confirmation by the Senate. Miss Edey ran into trouble there because she is president of the League of Conservation Voters, which annually publishes what it calls the Dirty Dozen, an unblinking list of Congressmen who the league contends have done the most to harm the environment. The Senate Committee on Public Works'voted last Oct. 17 to postpone indefinitely consideration of Miss Edey's nomination.

title: Carmen Viale Freire Dows, 70, A Farmer Chilean Ambassador
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Carmen Vial Freire Dows, a former Chilean diplomat, died last Sunday at her family's farm in Puente Alto, Chile, after a long illness. She was 70 years old.

title: South African President Warns Of Total Assault From. Outside
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 27 (Reuters)President Nicholaas Diederichs warned today that South Africa was under total assault from the outside world as he opened a new session of Parliament, at which the country's system of racial separation is expected to be stiffened.

title: For the Federal Bench, the. Best
description: CHICAGONo President in history has had the opportunity, to name in a single, sweep perhaps as many as 150 new Federal trial and appellate judge's. Yet this is exactly the oppor- tunity before President Carter with the additional Federal judgeships expected in the near future under pending legislation. These new judgeships represent a 25 percent increase in the Federal judicial complement. Thus, the quality and competence of a sizable portion of the Federal judiciary can be transformed almost in one stroke.

title: Navy Air Post for Kinnear

The dismissals are part of efforts to reduce costs following the withdrawal of the United States from the 134nation organization last year. The United States withdrew to protest what it called irrelevant political activites by members. It had paid a fourth of the budget.

The increase was due to a 7 percent rise in the production of cars to 3,790,000. Commercial vehicle output fell to 313.700.

title: Brownell Quits as Higbee President
description: The Higbee Company, Cleveland, operator of department stores and specialty shops, announced yesterday that Henry G. Brownell had resigned as president, general manager and a director of the company. effective today. Mr. Brownell said he was retiring because he would like time to explore other alternatives. No permanent replacement for Mr. Brownell has been selected as yet.

title: No Separation or Divorce at TriState
description: F:or nearly two years the NassauSuffolk. Regional Planning Board has sought to free itself from reliance on the TriState Regional Planning Commission in the clearance of applications for Federal grants. Long Island's complaint is that the TriState Commission. which in- cludes, representatives of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, does less well for Nassau and Suffolk Counties than they could do for themselves in obtaining financial help from Washington. The TriState Commission feels that separation of any part of the region will weaken the regional response to major issues of transportation, housing and economic development. The arguments, of TriState's membersincluding a commitment by New York's Secretary of State, Mario Cuomoto work for Long Island's direct representation on the commission, have failed to persuade the NassauSuffolk people that going through with a formal separation would be illadvised.

title: Beyond the Panama Treaties
description: There have always been two battles between proponents and opponents of the Panama Canal treaties. One is rationalto determine whether the treaties as negotiated provide a basis for turning the canal over to the Panamanians while still guaranteeing its safety and rights of rapid American passage in an emergency. The other battle is deeply subjective. As a recent pamphlet by the American Security Council put it, there lingers among Americans a desperate feeling that giving away the canal would be wrong in some way more important than they know how to say.

When that face happens to belong to a 31-year-old dancer of supreme classicism and articulate good taste, an element of relief creeps into the clamor. And if the ballet in question happens to be a respectable pas de deux full of individual impulse and is greeted by critics with encomiums ranging from breezy, witty, even cute to stunningly original and a mature choreographer at work, well, then, a star is born.

title: THE SPINOFF FROM SPAACE
description: Someday they will write of these past 20 years of the 20thcentury, and they will not dwell on Vietnam, Richard Nixon, the Woodstock generation or, if cool heads prevail, the Middle East crises. They will very likely remark on the precarious state of atfairs produced by the looming threat of nuclear holocaust, the antagonisms and adjustments of postcolonial people, the pressures of escalating population and profligacy in a world running out of room and its primary source of energy. But above all else, assuming, as we must, that there will be many somedays in the future, they will look back and remember this time as the moment in history when restless, imperfect man reached out and began the exploration of space.

title: Fashion and Beauty
description: Cheryl Tiegs  whose face and body exemplify today's idea of beautystresses that keeping in shape takes work. Six years ago, I was overweight. I never exercised. I rarely took care of my skin. I assumed I would always remain beautiful. Then, like many women, she woke up one morning, looked into the mirror and realized that to remain attractive I had to take care of myself, even if only fora few minutes each day. For Cheryl, this means eating lightly, not much drinking and lots of exercisea rigorous gym workout three times a week and playing tennis as often as possible. Cheryl's idea of how she should look has also changed. About two months ago I tried a soft perm. It changed everything 1 thought about hair. Every time I step out of the shower, I now have a hairstyle. Like most models, she used to carry around a vast array of cosmetics. Now she needs only six or seven products to create a basically natural look. People think of models as beauties, but they are really not much different from anyone else, Cheryl says. title: FILM VIEW

If so, we owe it to him to find out.

Almost from the day his Administration took office, the Council and its staff has been pouring reports and advice into his ear and onto his desk, and often they have been listened to.

description: PHILADELPHIA, jan. 28Pennsylvania may have wrapped up the Ivy League basketball championship today as the Quakers survived a difficult, physical struggle with Princeton to beat the Tigers, 4944, at the Palestra.

title: Freeport's New Pioneers: Homesteaders
description: FREEPORT WILLIAM H. WHITE says that when he was a boy in this South Shore village in the 1930's, he would steal apples from a neighbor's tree. Today, at age 50, Mr. White is in his second term as the village's Mayor; today, the Mayor hears, certain children who have set out on a new kind of life here are taking apples from that same tree.

title: Therese Rosenblatt Fiancee of Stuart Arbeit

title: Dockers End FourDay Strike At Eight Ports in West Germany
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 28. (AP)Agreement on a new dockworkers contract ended the first general walkout at West German ports in more than 80 years today. The strike virtually shut clown eight ports Hamburg, oremen, Bremerhaven, Cuxhaven, Emden, Brake, Nordenham and Ltibeck.

title: CONFEREES TO HIGH REGIONAL DISPARITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Five hundred Americans from places as near as Arlington. Va., and as far away as Juneau, Alaska, will gather here tomorrow for Ihe.niost serious .exploration to date of the economic issues that increasingly are dividing the people and regions of the United States, particularly the Sunbelt and the Snowbelt.

title: New Life for Terismo OperasThe Sons Of `Cavi and Tag; The Sons of `CaV and Tag; SUPPORT VERISMO OPERA ; . A campaign button from the Verismo Opera Company.
description: I have written the opera with clenched fists, like my spirit! Do not look for melody; do not look for culture: in Marat there is only blood! Pietro Mascagni hurled forth this defiant statement describing his new opera Il Piccolo Marat in 1921. The composer's words could just as well serve to epitomize the spirit of those hotblooded, slice-of-life Italian musical dramas collectively called verismo that flourished in the early years of the century, a trend that had by 1921 virtually burnt itself out. Mascagni, whose first produced opera Cavalleria Rusticana created an overnight sensation in 1890 and spawned the entire verismo school, died in 1995, an impoverished and forgotten man. With a handful of exceptions, verismo opera, it seemed, died with him. But now the world appears ready to take a second look at these longneglected works, put them back on the stage and reassess their worth.

title: PRESIDENT FEELS GREAT AFTER 21/2HOUR CHECKUP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)President Carter underwent a two-and-a-halfhour physical examination today, his first since becoming President. Afterward, he told reporters. I feel great.

description: The American Civil Liberties Union accused President Carter this weekend of a disappointing and erratic performance on civil liberties issues in his first year in office.

After nearly two decades in which the Department of Defense built more barracks, awarded more contracts and employed more people in the South than the East, politicians in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and other Northeast states are asking some blunt and angry questions.

title: Women Still Strike for Peace

title: Court in Albany Clears the Dairylea Cooperative in MilkAdditive Case
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24A State Supreme Cdurt justice has dismissed the last pending indictment against the Dairylea Cooperative. Inc., one of the largest milk dealers in the state, with sharp criticism of the State Attorney General for having prosecuted the case.

title: Oil Has a New Path to Profits
description: It's the oldtime religionthose with production gains, those with more petroleum selfsufficiency, will do better on average than those without. E. Anthony Copp, an oil analyst with Salomon Brothers, was talking about oil company earningsyearend results started pouring in last week and about a fundamental change that seems to be taking place in the formula for making money in the oil business.

title: Hollywood's Biggest New Star Is Little Old New York
description: Movie making, a very big occupation in New York last year, is almost certain to be very big this year again. In the next few months, about a dozen movies will be made here, and while no one can say what will happen after that, it is possible that this year the movie business will be even more wondrous here than it was last. The movie people did many wonderous things last year, but the most wondrous is that they are supposed to have spent $100 million in New York while they made their movies. Nothing like that had ever happened before.

title: A Fighter's Toughest Opponent: A Father Who Hated Fighting
description: It will be a different feeling for me next Friday night at Madison Square Garden when I fight Bennie Briscoe. My mother and father are flying back from a vacation in Bari, Italy, just to see the fight.
