title: What's Doing in SOUTHERN VERMONT
description: LITTLE NEW ENGLAND - Even with skiers pouring in, southern Vermont remains New England in microcosm. A relatively small areadefined by Bennington and Brattleboro in the south, and by Rutland and White River Junction on the northcontains all the essentials of Yankeedom: the covered bridge and country store, the red barn and white farmhouse against the greenandwhite embroidery of the winter landscape, and, above all, the prim New England town idealized by Norman Rockwell. Nowhere can the New England way of life be observed more conveniently and congenially.

title: Too Many Bureaucrats, Too Few Spare Parts
description: CAIRO  A young blacksmith's apprentice explained last week why he supported his President, Anwar elSadat. don't want war, I want to eat bread, Hamdi elSayed said.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28President Carter is taking President Anwar elSadat to his retreat at Camp David next weekend for limited purposesprimarily to clear up some misunderstandings and create a better atmosphere for compromise and direct IsraeliEgyptian negotiations later on.

title: The Greening of Over-the-Counter
description: Last February an investor, described by his broker as an ultraconservative fellow who usually buys bonds and preferred stocks, took a flier on an overthe counter issue called Boothe Computer. He bought 500 shares at $9 a share in the company, now known as Boothe Courier, a manufacturer of cathoderay tube computer terminals. By the end of 1977, Boothe had proven to be a real flier, taking off to the tune of $14.25 bid.

title: BRIDGE
description: Deliberate incompetence is virtually unknown at the bridge table, but there are some rare situations in which a player may have reason for wanting to lose. In rubber bridge players with short tempers have been known to bid outrageously, wishing to punish a partner for some offence and being willing to suffer the same nnancial punishment in the interests of venting their spleens.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN Susan Lucci is spotted by strangers, they are as likely as not to greet her with something on the order of: Gee, I'd like to kick you in the teeth. But keep up the good work.

The 25-year-old Jersey City sprinter won the first major race of his career on the indoor circuit, upsetting a strong field in the 50meter dash in 5.7 seconds at the Ottawa Citizen Indoor Games.

He radioed the United States Coast Guard static., :---.- 3 ':,p a nearby grassy bluff here and reported that the barge was leaking oil.

Yet from the writings of such men as Livingstone, Stanley, the German Emin Pasha, Speke and Burton, it is clear that these were men who enjoyed their difficulties and enjoyed recounting them.

description: SPOKANE, Wash.. Jan. 28 (UPI)Gary Mellen, 33 years old, who admitted robbing 29 banks from Louisiana to Cali- fornia because he said it seemed tiKe toe easiest way to make money. has been sentenced to 30 years in prison by Federal District judge. title: Three Sisters
description: FIRST novels are often considered to be fragile things, vulnerable, worthy of the tenderest and most tactful kind of attention. The authors are sometimes described as promising, as though they had submitted only a sample chapter or two and would later go on to write an entire book. And then what they have written is handled as though it might break at any moment, given the kind of softtouch treatment usually considered necessary only for the handling Faberge eggs.

Since the appeal's start on Dec. 4, almost 9,000 donors have sent contributions, large and small. The millionsioliar milestone is within reach. This year's appeal is not over; it will continue full force through February.

title: Haas Gets Eagle on 18th For 72, Leads by Stroke

The stage was set for an unusual juxtaposition of humaninterest elements in tomorrow's final round, to be televised nationally by CBS at 4 P.M., New York time.

title: In Quartet With Duel
description: Among the more amusing reasons for undertaking the laborious orchestration of a piano quartet is to hold the pianist In check. But it was one of the reasons cited by Arnold Schoenberg, and the resultant score ironically furnished the choreographer George Balanchine the opportunity to create one of his most unfettered and lushly Romantic works, the BrahmsSchoenberg Quartet. Friday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet presented the work with an authoritative Daniel Duell partnering a charming Susan Hendl in its first movement.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE PEOPLE'S ALMANAC PRESENTS THE BOOK OF LISTS, by David Wallechinsky, Irving Wallace and Amy Wallace. (Bantam, $2.50.) As an occupaht of the hardcover bestseller list for the last 33 Weeks, this has been known as The Book of Lists. Under any name it is - as our reviewer observed packed to the covers with more fascinating, trivial, vital and perverse non sequiturs than you can shake an encyclopedia at.

title: Fashion and Beauty
description: The hottest 1978 swimsuit shape is the onepiece maillot. But this year, the maillot isn't what it used to be. Whether strapless, gathered through the torso, cut out at the sides or with straps crisscrossed on the back, these new suits are all slashed high at the sides for a dazzling display of leg. They combine the best of two worlds  they look sensational and they're designed for serious swimming. Put Cheryl Tiegs, one of America's most famous models, these suits and the result is nothing short of stunning.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Senator Robert C. Byrd, the Majority leader, said today that the Sen'ate would set a prece,dent and allow live radio broadcasts, though not telecasts, of the floor debate. on the Panama Canal treaty.

title: Oakland Bus Drivers End Strike
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan 28 (Reuters)Bus drivers here have voted to end twomonth strike that forced more than 100,000 passengers to find alternate means of transportation The drivers, negotiating a new contract, decided to return to work as they became faced with termination of union strike benefits.

title: THE CARTERS FAVORITES
description: On a kitchen wall in Plains, Ga., there is a little painting of a teapot, a stalk of celery and a tomato. The work is by Rosalynn Carter. And a short distance away, at the home Miss Lillian, there is another oil, a lake scene, by Jimmy Carter. The two Sunday painters have not had time to pursue their hobby recently. But they have discovered that one of the unexpected delights of living at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue has been the opportunity to surround themselves with other artists paintings.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW; Can These Bones Live?; Steven Guarnaccla; Literary View
description: SOME fifty years ago Virginia Woolf lamented, Men of taste and learning and ability are forever lecturing the young grid celebrating the dead. But the too frequent result of their able and industrious pens is a desiccation of the living tissues of ti:_erature into a network of little bones. Today the literary cemeteries are filled to overflowing. Even as the prestige and economic health of literary study seem to be failing, the universities have given us plethora of explications and biographies. Though literary criticism verges on the esoteric, biographies writers show up in great quantity on lists of the best hooks of the year and tend to appear on the cover of the Book Review with more frequency than any other genre. We have seen elaborate lives of less than major figures  Sinclair Lewis, Lytton Strachey and elephantine drudgery on such great writers as Lawrence, Hemingway and Faulkner. The art of literary biography  a mixture of narrative, social history, psychology and criticism  has too often dwindled into gossip and academic disquisition, leaving the interpretation and judgment of a writer's work to the

title: SADAT IS EXPECTED TO VISIT 6 NATIONS
description: CAIRO, Jan. 28In an effort to rally more international support for his tactics toward achieving peace with Israel, President Anwar elSadat is expected to widen his trip to the United States next weekend to include visits to five countries in North Africa and Western Europe.

description: WEST BERLIN, Jan. 28Faced with hints of political instability in East Germany and the lingering controversy over West Berlin, the Soviet Union has moved swiftly in the last few days to remind both the East and West of Moscow's political weight and military power here.

title: DoeS a Rich Man Do. More Expensive Time Than a PoOr One?;  Closing the Ring Around WhiteCollar Criminals
description: What should the penalty be for stealing $2.5 million? The crime in question, said Justice Samuel J. Silverman of the Appellate Division of New York State Sunreme Court. involved a calculated series of thefts and forgeries on a large scale and the betrayal of trust by a prominent lawyer. On the other hand,, the justice said, the crime did not involve any .violence. And, hesaid, while it is just as much a crime to steal from the rich as from the poor; it remains true that defendant's crime seems not to have subjected anyone to severe privation, orperhaps any. privation.

description: NEW HAVEN,Jan. 28After a yearlong investigation, the Board of Police Commissioners this week issued a report concluding that police officers and two former police chiefs had broken the law by recording thousands of innocent telephone conversations  in a longstanding, massive, illegal wiretapping operation.

title: State Funds: Ups and Downs
Bowie Solomon
description: N foolish consistency, Mr. Emerson tells us, is the hobgoblin of little minds, adored by little statesmen, and philosophers and divines. In somewhat similar vejn, William Allen White, the Kansas editor, wrote that consistency is a paste jewel that only cheap men cherish. On the question of whether Bowie Kuhn is a statesman or prulosopher the jury is still out, but he definitely is not a little one The club owners who pay his salary can testify that he is not cheap. And no witness to his performance as baseball commissioner could accuse him of consistency, foolish or wise.

(When he landed the natives thought he was the god Lono, who was due to arrive on a floating island.)

title: No Cure for Laetrile
description: The.National Cancer Institute has launched an evaluation of laetrile that may, as one expert aptly put it, be doomed to failure. The institute is asking all doctors who believe their patients have responded favorably to laetrile to submit the case records for analysis; patients who believe laetrile has helped them are asked to urge their doctors to comply. The goal is to determine whether there is any documentation that laetrile is enective in reducing the size of tumors or otherwise combating cancer. But this review may backfire and make it impossible to conduct. the fullfledged clinical trial that offers the best hope of resolving, once and for all, whether the controversial substance made from apricot pits has any value whatsoever.

title: $97,381 Split in Twin Trifecta
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Jan. 28 (AP)Two fans in a crowd of 3,126 split a twin trifecta jackpot of $97,381.20 at New England Harness Raceway today, the largest payoff in New England harness racing history.

title: A Question of Judgment
description: ARECENT article ['Crime and Punishment, Dec. 25, 1977] discussed the proposals of the Connecticut Commission to Study Alternative Methods of Sentencing Criminals. While the article highlighted several specific proposals, it did not explain the reasoning of the commission. Knowledge of the underlying major assumptions is essential, in my opinion, to an understanding of the legislation that will be considered by the 1978 session of the General Assembly.

title: Always Ready on the Bay Beat
description: ON a still, cold morning in deep winter, Ted Sadleir drove to one of the Southampton Town docks in his land vehicle, four-wheel-drive Blazer, and lifted binoculars to scan the gray, iceedged bay. His uniform was sedate, grayer than the water and trimmed in black, and for a young man, its insignia seems incongruously old-Down-Easter: Bay Constable.

title: Roy Rogers Leaves Hospital
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Jan. 28 (UPI) Roy Rogers, the cowboy actor, has left Little Company of Mary Hospital yesterday, where he underwent open heart surgery two weeks ago. Mr. Rogers, 66 years old, walked to a car driven by his wife, Dale Evans, and the couple drove 100 mules to their desert home in Apple Valley. Doctors said that the operation was successful and predicted 2xcel,lent recovery.

title: Linda Cochran Wins Slalom
description: CERRETO LAGHI, Italy, Jan. 28 (UPI) Linda Cochran of Richmond, Vt., triumphed today in a European Cup women's slalom race that was dominated by the United States team.

title: F.B.I. NOMINEE'S LINKS FAIL TO STIR ST.LOUIS
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28Assertions that President Carter's nominee- to head the Federal Bureau Of Investigation is a member of four allegedly discriminatory social Organizations here have raised iew, eyebrows, let alone much apparent concern, in either the blck or white communities Of this old Mississippi River city.

title: The Piano Is This Duo's Forte
description: WHEN Joanne Polk and Robert Preston were married in 1974, their wedding guests were somewhat startled by the unusual vows the bride and bridegroom had written for the occasion. Yours will be a life of labor, began the judge at the ceremony. Your gifts to each other will be your joy, your understanding, your humor, your sadness, your musical sensitivity. Your partnership is that of two dedicated musicians.

title: SHOP TALK
description: OUTDOOR sportsmen say it better to put on skis than to curse the snowor words to that effect. The fact is, when the forecast is frigid and frosted and the I slopes are crystalcoated, the atmosphere is notably jubilant in local ski shops.

description: Butler

title: The World
description: In the apparent belief that a change of scenery might be helpful, toplevel discussions on a Middle East peace will move to Washington next weekend. President Anwar elSadat of Egypt plans to stay in the capital for about a week, allowing unhurried talks with President Carter and other officials. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel is expected to make a similar trip soon afterward and from Washington, Mr: Sadat will go on to London, Paris, Bonn and Vienna.

title: Klammer Leads Practice For Alpine Skiing Event
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 28 (AP)Franz Klammer of Austria, who is returning to form after having had a disappointing season thus tar, clocked tne fastest time today in the final practice run for the opening downhill event of the world Alpine ski championship. The men's downhill will be held tomorrow.

title: Nets Drop 12th Straight As Sonics Win by 9590
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 28 (AP)--Fred Brown scored 25 points and sparked a late Seattle rally last night as the SuperSonics posted a 9590 victory over the hapless New Jersey Nets in a National Basketball Association game.

description: Some prisoners in New York City jails are on the welfare rolls, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: 9 Are Dead and 9 Injured as Fire Sweeps Historic Kansas City Hotel
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 28 (AP)Fire swept through the historic downtown Coates House hotel today, killing at least nine persons, four of whom plunged to their deaths from upperstory windows, the authorities said. At least nine of the apartment hotel's 140 elderly residents were hospitalized with iniuries.

title: Carl rs s Sense of Value,s
description: One of the old. Brooklyn Dodgers; one of the Boys of Summer, Carl Erskine, will be honored tonight at the New York Baseball Writer's Dinner with a Casey Stengel You Could Look It Up Award for his two no. hitters at Ebbets Field in 1952 and 1956. Those were big days for Oisk, big years. Carl Erskine was a hand- some righthanded pitcher with a curveball that swooped downward as if it were a hawk. He once struck out 15 Yankees for a World Series record in 1953 when he was a 20game winner. But his manager then, Charlie Dressen, always wondered about him. Carl Erskine would not throw knockdown pitches and he would not curse. Carl Erskine always did have a sense of values. That is why the sports accomplishments of his son Jimmy mean. more to him now than those two nohitters.

title: Presbyterians Discuss Homosexuals Church Role
description: While a committee of the United Presbyterian Church of the U.S.A. has been studying the place ot the homosexual in the church, members of .a. Task Force on Religion and Homosexuality established by the Presbytery of Long Island have been visiting churches of that denomination throughout the area to discuss what has become a paramount issue 1 in religious circles.

title: Two Major Retailing Mergers and There Are More of Them in the Wind
description: Two big merger moves, this year's first in the retailing field, occurred on the same day last week. Potential exchanges of stock totaling about $420 million are at stake:

But there are still a few individualists, too, operating in the freeswinging tradition of such oldtime traders as Bet a Million Gates and Sell Em Ben Smith.

title: Apathy Has Drained the Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON - After a monthlong hiatus for rest and reflection, the HouseSenate energy conference has begun a race against the clock. The key legislators who returned to the Capitol last week substituted for the unproductive public sessions that had dragged on all fall a rush of private meetings designed to produce a rapid solution.

title: New Analysis Is Made
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 28Scientists have reexamined atmospheric data gathered along the track of a crippled Soviet satellite carrying a nuclearpower device and are now saying again that there are signs that it released radiation in the sub-Arctic wastes of northern Canada, according to a Canadian military spokesman.

title: Al Green Is Soulful at Music Hall City Ballet
description: Al Green, who opened a twoday engagement Friday night at Radio City Music Hall, is at once our greatest and most eccentric soul singer. In fact, his eccentricity is the key to his greatneSs, even if it has sometimes deflected him from the recognition and the accomplishment that could be his. Friday night, the results didn't quite match his fine new album, but Mr. Green still gave the best performance this listener has seen from him.

title: N. Carolina 98, Clemson 64
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 28 (AP)Phil Ford, the star senior guard for the University of North Carolina, scored 17 points and became the leading career scorer for his school as the Tar Heels routed Clemson, 9864. in an Atlantia Coast Conference basketball game tonight.

title: On Writing Good
description: WASHINGTONThe ability to write with sense and style has decreased and ought to be improved. There are an infinite number of cultural reasons for this form of educational illiteracy but policy decisions are more responsible than the effects of television or whatever social abstraction can be invoked. It ought to be fairly plain that the decline in writing ability coincides with the kind and amount of teaching that governs it.

title: Abbott, Shortridge Gain Final
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP)Bryan Abbott and George Shortridge moved into the final of the $20,000 Professional Golfers Association national matchplay championship with double . victories today. Abbott and Shortridge will meet tomorrow for the $2.000 first orize.

description: WASHINGTON  Assessing Ralph Nader's accomplishments and influence is a popular pasttime in this city, and for each point of view there is a wealth of illustrative anecdotes. :Such as this one:

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: On the eve of President Carter's State of the Union Address 10 days ago, several top Government officials were expressing confidence in private conversations that his new economic game plan would bolster the battered confidence of the business world. They and the President were also anticipating the reaction the stock market would show after that talk, the tax program's details and the presentation of the fiscal.1979 Federal budget.

title: Number of Whites in Rhodesia Leaving Country Set Record in 77
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 28 (Agence France Presse)  Rhodesia lost a record 10,908 whites during 1977, according to official figures published this week.

title: J. I. Maslen Weds Miss Stevenson
description: Laura H. Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stevenson of New York, was married yesterday to James 1. Maslon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel

title: Indira Gandhi's 19 Months
description: IT was only last March that Indira Gandhi's countrymen turned her out of office, and memories that stunning exercise in democracy are already fading. Ved Mehta's The New India is a cheering reminder that such things can really happen.

title: CRIME
description: Leave it to Peter Dickinson to dream up something unusual. This British writer creates mysteries that can have all kinds of threatening undertones, and that have an unusual milieu. In King and Joker, for instance, he wrote about an imaginary King of England and his family. In Sleep and His Brother he introduced a strange and scary group of children. Dickinson has imagination, and he also is sensitive writer. Every new book of his can be approached with anticipation.

title: When a Jeep Is Like a Good Right Hand
description: I 6fi T'S JUST like normal driving, but for the first couple of weeks you feel as though it's going to flip over when you make a turn. Thomas Ward was describing his bargain car that has this funny thing about it: The driver's wheel is on the right side. That, plus the boxy shape of the car, gave Mr. Ward that funny feeling when he made his turns for the first few weeks.

title: Coachesm Are Coached On Preventing Injuries
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.  The sudden deaths of high school football players during practice, the lack of accurate data on sportsrelated injuries of youngsters and the belief that it is as important to train volunteer coaches of 8- to 18yearolds as it is coaches of college and professional athletes have resulted in the establishment of an Injury Prevention Training Program for Little League volunteer coaches at Adelphi University.

description: I'm often asked if I wasn't born 20 years too soon. My philosophy in life is', a very simple one. I'm concerned with anything I can control. What I can't control, I don't think about.

A Third Try at School Aid Plan
description: GOVERNOR Carey's ,latest proposal to shift state public school aid to urban areas from the wealthier suburbsparticularly the Island and Westchesterhas been met here thus far with virtual silence.

title: Balanced Growth
description: The White House Conference on Balanced Growth and Economic Development, which starts today, is an important event. It refracts the concerns of a society in which entire regions are coming apart at the seams and intolerable rates of unemployment have become so commonplace that we celebrate when they drop to levels that once would have defined a deep recession. Any meeting that will try to confront this miserable reality is most welcome. As a socialist, my own regret is that the conference is not likely to confront the essential.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Kay McKemy is right and is properly appalled by the results of her quiz and its . implications [Unanswered Questions, Jan. 15], but she is directing her closing remarks to the wrong audience. People who read her article to the end do not.have to be told to get their children to do their homework. It is the people who do not read her article, who do not read The Times or, for that matter, any newspaper (at least not beyond the spcirts and comic pages) who need her admonition.

title: West Side Man Jumps to His Death To Avoid Fire in 7thFloor Apartment
description: A 20year-old man leaped to his death esterday from his burning seventhfloor apartment at 315 West 99th Street, fire officials said.

title: ART VIEW
description: Few American painters in this century have embraced quite so many aspects of its salient art history as Stuart Davis (18941964) while at the same time achieving so sustained, consistent and individual a vision in their work. As a very young man he was trained in the realist conventions of the Ashcan School, and he never lost his vivid interest in the peculiarly American look of the city or country scenes that furnished his art with its characteristic motifs. Yet he was one of the major modernists of his time, finding in Cubism the principal basis for his pictorial forms. He revered Seurat, and one of the primary ambitions of his art was to achieve a pure formalism, based on color, akin to the French master's. Mondrian, too, was a challenge to hima challenge he could never, apparently, quite resolve. Yet there was a social cur- rent in his art, especially in the 1920's and 30's, that is often regarded as inimical to formalist aspirations.

title: Hunter 56, Brooklyn 54
description: Hunter College held off a rally in the second half by Brooklyn College to defeat the Kingsmen, 5654, in City. University of New York Conference game last night.

title: New York City Is Seeking Law to Stem Pothole Suits
description: To motorists, New York City potholes appear no different than those in Buffalo or Rochester or any other city in the state. But in the eyes of the law, they are radically different, and that difference. costs New York City millions of dollars each year.

title: Where to Cut and Buy Firewood
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY residents have been scurrying around the state for months in search of an increasingly scarce commodity to get them through the winter months: firewood.

Vance's first anniversary as Secretary of Statecame while he was the Middle East, trying to patch up the EgyptianIsraeli peace initiative after Egypt's abrupt suspension of talks. The mission was not a disaster for the United States, yet like many of Mr. Vance's other trips, there was little to show for his efforts.

title: An Alarming Sound In a Swiss Hotel
description: We were on honeymoon in Switzerland in April. After several nights of deluxe accommodations in the Engadine Alps we drove back to Zurich looking for a place that might have mercy on a new-

title: Ohio School Tax Action in Doubt
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 25Amid warnings from state education officials that 156 school districts in Ohio face early closings or program cutbacks this year due to revenue shortages, state lawmakers this week began discussing ways to put public education back on a sound financial footing.

title: Franco Grandson Gets Goatand Jail Term
description: TORTOSA, Spain, Jan. 28 (AP)grandson of ,Francisco. Franco was sentenced today to 45 days in jail and suspension of his hunting license for illegally hunting a wild goat.

title: TV VIEW
description: These days, a performance by Luciano Pavarotti guaranteed to fill any opera house in the world. And indeed it has. The day the Pavarotti poster went up in front of the Met for his Feb. 12 concert of songs and arias by Donizetti, Rossini, Verdi, Liszt and Beethoven, it carried a sold out banner. Shrewd and lucky afficionados had long since snatched up every one of the house's 3,700 seats, and that could have left all of the other opera lovers in the world literally out in the cold.

title: Respectable Rebels Threaten Somoza Dynasty
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Perhaps more than any guerrilla group in Latin America, Nicaragua's Sandinist National Lib eration Front, or El Frente, as the movement is _known locally; has won the support or sympathy of broad sectors the population, not just disenchanted youths, but nonMarxist intellectuals, conservative politicians, progressive priests and some wealthy businessmen.

title: UPSTATE GETS EXEMPTION ON AUTO INSURANCE RULE
description: New York State's Insurance Superintendent, Albert B. Lewis, seeking to detuse a controversy over automobile inspection regulations, announced late yesterday that upstate areas would be exempt from a new requirement for visual and photographic inspections of cars being insured against theft or damage.

title: If You Go...
description: ...to Quebec City, you can choose from hundreds of hotels and tourist accommodations, recommended by the Department of Tourism, ranging in price from $2 a night in a dormitory to which you bring your own sleeping bag, to $50 a night for a dou ble room and private bath in one of the city's glamorous hotels such as the Quebec Hilton, Le Concorde or Chateau Frontenac. During the Winter Carnival hotel space is at a premium, but the Carnival Lodging Committee has set up a special line (4185248441) to help with accomodations. Visitors may also contact Quebec Urban Community, Quebec Tourism and Convention Bureau, 60 d'Auteuil Street, Quebec G1R 4M8 (418-6922471) fcr assistance and information.

title: Indications bi Mirex, A Toxic Compound Reported in Hudson
description: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. says it has found indications that Mirex, a highly toxic chemical compound, may be present in the Hudson River.

title: Carolyn B. Veemian And John Goodrich Are Planning to Wed

He is the son of Mrs. L. Keith Goodrich of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Goodrich.

description: ILL ER UP with 90 proof. There is a possibility that drivers may be giving just such commands at their neighborhood petrol pubs in another 10 or 15 years if oil becomes scarce.

title: Two French Conyicts Are Killed During Attempted Prison Escape
description: TROYES, France, Jan. 28 (AP)Two French convicts serving life terms for murder and robbery seized three prison officials in an escape attempt today, .but were killed by French policemen, officials at Clairvaux Prison said.

title: For the Sake of the Presidency
description: As Jimmy Carter once brilliantly perceivedI shall , never lieto youthe American people need their President back on the pedestal of authority and dignity. After a decade of Vietnam and Watergate, they want to be liberated from suspicion and cynicism; they want the Presidency rescued from its recent corrosion. They cringe at the spectacle of reporters questioning every Presidential phrase for evasion or inaccuracy. They abhor the idea of investigators taking affidavits from a President and Attorney General to deny an obstruction of justice. They do not want to hear, even from a party that hungers for political restitution, the chant of what did he know and when did he know it. Yet here we are, again. First Lance, now Marston.

title: ROBERT M. GIBSON
description: Robert McKenzie Gibson, a corporate attorney, died Thursday of cancer at his home. He was 61 years old and lived:at 63 Standish Drive, Ridgefield, Conn.

description: WASHINGTON --Perhaps the most telltale words uttered by President Carter during his recent outpouring of messages to Congress and the public was the simple, almost unnoticed, phrase: We here in Washington...

Edward Thomas Williams, U.S.A., retired, was !harried to Alexander Neave, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander CaldWell Neave of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Teience J. Finlay performed the ceremony.

title: Rights, and Wrongs
description: WASHINGTON Much has been written of late about the unhealthy state of human rights in non-Western countries. Many sovereign states on both sides of the ideological divide have been accused of gross violations of these rights. The Carter Administration and its more ardent supporters In the Congress have attempted to make the observance of human rights a condition of economic assistance to the developing countries not only by the United States but also by the international organizations which draw part of their financial resources from the United States Treasury.

title: Begin Optimistic on Resuming Cairo Military Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan, 28Prime Minister Menachem Begin expressed optimism tonight that the joint IsraeliEgyptian military talks would soon reconvene in Cairo, and called on President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to fulfill a pledge for the militarization of the demilitarization f the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Tanner Sets Back pibbs, Gains Final With Connors
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28This is one of those weeks when Roscoe Tanner's serve has become a cannon on the tennis court.

title: MUSIC

My tale of woe week ago Saturday involved driving around the icy back roads of Stamford (I had been misdirected by the tollbooth collector), trying to find the Westhill High School and the concert by the Stamford Symphony Orchestra that was supposed to be held there.

title: Sol LeWitt's Jungle Gym for the Mind
description: E uclid alone has looked on Beauty bare, wrote the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay musing about the great Greek geometer more than half-a-century ago.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The fate of Grand Central Terminal is now before the Supreme Court, which has agreed to hear an appeal from its bankrupt owner, the Penn Central, which hopes to reverse the New York State Court of Appeals decision in favor of the city's landmark designation. Penn Central wants to use the air rights above the terminal to build a piggyback tower on top of the turn-of-the-century Beaux Arts Monument, an idea almost everyone except the Penn Central and some unreconstructed realestate types considers architecturally and environmentally revolting. The scheme, which has been kicking around for a number of years, is an unmitigated horror; the last version, Grand Central would be the filling in a Pan Amoffice tower sandwich.

title: Do-It-Yourself Garages Give Amateur Mechanics a Lift
description: ON A rainy Wednesday recently, George Garcia spent a day of his vacation working on his 1972 Chevrolet pickup truck. , But he was not tinkering at his suburban home. He was 15 miles away in Houston 4t a do-it-yourself service station with the pickup on a hydraulic lift. I like to do it myself, he said, and this is the only place available.

title: Plunge From Orbit
description: Deep inside a mountain in Colorado, the North American Air Defense Cornmand (NORAD) watches the more than 4,000 satellites orbiting the earth. Something new could be a nuclear attack  or wrongly interpreted as a nu- clear attack, which would be almost as hairraising. Sometime last month, at least as early as Dec. 19, NORAD learned that a malfunctioning Soviet satellite, designed to track American ships at sea and thought to carry a nuclear powerplant, was in a disintegrating orbit that would soon bring it down. Last Tuesdaymorning it happened, setting off a search for signs of the satellite!s contents, and revealing an unusual cooperative venture between the United States and the Soviet Union to avoid public panic and minimize nuclear contamination from an accident that, even if it proves innocuous, was still a nuclear accident in thesky.

title: Street Smarts, Says Jon Peters, Are What Makes a Producer
description: jon Peters, movie producer, is marching across East 106th Street. He heads into a Harlem community center for the retarded, rings for the elevator, asks for the second floor and then arrives as if by magic, in a luxurious duplex apartment over Central Park Westor at least a good movieset imitation of one. The apartment is an important set for Eyes, a suspense film about a fashion photographer that stars Faye Dunaway, and Mr. Peters has come to consult, joke around with the construction crew, and make sure that some breakaway glass will break away exactly as he wants it to. Remember how the glass went flying in that Columbia picture with the truck?  he asks one of the technicians. It's gotta look that way, only better.

title: Urquhart, Baritone, Gives First Recital

The Alaskanborn bari- tone, who graduated from the University of Washington and has sung in opera in New York, has a light voice that sounds more or less made. There are some natural tones in the middle of the range, but those above and below have a dry or hollow quality. The singing resembled most closely that of young musicalcomedy performersa judgment arrived at before Mr. Urquhart gave as an encore a song by Cole Porter.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Anatole France was an ironist, and his famous novel, Thais, is a grand romp through the paganism and Christianity of fourthcentury Alexandria. It is a novel of ideas, and it also plays on the concept of having a monk redeem a courtesan. only to fall in love with her. This was a situa tion that appealed to Jules Massenet, always on the lookout for interesting heroines. Just as Puccini in Italy almost always wrapped his operas around an appealing womanManon Lescaut, Mimi, Cio-Cio-San, Turandot, Minnie, Toscaso Massenet sought heroines that would make his audiences weep. The difference between the two composers that almost everything Puccini composed has remained in the repertory, whereas Manon alone of the some 25 Massenet operas has survived as an international repertory piece. It true that a few other Massenet operas occasionally turn up, but they never stick around very long.

title: Controlled experiments
description: ACCRA, Ghana  In the decade that followed the rush to independence of black African states, beginning with Ghana 1957, Western observers looked on in dismay as, one after another, democracies toppled to military juntas or degenerated into despotisms such as Equatorial Guinea, where, according to reports last week, thousands of people have been executed by the regime of President Masie Nguema Biyogo. The parliamentary models devised in London anti Paris,it seemed, bore as little relation to political realities in the nascent states as their boundaries, drawn up in European staterooms and country houses, did to their ethnic composition.

title: Good Deed Brings Luhch Date

The two checks were made out by the Pacific Gas & Electric company to The Standard Oil Compamy. They were lost by a messenger and carried several blocks by the wind. When Miss Taylor returned. thim, the utility toad her to pick a day next week and that it would take her ito lUnch.

title: STAGE VIEW; The Actor Vs. the Legend --Who Should Win?; WALTER KERR; Taking On G.B.S.; STAGE VIEW; Actor Vs. Legend
description: I'd never quite thought of oneman shows as contests before, but I see now that that's what they are. You go hear James Earl Jones proclaim himself Paul Robeson for the evening, or to watch Donal Donnelly adopt the astonishing self of George Bernard Shaw. Who wins? The man on the stage or the man in your head? Who should win? The actor as actor, asserting something of his own rather than trying to submerge himself totally in a legend he can never really becomeor the legend, devouring the actor until you can't find him anymore?

description: The young Argentine pianist Ana Maria Cut is a superb technician and a fiery yet thoughtful interpreter, qualifications she impressively applied to Brahms's youthful Sonata in F minor Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

For no sooner had tycoons made their piles in this culturally virginal country than they plunged into the acquisition of art, and their accessions needed buildings house them.

description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward White of St. Petersburg, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Redding. White, to Thomas Hardy Dixon of Brooklyn.

title: Architecture
description: Respect in architecture, like love, takes many forms. The conventional way to respect an old building when expanding it is to use materials, scale and style similar to those of the original structure. But occasionally, the integrity of an old structure is best preserved by juxtaposing against it something that is dramatically different.

title: THEATER
description: STAMFORD THE COMPANY STORE, directly across the street from the main stage of the Hartman Theater Company, has just begun the Wednesday-through-Sunday run of its season's third bill, which ends Feb. 5.

title: CHESS
description: These days one has to admire the courage of practitioners of the Polugaevsky branch of the Najdorf Sicilian. Knowing, as they surely do, that their fate will be sealed by how well they walk a tightrope of tactics without a safety net, they repeatedly set out on the hazardous venture.

title: Hialeah Cup to Run Dusty Run
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI)Run Dusty Run caught the favored Silver Series at the finish, held off a foul claim and won the first running of the $100,000 Hialeah Challenge Cup by a nose today.

title: EDGAR FITCH BULLARD
description: Edgar Fitch Bullard, a former director of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and chairman of the company's exploration and production division from 1945 to 1963, died Friday at a Tulsa hospital. He was 79 years old and had lived in Tulsa for many years.

title: Bicycle Makers Are Getting Backon the Track
description: The nation's bicycle producers, cornout of an uphill stretch that saw at least two oldline companies drop cornpletely out of the running, are freewheeling again. They're still a distance from those glory days of 73 when, for the first time in history, Americans bought more bikes than cars, but they're on the way.

title: Pickups and Vans Keep Sales Rolling
description: UNTIL JUST a few years ago, pickup trucks and vans were regarded as little more than mechanized beasts of burden. They were simple, drab, utilitarian and appealed mostly to farmers and tradesMen. More recently, though, these vehl: ties have transcended their commercial roots and are serving increasing numbers of people in a variety of ways which were once unforseeable.

title: Linda Klein to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Klein of Tamarac, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Linda Anne Klein, to Dr. Jack Martin Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Shapiro of Brooklyn. Miss Klein, an alumna of Cornell University and Columbia School of Social Work,. is with Mount Sinai Hospital. Her fiance graduated from Brooklyn College and the Universidad Autonoma y Guadalajara in Mexico.

title: Capitol HillThe State's Helping Hands
description: WASHINGTON WOMEN are quietly playing vital roles as lobbyists and legislative experts on matters crucial to New Jersey on Capitol Hill. More than dozen of them head the staffs of members Congress; one of them, Marilyn Berry Thompson, runs the New Jersey state office here, and others hold high positions on those staffs. Their ages range from 27 up and their salaries from $21,000 to $41,000.

title: Strangers in the Promised Land
description: YOU could call him Carlos. He said he used to own a 6,000acre cattle ranch in Mexico and once bossed a staff of 80 men. His wife, Maria, ran a sevenroom house with a full crew of household help.

title: GAVIN W. M'KERROW
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 28 (UPI)Gavin W. McKerrow, founder of the Golden Guernsey Dairy Cooperative and one of the nation's leading dairy cattle and sheep raisers, died yesterday at Waukesha Memorial Hospital He was 84 years old.

It certainly was the most expensive and the most bothersome of all times, costing the New Jersey economy $100 million a day for five days in lost ,production and retail sales.

description: Mr. and Mrs. James Stealey Jenkins of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stealey Jenkins, to Richard Howarth Ashley of Washington. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Ashley. The wedding is planned for August in Greenwich.

He is in charge of all Michelin manufacturing operations in America. We clearly pay above average here, he. said, and each year we give an annual increase that is higher than the annual average. We are practically the highest payer in the region.

description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28----Senator Robert J. Dole, stepping up to a microphone to address a gathering of farm strikers in Wichita the other day, leaned forward and asked, Can you hear me in the back all right? After a pause, he added, Just in case I should say something. This was the new Robert Dole.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  President Carter rejected higher tariffs on imports of chrome alloys from South Africa today, despite arguments from Congress that his action conflicts with the Administration's official opposition to South Africa's system of racial discrimination.

title: Headliners
description: In what at once was a sentimental gesture and a political ex- pedient, Muriel Humphrey was named last week to fill the United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of her hus- band, Hubert. Mrs. Humphrey presumably will serve only until a special election next November, but she declined to rule out a possible candidacy. Her selection by Gov. Rudy Perpich was partly intended to silence grumblings in Minnesota about buddy system app.ointments, after Wendell R. Anderson re- signed as Governor and this successor, Mr.. Perpich, named him to the Senate seat vacated by Walter F. Mondale. When she takes office, Mrs. Humphrey will be the first woman in the Senate since Margaret Chase Smith of Maine was defeated in 1972. Mrs. Smith also first went to Washington by filling a va- cancy, in the House, created by her husband's death.

Columbia was left at 31 in the conference and 6.9 over all while Brown improved its overall record to 39 and its league mark to 12.

description: Some time ago a reader, Marion Burkat of Southbury, Conn., wrote to state that she always skimmed the surface of her soups as they simmered because she had always been taught to do so by her mother.

description: LUKAS FOSS has been organizing and conducting concerts of contemporary music for years, often with a tolerance for trash that went beyond all bounds of catholic taste. Those days apparently are over. His, Meet the Moderns series, presented by the Brooklyn Philharmonia in the Brooklyn Academy of Music over the last several seasons, has consistently shown him to be discerning and thoughtful. impresario for new music, and Saturday night's concert was an especially stimulating one.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Have you ever been on a boat in a bouncy surf trying to keep your binoculars sighted on a faroff buoy or a committeeboat signal? Almost impossible, wasn't it? Something called the GyroStabilizer, however, might solve the problemthe device, hermetically sealed so that water cannot damage it, uses double gyroscopes, attaches to binoculars or camera tripod and keeps the desired object steady in the viewfinder. is electrically driven by a portable power pack, at extra cost, or the power from the boat's engine, and it comes in three models: the Explorer ($540), for binoculars and 35millimeter cameras; the Universal ($1,014), for heavier equipment and 8mm. movie cameras, and the Commander ($1,278); for 16mm. cameras and videotaping outfits. Their weight ranges from 24 to 52 ounces, and they can be obtained directly from KenLab, Box 128, Old Lyme, Conn. 06371.

title: A. Lost Finger, a Federal Agency's Delays
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Wyeth Chandler, the Mayor of Memphis, came home one day last June after playing 36 holes of golf and, at his wife's urging, rushed out to cut the grass. In the process, he cut off the end of his finger.

title: Christa Ludwig In Viennese Songs
description: CHRISTA LUDWIG'S first New York appearance in nearly four years yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was in itself 2 lovely occasion. but it served to re- mind us how much the Austrian mezzosoprano has been missednot just from our recital stages, but in opera as well. And there wasn't much to reassure us that Miss Ludwig will be coming our way more frequently in the future; this was her only American performance of the season,. with apparently nothing firm set for years to come.

title: Energy Shortage Threatens Ohio In Wake of Blizzard in Midwest
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 29Ohio is slowly recovering from a fierce winter storm that has paralyzed the state for the past three days, Gov. James A. Rhodes reported today. But, he added, rapidly depleting power company coal supplies are threatening to thrust it into another critical situation, a shortage of energy.

title: MARGARET MEAD PREDICTS LOWER BIRTH RATE IN U.S.
description: SOUTH KINGSTON, R.I., Jan. 29 (AP) Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, says that America's marriage and birth rates will continue to drop in the next quarter century because of changing sex roles and expectations of marriage.

title: Carter News Parley On Television Today
description: President Carter is to hold a news conference at 2:30 P.M. today. It will be broadcast by the three television networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7. Live broadcasts have also been scheduled on radio by WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA and WNYCAM.

description: SOWETO, South Africa, Jan. 29 (AP) The leader of South Africa's 5.5 million Zulus told a crowd of 10.000 blacks today that they had reached the crossroads in the fight for racial co ualitv.

description: HUNTER, N.Y., Jan. 29  Andre Arnold, the 22-year-old rookie from Solden, a small Austrian winter resort, continued to be the surprise of the World Pro. Skiing competition today.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The House this week formally approved the selection of Representative Matthew F. McHugh, Democrat of Ithaca, to succeed Mayor Koch of New York City on the House Appropriations Committee.

description: The stage was set for the coaches and writers, who vote in the two wire service polls, to name Marquette the nation's No. 1 college basketball team.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Negotiations collapsed today for the fourth time in nearly four months of fruitless bargaining for a new coal labor contract that could end what is destined to be the longest strike in the 88year history of the United Mine Workers, the nation's oldest union.

description: A crater, believed caused by a. large piece of the Soviet satellite that broke up over Canada was found in the Northwest Territories. Page A3.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 29 (Reuters)Bishop Abel Muzorewa, one of the country's major black nationalist leaders, will boycott the Rhodesian settlement negotiations when they resume tomorrow, his aides said today. The bishop walked out of the talks Friday.BONN, Jan. 29 (AP)West Germany will reject as unallowable interference a warning by the Soviet leader, Leonid L Brezhnev, against deployment of the neutron bomb in Western Europe, Government sources said today.MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 29 (UPI)President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia says that he sees no chanoe of negotiated settlement with Ethiopia to end the war over the Ogaden region in the Horn of Africa.LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP)Storms swept through parts of Europe over the weekend, bringing blizzards to northern Scotland, snow to the Italian Riviera and flooding to Venice and other Italian communities.

title: Police in Madrid Disperse 600 And Detain 6 at Leftist Meeting
description: MADRID. Jan. 29 (Reuters)The police dispersed about 600 demonstrators trying to hold a leftwing meeting at a movie house today and detained six of them.

title: Economists Call Outlook for Egypt Good if It Makes Hard Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29World Bank specialists say they believe that Egypt has reached the stage where, with the right decisions, many of them very difficult, it could enter a period of solid economic development that would contribute to peace and stability in the Middle East.

title: Couple Killed as Fire Sweeps Apartment on Upper East Side
description: An elderly couple were killed last night when fire swept through their apartment at 332 East 84th Street.

title: How to Control Spying on Ourselves
description: Soon after his inauguration, President Carter took pains to locate, display and identify with Harry Truman's sign, The buck .stops here. TO Mr. Carter's credit, he has now taken pains to demonstrate that, when it comes to controlling American intelligence activities, the famous credo is wrong. In a new executive order, the Administration recognizes firmly that prevention of abuse by intelligence agencies requires Congressional as well as executive overseers. And it recognizes that even stronger overseers will not suffice; legal charters for the intelligence agencies are necessary. Though the new order welcome, its own shortcomings are evidence of that need.

title: U.S. Officials Fear Soviet's Lead In HunterKiller and Spy Satellites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29While the attention of the world was focused on flights to the Moon and the orbital handshake between Soviet and Americfn astronauts, a less publicized but more important competition was acceleratingan arms race in space.

title: Law on Education of Handicapped Poses Fiscal Burden for Districts
description: Aided by a new Federal law, tens of thousands of the nation's handicapped youngsters are starting to receive services from school systems that previously ignored them.

description: Walnut Creek; a town of 40,000 in the San Ramon Valley, not far from Oakland, Calif., has come up with a double donation to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: MIAMI, Jan. 29 (UPI)  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt called on American Jews today to support his peace efforts in the Middle East.

title: Bankruptcy Act Revision
description: The first major overhaul of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since 1938 is about to come before the House of Representatives for consideration. Proposed changes would give more protection to people overloaded with consumer debt and to employees of companies that fail. Page D6.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)The embattled chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission says his agency is being hurt by criticism of him but that he has no intention of resigning.

title: Law on Education of Handicapped Poses Fiscal Burden for Districts

title: Cuban Business? See Man Named Jones; Agent in Washington Knows Ins and Outs of Bureaucracy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Kirby Jones runs a threeperson consulting firm in this city where consultants usually do things big. Yet if the United States and Cuba normalize relations, Mr. Jones probably has the best private entree in the country to the estimated halfbillion dollars year in Cuban trade that could ensue.

title: Walkout Deepens a Strain of Pessimism in Appalachia
description: SMITHERS, W.Va., Jan 29'In my 30 years in the mines, I believe we got two contracts from the operators without striking, and we didn't get anything from them then, said David Forms, musing on his 55th payless day since the United Mine Workers walkout began.

title: Sports Guide

title: Opening Japan's Economy
description: Ten thousand tons of beef, 45,000 tons of oranges, 4,000 tons of citrus juice  these were the only hard numbers in the joint statement produced by the recent trade talks between the, United States and Japan. They are to be quotas for imports into Japan. Although they represent large increases over the existing quotas (a tenfold increase for beef) they are scarcely a bonanza for even one Texas or California county. Yet they signify a greater willingness by Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party to confront powerful domestic agricultural interests. They are tokens of a promised resolve to open more important sectors of Japan's economy to foreign competition.

title: College Instructor, With Tenure, Facing Dismissal
description: WAYNE, Jan. 29JacquesLeon Rose, atenured instructor at William Paterson College here is faced with dismissal by the college',s board of trustees on charges of conduct unbecoming to the teaching profession.

title: A Tax Loophole Localities Don't Need
description: State and local governments that Issue taxexempt bonds have a good thing goingso good that many are loath to accept changes in the system, no matter how reasonable. They can now borrow money cheaply because the interest they pay to lenders is exempt from Federal taxation. Investors wno demand an a percent return on Treasury securities will settle for 5.5 percent on a safe municipal bond when no income tax needs to be paid on it. This exemption privilege will cost the Federal Government about $8.5 billion in lost taxes next year. Unfortunately, however, only about $6 billion of that amount will find its way back to state and local governments in the form of reduced interest that they pay. The rest will stick to the palms of corporations and wealthy individual investors who are able to earn a much higher aftertax return on taxexempts than on ordinary, taxable securities.

title: Profits Again Exceet $100 billion Rate

title: Why the Athlete's Knee Is an OftDisjointed Joint
description: THE knee, the most vulnerable part of an athlete's body, is cause of disabling injury in nearly every major sport. It is a complex but rather poorly constructed joint, and simply was not designed to withstand the stress that sports impose on it.

title: Country Blues by John Hammond
description: JOHN HAMMOND, the bluessinging son of the celebrated record producer John Hammond Sr., is back on Vanguard records, his label during the folk boom of the middle 1960's. And he, was back at the Bottom Line over the weekend, accompanied, as he is on his new album, by nothing but his own guitar. His performance did not depart in any significant respect from the kind of performances he gave 10 years ago. He rendered country blues, ragtime and oldtime pop numbers as set pieces, investing much passion and not much originality in most of them.

title: New Lina Wertmuller Movie:Her First in English
description: "THE END of the World in Our Usual Bed in a Night Full of Rain," the title of Lina Wertmuller's new film, her first in English, is more or less a pictograph of a movie that uses too many words to say very little, at least very little that hasn't been said before with more wit and ebullience, often by the Italian director herself.The subject is once again sex and politics, which in "The Seduction of Mimi" and "Swept Away," two of Miss Wertmuller's funniest films, erupted all over the place as the natural consequences of ordinarythough far from commonplaceheterosexual relations.In Miss Wertmuller's little red book, men are capitalists and women the proletariats. Sex is a projection of the class struggle and romantic love is the foundation for an economic system that creates co-conspirators of masters and slaves, of lovers and those loved. What has made her films so surprising and moving and comic, perhaps even counterrevolutionary, until now, is the peculiar way in which contradictory class roles can become hilariously and naturally confused within a single character.The Communist deckhand in "Swept Away," the fellow played by Giancarlo Giannini, is as outrageously self-interested as a 19th-century railroad baron once he takes command of his woman on a desert island. The title character in "The Seduction of Mimi," another Communist played by Mr. Giannini, is seduced, abandoned and seduced again by love. The most appealing Wertmuller characters are earnest, sincere, sometimes none-too-bright, full of awareness about others and absolutely blind about themselves.This gult is what makes them figures of essential comedy. Pasqualino (Mr. Giannini), the third-rate Neapolitan hood who chooses survival above honor in "Seven Beauties," is comic not because of what he does, but because of the great value he puts on things the rest of us have been taught are worthless. We don't feel superior to him. We can recognize similar patterns in ourselves.Unfortunately, there are no surprises, no feelings of recognition, no real contradictions at work in "The End of the World," which opened yesterday at Loews Tower East and which Miss Wertmuller apparently considers her most political film. That may be, though I doubt that any movie as essentially lifeless as this one can be political in the sense that it might move one to specific action."The End of the World" is about Paolo (Mr. Giannini), a Communist journalist, a thinking male chauvinist, and his American wife, Lizzy (Candice Bergen), a feminist and a professional photographer, whose marriage is coming apart in the course of the film for reasons that could surprise only someone who's been out of the universe for the last 20 years.The setting is a magnificent Roman apartment on a rainy night that, through hints that march through the movie like painted elephants, could be the beginning of Armageddon. A television commentator speaks ominously of floods that are without precedent, of an upper atmosphere that's been worn out through air pollution down below.Lizzy represents not only liberated woman, but also the entire New World, which hasn't realized its potential. Paolo is the Old World intellectual who recognizes his defects and is powerless to correct them. Lizzy and Paolo aren't people. They are personalized shopping carts overloaded with large, economy-sized, precooked ideas.In a series of flashbacks, Miss Wertmuller fills us in on the meeting, courtship and marriage of Lizzy and Paolo, a series of scenes that becomes increasingly humorless as we approach the present night and its anticlimaxwhen Lizzy accuses Paolo of making love as if he were taking a walk before going to sleep. In his turn, Paolo accuses Lizzy of wanting to abandon the home. He: "You blame me for what you haven't done." she: "You're rightthat's why I have to go.""The End of the World" is virtually a two-character movie, though there's a hideous chorus made up of Lizzy and Paolo's friends who appear from time to time to make facetious comments about the married couple.The movie isn't witty and it's seldom funny, partly because Lizzy and Paolo are forever saying things Miss Wertmuller seems to agree with, but Miss Wertmuller is not Shaw. As a political philosopher, she'd be great at a cocktail party. There are no self-delusions in the characters. We are meant to attend to their clichs as if hearing them for the first time. There's nothing to discover in this movie, which hasn't evolved as a human comedy, from its characters, but from points of view for which characters have been created.Miss Bergen's is the least attractive, since the dialogue Miss Wertmuller has given her leans heavily on desperate sarcasm. Most of the time Mr. Giannini replays his familiar Italian male-chauvinist-pig character, which doesn't quite fit here because he is supposed to be an intelligent, knowing man. Neither actor is helped by Miss Wertmuller's addiction to tight close-ups that have the effect of exposing the film's emptiness.There is one very funny sequence near the beginning of the film, when Lizzy makes a shambles of a solemn religious procession by coming to the aid of a woman who's being beaten up by a boyfriend, but the rest of the movie is made tolerable only by the sets, including a beautiful 14th-century monastery and the huge, old-fashioned apartment where Lizzy and Paolo live. "The End of the World" appears not to have been written and directed, but furnished by a classy interior decorator.

title: Plain Dogs

Now there is an event for the masses: the MidIsland Kennel Club's dog match and obedience trials Sunday at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. This event is for working and house pets and is not a beauty show. The dogs will workfetching, leaping barriers, sniffing out correct prey they have been introduced to. It costs $4.50 to enter a dog, $1.50 simply to watch. Children under 12 are admitted free. The show starts at 8:30 A.M., when veterinary examinations begin, and should run till 6 P.M.

title: Grandpre Wins French Trot
description: PARIS, Jan. 29. (AP)Grandpre of France upset Hadol du Vivier today and won the 200,000 Prix d'Amerique trot classic by seven lengths in record time.

title: Long Autumns And Mr. Mara
description: EARLY one July several years ago, I was huddled in front of the television set at a friend's house watching something billed as the Coaches AllAmerican, which featured the rookie prospects the National Fottball League. My friend's wife came in, looked at the two of us and snarled, How come they're starting so late this year?

title: Bridge:
description: Swedish domination of the European bridge scene continued to be evident in the prestigious Sunday Times Pair Championship, which ended last night in London. In a select field of 16 invited pairs from many parts of the world, two Swedish pairs who are reigning European champions placed first and third.

title: Connors, Smiling More, Is Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29It is time to talk about the new Jimmy Connors, and not simply because of his 62, 64, 63 victory over Roscoe Tanner today in the final of the $225,000 United States Professional indoor tennis championship.

title: ALBANY CREDIT COSTS MAY CO UP MILLIONS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29Uneasiness over New York City's financial future and poor securities market are expected to raise the cost of New York State's spring borrowing this year by millions of dollars, according to state officials and financial analysts.

title: Carter Voices Worry to Israel On Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29A message expressing President Carter's personal concern over reports that a new civilian settlement was being established on the West Bank of the Jordan was ordered delivered orally to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel last week.

title: Part of Koch's Fiscal Plan Proves to Be a Plagiary
description: When Mayor Koch released his 100page financial plan, chockablock with text and figures, many, people wondered how his administration had pulled together such .a thorough document within three weeks of taking office. The answer is that at least part of it was plagiarized from another re- port written for a private foundation. When that was discovered last week. there were red faces and apologies all around.

title: Buffalo Area Residents Look Back On Anniversary of Blizzard of 77
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29  With gala parties, nostalgic reunions and an uneasy sense of dja vu, this snow-conscious city, stepped out last night (info 18 inches of accumulated snow) and marked the first anniversary of the blizzard of 1977.

title: The First  To Know
description: WASHINGTON  At 4:45 P.M., Wednesday, December 28, the DowJones ticker thudded out the news that known quantity Arthur Burns wac being replaced by unknown quan- tity William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve, a fact of enormous importance to anyone interested in money. The White House press office confirmed the fastleaking story, and at 5:07 P.M., President Carter made the official announcement.

title: Some Italians Are Joining Unions Without Links to Political Parties
description: ROME, Jan. 29When Stefano Leonardi, a 23-year-old rail worker, became unhappy with the policies of the Communistdominated trade union he belonged to, he had these alternatives:

title: Steinhardt Teams With Dichter
description: THE RECITAL given Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art by. Arnold Steinhardt and Misha Dichter was of interest beyond the simple fact of some excellent musicmakine. Mr. Steinhardt is best known these days as first violinist of the Guarneri Quartet, and although he has been less shy than some quartet members about offering himself in a solo capacity, it was still interesting to hear him divorced from his customary, context.

title: 76ers 118, Nuggets 117
description: DENVER, Jan. 29 (AP)Doug Collins led a balanced Philadelphia offense that overcame strong performances by David Thompson and Dan Issel of Denver today as the 76ers defeated the Nuggets, 118117, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: TV: Hostage, Study of Terrorism
description: IT IS A RARE PERSON who will not be caught up intellectually or emotionally by some aspect of ABCTV's Hostage, which is on view tonight between 10 and 11 o'clock For it is not merely a recapit- ulation of four terrible incidents in the war between combatants and neutrals two in the Middle East and two in the Netherlandsbut it is also an attempt to examine what it is that drove the terrorists to their deeds, their attitude toward the results, bloody and murderous as many were and, most interestingly, what effect the experience had on the hostages themselves.

title: Knicks: Behind Big Mac Attack
description: If I'm scoring, it's going to be hard for us not to Win.

description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflectS prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Dance: 3 Debuts
description: SO MANY of the New York City Ballet's most innovative ballets required so much of their dancers at the premieres that their first casts seemed irreplaceable. The question was whether future dancers would be able to do as well as the carefully selected original cast for whom these works were created. One of these ballets was The Goldberg Variations, which Jerome Robbins composed from 1970 to 1972.

description: When Capt, Fred L. DiOrio of the Newark arson squad recently investigated fire in a vacant lot in a marshy section of the city, he was surprised to see his shoes begin to disintegrate.

description: There is no Adam on the ceiling of the Sister Chapel, a work by 13 female artists now on view at P.S. 1, the Long Island City public school that graduated in 1976 into an art gallery. Instead, the big paintings that form the chapel walls celebrate feminst, antipatriarchal view of creativity and energy and a new womanspirit in art.

title: STRIKE BY FARMERS RAISES CALLS FOR AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Although the farm strike has had no effect as yet either on farm prices or the food supply, the presence all week of several hundred farmers in the Capitol corridors has stirred some farmstate Congressmen to call for increases in emergency aid.

title: STATES MEDICAID PACTS FOUND POORLY MONITORED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Government has done a poor job of monitoring Medicaid programs in states that permit private concerns to administer them, Congressional investigators reported today.

title: An Old Bell Tolls for a Church's 350 Fears
description: A 249-year-old bell pealed low and rich, and assuring, yesterday as a small congregation gathered in Manhattan to celebrate the birthday of a church even older.

title: Nation's Yardstick Agency Moves to Frontiers of Science

title: Other N.H.L. Games
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP)Bob MacMillan, Guy Chouinard and Harold Phillipoff scored goals in the second period to break the game open today and the Atlanta Flames defeated the Cleveland Barons, 62.DETROIT, Jan. 29 (UPI)Dale McCourt, a rookie, scored his 16th goal of the season on a power play at 4:14 of the third period today to give the Detroit Red Wings a 33 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: LABOR LEADER'S ARREST IS DISCLOSED BY TUNISIA
description: TUNIS, Jan. 29 (Reuters)A Tunisian opposition leader said today that about 100 people had died in antiGovernment riots last week and authorities disclosed that they had arrested the country's top labor union leader.PARIS, Jan. 29The number of people killed in police and army action against demonstrators last Thursday in Tunisia during a 24hour general strike is being put here at a minimum of 200 by in, formed Tunisian sources. That figure was said to have been obtained by a methodical checking of Tunisia's main hospitals by telephone from Paris was double an increased figure given this morning by the Tunisian Government.

title: Prosecution System Under Attack On Eve of an Inquiry in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 29On the eve of a special Federal grand jury investigation into allegations of widespread municipal corruption, in this city, the state's long standing and politically cherished system of selecting prosecutors has come under attack from a legislative committee and from Federal sources close to the inquiry.

title: Going There
description: Canadian Mountain Holidays, the pioneer in helicopter skiing in the Canadian Rockies, has its headquarters in Banff, Alberts and can be reached by telephone at (403) 7624531. It operates in six locales from Radium, British Columbia, north to Valemount and runs two 44skier lodges. Skiers are also housed at inns and motels that have helicopter staging areas.

title: Troubled Rangers Routed
description: JeanGuy Talbot's voice was quavering. It was the toughest hockey game I ever coached in my life, he said after his New York Rangers lost, 41, to the Los Angeles Kings in a helterskelter manner last night at Madison Square Garden. The players were nervous; I was nervous; even the crowd was nervous. You could feel it. Everybody on the bench was shaking. You know the reason why I don't have to explain it.

title: Ancient Title Captures Stakes At Santa Anita
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP)Ancient Title set a track record at Santa Anita today in winning the $52,750 an Pasqual Handicap by 1 lengths before a crowd of 42.047.

title: Israeli Bus Driver Is Stabbed to Death
description: TEL AVIV, Jan, 29An Israeli bus driver was stabbed to death today after taking Arab workers home to Ramallah near Jerusalem in the occupied West Bank.

title: Zukerman Gives Concert at Y
description: PINCHAS ZUKERMAN, who was heard in recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., plays the violin with unnatural ease. He brings an air of unruffled calm to everything he touches. Even where other players would scrape and scramble, the polish of Mr. Zukerman's tone seems never to desert him, and the notes are sweetly tuned beyond any legitimate cavil.

title: Amateur Tops Pros
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 29 (UPI)Pam Shriver needed 48 minutes to win the $20,000 Futures of Columbus tennis tournament today. She defeated Kate Latham, 61, 63. Miss Latham had beaten Renee Richards last night in the semifinals.

title: Mexico City, Intent on Healthy Economy, Suffers Its Smog
description: MECICO CITY Jan. 29As the Mexican airliner climbed steadily out of the Valley of Mexico, the captain spoke to the passengers. If you care to look out of your windows, he said, on the left side, you will see smog and, on the right side, you will see smog.

title: PRESIDENT FEELS GREAT AFTER 2HOUR CHECKUP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)President Carter underwent a two-and-a-halfhour physical examination today, his first since becoming President. Afterward, he told reporters I feel great.

title: Performance of Consumer Agency Disappoints Its Early Supporters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Consumers and lawmakers who hailed the creation of the Consumer Product Safety Commission five years ago with predictions that it would usher in a new era of safety are now immersed in anguished second thoughts.

title: Mongolian Folk Music by Choir
description: DAVID HYKES and his group, the Harmonics Choir, have mastered a spectacular, littleknown vocal technique that is traditional in Mongolia. It entails the production of two distinct voices simul- taneously in the same throat, one a steady drone voice, the other a moving melody of high, flutelike tones from the harmonic series. According to the notes accompanying an album of Mongolian folk music released by a Hungarian label, the effect is achieved by altering the shape of the oral cavity, tensing the vocal chords, and pushing air through them forcefully.

title: ISRAEL WILL RETURN TO MILITARY TALKS WITH EGYPT IN CAIRO
description: JERUSALEM; Jan. 29The Israeli Cabinet voted unanimously today to resume participation in the joint EgyptianIsraeli Military Committee in Cairo.

title: Some Donors to Neediest Cases Urge an Expansion of the Appeal
description: As the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund approaches its final month, many previous donors have come forward with new contributions. Others have expressed in thoughtful comments that the yearly drive should be expanded to assist many more of the destitute.

title: Bayonne Policeman Tells How He Freed Hostage
description: BAYONNE, Jan. 30  When Capt. Thomas Kollmer of the Bayonne police, posing as a Roman Catholic priest, got a close look at a gunman who had 20gauge shotgun trained on a young hostage in Famiglietti's Pharmacy here late Friday, he had even more reason to be apprehensive as the gunman turned the weapon- toward him.

title: Donor Recalls The Kennedys In Gif to Fund
description: The memory of prominent political figures are frequently recalled by donors to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Such was the case of one New Jersey resident, Alice Laughlin of North Bergen, who sent a check for $15 and asked that it be in the memory of President John F. Kennedy and Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Film Society to Honor Cukor
description: George Cukor, who over nearly five decades in Hollywood gained a reputation as the foremost director of women, will be honored at this year's gala of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, it was announced yesterday by Martin E. Segal, president of the society.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Robert S. Boyd of Washington was taken into Secret Service custody tonight after futile attempt to drive his car through the northeast White House gate, spokesman said.

title: Rep. Wright's Dinner Raises Funds and Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30A traditional $1,000aplate pdlitical dinner that raises funds to be dispensed by the House majority leader to colleagues campaigning for relection raised anew questions involving whether both the donors and the majority leader receive an undue political advantage.

The latest rash of disclosuresheaded by the announcement of G.D. Searle & Company that it plans to dispose of some 20 moneylosing businessesraises anew the issue of big bath accounting.

title: GRADUAL IMPROVING OF ECONOMY IS SEEN BY CARTER ADVISERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers. today predicted gradual improvement for the American economy in coming years but warned that the 4 percent unemployment rate envisioned by the HumphreyHawkins Bill by 1983 may not be achieved without a significant increase in the rate of inflation.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Following are the major changes in current law embodied in the bill, passed tonight by the Senate, revising the Federal criminal code:

title: Radioactive Fragment Is Identified as Part of Satellite
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 30Canadian and United States scientists announced today that a twisted cylindrical metal object discovered in northern Canada had been positively identified as part of the Soviet spy satellite that broke up over the area last Tuesday.

title: Pan Am Introduces 80Day World Fare
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday fired a new salvo in the steadily escalating war over air fares, introducing the RoundtheWorldin80 Days Fare.
